Try not to compare things to how they were before you were diagnosed with breast cancer.
Finding new ways of being intimate with your partner may help you to adjust to the physical and emotional changes that have happened.

Question (100 words): How can I improve vaginal dryness during sexual activity?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Using a vaginal moisturizer on a regular basis and a vaginal lubricant during sexual activity will help improve vaginal dryness and prevent pain.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Using a vaginal moisturiser on a regular basis, and a vaginal lubricant during sexual activity, will help improve vaginal dryness and help prevent pain.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I’m anxious about my first sexual experience after diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): It’s normal to feel anxious. Take things slowly, make time specifically for you and your partner, and create a relaxed atmosphere. Consider using pain relief for any ongoing post-surgery or treatment pain.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You might be anxious about your first sexual experience after your diagnosis, or worried things will not be the same as before. All these feelings are normal.

Question (100 words): How can pelvic floor exercises help with sexual activity?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Pelvic floor exercises increase blood flow to the vaginal area, which can heighten sexual feelings and help relax these muscles.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Doing pelvic floor exercises increases blood flow to the vaginal area (see page 17). This can heighten sexual feelings and help relax these muscles.

Question (100 words): What should I consider when resuming sexual activity after breast surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Consider what kind or level of intimacy you feel comfortable with, how much energy you have, and any practical things like taking pain relief for post-surgery pain. Wear what makes you comfortable.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data:
Don’t rush
Taking things slowly at first may help. Think about what kind or level of intimacy you feel comfortable with and how much energy you have.

Question (100 words): How might changes to my breasts after treatment affect my sexual satisfaction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Changes to or removal of a breast through surgery and radiotherapy may have a big impact on your sexual satisfaction, especially if having your breasts stimulated was an important part of your sex life.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Changes to or removal of a breast through surgery and radiotherapy may have a big impact on your sexual satisfaction, especially if having your breasts stimulated was an important part of your sex life.

Question (100 words): How should I communicate with my partner about my preferences for physical touch after treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Be open and honest about what kind of touching you want or don’t want. If talking about it is embarrassing, use your hand to guide them. Focus on other areas of your body if needed.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It may be helpful to tell your partner what sort of touching you want or don’t want. If you find talking about it embarrassing, it can be easier to use your hand to guide them.

Question (100 words): How might my partner react to my breast cancer diagnosis sexually?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your partner may continue as before, take on an overly protective role, need time to accept what’s happened, or may distance themselves. Communication is key.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: How your partner responds to you sexually may be influenced by how they reacted to your breast cancer diagnosis.

Question (100 words): What are some tips for talking to my partner about sex after breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Be open and honest about your feelings, talk when you’re not being intimate, discuss both enjoyable and difficult aspects, and keep talking to ensure clear boundaries and expectations.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data:
Tips for talking to your partner
While it may be difficult at first, try to be open and honest about how you are feeling and what you both now expect from sex and intimacy.

Question (100 words): How might a breast cancer diagnosis affect my existing relationship?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A cancer diagnosis and treatment might mean you and your partner adopt different roles in the relationship, which can be difficult to cope with. Open communication can help find solutions.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may find that an existing relationship changes after you’ve been diagnosed with breast cancer. Some couples become closer and their relationship gets stronger. However, a relationship can become strained.

Question (100 words): What should I consider when starting a new relationship after breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Decide when and how to tell your new partner about your breast cancer. Be open about your concerns and worries. Give each other time to adjust.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may find the thought of forming a new relationship daunting. Meeting someone new may mean telling them about your breast cancer.

Question (100 words): Is it safe to have sex during treatment for breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, it is generally safe, but it’s advisable to use barrier methods of contraception, such as condoms, during treatment and for a few days after chemotherapy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can still have sex during treatment. It’s thought chemotherapy drugs cannot pass into vaginal fluids or semen, but this cannot be completely ruled out as chemotherapy drugs can pass into the blood and some other bodily fluids.

Question (100 words): Is it safe to get pregnant during treatment for breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): It’s important to avoid getting pregnant while having breast cancer treatment, as the treatment can harm an unborn baby during the early stages of development.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s important to avoid getting pregnant while having breast cancer treatment, as the treatment can harm an unborn baby during the early stages of development.

Question (100 words): Will I be able to get pregnant after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you’re 40 or over, assume you can still get pregnant unless you haven’t had a period for at least a year. If you’re under 40, assume you can still get pregnant unless you haven’t had a period for 2 years.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data:
If you’re 40 or over
You should assume that you can still get pregnant unless you haven’t had a period for at least a year.
If you’re under 40 
You should assume that you can still get pregnant unless you haven’t had a period for 2 years.

Question (100 words): Where can I get support for issues relating to my body or sex life after breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can get support from organizations like OUTpatients, Flat Friends, Sex with Cancer, The Cancer, Sex and Intimacy project, Ann Summers, and Jo Divine.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There are places you can get support if you’re concerned about any issues relating to how you feel about your body or your sex life.

Question (100 words): How can a counsellor or therapist help with sexual issues related to breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A counsellor or therapist can help you or you and your partner deal with relationship and sexual issues. Your GP or breast care nurse can help arrange this.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data:
Talk to a counsellor or therapist
You, or you and your partner, may need to see a counsellor or a therapist who deals specifically with relationships and sexual issues.

Question (100 words): How can Breast Cancer Now support me with questions or information about breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can speak to nurses or trained experts by calling their free helpline, chat with others in their friendly community, find trusted information on their website, and see what local support is available.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data:
Support at Breast Cancer Now
We hope this information was helpful, but if you have questions, want to talk to someone or read more about breast cancer, here’s how you can.

Question (100 words): What changes to my body should I expect after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After breast cancer treatment, you may experience several changes to your body, including operation scars, reconstruction, radiotherapy skin changes, menopausal symptoms, lymphoedema, hair loss or regrowth, and weight changes. It's important to discuss these changes with your healthcare team to manage them effectively.

Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience pain, numbness, or sensitivity after breast surgery, inform your healthcare provider. They may recommend physical therapy, pain management techniques, or other interventions to help alleviate these symptoms.

Answer (Max 2000 words): Managing low energy or fatigue involves pacing yourself, prioritizing rest, and incorporating gentle exercise into your routine. Discuss these strategies with your healthcare provider for personalized advice.

Question (100 words): How can I address worries about starting a new relationship after breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Worries about starting a new relationship can be addressed through counseling or support groups. It's important to communicate openly with potential partners about your experiences and feelings.

Answer (Max 2000 words): If your relationship with your partner changes after breast cancer, consider seeking relationship counseling or sex therapy. Open communication and professional support can help navigate these changes.

Answer (Max 2000 words): Coping with the loss of fertility involves seeking emotional support, discussing your feelings with your partner, and exploring options like counseling or support groups. Your healthcare provider can offer additional resources.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Intimacy after breast cancer – emotional issues... Coping with the loss of my fertility and its impact on my relationship

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience low mood or depression after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience low mood or depression, seek professional help from a mental health provider. They can offer counseling, therapy, or medication to help manage these feelings.

Question (100 words): How can I regain confidence in my appearance after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Regaining confidence in your appearance can involve exploring options like prostheses, specialized bras, clothes, and swimwear. Support groups and counseling can also help you feel more confident.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Changes to my body and how I feel about my body... Regaining confidence in my appearance

Question (100 words): What resources are available for managing radiotherapy skin changes?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Resources for managing radiotherapy skin changes include moisturizers, gentle skincare routines, and professional advice from your healthcare team. Breast Cancer Now also offers guidance and support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Changes to my body and how I feel about my body... Radiotherapy skin changes

Question (100 words): How can I find specialist services for issues related to my body and intimacy after breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can find specialist services for issues related to your body and intimacy by discussing your concerns with your healthcare professional, using the prompt list provided by Breast Cancer Now, or contacting their helpline for guidance.

Question (100 words): What support does Breast Cancer Now offer for people affected by breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast Cancer Now offers life-changing support, world-class research, and change-making campaigns. They provide free services for anyone worried about breast cancer, dealing with a diagnosis, or living with or beyond treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Life-changing support... World-class research... Change-making campaigns

Question (100 words): What are the common emotions I might feel when my partner is diagnosed with breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): It's natural to feel a range of emotions such as stress, overwhelm, isolation, fear, and sadness. Your feelings may change frequently, and it's important to acknowledge these emotions rather than trying to suppress them.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Finding out your partner has breast cancer is very difficult and there’s no right or wrong way to feel.

Question (100 words): How might my partner feel after being diagnosed with breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your partner may experience a variety of emotions including anger, sadness, fear, and depression. They might also feel relieved that the cancer has been found and will be treated. Their feelings can fluctuate based on many factors.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Most people are shocked to hear they have breast cancer, and they go on to experience many different emotions.

Question (100 words): What are the main treatments for breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The main treatments for breast cancer include surgery, chemotherapy, radiotherapy, hormone (endocrine) therapy, targeted therapy, and bisphosphonates. The specific treatment plan will depend on the type and stage of the cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Treatment for breast cancer may include: Surgery, Chemotherapy, Radiotherapy, Hormone (endocrine) therapy, Targeted therapy, Bisphosphonates

Question (100 words): What happens during breast cancer surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast cancer surgery involves removing the cancer along with some or all of the breast tissue. It may also include removing some lymph nodes from under the arm to reduce the risk of cancer recurrence and spread.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Surgery is often the first treatment for people with breast cancer. It involves an operation to remove the cancer with some or all of the breast tissue.

Question (100 words): What is chemotherapy and when is it used in breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Chemotherapy uses anti-cancer drugs to destroy cancer cells. It is usually given after surgery to reduce the risk of the cancer returning or spreading (adjuvant chemotherapy). In some cases, it may be given before surgery (neo-adjuvant chemotherapy).
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Chemotherapy destroys cancer cells using anti-cancer drugs. It’s usually given after surgery to reduce the risk of breast cancer returning or spreading.

Question (100 words): What is radiotherapy and when is it used in breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Radiotherapy uses high-energy x-rays to destroy any remaining cancer cells after surgery. It is given to reduce the risk of the cancer coming back in the breast. Whether your partner needs radiotherapy depends on the type of breast cancer and the type of surgery they had.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Radiotherapy uses high energy x-rays to destroy any cancer cells that may be left behind after surgery.

Question (100 words): What is hormone (endocrine) therapy and when is it used?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Hormone therapy is used for breast cancers that are oestrogen receptor positive (ER-positive). These cancers use oestrogen to grow. Hormone therapies block or stop the effect of oestrogen on breast cancer cells, reducing the risk of cancer recurrence.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Hormone therapies block or stop the effect of oestrogen on breast cancer cells.

Question (100 words): What are targeted therapies and how are they used in breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Targeted therapies are drugs that block the growth and spread of cancer cells by interfering with specific processes in the cells that cause cancer to grow. Trastuzumab (Herceptin) is a commonly used targeted therapy for HER2-positive breast cancers.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Targeted therapies are a group of drugs that block the growth and spread of cancer cells.

Question (100 words): What are bisphosphonates and when are they used in breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Bisphosphonates are drugs that reduce the risk of breast cancer spreading in women who have been through menopause. They can be used if the menopause happened naturally or due to breast cancer treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Bisphosphonates are a group of drugs that can reduce the risk of breast cancer spreading in women who have been through the menopause.

Question (100 words): What physical changes can I expect after my partner's breast cancer surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After surgery, your partner's breast or breasts may look different, and there may be a loss of sensation. The breast area may appear bruised, swollen, and scarred. These changes can take time to adjust to.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Surgery for breast cancer will change the appearance of your partner’s breast or breasts. It may also cause a loss of sensation.

Question (100 words): Will my partner lose their hair during breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Many people experience hair loss, including loss of body hair, eyelashes, and eyebrows, as a side effect of chemotherapy. Hair loss is usually temporary, and hair will typically start to grow back after treatment ends.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Many people will lose either some or all of their hair as a result of their treatment for breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What can be done to reduce hair loss during chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Scalp cooling can be used to try to reduce hair loss during chemotherapy. This involves cooling the scalp to reduce blood flow and the amount of drugs reaching the hair follicles. However, it is not effective for everyone.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your partner may opt to have scalp cooling to try to reduce hair loss.

Question (100 words): What is fatigue and how does it affect breast cancer patients?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Fatigue is extreme tiredness and exhaustion that is a common side effect of breast cancer treatment. It may last for weeks or months after treatment ends and can affect both physical and emotional well-being.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Extreme tiredness and exhaustion is also known as fatigue. It’s a very common side effect of breast cancer treatment.

Question (100 words): What menopausal symptoms might my partner experience due to breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast cancer treatments can cause menopausal symptoms such as hot flushes, night sweats, vaginal dryness, weight gain, mood swings, and loss of sex drive. These symptoms are mainly due to changes in hormone levels.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast cancer treatments such as chemotherapy, hormone (endocrine) therapy or ovarian suppression can cause menopausal symptoms.

Question (100 words): How can I best support my partner during their breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Effective communication is key. Listen to your partner, acknowledge their feelings, and avoid trying to offer solutions unless asked. Simple acts like holding their hand or giving them a hug can also provide comfort.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: An important way to support your partner is by communicating effectively with them.

Question (100 words): What are some tips for active listening when supporting my partner?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Tips for active listening include avoiding distractions, letting your partner know you’re listening, checking your understanding, avoiding interruptions, encouraging silence, and using touch to provide comfort if appropriate.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Useful tips for active listening: Avoiding distractions, Letting your partner know you’re listening, Checking you’ve understood, Avoiding interrupting, Encouraging silence, Using touch to provide comfort

Question (100 words): Where can I find reliable information about breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Reliable sources of information include websites like breastcancernow.org, NHS.UK, Macmillan Cancer Support, and Cancer Research UK. Printed publications and helplines are also available if you prefer not to use the internet.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Be aware that some sites can be unreliable, so our website breastcancernow.org is a good place to start.

Question (100 words): How can I help my partner manage fatigue during and after treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Ask your partner what they need help with and respect their preferences. Offer support with daily tasks and consider involving other family members or friends. Resources like Macmillan Cancer Support’s booklet on coping with fatigue can also be helpful.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It might be useful to ask your partner what they would like you to do.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I’m struggling to cope with my partner’s breast cancer diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you’re finding it difficult to cope, talk to your GP, your partner’s breast care nurse, or call the helpline on 0808 800 6000. There are resources available to help you look after yourself during this challenging time.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re struggling to cope, you could talk to your GP or your partner’s breast care nurse.

Question (100 words): How can I help my partner adjust to changes in their appearance after treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Encourage open communication about their feelings and concerns. Offer support in practical ways, such as helping them choose a wig or headwear if they’ve experienced hair loss. Patience and understanding are key.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your partner may be concerned that you won’t find them attractive, and this may affect how they feel about sex and intimacy.

Question (100 words): How can I support my partner in talking about their feelings?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can support your partner by gauging how much they want to talk and encouraging them with gentle, open-ended questions. For example, you could ask, 'What did you feel like when the doctor said…?' or 'You said you feel frightened. What is it that frightens you the most?' This approach helps them express their emotions and feel supported.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Try to gauge how much your partner wants to talk. If they begin to tell you something about their cancer, ask them if they want to talk more about it. If they do, you could encourage them to talk by asking gentle, open-ended questions.

Question (100 words): What should I do if my partner directs their anger at me?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If your partner directs their anger at you, try to remember that this is often because they are upset about having cancer, rather than being upset with you. Understanding this can help you respond with empathy and patience, rather than taking their anger personally.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If your partner is feeling angry about their diagnosis, they may sometimes direct this anger at you. This reaction can be hurtful, particularly if you’re trying to support them. But try to remember this is often because they’re upset about having cancer, rather than being upset with you.

Question (100 words): How can I find time to talk with my partner about their cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Finding time and space to talk is crucial. Set aside a time when you’re able to talk undisturbed, somewhere you both feel at ease. Some people find it easier to talk while doing something else, such as walking, driving, or eating together.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Often, being able to talk comes down to finding the time and space to do so. It might be helpful to set aside a time when you’re able to talk undisturbed, somewhere you both feel at ease.

Question (100 words): What are some non-verbal ways to show my partner I care?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Non-verbal ways to show care include physical affection like hugs or holding hands, spending quality time together, and simple thoughtful gestures such as running a bath or giving inexpensive gifts they’ll appreciate.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There are other ways to show your partner you care, such as: Physical affection, like a hug or holding hands • Spending quality time together, and if possible spending time outside the house and enjoying each other’s company in different surroundings, such as a local coffee shop or park • Simple thoughtful gestures, such as running a bath or giving inexpensive gifts you know they’ll appreciate

Question (100 words): How can I support my partner during their appointments?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can support your partner by attending appointments with them if they want you to. Beforehand, talk about how involved they want you to be in discussions and plan any questions you want to ask. If you can’t attend in person, consider attending virtually or on the phone.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your partner may find it supportive if you go to appointments with them. Or they may prefer to go to some or all of their appointments on their own. If your partner does want you to go with them, you may find it helpful to talk beforehand about how involved they want you to be in any discussions and to plan any questions you want to ask.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I can’t take time off work for appointments?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Try to find out how long your partner will be in the hospital and how long any treatment sessions and courses last. Then try to come to a suitable arrangement with your employer. Some employers may expect you to use paid or unpaid holiday, while others are more flexible.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re working, taking time off to attend appointments may not always be easy. Try to find out how long your partner will be in hospital and how long any treatment sessions and courses last. Then try to come to a suitable arrangement with your employer.

Question (100 words): How can I help my partner with treatment decisions?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Talk about the treatment options with your partner to help them understand their thoughts and clarify any questions they may have for their treatment team. It’s important to be guided by your partner about how much information they want and to respect their decisions.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Talking about the options with your partner can help you to understand their thoughts and clarify any questions they may have for their treatment team. It's important to be guided by your partner about how much information they want about treatment options.

Question (100 words): What practical tasks can I help with to support my partner?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can offer to help with shopping, cooking, cleaning, washing, administration tasks like sending emails or paying bills, childcare responsibilities, driving, and gardening. Ask your partner what they would like you to do to help them feel in control.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Offering to do more practical tasks can be a very useful way of supporting your partner. This could include: • Shopping • Cooking • Cleaning • Washing • Administration, such as sending emails or paying bills • Childcare responsibilities • Driving • Gardening

Question (100 words): How might a breast cancer diagnosis change our relationship?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A breast cancer diagnosis can change your relationship in various ways. Some couples become closer, while others may experience strain if one partner becomes more dependent. Your roles and priorities may shift, and counseling can be very helpful in navigating these changes.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: When you partner is diagnosed with breast cancer it will often change your relationship with them. Some couples become closer and their relationship gets stronger. But if your partner was previously independent and becomes emotionally or practically dependent on you, this can put a strain on your relationship.

Question (100 words): How can I support my LGBTQ+ partner with breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Ensure your partner’s treatment team is aware of your sexuality to better support you both as a couple. Discuss any concerns either of you may have about this. You can find further support and information at LGBT Foundation, Stonewall, and OUTpatients.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Being diagnosed with breast cancer affects LGBTQ+ relationships in many of the same ways as heterosexual relationships. However, you may have different concerns if you or your partner identify as LGBTQ+. Your partner’s treatment team will be better able to support you both as a couple if they are aware of your sexuality.

Question (100 words): How might breast cancer affect our sex life?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast cancer and its treatments can affect your partner’s confidence, body image, and energy levels, impacting your sex life. Open communication about concerns and exploring new ways to be intimate can help. If needed, seek advice from a healthcare professional or counselor.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Being diagnosed with breast cancer will almost certainly affect how your partner feels about sex and intimacy. They might experience a lack of confidence and altered body image due to the side effects of treatment.

Question (100 words): Can breast cancer treatments affect fertility?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, some breast cancer treatments can affect a woman’s ability to become pregnant in the future. If having children is important, fertility preservation can usually be offered before starting treatment. Discuss options with a specialist or breast care nurse.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some breast cancer treatments can affect a woman’s ability to become pregnant in the future. This may have a significant impact on your plans as a couple and might affect how you view your relationship in the long term.

Question (100 words): How should we tell our family and friends about the diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Discuss with your partner who you want to tell, when, and how much information to share. Some people may react differently, and it’s important to find a way to involve them in supporting you without putting them under obligation.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Telling friends and family your partner has breast cancer can be very difficult. Before you do this, you and your partner may want to discuss who you want to tell and when and how much you want to tell them.

Question (100 words): How can we manage visitors during treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Work out the best times for visitors and communicate these to your friends and family. If you prefer not to take phone calls, let people leave messages or encourage them to text or email. Keep communication open to avoid misunderstandings.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may find that people drop in to see you and your partner. Although this is well-intended, unplanned visits can be inconvenient. If your partner is feeling upset or unwell, or if you’re tired or not in the mood for company, this can be frustrating.

Question (100 words): How should we talk to our children about the diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Decide together how and what to tell your children. Being open and honest helps them trust you. Children are good at picking up on emotions, so transparency is key. If needed, seek guidance from resources like 'Talking with your children about breast cancer.'
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s usually best if you and your partner decide together how and what to tell your children. Children are very good at picking up on other people’s emotions and can often tell if something isn’t right.

Question (100 words): What if my partner doesn’t want to talk about their cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Respect your partner’s preference if they don’t want to talk about their cancer. Avoiding conversations may make them feel unsupported, but it’s important to honor their need for space. Open communication when they’re ready can strengthen your support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Many people with breast cancer find it helpful to talk about what they’re thinking and how they’re feeling. However, some people prefer to cope on their own and don’t want to discuss their emotions or their diagnosis.

Question (100 words): How can I help my partner feel more in control during treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Support your partner in gaining information to make informed choices about their treatment. Offer to help with practical tasks they may find difficult due to side effects, and encourage them to continue doing what they can themselves to maintain a sense of control.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Supporting your partner to gain the information to make an informed choice can help them feel more in control. Offering to do more practical tasks can be a very useful way of supporting your partner.

Question (100 words): What resources are available for relationship counseling?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Counseling can be very helpful for couples dealing with the changes brought by a breast cancer diagnosis. Organizations like Relate offer relationship counseling, and many hospitals have counseling services, some specializing in cancer. Local community services may also be available.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Counselling can be very helpful, and discussing your feelings with someone impartial can help you both to see things more clearly. Organisations like Relate (details on page 26) offer relationship counselling.

Question (100 words): How can we maintain our relationship while dealing with breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Open communication, mutual support, and understanding each other’s needs and emotions are key. Spend quality time together, engage in non-verbal expressions of care, and seek professional help if needed to navigate the changes and challenges.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Open communication about how you’re both feeling can help you to understand and support each other and bring you closer together.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I feel overwhelmed by the situation?
Answer (Max 2000 words): It’s important to acknowledge your own feelings and seek support when needed. Talk to your partner, friends, family, or a professional counselor. Taking care of your emotional well-being will enable you to better support your partner.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re having problems communicating with your partner, there are places to go for help. Along with our helpline and website you may also benefit from contacting an organisation such as Relate

Question (100 words): How can I support my partner while taking care of myself?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To support your partner effectively, it's crucial to maintain your own well-being. Ensure you eat properly, engage in regular exercise, and get enough sleep. Dedicate time for yourself, whether it's through a walk, a social outing, or journaling. If you're feeling overwhelmed, reach out to friends, family, or your GP for support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: To be there for your partner, you need to look after yourself. Make sure you eat properly, get some regular exercise and try to get enough sleep.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I'm struggling to continue working while my partner is undergoing treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you're finding it difficult to work while your partner is undergoing treatment, consider discussing flexible working arrangements or time off with your employer. Utilize resources like your company’s HR department or occupational health adviser for additional support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If your partner is being treated for breast cancer and you’re struggling to continue working, you could consider talking to your employer about measures that might help you manage.

Question (100 words): How can talking to others help me cope with my partner's breast cancer diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Talking to close friends, family, or others who understand your situation can provide emotional support and prevent feelings of isolation. Consider joining support groups or online forums, and don’t hesitate to reach out to helplines for additional assistance.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It can help to talk to close friends or family about how you’re feeling. Communicating with people in a similar situation can help.

Question (100 words): What can I expect after my partner completes breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After treatment, you may experience a mix of emotions, including relief and anxiety. It’s normal to feel that things won’t return to exactly how they were. Your partner may continue to have check-ups, which can cause worry. Support each other through this transition and seek professional help if needed.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: When your partner does complete their treatment, you may have mixed emotions. While you will probably be keen to get your life back on track, you may also feel like things will never quite be the same as they were before.

Question (100 words): Where can I find support for sexual and relationship issues during this time?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The College of Sexual and Relationship Therapists (COSRT) offers information and support for sexual and relationship issues. You can visit their website at cosrt.org.uk or call them at 020 8543 2707 to find a therapist.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: College of Sexual and Relationship Therapists (COSRT) cosrt.org.uk 020 8543 2707 Information and support about sexual and relationship issues, and find a therapist.

Question (100 words): What resources are available for LGBTIQ+ individuals affected by cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): OUTpatients provides support and advocacy for LGBTIQ+ people affected by cancer. You can visit their website at outpatients.org.uk for more information and resources.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: OUTpatients outpatients.org.uk Supports and advocates for LGBTIQ+ people affected by cancer.

Question (100 words): How can Macmillan Cancer Support help me and my partner?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Macmillan Cancer Support offers information and support on all aspects of cancer, from diagnosis and treatment to finances, work, and practical issues. You can visit their website at macmillan.org.uk or call them at 0808 808 00 00 for assistance.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Macmillan Cancer Support macmillan.org.uk 0808 808 00 00 Information and support on all aspects of cancer, from diagnosis and treatment to finances, work and practical issues.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I'm experiencing mental health issues like anxiety or depression?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Mind provides information and help for mental health issues such as anxiety and depression. You can visit their website at mind.org.uk or call them at 0300 123 3393 for support and resources.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Mind mind.org.uk 0300 123 3393 Information about and help for mental health issues, such as anxiety and depression.

Question (100 words): Where can I find relationship counselling services?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Relate offers counselling services for all types of relationships nationwide. You can visit their website at relate.org.uk or call them at 0300 100 1234 for more information.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Relate relate.org.uk 0300 100 1234 Offers counselling services for every type of relationship nationwide.

Question (100 words): What support is available for LGBTQ+ individuals?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Stonewall supports lesbian, gay, bi, trans, queer, questioning, and ace (LGBTQ+) people. You can visit their website at stonewall.org.uk for resources and support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Stonewall stonewall.org.uk Supports lesbian, gay, bi, trans, queer, questioning and ace (LGBTQ+) people.

Question (100 words): How can Breast Cancer Now help me and my partner?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast Cancer Now offers life-changing support, world-class research, and change-making campaigns for those affected by breast cancer. You can visit their website at breastcancernow.org or call their helpline at 0808 800 6000 for free services and information.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: We’re Breast Cancer Now, the research and support charity. However you’re experiencing breast cancer, we’re here.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I feel constantly worried about my partner's cancer returning?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you find yourself constantly worried about your partner’s cancer returning, it might be helpful to talk to your GP or your partner’s breast care nurse. They can provide reassurance and support to help manage your anxiety.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you find yourself constantly worrying about your partner’s cancer coming back, it might be helpful to talk to your GP or your partner’s breast care nurse.

Question (100 words): How can I help my partner adjust to life after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Support your partner in moving forward without putting pressure on them. Reading resources like Breast Cancer Now’s booklet 'Moving forward' can help address common concerns after hospital-based treatment ends.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s important to support your partner to move forward without putting pressure on them. When your partner has finished treatment, you might both want to read our booklet Moving forward.

Question (100 words): What are some practical steps I can take to manage work during this time?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Consider discussing flexible working hours or taking time off with your employer to manage work alongside your partner’s treatment. Utilize your company’s HR department or occupational health adviser for additional support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If your employer has an HR department or occupational health adviser, they may be able to offer you support at work.

Question (100 words): How can I find a support group for people in similar situations?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can find support groups and online forums through organizations like Breast Cancer Now. Their Someone Like Me service and online forum are good places to start connecting with others who understand your situation.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may find our online forum or Someone Like Me service a good place to start.

Question (100 words): What are some healthy habits I should maintain to support myself and my partner?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Maintain a balanced diet, engage in regular physical activity, and ensure you get adequate sleep. Dedicate time for self-care activities like walking, socializing, or journaling to help manage stress and maintain your well-being.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Make sure you eat properly, get some regular exercise and try to get enough sleep.

Question (100 words): How can I communicate effectively with my partner about our feelings during this time?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Open and honest communication is key. Share your feelings and encourage your partner to do the same. Consider seeking professional counseling if needed to help navigate your emotions and strengthen your relationship.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s likely this will be a strange time for your partner too, and some of the feelings you have may be very similar.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I'm feeling overwhelmed by the situation?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you're feeling overwhelmed, reach out to friends, family, or your GP for support. Don’t hesitate to seek professional help if needed, and consider joining support groups to connect with others who understand your situation.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re finding it difficult to do these things or are feeling overwhelmed, let a friend, family member or your GP know.

Question (100 words): How can I help my partner prepare for upcoming medical appointments?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Help your partner by organizing transportation, making a list of questions to ask the doctor, and providing emotional support. Accompany them to appointments if possible to offer additional assistance and reassurance.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some people continue to work after a diagnosis of breast cancer and only take time off to attend appointments and undergo treatment.

Question (100 words): What are some signs that I may need professional help for my emotional well-being?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Signs that you may need professional help include persistent feelings of sadness, anxiety, or hopelessness, difficulty coping with daily activities, and thoughts of self-harm. Seek help from a mental health professional if you experience these symptoms.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you find yourself constantly worrying about your partner’s cancer coming back, it might be helpful to talk to your GP or your partner’s breast care nurse.

Question (100 words): What is capecitabine and how does it work?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Capecitabine is a chemotherapy drug, also known by its brand name Xeloda. It works by destroying cancer cells by affecting their ability to divide and grow. However, it can also affect other cells in the body, leading to side effects.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Capecitabine is a chemotherapy drug. You may hear it called by its brand name Xeloda. Chemotherapy destroys cancer cells by affecting their ability to divide and grow.

Question (100 words): When is capecitabine prescribed for breast cancer patients?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Capecitabine is prescribed for patients with primary breast cancer that is triple negative, for locally advanced or secondary breast cancer, and sometimes as part of a clinical trial.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may benefit from capecitabine if you have primary breast cancer that is triple negative (oestrogen receptor negative, progesterone receptor negative and HER2-negative). Capecitabine is used to treat breast cancer that has come back (recurrence) after previous treatment.

Question (100 words): How is capecitabine taken?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Capecitabine is taken as a tablet, usually twice a day for 14 days, followed by a 7-day break. This 21-day period is one treatment cycle.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You will take capecitabine as a tablet (orally). You usually take capecitabine twice a day (once in the morning and once in the evening) for 14 days. You will then have a 7-day break.

Question (100 words): What tests are done before starting capecitabine?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Before starting capecitabine, you will have blood tests, measurements of your height and weight, and tests to check your heart function, such as an ECG and an echocardiogram. You will also have a blood test to check your DPD levels.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You’ll have blood tests, and your height and weight will be measured. You may also have tests to check your heart function, such as: An ECG (electrocardiogram), a simple test that checks your heart rhythm An echocardiogram (an ultrasound scan of the heart)

Question (100 words): What should I do if I vomit after taking capecitabine?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you vomit after taking capecitabine, do not take an extra dose. Contact your treatment team for further instructions.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you are sick (vomit) after taking your tablets, do not take an extra dose.

Question (100 words): How should I store capecitabine tablets?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Store capecitabine tablets in their original packaging at room temperature, away from moisture, heat, and direct sunlight. Keep them out of the reach of children.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Keep the tablets in their original packaging. Store them at room temperature, away from moisture, heat and direct sunlight. Keep the tablets out of the reach of children.

Question (100 words): What are the common side effects of capecitabine?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common side effects include effects on the blood (such as reduced white blood cells, red blood cells, and platelets), diarrhoea, nausea, vomiting, sore mouth, hand-foot syndrome, and changes in appetite.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Capecitabine can temporarily affect the number of blood cells in the body... Diarrhoea is common during treatment and can sometimes be severe... You may feel sick (nausea) or be sick (vomit)... Sore mouth... Hand-foot syndrome (palmar-plantar syndrome) is a common side effect of capecitabine... Changes to your appetite

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience severe diarrhoea while taking capecitabine?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience severe diarrhoea, contact your chemotherapy team immediately. They can prescribe medication and may consider stopping your capecitabine for a time to help control it.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Diarrhoea is common during treatment and can sometimes be severe. Tell your chemotherapy team as they can prescribe medication and may consider stopping your capecitabine for a time to help control it.

Question (100 words): How can I manage hand-foot syndrome caused by capecitabine?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To manage hand-foot syndrome, regularly apply hand and foot creams or lotions containing urea, wear loose-fitting clothing, take lukewarm baths, pat skin dry, use rubber gloves, and avoid hot water, saunas, harsh chemicals, and sun exposure.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Regularly apply hand and foot creams or lotions containing urea to keep the skin well moisturised before starting treatment... Avoid having your hands or feet in hot water... Avoid using saunas or steam rooms... Avoid harsh chemicals... Avoid exposing any affected areas to the sun

Question (100 words): What should I do if I suspect I have a blood clot while taking capecitabine?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you suspect a blood clot, contact your treatment team or go to your local A&E department immediately. Symptoms include pain, redness, heat, and swelling of the arm or leg, shortness of breath, chest pain, and unexplained cough.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Contact your treatment team or go to your local A&E department straight away if you have any of the following symptoms: Pain, redness/discolouration, heat and swelling of the arm or leg... Shortness of breath... Pain or tightness in the chest... Unexplained cough (or coughing up blood)

Question (100 words): Can capecitabine cause hair loss?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Capecitabine occasionally causes temporary hair thinning when used alone. When combined with other chemotherapy drugs, it can cause complete hair loss, including eyebrows, eyelashes, and body hair.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: When used on its own, capecitabine occasionally causes some temporary hair thinning. It very rarely causes complete hair loss. If capecitabine is taken in combination with another chemotherapy drug, most people will lose all their hair including eyebrows, eyelashes and body hair.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience an allergic reaction to capecitabine?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience an allergic reaction, contact your hospital immediately. Symptoms include itchy red/discoloured bumps on your skin, swelling in your lips, tongue or throat, breathlessness, wheezing, and chest pain.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Contact your hospital immediately if you notice any of the following symptoms: Itchy red/discoloured bumps on your skin... Swelling in your lips, tongue or throat... Breathlessness, wheezing, a bad cough or sudden difficulty breathing... Tight chest or chest pain

Question (100 words): How long will I need to take capecitabine?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The duration of capecitabine treatment varies. For primary breast cancer, your treatment team will discuss the number of cycles. For secondary breast cancer, you’ll continue taking it as long as you’re benefiting and side effects are manageable.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: How long you need to take capecitabine for varies from person to person. If you have primary breast cancer, your treatment team will talk to you about how many treatment cycles of capecitabine you will have. If you have secondary breast cancer, you’ll keep taking capecitabine for as long as your treatment team feels you’re benefiting from the drug and any side effects are manageable.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I feel extremely tired while taking capecitabine?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you feel extremely tired, inform your GP or treatment team. They can assess you and offer advice on managing your energy levels.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Extreme tiredness (cancer-related fatigue) is a very common side effect of cancer treatment. If you think you have fatigue, tell your GP or treatment team. They can assess you and offer advice on how to manage your energy levels.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I develop severe and ongoing hand-foot syndrome?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you develop severe and ongoing hand-foot syndrome, inform your treatment team. They may prescribe emollients or creams, delay treatment, reduce the dose, or stop treatment. In rare cases, you may lose your fingerprints permanently.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If your symptoms are severe, your treatment team may recommend delaying treatment, reducing the dose, or stopping treatment. If you develop severe and ongoing hand-foot syndrome while taking capecitabine, you may lose your fingerprints. This is a rare symptom, but it may be permanent.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I feel breathless, dizzy, or particularly tired?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you feel breathless, dizzy, or particularly tired, inform your treatment team as you may have anaemia due to reduced red blood cells.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Having too few red blood cells is called anaemia. If you feel breathless, dizzy or particularly tired, let your treatment team know.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice bruising, nosebleeds, or bleeding gums?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you notice bruising, nosebleeds, or bleeding gums, inform your treatment team as capecitabine can reduce the number of platelets, which help the blood to clot.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Capecitabine can reduce the number of platelets, which help the blood to clot. Tell your treatment team if you have any of these symptoms.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I have a high temperature or symptoms of an infection?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you have a high temperature (over 37.5°C) or symptoms of an infection such as a sore throat, cough, or feeling cold or shivery, contact your hospital advice line immediately.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If these show the number of blood cells is too low, your next cycle of treatment may be delayed or the dose of chemotherapy reduced. Your treatment team may give you advice to follow for reporting signs of an infection.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience joint and back pain, taste changes, headache, dizziness, difficulty sleeping, or sore and watery eyes?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience these less common side effects, inform your treatment team for advice on how to manage them.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Other less common side effects of capecitabine include: Joint and back pain... Taste changes... Headache... Dizziness... Difficulty sleeping... Sore and watery eyes. Your treatment team can advise on how to manage these.

Question (100 words): What should I do with unused capecitabine tablets at the end of my treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Do not throw away unused capecitabine tablets. Return them to your treatment team.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: At the end of your capecitabine treatment Do not throw away unused capecitabine tablets. Return them to your treatment team.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I miss a dose of capecitabine?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you miss a dose of capecitabine, do not take an extra dose to make up for it. Simply take the next scheduled dose at the usual time. It's important to inform your treatment team about the missed dose.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you miss a dose of capecitabine, do not take an extra dose to make up for the one you missed. Take the next dose at the usual time and speak to your treatment team.

Question (100 words): Can capecitabine affect my ability to drive or operate machinery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, capecitabine may cause dizziness, nausea, or fatigue, which can affect your ability to drive or operate machinery safely. Avoid these activities if you experience any such symptoms.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Capecitabine may make you feel dizzy, sick or tired. This could affect your ability to drive or operate machinery safely. Avoid driving or using machinery if you have any symptoms that may affect your ability to do this.

Question (100 words): Can I take capecitabine with other medications?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you are taking any other prescribed or over-the-counter medicines, inform your treatment team. Capecitabine can interact with blood-thinning drugs like warfarin, increasing the risk of bleeding. Your treatment team may adjust your medication or monitor you more closely.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re taking any other prescribed or over-the-counter medicines, let your treatment team know. If you take drugs to thin the blood (anti-coagulants) such as warfarin, capecitabine can increase your risk of bleeding.

Question (100 words): Is it safe to have sex during capecitabine treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can still have sex during treatment. While chemotherapy drugs are not thought to pass into vaginal fluids or semen, using barrier methods like condoms is advised. Avoid becoming pregnant during treatment and for 6 months after your last dose.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can still have sex during treatment. It’s thought chemotherapy drugs cannot pass into vaginal fluids or semen, but this cannot be completely ruled out. Most treatment teams will advise using barrier methods of contraception, such as condoms, during treatment.

Question (100 words): Can I get vaccinated while on capecitabine treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You should avoid live vaccines while on chemotherapy due to a weakened immune system. Live vaccines include mumps, measles, rubella, polio, BCG, and yellow fever. It’s safe to have these vaccinations 6 months after treatment finishes. Consult your treatment team before any vaccinations.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You should not have any live vaccines while you’re having chemotherapy. Live vaccines include: Mumps, Measles, Rubella (German measles), Polio, BCG (tuberculosis), Yellow fever.

Question (100 words): When should I get a COVID-19 vaccination if I'm on capecitabine?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your treatment team will advise the best time to have a COVID-19 vaccination if you are having chemotherapy or targeted therapies. It’s important to follow their guidance to ensure safety and effectiveness.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re having chemotherapy or targeted therapies, your treatment team will advise the best time to have a COVID-19 vaccination.

Question (100 words): Should I get a flu vaccine while on capecitabine?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, anyone at risk of a weakened immune system, including those on chemotherapy, should have the flu vaccine. The flu vaccine is not a live vaccine, so it is safe to have during treatment. Consult your chemotherapy team for the best timing.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Anyone at risk of a weakened immune system, and therefore more prone to infection, should have the flu vaccine. This includes people due to have, or already having, chemotherapy. The flu vaccine is not a live vaccine so does not contain any active viruses.

Question (100 words): What should I do if someone I live with needs a nasal flu vaccine?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Inform your treatment team if someone you live with needs the nasal flu vaccine, as it is a live vaccine. They can advise on any necessary precautions.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The nasal flu vaccine offered to children is a live vaccine. Let your treatment team know if someone you live with needs the nasal flu vaccine.

Question (100 words): Where can I get further support during my capecitabine treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your chemotherapy team and breast care nurse can provide support. Additionally, you can call Breast Cancer Now’s free helpline on 0808 800 6000 for information and support, or visit their website at breastcancernow.org.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your chemotherapy team and breast care nurse can help with any questions you have. You can also call our free helpline on 0808 800 6000 for information and support, or visit our website breastcancernow.org

Question (100 words): Can I connect with others who are going through similar treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, Breast Cancer Now’s Someone Like Me service can connect you with someone who has had the same experience. You can also find support on the monthly chemotherapy threads on their online forum at forum.breastcancernow.org.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re having chemotherapy for primary breast cancer, our Someone Like Me service can put you in touch with someone who has had the same experience as you. You can find people going through treatment at the same time as you on the monthly chemotherapy threads on our online forum forum.breastcancernow.org

Question (100 words): What should I do if I plan to travel overseas while on capecitabine?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Check with your treatment team before traveling overseas. They can provide advice on any necessary precautions, especially regarding vaccinations and your weakened immune system.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re planning a holiday or need to travel overseas, check with your treatment team first.

Question (100 words): How can I support Breast Cancer Now’s work?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can support Breast Cancer Now by making a donation or including a gift in your will. They rely on donations to fund their support services and health information. Visit breastcancernow.org/give for more information.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: We don’t get any government or NHS funding for our support services or health information. So, we rely on donations and gifts in wills to make our vital work happen. If you’d like to support us, go to breastcancernow.org/give

Question (100 words): What is the best way to get in touch with Breast Cancer Now for help?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can call Breast Cancer Now’s helpline on 0808 800 6000 to speak with a helpline nurse, or visit their website at breastcancernow.org for reliable breast cancer information.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Call 0808 800 6000 to talk things through with our helpline nurses. Visit breastcancernow.org for reliable breast cancer information.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience severe side effects from capecitabine?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience severe side effects from capecitabine, contact your treatment team immediately. They can provide guidance on managing side effects and may adjust your treatment plan if necessary.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you experience any severe side effects, it is crucial to contact your healthcare provider immediately for appropriate management and possible adjustments to your treatment plan.

Question (100 words): How can I manage fatigue while on capecitabine treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To manage fatigue, try to balance rest and activity, prioritize tasks, and ensure you get enough sleep. Discuss any persistent fatigue with your treatment team, as they may offer additional strategies or adjustments to your treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Fatigue is a common side effect of capecitabine. Managing it involves balancing rest and activity, prioritizing tasks, and ensuring adequate sleep. Discuss persistent fatigue with your treatment team for further support.

Question (100 words): What dietary considerations should I keep in mind while taking capecitabine?
Answer (Max 2000 words): While taking capecitabine, maintain a balanced diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and whole grains. Stay hydrated and avoid excessive alcohol. Consult your healthcare team for specific dietary recommendations tailored to your needs.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Maintaining a balanced diet and staying hydrated are important while taking capecitabine. Avoid excessive alcohol and consult your healthcare team for personalized dietary advice.

Question (100 words): How can I maintain my emotional well-being during capecitabine treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To maintain emotional well-being, consider talking to a counselor or support group, practicing relaxation techniques, and staying connected with loved ones. Your treatment team can also provide resources and support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Maintaining emotional well-being involves seeking support from counselors, support groups, and loved ones, and practicing relaxation techniques. Your treatment team can offer additional resources and support.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I suspect an allergic reaction to capecitabine?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you suspect an allergic reaction to capecitabine, seek medical attention immediately. Symptoms may include rash, itching, swelling, severe dizziness, or trouble breathing. Your treatment team will provide further instructions.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you experience symptoms of an allergic reaction such as rash, itching, swelling, severe dizziness, or trouble breathing, seek medical attention immediately.

Question (100 words): Can capecitabine affect my fertility?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Capecitabine can affect fertility. It is advised not to become pregnant during treatment and for 6 months after your last dose. Discuss fertility preservation options with your treatment team if this is a concern for you.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You’re advised not to become pregnant while having treatment and for 6 months after taking your last dose. This is because capecitabine can harm a developing baby.

Question (100 words): What should I know about capecitabine and its potential impact on my liver function?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Capecitabine can affect liver function. Your treatment team will monitor your liver function through blood tests. Inform them of any symptoms like jaundice, dark urine, or abdominal pain, as these may indicate liver issues.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your treatment team will monitor your liver function through regular blood tests while you are on capecitabine. Report any symptoms like jaundice, dark urine, or abdominal pain immediately.

Question (100 words): Why might some women choose not to have breast reconstruction surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Some women choose not to have breast reconstruction for various reasons, including being less concerned about body changes, not wanting additional surgery and recovery, medical reasons, or wanting time to adjust to their new body shape. The decision should be based on what feels right for the individual.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Many women choose not to have breast reconstruction. This can be for a number of different reasons.

Question (100 words): What type of bra should I wear in the first weeks after breast surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): In the first few weeks after surgery, it is generally recommended to wear a soft, non-wired bra that isn’t too restrictive. A front-fastening bra may be easier to put on if your shoulder is stiff. Your surgeon or breast care nurse can provide specific advice based on your surgery type.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: In the first few weeks after surgery, most women wear a soft, non-wired bra that isn’t too restrictive.

Question (100 words): What features should I look for in a bra while I am healing from breast surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): While healing, choose a bra with soft seams, a wide underband, deep front and side panels, full cups, cup separation, fully adjustable straps, a simple design, and no underwires. High cotton content bras are gentler on healing skin.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: While the area recovers from surgery, the nerves repair and any skin changes from radiotherapy settle down, you may want to choose a bra that has: • Soft seams • A wide underband (the band that goes under the cups and round your back) • Deep front and side panels • Full cups • Cup separation (the centre of the bra between the cups should sit flat on your chest) • Fully adjustable straps • A simple design (details on the bra, like lace, may make it less comfortable) • No underwires (the wires sew

Question (100 words): How can I get fitted for a permanent breast prosthesis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Once your wound is healed and any swelling has gone down (usually within six to eight weeks), you can be fitted for a permanent prosthesis. This can be done by a professional fitter who will help you choose the right size, shape, and style that suits your needs and lifestyle.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Once your wound is healed and any swelling has gone down (usually within six to eight weeks) you can be fitted for a permanent prosthesis if you choose

Question (100 words): What is a breast prosthesis and how does it work?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A breast prosthesis is an artificial breast form that replaces the shape of all or part of a breast that has been removed. It fits in a bra cup with or without a bra pocket. Most are made from soft silicone gel, designed to move, feel, and weigh as similar to a natural breast as possible.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A breast prosthesis is an artificial breast form that replaces the shape of all or part of the breast that has been removed.

Question (100 words): What are the different styles of breast prostheses available?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast prostheses come in various styles including full or standard prostheses, partial or shaped prostheses, shell prostheses, and stick-on prostheses. Each style is designed to meet different needs, whether you’ve had all or part of your breast removed, or if your breasts are naturally different in size.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Prostheses come in a wide variety of shapes, sizes and skin tones.

Question (100 words): Can I wear a stick-on prosthesis after breast surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Most women are advised not to wear a stick-on prosthesis for 6–12 months after surgery or during (and sometimes after) radiotherapy as it may damage the skin. However, they can be suitable for more physically active women or those wanting to wear less supportive bras.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Most women will be advised not to wear a stick-on prosthesis for 6–12 months after surgery or during (and sometimes after) radiotherapy as it may damage the skin.

Question (100 words): What should I consider when choosing a bra after breast surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): When choosing a bra after breast surgery, consider features like soft seams, a wide underband, deep front and side panels, full cups, cup separation, fully adjustable straps, a simple design, and no underwires. High cotton content bras are recommended for gentler skin contact.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: While the area recovers from surgery, the nerves repair and any skin changes from radiotherapy settle down, you may want to choose a bra that has: • Soft seams • A wide underband (the band that goes under the cups and round your back) • Deep front and side panels • Full cups • Cup separation (the centre of the bra between the cups should sit flat on your chest) • Fully adjustable straps • A simple design (details on the bra, like lace, may make it less comfortable) • No underwires (the wires sew

Question (100 words): Where can I buy post-surgery bras and how can I get financial help?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Post-surgery bras can be bought from specialist suppliers, high-street shops, or online. They are exempt from VAT if bought by someone who’s had breast surgery. Financial help is available through Macmillan Cancer Support grants, NHS Low Income Scheme, and certain benefits.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Post-surgery bras are exempt from VAT if they’re bought by someone who’s had breast surgery.

Question (100 words): What type of bra is best for wearing a breast prosthesis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A well-fitting bra with a full cup is often sufficient to hold a prosthesis in place. Some women prefer a bra with a pocket designed to help the prosthesis sit more securely. Post-surgery bras come with bra pockets or you can adapt an ordinary bra by sewing a piece of stretchy material across the back of the bra cup.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you choose to wear a prosthesis, a well-fitting bra with a full cup is often all that’s needed to hold your prosthesis in place.

Question (100 words): How do I look after my breast prosthesis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To look after your breast prosthesis, wash it regularly with mild soap and warm water. Avoid harsh chemicals and abrasives. Store it in a cool, dry place when not in use. Check for any damage or wear and replace it if necessary.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Looking after your prosthesis

Question (100 words): When should I replace my breast prosthesis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You should replace your breast prosthesis every 6 to 12 months, or sooner if it shows signs of wear or damage. Regular replacement ensures it continues to provide a natural appearance and comfortable fit.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Replacing a prosthesis

Question (100 words): Can I travel by air with my breast prosthesis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, you can travel by air with your breast prosthesis. It is advisable to pack it in your carry-on luggage to avoid damage. Inform the airline staff if necessary for security checks.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Air travel with a prosthesis

Question (100 words): Is it okay to not wear a breast prosthesis after surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, it is perfectly okay to choose not to wear a breast prosthesis after surgery. Some women prefer this option and find it more comfortable or suitable for their lifestyle.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Not wearing a prosthesis

Question (100 words): What clothing options are available for women who have had breast surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Women who have had breast surgery can wear a variety of clothing options. Practical tips include choosing clothes that are comfortable and fit well, and considering styles that accommodate a prosthesis if worn. Swimwear options are also available.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Clothing

Question (100 words): What swimwear options are there for women who have had breast surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Swimwear options for women who have had breast surgery include one-piece suits, tankinis, and bikinis. Some styles are designed to accommodate a prosthesis, while others offer support and coverage without one.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Swimwear

Question (100 words): Where can I find further support and information after breast surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Further support and information can be found by calling the free Helpline on 0808 800 6000. Additional resources and organizations are listed in the ‘Further support’ and ‘Useful organisations and suppliers’ sections of the booklet.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Further support

Question (100 words): What temporary prosthesis is provided after breast surgery and how should I use it?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After breast surgery, you may be given a fabric-covered temporary prosthesis, often called a ‘softie’ or ‘cumfie/comfie’. To make it look better and feel more secure, you can remove some of the stuffing and either stitch it to the bottom of your bra cup or keep it in place with a safety pin.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your breast care nurse or one of the ward nurses will usually give you a fabric-covered temporary prosthesis, often called a ‘softie’ or ‘cumfie/comfie’, to wear during this time.

Question (100 words): What should I do if my chest area feels particularly sensitive after breast surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If your chest area feels particularly sensitive after breast surgery, wearing a bra may help you feel more comfortable. Your surgeon or breast care nurse can advise you on the best type of bra to wear based on your surgery.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast surgery, and sometimes radiotherapy, may make your chest area feel particularly sensitive. Wearing a bra may make you feel more comfortable, but this isn’t always the case.

Question (100 words): How can I adapt an ordinary bra to hold a breast prosthesis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can adapt an ordinary bra to hold a breast prosthesis by sewing a piece of stretchy material across the back of the bra cup to act as a pocket. Pockets are also available to sew in yourself, which can be purchased online from most mastectomy bra stockists.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can adapt an ordinary bra by sewing a piece of stretchy material across the back of the bra cup to act as a pocket.

Question (100 words): What are asymmetrical breast prostheses and who are they suitable for?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Asymmetrical breast prostheses are designed for women who have had more tissue removed, as they have extensions to fit under the arm or upper chest. They can also be used by women who have not had extensive surgery and are specifically designed for either the left or right side.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: These are generally more suitable for women who have had more tissue removed, as they have extensions to fit under the arm or upper chest. However, they can also be used by women who have not had extensive surgery. They are specifically designed for either the left or right side.

Question (100 words): What is a made-to-measure breast prosthesis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A made-to-measure breast prosthesis uses a 3D scanner to produce a computerized 3D image of the chest area, which is then used to create a customized prosthesis shape. This ensures a good fit to the chest, preventing movement, and is matched to your skin tone. These prostheses are not currently available on the NHS.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: This technique uses a 3D scanner to produce a computerised 3D image of the chest area, which can then be used to create a customised prosthesis shape.
