It is made to give a good fit to the chest, which stops the prosthesis moving, and is matched to your skin tone. Made-to-measure breast prostheses are not currently available on the NHS.

Question (100 words): What is an air-inflated prosthesis and where can I get one?
Answer (Max 2000 words): An air-inflated prosthesis comes with a pump so it can be inflated to the required size. It may not be available in all hospitals. You should check with your hospital or a specialist supplier to see if they offer this type of prosthesis.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: This prosthesis comes with a pump so it can be inflated to the required size. It may not be available in all hospitals.

Question (100 words): How do I choose the right weight for my silicone prosthesis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The most suitable weight for your silicone prosthesis will depend on how heavy your other breast is. If you have had both breasts removed, you can choose the weight you feel most comfortable with. If you have had a single mastectomy, a full-weight prosthesis may make you feel more balanced, but a lighter-weight version might be more comfortable if you need a large size.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The most suitable weight will depend on how heavy your other breast is. If you have had both breasts removed, you can choose the weight you feel most comfortable with. If you have had a single mastectomy, a full-weight prosthesis may make you feel more balanced as it matches the weight of your other breast.

Question (100 words): What materials are breast prostheses made from?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Most prostheses are made from silicone, which is a soft gel-like substance. Foam prostheses are also available and are lighter and cooler. Some prostheses are filled with polypropylene beads, which allow air to circulate and are also cooler.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Most prostheses are made from silicone, which is a soft gel-like substance. Foam prostheses are also available. A foam prosthesis is lighter and cooler. It may be more suitable if you’re particularly active or you may find this style more comfortable in warmer weather.

Question (100 words): Are breast prostheses available in different skin tones?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, many prostheses are available in different skin tones. Having a prosthesis that is as close to your skin tone as possible may help you feel more comfortable and confident. Some companies make prostheses to order or can add color to existing products.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Although it might be difficult to achieve an exact match, many prostheses are available in different skin tones. Having a prosthesis that is as close to your skin tone as possible may help you feel more comfortable and confident.

Question (100 words): What are the different types of backings available for breast prostheses?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The backing of most prostheses is made of the same material as the front. Some may have a different backing, such as fabric or a soft panel of gel, designed to make them more comfortable. Backings that can be molded to fit an uneven chest wall are also available. Some prostheses have backings that allow more airflow and may be cooler.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The backing of most prostheses is made of the same material as the front. Some may have a different backing, such as fabric or a soft panel of gel, designed to make them more comfortable.

Question (100 words): Can I use a cover over my prosthesis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, you can use a soft fabric cover to fit over the silicone surface of your prosthesis. Although the prosthesis may not sit as well, this can prevent a rash or skin reaction developing, which might happen if you get hot and sweat behind your prosthesis.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can use a soft fabric cover to fit over the silicone surface, although the prosthesis may not sit as well. This can prevent a rash or skin reaction developing, which might happen if you get hot and sweat behind your prosthesis.

Question (100 words): What are swim prostheses and how are they different from regular prostheses?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Swim prostheses are made especially for use when swimming and don’t get damaged by salt water or chlorine. Some swim prostheses are clear. They are designed to be durable in aquatic environments and maintain their shape and integrity while swimming.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Swim prostheses are made especially for use when swimming and don’t get damaged by salt water or chlorine. Some swim prostheses are clear.

Question (100 words): What are prosthetic nipples and how do they work?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Prosthetic nipples are made of soft silicone that can be worn on a reconstructed breast or prosthesis. They are either self-sticking or come with special skin glue that can hold the prosthetic nipple in place for several days. They come in different sizes and skin colors, and some hospitals custom-make them to match the nipple on your other breast.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Prosthetic (artificial) nipples are made of soft silicone that can be worn on a reconstructed breast or prosthesis. They are either self-sticking or come with special skin glue that can hold the prosthetic nipple in place for several days.

Question (100 words): How do I get a breast prosthesis fitting appointment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your breast care nurse will usually arrange a fitting appointment for you if you want to have a permanent prosthesis. If you’re not given an appointment, ask your breast care nurse about this. Your appointment will often be at your local hospital, and the fitting may be done by your breast care nurse or another trained fitter.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your breast care nurse will usually arrange a fitting appointment for you if you want to have a permanent prosthesis. If you’re not given an appointment, ask your breast care nurse about this.

Question (100 words): Do I have to pay for my breast prosthesis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): NHS patients do not have to pay for their prosthesis. However, not all prosthesis styles are available on the NHS. If you are a private patient, check to see if your private health scheme covers the cost of your prosthesis. If you have to pay for your prosthesis, you won’t have to pay the VAT on it.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: NHS patients do not have to pay for their prosthesis. However, not all prostheses styles are available on the NHS.

Question (100 words): What should I bring to my prosthesis fitting appointment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): It’s important to bring a well-fitting bra to your appointment so you and the fitter can see how the prosthesis will sit in your bra. It’s useful to wear a plain, light-colored top. You might also want to bring a variety of tops with different necklines to see how the prosthesis might work with different clothes.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s important to take a well-fitting bra (see page 8) to your appointment so you and the fitter can see how the prosthesis will sit in your bra.

Question (100 words): How should I look after my silicone breast prosthesis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You should look after a silicone breast prosthesis as you would your own skin. Wash it daily in warm soapy water and dry it with a towel. When you are not using a silicone prosthesis, store it in the shaped unit inside the box it came in. Take care not to catch the prosthesis with sharp objects as these may damage it.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Generally, you should look after a silicone breast prosthesis as you would your own skin. Wash it daily in warm soapy water and dry it with a towel.

Question (100 words): How often do I need to replace my breast prosthesis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A prosthesis will have a guarantee, but the length of this can vary. Most prostheses will last longer than the period of the guarantee. You can request a replacement prosthesis on the NHS when it is worn out. You can also ask for a reassessment if your prosthesis is no longer a good fit.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A prosthesis will have a guarantee but the length of this can vary. Most prostheses will last longer than the period of the guarantee.

Question (100 words): What should I do if my silicone prosthesis gets damaged?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If a silicone prosthesis gets damaged, you can usually seal the tear temporarily with a sticking plaster. If your prosthesis is damaged due to a manufacturing fault, you should be refitted with a new one free if you’re an NHS patient. If it’s damaged because you have punctured it or not followed the care instructions, you may be charged for replacing it.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If a silicone prosthesis gets damaged, you can usually seal the tear temporarily with a sticking plaster.

Question (100 words): Can I donate my used breast prosthesis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, you may wish to donate your used prosthesis so it can be sent to countries where it is difficult or impossible to get a breast prosthesis. You can contact Hospices of Hope (hospicesofhope.co.uk) and Prostheses to India (prosthesestoindia.co.uk) to arrange a donation.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may wish to donate your used prosthesis, so it can be sent to countries where it is difficult or impossible to get a breast prosthesis.

Question (100 words): What happens if I have a breast prosthesis and go through airport security?
Answer (Max 2000 words): External breast prostheses will show up on body scanners. If selected for a scan, you might want to tell the security staff that you are wearing a breast prosthesis before being scanned. It may also be helpful for you to carry a letter from your GP or treatment team, confirming this.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: External breast prostheses will show up on body scanners.

Question (100 words): Is it okay to not wear a breast prosthesis after surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, many women choose not to wear a prosthesis. If you have had one of your breasts removed, it’s worth trying a number of different styles of clothing to find out what you feel most comfortable in. You can make the two sides of your body seem more balanced by wearing dark or patterned fabrics and loose-fitting clothes.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may choose not to wear a prosthesis. Many women prefer how this looks and feels.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I get a skin rash under my prosthesis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you get a skin rash under your prosthesis, talk to your breast care nurse or GP. They can provide advice on how to prevent and treat the rash, and may suggest using a bra pocket or a soft fabric cover to prevent further irritation.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you get a skin rash under the prosthesis, talk to your breast care nurse or GP.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I want to wear strapless clothes after breast surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you want to wear strapless clothes after breast surgery, you can try using a safety pin to attach a softie directly inside the garment, wearing a strapless bra with your usual prosthesis (if it's not too heavy), or wearing a bra with transparent or decorative straps.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Using a safety pin to attach a softie directly inside the garment, wearing a strapless bra with your usual prosthesis (providing your usual prosthesis is not too heavy for a strapless bra), wearing a bra with transparent or decorative straps.

Question (100 words): How can I cover my chest area if I want to wear a low neckline?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To cover your chest area while wearing a low neckline, you can try wearing a camisole or vest top underneath a V-necked top, using a camisole-style bra with lace between the cups, wearing a lightweight lacy or semi-transparent top over a low-necked item, using lingerie tape to attach clothing securely to the skin, or using a tie-in fabric panel that covers the mid-chest.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A camisole or vest top underneath a V-necked top so that it is visible across the ‘V’, a camisole-style bra, available from some specialist suppliers, made with lace inserted between the cups that will cover the cleavage area, a lightweight lacy or semi-transparent top worn over a low-necked item, to disguise the cleavage area while still allowing the clothing beneath to show through, using lingerie tape to attach clothing securely to the skin, a tie-in fabric panel that covers the mid-chest, so

Question (100 words): What options do I have for wearing clothes with low backs after surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): For wearing clothes with low backs after surgery, you can buy bra extenders that continue round your body and fasten lower down at the front, or bras with straps that can be crossed at the back, designed to not show when wearing tops with cut-away shoulders.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can buy bra extenders from specialist suppliers and some department stores. Instead of fastening at your back, these continue round your body and fasten lower down at the front to enable you to wear clothes with low backs. You can also buy bras with straps that can be crossed at the back, designed to not show when wearing tops with cut-away shoulders.

Question (100 words): Can I go without wearing a bra after breast surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, you can go without wearing a bra after breast surgery. Some women pin a softie into other underwear such as a vest top or camisole, use a stick-on prosthesis with clothing that has good in-built support, or wear pocketed clothing designed to be worn with a silicone prosthesis.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you prefer not to wear a bra, there are ways you can adjust your clothes to wear them with a prosthesis if you want to. Try things on first and see what works for you. Some women: pin a softie into other underwear such as a vest top or camisole, use a stick-on prosthesis with clothing that has good in-built support, wear pocketed clothing, available online and from some specialist shops (these clothes are usually designed to be worn with a silicone prosthesis).

Question (100 words): What are some options for sleepwear after breast surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): For sleepwear after breast surgery, you could consider wearing a ‘sleep bra’ or very soft, low-support bra with a softie, pocketed nightwear available online and from some specialist suppliers, or a camisole or nightdress with a softie pinned in place.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If it helps you feel more confident or comfortable, you may want to wear a prosthesis in bed. You could consider: a ‘sleep bra’ or very soft, low-support bra with a softie, pocketed nightwear, available online and from some specialist suppliers, a camisole or nightdress with a softie pinned in place.

Question (100 words): Can I wear a prosthesis when swimming?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, you can wear a prosthesis when swimming. Look for high-street swimwear with structure, usually provided by cups. You can adapt a high-street swimsuit by making your own pocket to hold a prosthesis in place. Ensure you rinse the prosthesis well afterwards to avoid damage from chlorine or salt water.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you want to wear a prosthesis when swimming, you can often find suitable swimwear in high-street shops. The top needs to be cut high enough over the breast area and under the arms to cover the prosthesis. It also needs to have some structure, which is usually provided by cups. If you choose to wear a bikini top, choose one that comes in bra cup sizes, has a full cup and a supportive underband. You could adapt a high-street swimsuit that has cups by making your own pocket to hold a prosthesis

Question (100 words): What type of swimwear is best for post-surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): For post-surgery, you may prefer to wear pocketed post-surgery swimwear, which can be found in high-street shops, large department stores, or from specialist suppliers. These come in one-piece costumes, two-piece bikinis, and tankinis. You can use a regular silicone prosthesis or a swim prosthesis in a post-surgery swimsuit.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may prefer to wear pocketed post-surgery swimwear. This type of swimwear can be found in some high-street shops, large department stores or from specialist suppliers. They come in one-piece costumes, two-piece bikinis and tankinis. You can use a regular silicone prosthesis or a swim prosthesis in a post-surgery swimsuit.

Question (100 words): Do I need to pay VAT on post-surgery swimwear?
Answer (Max 2000 words): No, you don’t need to pay VAT on post-surgery swimwear if you have had breast cancer surgery.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You don’t need to pay VAT on post-surgery swimwear if you have had breast cancer surgery (see the ‘Financial help’ section on page 11).

Question (100 words): Where can I find made-to-measure swimwear?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Made-to-measure swimwear is available from some companies, allowing you to choose the print and design for a swimsuit, tankini, or bikini.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Made-to-measure swimwear is available from some companies. This allows you to choose the print and design for a swimsuit, tankini or bikini.

Question (100 words): How can I become more confident about my body after breast surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Simple measures can help you become more confident about your body after breast surgery. This might include having a suitable prosthesis fitted, choosing an attractive, well-fitting bra, or making some adjustments to your clothes. Support groups and your breast care nurse can also provide additional support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Simple measures can help you become more confident about your body and how you look. This might include having a suitable prosthesis fitted, choosing an attractive, well-fitting bra, or making some adjustments to your clothes. Some areas have support groups, in person and online, where you can talk to other women and find out what has worked for them. Your breast care nurse will also be able to tell you about local support.

Question (100 words): How can I get in touch with Breast Cancer Now for support?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can get in touch with Breast Cancer Now by calling their Helpline on 0808 800 6000 to speak to a specialist nurse or trained staff, or by visiting their website at breastcancernow.org for more information and services.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can call our Helpline to speak to one of our specialist nurses or trained staff on 0808 800 6000. Our Someone Like Me service can put you in contact by phone or email with someone else who has been affected by breast cancer and who’s been trained to help.

Question (100 words): What are some suppliers of post-surgery bras and prostheses?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Some suppliers of post-surgery bras and prostheses include Amoena, Boost, The Bra Sisters, Eloise, Knitted Knockers UK, Marks and Spencer, Nicola Jane, Primark, Skarlette Lingerie, Silima, Trulife, and Womanzone.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Amoena, Boost, The Bra Sisters, Eloise, Knitted Knockers UK, Marks and Spencer, Nicola Jane, Primark, Skarlette Lingerie, Silima, Trulife, Womanzone.

Question (100 words): How can I find more information about bras, prostheses, and clothes after breast surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can find more information about bras, prostheses, and clothes after breast surgery by visiting the Breast Cancer Now website at breastcancernow.org or by calling their Helpline on 0808 800 6000.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Or you can call our Helpline on 0808 800 6000 to find out what may be available near you.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I want to wear a bikini after breast surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you want to wear a bikini after breast surgery, choose one that comes in bra cup sizes, has a full cup, and a supportive underband. You can also adapt a high-street swimsuit by making your own pocket to hold a prosthesis in place.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you choose to wear a bikini top, choose one that comes in bra cup sizes, has a full cup and a supportive underband. You could adapt a high-street swimsuit that has cups by making your own pocket to hold a prosthesis in place (see ‘Bra pockets’ on page 10).

Question (100 words): What are some tips for adjusting my clothes after breast surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Some tips for adjusting your clothes after breast surgery include trying different options to see what works best for you, such as pinning a softie into other underwear, using a stick-on prosthesis with supportive clothing, or wearing pocketed clothing designed for prostheses.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Try things on first and see what works for you. Some women: pin a softie into other underwear such as a vest top or camisole, use a stick-on prosthesis with clothing that has good in-built support, wear pocketed clothing, available online and from some specialist shops (these clothes are usually designed to be worn with a silicone prosthesis).

Question (100 words): What are some options for bras after breast surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Some options for bras after breast surgery include post-surgery bras available from specialist suppliers or high-street shops, bras with transparent or decorative straps, and bras with bra extenders or crossed straps for low backs.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Post-surgery bras are available from specialist suppliers or many high-street shops, which can often be a cheaper option.

Question (100 words): How can I find local support groups for breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can find local support groups for breast cancer by contacting your breast care nurse, who can provide information about available support, or by visiting the Breast Cancer Now website for a list of support services.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some areas have support groups, in person and online, where you can talk to other women and find out what has worked for them. Your breast care nurse will also be able to tell you about local support.

Question (100 words): What should I consider when choosing swimwear after breast surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): When choosing swimwear after breast surgery, consider the cut, structure, and support of the swimsuit. Look for options that cover the breast area and under the arms, and have some structure, usually provided by cups. You can also adapt high-street swimwear by making your own pocket for a prosthesis.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The top needs to be cut high enough over the breast area and under the arms to cover the prosthesis. It also needs to have some structure, which is usually provided by cups. If you choose to wear a bikini top, choose one that comes in bra cup sizes, has a full cup and a supportive underband. You could adapt a high-street swimsuit that has cups by making your own pocket to hold a prosthesis in place (see ‘Bra pockets’ on page 10).

Question (100 words): What are some ways to feel more comfortable and confident after breast surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Some ways to feel more comfortable and confident after breast surgery include having a suitable prosthesis fitted, choosing an attractive, well-fitting bra, making adjustments to your clothes, and seeking support from local groups or your breast care nurse.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Simple measures can help you become more confident about your body and how you look. This might include having a suitable prosthesis fitted, choosing an attractive, well-fitting bra, or making some adjustments to your clothes. Some areas have support groups, in person and online, where you can talk to other women and find out what has worked for them. Your breast care nurse will also be able to tell you about local support.

Question (100 words): How can I get a post-surgery bra fitting?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can get a post-surgery bra fitting from specialist suppliers or from stores like Marks and Spencer, which provide post-surgery bra fitting services both online and in-store.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Marks and Spencer: post-surgery bras and non-wired bras, bra accessories and post-surgery swimwear. They also provide post-surgery bra fitting services both online and instore.

Question (100 words): What are the common symptoms of lobular breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common symptoms of lobular breast cancer include changes in breast size and shape, changes in skin texture, and nipple changes. Unlike other types of breast cancer, a lump may not always be felt.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The way lobular breast cancer grows means a lump can’t always be felt. Other symptoms can include nipple changes, a change in skin texture, and changes in breast size and shape.

Question (100 words): What is DIEP flap breast reconstruction surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): DIEP flap breast reconstruction surgery involves taking a flap of skin and fat from the lower tummy (abdomen) to create a new breast shape after a mastectomy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: This involves taking a flap of skin and fat from the lower tummy (abdomen) to create a new breast shape.

Question (100 words): How can I decide which breast reconstruction option is best for me?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Attending hospital Show and Tell events, speaking with breast care nurses, and consulting with Someone Like Me volunteers can help you make an informed decision about breast reconstruction options.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Tess’ breast care nurse invited her to a hospital Show and Tell event run by the charity Restore, where women who’d had breast cancer surgery spoke about their experiences and modelled their bodies and scars.

Question (100 words): What mental health support is available after breast cancer surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Mental health support after breast cancer surgery can include prescribed antidepressants, sessions with a psychologist, and engaging in supportive communities.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: She was prescribed the antidepressant sertraline to help manage her anxiety. She also saw a psychologist through her hospital.

Question (100 words): What lifestyle changes can help with recovery after breast cancer surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Lifestyle changes such as regular exercise, meditation, cutting out alcohol, and eating healthier foods can aid recovery after breast cancer surgery.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Tess exercises regularly – she enjoys Pilates, BODYPUMP and walking with friends, and finds meditation helpful.

Question (100 words): How can I get involved in support groups for younger women with breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can join Younger Women Together in-person events organized by Breast Cancer Now to meet, talk, and share experiences with other women your age.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: ARE YOU AGED 18 TO 45? THEN JOIN OUR YOUNGER WOMEN TOGETHER IN-PERSON EVENTS

Question (100 words): What research is being done to improve breast screening accessibility?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Researchers are investigating ways to reduce pain during mammograms and developing robotic assistants to support posture during screening to make the process more comfortable and accessible.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Dr Judith Offman is investigating the experiences of women from all ethnic backgrounds to find ways to reduce pain. Jihong, a roboticist at the University of York, is creating a robotic assistant to support posture during screening.

Question (100 words): What challenges do people with secondary breast cancer face?
Answer (Max 2000 words): People with secondary breast cancer face challenges related to poor physical and emotional wellbeing, often feeling isolated or excluded, and there is a lack of accurate data on their experiences.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: People with secondary breast cancer face many challenges related to poor physical and emotional wellbeing that can lead to them feeling isolated or excluded.

Question (100 words): How can I cope with skin changes during radiotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Coping with skin changes during radiotherapy involves understanding the changes, using recommended skincare products, and seeking advice from healthcare professionals.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Coping with radiotherapy skin changes

Question (100 words): What is lymphoedema and how is it managed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Lymphoedema is a condition characterized by swelling due to a build-up of lymph fluid. It is managed through specialized exercises, compression garments, and sometimes manual lymphatic drainage.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: "I didn’t know what it was until I got it" – living with lymphoedema

Question (100 words): What are the benefits of journaling for wellbeing?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Journaling can help improve mental wellbeing by providing an outlet for expressing emotions, tracking progress, and reflecting on experiences.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Words and wellbeing

Question (100 words): How can I find more information about breast cancer surgery and reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can find more information about breast cancer surgery, breast reconstruction, and support services on the Breast Cancer Now website.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can also find more information about breast cancer surgery, breast reconstruction and our Someone Like Me service on our website breastcancernow.org

Question (100 words): What is the MammoBot and how does it help with breast screening?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The MammoBot is a device developed by Dr. Jihong Zhu to gently support and position people accurately during their mammogram, making the process more comfortable for those with limited mobility.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Jihong and his team are developing a device called the MammoBot to gently support and position people accurately during their scan.

Question (100 words): How can I get involved in modeling my scars to help others with breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can get involved by volunteering with organizations like Restore, which host Show and Tell events where women share their experiences and model their scars and reconstructed breasts.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Since recovering from surgery, Tess has modelled with Restore, sharing her experience with women awaiting mastectomies and showing them her scars and reconstructed breast.

Question (100 words): What topics are covered in the Younger Women Together events?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The events cover topics like menopausal symptoms, sexuality and intimacy, relationships, and coping with change and uncertainty, with the help of experts and specialists.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: We look at topics like menopausal symptoms, sexuality and intimacy, relationships and coping with change and uncertainty, all with the help of experts and specialists.

Question (100 words): What is the goal of the IPHEW funding round?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The goal of the IPHEW funding round is to tackle inequalities in breast cancer care by improving access to screening and better supporting people with secondary breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Our latest funding round, called Improving Public Health Equity and Wellbeing (IPHEW), is all about tackling the inequalities in breast cancer care.

Question (100 words): How can I support breast cancer research and fundraising efforts?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can support breast cancer research and fundraising efforts by participating in events like Asda Tickled Pink, which raises funds and awareness for breast cancer support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Fundraising - How Asda Tickled Pink is opening doors to breast cancer support

Question (100 words): What is the significance of Dr. Charlene McShane's research on secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Dr. Charlene McShane's research aims to develop a deeper understanding of the inequalities faced by people with secondary breast cancer and to improve their treatment and wellbeing.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Dr Charlene McShane is working closely with people living with secondary breast cancer to develop a deeper and wider understanding of what inequalities people diagnosed with secondary breast cancer face in Northern Ireland.

Question (100 words): How can I find more information about the benefits of journaling for wellbeing?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can find more information about the benefits of journaling for wellbeing in the feature article on Words and Wellbeing in the magazine.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Words and wellbeing

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience severe side effects from my breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience severe side effects from your breast cancer treatment, contact your healthcare team immediately for advice and support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Contact your healthcare team immediately for advice and support.

Question (100 words): What is lymphoedema and what causes it?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Lymphoedema is swelling caused by a build-up of fluid in the body’s tissues. It can happen after surgery or radiotherapy to the lymph nodes under the arm. It usually affects the hand or arm on the side you had treatment, also known as your at-risk side, but it can also affect the breast, chest, armpit or shoulder.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Lymphoedema is swelling caused by a build-up of fluid in the body’s tissues. It can happen after surgery or radiotherapy to the lymph nodes under the arm.

Question (100 words): How was Moke diagnosed with lymphoedema?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Moke was diagnosed with lymphoedema after noticing she couldn’t put her wristwatch on. She was referred to a specialist clinic who confirmed the diagnosis by measuring her wrist and finding it was bigger than the other one.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: She was referred to a specialist clinic who diagnosed her with lymphoedema in her hand and arm on her left side.

Question (100 words): What are some ways to reduce the risk of developing lymphoedema?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To reduce your risk of lymphoedema, look after your skin on the side you’ve had treatment, watch out for signs of infection, maintain a healthy body weight, and use your at-risk arm as much as possible.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: We don’t know why some people develop lymphoedema after breast cancer treatment and some don’t, but there are things you can do to reduce your risk.

Question (100 words): How can lymphoedema be managed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Although there’s no cure for lymphoedema, it can be managed using self-care techniques such as exercises, wearing compression garments, and self-massage techniques.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Although there’s no cure for lymphoedema, it can be managed using self-care techniques.

Question (100 words): What kind of compression garments are used for lymphoedema?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Compression garments for lymphoedema usually include tight sleeves or gloves fitted by a specialist to help move and drain fluid from the affected area.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Wearing compression garments (usually tight sleeves or gloves fitted by a specialist) can help move and drain fluid from the affected area.

Question (100 words): How did Moke manage her lymphoedema?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Moke manages her lymphoedema by wearing a compression sleeve and glove almost every day, and by massaging her hand if she doesn’t wear the compression garments.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: "I have a compression sleeve and glove now, which I wear almost every day," Moke explains. "If I don’t wear it for a day, I’m always massaging my hand."

Question (100 words): How does lymphoedema affect daily life?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Lymphoedema can affect daily life in various ways, such as changing wardrobe choices and requiring regular use of compression garments. However, with proper management, it doesn’t have to stop you from living life to the full.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: "It has changed my life in terms of my wardrobe – I can’t wear clothes with long sleeves anymore. But I don’t hide my lymphoedema."

Question (100 words): What is journalling and how can it help with breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Journalling is the practice of writing down your thoughts and feelings. It can help reduce stress levels, make you feel more resilient, and improve mental health. For breast cancer patients, it can be a great outlet for reflecting on their experiences and feelings.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Journalling can be a useful wellbeing tool for people going through cancer treatment. It can help reduce stress levels, make you feel more resilient and improve mental health.

Question (100 words): How did Alice-May Purkiss use journalling to cope with her breast cancer diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Alice-May Purkiss used journalling, blogging, and other creative outlets to process and better understand her breast cancer experience. She found it helpful for her emotional wellbeing and now works as a mindset and wellbeing coach.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Through writing, blogging and other creative outlets, Alice began to process and better understand her experience.

Question (100 words): What are some tips for getting started with journalling?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Some tips for getting started with journalling include using prompts, trying different forms of writing or art, not overthinking it, and making it a daily habit by stacking it with another activity.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Alice recommends starting small and setting a 2-minute timer. "Don’t give it too much thought, just see what comes up for you and get it on the page," she says.

Question (100 words): How did Rachel navigate her secondary breast cancer diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Rachel navigated her secondary breast cancer diagnosis by staying connected to the present, using techniques like mindfulness, breathwork, and spending time in nature. She also found joy in crafting and supporting others in online groups.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Rachel uses a range of techniques to connect her to the present while she travels the UK’s waterways with her husband on the narrowboat they now call home.

Question (100 words): What is the difference in Rachel's approach to treatment for primary vs. secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): For primary breast cancer, Rachel viewed treatment as a triathlon with a goal of finishing. For secondary breast cancer, she focuses on how she feels day to day rather than a final treatment date.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: "Treatment for primary breast cancer was like doing a triathlon, with stages to get through and a goal of the final treatment date to focus on. But treatment doesn’t finish in the same way when you have secondary breast cancer, so I’ve found it’s more important to focus on how you feel day to day."

Question (100 words): What activities does Rachel engage in to stay connected to the present?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Rachel engages in activities like walking, calling friends, practicing mindfulness and breathwork, participating in sound baths, and crafting with recycled materials.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: "I’m fortunate we live on a narrowboat because we’re always surrounded by nature, which I find very grounding. Things like going for a walk or calling a friend can really help too," Rachel explains.

Question (100 words): How does Rachel support others with secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Rachel supports others with secondary breast cancer by being active in online groups, sharing her experiences, and giving hope to those newly diagnosed.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Rachel is also active in online groups for people with secondary breast cancer, where she particularly enjoys supporting and giving hope to people newly diagnosed.

Question (100 words): What is the significance of Rachel's narrowboat named BoobyDo?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The narrowboat named BoobyDo is significant as it symbolizes Rachel's journey with breast cancer. It was a source of distraction and a way to raise funds for breast cancer support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: "We named it BoobyDo – a reference to the boobs making us do it!" Rachel explains.

Question (100 words): What role did Rachel's job as a horticulture teacher play in her cancer journey?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Rachel's job as a horticulture teacher provided a much-needed distraction during her cancer treatment. The support from her students, including shaving their hair in solidarity, was heartwarming.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: "I was teaching horticulture in a prison at the time, and that proved to be a much-needed distraction," she recalls.

Question (100 words): How does Rachel view her treatment for secondary breast cancer compared to primary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Rachel views her treatment for secondary breast cancer as an ongoing process rather than a finite goal, unlike her treatment for primary breast cancer which had a clear end date.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: "Treatment for primary breast cancer was like doing a triathlon, with stages to get through and a goal of the final treatment date to focus on. But treatment doesn’t finish in the same way when you have secondary breast cancer, so I’ve found it’s more important to focus on how you feel day to day."

Question (100 words): What techniques does Rachel use to stay grounded and present?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Rachel uses techniques such as spending time in nature, practicing mindfulness and breathwork, participating in sound baths, and engaging in crafting to stay grounded and present.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: "I’m fortunate we live on a narrowboat because we’re always surrounded by nature, which I find very grounding. Things like going for a walk or calling a friend can really help too," Rachel explains.

Question (100 words): How does Rachel contribute to the secondary breast cancer community?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Rachel contributes to the secondary breast cancer community by being active in online support groups, sharing her experiences, and providing hope and support to those newly diagnosed.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Rachel is also active in online groups for people with secondary breast cancer, where she particularly enjoys supporting and giving hope to people newly diagnosed.

Question (100 words): What message does Rachel want to convey about living with secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Rachel wants to convey that it is possible to live well with secondary breast cancer and that having cancer does not define her life. She emphasizes the importance of focusing on the present and not putting life on hold.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: "I want to show that you can live well with secondary breast cancer and that, although I have cancer, cancer doesn’t have me."

Question (100 words): Where can I find support after my breast cancer treatment ends?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can join Breast Cancer Now’s Moving Forward courses, which are designed for people who have completed hospital-based treatment for primary breast cancer. Additionally, the Someone Like Me service can match you with a trained volunteer who has had a similar experience. Their helpline is also available for support and information.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Many people are surprised by how emotional they feel when their breast cancer treatment ends. Adapting to life after treatment can be difficult – often you still need support and information.

Question (100 words): How can I manage the side effects of hormone therapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Menopausal symptoms like hot flushes, brain fog, and joint pain are common side effects of hormone therapy. Some women find these side effects ease over time, but if they persist, you should talk to your treatment team. They may suggest switching to a different type of hormone therapy or refer you to a menopause clinic for specialist advice.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Menopausal symptoms are common side effects of hormone therapy. Some women find the side effects ease as their body gets used to the medication, but for some they can persist and impact on quality of life.

Question (100 words): What is scalp cooling and how does it work during chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Scalp cooling is a method used to reduce hair loss during chemotherapy. It involves wearing a special cold cap while receiving chemotherapy and for a little while before and after treatment. The cold cap reduces blood flow to the hair follicles, which reduces the amount of chemotherapy drug that can reach them. It’s not available at all hospitals, so you should ask your treatment team if it’s an option for you.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Scalp cooling may stop or reduce hair loss during chemotherapy, but how well it works varies from person to person.

Question (100 words): Can I exercise if I have secondary breast cancer in the bone?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, physical activity can help strengthen bones and reduce pain. It’s important to choose low-impact exercises and avoid contact sports. Walking, swimming, and riding a stationary bike are great choices. If your cancer has spread to the spine, avoid movements like twisting or large forward bends of the spine. Check with your treatment team about the best type of exercise for your individual situation.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Physical activity can help strengthen bones and reduce pain, as well as boosting your energy levels and improving quality of life.

Question (100 words): What does electrochemotherapy involve for treating skin metastases?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Electrochemotherapy combines a low dose of a chemotherapy drug with electrical impulses to help with the symptoms of skin metastases, including bleeding, broken skin, and pain. The chemotherapy is usually given into a vein or directly into the area of cancer being treated. Electrical impulses are then given directly to the area using an electrode. The procedure usually takes about 30 minutes and is often done under general anaesthetic.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Electrochemotherapy combines a low dose of a chemotherapy drug with electrical impulses. It’s given to help with the symptoms of skin metastases, including bleeding, broken skin (ulceration) and pain.

Question (100 words): What are the common skin reactions from radiotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common skin reactions from radiotherapy include color changes, dryness, pain, itching, and blistering. These reactions are often at their worst 2 or 3 weeks after treatment ends but can happen sooner or later. It’s important to keep the treatment area moisturized and avoid very hot or cold temperatures, sun exposure, and irritating chemicals like those in swimming pools.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Skin reactions are the most common side effect of radiotherapy – a treatment that uses high-energy x-rays to destroy cancer cells.

Question (100 words): How does skin tone affect radiotherapy skin reactions?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your natural skin tone can significantly affect how your skin reacts to radiotherapy. For people with white skin, the area may go pink or red and look like a tan towards the end of treatment. For people with brown or black skin, the area may become more pigmented and look darker, maroon, or purple.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: How your skin reacts to radiotherapy can vary significantly depending on your natural skin tone.

Question (100 words): What tips can help me take care of my skin during and after radiotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To take care of your skin during and after radiotherapy, wash the treated area gently with warm water, pat the skin dry with a soft towel, avoid very hot or cold temperatures, protect the area from the sun, and avoid clothes that may rub your skin. Use natural fibers like soft cotton for clothing and bras.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re having radiotherapy or have had it recently, these tips may help you take care of your skin: Washing the skin, Heat and cold, Sun protection, Swimming, Clothing, bras and prostheses.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience skin reactions from radiotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience skin reactions from radiotherapy, you should phone your therapeutic radiographers as soon as you see the reaction. They can provide help and advice. You don’t need to wait until your next appointment with your oncologist.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can phone your therapeutic radiographers as soon as you see the reaction, as we can help.

Question (100 words): What moisturiser should I use on the treated area after radiotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): It’s best to use a moisturiser that doesn’t contain perfume or metals and that you’ve used before without any reactions. There isn’t one specific moisturiser that’s better than any other. Some people use aloe vera-based gels, but they can dry the skin, so you may need a moisturiser as well.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It can be helpful to keep the treatment area moisturised by applying moisturiser at least 2 or 3 times a day.

Question (100 words): Can I use Sudocrem or talcum powder on the treated area during radiotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): No, you should not use Sudocrem or talcum powder on the treated area during radiotherapy and for at least 3 weeks after you’ve finished treatment. Sudocrem can actually make the skin reaction worse.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Naman also recommends not using Sudocrem or talcum powder on the treated area during radiotherapy and for at least 3 weeks after you’ve finished treatment.

Question (100 words): What is the ‘Eyes Down, Check Up’ campaign?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The ‘Eyes Down, Check Up’ campaign is a partnership between Breast Cancer Now and tombola, Britain’s leading bingo brand. The campaign aims to raise awareness of breast cancer and encourage more people to regularly check their breasts. 50% of all ticket sales from special ‘Bingo Against Breast Cancer’ games are donated to Breast Cancer Now.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Our ‘Eyes Down, Check Up’ campaign aims to encourage 1 million people to regularly check their breasts and raise up to £1 million to support our work.

Question (100 words): How are researchers improving post-treatment bras for breast cancer patients?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Researchers at the University of Portsmouth are using sensors and 3D scanning to study how the biomechanics of breasts change during treatment. This technology helps them understand what women need from post-treatment bras, aiming to create more comfortable and supportive bras that can also help women return to exercise after treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The researchers hope this will lead to more comfortable and supportive bras that can also help women return to exercise after treatment.

Question (100 words): Why is breast screening uptake in Wales a concern?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast screening uptake in Wales dropped to 69.5% between 2022 and 2023, below the 70% minimum standard and the 80% target. It’s estimated that 154 more breast cancers would have been detected if the target was met. Breast Cancer Now is calling on the government to improve uptake and address inequalities that make it difficult for people to access breast screening.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s estimated that 154 more breast cancers would have been detected if the target was met. That’s why we’re calling on the government to improve uptake and address inequalities that make it difficult for people to access breast screening.

Question (100 words): How can Asda Tickled Pink help me access breast cancer support services?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Asda Tickled Pink has raised £100 million over 29 years for breast cancer charities, powering things like Breast Cancer Now’s Access Fund. The Access Fund helps people get to support services when costs get in the way, covering travel, accommodation, and other expenses.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Asda Tickled Pink has already raised £100 million over 29 years for breast cancer charities. The money it’s raised powers things like our life-changing Access Fund.

Question (100 words): What is the Access Fund and how can it help me?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The Access Fund, funded by Asda Tickled Pink, helps people get to Breast Cancer Now’s support services when costs get in the way. It covers travel, accommodation, and other expenses, ensuring that financial barriers do not prevent you from accessing the support you need.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Have you heard of our Access Fund? Funded by Asda Tickled Pink, the Access Fund helps people get to our support services when costs get in the way.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I feel low after my breast cancer treatment ends?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Feeling low after treatment ends is common. You can seek support through Breast Cancer Now’s Moving Forward courses, which provide tools to adjust to life beyond breast cancer. Additionally, the Someone Like Me service can match you with a trained volunteer for phone or email support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Many people are surprised by how emotional they feel when their breast cancer treatment ends.

Question (100 words): How can I manage joint pain caused by letrozole?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If letrozole is causing joint pain, talk to your treatment team. They can help you manage the symptoms and may suggest switching to a different type of hormone therapy if needed. They might also refer you to a menopause clinic for specialist advice.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: I’m taking letrozole and it’s causing my joints to ache. Is there anything I can do to relieve this?

Question (100 words): What exercises are safe for someone with secondary breast cancer in the bone?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Low-impact exercises like walking, swimming, and riding a stationary bike are safe and can help strengthen bones and reduce pain. Avoid contact sports and movements like twisting or large forward bends of the spine if your cancer has spread to the spine. Consult your treatment team for personalized advice.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Physical activity can help strengthen bones and reduce pain, as well as boosting your energy levels and improving quality of life.

Question (100 words): What resources are available to help me understand radiotherapy skin reactions?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Rad Chat (radchat.co.uk) is a platform founded by therapeutic radiographers Naman Julka-Anderson and Jo McNamara. It provides helpful resources and an award-winning podcast about radiotherapy. They also have an image library showing photos of radiotherapy skin reactions across different skin tones.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Naman and Jo founded a platform called Rad Chat (radchat.co.uk) in 2021 to help educate and inform people about radiotherapy.

Answer (Max 2000 words): You can subscribe to Vita magazine by visiting breastcancernow.org/vita, emailing vita@breastcancernow.org, or filling in a form and sending it to Freepost RUHG–GYAY–GHYK, Breast Cancer Now, 10 Whitechapel High Street, London E1 8QS.

Question (100 words): What is lobular neoplasia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Lobular neoplasia is a benign condition where there is an increase in the number of cells in the breast lobules and a change in their appearance and behavior. It is not cancerous.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Lobular neoplasia is a benign (not cancer) condition.

Question (100 words): What are the types of lobular neoplasia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The types of lobular neoplasia include atypical lobular hyperplasia (ALH), classical lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS), and pleomorphic lobular carcinoma in situ (PLCIS).
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There are different types of lobular neoplasia. These are: Atypical lobular hyperplasia (ALH), Classical lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS), Pleomorphic lobular carcinoma in situ (PLCIS).

Question (100 words): Who is most commonly affected by lobular neoplasia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Lobular neoplasia is most common in women aged 40–50, but it can be found in women of any age. It can also be found in men, though this is extremely rare.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Lobular neoplasia is most common in women aged 40–50, but it can be found in women of any age. It can be found in men, but this is extremely rare.

Question (100 words): How is lobular neoplasia diagnosed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Lobular neoplasia is usually diagnosed during a biopsy or other test being done for another breast change, such as when calcifications are detected on a mammogram.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Lobular neoplasia doesn’t usually cause any symptoms or show up on a mammogram. It’s usually found during a biopsy or other test being done for another breast change.

Question (100 words): Do I need treatment for atypical lobular hyperplasia (ALH) or classical lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS)?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You will not usually need treatment for ALH and classical LCIS, but your specialist may discuss treatment options with you based on current guidelines and your individual situation.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You will not usually need treatment for ALH and classical LCIS, but your specialist may discuss treatment options with you based on current guidelines and your individual situation.

Question (100 words): What treatment is recommended for pleomorphic lobular carcinoma in situ (PLCIS)?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If the biopsy shows PLCIS, your specialist may suggest an operation to remove the area with a margin of healthy breast tissue. Radiotherapy or hormone therapy may also be recommended.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If the biopsy shows PLCIS, your specialist may suggest an operation to remove the area with a margin (border) of healthy breast tissue.

Question (100 words): Does lobular neoplasia increase my risk of breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Most women with ALH or classical LCIS will never get breast cancer, but there is a slightly higher risk than the general population. Women with PLCIS are more at risk.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Most women diagnosed with ALH or classical LCIS will never get breast cancer. However, there is a slightly higher risk than the general population of developing breast cancer in either breast.

Question (100 words): What is hormone therapy and how does it relate to lobular neoplasia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Hormone therapy, such as tamoxifen, can reduce the risk of breast cancer developing in women with lobular neoplasia. However, the benefits need to be weighed against the risks and side effects.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Research has shown that treating women who have lobular neoplasia with tamoxifen (a hormone therapy treatment for breast cancer) can reduce the risk of breast cancer developing.

Question (100 words): What follow-up is recommended after a diagnosis of lobular neoplasia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your specialist will usually recommend having yearly follow-up mammograms for up to five years. Additional scans like an MRI may be recommended if you have other risk factors.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your specialist will usually recommend having yearly follow-up mammograms for up to five years.

Question (100 words): Is hormone replacement therapy (HRT) recommended after a diagnosis of lobular neoplasia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): HRT and oral contraceptives are not usually recommended for people after a diagnosis of lobular neoplasia.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: HRT and oral contraceptives are not usually recommended for people after a diagnosis of lobular neoplasia.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I find a new or unusual change in my breasts?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you find a new or unusual change in your breasts, you should check it with a GP. Regular breast checks are important for early detection.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: CHECK ANY NEW OR UNUSUAL CHANGES WITH A GP

Question (100 words): How often should I check my breasts for changes?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You should get into the habit of regularly checking your breasts. This helps in early detection of any changes.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Get into the habit of regularly checking your breasts.

Question (100 words): What emotions are common after a diagnosis of lobular neoplasia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common emotions after a diagnosis of lobular neoplasia include fear, shock, and anger. It’s normal to feel anxious about your future risk of breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Fear, shock and anger are all common feelings.

Question (100 words): Where can I get further support if I’m worried about lobular neoplasia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can call Breast Cancer Now’s free Helpline on 0808 800 6000 for support and to discuss any questions or worries you have about lobular neoplasia.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re worried about breast cancer or have a question about lobular neoplasia, our specialist team are ready to listen. Call our free Helpline on 0808 800 6000.

Question (100 words): What types of biopsies are used to diagnose lobular neoplasia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The types of biopsies used to diagnose lobular neoplasia include core biopsy, vacuum-assisted excision biopsy, and excision biopsy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Core biopsy, vacuum assisted excision biopsy, and excision biopsy are used to diagnose lobular neoplasia.

Question (100 words): What does 'in situ' mean in the context of lobular neoplasia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): 'In situ' means the changes only occur in the breast lobules and do not affect the surrounding breast tissue.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: ‘In situ’ means the changes only occur in the breast lobules and do not affect the surrounding breast tissue.

Question (100 words): Can men get lobular neoplasia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, men can get lobular neoplasia, though it is extremely rare.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It can be found in men, but this is extremely rare.

Question (100 words): What is the difference between ALH, LCIS, and PLCIS?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Atypical lobular hyperplasia (ALH) and classical lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) can look very similar under a microscope, while pleomorphic lobular carcinoma in situ (PLCIS) is made up of larger, more abnormal cells.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: ALH and classical LCIS can look very similar. PLCIS is made up of larger, more abnormal cells.

Question (100 words): What is the role of a mammogram or ultrasound in diagnosing lobular neoplasia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A mammogram or ultrasound scan may be used to help identify the area where lobular neoplasia is suspected, assisting in the biopsy procedure.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A mammogram or ultrasound scan may also be used to help identify the area.

Question (100 words): What factors determine my individual risk of developing breast cancer after lobular neoplasia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your individual risk depends on several factors, which your specialist can discuss with you, including the type of lobular neoplasia and other personal risk factors.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your individual risk depends on several factors, which your specialist can discuss with you.

Question (100 words): What should I bring to the pre-assessment clinic before my surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You should bring contact details for your GP, a relative or friend, details of any medication you are taking, any current or past conditions, treatments or operations, and any forms you have been sent to fill in. Also, inform them about any allergies you have.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You’ll need to bring the following information with you: • Contact details for your GP • Contact details for a relative or friend • Details of any medication you are taking, the dose and how long you have been taking it for • Details of any current or past conditions, treatments or operations• Any forms you have been sent to fill in and bring to the appointment You’ll also need to tell the person doing the assessment about any allergies you have.

Question (100 words): What tests will be done during the pre-assessment clinic?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The pre-assessment may include blood tests, an electrocardiogram (ECG), blood pressure, temperature, pulse, screening for MRSA, a chest x-ray, a urine test, and a COVID-19 lateral flow test.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The assessment may include: • Blood tests • Electrocardiogram (ECG): a test that measures the electrical activity of the heart and detects any possible problems • Blood pressure • Temperature • Pulse • Screening for MRSA (a type of bacterial infection) • Chest x-ray • Urine test • COVID-19 lateral flow test (your treatment team will decide the best time to do this)

Question (100 words): Should I stop taking my medication before surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you’re taking blood thinners (anti-coagulants) or hormone therapy, your doctors may ask you to stop them a few days before the operation. Always inform your treatment team if you're taking either of these.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Sometimes, if you’re taking blood thinners (anti-coagulants) or tablets to reduce the size of the cancer (hormone therapy), your doctors may ask you stop them a few days before the operation. If you're taking either of these, tell your treatment team as soon as you get your operation date.

Question (100 words): What kind of clothes should I wear to the hospital for my surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Choose loose-fitting, easy-to-remove nightwear that allows easy access to the breast or chest and armpit. Pyjamas or nightdresses that open fully down the front are most convenient.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If possible, choose loose-fitting nightwear that’s simple to put on and take off, and allows easy access to the breast or chest and armpit. This will help the nurse check your dressings after surgery. Pyjamas or nightdresses that open fully down the front are the most convenient as pulling clothing over your head can be difficult after surgery.

Question (100 words): What type of bra should I bring for after my surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Bring a supportive and comfortable bra, preferably a front-buttoning post-surgery bra or a crop top. Avoid underwired and tight bras until the area has healed.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: For women, it’s a good idea to bring a supportive and comfortable bra to wear after your operation. Your breast care team will advise you when you can start wearing it again. It may be more comfortable to wear a crop top or a front-buttoning post-surgery bra.

Question (100 words): Can I bring my own food and drinks to the hospital?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, you can usually take some of your own food and drinks into the hospital. However, let the ward staff know about any specific dietary needs you have.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can usually take some of your own food and drinks into hospital with you. Drinks and snacks are also available in most hospital shops. Most specific diets are catered for in hospitals but let the ward staff know your needs.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I feel anxious about the anaesthetic?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can ask your treatment team if a mild sedative can be prescribed to help you relax before the procedure.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re nervous about the anaesthetic, you can ask if a mild sedative can be prescribed to help relax you before the procedure.

Question (100 words): Will I need to stop smoking before my surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, if you smoke, you may be asked to cut down or stop smoking to help your recovery from the anaesthetic and surgery.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you smoke, you may be asked to cut down or stop smoking to help your recovery from the anaesthetic and surgery.

Question (100 words): What happens if I need to cancel my surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If your operation needs to be canceled due to unforeseen circumstances, your treatment team will discuss another date with you.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Rarely, it may be necessary to cancel your operation due to unforeseen circumstances. If this happens, your treatment team will discuss another date with you.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I have more questions about my surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): It’s best to speak to your breast care nurse. If you cannot do this, write your questions down and take them with you to ask your consultant on the day of your operation.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you still have questions about your operation, it’s best to speak to your breast care nurse. If you cannot do this for any reason, write your questions down and take them with you to ask your consultant on the day of your operation.

Question (100 words): Will I have to stay in the hospital after my surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Many people have day surgery and are discharged the same day. However, you may want to bring extra items in case you need to stay unexpectedly.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Many people have day surgery and are discharged to go home the same day as their operation. Even if this is the case, you may want to take some extra things in case you need to stay unexpectedly.

Question (100 words): What is prehabilitation and how can it help me?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Prehabilitation involves increasing mild forms of activity before surgery, such as walking, swimming, and cycling, which may help in the recovery period both physically and mentally.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Recent research has shown increasing mild forms of activity before surgery, such as walking, swimming and cycling, may help in the recovery period, both physically and mentally. You may hear this referred to as prehabilitation.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I have questions about preparing for surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You will usually be given a telephone number at your pre-assessment appointment that you can call if you have any questions about preparing for surgery or are unclear about any instructions.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have any questions about preparing for surgery or are unclear about any instructions you have been given (such as stopping eating and drinking), you will usually be given a telephone number at your pre-assessment appointment that you can call.

Question (100 words): What happens before my surgery on the day of the operation?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A doctor from the surgical team will talk to you about your operation and discuss what has been planned. You’ll also be asked for your written consent if you haven’t already signed it.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A doctor from the surgical team will talk to you about your operation and discuss what has been planned. Giving consent If you have not already signed a consent form, you’ll be asked for your written consent. This confirms that you understand the benefits and risks of your surgery, and what you are agreeing to.

Question (100 words): What preparations are made before the surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You’ll usually be asked to remove any nail varnish and makeup before surgery. The surgical team may use a marker pen to draw on your skin to mark the site of the operation.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You’ll usually be asked to remove any nail varnish and makeup before surgery. It’s common for the surgical team to use a marker pen to draw on your skin to mark the site of the operation.

Question (100 words): Will I be given any special stockings for my surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You might be given elasticated support (anti-embolism) stockings to wear during, and for a short time after, your operation to reduce the risk of harmful blood clots forming.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You might be given elasticated support (anti-embolism) stockings to wear during, and for a short time after, your operation. They reduce the risk of harmful blood clots forming.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I feel anxious before my surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your anaesthetist will usually visit you on the ward before your surgery. If you’re feeling anxious and would like some medication to relax you before the operation, this is the time to discuss it.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your anaesthetist (who will give you the anaesthetic), will also usually visit you on the ward before your surgery. If you’re feeling anxious and would like some medication to relax you before the operation, this is the time

Question (100 words): Can I bring electronic devices to the hospital?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, you may bring a mobile phone or a tablet. However, you may need to put it on silent and avoid using it if it could disturb other people.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may also want to bring a mobile phone or a tablet to listen to music or watch a film. If you do, take headphones so you don’t disturb others. In many cases you’ll be able to use your mobile phone but you may need to put it on silent and avoid using it if it could disturb other people.

Question (100 words): What should I avoid applying to my skin before and after surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Avoid using deodorant, talcum powder, or body lotion immediately before surgery. After the operation, do not apply these to the area until your wounds are fully healed.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may want to avoid using deodorant, talcum powder or body lotion immediately before surgery. After the operation, it’s important not to apply these to the area until your wounds are fully healed.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I need emotional support during this time?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can call the free confidential helpline on 0808 800 6000 to talk through any concerns you have. Additionally, the NHS website has a section called Every Mind Matters with tips to help improve your mental wellbeing.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can call our free confidential helpline on 0808 800 6000 to talk through any concerns you have. The NHS website (nhs.uk) has lots of information about mental health, including a section called Every Mind Matters which has tips to help improve your mental wellbeing.

Question (100 words): What should I do with my jewellery before surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Discuss with the staff whether it can be secured with tape or needs to be removed and possibly placed in the ward safe.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have any jewellery, the staff will discuss with you whether it can be secured with tape or will need to be removed before the operation and possibly placed in the ward safe.

Question (100 words): Do I need to remove my false teeth before surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, you’ll probably need to remove false teeth before going to the operating room.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have false teeth you’ll probably need to remove these before going to the operating room.

Question (100 words): Can I wear my glasses or hearing aid to the anaesthetic room?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You may be able to wear them to the anaesthetic room, but you’ll be asked to remove them there.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you wear glasses or use a hearing aid, you may be able to wear these to the anaesthetic room, where you’ll be asked to remove them.

Question (100 words): What happens when I arrive at the anaesthetic room?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The theatre checklist will be done again by the theatre staff, and you will be given a combination of drugs into a vein, including an anaesthetic, pain relief, and anti-sickness drugs.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You’ll be taken to the anaesthetic room where the theatre checklist will be done again, this time by the theatre staff. Next you will be given a combination of drugs into a vein. This will usually include an anaesthetic, pain relief and anti-sickness drugs.

Question (100 words): What checks are done before I go into the operating theatre?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The nursing staff will check your name band, any allergies, when you last ate and drank, that you have a theatre gown on, whether you have jewellery or body piercings, that you are not wearing any nail varnish or makeup, whether you have crowned, capped or false teeth, and whether you are wearing contact lenses.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Before going into the operating theatre for your surgery, the nursing staff will check: • Your name band • Whether you have any allergies • When you last ate and drank • That you have a theatre gown on • Whether you have jewellery or body piercings • That you are not wearing any nail varnish or makeup • Whether you have crowned, capped or false teeth • Whether you are wearing contact lenses

Question (100 words): How will I feel when I wake up from the anaesthetic?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Some people wake up quickly, while others may feel very sleepy for several hours. You may have an oxygen mask or nasal cannula, a blood pressure cuff, and a device to check your oxygen level.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some people wake up quickly from the anaesthetic while others can feel very sleepy for several hours afterwards. While you’re waking up you may be wearing an oxygen mask or nasal cannula (short, soft-tipped tubes in the nostrils) to give you extra oxygen. You may have a blood pressure cuff on your arm and a small device clipped to your finger so your blood pressure, pulse and oxygen level in your blood can be checked.

Question (100 words): When can I start drinking after my operation?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can start drinking water when you feel able. Start with a few sips and gradually drink more. Once you’re drinking without any problems, you can then usually start eating.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: When you feel able, you can drink some water. The staff on the ward will advise you about this. It’s best to start by taking a few sips and gradually drink more. Once you’re drinking without any problems, you can then usually start eating.

Question (100 words): When can I get out of bed after surgery?
