Answer (Max 2000 words): You’ll be encouraged to get out of bed soon after surgery once you feel able. The nursing staff will advise you on whether you should call for help and how far you should walk.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You’ll be encouraged to get out of bed soon after surgery once you feel able. People can feel dizzy immediately after their operation because they may have lost some blood or because their blood pressure is low. The nursing staff will advise you on whether you should call for help if you need to get out of bed and how far you should walk.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I have wound drains after surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You may have wound drains inserted to drain blood and fluid from the wound. You can walk around with them. They will stay in for up to a few weeks and be removed by a member of the treatment team when drainage is minimal.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may have wound drains inserted during the operation. These are tubes that drain blood and fluid from the wound into a bottle or small bag. These drains will stay in for up to a few weeks, depending on the type of surgery, and will be removed by a member of the treatment team as soon as the drainage is minimal.

Question (100 words): How should I care for my dressings after surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After surgery, you will have an adhesive dressing applied to your wound. Let your treatment team know if you have any allergies to certain dressings or if your dressing causes a skin reaction. Your treatment team should tell you how to care for your dressings.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: After your surgery you will have an adhesive dressing applied to your wound. Let your treatment team know if you have any allergies to certain dressings or if your dressing causes a skin reaction. Your treatment team should tell you how to care for your dressings.

Question (100 words): What types of pain relief are available after surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Pain relief can be given as tablets, suppositories, injections, or through a PCA (patient-controlled analgesia) pump. It’s important to take it as prescribed.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Pain relief can be given as: • Tablets • Suppositories: waxy pellets placed into your rectum (back passage) • Injections You’ll be given pain relief according to your needs. It’s important to take it as prescribed.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I feel sick after surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Tell the nursing staff if you feel sick. Anti-sickness drugs (anti-emetics) given as a tablet or injection can help relieve nausea.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Anti-sickness drugs (anti-emetics) given as a tablet or injection can help relieve nausea, so tell the nursing staff if you feel sick.

Question (100 words): What is a seroma and what should I do if I develop one?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A seroma is a collection of fluid that can develop after surgery. If it causes discomfort or doesn’t go away, your specialist or breast care nurse may decide to draw off the fluid using a syringe and needle.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: After surgery some people develop a collection of fluid called a seroma. This normally occurs under the arm or in the breast or chest wall and is usually reabsorbed by the body over time. If the seroma causes discomfort or doesn’t reduce or go away, your specialist or breast care nurse may decide to draw off (aspirate) the fluid using a syringe and needle.

Question (100 words): What are the signs of a wound infection and what should I do if I suspect one?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Signs of a wound infection include tenderness, swelling, warmth, redness, fluid discharge, and feeling generally unwell with a raised temperature. Contact your GP, breast care nurse, or specialist straight away if you suspect an infection.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Any of the following symptoms could mean you have a wound infection: • The wound feels tender, swollen or warm to touch • Redness in the area • Fluid (discharge) from the wound • Feeling generally unwell with a raised temperature Contact your GP, breast care nurse or specialist straight away if you think you may have a wound infection.

Question (100 words): What is a haematoma and how is it treated?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A haematoma is when blood collects in the tissues surrounding the wound, causing swelling, discomfort, and hardness. It will eventually be reabsorbed by the body, but a very large haematoma may need to be removed by a surgeon.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Occasionally blood collects in the tissues surrounding the wound causing swelling, discomfort and hardness. This is called a haematoma. The blood will eventually be reabsorbed by the body but this can take a few weeks. If a very large haematoma develops after your surgery, your surgeon may suggest removing it by drawing the blood off with a needle and syringe. Occasionally, a small operation is needed to remove it.

Question (100 words): What changes in sensation can I expect after surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You may experience pins and needles, burning, numbness, or darting sensations in the breast area and down the arm on the operated side. These symptoms are usually temporary and improve with time.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some people experience pins and needles, burning, numbness or darting sensations in the breast area and down the arm on the operated side. These symptoms are quite common and may last for a few weeks or even months.

Question (100 words): What should I know about my scars after surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your surgery will leave some type of scar. Initially, the scar may feel uneven, tight, and tender, and may be red but will fade over time. Your treatment team will advise you when you can start moisturising your scars.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Whatever breast surgery you have will leave some type of scar. Looking at and feeling the scar for the first time can be difficult. At first your scar will feel uneven to the touch and may feel tight and tender. Scars are often initially red but will fade and become less obvious over time. Your treatment team should be able to tell you when you can start moisturising your scars to help them to heal.

Question (100 words): Why might my shoulder feel stiff after surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your arm and shoulder on the operated side may feel stiff and sore for some weeks. Your breast care nurse or physiotherapist will give you exercises to help regain movement.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your arm and shoulder on the operated side may feel stiff and sore for some weeks. Your breast care nurse or physiotherapist will give you some gentle exercises to help you get back the range of movement you had before your surgery.

Question (100 words): What is cording and how is it treated?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Cording is a tight ‘cord’ of tissue under the skin that can cause pain and restrict arm movement. It can be treated with stretching, massaging, and physiotherapy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: After surgery, some people develop a tight ‘cord’ of tissue under the skin, causing pain and restricting arm movement. The cord is not always visible, but can usually be felt. This cord starts in the armpit and can vary in length. It may just be in the armpit, or may travel down to the elbow or wrist. This ‘cording’ is also known as axillary web syndrome. Stretching and massaging the cord can improve your symptoms and you may need physiotherapy to help with this.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice discolouration in my breast after a sentinel lymph node biopsy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you have a sentinel lymph node biopsy including the use of radioactive dye, your breast may be discoloured with a blue or grey–black tinge. This is temporary and usually fades slowly.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have a sentinel lymph node biopsy including the use of radioactive dye, your breast may be discoloured and your skin may have a blue or grey–black tinge, depending on the dye used. This is temporary and usually fades slowly, though can sometimes take several months to go completely.

Question (100 words): What is lymphoedema and what causes it?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Lymphoedema is swelling of the arm, hand, breast, or chest area caused by a build-up of lymph fluid in the surface tissues. It can occur due to damage to the lymphatic system, often as a result of surgery or radiotherapy to the lymph nodes under the arm and surrounding areas.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Lymphoedema is swelling of the arm, hand, breast or chest area caused by a build-up of lymph fluid in the surface tissues of the body. It can occur as a result of damage to the lymphatic system, for example because of surgery or radiotherapy to the lymph nodes under the arm and surrounding area.

Question (100 words): How long will I stay in the hospital after breast surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The length of your hospital stay depends on the type of operation, your recovery, and the support available at home. Some patients are discharged within 23 hours, while others, especially those with reconstruction, may stay up to a week.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The length of your hospital stay will depend on what sort of operation you had, how you recover and the support available at home.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice swelling after my surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you notice any swelling in your breast/chest, arm, or hand that doesn’t settle after your surgery, inform your breast care nurse. They can refer you to a lymphoedema specialist for further advice and treatment if necessary.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you notice any swelling in your breast/chest, arm or hand that doesn’t settle after your surgery, tell your breast care nurse.

Question (100 words): When will my wound drains be removed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Wound drains are usually removed after about a week, even if they continue to drain, to reduce the risk of infection. They are taken out once they are draining only a small amount of fluid.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: They are usually removed after about a week, even if they continue to drain, to reduce the risk of infection.

Question (100 words): Can I bathe or shower after my surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can usually bathe and shower normally after surgery if you have a waterproof dressing covering the wound. Avoid using soaps or deodorant products on or around the area of your wound.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can usually bathe and shower normally after surgery if you have a waterproof dressing covering the wound. However, it’s advisable not to use any soaps or deodorant products on or around the area of your wound.

Question (100 words): When can I start doing arm and shoulder exercises after surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can usually continue gentle arm and shoulder exercises after surgery. More challenging exercises can be started once any drains have been removed. Your healthcare team will advise you on the best exercises and timing.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can usually move on to more challenging exercises once any drains have been removed. The nurses on the ward, your breast care nurse or a physiotherapist will advise you.

Question (100 words): How long will it take for my wound to heal completely?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your wound should heal within six to eight weeks. However, it may take several months for your affected breast or chest area and arm to feel ‘normal’ again, particularly if you had surgery under your arm.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your wound should heal within six to eight weeks. However, it may take several months for your affected breast or chest area and arm to feel ‘normal’ again, particularly if you had surgery under your arm.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience ongoing pain after surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Ongoing pain can be caused by nerve damage, particularly under the arm. Discuss this with your treatment team. They may refer you to a pain clinic or recommend pain management courses.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Ongoing (chronic) or persistent pain can be caused by damage to the nerves, particularly those under the arm. There are different ways of controlling this type of pain so discuss this with your treatment team.

Question (100 words): When can I return to driving after my surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your treatment team will advise you on when to return to driving. You need to feel comfortable and safe, and be confident in your ability to drive normally. A small cushion may help if the seatbelt is uncomfortable.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your treatment team will usually offer advice on when to return to driving. You need to feel comfortable and safe to do so, as well as being confident that you’re able to drive normally.

Question (100 words): When can I resume sexual activity after my surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can begin sexual activity whenever you feel comfortable. However, the areas around where you were operated on may continue to feel sore, and your arm may feel stiff for several weeks or longer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can begin sexual activity whenever you feel comfortable. However, after breast surgery the areas around where you were operated on may continue to feel sore and your arm may feel stiff for several weeks or longer.

Question (100 words): When can I return to work after my surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): When you return to work will depend on the type of job you have, the extent of your surgery, and any other treatments you will be having. Your specialist, breast care nurse, or GP can give you more specific advice.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: When you return to work will depend on the type of job you have, the extent of your surgery and any other treatments you will be having.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I feel extremely tired after surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Extreme tiredness (fatigue) is different from normal tiredness and may not be improved by sleep. Try to take things easy, pace yourself, and accept offers of help. Gentle exercise can also help improve fatigue.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Extreme tiredness (fatigue) is different from normal tiredness. It’s more extreme and unpredictable, and it’s often not improved by a good night’s sleep.

Question (100 words): What emotional support is available during my recovery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): People experience different emotions during recovery. It’s common to struggle at times. Discuss your feelings with your family, specialist, or breast care nurse. Counselling sessions and support groups are also available.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: But there may be times when you struggle to cope or feel on your own. This is common and there are people who can help you.

Question (100 words): What type of prosthesis will I be given after a mastectomy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Women who have had a mastectomy without reconstruction will be given a lightweight prosthesis (artificial breast form) to wear before leaving hospital. A permanent silicone prosthesis fitting will be arranged after the scar area is fully healed, usually after four to six weeks.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Women who have had a mastectomy without a reconstruction will be given a lightweight prosthesis (artificial breast form) to wear before leaving hospital.

Question (100 words): What should I eat to help my body recover after surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Eating well will help your body recover and your wound to heal. A healthy diet with foods you enjoy is best. Your healthcare team can provide more specific dietary advice if needed.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Eating well will also help your body recover and your wound to heal. A healthy diet with foods you enjoy is best.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I have concerns after leaving the hospital?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you have any concerns after leaving the hospital and before your follow-up appointment, contact your treatment team. They will provide you with contact details before you are discharged.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have any concerns after leaving hospital and before your follow-up appointment, get in touch with your treatment team.

Question (100 words): When will I receive my pathology results after surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your pathology results, which describe the results of any tests done on tissue removed during surgery, will be discussed at your follow-up appointment. For more detailed information, see the booklet Understanding your pathology results.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: At this appointment your surgeon will check your wound and discuss how the operation went, your pathology report (which describes the results of any tests done on tissue removed during surgery) and any further treatment that may be recommended.

Question (100 words): What support is available for people with breast cancer in my area?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Support services for people with breast cancer vary by area. Your breast care nurse can provide information about local support groups. You can also call Breast Cancer Now’s free helpline on 0808 800 6000 or visit their website for more information.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your breast care nurse may also be able to provide information about local support groups.

Question (100 words): What household chores can I do when I go home after surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You should be able to return to most of your normal activities within a few weeks of your operation. However, avoid lifting or carrying anything heavy until your wounds have fully healed. Take things gently at first.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You should be able to return to most of your normal activities within a few weeks of your operation. However, this will vary from person to person and will depend on the type of surgery you’ve had.

Question (100 words): Can I go on holiday or fly after my surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can go on holiday or fly after your surgery, but it’s important to check with your treatment team and insurance provider to ensure you are covered. Take any necessary precautions and rest as needed.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Can I go away on holiday? Is it OK to fly? What about travel insurance?

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice a lump in my breast?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you notice a lump in your breast, it's important to contact your healthcare provider immediately for an evaluation. Early detection is crucial for effective treatment. Your doctor may recommend a series of tests, including a mammogram, ultrasound, or biopsy, to determine the nature of the lump.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Whoever you are, and whatever your experience of breast cancer, our free services are here. Whether you’re worried about breast cancer, dealing with a diagnosis, working out life with or beyond treatment – or someone you love is.

Question (100 words): What types of surgery are available for breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The types of surgery for breast cancer include lumpectomy (removal of the tumor and a small margin of surrounding tissue) and mastectomy (removal of the entire breast). The choice of surgery depends on the size and location of the tumor, as well as your overall health and preferences.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your operation and recovery was written by Breast Cancer Now’s clinical specialists, and reviewed by healthcare professionals and people affected by breast cancer.

Question (100 words): How long does it take to recover from breast cancer surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Recovery time from breast cancer surgery varies depending on the type of surgery and individual health factors. Generally, it can take several weeks to a few months. Your healthcare team will provide specific guidelines and support to help you through the recovery process.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your operation and recovery was written by Breast Cancer Now’s clinical specialists, and reviewed by healthcare professionals and people affected by breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What are the common side effects of breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common side effects of breast cancer treatment include fatigue, nausea, hair loss, and changes in appetite. These side effects can vary depending on the type of treatment (surgery, chemotherapy, radiation therapy) and individual response. Your healthcare team can provide strategies to manage these side effects.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: We support over 290 of the brightest minds in breast cancer research. They’re discovering how to prevent breast cancer, live well with the disease, and save lives.

Question (100 words): How can I manage pain after breast cancer surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Pain management after breast cancer surgery typically involves a combination of medications prescribed by your doctor, such as painkillers and anti-inflammatory drugs. Additionally, techniques like rest, ice packs, and gentle exercises may be recommended to help alleviate discomfort.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your operation and recovery was written by Breast Cancer Now’s clinical specialists, and reviewed by healthcare professionals and people affected by breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What is the role of a drain after breast cancer surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A drain is often placed after breast cancer surgery to remove excess fluid that can accumulate in the surgical area. This helps reduce the risk of infection and promotes healing. Your healthcare team will provide instructions on how to care for the drain.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your operation and recovery was written by Breast Cancer Now’s clinical specialists, and reviewed by healthcare professionals and people affected by breast cancer.

Question (100 words): How often should I have follow-up appointments after treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Follow-up appointments after breast cancer treatment are typically scheduled every 3 to 6 months for the first few years, then less frequently. These appointments are crucial for monitoring your recovery and detecting any signs of recurrence early.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your operation and recovery was written by Breast Cancer Now’s clinical specialists, and reviewed by healthcare professionals and people affected by breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What lifestyle changes can help during breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Adopting a healthy lifestyle can support your body during breast cancer treatment. This includes maintaining a balanced diet, staying physically active within your limits, managing stress through relaxation techniques, and avoiding tobacco and excessive alcohol.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: We support over 290 of the brightest minds in breast cancer research. They’re discovering how to prevent breast cancer, live well with the disease, and save lives.

Question (100 words): Are there any dietary recommendations during breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): During breast cancer treatment, it's important to eat a well-balanced diet rich in fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and lean proteins. Staying hydrated and limiting processed foods and sugars can also support your overall health and energy levels.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: We support over 290 of the brightest minds in breast cancer research. They’re discovering how to prevent breast cancer, live well with the disease, and save lives.

Question (100 words): How can I get emotional support during my breast cancer journey?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Emotional support during breast cancer can be found through various resources, including support groups, counseling services, and helplines. Organizations like Breast Cancer Now offer free services and a community of people who understand your experience.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Life-changing support Whoever you are, and whatever your experience of breast cancer, our free services are here.

Question (100 words): What tests are done to diagnose breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common tests for diagnosing breast cancer include mammograms, ultrasounds, MRIs, and biopsies. These tests help determine the presence, size, and type of breast cancer, guiding the treatment plan.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your operation and recovery was written by Breast Cancer Now’s clinical specialists, and reviewed by healthcare professionals and people affected by breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What should I expect during a mammogram?
Answer (Max 2000 words): During a mammogram, your breast is compressed between two plates while an X-ray image is taken. This process may cause some discomfort but is quick and helps detect any abnormalities in the breast tissue.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your operation and recovery was written by Breast Cancer Now’s clinical specialists, and reviewed by healthcare professionals and people affected by breast cancer.

Question (100 words): How is a biopsy performed to confirm breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A biopsy involves removing a small sample of breast tissue, which is then examined under a microscope for cancer cells. This can be done using a fine needle, core needle, or surgical procedure, depending on the situation.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your operation and recovery was written by Breast Cancer Now’s clinical specialists, and reviewed by healthcare professionals and people affected by breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What are the red flags I should watch for after surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After surgery, watch for signs of infection such as increased redness, swelling, warmth, or discharge from the incision site. Also, be alert for unusual pain, fever, or any changes in your overall health that could indicate complications.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your operation and recovery was written by Breast Cancer Now’s clinical specialists, and reviewed by healthcare professionals and people affected by breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What medications might I need after breast cancer surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After breast cancer surgery, you may be prescribed pain medications, antibiotics to prevent infection, and possibly hormone therapy or other medications depending on the type of breast cancer and your treatment plan.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your operation and recovery was written by Breast Cancer Now’s clinical specialists, and reviewed by healthcare professionals and people affected by breast cancer.

Question (100 words): How can I prepare my home for recovery after breast cancer surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To prepare your home for recovery, ensure you have comfortable seating, easy access to essentials, and any necessary medical supplies. Arrange for help with daily tasks if needed and create a relaxing environment to support your healing process.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your operation and recovery was written by Breast Cancer Now’s clinical specialists, and reviewed by healthcare professionals and people affected by breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What are the benefits of joining a breast cancer support group?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Joining a breast cancer support group provides emotional support, shared experiences, and practical advice from others who understand your journey. It can help reduce feelings of isolation and offer encouragement throughout your treatment and recovery.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Life-changing support Whoever you are, and whatever your experience of breast cancer, our free services are here.

Question (100 words): How can I manage fatigue during breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Managing fatigue during breast cancer treatment involves pacing yourself, prioritizing rest, and incorporating gentle physical activity as tolerated. Communicating with your healthcare team about your symptoms can also lead to adjustments in your treatment plan if needed.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: We support over 290 of the brightest minds in breast cancer research. They’re discovering how to prevent breast cancer, live well with the disease, and save lives.

Question (100 words): What should I know about clinical trials for breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Clinical trials for breast cancer test new treatments and therapies. Participating in a trial can provide access to cutting-edge treatments, but it's important to understand the risks and benefits. Discuss with your healthcare team to determine if a trial is right for you.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: We support over 290 of the brightest minds in breast cancer research. They’re discovering how to prevent breast cancer, live well with the disease, and save lives.

Question (100 words): How can I access more information and support from Breast Cancer Now?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can access more information and support from Breast Cancer Now by visiting their website at breastcancernow.org, calling their helpline at 0808 800 6000, or emailing health-info@breastcancernow.org for additional resources and publications.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Information you can trust, support you can count on Whatever breast cancer brings, we’re here for you.

Question (100 words): What is periductal mastitis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Periductal mastitis is a benign breast condition where the tissue around the ducts becomes inflamed. It is not cancerous and can often be treated with antibiotics. It is more common in younger women and people who smoke.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Periductal mastitis is a benign (not cancer) breast condition. It can affect anyone but is most common in younger women and people who smoke.

Question (100 words): What are the symptoms of periductal mastitis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Symptoms include a tender, hot, or reddened breast, liquid discharge from the nipple (which may be bloody), a lump behind the nipple, inverted nipple, high temperature or fever, and less commonly, an abscess or fistula.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Symptoms of periductal mastitis can include: • A tender, hot or reddened breast (this can be harder to see if you have black or brown skin) • Liquid (discharge) from the nipple that may be bloody • A lump that can be felt behind the nipple • The nipple becoming pulled in (inverted) • A high temperature or fever

Question (100 words): Who is most commonly affected by periductal mastitis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Periductal mastitis is most common in younger women, though it can affect people of any age. It is also more common in people who smoke and those with nipple piercings.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Periductal mastitis can affect people of any age, though it’s much more common in younger women.

Question (100 words): How is periductal mastitis diagnosed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Diagnosis typically involves a breast examination followed by tests such as an ultrasound scan or fine needle aspiration (FNA) to take a sample of cells for analysis.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: At the breast clinic, most people have a breast examination followed by 1 or more of the following tests: • Ultrasound scan – using high-frequency sound waves to produce an image • Fine needle aspiration (FNA) – using a fine needle and syringe to take a sample of cells to be looked at under a microscope

Question (100 words): Can periductal mastitis be treated with antibiotics?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, most cases of periductal mastitis can be treated with antibiotics. However, it may sometimes clear up on its own without treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Most cases of periductal mastitis are treated with antibiotics. However, sometimes it clears up by itself without any treatment.

Question (100 words): What should I do if my symptoms do not improve with antibiotics?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If your symptoms do not improve, return to your GP for further evaluation. You may need additional treatment or a different approach.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s important to go back to your GP if: • Your symptoms do not improve • Your symptoms come back • You have any new symptoms

Question (100 words): What are the treatment options for abscesses and fistulas?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Treatment for abscesses and fistulas may involve aspirating the pus using a fine needle and syringe, sometimes under ultrasound guidance. In some cases, an opening may be made in the skin to drain the pus, which can be done under local or general anesthetic.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you develop an abscess or a fistula (see “Symptoms of periductal mastitis”), your specialist will decide the best way to treat it. This may involve using a fine needle and a syringe to draw off (aspirate) the pus, using an ultrasound scan for guidance.

Question (100 words): When might surgery be necessary for periductal mastitis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Surgery may be necessary if periductal mastitis does not improve with antibiotics or if it recurs. The operation is usually performed under general anesthetic and may require an overnight hospital stay.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If periductal mastitis doesn’t get better after taking antibiotics, or if it comes back, you may need to have an operation to remove the affected area. This operation is usually done under general anaesthetic, and you’ll be in hospital for the day or overnight.

Question (100 words): Will I have a scar after surgery for periductal mastitis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, the operation will leave a small scar, but it usually fades with time. Your nipple may also be less sensitive than before.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The operation will leave a small scar, but this usually fades with time. Your nipple may also be less sensitive than before.

Question (100 words): Does periductal mastitis increase my risk of breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): No, having periductal mastitis does not increase your risk of developing breast cancer. However, it’s important to report any changes in your breasts to your GP.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Having periductal mastitis does not increase your risk of developing breast cancer in the future.

Question (100 words): How can smoking affect periductal mastitis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Smoking increases the risk of periductal mastitis and can slow down the healing process after treatment. Stopping smoking can reduce the risk of recurrence.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: People who smoke have an increased risk of periductal mastitis because substances in cigarette smoke can damage the ducts behind the nipple. Smoking can also slow down the healing process after treatment.

Question (100 words): Can nipple piercings affect periductal mastitis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, nipple piercings can increase the chances of infection and may make periductal mastitis more difficult to treat.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Nipple piercings can increase the chances of infection and may make periductal mastitis more difficult to treat.

Question (100 words): Is periductal mastitis common in breastfeeding women?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Mastitis is common in breastfeeding women, but this is usually called lactational mastitis and is different from periductal mastitis.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Mastitis is also common in people who are breastfeeding or have recently given birth. This type of mastitis is usually called lactational mastitis and is different from periductal mastitis.

Question (100 words): What pain relief can I take for periductal mastitis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can take over-the-counter pain relief such as paracetamol to manage pain associated with periductal mastitis.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If your breast is painful, you may want to take pain relief such as paracetamol.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice new symptoms after treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you notice any new symptoms after treatment, it’s important to return to your GP for further evaluation.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s important to go back to your GP if: • Your symptoms do not improve • Your symptoms come back • You have any new symptoms

Question (100 words): How often should I be breast aware after having periductal mastitis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): It’s important to be breast aware and report any changes in your breasts to your GP, regardless of how soon after your diagnosis of periductal mastitis.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: But it’s important to go back to your GP if you notice any changes in your breasts, no matter how soon after your diagnosis of periductal mastitis.

Question (100 words): Can men get periductal mastitis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, men can get periductal mastitis, although it is very rare. It is diagnosed and treated in the same way as in women.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Men can also get periductal mastitis, but this is very rare. Periductal mastitis in men is diagnosed and treated in the same way as in women.

Question (100 words): What resources are available to help me stop smoking?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The NHS offers a range of resources to help you stop smoking, which can be found on their website.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Stopping smoking can reduce your risk of getting periductal mastitis again. The NHS has a range of resources to help you stop smoking on its website.

Question (100 words): What is the role of an ultrasound scan in diagnosing periductal mastitis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): An ultrasound scan uses high-frequency sound waves to produce an image of the breast, helping doctors identify inflammation or other abnormalities associated with periductal mastitis.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: At the breast clinic, most people have a breast examination followed by 1 or more of the following tests: • Ultrasound scan – using high-frequency sound waves to produce an image

Question (100 words): What is fine needle aspiration (FNA) used for in periductal mastitis diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Fine needle aspiration (FNA) is used to take a sample of cells from the breast, which is then examined under a microscope to confirm the presence of periductal mastitis, especially if there is bloody discharge from the nipple.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: At the breast clinic, most people have a breast examination followed by 1 or more of the following tests: • Fine needle aspiration (FNA) – using a fine needle and syringe to take a sample of cells to be looked at under a microscope

Question (100 words): What is gynaecomastia and who does it affect?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Gynaecomastia is a common, benign condition where male breast tissue is enlarged or swollen. It mainly affects teenage boys and older men, but it can affect men at any age. It is not cancerous.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Gynaecomastia is a common, benign (not cancer) condition where male breast tissue is enlarged or swollen. It mainly affects teenage boys and older men, but it can affect men at any age.

Question (100 words): What are the symptoms of gynaecomastia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Symptoms of gynaecomastia include tenderness or pain in the breast area, a lump or swelling (often behind the nipple), and noticeably larger breast or breasts.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Symptoms include: The breast area being tender to touch, The breast area being painful, A lump or swelling (more common behind the nipple but can occur anywhere in the breast area, upper chest or armpit), A noticeably larger breast or breasts.

Question (100 words): What causes gynaecomastia during puberty?
Answer (Max 2000 words): During puberty, increased hormone levels, particularly higher oestrogen than testosterone, can cause breast tissue to grow, leading to gynaecomastia.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Puberty in boys usually starts once you reach your teenage years... You may notice your breasts are tender or growing. This is because there will be times during puberty when there’s more of the hormone oestrogen than testosterone in your body.

Question (100 words): Can ageing cause gynaecomastia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, ageing can cause gynaecomastia. As men get older, they tend to have more body fat, which produces oestrogen, and less testosterone, leading to larger breasts.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: As people get older, they tend to have more body fat. This produces oestrogen. As men get older, they also produce less testosterone.

Question (100 words): Can medications cause gynaecomastia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, certain medications, including those for high blood pressure, heart conditions, and some psychiatric conditions, can cause gynaecomastia by altering hormone balance.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some drugs, both prescription and recreational, can cause gynaecomastia. Several types of drugs can change the hormone balance in the body and cause gynaecomastia.

Question (100 words): How is gynaecomastia diagnosed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Gynaecomastia is diagnosed through a breast examination by a GP or specialist, and may involve additional tests such as a mammogram, ultrasound scan, fine needle aspiration, or core biopsy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your GP will usually be able to confirm if you have gynaecomastia... You may need to have other tests to make a definite diagnosis.

Question (100 words): Do I need treatment for gynaecomastia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): In most cases, gynaecomastia does not require treatment. However, if it causes significant discomfort or concern, treatments such as medication or surgery may be considered.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Gynaecomastia does not usually need any treatment... For some people, removing the cause of the gynaecomastia is all that’s needed to shrink the enlarged breast tissue.

Question (100 words): What medications are used to treat gynaecomastia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Medications such as tamoxifen and aromatase inhibitors may be prescribed to treat gynaecomastia, though they are not always licensed specifically for this use.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your specialist may prescribe you drugs to treat gynaecomastia. These are: Tamoxifen, Aromatase inhibitors (although these are prescribed very occasionally)

Question (100 words): What are the side effects of tamoxifen?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common side effects of tamoxifen include hot flushes and a loss of sex drive (libido).
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Tamoxifen can have several side effects, including hot flushes and loss of sex drive (libido).

Question (100 words): Is surgery an option for treating gynaecomastia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Surgery may be recommended in exceptional circumstances for gynaecomastia, though it is not typically available on the NHS without an Individual Funding Request.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Surgery for gynaecomastia may be recommended in exceptional circumstances. It’s not available on the NHS and will most likely need an Individual Funding Request (IFR).

Question (100 words): What types of surgery are used for gynaecomastia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common surgical procedures for gynaecomastia include liposuction and breast reduction operations, sometimes combined. The specific procedure depends on the extent of the condition and excess skin.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Liposuction (a surgical procedure where fat is removed from the affected area) is one of the most common procedures. It can be a treatment by itself or used at the same time as a breast reduction operation.

Question (100 words): How should I feel about having gynaecomastia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): It's normal to feel anxious or worried about gynaecomastia, especially during puberty. Remember, it is a common condition and often resolves on its own. Seek support if needed.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you are going through puberty and coping with other physical changes, you may find it particularly hard to discuss growing or painful breasts with anyone.

Question (100 words): Does gynaecomastia increase the risk of breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Having gynaecomastia does not increase your risk of developing breast cancer. However, it’s important to be breast aware and report any new changes to your GP.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Having gynaecomastia does not increase your risk of developing breast cancer, but it’s still important to be breast aware.

Question (100 words): What should I do if my gynaecomastia symptoms worsen?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If your breast tissue grows larger, becomes painful, or you notice any new symptoms, it’s important to go back to your GP for further evaluation.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s important to go back to your GP if your breast tissue grows larger or becomes painful, or if you have any new symptoms.

Question (100 words): Can lifestyle changes help with gynaecomastia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, reducing excess body weight, cutting down on alcohol, and maintaining a balanced diet and regular exercise can help manage gynaecomastia.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: For some people, removing the cause of the gynaecomastia is all that’s needed to shrink the enlarged breast tissue. This may mean changing medicines, reducing excess body weight or reducing alcohol intake.

Question (100 words): What is the role of oestrogen in gynaecomastia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Oestrogen plays a significant role in gynaecomastia. Higher levels of oestrogen compared to testosterone can lead to the growth of breast tissue in men.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Increased hormone levels during puberty affect how breast tissue continues to develop. You may notice your breasts are tender or growing. This is because there will be times during puberty when there’s more of the hormone oestrogen than testosterone in your body.

Question (100 words): Can herbal supplements cause gynaecomastia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, some herbal supplements and skincare products contain oestrogen or mimic its effects, which can lead to gynaecomastia.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some herbal supplements and skincare products contain oestrogen. This may increase the level of oestrogen in your body or mimic the effect of oestrogen.

Question (100 words): What tests might be done at a breast clinic for gynaecomastia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Tests at a breast clinic may include a mammogram, ultrasound scan, fine needle aspiration, or core biopsy to confirm the diagnosis of gynaecomastia.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may need to have other tests to make a definite diagnosis. These tests can include: A mammogram (breast x-ray), An ultrasound scan – uses sound waves to produce an image, A fine needle aspiration (FNA) – uses a fine needle and syringe to take a sample of cells to be looked at under a microscope, A core biopsy – uses a hollow needle to take a small sample of breast tissue to be looked at under a microscope.

Question (100 words): What should I expect during a breast clinic appointment for gynaecomastia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): During a breast clinic appointment, you will have a breast examination and may undergo additional tests. The specialist may also examine other parts of your body and request further tests like a blood test.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: At the clinic you’ll have a breast examination. You may need to have other tests to make a definite diagnosis... They may also ask you to have further tests, such as a blood test.

Question (100 words): Where can I find further support and information about gynaecomastia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can find further support and information by calling the Breast Cancer Now Helpline on 0808 800 6000 or visiting their website at breastcancernow.org.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have any questions about gynaecomastia or just want to talk things through, you can call our helpline on 0808 800 6000 and speak with one of our team.

Question (100 words): What are pathology results and why are they important?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Pathology results are detailed reports about your breast cancer, obtained by examining tissue samples under a microscope. These results are crucial as they help your treatment team decide the most effective treatment plan for you based on the specific features of your cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Pathology is the study of disease. If you’ve had a biopsy to diagnose breast cancer, or you have had breast cancer surgery, a doctor called a pathologist will look at the tissue under a microscope. They’ll confirm the diagnosis and look at the features of the cancer cells.

Question (100 words): How long do I have to wait for my pathology results?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Typically, pathology results take between 1 and 2 weeks. However, some tests may take longer, especially if they need to be done in a different hospital or if additional tests are required. Your specialist or breast care nurse can provide you with a more accurate timeline.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Results usually take between 1 and 2 weeks. Some tests take longer than others and may be done in a different hospital to the one where you’re being treated.

Question (100 words): What should I do when I receive my pathology results?
Answer (Max 2000 words): When you receive your pathology results, it may be helpful to bring a pen and paper to take notes or record the appointment with permission. You might also consider bringing a relative or friend for support. If there’s anything you don’t understand, ask your treatment team to explain it to you.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: When you first get your results, you may find it difficult to take everything in. You might want to bring a pen and paper to your appointment so you can make notes. Or you could record the appointment on your phone so you can listen back to it later. Just ask permission first.

Question (100 words): What information is included in a pathology report?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A pathology report typically includes general information like your name, date of birth, and hospital number, clinical information about the tissue removed, features of the breast tissue before and after microscopic examination, and a summary of the main points. The level of detail can vary depending on the type of tissue removed.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Not all pathology reports look the same. The layout and words used might be different between hospitals. However, most follow this structure.

Question (100 words): How does the type of breast cancer affect my treatment options?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The type of breast cancer you have, determined by how the cancer cells look under a microscope, influences the treatment options available to you. Different types of breast cancer may require different approaches, and your treatment team will recommend the best treatment based on your specific type of cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The treatment your team recommends will depend on the type of breast cancer you have, along with other features of your cancer.

Question (100 words): What does the size of the breast cancer indicate in my pathology results?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The size of the breast cancer, measured in millimeters, is a critical factor in determining your treatment plan. Larger cancers may require more extensive surgery or additional treatments like chemotherapy. The size also affects whether you might need breast-conserving surgery or a mastectomy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The size of the cancer is usually given in millimetres (mm). There may be more than one area of cancer. The size may affect the type of operation you have, and whether you need other treatments.

Question (100 words): What does the grade of my breast cancer mean?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The grade of your breast cancer indicates how fast the cancer is growing. Faster-growing cancers (higher grade) are more likely to be treated with chemotherapy, whereas slower-growing cancers may have different treatment approaches.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast cancers can grow at different speeds. If you have a faster-growing cancer, you're more likely to be offered chemotherapy.

Question (100 words): What happens if not all the cancer was removed during surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If pathology results suggest that not all the cancer was removed during surgery, you may need another operation to remove more breast tissue to ensure all cancerous cells are eliminated.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If it looks like not all the cancer was removed, you may need another operation to remove more breast tissue.

Question (100 words): What if the cancer has spread to the lymph nodes under my arm?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If your breast cancer has spread to the lymph nodes under your arm, you may be offered additional surgery, radiotherapy to the area, or chemotherapy to address the spread and reduce the risk of further progression.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If the cancer has spread to the lymph nodes under the arm, you may be offered more surgery or radiotherapy to this area. Some people will be offered chemotherapy.

Question (100 words): What tests are done to determine what is helping my cancer grow?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Tests are conducted to identify hormones and proteins in your body that may be contributing to the growth of your breast cancer. Based on these results, you may be offered hormone therapy or targeted therapy to inhibit these growth factors.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Hormones and proteins found naturally in your body can sometimes help your cancer grow. Tests will be done to find out what might be helping your breast cancer grow.

Question (100 words): What does it mean if I have both invasive and non-invasive breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you have both invasive and non-invasive breast cancer, your pathology report will provide information about both types. The treatment plan will consider both types, though they may be addressed differently.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Sometimes there are areas of both invasive and non-invasive breast cancer at the same time. If this is the case, the report will include information about both.

Question (100 words): What is invasive breast cancer (no special type)?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Invasive breast cancer (no special type) is the most common type of invasive breast cancer. It is called no special type (NST) because it doesn’t have specific features that classify it as a special type under a microscope. It is also known as invasive ductal breast cancer or invasive breast cancer not otherwise specified (NOS).
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Most invasive breast cancers are of no special type (NST). They’re called no special type (NST) because they have no features that class them as a special type of breast cancer when examined under a microscope.

Question (100 words): What are the different types of invasive breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Other types of invasive breast cancer include cribriform, inflammatory, invasive lobular, invasive micropapillary, malignant phyllodes, medullary, metaplastic, mucinous, Paget’s disease of the breast, papillary, and tubular. These are treated similarly to invasive breast cancer (NST).
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Other breast cancers are known as “special” types. When these cancer cells are looked at under a microscope, some have certain features that identify them as a particular type.

Question (100 words): What is ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS)?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is an early, non-invasive type of breast cancer. It is confined to the milk ducts and has not spread to surrounding breast tissue. It is sometimes called pre-invasive or intraductal.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Ductal carcinoma in situ (also called DCIS) is an early type of non-invasive breast cancer. It’s sometimes called pre-invasive or intraductal.

Question (100 words): How is the size of breast cancer measured in pathology results?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The size of breast cancer is measured at its widest point in millimeters. If both DCIS and invasive breast cancer are present, the report will indicate their combined size, but treatment decisions are based on the invasive cancer details.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The size of the breast cancer is measured at its widest point, usually in millimetres (mm).

Question (100 words): What does it mean if there is more than one area of breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If there is more than one area of breast cancer, each area is measured separately. If these areas are in the same quarter of the breast, it is called multi-focal. If they are in different quarters, it is called multi-centric.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your pathology results usually say whether there’s only 1 area of cancer or more than 1 area. If there’s more than 1 area of breast cancer, each area is measured separately.

Question (100 words): What happens if I had chemotherapy or hormone therapy before surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you had chemotherapy or hormone therapy before surgery, your pathology report will indicate the size of any remaining cancer. This is called the residual size and helps determine the effectiveness of the pre-surgery treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your pathology report will tell you the size of any cancer still present. On the report this is sometimes called the residual size of the cancer.

Question (100 words): How does the size of the breast cancer affect my treatment options?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The size of the breast cancer, relative to your breast size and its position, influences whether you might need a mastectomy or breast-conserving surgery. Chemotherapy may also be recommended based on the size and other features of the cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The size of the cancer in relation to your breast size, as well as its position in the breast, may affect what treatment you’re offered.

Question (100 words): What is a complete pathological response?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A complete pathological response means that no remaining cancer is detected after pre-surgery chemotherapy or hormone therapy. This indicates a successful response to the treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Complete pathological response, meaning no remaining cancer

Question (100 words): What additional tests might my treatment team conduct on my cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your treatment team may conduct additional tests to gather more information about your breast cancer. These tests help determine the best treatment plan for you. Your team will explain the purpose and nature of these tests.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your treatment team may do other tests on the cancer. They will explain what the tests are and why they would like you to have them.

Question (100 words): What does the grade of breast cancer indicate?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The grade of breast cancer indicates how different the cancer cells are from normal breast cells and how quickly they are growing. There are three grades: Grade 1 (most like normal cells, slower growing), Grade 2 (less like normal cells, growing faster), and Grade 3 (least like normal cells, growing quickest). This grading helps determine treatment options.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast cancers are given a grade according to How different the cancer cells are to normal breast cells How quickly they are growing

Question (100 words): How does the grade of breast cancer affect my treatment options?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The grade of your breast cancer influences your treatment options. For instance, if you have Grade 3 breast cancer, you are more likely to be offered chemotherapy to destroy any potentially spread cancer cells due to its faster growth. Grade 1 and 2 cancers are less likely to require chemotherapy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your treatment team will consider the grade of your cancer when deciding which treatment to offer you.

Question (100 words): What is Ki67 and why is it important in my pathology results?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Ki67 is a protein found in cells that indicates how fast the cells are dividing and growing. Higher levels of Ki67 suggest faster cell growth. If included in your pathology results, it can help your treatment team decide on the most appropriate treatment plan for you.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Ki67 is a protein found in cells. The higher the levels of Ki67, the faster the cells are dividing and growing.

Question (100 words): What do negative or clear surgical margins mean in my pathology report?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Negative or clear surgical margins mean that no cancer cells were seen at the outer edge of the tissue removed. This usually indicates that the cancer has been completely removed and you are unlikely to need more surgery.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Negative or clear margins, meaning no cancer cells were seen at the outer edge of the tissue removed

Question (100 words): What happens if I have positive surgical margins after my surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you have positive surgical margins, it means the cancer cells are very close to, or reach the edge of, the tissue removed. You may need another operation to remove more tissue, which could involve more breast-conserving surgery or a mastectomy to ensure all cancer is removed.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Positive margins, meaning the cancer cells are very close to, or reach the edge of, the tissue

Question (100 words): What is lymphovascular invasion and how does it affect my treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Lymphovascular invasion occurs when breast cancer cells spread into the blood or lymph vessels. This increases the risk of the cancer spreading elsewhere in the body. If detected, you may be offered treatments such as chemotherapy or radiotherapy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If breast cancer cells spread into these vessels, it’s called lymphovascular invasion. This increases the chances of the breast cancer spreading to somewhere else in the body.

Question (100 words): Why is it important to check for cancer cells in the lymph nodes?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Checking for cancer cells in the lymph nodes is important because if cancer has spread to the lymph nodes, it increases the likelihood of the cancer spreading to other parts of the body. This information helps determine the most effective treatment plan for you.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have invasive breast cancer, your treatment team will usually want to check if any of the lymph nodes (glands) under the arm contain cancer cells.

Question (100 words): What does it mean if my lymph nodes are negative for cancer cells?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If your lymph nodes are negative for cancer cells, it means that the nodes tested do not contain any cancer cells. This generally indicates a lower risk of the cancer having spread and may influence your treatment options.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Negative lymph nodes, meaning the nodes tested do not contain cancer cells

Question (100 words): How do hormone receptors in breast cancer affect my treatment options?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Hormone receptors, such as oestrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR), can influence your treatment. If your breast cancer is ER-positive, you may be prescribed hormone therapy to block the effect of oestrogen on cancer cells. PR-positive but ER-negative cases are less common and require discussion with your specialist.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Hormone therapies block or stop the effect of oestrogen on breast cancer cells. Different hormone therapy drugs do this in different ways.

Question (100 words): What are HER2 levels and how do they affect my treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): HER2 levels refer to the amount of a protein called HER2 on the surface of breast cancer cells. Higher levels (HER2-positive) mean the cancer cells grow more quickly. If your cancer is HER2-positive, you may be advised to have chemotherapy and targeted therapy like trastuzumab.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some breast cancer cells have a higher-than-normal level of a protein called HER2 on their surface, which makes them grow more quickly.

Question (100 words): What are genomic assays and why might I need them?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Genomic assays are tests that analyze groups of genes in breast cancer cells to help determine the likelihood of cancer recurrence and the potential benefit from chemotherapy and hormone therapy. They are usually considered for invasive, ER-positive, HER2-negative, and lymph node-negative breast cancers or those with up to 3 positive lymph nodes.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Genomic assays are tests that look at groups of genes found in breast cancer cells. They help identify who is most likely to benefit from chemotherapy as well as hormone therapy, and how likely the cancer is to return (recurrence).

Question (100 words): What does a low EndoPredict risk score mean for my treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A low EndoPredict risk score means it is unlikely that your breast cancer will spread to other parts of the body. Most people with a low risk score will not need chemotherapy, focusing instead on hormone therapy if applicable.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A low risk score means it’s unlikely the breast cancer will spread to somewhere else in the body. Most people with a low risk score will not need chemotherapy.

Question (100 words): How does the Oncotype DX test influence my treatment plan?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The Oncotype DX test provides a Recurrence Score from 0 to 100. A higher score indicates a greater likelihood of cancer recurrence and potential benefit from chemotherapy in addition to hormone therapy. Chemotherapy is usually recommended for scores of 26 or above if you are over 50, or 16 or above if you are 50 or under.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The test gives a score, called a Recurrence Score, from 0 to 100. The higher the score, the more likely breast cancer is to come back and the more likely you are to benefit from having chemotherapy as well as hormone therapy.

Question (100 words): What does a high Prosigna risk score mean for my treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A high Prosigna risk score indicates a greater likelihood that your breast cancer will spread to other parts of the body. Based on this score and the status of your lymph nodes, chemotherapy may be recommended in addition to hormone therapy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The test gives a score, called a Recurrence Score, between 0 and 100. Based on this score and whether any lymph nodes under the arm are affected, the results are reported as low, intermediate or high risk.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice new symptoms after my surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you notice new symptoms after your surgery, such as unusual swelling, pain, or changes in the surgical area, it is important to contact your healthcare provider immediately. These could be signs of complications or other issues that need to be addressed promptly.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s important to monitor your recovery and report any new or concerning symptoms to your healthcare team.

Question (100 words): How can I manage side effects from my chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To manage side effects from chemotherapy, maintain open communication with your healthcare team. They can provide medications to alleviate symptoms like nausea or fatigue. Additionally, adopting a balanced diet, staying hydrated, and getting adequate rest can help mitigate some side effects.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your treatment team can offer medications and other strategies to help manage side effects.

Question (100 words): What lifestyle changes can help during my breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Adopting a healthy lifestyle can support your treatment. This includes eating a balanced diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and whole grains, staying physically active within your limits, avoiding alcohol and tobacco, and managing stress through relaxation techniques or support groups.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Adopting a healthy lifestyle can help you feel better during and after treatment.

Question (100 words): How can I get emotional support during my breast cancer journey?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Emotional support can be found through various resources such as support groups, counseling services, and helplines. Connecting with others who are going through similar experiences can provide comfort and practical advice. Additionally, speaking with a mental health professional can help you navigate your emotions and stress.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There are many sources of support available, including support groups, counseling services, and helplines.

Question (100 words): What follow-up care should I expect after completing my breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After completing your breast cancer treatment, you should expect regular follow-up appointments with your healthcare team. These appointments will include physical exams, imaging tests, and blood work to monitor your health and check for any signs of recurrence. Your care plan will be tailored to your specific needs and risk factors.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Regular follow-up appointments are important to monitor your health and check for any signs of recurrence.

Question (100 words): What administrative steps should I take to manage my breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To manage your breast cancer treatment administratively, keep detailed records of all appointments, test results, and treatments. Communicate regularly with your healthcare team about any changes in your condition or concerns. Ensure you understand your treatment plan and any necessary paperwork, and don’t hesitate to ask for help if needed.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Keeping organized records and maintaining clear communication with your healthcare team can help manage the administrative aspects of your treatment.

Question (100 words): What type of breast cancer do I have?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your pathology report will specify the type of breast cancer you have, such as invasive ductal carcinoma or lobular carcinoma. Understanding the type helps in determining the best treatment approach.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: • What type of breast cancer do I have?

Question (100 words): Is my breast cancer invasive, non-invasive, or both?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your report will indicate whether the cancer is invasive (has spread beyond the milk ducts or lobules), non-invasive (remains within the ducts or lobules), or a combination of both. This distinction is crucial for treatment planning.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: • Is it invasive, non-invasive or both?

Question (100 words): What size is the cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The size of the cancer, measured in centimeters, is an important factor in staging and treatment decisions. Smaller cancers may require less aggressive treatment compared to larger ones.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: • What size is the cancer?

Question (100 words): Is there more than one area of cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your pathology report will indicate if there are multiple areas of cancer. This information helps in assessing the extent of the disease and planning appropriate treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: • Is there more than 1 area of cancer?

Question (100 words): What grade is the cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The grade of the cancer (1, 2, or 3) describes how abnormal the cancer cells look under a microscope and how quickly the cancer is likely to grow. Higher grades indicate more aggressive cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: • What grade is the cancer?

Question (100 words): Has all the cancer been removed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your pathology report will state whether all detectable cancer has been removed during surgery. This is critical for determining if further treatment is needed.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: • Has all the cancer been removed?

Question (100 words): Are there any signs of lymphovascular invasion?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Lymphovascular invasion indicates that cancer cells are present in the lymphatic or blood vessels, which may increase the risk of the cancer spreading. Your report will specify if this is present.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: • Are there any signs of lymphovascular invasion?

Question (100 words): Has the cancer spread to the lymph nodes?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your report will detail if the cancer has spread to nearby lymph nodes and how many are affected. This information is vital for staging and treatment planning.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: • Has the cancer spread to the lymph nodes? If so, how many lymph nodes are affected?

Question (100 words): Is the cancer hormone receptor positive (ER-positive or PR-positive)?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If the cancer is hormone receptor positive, it means the cancer cells have receptors for estrogen (ER) or progesterone (PR). This can influence the type of treatment recommended, such as hormone therapy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: • Is the cancer hormone receptor positive (ER-positive or PR-positive)?

Question (100 words): Is the cancer HER2-positive?
Answer (Max 2000 words): HER2-positive breast cancer means the cancer cells have higher than normal levels of the HER2 protein, which can make the cancer grow faster. Targeted therapies are often used to treat HER2-positive cancers.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: • Is the cancer HER2-positive?

Question (100 words): Is a genomic assay test suitable for me?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A genomic assay test, such as Oncotype DX, can provide additional information about the risk of the cancer coming back and the likely benefit of chemotherapy. Your doctor will recommend if this test is suitable for you based on your specific situation.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: • Is a genomic assay test suitable for me? If so, what test will I have?

Question (100 words): What does a low risk score mean for my treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A low risk score indicates that it’s unlikely the breast cancer will spread elsewhere in the body, and most people with a low risk score will not need chemotherapy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A low risk score means it’s unlikely the breast cancer will spread somewhere else in the body. Most people with a low risk score will not need chemotherapy.

Question (100 words): What if I have an intermediate risk score?
Answer (Max 2000 words): An intermediate risk score means the decision to have chemotherapy is less clear. Your specialist will discuss with you what they recommend and why based on your specific case.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: An intermediate risk score means the decision to have chemotherapy is less clear. Your specialist will discuss with you what they recommend and why.

Question (100 words): What does a high risk score suggest about my treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A high risk score means it’s more likely the breast cancer will spread to other parts of the body. Chemotherapy is generally recommended for most people with a high risk score.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A high risk score means it’s more likely the breast cancer will spread to somewhere else in the body. Chemotherapy is recommended for most people with a high risk score.

Question (100 words): Who can I talk to if I have questions about my pathology report?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can speak to your treatment team, call the helpline on 0808 800 6000, join the online forum, or use the Someone Like Me service for support and answers to your questions.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Speak to your treatment team... Helpline... Forum... Someone Like Me

Question (100 words): What support is available while waiting for my pathology results?
Answer (Max 2000 words): There is a lot to take in when you get your pathology results back. Support is available through your treatment team, helpline, online forum, and the Someone Like Me service to help you through this worrying time.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There can be a lot to take in when you get your pathology results back, and waiting for them can be a worrying time. But there's support available to help you.

Question (100 words): How can I get more information about breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can visit breastcancernow.org for reliable breast cancer information, call the helpline on 0808 800 6000 to talk with specialist nurses, or email health-info@breastcancernow.org for additional resources.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Visit breastcancernow.org for reliable breast cancer information. Call 0808 800 6000 to talk things through with our helpline nurses.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I don’t understand something in my pathology report?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If there’s anything in your pathology report that you do not understand, ask your treatment team to explain it to you. They are there to help clarify any confusion you may have.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If there’s anything in your pathology report that you do not understand, ask them to explain it to you.

Question (100 words): What are the contact details for Breast Cancer Now’s support services?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can call the helpline on 0808 800 6000, visit breastcancernow.org, or email health-info@breastcancernow.org for support services and additional information.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Call our helpline on 0808 800 6000... Visit breastcancernow.org... Email health-info@breastcancernow.org

Question (100 words): How can I find someone who has had a similar experience to mine?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The Someone Like Me service will match you with a trained volunteer who’s had a similar experience to you. They can answer your questions, offer support, or simply listen.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’ve been diagnosed with primary breast cancer, our Someone Like Me service will match you with a trained volunteer who’s had a similar experience to you.

Question (100 words): What does it mean if my doctor says there is 'no evidence of disease'?
Answer (Max 2000 words): When your doctor says there is 'no evidence of disease,' it means that after your treatment, no signs of breast cancer are currently detectable.
