However, this does not guarantee that the cancer won't return. It's important to continue monitoring for any new symptoms and attend follow-up appointments as advised.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The term “cured” means there’s no chance of the breast cancer coming back. While most people’s cancer won’t come back, your treatment team may not use words like “cured” or “all clear”. They’re more likely to talk about your percentage chance of surviving 5 or 10 years and beyond. Or say there is “no evidence of disease” at the time.

Question (100 words): How will I be followed up after my breast cancer treatment ends?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your follow-up care will depend on your individual needs and the hospital's arrangements. You may have regular mammograms and possibly clinic appointments. Some patients may have open access follow-up, where they can contact their treatment team if they have concerns. Your treatment team will provide details on who to contact and what symptoms to report.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: How you’re followed up after treatment finishes depends on your individual needs, such as how likely you are to have side effects from treatment and the risk of the cancer coming back. It also depends on the arrangements at the hospital where you’ve been treated.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice new or unusual symptoms after treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience new or unusual symptoms, especially those that don't have an obvious cause or don't go away, it's important to contact your GP or breast care nurse. They can assess whether these symptoms need further investigation. Being vigilant about your health can help in early detection of any potential recurrence.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Talk to your GP or breast care nurse about any symptoms that are: • New or unusual for you • Don’t have an obvious cause • Don’t go away

Question (100 words): Will I need regular mammograms after my treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, you will likely need regular mammograms after your treatment. The frequency and duration of these mammograms depend on your age and the type of surgery you had. For instance, if you're under 50, you'll have a follow-up mammogram every year for at least 5 years. If you're aged 50 to 70, you'll have a yearly mammogram for 5 years, and if you're over 70, you can request a mammogram every 3 years.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: After your treatment, you’ll be invited to have regular mammograms (breast x-rays). If you’re under 50 You’ll have a follow-up mammogram every year for at least 5 years.

Question (100 words): What is a holistic needs assessment and why is it important?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A holistic needs assessment (HNA) is a comprehensive evaluation of your physical, social, psychological, and spiritual needs. It helps identify any support or solutions you might need to improve your quality of life after treatment. This assessment is crucial as it ensures that all aspects of your well-being are considered and addressed.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A holistic needs assessment (HNA) helps you think about your needs and concerns across all areas of your life and find support and possible solutions. It will consider your physical, social, psychological and spiritual needs.

Question (100 words): What is included in a treatment summary?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A treatment summary is a document produced by your hospital team at the end of your treatment. It includes information about side effects (both during and after treatment), signs and symptoms of possible recurrence or spread of the cancer, and any actions your GP needs to take. You may also receive a copy of this summary.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The treatment summary includes information about: • Side effects, including those that occur during treatment and after treatment (known as late side effects) • Signs and symptoms of a possible recurrence or spread of the cancer • Symptoms that should be referred to your treatment team • Any action the GP needs to take

Question (100 words): What is a Cancer Care Review and who conducts it?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A Cancer Care Review is a meeting with your GP or practice nurse within 12 months of your treatment. The purpose is to review any concerns you have and to help you understand what information and support is available in your local area. If you haven’t been offered a review and would like one, you should contact your GP.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A Cancer Care Review is a meeting with your GP or practice nurse within 12 months of having treatment. The purpose is to review any concerns you have and to help you understand what information and support is available in your local area.

Question (100 words): What types of recurrence can occur after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): There are three types of recurrence: local recurrence (cancer returns in the chest, breast, or near the original site), locally advanced breast cancer (cancer spreads to lymph nodes but not other body parts), and secondary (metastatic) breast cancer (cancer spreads to other parts of the body such as bones, lungs, liver, or brain).
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There are 3 different types of recurrence depending on where in the body the cancer has returned.

Question (100 words): What are the signs of secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Signs of secondary breast cancer can include feeling sick most of the time, severe or ongoing headaches, feeling much more tired than usual, discomfort or swelling under the ribs, any lumps or swellings under the arm, breastbone or collarbone, loss of balance or weakness/numbness of the limbs, a dry cough or feeling out of breath, altered vision or speech, unexpected weight loss and loss of appetite, and pain in bones that doesn’t get better with pain relief.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Possible signs of secondary breast cancer include: Feeling sick most of the time, Severe or ongoing headaches, Feeling much more tired than usual, Discomfort or swelling under the ribs, Any lumps or swellings under the arm, breastbone or collarbone, Loss of balance or any weakness or numbness of the limbs, A dry cough or feeling out of breath, Altered vision or speech, Unexpected weight loss and a loss of appetite, Pain in your bones.

Question (100 words): What should I look for in terms of changes to my breast or chest area?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You should look for swelling on your chest, in your armpit or around your collarbone, a change in shape or size, a change in skin texture such as puckering or dimpling, the nipple becoming inverted or looking different, liquid discharge from the nipple without squeezing it, swelling in the arm or hand, redness or a rash on the skin, in or around the nipple or in the area of the scar line of your treated breast, and a lump or thickening that feels different.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Look for changes to the other breast too. • Swelling on your chest, in your armpit or around your collarbone • A change in shape or size • A change in skin texture, such as puckering or dimpling •  The nipple has become inverted (pulled in) or looks different, for example changed position or shape •  Liquid (discharge) that comes from the nipple without squeezing it • Swelling in the arm or hand •  Redness or a rash on the skin, in or around the nipple or in the area of the scar line of your tre

Question (100 words): What is the Recovery Package and what does it include?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The Recovery Package is a comprehensive care and support program offered at the end of your treatment. It includes a holistic needs assessment and care planning, a treatment summary, a Cancer Care Review with your GP, and health and wellbeing support events. This package aims to help you feel more in control and improve your quality of life.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The Recovery Package is a package of ongoing care and support at the end of treatment. It’s made up of 4 main parts to help you feel more in control and improve your quality of life.

Question (100 words): How often will I need mammograms if I am under 50 years old?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you are under 50 years old, you will need a follow-up mammogram every year for at least 5 years. However, the duration may be longer depending on your age. Around the age of 50, you will be invited to participate in a national breast screening program.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re under 50 You’ll have a follow-up mammogram every year for at least 5 years. However, you may have these for longer depending on your age. At around the age of 50, you’ll be invited to take part in a national breast screening programme.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I am over 70 and need a mammogram?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you are over 70, you will have yearly mammograms for 5 years. After this period, you can request a mammogram every 3 years as part of a national screening program. You will need to arrange this yourself by contacting the screening unit in your area.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you are over 70 You’ll have yearly mammograms for 5 years. After this you can request a mammogram every 3 years as part of a national screening programme. You’ll need to arrange this yourself by contacting the screening unit in your area.

Question (100 words): What additional tests might I need if I have a family history of breast cancer or an altered BRCA gene?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you have a family history of breast cancer or an altered BRCA gene, you will be offered regular tests for a longer period. This is because you remain at a higher risk of developing breast cancer. You may find it helpful to read the booklet 'Family history of breast cancer: managing your risk' for more information.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you remain at high risk because of a family history of breast cancer, or you have an altered BRCA gene, you’ll be offered regular tests for a longer period.

Question (100 words): Why aren't routine scans and tests usually recommended after treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Routine scans and tests are usually not recommended after treatment because several large studies have shown that they are not useful in finding recurrence and do not improve overall survival. Scans are typically only conducted if you report symptoms that need checking.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You won’t usually have other routine scans and tests, unless you report any symptoms that need checking. Several large studies have shown having regular scans when there are no symptoms is not useful in finding recurrence and doesn’t improve overall survival.

Question (100 words): What is the difference between a recurrence and a new primary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A recurrence refers to the same breast cancer coming back, either in the remaining breast tissue after a lumpectomy or in the chest wall or skin after a mastectomy. A new primary breast cancer is a completely new cancer that can occur in the same or the other breast after treatment and is treated as a new case.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Recurrence is the term used when the same breast cancer has come back. This would be treated as an entirely new breast cancer and not a recurrence.

Question (100 words): What are the common areas affected by secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Secondary breast cancer commonly affects the bones, lungs, liver, and brain. Other areas that may be affected include lymph nodes in the chest, armpit or neck area, the skin, or the abdomen (belly).
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Secondary breast cancer commonly affects the: • Bones • Lungs • Liver • Brain

Question (100 words): What is the goal of treatment for secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The goal of treatment for secondary breast cancer is to control the cancer, relieve any symptoms, and maintain health, wellbeing, and a good quality of life for as long as possible. Secondary breast cancer cannot be cured, but treatment aims to manage it effectively.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Secondary breast cancer can be treated but cannot be cured. Treatment aims to control the cancer, relieve any symptoms, and maintain health, wellbeing and a good quality of life for as long as possible.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I'm having trouble coping after treatment ends?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you're having trouble coping after treatment ends, consider reaching out for support. Resources such as Moving Forward courses and booklets can help you adjust to life after treatment. Additionally, speaking with a counselor or support group can provide emotional support and practical advice.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Having trouble coping? The end of treatment can be a difficult and emotional time for a number of reasons. Our Moving Forward courses and Moving Forward booklet can help you adjust to life after treatment.

Question (100 words): What resources are available to help me manage my health after treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After treatment, you can access various resources to help manage your health. These include information on managing treatment side effects, signs and symptoms of recurrence, and support services like Moving Forward courses. Your treatment team should provide details on who to contact and how to seek help if you have concerns.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: After treatment finishes, you may have an appointment to: • Explain your planned follow-up and any regular tests you’ll be offered • Provide you with information about managing treatment side effects • Tell you about possible signs and symptoms of recurrence or spread of the cancer to be aware of

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice changes in my breast or scar area after surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you notice any changes in your breast, chest, or surrounding area, it's important to report them to your treatment team or GP. This includes any new or unusual symptoms that don’t have an obvious cause or don’t go away within a couple of weeks. Regular self-checks can help you become familiar with what is normal for you, making it easier to identify changes early.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s important to be aware of any changes to the breast, chest or surrounding area, even if you’re having follow-up appointments or regular mammograms.

Question (100 words): How can I check for changes in my breast or scar area?
Answer (Max 2000 words): There’s no set way to check for changes. You should get to know how the area looks and feels so you know what’s normal for you. This can be done during regular activities like bathing, applying lotion, or getting dressed. Make it a habit to check both sides of your chest regularly.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There’s no set way to check for any changes. You’ll need to get to know how the area looks and feels so you know what’s now normal for you.

Question (100 words): Who should I contact if I have concerns about my breast or scar area?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You should talk to your breast care nurse or GP about any new or unusual symptoms. If you have follow-up appointments, you can call your breast care nurse to discuss concerns. If you have open access follow-up, you will be given details of who to contact. After follow-up has ended, your GP may be your main contact.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Talk to your breast care nurse or GP about any symptoms that: • Are new or unusual for you • Don’t have an obvious cause • Don’t go away within a couple of weeks

Question (100 words): Can I do anything to reduce my risk of breast cancer recurrence?
Answer (Max 2000 words): While the risk of recurrence is largely out of your control, research suggests that regular exercise, maintaining a healthy weight, and limiting alcohol intake may help reduce your risk. For more detailed information, you can refer to the booklet 'Diet and breast cancer' or visit the website for additional resources.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Research suggests that regular exercise, maintaining a healthy weight and limiting your alcohol intake may help reduce your risk of recurrence.

Question (100 words): What should I expect emotionally after finishing breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Finishing treatment can be an emotional time. You may feel relief, but others might experience anxiety, especially as they reflect on the impact of their diagnosis. It’s normal to have mixed emotions, including anxiety about potential recurrence and the end of regular hospital contact. Support services are available to help you adjust.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Many people expect to feel relief once their hospital-based treatments have finished, and for some people this is the case. But for others, coming to the end of treatment can be a difficult and emotional time.

Question (100 words): What support is available after breast cancer treatment ends?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Support after treatment can be as important as during treatment. Options include talking therapy like counselling, Moving Forward courses and booklets, local support groups, and online forums. Breast Cancer Now’s Someone Like Me service can also connect you with a trained peer supporter.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Support after treatment For some people, getting support after treatment has finished is as important as it was at diagnosis and during treatment.

Question (100 words): How can I manage side effects after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Side effects can persist after treatment, including those from hormone therapy. It’s important to communicate with your treatment team about any ongoing symptoms. They can provide guidance and possible treatments to help manage these side effects.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may still have side effects, either from hospital treatment or ongoing treatment such as hormone therapy.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience severe pain in my scar area?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience severe or worsening pain in your scar area, you should contact your treatment team or GP immediately. Pain and sensations like burning and numbness are common after treatments like surgery and radiotherapy, but severe pain requires medical attention.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have pain that gets worse or is severe, contact your treatment team or GP.

Question (100 words): How often should I check my other breast for changes?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You should regularly check both sides of your chest to become familiar with what is normal for you. This habit can help you quickly identify any new changes in the other breast and report them to your healthcare provider.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s also important to be aware of any new changes in the other breast and to report these as soon as possible.

Question (100 words): What are the common sensations I might feel in the scar area after treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After treatments like surgery and radiotherapy, it’s common to experience pain, burning, numbness, lumpiness, or sensitivity in the scar area and under the arm. These sensations are normal as the area heals, but any severe or worsening symptoms should be reported to your healthcare provider.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: After treatments like surgery and radiotherapy, you may have pain and sensations such as burning and numbness in the scar area and under the arm.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I miss a follow-up appointment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you miss a follow-up appointment, it’s important to contact your breast care nurse or GP to reschedule. Regular follow-ups are crucial for monitoring your health and catching any potential issues early.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you still attend follow-up appointments, calling your breast care nurse can be a good way to discuss any concerns in between your follow-up appointments.

Question (100 words): How can I get more information about diet and breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can find more information about diet, lifestyle, and the risk of breast cancer recurrence in the booklet 'Diet and breast cancer' or on the Breast Cancer Now website. These resources provide detailed guidance on how dietary choices can impact your health.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Our booklet Diet and breast cancer has more information about diet, lifestyle and the risk of breast cancer coming back.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I have concerns between follow-up appointments?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you have concerns between follow-up appointments, you can call your breast care nurse. They may be able to make you an earlier appointment if necessary, ensuring you receive timely care and support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you still attend follow-up appointments, calling your breast care nurse can be a good way to discuss any concerns in between your follow-up appointments.

Question (100 words): Who can I contact if I have open access follow-up?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you have open access follow-up, you will be given details of who to contact if you have any concerns. This information is typically provided at the end of your treatment or follow-up period.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have open access follow-up, you will be given details of who to contact if you have any concerns.

Question (100 words): What should I tell my GP about my previous breast cancer diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): When speaking to your GP, make sure they know about your previous breast cancer diagnosis, especially if it was some time ago. This information is crucial for them to provide appropriate care and refer you back to your treatment team if necessary.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: When speaking to your GP, make sure they know about your previous breast cancer diagnosis, particularly if you were diagnosed some time ago.

Question (100 words): How can I find local support groups or health and wellbeing events?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your local cancer information centre will have details of local support groups and health and wellbeing events. These resources can provide additional support and community connections as you navigate life after treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There may also be local services such as support groups or health and wellbeing events. Your local cancer information centre will have details.

Question (100 words): What is the Someone Like Me service?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The Someone Like Me service is a support program offered by Breast Cancer Now that connects you by phone or email with someone else who’s had breast cancer and who’s been trained to help. This peer support can provide understanding and guidance from someone who has gone through a similar experience.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Our Someone Like Me service puts you in contact by phone or email with someone else who’s had breast cancer and who’s been trained to help.

Question (100 words): How can I access online support from Breast Cancer Now?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can access online support from Breast Cancer Now by visiting their forum, where you can chat with other people going through breast cancer. This platform provides a space for sharing experiences and gaining support from others in similar situations.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Online, you can chat to other people going through breast cancer on our forum.

Question (100 words): What services does Breast Cancer Now offer for people affected by breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast Cancer Now offers a range of free services including life-changing support, world-class research, and change-making campaigns. They provide information, support, and advocacy for anyone affected by breast cancer, whether you’re dealing with a diagnosis, treatment, or life beyond cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Life-changing support Whoever you are, and whatever your experience of breast cancer, our free services are here.

Question (100 words): How can I support Breast Cancer Now’s work?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can support Breast Cancer Now’s work by making a donation or including a gift in your will. They rely on donations and gifts in wills to fund their support services, health information, and research efforts. Your contribution helps them continue their vital work in breast cancer prevention, treatment, and support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: We don’t get any government or NHS funding for our support services or health information. So, we rely on donations and gifts in wills to make our vital work happen.

Question (100 words): What is chemotherapy and how does it work?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Chemotherapy is a treatment that uses anti-cancer drugs to destroy cancer cells. It works by affecting the ability of cancer cells to divide and grow, which they do in a disordered and uncontrolled manner. Different chemotherapy drugs work in different ways and at different times in the cancer cell growth cycle, which is why combinations of drugs are often used.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Chemotherapy is a treatment that destroys cancer cells using anti-cancer drugs. Chemotherapy destroys cancer cells by affecting their ability to divide and grow.

Question (100 words): When is chemotherapy given for breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Chemotherapy for breast cancer can be given before surgery to shrink the tumor (neoadjuvant chemotherapy) or after surgery to reduce the risk of cancer recurrence (adjuvant chemotherapy). It can also be used to treat secondary (metastatic) breast cancer to control its growth and relieve symptoms.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may have chemotherapy before surgery to slow the growth of fast-growing breast cancer. Or you may have it to shrink a larger breast cancer before surgery... You may have chemotherapy after surgery for primary breast cancer to reduce the risk of the cancer coming back or spreading.

Question (100 words): What factors determine if I will receive chemotherapy for primary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The decision to offer chemotherapy for primary breast cancer depends on several factors including the size, stage, and grade of the cancer, the oestrogen receptor status, the HER2 status, and whether you have an inherited altered gene like BRCA1. Your general health and other medical conditions are also considered.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have primary breast cancer, whether you’re offered chemotherapy will depend on: The size, stage and grade of your breast cancer The oestrogen receptor status The HER2 status Whether you have an inherited altered gene that increases breast cancer risk, such as BRCA1.

Question (100 words): What are genomic assays and how are they used in chemotherapy decisions?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Genomic assays are tests that look at groups of genes in breast cancer cells to help identify who is most likely to benefit from chemotherapy and the likelihood of cancer recurrence. Tests like EndoPredict, Oncotype DX, and Prosigna are examples. These tests are considered alongside other pathology results to guide treatment recommendations.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: These tests look at groups of genes found in breast cancer cells. They help identify who is most likely to benefit from chemotherapy and how likely the cancer is to come back (recurrence).

Question (100 words): What preparations are needed before starting chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Before starting chemotherapy, you will have blood tests, your height and weight measured, and possibly tests to check your heart function such as an ECG, echocardiogram, or MUGA scan. You’ll also be given anti-sickness drugs and asked to sign a consent form after the benefits and risks are explained to you.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Before starting your treatment, a member of your treatment team will discuss how and when you’ll have chemotherapy and how side effects can be managed. You’ll have blood tests and your height and weight will be measured.

Question (100 words): How is chemotherapy administered?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Chemotherapy for breast cancer is most commonly given intravenously (into a vein) or orally (as tablets or capsules). The method, drugs used, dose, frequency, and number of cycles are tailored to the individual patient.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: For breast cancer, the drugs are most commonly given: Into a vein (intravenously) By mouth as tablets or capsules (orally)

Question (100 words): What is a chemotherapy cycle and how long does it last?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A chemotherapy cycle consists of a series of treatments with a break in between to allow the body to recover from side effects. Cycles usually last between 1 and 6 weeks. Blood tests are conducted before each cycle to check if treatment can proceed.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You’ll normally have chemotherapy as a series of treatments with a break between each treatment. This allows your body time to recover from any short-term side effects. The treatment and period of time before the next one starts is called a cycle. Cycles usually last between 1 and 6 weeks.

Question (100 words): What is the risk of lymphoedema after chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Lymphoedema, swelling caused by fluid build-up in tissues, can develop after surgery or radiotherapy to the lymph nodes. There is no consistent evidence that intravenous chemotherapy increases the risk of lymphoedema, though practice may vary between hospitals regarding which arm is used for administration.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There’s no consistent evidence that having injections or intravenous medicines in your “at risk” arm (the arm the side of your operation) will increase your risk of lymphoedema.

Question (100 words): What are the different ways intravenous chemotherapy can be administered?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Intravenous chemotherapy can be given through a cannula, a central venous access device like a skin-tunnelled catheter (Hickman or Groshong line), a peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC), or an implanted port. These devices allow for the administration of chemotherapy and can remain in place throughout treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The most common way of giving chemotherapy involves inserting a small needle and a plastic tube called a cannula into a vein... Other ways of giving intravenous chemotherapy Sometimes a central venous access device (a device inserted through a vein that fluids and medication can be given through) is used to give chemotherapy.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I feel unwell during chemotherapy treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You should contact the 24-hour contact number provided by your treatment team or the person they have designated for you to reach out to if you feel unwell at any time during your treatment, including nights and weekends.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You should be given a 24-hour contact number or told who to contact if you feel unwell at any time during your treatment, including overnight or at the weekends.

Question (100 words): Will I lose my hair during chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Chemotherapy can cause hair loss. It’s important to discuss this potential side effect with your treatment team before beginning treatment so you can be prepared.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Chemotherapy can cause hair loss

Question (100 words): How might chemotherapy affect my fertility?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Chemotherapy may affect your fertility. If you’re concerned about this, it’s important to discuss it with your treatment team before you begin treatment to understand the risks and possible fertility preservation options.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Chemotherapy may affect your fertility

Question (100 words): What anti-sickness drugs are given before chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You’ll usually be given anti-sickness (anti-emetic) drugs before each chemotherapy treatment. These often include a steroid drug called dexamethasone as well as other anti-sickness medications.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You’ll usually be given anti-sickness (also called anti-emetic) drugs before each chemotherapy treatment. The drugs you’re given will depend on the type of chemotherapy you’re having, but will often include a steroid drug called dexamethasone as well as the anti-sickness medication.

Question (100 words): Can chemotherapy be given at home or in a mobile treatment center?
Answer (Max 2000 words): In some areas, chemotherapy may be given in a mobile treatment center or in your home. For more information about chemotherapy safety at home, visit Cancer Research UK’s website.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: In some areas of the country, chemotherapy may be given in a mobile treatment centre or in your home.

Question (100 words): What is a skin-tunnelled catheter and how is it used for chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A skin-tunnelled catheter, also known as a Hickman or Groshong line, is a fine silicone tube inserted into a vein through a small cut in the chest. It stays in place throughout your treatment and can be used to give chemotherapy and take blood samples.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A skin-tunnelled catheter is a fine silicone tube that’s inserted into a vein through a small cut in the chest. It’s also called a Hickman or Groshong line.

Question (100 words): What is a PICC line and how is it used for chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A PICC (peripherally inserted central catheter) is inserted into a vein in your arm, at or above the bend in your elbow, and into the large vein leading to your heart. It stays in place throughout your treatment and can be used to give chemotherapy and take blood samples.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A PICC is inserted into a vein in your arm, at or above the bend in your elbow, and into the large vein leading to your heart.

Question (100 words): What is an implanted port and how is it used for chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): An implanted port is a small disc connected to a thin tube (catheter) placed under the skin, usually in your chest or arm. Chemotherapy drugs are given directly into the port, and it can stay in place throughout your treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: An implanted port is a small disc connected to a thin tube (catheter). It’s put under the skin, usually in your chest or arm.

Question (100 words): How is an implanted port removed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): When it needs to be removed, a small cut is made over the site of the port. The port is removed and the catheter is taken out of the vein. The wound is stitched and covered with a dressing.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: When it needs to be removed, a small cut is made over the site of the port. The port is removed and the catheter is taken out of the vein. The wound is stitched and covered with a dressing.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I feel sore or bruised after the port is removed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You’ll be given instructions on caring for your dressing and what to do if you feel sore or bruised after the port is removed. Follow these instructions carefully and contact your treatment team if you have any concerns.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You’ll be given instructions on caring for your dressing and what to do if you feel sore or bruised after the port is removed.

Question (100 words): How can I manage the emotional impact of chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): It’s completely natural to feel anxious about having chemotherapy. Talking through your concerns with your treatment team or breast care nurse can help. Additionally, our specialist nurses are available to provide support and answer your questions. You can reach them by calling our helpline on 0808 800 6000 or visiting breastcancernow.org.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s completely natural to feel anxious about having chemotherapy to treat your breast cancer... You can talk this through with your treatment team or breast care nurse. They can answer your questions and support you with your decision. You can also speak to our specialist nurses on 0808 800 6000 or at breastcancernow.org

Question (100 words): What should I do if I suspect a blood clot?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you suspect a blood clot, contact your treatment team or go to your local A&E department immediately. Symptoms include pain, redness, swelling, and warmth in the arm or leg, shortness of breath, chest pain, and unexplained cough or coughing up blood.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Contact your treatment team or go to your local A&E department straight away if you have any of the following symptoms: Pain in your arm or leg, Redness/discolouration of the skin of the arm or leg, Heat and swelling of the arm or leg, Shortness of breath that comes on suddenly, Pain or tightness in the chest, Unexplained cough or coughing up blood.

Question (100 words): How should I handle and store oral chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The hospital pharmacist or your chemotherapy nurse will provide specific instructions on how to handle and store oral chemotherapy. Always read the labels on the boxes before leaving the hospital. If instructions are unclear, ask your treatment team or pharmacist for clarification.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The hospital pharmacist or your chemotherapy nurse will give you instructions on how to handle and store oral chemotherapy.

Question (100 words): What is electrochemotherapy and who can get it?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Electrochemotherapy is a treatment for secondary breast cancer that has spread to the skin. It combines a low dose of chemotherapy with electrical impulses. If suitable, your treatment team can refer you to the nearest available hospital for this treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Electrochemotherapy, sometimes called ECT, is a treatment for secondary breast cancer that has spread to the skin (skin metastases). It combines a low dose of a chemotherapy drug with electrical impulses.

Question (100 words): What are the common side effects of chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common side effects of chemotherapy include effects on blood cells (anemia, increased infection risk, bruising), nausea and vomiting, hair loss, and extreme tiredness (fatigue). These can usually be managed with medication and lifestyle changes.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Like any treatment, chemotherapy can cause side effects. Everyone reacts differently to drugs and some people have more side effects than others.

Question (100 words): How can I reduce the risk of infection during chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To reduce the risk of infection, regularly wash and dry your hands, clean and cover any cuts, avoid people who are unwell, eat healthily, drink plenty of fluids, and store and cook food correctly. Your treatment team may also recommend growth factors to boost white blood cell production.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can help reduce the risk of infection by: Regularly washing and drying your hands thoroughly, Cleaning any cuts and grazes and covering them with a dressing or plaster, Avoiding people who are unwell or may be infectious, Eating as healthily as possible, and following any advice about food and drink given to you by your treatment team, Drinking plenty of fluids, Storing and cooking food correctly.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience nausea or vomiting after chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You will be given anti-sickness medication before each cycle of chemotherapy and additional tablets to take at home. If you experience persistent nausea, vomiting, or difficulty keeping fluids down, contact your treatment team immediately.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You’ll be given anti-sickness medication, as tablets or into a vein, before each cycle of chemotherapy. You’ll also be given anti-sickness tablets to take at home.

Question (100 words): Will I lose my hair during chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Hair loss during chemotherapy depends on the type and amount of drugs you receive. Some drugs cause no hair loss, while others may cause thinning or complete hair loss. Hair usually starts to grow back a few weeks after treatment ends.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Chemotherapy can cause hair loss. It’s completely natural to find this upsetting. How likely you are to lose your hair depends on the type and amount of chemotherapy drugs you’re given.

Question (100 words): What is scalp cooling and how does it work?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Scalp cooling involves wearing a “cold cap” before, during, and after chemotherapy to reduce blood flow to hair follicles, thereby minimizing the amount of chemotherapy drugs reaching them. It may prevent some hair loss but is not effective for everyone.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Scalp cooling may stop you losing some, or all, of the hair on your head. This involves wearing a “cold cap” before, during and for 1 to 2 hours after your treatment. It works by reducing blood flow to your hair follicles, which reduces the amount of chemotherapy drugs reaching them.

Question (100 words): Are wigs available on the NHS for chemotherapy-related hair loss?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Synthetic wigs are available on the NHS and are free in Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland. In England, you may need to pay a charge, but financial help may be available. Human hair and bespoke wigs are not available on the NHS but can be purchased.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Synthetic wigs are available on the NHS. They’re free in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. In England, you’ll usually have to pay a charge for an NHS wig.

Question (100 words): What is cancer-related fatigue and how can it be managed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Cancer-related fatigue is extreme tiredness that does not improve with rest or sleep. It is a common side effect of chemotherapy. Inform your GP or treatment team, who can offer advice on managing your energy levels.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Fatigue is extreme tiredness that does not go away with rest or sleep. It’s a very common side effect of chemotherapy and may last for weeks or months after your treatment has finished.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I have a high temperature during chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you have a high temperature (over 37.5°C) or low temperature (under 36°C), contact your hospital immediately. A high temperature can indicate an infection, especially if your white blood cell count is low.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have any of the following: A high temperature (over 37.5°C) or low temperature (under 36°C), Suddenly feeling unwell, even with a normal temperature, Symptoms of an infection, such as a sore throat, cough, needing to pee often or feeling cold or shivery, even if you do not have a high temperature, contact your hospital immediately.

Question (100 words): How can I manage bruising and bleeding during chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Chemotherapy can reduce platelet count, leading to easier bruising and bleeding. Inform your treatment team if you notice increased bruising, nosebleeds, bleeding gums, or prolonged bleeding from cuts. They may adjust your treatment plan.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Chemotherapy can reduce the number of platelets. Platelets help the blood to clot. If your platelets are low you may: Bruise more easily, Have nosebleeds, Notice that your gums bleed when you brush your teeth, Take longer to stop bleeding if you cut yourself.

Question (100 words): What are the symptoms of anaemia during chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Anaemia, or having too few red blood cells, can cause symptoms like breathlessness, dizziness, and extreme tiredness. Inform your treatment team if you experience these symptoms.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Having too few red blood cells is called anaemia. If you feel breathless, dizzy or particularly tired, let your treatment team know.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice signs of a blood clot?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you notice signs of a blood clot such as pain, redness, swelling, or warmth in the arm or leg, shortness of breath, chest pain, or unexplained cough, contact your treatment team or go to your local A&E department immediately.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Contact your treatment team or go to your local A&E department straight away if you have any of the following symptoms: Pain in your arm or leg, Redness/discolouration of the skin of the arm or leg, Heat and swelling of the arm or leg, Shortness of breath that comes on suddenly, Pain or tightness in the chest, Unexplained cough or coughing up blood.

Question (100 words): How can I reduce nausea during chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To reduce nausea, drink plenty of fluids like water or herbal teas, eat little and often, and avoid large meals. If concerned about your diet, ask your treatment team to refer you to a dietitian.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Tips for reducing nausea: Drink plenty of fluids, such as water or mint or ginger herbal teas. Taking frequent sips is better than trying to drink large amounts in one go. Eating little and often is a good way to try to stop you feeling sick.

Question (100 words): What tips can help me cope with hair loss during chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Tips to cope with hair loss include being prepared by cutting your hair shorter or shaving it off before treatment, avoiding razors or clippers without a guard to prevent skin irritation, and seeking support from organizations like Cancer Hair Care.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Tips on coping with hair loss: Some people find it helps if they’re prepared to lose their hair before it happens. For example, some people cut their hair shorter or shave it off before starting chemotherapy.

Question (100 words): Can I claim back VAT on wigs purchased due to chemotherapy-induced hair loss?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, if your hair loss is due to chemotherapy, you do not have to pay VAT on wigs. To claim back the VAT, complete and post a VAT form to the supplier. Most stores will provide this form at the time of purchase.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If your hair loss is caused by chemotherapy, you do not have to pay VAT on wigs bought from a shop or other supplier. To claim back the VAT, you’ll need to complete and post a VAT form to the supplier.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I feel extremely tired during chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you feel extreme tiredness that does not improve with rest or sleep, inform your GP or treatment team. They can assess you and offer advice on managing your energy levels.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you think you have fatigue, tell your GP or treatment team. They can assess you and offer advice on how to manage your energy levels.

Question (100 words): How can I manage the side effects of oral chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To manage the side effects of oral chemotherapy, follow the instructions provided by your hospital pharmacist or chemotherapy nurse. Take the medication exactly as prescribed, and contact your treatment team if you experience any side effects.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The hospital pharmacist or your chemotherapy nurse will give you instructions on how to handle and store oral chemotherapy. They’ll also tell you when and how to take it, for example if it should be taken with food.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I miss a dose of oral chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you cannot take your chemotherapy for any reason, or if you are sick after taking your tablets, do not take an extra dose. Contact your treatment team immediately for advice.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you cannot take your chemotherapy for any reason, or if you are sick after taking your tablets, do not take an extra dose. Contact your treatment team immediately for advice.

Question (100 words): How can I manage fatigue during chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To manage fatigue, keep a fatigue diary to track your energy levels and activities. Engage in regular, light exercise like walking or yoga. Allow time to rest between activities but limit naps to less than 30 minutes. Try relaxation techniques and complementary therapies like massage or acupuncture. Drink plenty of fluids, eat healthily, and seek emotional support. Accept offers of help from others.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The following suggestions may help you manage fatigue: • Keep a fatigue diary – recording your fatigue level each day, as well as any activities you do and treatment you’re having, can help identify the causes of fatigue and show changes in energy levels.

Question (100 words): What should I do if chemotherapy causes a sore mouth?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If chemotherapy causes a sore mouth, use a mouthwash provided by the hospital and a small, soft toothbrush. See your dentist for a check-up before starting chemotherapy. Avoid dental treatment during chemotherapy if possible. If you need dental work, talk to your treatment team about the best time. If you have mouth problems, inform your chemotherapy nurse or treatment team immediately.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You’ll be given mouthwash to try to reduce soreness and stop mouth ulcers developing. It’s a good idea to use a small, soft toothbrush during this time.

Question (100 words): How can I reduce the risk of dental problems during chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To reduce dental problems, clean your teeth or dentures after each meal, use a soft toothbrush, and a hospital-provided mouthwash. Take regular sips of water, use artificial saliva sprays, and chew sugar-free gum. Avoid citrus fruits, spicy, hard, or salty foods, alcohol, very hot or cold drinks, and try to limit smoking.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Other tips to reduce dental problems: • Clean your teeth or dentures after each meal • Use a soft toothbrush • Use a mouthwash (often provided by the hospital)

Question (100 words): Why might I experience taste changes during chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Taste changes during chemotherapy can make foods taste different, such as more salty, bitter, or metallic. This is a common side effect. Your taste should return to normal once treatment has finished. Speak to your treatment team for management tips.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may notice taste changes while having chemotherapy. Some foods may taste different, for example more salty, bitter or metallic.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience pain at the injection site?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience pain, redness, discoloration, or swelling at the injection site, inform your chemotherapy nurse immediately. This could indicate an issue that needs attention.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Tell your chemotherapy nurse immediately if you have pain, stinging or a burning sensation around the cannula (small plastic tube) while you’re being given chemotherapy.

Question (100 words): How can I care for my skin during chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To care for your skin during chemotherapy, eat a healthy diet, drink plenty of water, protect your skin from the sun, wear high protection sunscreen, avoid very hot showers or baths, avoid scented soap, and apply unperfumed body lotion to keep your skin moist.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Tips for looking after your skin: • Eating a healthy diet • Drinking plenty of water • Taking care in the sun by covering your skin and wearing a hat

Question (100 words): What changes might I notice in my nails during chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Chemotherapy may cause changes in the appearance of your fingernails and toenails, such as changes in color or texture, ridges forming, or nails becoming more brittle and cracked. Report any signs of infection to your treatment team.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Chemotherapy may cause changes to the appearance of your fingernails and toenails. This can be a change in the nail colour or texture, such as ridges forming.

Question (100 words): How can I care for my hands and nails during chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To care for your hands and nails, use hand cream to moisturize, wear gloves for household chores, avoid tight-fitting shoes if your toenails are affected, don’t wear false nails, avoid nail varnish, and keep nails short.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Tips for caring for your hands and nails • Use hand cream to help moisturise your hands, feet and nails • Use gloves for household chores to protect your nails

Question (100 words): Why might I feel numbness or tingling in my hands or feet during chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Numbness or tingling in your hands or feet during chemotherapy is due to peripheral neuropathy, a condition where chemotherapy drugs affect the nerves. Symptoms may include pain, numbness, altered sensation, pins and needles, and increased sensitivity to temperature. Symptoms usually improve after treatment ends.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may have pain, numbness or tingling in your hands and feet while having chemotherapy. This is because some chemotherapy drugs can affect the nerves. This is known as peripheral neuropathy.

Question (100 words): What can I do if chemotherapy affects my concentration?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If chemotherapy affects your concentration, this is sometimes called ‘chemo brain’ or ‘chemo fog.’ It usually improves over time after treatment. Some people find mental exercises like crosswords and puzzles help keep their minds active.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You might find your treatment affects your ability to concentrate and makes you more forgetful. This is sometimes called “chemo brain” or “chemo fog”

Question (100 words): How can chemotherapy affect my digestive system?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Chemotherapy can cause constipation or diarrhea. If you have diarrhea three or more times than usual in 24 hours, contact your treatment team. Some drugs may cause indigestion or heartburn. Drink plenty of fluids to avoid dehydration and inform your team about any side effects.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Chemotherapy can affect your digestive system in different ways. Some people become constipated while others have diarrhoea.

Question (100 words): What menopausal symptoms might I experience during chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Chemotherapy can cause menopausal symptoms such as hot flushes, night sweats, mood changes, joint aches, vaginal dryness, and memory problems. Talk to your treatment team about ways to cope with these symptoms.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may experience menopausal symptoms as a result of chemotherapy. Some common menopausal symptoms include: • Hot flushes • Night sweats• Mood changes

Question (100 words): How does chemotherapy affect fertility?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Chemotherapy can affect fertility by causing changes in the ovaries. Whether your fertility is affected depends on the type and dose of drugs used, your age, and your current fertility status. Discuss fertility concerns with your treatment team before starting treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Chemotherapy causes changes in the ovaries, which can affect your ability to become pregnant (your fertility). Whether your fertility is affected depends on the type and dose of drugs used, your age and your current fertility status.

Question (100 words): What are the long-term effects of chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Most chemotherapy side effects are temporary, but some may continue after treatment. Rare long-term effects can include heart or lung problems and an increased risk of another cancer. Discuss these risks with your treatment team.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Most chemotherapy side effects are temporary and improve once your treatment has finished. However, you might find side effects continue after you’ve finished treatment.

Question (100 words): Can complementary therapies help with chemotherapy side effects?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Many people find complementary therapies like acupuncture, aromatherapy, and herbal remedies help cope with chemotherapy side effects. Check with your treatment team before trying any therapies, as some may interact with your treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Many people find complementary therapies help them cope with the side effects of chemotherapy, even though there may not be the evidence to support this.

Question (100 words): How should I manage my diet during chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Eat and drink what you feel able to, maintaining a healthy, well-balanced diet wherever possible. Some people may lose or gain weight during treatment. For more detailed information, see the Diet and breast cancer booklet.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s important to eat and drink what you feel able to, maintaining a healthy, well-balanced diet wherever possible.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I develop a rash during chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you develop a rash during chemotherapy, inform your treatment team as soon as possible. They may prescribe gels or creams to apply to the affected areas.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Tell your treatment team as soon as possible if you develop a rash.

Question (100 words): How can I protect my skin from the sun during chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To protect your skin from the sun during chemotherapy, cover your skin, wear a hat, use high protection sunscreen, and stay out of the sun during the hottest part of the day (11am to 3pm).
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Taking care in the sun by covering your skin and wearing a hat • Wearing high protection sunscreen • Staying out of the sun during the hottest part of the day (11am to 3pm)

Question (100 words): What is hand-foot syndrome and how is it treated?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Hand-foot syndrome is a skin reaction caused by some chemotherapy drugs, affecting the palms of the hands and soles of the feet. It can make daily activities harder. Your treatment team may prescribe gels or creams to apply to the affected areas.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some chemotherapy drugs can cause a skin reaction called hand-foot syndrome (palmar-plantar erythrodysesthesia). It usually affects the palms of the hands and soles of the feet.

Question (100 words): What emotional support is available during chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Emotional support during chemotherapy can include individual counseling or support groups. Talking to others who have gone through a similar experience can also be helpful. Visit breastcancernow.org/information-support/support-you for more information.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Seek emotional support – individual counselling or a support group may help reduce fatigue. You could try talking to others who have gone through a similar experience.

Question (100 words): Can I take vitamin supplements during chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): It is recommended to inform your treatment team about any supplements you are taking or plan to start. The safety of taking high-dose antioxidants during chemotherapy is not clear, and many specialists advise against it due to potential interference with treatment effectiveness.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The evidence is conflicting about how safe it is to take vitamin supplements, particularly high-dose antioxidants (including vitamins A, C and E, Co-enzyme Q10 and selenium), during chemotherapy.

Question (100 words): Is it safe to have sex during chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can still have sex during treatment. While chemotherapy drugs are not thought to pass into vaginal fluids or semen, using barrier methods of contraception, such as condoms, is advised during treatment and for a few days after.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can still have sex during treatment. It’s thought chemotherapy drugs cannot pass into vaginal fluids or semen, but this cannot be completely ruled out.

Question (100 words): Can I get pregnant while on chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): It is advised not to become pregnant while having chemotherapy as it can harm a developing baby. If you have not been through menopause, discuss the most suitable method of contraception with your treatment team.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You’re advised not to become pregnant while having treatment because chemotherapy can harm a developing baby.

Question (100 words): What vaccinations should I avoid during chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You should avoid live vaccines such as mumps, measles, rubella, polio, BCG, and yellow fever while on chemotherapy due to the risk of infection from a weakened immune system.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You should not have any live vaccines while you’re having chemotherapy. Live vaccines include: Mumps, Measles, Rubella (German measles), Polio, BCG (tuberculosis), Yellow fever

Question (100 words): Can I get the flu vaccine while on chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, it is usually safe to get the flu vaccine while on chemotherapy as it is not a live vaccine and does not contain any active viruses.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The flu vaccine is not a live vaccine so doesn’t contain any active viruses.

Question (100 words): When should I get the COVID-19 vaccination if I’m on chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Speak to your treatment team about the best time to have a COVID-19 vaccination while on chemotherapy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re having chemotherapy, you’re advised to speak to your treatment team about the best time to have a COVID-19 vaccination.

Question (100 words): How can I find emotional support during chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): It’s important to share your feelings with family, friends, or your treatment team. Counselling services are available through your treatment team, GP, local support groups, or privately.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s important to have the right support during and after treatment. Let other people, particularly your family and friends, know how you’re feeling so they can support you.

Question (100 words): What resources are available for support during breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast Cancer Now offers a free helpline, online support, information resources, and peer support through their Someone Like Me service and chemotherapy threads on their forum.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast Cancer Now has a number of services to help support you: You can call our free helpline and speak to our specialist nurses on 0808 800 6000 or talk to us online at breastcancernow.org

Question (100 words): Where can I get help with hair loss due to chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Cancer Hair Care provides detailed information on scalp and hair care, wigs, headwear, and hair regrowth for people experiencing hair loss due to chemotherapy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Cancer Hair Care: A website for people who are experiencing hair loss due to chemotherapy.

Question (100 words): What care packages are available for people undergoing breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Little Lifts offers free chemotherapy boxes containing various products to help people through treatment. Anyone having treatment in the UK is eligible to apply.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Little Lifts provides handpicked, NHS-approved care packages for people having breast cancer treatment.

Question (100 words): How can Macmillan Cancer Support help me during treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Macmillan Cancer Support provides practical, medical, emotional, and financial support to people living with cancer, their carers, and families. They also fund expert health and social care professionals.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Macmillan Cancer Support provides practical, medical, emotional and financial support to people living with cancer, their carers and families.

Question (100 words): Where can I get reliable information about cancer and nutrition?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The World Cancer Research Fund offers a helpline staffed by oncology specialist dietitians who can answer questions about cancer and diet.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: World Cancer Research Fund believe everyone who has been diagnosed with cancer should have access to the most reliable and up-to-date information about cancer and nutrition.

Question (100 words): How can I order more copies of this booklet?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can order or download more copies of this booklet from breastcancernow.org/publications.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can order or download more copies from breastcancernow.org/publications

Question (100 words): Who wrote this booklet and who reviewed it?
Answer (Max 2000 words): This booklet was written by Breast Cancer Now’s clinical specialists and reviewed by healthcare professionals and people affected by breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Chemotherapy for breast cancer was written by Breast Cancer Now’s clinical specialists, and reviewed by healthcare professionals and people affected by breast cancer.

Question (100 words): How can I provide feedback on this publication?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can provide feedback on this publication by emailing health-info@breastcancernow.org.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: We welcome your feedback on this publication: health-info@breastcancernow.org

Question (100 words): What should I do if I need a large print, Braille, or audio CD version of this booklet?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Email health-info@breastcancernow.org to request a large print, Braille, or audio CD version of this booklet.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: For a large print, Braille or audio CD version: Email health-info@breastcancernow.org

Question (100 words): What is the next planned review date for this booklet?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The next planned review date for this booklet is July 2027.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: BCC17 Edition 9, next planned review July 2027

Question (100 words): How can I contact Breast Cancer Now’s helpline?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can contact Breast Cancer Now’s helpline by calling 0808 800 6000.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Call 0808 800 6000 to talk things through with our helpline nurses.

Question (100 words): Where can I find reliable breast cancer information online?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can find reliable breast cancer information by visiting breastcancernow.org.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Visit breastcancernow.org for reliable breast cancer information.

Question (100 words): What is the registered office address of Breast Cancer Now?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The registered office address of Breast Cancer Now is 6th Floor, The White Chapel Building, 10 Whitechapel High Street, London E1 8QS.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Registered Office: 6th Floor, The White Chapel Building, 10 Whitechapel High Street, London E1 8QS.

Question (100 words): What is secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Secondary breast cancer occurs when breast cancer cells spread from the primary cancer in the breast to other parts of the body, such as the bones, lungs, liver, or brain. It is also known as metastatic breast cancer, metastases, advanced breast cancer, secondaries, or Stage 4 breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Secondary breast cancer occurs when breast cancer cells spread from the primary (first) cancer in the breast to other parts of the body.

Question (100 words): Can secondary breast cancer be cured?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Secondary breast cancer cannot currently be cured, but it can be treated. Treatment aims to control the cancer, relieve symptoms, and maintain health and quality of life for as long as possible.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Secondary breast cancer can be treated, but it can’t currently be cured. Treatment aims to control the cancer, relieve any symptoms, and maintain health, wellbeing and a good quality of life for as long as possible.

Question (100 words): What factors affect my prognosis with secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your prognosis with secondary breast cancer can depend on several factors, including the amount of cancer in your body, the areas affected, and the specific features of your breast cancer. Each case is unique, and predicting life expectancy is challenging.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A prognosis may depend on a number of factors including: How much cancer there is in the body, Which area or areas of the body are affected, The features of the breast cancer.

Question (100 words): How can I cope with the emotional impact of a secondary breast cancer diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Coping with a secondary breast cancer diagnosis involves acknowledging your emotions, seeking support from family, friends, or support groups, and talking to healthcare professionals. It's important to find ways to manage your feelings and take control of your situation.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may experience many different emotions, including disbelief, denial, shock, anger, fear, numbness and helplessness. Your emotions may swing from one extreme to the other or change from one day to the next.

Question (100 words): Who are the healthcare professionals involved in treating secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your treatment team for secondary breast cancer may include an oncologist, a specialist nurse, your GP, district or community nurses, palliative and supportive care teams, occupational therapists, and social workers. Each plays a specific role in your care.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A number of healthcare professionals may be involved in your care. Some of these you may see regularly and others only when specific needs arise, but it’s important to know what help is available to you.

Question (100 words): What is the role of a specialist nurse in my care?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A specialist nurse provides information and support to those diagnosed with breast cancer. They can help address any questions or concerns you have about your cancer or its treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Everyone diagnosed with breast cancer should have access to a specialist nurse who’s there to provide them with information and support.

Question (100 words): What support is available for me and my family during treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Support for you and your family during treatment includes access to specialist nurses, palliative and supportive care teams, and community-based services. These teams can help manage symptoms and provide emotional and practical support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Palliative and supportive care teams are based in the hospital, hospice or community. They can help you with managing symptoms and can provide support for you and your family, friends and carers.

Question (100 words): How can an occupational therapist help me?
Answer (Max 2000 words): An occupational therapist can assess what aids and adaptations you may need to help you be more independent at home, such as stair rails and bathing aids. They can also help manage symptoms like fatigue.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: An occupational therapist can assess what aids and adaptations you may need, such as stair rails and bathing aids, to help you be more independent at home. They can also be very helpful with managing symptoms such as fatigue.

Question (100 words): What is de novo metastatic breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): De novo metastatic breast cancer is when secondary breast cancer is diagnosed at the same time as or before the primary breast cancer. It is sometimes referred to as being ‘treatment naïve’ because it has not previously been treated with any anti-cancer treatments.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Secondary breast cancer usually occurs years or sometimes months after primary breast cancer, but for some people it’s diagnosed at the same time as the primary breast cancer or before the primary breast cancer has been discovered. This is referred to as ‘de novo’ (which means ‘new’) metastatic breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I’m overwhelmed by my diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you’re overwhelmed by your diagnosis, take it one step at a time. Read the information provided, but focus on the parts most relevant to you. Seek support from your treatment team, specialist nurses, or support groups. Talking about your feelings can also help.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: ‘I felt overwhelmed by everything at the beginning – the diagnosis and all the information being provided. My advice is take it all slowly and read everything but then go back to those pertinent points for you as it won’t all be relevant.’

Question (100 words): How can I get more information about secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can get more information about secondary breast cancer by visiting breastcancernow.org, contacting their Helpline on 0808 800 6000, or joining their online discussion Forum and Living with Secondary Breast Cancer groups.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Our website breastcancernow.org has an online discussion Forum where you can talk to other people with secondary breast cancer. We run Living with Secondary Breast Cancer groups around the country and online – these are facilitated by trained counsellors to help you find the support you need and share experiences and tips with others.

Question (100 words): What are the common areas where breast cancer spreads?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The most common areas where breast cancer spreads are the bones, lungs, liver, and brain. Sometimes it can also affect lymph nodes, skin, or the abdomen.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The most common areas breast cancer spreads to are the: Bones, Lungs, Liver, Brain

Question (100 words): What is the purpose of palliative and supportive care?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The purpose of palliative and supportive care is to help manage symptoms, provide support for you and your family, and improve your quality of life. These teams can include specialist nurses, doctors, psychologists, social workers, and other professionals.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Palliative and supportive care teams are based in the hospital, hospice or community. They can help you with managing symptoms and can provide support for you and your family, friends and carers.

Question (100 words): How can I find a specialist nurse if I don’t have one?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can ask your treatment team or your oncologist to connect you with a specialist nurse. They are there to provide information and support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can talk to your specialist nurse or a member of your treatment team about any questions or concerns you have about the cancer or its treatment, or about the information in this pack.

Question (100 words): What should I do in case of an emergency related to my secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): In case of an emergency, contact your healthcare provider immediately. If it’s outside of regular hours, seek help from a 24-hour service provided by your district nursing team or palliative care team.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If needed, community-based teams can visit you in your home and some offer a 24-hour, on-call service.

Question (100 words): How can I manage the physical effects of secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Managing the physical effects of secondary breast cancer involves working closely with your healthcare team to control symptoms, maintain your health, and improve your quality of life. This may include medication, lifestyle changes, and supportive care.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Coping with physical effects 51

Question (100 words): What is the role of a social worker in my care?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A social worker can help you assess what welfare benefits you may be entitled to, assist you in applying for them, arrange social services, and provide practical help. Some social workers also offer counseling, especially those based in hospices or palliative care teams.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A social worker can assess what welfare benefits you may be entitled to and help you apply for them. They can arrange social services and other practical help. Some social workers offer counselling, particularly those based in hospices or palliative care teams.

Question (100 words): How can I get involved with clinical trials and research studies?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can discuss the possibility of participating in clinical trials and research studies with your oncologist or specialist nurse. They can provide information about ongoing trials and how you can get involved.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Clinical trials and research studies 36

Question (100 words): What should I do to prepare for my appointments with the healthcare team?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To prepare for your appointments, write down any questions or concerns you have, keep a record of your symptoms and side effects using the Personal Organiser provided in this pack, and bring any relevant information or documents to your appointments.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Getting the most out of your appointments 49

Question (100 words): How can I find emotional support from others in a similar situation?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can find emotional support from others in a similar situation by joining Breast Cancer Now’s online discussion Forum, participating in Living with Secondary Breast Cancer groups, or contacting their Helpline for information and support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can make contact with other people with secondary breast cancer through our online discussion Forum (forum.breastcancernow.org) or Living with Secondary Breast Cancer groups (see page 122).

Question (100 words): What is the aim of treatment for secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The aim of treatment for secondary breast cancer is to control and slow down the spread of the cancer, relieve symptoms, maintain health and wellbeing, and give you the best quality of life for as long as possible. It’s important for your doctors and nurses to know your wishes so they can plan the treatment and care that’s right for you.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The aim of treatment for secondary breast cancer is to: Control and slow down the spread of the cancer, Relieve symptoms, Maintain health and wellbeing, Give you the best quality of life for as long as possible
