Question (100 words): What factors are considered when deciding on treatment for secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): When deciding on treatment, factors considered include the location and extent of the secondary breast cancer, any symptoms you have, past treatments, the features of the secondary cancer, your general health, and any other medical conditions you have. Your treatment team will discuss options with you and consider your wishes.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: When making decisions about how best to treat you, your treatment team will consider factors such as: Where the secondary breast cancer is in the body, How extensive it is (how many sites and how large), Any symptoms you have, What treatment you’ve had in the past (if any), The features of the secondary cancer, Your general health and any other medical conditions you have

Question (100 words): How can I get involved in decisions about my treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can get involved in decisions about your treatment by understanding your options, preparing a list of questions, discussing with your family or friends, and bringing a support person to your appointments. Shared decision making is important, and your team should discuss recommendations with you, taking your wishes into account.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your treatment team should discuss any recommendations for treatment with you and take into account your wishes. Shared decision making is an important part of planning treatment and care.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I don’t want to be involved in treatment decisions?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you don’t want to be involved in treatment decisions, there is no pressure on you to be. However, your team will need your consent for treatment. This involves discussing the planned treatments, the aim of the treatment, what to expect, and any potential side effects.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you don’t want to be involved in making decisions about your treatment or you may prefer your treatment team to guide you. There shouldn’t be any pressure on you to be involved if you don’t want to be.

Question (100 words): Is it common to seek a second opinion about treatment options?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, seeking a second opinion about treatment options is very common. Doctors are used to patients asking for second opinions. It can help you feel more confident about your diagnosis and treatment plan, and you may be offered different treatment options.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: People often worry about asking their current specialist for a second opinion as they’re concerned it may cause offence or upset. Requesting a second opinion is very common and doctors are used to patients asking.

Question (100 words): What are the pros and cons of getting a second opinion?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The pros of getting a second opinion include feeling more confident about your diagnosis, finding a specialist easier to talk to, and being offered different treatment options. The cons may include delays in starting treatment, feeling disappointed if the opinions match, and potential travel if the specialist is not local.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The pros and cons of getting a second opinion may be: If the second opinion matches the first you may feel more confident about the diagnosis and treatment, You may find the second specialist easier to talk to about your options, You may be offered different treatment options, The wait to get a second opinion may delay starting your treatment.

Question (100 words): What treatments are available for secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Treatments for secondary breast cancer include hormone therapy, chemotherapy, and targeted (biological) therapies. These treatments may be given alone or in combination. If one treatment stops working, your team will recommend a different one.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Several different types of treatment may be given for secondary breast cancer depending on the features of the cancer. The following treatments may be given alone or in combination.

Question (100 words): What is hormone therapy and who can benefit from it?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Hormone therapy blocks or stops the effect of oestrogen on breast cancer cells. It is prescribed for oestrogen receptor positive (ER+) secondary breast cancer to control and slow down the growth of the cancer. It is often the first treatment recommended and can be taken for as long as it keeps the cancer under control.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Hormone therapies block or stop the effect of oestrogen on breast cancer cells. Different hormone therapy drugs do this in different ways. Hormone therapy will only be prescribed if your secondary breast cancer is ER+.

Question (100 words): How is oestrogen receptor status determined in secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Oestrogen receptor status is determined through testing tissue from a biopsy or after surgery. Most people will have had their primary breast cancer tested for oestrogen receptors. Your specialist may discuss having a biopsy of the secondary breast cancer to retest the hormone receptors if your situation requires it.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Invasive breast cancers are tested for oestrogen receptors using tissue from a biopsy or after surgery. In some people the oestrogen receptors may have changed during the development of the secondary breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What is the role of chemotherapy in treating secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Chemotherapy aims to control and slow down the growth of secondary breast cancer and can help relieve some symptoms. The treatment recommended will depend on previous drugs used and how long ago they were administered. Chemotherapy often has side effects, but these can usually be managed.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Chemotherapy for secondary breast cancer aims to control and slow down the growth of the cancer. It can also help relieve some symptoms.

Question (100 words): What are targeted (biological) therapies and how are they used?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Targeted (biological) therapies are drugs that block the growth and spread of cancer by interfering with processes in cancer cells. They are used to control and slow down the growth of secondary breast cancer. The type of targeted therapy offered depends on the features of your breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: This is a group of drugs that block the growth and spread of cancer. They target and interfere with processes in the cells that cause cancer to grow.

Question (100 words): What is HER2 targeted therapy and who might benefit from it?
Answer (Max 2000 words): HER2 targeted therapy is used for people whose cancer has high levels of the HER2 protein, which makes cancer cells grow. Drugs used include Pertuzumab, Trastuzumab emtansine, Trastuzumab deruxtecan, Trastuzumab, and Tucatinib. If your cancer is HER2 negative, these therapies will not be beneficial.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: HER2 is a protein that makes cancer cells grow. People whose cancer has high levels of HER2 (called HER2 positive) are likely to be offered HER2 targeted therapy.

Question (100 words): What other targeted therapies are available for HER2 negative, ER positive breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Other targeted therapies for HER2 negative, ER positive breast cancer include Abemaciclib, Everolimus, Palbociclib, and Ribociclib. These drugs are used to treat breast cancer that has spread and help control its growth.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some targeted therapies are used to treat HER2 negative, ER positive breast cancer that has spread. These include: Abemaciclib (Verzenios), Everolimus (Afinitor), Palbociclib (Ibrance), Ribociclib (Kisqali)

Question (100 words): What support services are available through social services for patients with secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Social services can provide practical support such as home carers for assistance with daily activities like washing, dressing, and shopping. They may also offer services like meals on wheels. In some areas, you may need to pay for these services.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: This department is part of the local council. It can provide practical information and support, such as home carers to assist with things like washing, dressing and shopping.

Question (100 words): How can a benefits and finance adviser help me?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A benefits adviser provides specialist advice on benefits, tax credits, grants, and loans to help you determine what financial help you may be entitled to. They can also offer advice on insurance, household bills, and pensions.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A benefits adviser gives specialist advice and information on benefits, tax credits, grants and loans to help you work out what financial help you could be entitled to.

Question (100 words): What services do hospices offer to patients with secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Hospices offer support to patients and their families, including inpatient units for short-term stays, home care teams, and day units. They provide free services such as counseling, complementary therapies, and respite care.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Hospices are there to support you and your family and to help you live with secondary breast cancer. Their services are free.

Question (100 words): What is the role of a Marie Curie or Hospice at Home nurse?
Answer (Max 2000 words): These nurses provide hands-on care for people with secondary cancer in their own homes. They can stay with you day or night depending on your needs. This service can be organized by your district nurse or GP.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Marie Curie or Hospice at Home nurse These nurses provide hands-on care for people with secondary cancer in their own homes.

Question (100 words): How can I ensure I’m getting the best care for my secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To ensure you’re getting the best care, ask your treatment team about your treatment options, the aim of your treatment, possible side effects, additional options, clinical trials, referrals to experts, risks and benefits of each treatment, and what to do if you experience new symptoms or side effects.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: To help you feel confident that you’re getting the best care, you may want to ask your treatment team about: What your treatment options are, and why they’re recommending a particular drug or procedure for you, The aim of your treatment, The possible side effects of your treatment and what can be done to help manage them.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience new symptoms or side effects from my treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience new symptoms or side effects from your treatment, contact your treatment team immediately. They will provide guidance on what steps to take and how to manage the symptoms or side effects.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: What to do if you get new symptoms or side effects from your treatment

Question (100 words): How will my treatment team know if the treatment is working?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your treatment team will monitor the effectiveness of your treatment through regular tests and assessments. They will discuss with you when and how these tests will be conducted to determine if the treatment is working.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: How will they know if the treatment is working? When will they test to find out if it is?

Question (100 words): What is Denosumab (Xgeva) used for in treating secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Denosumab (Xgeva) is a targeted therapy used specifically for treating secondary breast cancer that has spread to the bones. It helps reduce bone loss, relieve bone pain, and lower the risk of fractures and spinal cord compression.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Denosumab (Xgeva) is a targeted therapy used for treating secondary breast cancer in the bone.

Question (100 words): What are the common targeted therapy drugs for triple negative breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common targeted therapy drugs for triple negative breast cancer include Atezolizumab (Tecentriq), Pembrolizumab (Keytruda), and Sacituzumab govitecan (Trodelvy). These drugs are used when the cancer is oestrogen receptor negative, progesterone receptor negative, and HER2 receptor negative.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Targeted therapies that can be used to treat some secondary triple negative breast cancers include: • Atezolizumab (Tecentriq) • Pembrolizumab (Keytruda) • Sacituzumab govitecan (Trodelvy)

Question (100 words): How do bisphosphonates and denosumab help in treating secondary breast cancer in the bone?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Bisphosphonates and denosumab help reduce bone loss, relieve bone pain, and lower the risk of fractures and spinal cord compression. They also help control the level of calcium in the blood to prevent hypercalcaemia.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Bisphosphonates and denosumab are drugs used to treat secondary breast cancer in the bone. They work in slightly different ways to reduce bone loss and make complications of secondary breast cancer in the bone less likely to happen.

Question (100 words): What is the purpose of radiotherapy for secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Radiotherapy for secondary breast cancer aims to control the cancer and relieve symptoms such as pain. It is commonly used when the cancer has spread to the bones or brain, and for locally advanced breast cancer in the skin, neck, or under the arm.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Radiotherapy for secondary breast cancer aims to control the cancer and relieve symptoms such as pain.

Question (100 words): What is electrochemotherapy and when is it used?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Electrochemotherapy (ECT) is a treatment for secondary breast cancer that has spread to the skin (skin metastases). It combines a low dose of a chemotherapy drug with electrical impulses to target the treated areas specifically.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Electrochemotherapy, sometimes called ECT, is a treatment for secondary breast cancer that has spread to the skin (skin metastases).

Question (100 words): Is surgery commonly used to treat secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Surgery is not commonly used to treat secondary breast cancer because it is unlikely to remove all cancer cells, especially if the cancer has spread to multiple sites. However, it may be considered for small, accessible secondary cancers or to improve symptoms like bone fractures.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Surgery is not commonly used to treat secondary breast cancer, as it’s unlikely to be able remove all of the cancer cells in the body.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience side effects from my treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience side effects from your treatment, it’s important to report them to your treatment team immediately. They can help you manage them and may adjust your treatment plan. Keeping a symptom and side effects diary can also be helpful.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s important to report any side effects you notice to your treatment team so they can help you manage them as well as possible.

Question (100 words): Can complementary therapies be used alongside medical treatments for secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Some complementary therapies may improve the side effects of medical treatments without affecting their effectiveness. However, others could reduce the effectiveness of medical treatments or cause additional side effects. Always talk to your treatment team before starting any complementary therapy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some complementary therapies are thought to improve the side effects of medical treatments without affecting the way they work. However, others could reduce the effectiveness of medical treatments or cause other side effects.

Question (100 words): What are clinical trials and why might someone with secondary breast cancer participate in one?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Clinical trials are research studies aimed at finding new, more effective treatments with fewer side effects for secondary breast cancer. Participating in a clinical trial may give you access to new treatments not yet available and help advance breast cancer research.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Clinical trials and research studies are common as a treatment option for secondary breast cancer. They aim to find new, more effective treatments that have fewer side effects.

Question (100 words): What are the benefits of taking part in a clinical trial for secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Benefits of taking part in a clinical trial include being one of the first to benefit from a new treatment, receiving a treatment not otherwise available, contributing to research, more frequent hospital visits for closer monitoring, and increased access to nursing support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Benefits of taking part in a clinical trial might include: • Being one of the first people who may benefit from a new treatment • Receiving a treatment that may otherwise not be available

Question (100 words): What are the potential drawbacks of participating in a clinical trial?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Potential drawbacks include unexpected side effects from the new treatment, the new treatment not being more effective than standard treatment, extra hospital visits, additional tests causing anxiety, and not receiving the new treatment if you are in the control group.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Drawbacks of taking part in a clinical trial might include: • Unexpected side effects from the new treatment • The new treatment not being any more effective than the standard treatment

Question (100 words): How can I find out about current clinical trials for secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can find current trials for secondary breast cancer on websites like Be Part of Research (bepartofresearch.nihr.ac.uk) and Cancer Research UK (cancerresearchuk.org). Your local NHS trust website may also have details of trials.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can search for current trials for secondary breast cancer on the following websites: • Be part of research bepartofresearch.nihr.ac.uk • Cancer Research UK cancerresearchuk.org

Question (100 words): What is genomic research and how is it used in treating secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Genomic research involves studying groups of genes found in cancer to identify who will benefit from particular treatments and understand what is causing the cancer to spread. Genomic tests are performed on tissue removed during a biopsy or surgery.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Genomic tests look at groups of genes found in cancer. They may help identify who will benefit from particular treatments and can help doctors understand what is causing the cancer to spread.

Question (100 words): What should I ask before consenting to join a clinical trial?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Before consenting to join a clinical trial, ask about the number of participants, duration of the trial, hospital stays, extra tests, travel reimbursement, data confidentiality, access to trial findings, contact persons, optional parts like blood or tissue donation, questionnaires or diaries, physical and emotional impacts, alternative treatments, results disclosure, treatment location, and reasons for withdrawal.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You might like to ask some of the following questions if they’re not already covered in the information given to you by the trial team.

Question (100 words): How do I consent to join a clinical trial?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After the details are explained, you will be given written information and time to think it over. If you decide to participate, you will sign a form indicating your agreement and understanding, known as informed consent. You can withdraw from the trial at any time.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you decide to take part in a clinical trial, you will be asked to sign a form saying that you agree to take part and understand what is involved. This is called giving informed consent.

Question (100 words): What are the options for getting treatments not routinely available on the NHS?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Options include applying to your local health body, making an individual funding request to the NHS, applying to The Cancer Drugs Fund (in England) or other funding bodies, paying for treatment yourself, using co-payment options, or contacting your local member of parliament.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: To get treatments unavailable on the NHS you can: • Apply to your local health body – the way this is done will depend on where you live in the UK • Make an individual funding request to the NHS in the UK nation where you live

Question (100 words): What is the role of radiotherapy in treating secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Radiotherapy is used to control secondary breast cancer and relieve symptoms such as pain. It is often used when the cancer has spread to the bones or brain, and for locally advanced breast cancer in the skin, neck, or under the arm.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Radiotherapy for secondary breast cancer aims to control the cancer and relieve symptoms such as pain.

Question (100 words): What are the techniques used in radiotherapy for secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The techniques used in radiotherapy for secondary breast cancer include external beam radiotherapy, which directs x-rays to the treatment area, and stereotactic radiotherapy (SRT), which delivers high doses of radiation to the tumour from multiple angles while sparing surrounding tissues.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The techniques used are: • External beam radiotherapy – x-rays delivered by a machine which directs a beam of radiation to the area being treated • Stereotactic radiotherapy (SRT) which gives radiotherapy from many different angles around the body.

Question (100 words): How long does a course of radiotherapy for secondary breast cancer usually last?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A course of radiotherapy for secondary breast cancer is usually short, consisting of a few treatment sessions or sometimes only one session. It is often used alongside other treatments.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A course of radiotherapy for secondary breast cancer is usually short. You may have a few treatment sessions or sometimes only one. Radiotherapy is often used alongside other treatments.

Question (100 words): What should I know about the side effects of treatments for secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Treatments for secondary breast cancer can cause side effects, which vary from person to person. Before starting treatment, discuss potential side effects with your treatment team and report any you experience. Your dose may be adjusted to manage side effects, and you can use a symptom and side effects diary to track them.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Treatments for secondary breast cancer cause side effects. Everyone reacts differently to treatment and some people have more side effects than others.

Question (100 words): What is palliative and supportive care, and how can it help me?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Palliative and supportive care focuses on symptom control and support, helping to prevent and relieve symptoms and deal with physical, emotional, social, and spiritual effects of secondary breast cancer. It involves a team of healthcare professionals and can be accessed at any stage of your treatment. It can be particularly helpful for managing pain, improving fatigue, and providing psychological support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Palliative and supportive care also focuses on symptom control and support. Many people benefit from having advice from a palliative care team much sooner, alongside their medical treatment.

Question (100 words): Can I take a break from my cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, your treatment team may suggest a break from treatment if you find it difficult to manage daily routines alongside ongoing side effects. You can also choose to take a break for personal reasons. Discuss this with your treatment team to understand the possible effects on your condition.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your treatment team can talk this through with you and explain the possible effect on your condition.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I decide to stop cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you decide to stop cancer treatment, it’s important to communicate this decision to your treatment team. They will continue to provide supportive care and symptom control. It’s a personal decision, and you shouldn’t feel guilty about choosing what’s right for you.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you don’t want to carry on with treatment, try not to feel guilty about something that you feel is the right step for you.

Question (100 words): How often should I have hospital appointments for monitoring my condition?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You should have regular hospital appointments with your treatment team to assess your physical and emotional well-being, discuss new symptoms, and manage day-to-day activities. These appointments are crucial for monitoring your condition and making necessary adjustments to your treatment plan.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You should have regular hospital appointments with your treatment team to check how you are feeling both physically and emotionally.

Question (100 words): What are tumour marker tests, and how reliable are they?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Tumour marker tests are blood tests that measure proteins produced by the body in response to cancer. However, their reliability is unclear as they can be raised for various reasons, including other benign conditions or treatments. They are a small part of monitoring and not often used alone to make treatment decisions.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: These are proteins found in the blood that may be produced by the body in response to the presence of cancer. However, it’s not clear how reliable the measurement of blood tumour markers is.

Question (100 words): When are scans usually done for secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Scans may not be routinely done but are planned by your oncologist to assess how secondary breast cancer is responding to treatment or if you have new or worsening symptoms. If you’re in a clinical trial, you may have scans more frequently.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Scans may not always be routinely done but may be planned by your oncologist to see how the secondary breast cancer is responding to a new treatment or if you have new or worsening symptoms.

Question (100 words): How can I prepare for my hospital appointments?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To prepare for your hospital appointments, write a list of what you want to discuss, including your physical and emotional well-being, any new or lasting symptoms or side effects, and any questions you have. Having a family member or friend with you can also be helpful.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Write a list of what you want to discuss, including how you’re feeling physically and emotionally, any new or lasting symptoms or side effects, and any questions you have.

Question (100 words): How can I get copies of letters about my treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You are entitled to copies of letters about you from one healthcare professional to another. These can be provided in different languages, large print, or as audio recordings. Talk to your treatment team about how to request these copies.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You’re entitled to copies of letters about you from one healthcare professional to another.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience pain due to secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience pain, it’s important to talk to your treatment team or GP. Pain relief is a crucial part of cancer care, and there are various methods available, including medications, complementary therapies, and other treatments like bisphosphonates or radiotherapy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Pain relief is a very important part of the care of anyone with cancer.

Question (100 words): How can I describe my pain to my doctor effectively?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To describe your pain effectively, keep a pain diary noting the severity, location, frequency, duration, type of pain, what makes it worse or better, and any medications you’ve taken. This will help your doctor find the best treatment for your pain.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Keeping a pain diary can help you do this.

Question (100 words): What is the three-step approach to pain control?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The three-step approach to pain control starts with mild pain relief taken regularly, moves to moderate pain relief, and then to strong pain relief, often morphine-based, if necessary. Your doctor may use a combination of short- and long-acting drugs.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your doctor or nurse will probably recommend a frequently used three-step approach to pain control.

Question (100 words): Can morphine-based pain relief make my cancer worse?
Answer (Max 2000 words): No, morphine-based pain relief does not necessarily mean your cancer is getting worse. It is highly effective for controlling many types of pain and can improve your quality of life. If you experience side effects, your doctor may switch to a different pain relief.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Morphine-based pain relief is extremely effective for controlling many types of pain which can improve your quality of life.

Question (100 words): Are there other treatments besides medication for pain relief?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, other treatments for pain relief include anti-inflammatory drugs, steroids, drugs usually used for depression or epilepsy, bisphosphonates, denosumab, and radiotherapy. Complementary therapies can also be helpful in reducing symptoms like stress and anxiety.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Doctors often use other drugs alongside pain relief.

Question (100 words): How often should my pain be assessed by healthcare professionals?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your pain should be assessed regularly by your nurse or doctor to ensure it remains under control. Inform your treatment team if you experience any changes in pain, new pain, or if existing pain worsens or doesn’t improve with treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s important that your pain is assessed regularly by your nurse or doctor to make sure it remains under control.

Question (100 words): Can pain medications affect my ability to drive?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, some pain medications, including morphine and drugs used to treat anxiety or insomnia, can affect your ability to drive. It’s an offence to drive if you have certain prescription drugs above a particular level in your blood. Consult your doctor, pharmacist, and insurance provider for more information.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s an offence to drive if you have certain prescription drugs (including morphine and some drugs used to treat anxiety or insomnia) above a particular level in the blood, whether or not your driving is impaired.

Question (100 words): What should I discuss during my hospital appointments?
Answer (Max 2000 words): During your hospital appointments, discuss how you’re feeling physically and emotionally, any new or lasting symptoms or side effects, and any questions you have. It’s important to communicate your concerns and what information you would like from your healthcare professionals.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Say what’s important to you. It helps healthcare professionals to care for you effectively if they know what your concerns are and what information you would like.

Question (100 words): How can I ensure I understand the information given during my appointments?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To ensure you understand the information given during your appointments, don’t hesitate to ask questions if something is unclear. If you don’t feel you’ve had a full enough explanation, ask again. Your healthcare professional should be able to explain why if a definite answer isn’t possible.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you don’t feel you’ve had an answer to your question, a full enough explanation or been given the reasoning behind any part of your treatment and care, or don’t understand any information you’ve been given, ask again.

Question (100 words): What is the ‘Please Write to Me’ initiative?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The ‘Please Write to Me’ initiative encourages doctors to write to their patients after a clinic appointment in language they can easily understand. This helps patients remember what was discussed in the clinic and gives them confidence that they are included in decisions about their care.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The ‘Please Write to Me’ initiative encourages doctors to write to their patients after a clinic appointment in language they can easily understand.

Question (100 words): How can I cope with the physical effects of secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To cope with the physical effects of secondary breast cancer, treatment aims to improve symptoms so you can continue enjoying your activities. Common symptoms depend on where the cancer has spread and may include pain, which can be managed with various treatments and therapies.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Treatment aims to improve these so you can carry on doing the things you enjoy for as long as possible.

Question (100 words): What complementary therapies can help with pain and other symptoms?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Complementary therapies, such as relaxation and wellbeing practices, have been shown to be helpful in reducing symptoms like stress and anxiety, which may contribute to pain in cancer patients. More information can be found on the breastcancernow.org website.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: When used alongside conventional drug treatment, some complementary therapies have been shown to be helpful in reducing symptoms such as stress and anxiety which may contribute to pain in cancer patients.

Question (100 words): What are the common signs of fatigue in secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common signs of fatigue include tiredness unrelated to activity, persistent tiredness despite rest, feeling weak, sleeping difficulties, confusion, breathlessness, irritability, and depression.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Common signs of fatigue include: • Tiredness that is not related to any activity • Tiredness that doesn’t go away or keeps returning however much rest or sleep you have • Feeling weak, as though you have no strength • Sleeping more or difficulty sleeping • Feeling confused, lack of concentration or unable to focus your thoughts • Feeling breathless or light-headed • Feeling irritable, sad or depressed

Question (100 words): How can I manage my energy levels if I have secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can manage your energy levels by pacing yourself, prioritizing tasks, balancing activity with rest, engaging in gentle physical activity, controlling pain, maintaining a nutritious diet, and seeking help when needed.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Tips for managing your energy levels: • Be realistic about what you can do and pace yourself • Prioritise tasks and plan your days so you have a balance of activity and rest • Stop any activity before you become too tired, so you keep some energy in reserve • Prepare for a special occasion or days out by planning some additional rest before and after • Do some physical activity. Evidence suggests that some physical activity can help improve fatigue. Gentle strengthening exercises and short walks

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience breathlessness with secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can relieve breathlessness by using relaxation and breathing techniques, physiotherapy, cooling your face with cold water, using a fan, or sitting near an open window. Exercise and singing can also help.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There are several practical things you can do to help ease breathlessness. Cooling your face with cold water, using a hand-held fan or sitting near an open window can help. You may find exercise can help relieve breathlessness. There’s increasing evidence that singing regularly as part of a group is good for your general health and wellbeing and can be a great activity to improve lung health. Some people find singing helps their breathlessness, strengthening the muscles used to breathe, so they

Question (100 words): What causes nausea and vomiting in secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Nausea and vomiting can be caused by the cancer itself, its treatment, or emotional side effects such as anxiety.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you feel sick (nausea) or are being sick (vomiting), it’s likely to be because of the cancer, its treatment or emotional side effects such as anxiety.

Question (100 words): How can constipation be managed in secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Constipation can be managed by eating high-fiber foods, drinking plenty of water, exercising, and using laxatives if necessary.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Try to eat fresh fruit and vegetables and other high-fibre foods such as wholemeal bread or bran. Increasing the amount of water you drink, including some fruit juice in your diet, and daily exercise may also help. Laxatives can help relieve the constipation, especially if you’re on regular pain relief. Your GP, treatment team or palliative and supportive care team can prescribe these for you.

Question (100 words): What dietary tips can help if I have a poor appetite with secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Eat smaller amounts often, add high-energy ingredients to meals, avoid strong-smelling foods, snack on high-calorie foods, take your time eating, and consider a small alcoholic drink before meals to stimulate appetite.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have problems eating, the following tips may help: • Eat smaller amounts often rather than trying to eat a large plateful of food at set mealtimes • Add high-energy ingredients and foods containing protein to your meals. For example, add cream or butter to mashed potatoes and vegetables, grated cheese to soups, and syrup or jam to porridge or desserts • Avoid strong-smelling foods that may put you off your meal • Snack on high-calorie foods and drinks such as chocolate, cake, crisps, nuts

Question (100 words): What are the symptoms of a blood clot in secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Symptoms include pain, redness, heat, and swelling of the arm or leg, shortness of breath, chest pain or tightness, and unexplained cough or coughing up blood.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you experience any of the following symptoms contact your local A&E department, GP or treatment team straight away: • Pain, redness/discolouration, heat and swelling of the arm or leg • Swelling, redness or tenderness where a central line is inserted to give chemotherapy, for example in the arm, chest area or up into the neck • Shortness of breath • Pain or tightness in the chest • Unexplained cough or coughing up blood

Question (100 words): What are the symptoms of hypercalcaemia in secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Symptoms include feeling sick, constipation, drowsiness, extreme thirst, weakness, and confusion.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If the calcium level in the blood is too high you may get symptoms such as: • Feeling sick and being sick • Constipation • Drowsiness • Feeling very thirsty • Weakness and confusion

Question (100 words): What should I do if I suspect I have febrile neutropenia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Contact your hospital immediately if you have a high or low temperature, suddenly feel unwell, or experience symptoms of infection such as a sore throat, cough, frequent urination, or feeling cold or shivery.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your treatment team may give you guidelines to follow for reporting signs of an infection, but generally you should contact your hospital immediately if you experience any of the following: • A high temperature (over 37.5°C) or low temperature (under 36°C), or whatever your treatment team has advised • Suddenly feeling unwell, even with a normal temperature • Symptoms of an infection, for example a sore throat, a cough, a need to pass urine frequently or feeling cold or shivery

Question (100 words): What are the symptoms of spinal cord compression in secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Symptoms include severe or unexplained back pain, pain that changes with movement, difficulty walking, numbness or pins and needles in extremities, and problems controlling urine or bowel movements.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Symptoms can include: • Severe or unexplained back pain which may also be felt around the front of the chest and belly • Pain in the back which changes when you lie down, stand up or lift something • Difficulty walking • Numbness or pins and needles in the fingers, toes or bottom • Problems controlling urine or bowel movements

Question (100 words): How is spinal cord compression usually treated?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Spinal cord compression is usually treated with radiotherapy and steroids. Some people may have surgery, and a combination of all three treatments may also be used.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Spinal cord compression is usually treated with radiotherapy and steroids. Some people may have surgery. A combination of all three treatments may also be used.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience symptoms of spinal cord compression?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Seek medical advice without delay to reduce the risk of any long-lasting effects. An MRI scan is usually done to confirm the diagnosis.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s important to know who to contact at the hospital if you have any of these symptoms at any time. Spinal cord compression can have serious effects if not diagnosed quickly, so seek medical advice without delay to reduce the risk of any long-lasting effects. An MRI scan is usually done to confirm the diagnosis.

Question (100 words): How can I manage weight gain due to secondary breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Talk to your treatment team or a dietitian for advice on diet and exercise. Your GP can refer you to local exercise programs.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If weight gain becomes a problem for you, it might help to talk to your treatment team or a dietitian who can advise you about diet and monitor your weight. If you want to exercise, speak to your treatment team to find out if there are any limitations on the type or level of exercise you can do. Your GP can refer you to an exercise programme in your local area. These can be helpful to people with secondary breast cancer, including those wanting to lose weight.

Question (100 words): What can I do to help relieve stress and anxiety contributing to fatigue?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Counselling, talking therapies, or complementary therapies can help relieve stress and anxiety, which may contribute to fatigue.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Counselling, talking therapies or complementary therapies can help relieve stress and anxiety, which may contribute to fatigue.

Question (100 words): What medications can help control nausea and vomiting?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Anti-sickness medications can help control nausea and vomiting. It’s important to find the cause to manage it effectively.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: In most cases this can be controlled using anti-sickness medication. It’s important for your doctor to find the cause so that it can be managed effectively.

Question (100 words): How can I manage diarrhoea caused by secondary breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Drink plenty of fluids, avoid high-fiber and fatty foods, eat little and often, and inform your treatment team if you have more than four episodes of diarrhoea in 24 hours.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Try to drink plenty of fluids during the day, avoid foods high in fibre, eat little and often and avoid fatty foods. You may be given specific advice, but generally if you have more than four episodes of diarrhoea in 24 hours, tell your treatment team or palliative and supportive care team.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I have difficulty maintaining my weight due to secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Talk to your GP or treatment team about dietary supplements or consult a dietitian for specialist advice. You may be prescribed medication to help stimulate your appetite.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you still aren’t eating enough or you’re losing weight, talk to your GP or treatment team about dietary supplements or ask to speak to a dietitian for specialist advice. In some circumstances you may be prescribed medication to help stimulate your appetite.

Question (100 words): What are the potential side effects of pain relief medication in secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Some pain relief can cause nausea or vomiting when you first start to take it, although this usually wears off. You may be prescribed an anti-sickness tablet to prevent this.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some pain relief can cause you to feel sick or be sick when you first start to take it, although this usually wears off. You may be prescribed an anti-sickness tablet to take with your pain relief to prevent this happening.

Question (100 words): How can I get support for managing fatigue and other symptoms?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Tell your doctor or palliative care team about your symptoms so you can be fully assessed. You can be referred to specialists like occupational therapists for additional support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Tell your doctor or palliative care team about the fatigue so you can be fully assessed. Causes such as difficulty sleeping or anaemia can be treated. Ask to be referred to a specialist, such as an occupational therapist, in your local palliative and supportive care team. They may be able to suggest adaptations, equipment and ideas that may help you manage fatigue.

Question (100 words): What practical steps can I take to manage breathlessness?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Use relaxation and breathing techniques, physiotherapy, cooling your face with cold water, using a fan, or sitting near an open window. Exercise and singing can also help.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There are several practical things you can do to help ease breathlessness. Cooling your face with cold water, using a hand-held fan or sitting near an open window can help. You may find exercise can help relieve breathlessness. There’s increasing evidence that singing regularly as part of a group is good for your general health and wellbeing and can be a great activity to improve lung health. Some people find singing helps their breathlessness, strengthening the muscles used to breathe, so they

Question (100 words): What is Abemaciclib and how is it used in breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Abemaciclib, also known as Verzenio, is a targeted therapy used to treat ER positive, HER2 negative secondary breast cancer. It belongs to a group of drugs called CDK 4/6 inhibitors, which help control cell growth and division.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Abemaciclib : also called Verzenio. A targeted therapy used to treat ER positive, HER2 negative secondary breast cancer, and one of a group of drugs called CDK 4/6 inhibitors.

Question (100 words): What is Abraxane and how is it administered?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Abraxane, also known as nab-paclitaxel, is a chemotherapy drug used to treat breast cancer. It is administered intravenously (IV), meaning it is injected directly into a vein.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Abraxane : also called nab-paclitaxel. A chemotherapy drug used to treat breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What are the common side effects of Adriamycin?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Adriamycin, also known as doxorubicin, is a chemotherapy drug used in breast cancer treatment. Common side effects include nausea, vomiting, hair loss (alopecia), and an increased risk of infections due to lowered white blood cell count.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Adriamycin : also known as doxorubicin. A chemotherapy drug used in breast cancer. One of a group of chemotherapy drugs known as anthracyclines.

Question (100 words): What is Alpelisib and when is it used?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Alpelisib, also called Piqray, is a targeted therapy used to treat ER positive, HER2 negative secondary breast cancer. It is typically used in combination with other treatments to manage the disease.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Alpelisib : also called Piqray. A targeted therapy used to treat ER positive, HER2 negative secondary breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What is Anastrozole and how does it work?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Anastrozole, also known as Arimidex, is a hormone therapy used to treat postmenopausal women with oestrogen receptor positive (ER+) breast cancer. It works by reducing the amount of oestrogen in the body, thereby slowing or stopping the growth of cancer cells that rely on oestrogen.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Anastrozole : also known as Arimidex. A hormone therapy and one of a group of drugs called aromatase inhibitors.

Question (100 words): What are anthracyclines and how are they used in breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Anthracyclines are a group of chemotherapy drugs commonly used to treat breast cancer. They include doxorubicin and epirubicin. These drugs work by interfering with the DNA of cancer cells, preventing them from growing and dividing.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Anthracyclines : a group of chemotherapy drugs commonly used to treat breast cancer. Doxorubicin and epirubicin are both anthracycline drugs.

Question (100 words): What are aromatase inhibitors and who can benefit from them?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Aromatase inhibitors are a group of hormone therapies used to treat postmenopausal women with oestrogen receptor positive (ER+) breast cancer. They work by blocking the enzyme aromatase, which reduces the amount of oestrogen in the body and helps slow or stop the growth of cancer cells that rely on oestrogen.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Aromatase inhibitors : a group of hormone therapies used to treat postmenopausal women with oestrogen receptor positive (ER+) breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What is Atezolizumab and how does it work?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Atezolizumab, also called Tecentriq, is a targeted (biological) therapy referred to as an immunotherapy. It works by helping the body’s immune system recognize and attack cancer cells.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Atezolizumab : also called Tecentriq. A targeted (biological) therapy, it’s also referred to as an immunotherapy.

Question (100 words): What is Bevacizumab and how is it used?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Bevacizumab, also known as Avastin, is a targeted therapy that works by stopping cancer cells from developing their own blood supply (angiogenesis). It is not routinely used in the UK for breast cancer treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Bevacizumab : also known as Avastin. A targeted therapy that works by stopping cancer cells from developing their own blood supply (angiogenesis). Not routinely used in the UK.

Question (100 words): What are bisphosphonates and why are they used in breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Bisphosphonates are a group of drugs used to treat the effects of secondary breast cancer in the bone. They help to strengthen the bones and reduce the risk of fractures.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Bisphosphonates : a group of drugs used to treat the effects of secondary breast cancer in the bone.

Question (100 words): What is a bone scan and why is it important in breast cancer diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A bone scan is a test used to help identify any changes such as tumours, infection, or fractures in the bones. It is important in breast cancer diagnosis because it can detect bone metastases, which are cancer cells that have spread from the breast to the bones.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Bone scan : a test to help identify any changes such as tumours, infection or fractures in the bones.

Question (100 words): What are brain metastases and how are they detected?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Brain metastases are cancer cells that have spread from the breast to the brain. They are detected using imaging tests such as MRI or CT scans, which can show the presence of tumours in the brain.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Brain metastases : also known as secondary breast cancer in the brain. Cancer cells that have spread from the breast to the brain.

Question (100 words): What is Capecitabine and how is it administered?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Capecitabine, also known as Xeloda, is a chemotherapy drug used to treat breast cancer. It is administered as a tablet, making it convenient for patients to take at home.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Capecitabine : also known as Xeloda. A chemotherapy drug used to treat breast cancer, given as a tablet.

Question (100 words): What is Carboplatin and how is it used in breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Carboplatin is a chemotherapy drug used to treat breast cancer. It works by interfering with the DNA of cancer cells, preventing them from growing and dividing.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Carboplatin : a chemotherapy drug used to treat breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What is cardiotoxicity and which treatments can cause it?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Cardiotoxicity is damage to the heart muscle, causing the heart to become weaker and less efficient in pumping. It can be caused by some chemotherapy and targeted therapy drugs, such as anthracyclines and certain HER2-targeted therapies.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Cardiotoxicity : damage to the heart muscle causing the heart to become weaker and less efficient in pumping. May be caused by some chemotherapy and targeted therapy drugs.

Question (100 words): What are CDK inhibitors and how are they used in breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): CDK inhibitors are a group of targeted (biological) therapies including abemaciclib, palbociclib, and ribociclib. They are often used alongside hormone (endocrine) therapy to treat ER positive, HER2 negative secondary breast cancer by helping control cell growth and division.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: CDK inhibitors : a group of targeted (biological) therapies including abemaciclib, palbociclib and ribociclib, often used alongside hormone (endocrine) therapy.

Question (100 words): What is chemotherapy and how does it work?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Chemotherapy is a treatment aimed at destroying cancer cells using anti-cancer drugs. These drugs work by interfering with the ability of cancer cells to grow and divide, ultimately leading to their death.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Chemotherapy : treatment aimed at destroying cancer cells using anti-cancer drugs.

Question (100 words): What is a CT scan and why is it used in breast cancer diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A CT (computerised tomography) scan is a type of scan that uses x-rays to take detailed pictures across the body. It is used in breast cancer diagnosis to detect the presence of tumours, assess the spread of cancer, and evaluate the effectiveness of treatments.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: CT (computerised tomography) scan : a type of scan that uses x-rays to take detailed pictures across the body.

Question (100 words): What is Denosumab and how is it used in breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Denosumab is a targeted therapy used to treat the effects of secondary breast cancer in the bone. It helps to strengthen the bones and reduce the risk of fractures by inhibiting the activity of cells that break down bone.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Denosumab : a targeted therapy used to treat the effects of secondary breast cancer in the bone.

Question (100 words): What is Docetaxel and how is it administered?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Docetaxel, also known as Taxotere, is a chemotherapy drug used to treat breast cancer. It belongs to a group of chemotherapy drugs called taxanes and is administered intravenously (IV), meaning it is injected directly into a vein.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Docetaxel : a chemotherapy drug also known as Taxotere. One of a group of chemotherapy drugs called taxanes.

Question (100 words): What is secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Secondary breast cancer, also known as advanced, stage 4, or metastatic breast cancer, is breast cancer that has spread beyond the breast and the lymph nodes under the arm to other parts of the body.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Secondary breast cancer : breast cancer that has spread beyond the breast and the lymph nodes under the arm to other parts of the body. Also known as advanced, stage 4 or metastatic breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What is radiotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Radiotherapy is the use of high-energy X-rays to destroy cancer cells.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Radiotherapy : the use of high energy x-rays to destroy cancer cells.

Question (100 words): What is Ribociclib and what is it used for?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Ribociclib, also called Kisqali, is a targeted therapy used to treat ER positive, HER2 negative secondary breast cancer. It belongs to a group of drugs called CDK 4/6 inhibitors.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Ribociclib : also called Kisqali. A targeted therapy used to treat ER positive, HER2 negative secondary breast cancer, and one of a group of drugs called CDK 4/6 inhibitors.

Question (100 words): What is Sacituzumab govitecan and what type of cancer does it treat?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Sacituzumab govitecan, also called Trodelvy, is a type of targeted therapy used to treat some triple negative breast cancers.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Sacituzumab govitecan : also called Trodelvy. A type of targeted therapy for some triple negative breast cancers.

Question (100 words): What is spinal cord compression and what can cause it?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Spinal cord compression is pressure on the spinal cord and nerves. It can be caused by cancer growing in, or spreading into, the bones of the spine, which can result in permanent damage to the spinal cord.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Spinal cord compression : pressure on the spinal cord and nerves. It can be caused by the cancer growing in, or spreading into, the bones of the spine and can result in permanent damage to the spinal cord.

Question (100 words): What does stable disease mean in the context of cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Stable disease means that the cancer has stayed the same size or has grown only a little.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Stable disease : the cancer has stayed the same size or has grown only a little.

Question (100 words): What is stereotactic radiotherapy and what is it used for?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Stereotactic radiotherapy, also known as radiosurgery, is a precise radiation treatment used in secondary breast cancer. It may also be referred to as Gamma Knife or CyberKnife.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Stereotactic radiotherapy (also known as radiosurgery ): a precise radiation treatment used in secondary breast cancer. May also be referred to as Gamma Knife or CyberKnife.

Question (100 words): What are steroids used for in cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Steroids may be given as part of cancer treatment to help with side effects of chemotherapy such as nausea and vomiting, or to control some symptoms caused by cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Steroids : may be given as part of cancer treatment, for example to help with side effects of chemotherapy such as nausea and vomiting, or to control some symptoms caused by cancer.

Question (100 words): What is Tamoxifen and what type of breast cancer does it treat?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Tamoxifen is a hormone therapy drug used to treat oestrogen receptor positive breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Tamoxifen : a hormone therapy drug used to treat oestrogen receptor positive breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What are targeted (biological) therapies?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Targeted (biological) therapies are a group of drugs that block the growth and spread of cancer by targeting and interfering with processes in the cells that cause cancer to grow.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Targeted (biological) therapies : a group of drugs that block the growth and spread of cancer. They target and interfere with processes in the cells that cause cancer to grow.

Question (100 words): What is thrombosis and what is a deep vein thrombosis (DVT)?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Thrombosis occurs when blood forms a clot. If the clot occurs in a major vein, the condition is known as a deep vein thrombosis or DVT.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Thrombosis : occurs when blood forms a clot. If the clot occurs in a major vein, the condition is known as a deep vein thrombosis or DVT.

Question (100 words): What is Trastuzumab and what type of breast cancer does it treat?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Trastuzumab is a targeted therapy used to treat HER2 positive breast cancer. It belongs to a group of drugs called monoclonal antibodies.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Trastuzumab : a targeted therapy used to treat HER2 positive breast cancer, and one of a group of drugs called monoclonal antibodies.

Question (100 words): What is triple negative breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Triple negative breast cancer is the name given to breast cancer that is oestrogen receptor negative (ER-), progesterone receptor negative (PR-), and HER2 negative.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Triple negative breast cancer : the name given to breast cancer that is: • Oestrogen receptor negative (ER-) • Progesterone receptor negative (PR-) • HER2 negative

Question (100 words): What are tumour markers?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Tumour markers are substances produced by cancer, or by the body as a response to cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Tumour markers : substances produced by cancer, or by the body as a response to cancer.

Question (100 words): What is Vinorelbine and what is it used for?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Vinorelbine, also known as Navelbine, is a chemotherapy drug used to treat breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Vinorelbine : also known as Navelbine. A chemotherapy drug used to treat breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What is an X-ray used for in medical imaging?
Answer (Max 2000 words): An X-ray is used to produce images of dense tissues in the body such as bone or lungs.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: X-ray: used to produce images of dense tissues in the body such as bone or lungs.

Question (100 words): What is a holistic needs assessment (HNA)?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A holistic needs assessment (HNA) helps you think about your needs and concerns across all areas of your life and find possible solutions. It usually includes a checklist or simple set of questions, a discussion with a healthcare professional, a written plan of care, and referrals to other healthcare professionals for care and support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A holistic needs assessment or HNA helps you to think about your needs and concerns across all areas of your life and find possible solutions.

Question (100 words): What are the benefits of a holistic needs assessment (HNA)?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The benefits of an HNA include getting support and information specific to your needs, prioritising your most important concerns, being referred to relevant organisations and services for help, and planning ahead.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Benefits of an HNA An HNA can help you: • Get support and information specific to your needs • Prioritise your most important concerns • Be referred to relevant organisations and services for help • Plan ahead

Question (100 words): What are some techniques to cope with anxiety and stress?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Techniques to cope with anxiety and stress include distraction, relaxation, visualisation, meditation, mindfulness, cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT), counselling, and acceptance and commitment therapy. Complementary therapies like aromatherapy, massage, or reflexology can also help.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There are various techniques, talking therapies and apps specifically designed to help you cope at a difficult time, including: • Distraction: learning to focus on the things around you so you can shut out negative thoughts • Relaxation, visualisation and meditation: can be used separately or together to reduce stress and tension, relax the mind and body and help improve wellbeing • Mindfulness: focusing on the present moment to reduce stress and improve quality of life. • Cognitive behavioural

Question (100 words): What are the symptoms of depression and when should I seek help?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Symptoms of depression include loss of enjoyment and interest in everyday things, persistent negative thoughts, social withdrawal, tearfulness, difficulty concentrating, sleep disturbances, changes in appetite, and feeling very low or having suicidal thoughts. Seek help quickly if you’re feeling very low or thinking about taking your own life.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Symptoms of depression can include: • Loss of enjoyment and interest in everyday things and experiences • Loss of interest in your appearance • Persistent thoughts such as ‘I can’t be bothered’ or ‘What’s the point?’ • Not going out or socialising • Feeling persistently tearful and irritable • Difficulty concentrating • Difficulty sleeping or wanting to sleep all the time • Loss of appetite or overeating • Feeling very low or having suicidal thoughts If you or those close to you are worried beca

Question (100 words): How can I find local support groups for secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can find local support groups through your specialist nurse, chemotherapy or palliative care nurse, or local cancer information centre. Breast Cancer Now also offers support groups both in-person and online.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your specialist nurse, chemotherapy or palliative care nurse or local cancer information centre can give you the details of any support groups in your local area, nationally and online.

Question (100 words): What resources are available for emotional support?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Resources for emotional support include Breast Cancer Now’s Helpline, Samaritans for confidential support, and the Mental Health Foundation’s resources. Additionally, local cancer centres and online forums can provide further support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Samaritans provides confidential, non-judgemental emotional support, 24 hours a day for people who are experiencing feelings of distress or despair.

Question (100 words): How can I manage the information overload after my diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To manage information overload, keep a record of healthcare professionals' contact details, ask your treatment team to explain anything you don’t understand, and utilize local and national support services for additional information.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Keeping a record of the names of healthcare professionals and how to contact them can help you get information when you need it.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I suspect my cancer has spread?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you suspect your cancer has spread, contact your healthcare team immediately. They need to be informed about any new concerns or symptoms you may be experiencing.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your team will especially want to hear from you if you’re concerned that your cancer may have spread, either in its current area(s) or to other parts of the body.

Question (100 words): How might a cancer diagnosis affect my relationship with my partner?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A cancer diagnosis can lead to emotional and practical changes in your relationship. Both partners may experience worry, changes in roles, and emotional distress. Open communication and seeking support can help navigate these changes.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A diagnosis of cancer can affect your relationship with those closest to you, and many people worry how their loved ones will cope.

Question (100 words): What should I discuss with my partner about my diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Discuss practical matters, emotional feelings, and any changes in your physical and sexual needs. Open communication can help both partners cope better with the diagnosis.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You’ll probably have lots to discuss, and you may need to make time and space to talk to each other about practical things, as well as how you’re both feeling.

Question (100 words): How can I talk to my children about my secondary breast cancer diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Explain the situation as simply as possible, depending on their age. Be truthful, avoid making promises you can’t keep, and encourage them to ask questions. Additional support may be available through schools or palliative care services.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: How much children can understand about secondary breast cancer will depend on their age, so try to explain the situation to them as simply as you can.

Question (100 words): What impact might secondary breast cancer have on my sexual relationship?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Secondary breast cancer and its treatment can affect your sexual relationship due to physical changes, emotional impact, and side effects like vaginal dryness from hormone therapies. Communication with your partner and healthcare team can help address these issues.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The physical and emotional impact of having secondary breast cancer and its treatment can affect how you feel about yourself, and your sexual needs may change depending on how well you feel.

Question (100 words): Can I plan a family after being diagnosed with secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Many treatments for secondary breast cancer affect fertility and are not suitable during pregnancy. Discuss your options with your treatment team and consider speaking with a clinical psychologist or counsellor for additional support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Many of the treatments for secondary breast cancer will affect your ability to have children and are not suitable while pregnant due to the effect these could have on a growing baby.

Question (100 words): How can I handle the reactions of my family and friends to my diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Communicate your feelings and needs clearly to your family and friends. Joining a support group or seeking professional counselling can also help you manage their reactions and find the support you need.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may feel friends and family don’t understand the support you need. If you can talk to them about how you’re feeling and what you need from them, they can begin to understand how best to support you.

Question (100 words): Should I consider genetic testing for breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you’re concerned about a family history of breast cancer, discuss this with your treatment team. They can refer you for genetic testing and counselling to understand the process and potential impacts.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re concerned this may be the case for you, and you have not discussed this before, talk to your treatment team. They can refer you for an assessment if necessary.

Question (100 words): What kind of practical help can friends offer during my treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Friends can offer practical help such as cooking meals, running errands, or providing transportation to appointments. Clearly communicate your needs to them.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Practical help may be easier to find from friends than emotional support.

Question (100 words): How can I accept help from others without feeling guilty?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Realize that many people want to help and it’s okay to accept their offers. Be clear about what you need and don’t hesitate to say no to things that aren’t right for you.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: I learned to accept help from friends – something I initially was not comfortable doing.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I feel overwhelmed by the support from my loved ones?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Communicate your feelings and needs to your loved ones. Joining a support group or seeking professional help can also provide additional support and understanding.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may be overwhelmed by the support and concern from those close to you.

Question (100 words): How can I find more information about secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can find more information through local cancer information centres, Breast Cancer Now’s Helpline, website, and publications. Additionally, there are various organizations listed that can provide further resources.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast Cancer Now’s free Helpline can also answer any questions about secondary breast cancer, as well as listen to and talk through your concerns.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I have new concerns or symptoms?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Contact your healthcare team immediately if you have any new concerns or symptoms. They need to be informed to provide appropriate care and support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s important to contact someone if you have any new concerns.

Question (100 words): How can I cope with the emotional impact of my diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Seek support from healthcare professionals, join support groups, and consider talking to a counsellor or therapist. Open communication with loved ones and utilizing available resources can help you cope.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Joining a cancer support group to meet other people with a similar experience may be helpful.

Question (100 words): What are the benefits of talking openly with my partner about my diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Talking openly can help both partners cope with emotions, practical matters, and changes in the relationship. It can strengthen your bond and provide mutual support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Being able to talk openly with your partner is important, even though it’s natural to want to protect them from any distress or sadness.

Question (100 words): How can I manage changes in my sexual relationship due to my diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Discuss physical and emotional changes with your partner and healthcare team. Explore alternative forms of intimacy such as kissing, hugging, or massage. Seek treatments for side effects like vaginal dryness.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Talking to each other about your physical and sexual needs can help you deal with any tensions or changes in this area of your relationship.

Question (100 words): What resources are available for partners and carers of someone with secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Resources include support from treatment teams, palliative care teams, local cancer centres, and organizations like Breast Cancer Now. Encourage partners to seek personal space and support for themselves as well.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Help and support are available for partners, carers and children. Your treatment team, palliative team or local cancer centre can tell you what’s available in your area.

Question (100 words): What practical help is available for me if I live alone?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you live alone, you can seek practical help from neighbors, colleagues, friends of friends, or members of a religious or social group. Voluntary services like the British Red Cross and the Carers Trust can provide support with everyday tasks such as shopping, cleaning, and managing pets. Your treatment team, GP, social worker, or local cancer information center can also inform you about other sources of practical support. Occupational therapists can help you continue to be independent by suggesting practical aids.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: While family and friends may offer some practical help, this may not be enough, especially if you live alone or don’t have close family or friends nearby. It can be useful to know about support services you can access to help you maintain your quality of life.

Question (100 words): How can I get a breast prosthesis or wig?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The process for getting or replacing a breast prosthesis or wig depends on arrangements in your local area. You can find more information in the booklets 'Breast prostheses, bras and clothes after surgery' and 'Breast cancer and hair loss'. Additionally, you can visit the dedicated webpages on breastcancernow.org for detailed guidance.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have or need a breast prosthesis or wig, the process for getting or replacing these depends on arrangements in your local area.

Question (100 words): Am I eligible for a Blue Badge if I have secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, people with secondary breast cancer are often eligible for a Blue Badge, which provides parking concessions for those with severe mobility problems. You can apply for a Blue Badge through your local authority or online at gov.uk.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: People with secondary breast cancer are often eligible, depending on their circumstances.

Question (100 words): What rights do I have at work after a cancer diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Under the Equality Act 2010, secondary breast cancer is classed as a disability, giving you the right to ask your employer to make reasonable adjustments such as flexible working, including working shorter days or part-time, or changing your role. You can also seek advice from the Macmillan work support service or Working With Cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Like all other cancers, secondary breast cancer is classed as a disability under the Equality Act 2010.

Question (100 words): What should I discuss with my employer about my treatment?
