Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Lymphoedema is swelling caused by a build-up of fluid in the body’s tissues. The swelling commonly affects the arm and can include the hand and fingers. Swelling can also affect the breast, chest, shoulder or the area on the back behind the armpit.

Question (100 words): Can lymphoedema develop years after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, lymphoedema can develop many years after breast cancer treatment. It may be triggered by a skin infection (cellulitis) or possibly injury.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Lymphoedema may develop soon after surgery, radiotherapy or chemotherapy, but it can occur many years later and may be triggered by a skin infection (cellulitis) or possibly injury.

Question (100 words): How can I care for my skin to reduce the risk of lymphoedema?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To care for your skin and reduce the risk of lymphoedema, wash your skin with warm water every day and dry it thoroughly, moisturize daily, use sunscreen, apply insect repellent, wear protective gloves, and be cautious with nail cutting and hair removal under the arm.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: To help reduce your risk of developing an infection: •Wash your skin with warm water every day and dry it thoroughly •Moisturise the skin daily to prevent dry and cracked skin (use a moisturising cream that suits your skin type) •Use a high factor sunscreen to protect against sunburn

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice symptoms of lymphoedema?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you notice symptoms of lymphoedema such as swelling, tightness, discomfort, dry skin, or arm stiffness, contact your breast care nurse or treatment team as soon as possible for assessment and management.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Contact your breast care nurse or treatment team as soon as possible if you notice any of the following symptoms.

Question (100 words): How can I manage lymphoedema if I develop it after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you develop lymphoedema, it can be managed through various methods such as compression garments, manual lymphatic drainage, exercise, and skin care. You can read more about managing lymphoedema in the booklet 'Living with lymphoedema after breast cancer.'
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have developed lymphoedema, you can read more about how it can be managed in our booklet Living with lymphoedema after breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What resources are available to help me with hair care after chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Cancer Hair Care (cancerhaircare.co.uk) offers lots of information and tips on hair loss and regrowth after cancer treatment. They provide guidance on using essential oils, massaging the scalp, protecting new hair from heat, and avoiding certain hair products.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Cancer Hair Care cancerhaircare.co.uk has lots of information and tips on hair loss and regrowth after cancer treatment.

Question (100 words): What are some practical tips to manage hot flushes and night sweats?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To manage hot flushes and night sweats, keep a battery-operated or paper fan with you, wear layers, choose loose-fitting clothing made from natural fibers, use a silk pillowcase or a cooling pillow, carry a bottle of water, avoid caffeine, alcohol, and spicy foods, and use a water spray to cool down. Treatments like non-hormonal drugs and complementary therapies such as acupuncture can also be effective.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Tips for coping with hot flushes and night sweats •Keep a battery-operated or paper fan with you at all times •Wear layers so you can remove clothing when a flush starts •Wear loose-fitting clothing made from natural fibres •Use a silk pillowcase, a specially designed pillow that stays cool or a cooling scarf •Always keep a bottle of water with you •Avoid caffeine, alcohol and spicy foods •Carry a water spray to use on your face or wrists to cool you down

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience lasting pain after breast surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience lasting pain after breast surgery, inform your GP or treatment team. They can assess and help manage your pain. Simple pain relief like paracetamol or ibuprofen, regular exercise, physiotherapy, complementary therapies such as acupuncture, talking therapies, and wearing a well-fitting bra can help. If needed, you may be referred to a specialist pain clinic.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The pain is usually caused by bruising, stretching or damage to nerves during surgery or when scar tissue forms. Tell your GP or treatment team about any ongoing pain, so they can assess it and help you manage it.

Question (100 words): How can I manage joint pain caused by hormone therapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To manage joint pain caused by hormone therapy, use mild pain relief like paracetamol or anti-inflammatory drugs such as ibuprofen. Gentle exercise that stretches your joints or strengthens your muscles can also help. If the pain is severe, speak to your treatment team about changing your medication or seeing a rheumatologist or pain management specialist.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Joint pain can usually be relieved with mild pain relief like paracetamol or an anti-inflammatory drug such as ibuprofen. Exercise that gently stretches your joints or strengthens your muscles can help.

Question (100 words): What can I do to maintain bone health during breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To maintain bone health during breast cancer treatment, eat a healthy diet rich in calcium and vitamin D, engage in regular exercise, limit alcohol intake to below five units a week, and consider taking calcium and vitamin D supplements as recommended by your doctor.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Eat a healthy diet A varied, balanced diet will give you the nutrients that are important for strong, healthy bones. Get enough calcium Calcium is a vital mineral for teeth and bones. Good sources include milk and dairy products, dried fruit and green leafy vegetables.

Question (100 words): What are the signs of breast cancer recurrence I should be aware of?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Signs of breast cancer recurrence include swelling on your chest, in your armpit or around your collarbone, liquid discharge from the nipple, changes in breast shape or size, swelling in the arm or hand, changes in skin texture, redness or rash on the skin, inverted or changed nipple, and lumps or thickening in the breast. Report any new or unusual symptoms to your breast care nurse or GP.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: TELL YOUR BREAST CARE NURSE OR GP IF YOU HAVE ANY SYMPTOMS THAT ARE NEW OR UNUSUAL FOR YOU, DON’T HAVE ANY OBVIOUS CAUSE  AND DON’T GO AWAY.

Question (100 words): How can I cope with worries about breast cancer recurrence?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To cope with worries about breast cancer recurrence, talk about your feelings with someone you trust, seek support from groups like Breast Cancer Now’s online Forum, use self-help techniques such as distraction, planning, relaxation, and exercise, and consider talking therapies like counseling or cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT).
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Coping with worries about recurrence Nearly everyone who has been treated for cancer worries about it coming back. At first, every ache or pain can frighten you. But, as time passes, you may come to accept minor symptoms for what they are in most cases – maybe a cold or flu or the result of over-exerting yourself.

Question (100 words): What follow-up care is typically offered after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After breast cancer treatment, you are usually offered regular mammograms depending on the type of surgery you’ve had. You may also have regular appointments. For detailed information, refer to Breast Cancer Now’s booklet 'After breast cancer treatment: what now?'
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Follow-up after treatment Once hospital treatment for breast cancer ends, you’ll usually be offered regular mammograms depending on the type of surgery you’ve had. You may or may not also have regular appointments.

Question (100 words): What are the possible signs of secondary breast cancer I should watch for?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Possible signs of secondary breast cancer include unexpected weight loss, discomfort or swelling under the ribs, severe or ongoing headaches, a dry cough or breathlessness, altered vision or speech, feeling sick most of the time, loss of balance or limb weakness, feeling more tired than usual, lumps or swellings under your arm, breastbone or collarbone, and bone pain that doesn’t improve with pain relief.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Possible signs of secondary breast cancer TELL YOUR BREAST CARE NURSE OR GP IF YOU HAVE ANY SYMPTOMS THAT ARE NEW OR UNUSUAL FOR YOU, DON’T HAVE ANY OBVIOUS CAUSE  AND DON’T GO AWAY.

Question (100 words): How can I reduce my risk of breast cancer recurrence?
Answer (Max 2000 words): While the risk of breast cancer recurrence is largely out of your control, research suggests that regular exercise, maintaining a healthy weight, and keeping your alcohol intake within current guidelines may help reduce your risk.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Can I reduce my risk of recurrence? As with the risk of breast cancer developing, the risk of a recurrence is largely out of a person’s control. But research suggests regular exercise, maintaining a healthy weight and keeping your alcohol intake within current guidelines may help reduce your risk of recurrence.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience anxiety or stress after my breast cancer diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience anxiety or stress after your breast cancer diagnosis, try self-help techniques like distraction, planning, relaxation, visualization, mindfulness, meditation, exercise, and eating healthily. Consider talking therapies such as one-to-one counseling or cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT). Reach out to support services like Breast Cancer Now’s Helpline or online Forum.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Anxiety and stress After a diagnosis of breast cancer, you may feel more stressed or anxious than usual. Some people may experience anxiety for the first time. If you have had anxiety in the past, your anxiety may feel different or worse than before. There are techniques and support to help you reduce stress and cope with anxiety.

Question (100 words): What are the common side effects of aromatase inhibitors?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common side effects of aromatase inhibitors include pain or stiffness in the joints. These can usually be managed with mild pain relief like paracetamol or anti-inflammatory drugs such as ibuprofen. Gentle exercise and, if necessary, a change in medication can also help.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Many women taking hormone therapy, particularly aromatase inhibitors such as anastrozole, exemestane or letrozole, have pain or stiffness in the joints.

Question (100 words): How can complementary therapies help manage pain after breast cancer surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Complementary therapies such as acupuncture have been shown in some studies to help reduce pain after breast cancer surgery. Discuss these options with your treatment team to see if they might be beneficial for you.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Complementary therapies Some studies show acupuncture may help reduce pain after breast cancer surgery.

Question (100 words): What types of exercise are recommended to keep bones strong during and after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Regular exercise, including weight-bearing exercises like walking or dancing and muscle-strengthening activities like yoga or lifting light weights, is recommended to keep bones strong during and after breast cancer treatment. For more detailed information, visit the Royal Osteoporosis Society’s website at theros.org.uk.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Keep active Regular exercise can help keep bones strong. The Royal Osteoporosis Society has lots of information on what types of exercise are best for keeping bones strong and healthy. Visit theros.org.uk

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice changes in my breast or chest area after surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you notice any changes in your breast or chest area after surgery, such as swelling, changes in shape or size, skin texture changes, or lumps, report these to your breast care nurse or GP immediately. Early detection is crucial for effective management.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Changes to the breast or chest area Whether you’ve had breast-conserving surgery or a mastectomy, with or without reconstruction, it’s important to be aware of any changes to either side, such as: SIGNS TO BE AWARE OF

Question (100 words): How can I manage low mood or depression after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience low mood or depression after breast cancer treatment, talk to your treatment team or GP. They can refer you to a counselor, psychiatrist, or psychologist for help and support. Self-help techniques and talking therapies can also be beneficial.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Low mood and depression Most people experience some low mood and sadness after treatment for breast cancer. Low mood usually improves after a short while, but if it doesn’t then you could have depression.

Question (100 words): What role does vitamin D play in bone health during breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Vitamin D is essential for bone health as it helps your body absorb calcium. The main source of vitamin D is sunlight, but it’s recommended that adults take a vitamin D supplement, especially in the winter months. Your doctor may prescribe a combined calcium and vitamin D supplement.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Vitamin D is needed to help your body absorb calcium. The main source is sunlight, which your body uses to make this vitamin in your skin. However, it’s recommended adults take a vitamin D supplement especially in the winter months.

Question (100 words): How can I find support from others who have experienced breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can find support from others who have experienced breast cancer by calling Breast Cancer Now’s Helpline on 0808 800 6000, using the Ask Our Nurses email service or online Forum, speaking to a trained volunteer through the Someone Like Me service, or contacting your local breast care nurse for available support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re finding it difficult to cope emotionally, you might want to talk to someone about how you’re feeling. You may find it helpful to: • Call our Helpline ( 0808 800 6000 ) to speak to one of our breast care nurses or trained staff who have a personal or work-related experience of breast cancer

Question (100 words): What are the chances of breast cancer returning after treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The chances of breast cancer returning after treatment vary for each person and depend on factors such as the size, type, grade, and features of the cancer, and whether the lymph nodes were affected. Most people diagnosed with primary breast cancer will not have a recurrence. Your treatment team can provide more information about your individual risk.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Each person’s risk of breast cancer recurrence is different and depends on many factors, such as the size, type, grade and features of the cancer and whether the lymph nodes were affected. Your treatment team can tell you more about your individual risk of recurrence if you want to know this.

Question (100 words): How can I maintain a healthy weight during and after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To maintain a healthy weight during and after breast cancer treatment, engage in regular physical activity, eat a balanced diet rich in fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and lean proteins, limit your intake of processed foods and sugars, and consult with a dietitian if needed for personalized advice.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Can I reduce my risk of recurrence? As with the risk of breast cancer developing, the risk of a recurrence is largely out of a person’s control. But research suggests regular exercise, maintaining a healthy weight and keeping your alcohol intake within current guidelines may help reduce your risk of recurrence.

Question (100 words): What should I know about the risk of osteoporosis during breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Some breast cancer treatments, including chemotherapy, hormone therapy, and ovarian suppression, can increase the risk of osteoporosis. To mitigate this risk, maintain a diet rich in calcium and vitamin D, engage in regular weight-bearing exercise, limit alcohol intake, and consider taking supplements as recommended by your doctor. For more information, visit the Royal Osteoporosis Society’s website at theros.org.uk.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some breast cancer treatments can increase the risk of osteoporosis, a condition where bones lose their density and strength. The hormone oestrogen protects against bone loss and helps to keep bones strong. Breast cancer treatments that affect the amount of oestrogen in the body include chemotherapy, hormone therapy and ovarian suppression (removing the ovaries or stopping them from working).

Question (100 words): What are the common symptoms of depression after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common symptoms of depression after breast cancer treatment include feeling incredibly low for no apparent reason, difficulty relating to others, and feeling isolated. It's important to seek professional support such as counseling or Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT).
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: ‘Some days I just feel incredibly low for no conceivable reason and that’s difficult to deal with.’ Sarah

Question (100 words): How can I manage feelings of isolation after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Managing feelings of isolation can be achieved by sharing your feelings with your healthcare team or a counselor, asking loved ones to read informational booklets to understand your situation better, and connecting with others who have gone through similar experiences.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re feeling isolated Sharing your feelings with your healthcare team or a counsellor can help you feel more confident and comfortable with yourself.

Question (100 words): What changes to my body can I expect after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After breast cancer treatment, you may experience changes such as scars from surgery, hair loss from chemotherapy, and weight gain. These changes can affect your confidence and self-esteem, but these feelings often lessen over time.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Being treated for breast cancer can cause changes to your body and the way you look. If you had surgery you’ll be left with a scar or scars.

Question (100 words): How can diet affect the risk of breast cancer recurrence?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A higher fiber intake and lower saturated fat intake may reduce the risk of breast cancer recurrence. Maintaining a healthy weight, limiting alcohol, and being physically active may also help reduce the risk of recurrence.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There’s some evidence that a higher fibre intake may reduce the risk of breast cancer recurrence, but further research is needed to find out more.

Question (100 words): What are some tips for starting an exercise routine after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Start with short walks, gentle stretching, or deep breathing exercises. Find a buddy to exercise with, use a walking app or pedometer, set realistic goals, identify potential barriers, choose enjoyable activities, select a time when your energy levels are higher, and keep a journal to note your progress.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Getting started and staying motivated •Start with short walks, gentle stretching or deep breathing exercises •Find a buddy to exercise with

Question (100 words): What complementary therapies are popular among breast cancer patients?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Popular complementary therapies include acupuncture, acupressure and shiatsu, aromatherapy, healing and energy therapies, hypnotherapy, massage, and reflexology. It's important to discuss these with your treatment team before starting.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Popular complementary therapies include: • Acupuncture • Acupressure and shiatsu • Aromatherapy • Healing and energy therapies • Hypnotherapy • Massage • Reflexology

Question (100 words): How can I improve my sleep after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To improve sleep, engage in regular moderate exercise during the day, avoid caffeine after mid-afternoon, limit alcohol, keep daytime naps short, maintain a consistent sleep routine, relax before bedtime, avoid screens before bed, and create a comfortable sleep environment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Tips that might help you get a good night’s sleep •Exercise – regular moderate exercise during the day can help, but try to avoid exercise late in the evening.

Question (100 words): What should I discuss with my treatment team before starting complementary therapies?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Before starting complementary therapies, discuss with your treatment team to ensure they won’t interfere with your breast cancer treatment. Your team may advise avoiding certain therapies if they could affect treatment efficacy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you want to have a complementary therapy, speak to your treatment team first.

Question (100 words): How can I talk to my children about my breast cancer experience?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Continue talking with your children about your experience even after treatment. Ensure they have realistic expectations about your energy levels and involvement. Address any fears they may have about your health or their future.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Continue talking with your children about your experience of breast cancer even after treatment has finished.

Question (100 words): What are some tips for resuming sexual activity after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Tips include starting afresh without comparing to before, exploring your body to discover what touch is pleasant, using lubricants or moisturizers, doing pelvic floor exercises, taking things slowly, creating a relaxed atmosphere, wearing what makes you comfortable, and considering masturbation to remove anxiety.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Tips for getting back to sex •Start afresh – try not to compare things now to how they were before you were diagnosed with breast cancer

Question (100 words): How can I manage my weight after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your GP or practice nurse can assess if your current weight is healthy and may refer you to a dietitian if needed. They can also inform you about local schemes aimed at helping people manage their weight.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your GP or practice nurse can assess if your current weight is healthy and may refer you to a dietitian if needed.

Question (100 words): What should I know about calcium intake after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Ensure you get enough calcium from your diet, as some treatments can affect bone health. Good sources include milk and dairy products, green leafy vegetables, and dried fruit such as apricots and figs.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: So make sure you get enough calcium from your diet. Good sources include milk and dairy products, green leafy vegetables and dried fruit such as apricots and figs.

Question (100 words): Are herbal products safe to use after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): There’s conflicting evidence about the safety and effectiveness of herbal products. Talk to your specialist, GP, pharmacist, or a dietitian before taking them. You can also find information about herbal medicine on the Sloane Kettering website.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There’s conflicting evidence about whether some herbal products are safe or effective… So talk to your specialist, GP, pharmacist or a dietitian before taking them.

Question (100 words): How can I find a complementary therapist?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Some hospitals, cancer support centers, and charities provide complementary therapies. Your breast care nurse may be able to tell you more about this or give you a list of therapists in your area.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some hospitals, cancer support centres, and charities provide complementary therapies. Your breast care nurse may be able to tell you more about this or give you a list of therapists in your area.

Question (100 words): What should I tell a complementary therapist about my breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you see a therapist, tell them about your breast cancer and its treatment. You may want to ask the therapist if they’ve worked with people diagnosed with breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you see a therapist, tell them about your breast cancer and its treatment.

Question (100 words): How can I deal with changes in my relationship after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Talk openly about your situation with your partner. This can help you find solutions together. Avoid problems altogether, as this can make them more difficult to resolve in the long term.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Being able to talk openly about your situation can mean that together you’re able to find solutions.

Question (100 words): What role can professional support play in managing depression after breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Professional support such as counseling or Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) can help manage symptoms of depression. Your treatment team or GP can tell you about services in your area.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Professional support such as counselling or CBT (see page 28) can help. Your treatment team or GP can tell you about services in your area.

Question (100 words): How long does it take for antidepressants to start working?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Antidepressant drugs may be recommended to treat symptoms of depression. It usually takes up to six weeks before you notice the effects and start to feel an improvement in mood.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Antidepressant drugs may be recommended to treat symptoms of depression. It usually takes up to six weeks before you notice the effects and start to feel an improvement in mood.

Question (100 words): What organizations can provide support for mental health after breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Organizations that provide information or support include Anxiety UK, Mental Health Foundation, Mind, NHS website, SAHM for Scotland’s mental health, and Samaritans.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Useful organisations Organisations that provide information or support that might help include: • Anxiety UK anxietyuk.org.uk • Mental Health Foundation mentalhealth.org.uk • Mind mind.org.uk • NHS website nhs.uk/mental-health • SAHM for Scotland’s mental health samh.org.uk • Samaritans samaritans.org or call 116 123

Question (100 words): How can I adjust to the changes in my body after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Getting used to the changes and adjusting to life after breast cancer can take time. If you continue to find looking at your body difficult, it may help to speak to a counselor. Your treatment team or GP should be able to arrange this.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Getting used to the changes that have taken place and adjusting to life after breast cancer can take time.

Question (100 words): How should I tell a new partner about my breast cancer diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): There’s no set answer to this, and you’ll probably just know if and when the time is right. Discussing it with them first can help to take away some of the pressure. It’s important to move at a pace that you’re comfortable with.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A lot of women worry about when and how to tell a new partner that they have had breast cancer. There’s no set answer to this and you’ll probably just know if and when the time is right.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I feel anxious about a new partner's reaction to my diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): It can help to discuss your concerns with your new partner to try and take away some of the pressure. Everyone is different, and some people will take longer than others to feel comfortable sharing aspects of their diagnosis.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You might feel unsure about being intimate with a new partner and anxious about their reaction. It can help to discuss this with them first to try and take away some of the pressure.

Question (100 words): How can I manage financial issues caused by breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You may be able to claim benefits or get other financial support. For example, if you’re employed and have to take time off sick, you’ll probably be entitled to Statutory Sick Pay (SSP). Employment and Support Allowance (ESA) is for people who cannot work because of illness or disability. If you're out of work or on a low income, you may be able to claim Universal Credit.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast cancer can cause financial and practical issues during and after treatment. You may be able to claim benefits or get other financial support.

Question (100 words): What are my rights at work if I have breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): People with cancer are protected at work by the Equality Act 2010 in England, Scotland and Wales, and the Disability Discrimination Act 1995 in Northern Ireland. According to the law, someone with cancer is classed as having a disability. The law protects employees from being discriminated against because of their disability.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: People with cancer are protected at work by the Equality Act 2010 in England, Scotland and Wales, and the Disability Discrimination Act 1995 in Northern Ireland.

Question (100 words): What adjustments can my employer make to help me return to work?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your employer is required to make reasonable adjustments during the period you’re returning to work. For example, a phased return to work can help you gradually adjust to your normal working pattern. There may be other adjustments that could benefit you.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your employer is required to make reasonable adjustments during the period you’re returning to work. For example, a phased return to work can help you gradually adjust to your normal working pattern.

Question (100 words): How can I plan my return to work after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): It can be helpful to discuss your plan to return to work with your treatment team, occupational health or human resources department, and your manager. Your treatment team can recommend adjustments that may benefit you, which you can then share with your employer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It can be helpful to discuss your plan to return to work with your treatment team, occupational health or human resources department and your manager.

Question (100 words): What benefits can I claim if I’m self-employed and have breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you’re self-employed, you may worry that your diagnosis and treatment will affect your business. Macmillan Cancer Support has useful information about self-employment and cancer on its website.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re self-employed you may worry that your diagnosis and treatment will affect your business. Macmillan Cancer Support has useful information about self-employment and cancer on its website.

Question (100 words): Where can I get help with financial issues related to breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Specialist help with financial issues is available. Welfare advisers at some hospitals can give you guidance on benefits. You can also speak to a Macmillan welfare rights adviser by calling 0808 808 00 00. Citizens Advice and Age UK can also provide assistance with benefits and local government assistance.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: As the benefits system can be confusing, specialist help with financial issues is available. Welfare advisers, Macmillan Cancer Support, Citizens Advice, and Age UK can provide assistance.

Question (100 words): How can I get support from Breast Cancer Now?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast Cancer Now offers various support services including a Helpline, Ask Our Nurses, online Forum, BECCA app, and Someone Like Me service. You can find more information on their website.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Everyone affected by breast cancer can turn to us for support. You can find out more about Breast Cancer Now’s support services on our website.

Question (100 words): What resources are available for managing menopausal symptoms after breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Menopause Matters (menopausematters.co.uk) provides resources and support for managing menopausal symptoms.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Menopausal symptoms: Menopause matters menopausematters.co.uk

Question (100 words): Where can I find support for hair loss due to breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Cancer Hair Care (cancerhaircare.co.uk) and My New Hair (mynewhair.org) offer support and resources for hair loss.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Hair loss: Cancer Hair Care cancerhaircare.co.uk, My New Hair mynewhair.org

Question (100 words): What organizations can help me manage lymphoedema?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The British Lymphology Society (thebls.com) and The Lymphoedema Support Network (lymphoedema.org) provide resources and support for lymphoedema.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Lymphoedema: British Lymphology Society (BLS) thebls.com, The Lymphoedema Support Network lymphoedema.org

Question (100 words): Where can I get information and support for osteoporosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The National Osteoporosis Society (nos.org.uk) offers information and support for osteoporosis.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Osteoporosis: National Osteoporosis Society nos.org.uk

Question (100 words): What resources are available for relationships and sex after breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The College of Sexual and Relationship Therapists (COSRT) (cosrt.org.uk) and Relate (relate.org.uk) provide support for relationships and sex.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Relationships and sex: College of sexual and relationship therapists (COSRT) cosrt.org.uk, Relate relate.org.uk

Question (100 words): Where can I find mental health and wellbeing support?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Anxiety UK (anxietyuk.org), Maggie’s Centres (maggies.org), Mental Health Foundation (mentalhealth.org.uk), and Mind (mind.org.uk) offer mental health and wellbeing support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Mental health and wellbeing: Anxiety UK anxietyuk.org, Maggie’s Centres maggies.org, Mental Health Foundation mentalhealth.org.uk, Mind mind.org.uk

Question (100 words): How can I support Breast Cancer Now’s work?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can support Breast Cancer Now’s vital care and research work by visiting breastcancernow.org/give to make a donation or leave a gift in your will.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast Cancer Now is a charity that relies on voluntary donations and gifts in wills. If you have found this information helpful, please visit breastcancernow.org/give to support our vital care and research work.

Question (100 words): Who wrote this booklet and how can I provide feedback?
Answer (Max 2000 words): This booklet was written by Breast Cancer Now’s clinical specialists and reviewed by healthcare professionals and people affected by breast cancer. You can provide feedback by emailing health-info@breastcancernow.org.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Moving forward was written by Breast Cancer Now’s clinical specialists, and reviewed by healthcare professionals and people affected by breast cancer. We welcome your feedback on this publication: health-info@breastcancernow.org

Question (100 words): Where can I get more copies of this booklet or alternative formats?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can order or download more copies from breastcancernow.org/publications. For large print, Braille, or audio CD versions, email health-info@breastcancernow.org.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can order or download more copies from breastcancernow.org/publications. For a large print, Braille or audio CD version: Email health-info@breastcancernow.org

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience side effects from my treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience side effects from your treatment, it’s important to discuss them with your healthcare team. They can provide guidance on managing these side effects and may adjust your treatment plan if necessary.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: This may be because of side effects of their treatment such as fatigue, or because they’re adjusting to life after a cancer diagnosis and the emotional changes this can bring.

Question (100 words): How can I regain confidence at work after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Regaining confidence at work may take time. Discussing your return to work plan with your treatment team, occupational health, or HR department can help. A phased return to work and other reasonable adjustments can also aid in gradually regaining your confidence.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s common to feel less confident at work, particularly if you’ve been off work for a while. Planning your return and discussing it with your treatment team can help.

Question (100 words): What are the normal changes in breasts during puberty?
Answer (Max 2000 words): During puberty, breasts usually start to develop around the age of 9 to 11. A small bump called a breast bud grows under the areola and the nipple. The areolas get bigger and darker, and the nipples may stick out. Tingling, aching, or itching in the chest and tender nipples are also normal.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breasts usually start to develop around the age of 9 to 11, but it’s not unusual for them to start earlier or later. By the age of 17, a girl’s breasts will usually be fully developed. This time in a girl’s life is called puberty.

Question (100 words): How do breasts change around the time of my period?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Around the time of your period, your breasts may feel heavier, fuller, tender, or lumpy due to the hormones oestrogen and progesterone. These changes usually lessen or disappear after your period.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Oestrogen and progesterone play a vital part in regulating a woman’s periods. These hormones are responsible for the changes you may notice in your breasts just before your period.

Question (100 words): Is breast pain a sign of breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast pain on its own is rarely a sign of breast cancer. However, it’s important to be breast aware and see your GP if the pain increases or changes.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast pain is very common in women of all ages. It can have lots of different causes but, on its own, breast pain is rarely a sign of breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What can I do to reduce soreness under my breasts?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To reduce soreness under your breasts (intertrigo), wash the area every morning and night with a soap substitute, dry thoroughly, wear a well-fitting, supportive bra, and maintain a healthy weight.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: To reduce your risk of getting intertrigo, or to stop an infection getting worse, you should: Wash under your breasts every morning and night with a soap substitute, such as emulsifying ointment (you can ask your pharmacist about this) Gently dry the skin under your breasts thoroughly after washing Wear a well-fitting, supportive bra made from a natural material such as cotton Try to maintain a weight that’s normal for you

Question (100 words): What breast changes can I expect during pregnancy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): During pregnancy, you may feel a change in sensation in your breasts such as tingling and soreness, particularly of the nipples. The breasts and areolas begin to get bigger, and the nipples and areolas become darker.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast changes can be an early sign of pregnancy. Many pregnant women feel a change in sensation in their breasts such as tingling and soreness, particularly of the nipples.

Question (100 words): What are common causes of breast lumps?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common causes of breast lumps include breast cysts, which are fluid-filled sacs, and fibroadenomas, which are solid lumps. It’s important to get any breast lumps checked by your doctor.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Common causes of breast lumps include: Breast cyst – a fluid-filled sac that can develop as the breasts change with age, more common in women who haven’t been through the menopause (pre-menopausal women) Fibroadenoma – a lump that often develops during puberty but can occur at any age

Question (100 words): How do breasts change during and after menopause?
Answer (Max 2000 words): During and after menopause, as oestrogen levels fall, breasts may change size, lose their firmness, feel softer, and may droop. Tenderness may be due to non-cyclical breast pain.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: As oestrogen levels fall during and after the menopause, breasts may change size, lose their firmness, feel softer and may droop.

Question (100 words): How can I check my breasts for any unusual changes?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Check your breasts by touching them to feel for anything new or unusual, looking for any changes in appearance, and checking any new or unusual changes with a GP. A good time to do this might be when you’re in the bath or shower.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Checking your breasts is as easy as TLC: Touch your breasts: can you feel anything new or unusual? Look for changes: does anything look different to you? Check any new or unusual changes with a GP

Question (100 words): What should I look for when checking my breasts?
Answer (Max 2000 words): When checking your breasts, look for a lump or swelling, changes to the skin such as puckering or dimpling, changes in the colour of the breast, nipple changes, rash or crusting around the nipple, unusual liquid discharge from the nipple, and changes in size or shape of the breast.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Changes to look and feel for: A lump or swelling in the breast, upper chest or armpit A change to the skin, such as puckering or dimpling A change to the colour of the breast – the breast may look darker, red or inflamed A nipple change, for example it has become pulled in (inverted) Rash or crusting around the nipple Unusual liquid (discharge) from either nipple Changes in size or shape of the breast

Question (100 words): What should I do if I find a change in my breasts?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you notice a change in your breasts, see your GP as soon as possible. Most changes are likely to be normal or due to a benign condition, but it’s important to find out what’s causing the change.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You know better than anyone how your breasts look and feel normally, so see your GP as soon as you can if you notice a change.

Question (100 words): What happens if my GP refers me to a breast clinic?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Being referred to a breast clinic doesn’t mean you have breast cancer. It means further assessment is needed to find out what is going on. You may have various tests to determine the cause of the change.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Being referred to a breast clinic doesn’t mean you have breast cancer, just that further assessment is needed to find out what is going on.

Question (100 words): At what age do women get invited for breast screening in the UK?
Answer (Max 2000 words): In the UK, women aged 50 or over are invited for a mammogram every 3 years until their 71st birthday as part of the national breast screening programme.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: In the UK, women aged 50 or over are invited for a mammogram every 3 years until their 71st birthday.

Question (100 words): Why aren't women under 50 invited for breast screening?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Women under 50 are not automatically invited for breast screening because the number of women who get breast cancer is much lower in this age group. Younger women also have denser breast tissue, which can make the x-ray image less clear.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Women under 50 are not automatically invited for breast screening because the number of women who get breast cancer is much lower in this age group. Younger women also have denser breast tissue, which can make the x-ray image less clear and changes harder to identify.

Question (100 words): Can transgender or non-binary people get breast screening?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, some transgender or non-binary people can access breast screening. This includes transgender men and non-binary people assigned female at birth who have not had an operation to remove their breast tissue, and transgender women and non-binary people assigned male at birth who have taken feminising hormones.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some transgender or non-binary people can access breast screening. This includes: Transgender men and non-binary people assigned female at birth who have not had an operation to remove their breast tissue Transgender women and non-binary people assigned male at birth who have taken feminising hormones

Question (100 words): What are the benefits of breast screening?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast screening can find breast cancer early, before it can be seen or felt, making treatment more successful. It also prevents an estimated 1,300 deaths from breast cancer each year in the UK.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast screening can find a breast cancer early, before it can be seen or felt. The sooner breast cancer is found, the more likely it is to respond well to treatment, and the less likely you are to need more extensive surgery. Screening prevents deaths Screening prevents an estimated 1,300 deaths from breast cancer each year in the UK.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience severe intertrigo under my breasts?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience severe intertrigo under your breasts, you may need treatment. Consult your healthcare provider for appropriate medication or treatment options to address the infection and relieve symptoms.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If your intertrigo is severe, you may need treatment.

Question (100 words): How can I maintain breast awareness throughout my life?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To maintain breast awareness, regularly check your breasts for any changes in size, shape, or texture. Be mindful of any unusual lumps, skin changes, or nipple discharge. If you notice anything out of the ordinary, consult your healthcare provider promptly.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Being breast aware means getting to know how your breasts look and feel so you know what’s normal for you.

Question (100 words): What role do hormones play in breast changes throughout life?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Hormones, particularly oestrogen and progesterone, play a significant role in breast changes throughout a woman's life. Fluctuations in these hormones during different life stages, such as puberty, menstruation, pregnancy, and menopause, can lead to various breast changes.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your breasts change throughout your life. This is because levels of the hormones oestrogen and progesterone in your body change at different times during your life.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice a change in my breasts?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you notice any changes in your breasts, such as lumps, skin changes, or nipple discharge, it's important to see your GP promptly. Most changes are benign, but it's crucial to get them checked to rule out any serious conditions.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you notice a change, it’s important to see your GP.

Question (100 words): How often should women over 71 get breast screening in the UK?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Women over 71 in the UK are not automatically invited for breast screening. However, in some parts of the UK, they can continue to have breast screening every 3 years if they contact their local breast screening unit and request it.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re 71 or over, you will not be automatically sent an invitation for screening. However, in some parts of the UK you can continue to have breast screening every 3 years if you contact your local breast screening unit and ask for it.

Question (100 words): Why might a mammogram be uncomfortable?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A mammogram can be uncomfortable because your breast will be pressed down firmly on the surface by a clear plate during the x-ray process. However, this discomfort is temporary and the procedure only takes a few seconds.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some people find having a mammogram uncomfortable. However, this isn’t always the case and a mammogram only takes a few seconds.

Question (100 words): Can a mammogram detect all breast cancers?
Answer (Max 2000 words): While mammograms are the most reliable way of detecting breast cancer sooner, they are not 100% reliable. A small number of breast cancers can be missed during screening.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Mammograms are the most reliable way of detecting breast cancer sooner. However, they’re not 100% reliable and a small number of breast cancers are missed.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I am recalled for further assessment after a mammogram?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you are recalled for further assessment, it means more tests are needed to assess a change seen on the mammogram. This does not necessarily mean you have breast cancer. For more detailed information, refer to the booklet 'Your breast clinic appointment.'
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some people will get a letter asking them to come back for further assessment. This is because more tests are needed to assess a change seen on the mammogram. Being recalled doesn’t necessarily mean that you have breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What happens if my mammogram images are unclear?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If a technical issue causes your mammogram images to be unclear, you may receive a letter asking you to return for another mammogram to ensure accurate results.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Occasionally some people receive a letter asking them to go back for another mammogram because a technical issue meant the image was unclear.

Question (100 words): How often should I have a mammogram?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You should have a mammogram every 3 years if you are within the recommended age range for screening. However, it’s important to continue being breast aware and report any changes to your GP, even between screenings.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Having mammograms cannot prevent breast cancer, and it’s possible for breast cancer to develop in the 3 years between each mammogram. It’s important to continue to be breast aware and report any changes to your GP, even if you have had a mammogram recently.

Question (100 words): What are the disadvantages of breast screening?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The disadvantages of breast screening include discomfort during the procedure, potential overtreatment of slow-growing or non-harmful cancers, a small risk of missing some cancers, emotional distress from being recalled for further tests, and slight radiation exposure.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Disadvantages of breast screening: It can be uncomfortable... You’re exposed to a small amount of radiation.

Question (100 words): What should I expect during a breast screening appointment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): During a breast screening appointment, you will complete a questionnaire about your medical history, remove your clothing from the waist up, and have your breasts x-rayed by a female mammography practitioner. At least two pictures of each breast will be taken.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You’ll be asked to complete a questionnaire... At least 2 pictures (x-rays) of each breast will be taken, one from top to bottom and then a second from side to side to include the part of your breast that extends into your armpit.

Question (100 words): How will I receive the results of my mammogram?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The results of your screening mammogram will be sent by post to you and your GP. Most people will receive a letter indicating no signs of cancer and an invitation for the next screening in 3 years.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The results of your screening mammogram are sent by post to you and your GP. Most people will receive a letter telling them that their mammogram showed no signs of cancer.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice changes in my breasts between mammograms?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you notice any changes in your breasts between mammograms, it’s important to report them to your GP immediately. Regular mammograms do not prevent breast cancer, and changes can occur between screenings.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s important to continue to be breast aware and report any changes to your GP, even if you have had a mammogram recently.

Question (100 words): Who performs the mammogram during breast screening?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The mammogram is performed by a female mammography practitioner, who is an expert in taking breast x-rays. She will explain the procedure and answer any questions you have.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your mammogram will be carried out by a woman. A female mammography practitioner (an expert in taking breast x-rays) will explain what will happen and answer any questions you have.

Question (100 words): What should I inform the mammography practitioner before the procedure?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Before the procedure, inform the mammography practitioner if you are pregnant or think you may be pregnant. Also, let her know about any ongoing medical conditions or if you are using hormone replacement therapy (HRT).
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Let her know if you’re pregnant or think you may be pregnant... It will ask about any ongoing medical conditions, if you’re having hormone replacement therapy (HRT), and if you’ve had any breast problems.

Question (100 words): How long does it take to get the results of a mammogram?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The results of your mammogram are typically sent by post, and you should receive them within a few weeks. Most people will get a letter indicating no signs of cancer and an invitation for the next screening in 3 years.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The results of your screening mammogram are sent by post to you and your GP.

Question (100 words): What does it mean if I am asked to come back for further assessment after a mammogram?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you are asked to come back for further assessment, it means that additional tests are needed to evaluate a change seen on the mammogram. This does not necessarily indicate that you have breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some people will get a letter asking them to come back for further assessment. This is because more tests are needed to assess a change seen on the mammogram. Being recalled doesn’t necessarily mean that you have breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What is the purpose of taking multiple x-ray pictures of each breast during a mammogram?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Multiple x-ray pictures of each breast are taken to ensure comprehensive coverage, including views from top to bottom and side to side, to capture the part of the breast that extends into the armpit.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: At least 2 pictures (x-rays) of each breast will be taken, one from top to bottom and then a second from side to side to include the part of your breast that extends into your armpit.

Question (100 words): How can I stay informed and supported throughout my breast cancer journey?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can stay informed and supported by contacting Breast Cancer Now’s helpline on 0808 800 6000, visiting their website at breastcancernow.org, and utilizing their free services and resources for anyone affected by breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Call 0808 800 6000 to talk things through with our helpline nurses. Visit breastcancernow.org for reliable breast cancer information.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I have questions about breast screening?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you have any questions about breast screening, you can call Breast Cancer Now’s helpline on 0808 800 6000 for assistance and information.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have any questions about breast screening, call our helpline on 0808 800 6000.

Question (100 words): What is the role of Breast Cancer Now in supporting those affected by breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast Cancer Now provides life-changing support, world-class research, and change-making campaigns to improve treatment, services, and care for everyone affected by breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: We’re Breast Cancer Now, the research and support charity. However you’re experiencing breast cancer, we’re here.

Question (100 words): How can I contribute to Breast Cancer Now’s mission?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can support Breast Cancer Now’s mission by making donations or including gifts in your will. They rely on public support to fund their vital work.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: We don’t get any government or NHS funding for our support services or health information. So, we rely on donations and gifts in wills to make our vital work happen.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience any side effects from breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience any side effects from breast cancer treatment, it is important to discuss them with your healthcare team. They can provide guidance, support, and potential adjustments to your treatment plan to manage these side effects effectively.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Information you can trust, support you can count on Whatever breast cancer brings, we’re here for you.

Question (100 words): How can I access more information or resources about breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can access more information and resources about breast cancer by visiting Breast Cancer Now’s website at breastcancernow.org, ordering or downloading publications, or contacting their helpline on 0808 800 6000 for personalized support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can order or download more copies from breastcancernow.org/publications. Call 0808 800 6000 to talk things through with our helpline nurses. Visit breastcancernow.org for reliable breast cancer information.

Question (100 words): What is tamoxifen and how does it work?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Tamoxifen is a drug used to treat breast cancer. It is a type of hormone therapy, also known as endocrine therapy. It works by blocking the effects of oestrogen on oestrogen receptor positive (ER-positive) breast cancers, thereby stopping oestrogen from helping the breast cancer cells grow.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Tamoxifen is a drug used to treat breast cancer. It’s a type of hormone therapy, also known as endocrine therapy. It can be used by both premenopausal women (women who still have periods) and postmenopausal women (women whose periods have stopped). It can also be taken by men who have breast cancer. Tamoxifen blocks the effects of oestrogen on ER-positive breast cancers. This stops oestrogen from helping the breast cancer cells grow.

Question (100 words): Who might be offered tamoxifen as part of their treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Tamoxifen is prescribed for individuals with oestrogen receptor positive (ER-positive) breast cancer. This includes both premenopausal and postmenopausal women, as well as men with breast cancer. It is not beneficial for those with oestrogen receptor negative (ER-negative) breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You’ll only be prescribed tamoxifen if your breast cancer is ER-positive. Invasive breast cancers are tested to see if they’re ER-positive using tissue from a biopsy or after surgery. If your breast cancer doesn’t use oestrogen to help it grow, it is known as oestrogen receptor negative (ER-negative). If your cancer is found to be hormone receptor negative, then tamoxifen will not be of any benefit to you.

Question (100 words): When is tamoxifen prescribed for breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Tamoxifen is usually prescribed after surgery for primary breast cancer to reduce the risk of recurrence. It can also be used for local recurrence, locally advanced breast cancer, and secondary (metastatic) breast cancer. In some cases, it may be used as the first treatment when surgery is not appropriate.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Tamoxifen may be prescribed if you have primary breast cancer. This is breast cancer that has not spread beyond the breast or the lymph nodes under the arm. It’s usually given after surgery to reduce the risk of breast cancer returning in the same breast or spreading somewhere else in the body. This is known as adjuvant therapy.

Question (100 words): How is tamoxifen taken and what is the recommended dosage?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Tamoxifen is taken as a tablet, usually once a day. The recommended dose is 20mg daily. It’s best to take it at the same time every day. If you miss a dose, do not take an extra one the next day.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You take tamoxifen as a tablet. Occasionally it may be prescribed as a liquid if you have difficulty swallowing. The recommended dose is usually 20mg daily. It’s best to take it at the same time every day. If you miss a dose, you do not need to take an extra one the next day.

Question (100 words): How long will I need to take tamoxifen?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The duration of tamoxifen treatment depends on your individual situation. For primary breast cancer, it is usually taken for 5 to 10 years. For locally advanced or secondary breast cancer, it is taken as long as it keeps the cancer under control. For those taking it as chemoprevention, it is usually taken for 5 years.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: How long you take tamoxifen for will depend on your individual situation. If you’re being treated for primary breast cancer, you will usually take tamoxifen for between 5 and 10 years. If you’re taking tamoxifen for locally advanced breast cancer or secondary breast cancer, you’ll usually continue to take it for as long as it’s keeping the cancer under control. If you have a significant family history and are taking tamoxifen to reduce your risk of breast cancer developing, you’ll usually take i

Question (100 words): What are the common side effects of tamoxifen?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common side effects of tamoxifen include menopausal symptoms such as hot flushes, night sweats, vaginal irritation, loss of sex drive, mood changes, and headaches. Other common side effects are vaginal discharge, changes in periods, fluid retention, indigestion, and extreme tiredness (fatigue).
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The most common side effects of tamoxifen are menopausal symptoms. These include: Hot flushes, Night sweats and sleep disturbance, Vaginal irritation such as dryness and itching, Loss of sex drive, Mood changes or low mood, Headaches.

Question (100 words): Can tamoxifen affect my bone health?
Answer (Max 2000 words): For postmenopausal women, tamoxifen may slow down bone loss, reducing the risk of osteoporosis. However, for premenopausal women, tamoxifen may slightly increase the risk of osteoporosis, especially if treatment has been given to stop the ovaries from working.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you are postmenopausal there is evidence that tamoxifen slows down bone loss, reducing the risk of your bones losing strength and being more likely to break (osteoporosis). However, tamoxifen may slightly increase the risk of osteoporosis for premenopausal women.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience unexpected vaginal bleeding while taking tamoxifen?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience unexpected vaginal bleeding or pain while taking tamoxifen, you should inform your GP or treatment team immediately. Tamoxifen can affect the lining of the womb, and unexpected bleeding may indicate a more serious condition.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Tamoxifen can affect the lining of the womb (uterus), known as the endometrium, which may become thickened. If you have any unexpected vaginal bleeding or pain, tell your GP or treatment team.

Question (100 words): Can tamoxifen increase the risk of blood clots?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, tamoxifen can increase the risk of blood clots, such as deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE). If you have a history of blood clots or are at risk, your treatment team may recommend an alternative to tamoxifen.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: People with breast cancer have a higher risk of blood clots. Taking tamoxifen also increases the risk of blood clots such as a DVT (deep vein thrombosis). If you have a DVT, there’s a risk part of the blood clot could break away and travel to the lung. This is known as a pulmonary embolism (PE). Blood clots can be life-threatening and should be treated quickly.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I think I have a blood clot while taking tamoxifen?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you suspect you have a blood clot, contact your treatment team or go to your local A&E department immediately. Symptoms include pain, redness or discolouration of the skin, heat and swelling of the arm or leg, shortness of breath, pain or tightness in the chest, and unexplained cough or coughing up blood.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Contact your treatment team or go to your local A&E department straight away if you have any of the following symptoms: Pain, redness/discolouration of the skin, heat and swelling of the arm or leg, Swelling, redness or tenderness where a central line is inserted to give chemotherapy, for example in the arm, chest area or up into the neck, Shortness of breath, Pain or tightness in the chest, Unexplained cough or coughing up blood.

Question (100 words): Can men experience side effects from tamoxifen?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, men can experience similar side effects from tamoxifen as women, such as hot flushes and headaches. Some studies have noted other side effects in men, such as decreased sex drive, though this usually recovers after treatment ends.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Men can have similar side effects as women, such as hot flushes and headaches. A number of small studies have noted other side effects, such as decreased sex drive, though this usually recovers after tamoxifen treatment has ended.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I miss a dose of tamoxifen?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you miss a dose of tamoxifen, do not take an extra dose the next day. The level of the drug in your body will remain high enough from the previous day. Simply take your next scheduled dose at the usual time.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you miss a dose, you do not need to take an extra one the next day. The level of the drug in your body will remain high enough from the previous day.

Question (100 words): Can tamoxifen affect my fertility?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Tamoxifen may cause changes in your menstrual cycle, including lighter, irregular periods or even stopping altogether. Sometimes periods may return after you stop taking tamoxifen. It’s important to discuss any concerns about fertility with your treatment team.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re still having regular periods, you may find your periods change. For example, they may be lighter, irregular or they may stop altogether. This may also be because the menopause has occurred naturally during this time or because other treatment such as chemotherapy has caused an earlier menopause. Sometimes periods may return after you stop taking tamoxifen.

Question (100 words): Are there any dietary restrictions while taking tamoxifen?
Answer (Max 2000 words): There are no specific dietary restrictions while taking tamoxifen. However, some versions of tamoxifen contain small amounts of lactose. If you are lactose intolerant, discuss this with your treatment team or pharmacist.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some versions of tamoxifen contain small amounts of lactose. If you know you are lactose intolerant, discuss this with your treatment team or pharmacist.

Question (100 words): Can I switch to a different brand of tamoxifen if I experience side effects?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, you may discuss switching to a different brand of tamoxifen with your treatment team or GP if you experience side effects. Some people find that tamoxifen produced by one manufacturer suits them better than another.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some people say they notice a change in the side effects they have if they take tamoxifen made by a different manufacturer. This suggests that some people find tamoxifen produced by one manufacturer seems to suit them better than another. You may wish to discuss this with your treatment team or GP.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I want to stop taking tamoxifen before the recommended time?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you want to stop taking tamoxifen before the recommended time, you should talk to your treatment team first. Not taking the drug for the recommended time may increase your risk of the breast cancer coming back or progressing.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If, for any reason, you want to stop taking tamoxifen before the recommended time, talk to your treatment team first. Not taking the drug for the recommended time may increase your risk of the breast cancer coming back or progressing.

Question (100 words): How can I manage fatigue while taking tamoxifen?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Fatigue is a common side effect of tamoxifen and may last for weeks or months. To manage fatigue, inform your GP or treatment team. They can assess you and offer advice on how to manage your energy levels and rule out any other conditions. There are various ways to cope with and manage fatigue, and your treatment team may be able to help you with this.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Extreme tiredness Fatigue is extreme tiredness that does not go away with rest or sleep. It’s a very common side effect of tamoxifen and may last for weeks or months even if your treatment has finished. If you think you have fatigue, tell your GP or treatment team. They can assess you and offer advice on how to manage your energy levels and rule out any other conditions.

Question (100 words): Can tamoxifen cause changes to my vision?
Answer (Max 2000 words): There is a very slight risk of changes to your vision while taking tamoxifen, including a slightly higher risk of developing cataracts. If you notice any changes to your vision, inform your GP or treatment team.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Changes to vision There is a very slight risk of changes to your vision, including a slightly higher risk of developing cataracts. If you notice any changes to your vision, tell your GP or treatment team.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I develop a skin rash while taking tamoxifen?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you develop a skin rash, itchy or dry skin while taking tamoxifen, consult your pharmacist, GP, or treatment team. They can recommend products to help manage these symptoms.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Skin rash You may develop a skin rash, itchy or dry skin while taking tamoxifen. Your pharmacist, GP or treatment team can tell you what products you can use on your skin to help.

Question (100 words): Can tamoxifen be used to reduce the risk of developing breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, tamoxifen may be an option for some women who do not have breast cancer but have a higher risk of developing it because of their family history. This is known as chemoprevention. Your specialist will discuss this if it’s an option for you.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: To reduce the risk of breast cancer developing Tamoxifen may be an option for some women who do not have breast cancer but have a higher risk of developing it because of their family history. It’s given to try to reduce the risk of breast cancer developing. This is known as chemoprevention. Your specialist will discuss this if it’s an option for you.

Question (100 words): Can I take tamoxifen with other drugs?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Always check with your treatment team or pharmacist if you’re taking any other medicines with tamoxifen. Some drugs, like fluoxetine, paroxetine, bupropion, quinidine, and cinacalcet, may interfere with tamoxifen, making it less effective. Your treatment team may suggest alternatives.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Always check with your treatment team or pharmacist if you’re taking any other medicines with tamoxifen.

Question (100 words): Is it safe to take herbal products or supplements while on tamoxifen?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The exact effect and safety of taking herbal products or supplements after a breast cancer diagnosis is not fully understood. Ask your treatment team or pharmacist before taking any herbal products or supplements.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: However, the exact effect and safety of taking these after a diagnosis of breast cancer is not fully understood. Ask your treatment team or pharmacist before taking any herbal products or supplements.

Question (100 words): Can I get vaccinations while taking tamoxifen?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, tamoxifen does not affect your immune system, so it’s safe to have vaccines while you’re taking it.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Tamoxifen does not affect your immune system. This means it’s safe to have vaccines while you’re taking it.

Question (100 words): Can I get pregnant while taking tamoxifen?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, it’s possible to become pregnant while taking tamoxifen even if your periods have become irregular or stopped. It’s advised to use a non-hormonal method of contraception while taking tamoxifen and for 2 months after stopping.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s possible to become pregnant while taking tamoxifen even if your periods have become irregular or stopped.

Question (100 words): Does tamoxifen affect fertility?
Answer (Max 2000 words): In most premenopausal women, tamoxifen may stimulate ovulation and could make you more fertile. However, getting pregnant is not recommended. Continued use may make periods less regular or stop them altogether.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: In most premenopausal women who take tamoxifen, the ovaries continue to work.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I think I may be pregnant while taking tamoxifen?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you think you may be pregnant, tell your specialist as soon as possible.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you think you may be pregnant, tell your specialist as soon as possible.

Question (100 words): Can I breastfeed while taking tamoxifen?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You’re advised not to breastfeed when taking tamoxifen as it may pass through the bloodstream into the breast milk.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You’re advised not to breastfeed when taking tamoxifen as it may pass through the bloodstream into the breast milk.

Question (100 words): How long should I wait to get pregnant after stopping tamoxifen?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You’ll likely be advised to wait at least 2 months after stopping tamoxifen to allow time for the drug to leave your body completely. Talk to your treatment team about the most appropriate length of time for you.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re planning to get pregnant after you’ve finished taking tamoxifen, you’ll likely be advised to wait at least 2 months to allow time for the drug to leave your body completely.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I need treatment or surgery that will reduce my mobility while taking tamoxifen?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Discuss this with your specialist. They will let you know if you need to stop taking tamoxifen and how long for.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you need to have treatment or surgery that will reduce your mobility, discuss this with your specialist.

Question (100 words): Where can I find emotional support if I’ve been diagnosed with breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can find emotional support by talking to someone who has been through the same experience, using online forums, or through services like Breast Cancer Now’s Someone Like Me. You can also speak to specialist nurses by calling the free helpline on 0808 800 6000.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may find it helps to talk to someone who has been through the same experience as you.

Question (100 words): What support is available for those living with secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast Cancer Now offers a range of support services for those living with secondary breast cancer through their Living with Secondary Breast Cancer services.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re living with secondary breast cancer, we have a range of support available through our Living with Secondary Breast Cancer services.

Question (100 words): How can I get more information about diet and breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can find more information about diet and breast cancer in Breast Cancer Now’s Diet and breast cancer booklet.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Find out more about supplements in our Diet and breast cancer booklet.

Question (100 words): What is the recommended method of contraception while taking tamoxifen?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The recommended method of contraception while taking tamoxifen is a non-hormonal method, such as condoms, Femidoms, a diaphragm, or possibly a coil (IUD). Discuss with your treatment team for suitability.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your treatment team is likely to advise you use a non-hormonal method of contraception while taking tamoxifen and for 2 months after stopping.

Question (100 words): How does tamoxifen affect menstrual periods?
