Answer (Max 2000 words): Tamoxifen may make your periods less regular, lighter, or stop altogether. Generally, your periods will start again once you stop taking tamoxifen, though it may take 4 to 5 months for them to become regular again.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Continued use of tamoxifen may make your periods less regular, lighter or stop altogether.

Question (100 words): Can I take a break from tamoxifen if I want to have children?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you’re in your 30s or early 40s and want to have children, discuss with your treatment team if taking a break from tamoxifen is possible.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you want to have children and you’re in your 30s or early 40s, taking hormone treatment for 5 years or more may be a concern. You may want to discuss this with your treatment team and if taking a break from treatment is possible.

Question (100 words): Discuss with your specialist if you need to stop taking tamoxifen before surgery that will reduce your mobility and how long you should stop it for.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you need to have treatment or surgery that will reduce your mobility, discuss this with your specialist.

Question (100 words): How can I get more information and support from Breast Cancer Now?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can get more information and support by calling Breast Cancer Now’s free helpline on 0808 800 6000 or visiting their website at breastcancernow.org.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: For further information and support or to talk things through, you can speak to one of our specialist nurses by calling our free helpline on 0808 800 6000 or on our website breastcancernow.org

Question (100 words): What are the side effects of taking tamoxifen?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The side effects of tamoxifen may include irregular or stopped menstrual periods, increased fertility in some women, and potential interference with certain medications. It’s important to discuss any concerns with your treatment team.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Because of the length of time tamoxifen is taken for, the side effects may hide the signs of a natural menopause.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience side effects from tamoxifen?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience side effects from tamoxifen, discuss them with your treatment team. They can provide guidance and may suggest alternatives or adjustments to your treatment plan.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The side effects of tamoxifen may include irregular or stopped menstrual periods, increased fertility in some women, and potential interference with certain medications.

Question (100 words): How can I support Breast Cancer Now’s work?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can support Breast Cancer Now’s work by making donations or including gifts in wills. Visit breastcancernow.org/give for more information on how to contribute.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: We don’t get any government or NHS funding for our support services or health information. So, we rely on donations and gifts in wills to make our vital work happen.

Question (100 words): What are the common symptoms of breast cancer I should look out for?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common symptoms of breast cancer include a lump or swelling in the breast, upper chest, or armpit; changes to the skin such as puckering or dimpling; changes in the color of the breast; nipple changes like inversion; rash or crusting around the nipple; unusual discharge from the nipple; and changes in the size or shape of the breast. Pain in the breast or armpit that persists is also a concern.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data:
A lump or swelling in the breast, upper chest or armpit
A change to the skin, such as puckering or dimpling
A change to the colour of the breast – the breast may look darker, red or inflamed
A nipple change, for example it has become pulled in (inverted)
Rash or crusting around the nipple
Unusual liquid (discharge) from either nipple
Changes in size or shape of the breast

Question (100 words): How often should I check my breasts for any unusual changes?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You should get into the habit of regularly checking your breasts. There’s no specific frequency mentioned, but making it a routine part of your self-care can help you notice any changes early.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Get used to checking regularly and be aware of anything that’s new or different for you.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice a new or unusual change in my breasts?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you notice any new or unusual changes in your breasts, you should check them with a GP. Early detection is crucial for successful treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Get any new or unusual changes checked by a GP.

Question (100 words): Can men get breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, men can get breast cancer, although it is very rare. It’s important for men to be aware of any changes in their breast tissue as well.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Men can also get breast cancer, but this is very rare.

Question (100 words): Is breast pain usually a sign of breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): On its own, breast pain is not usually a sign of breast cancer. However, persistent pain in the breast or armpit should be checked by a healthcare professional.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: On its own, pain in your breasts is not usually a sign of breast cancer. But look out for pain in your breast or armpit that’s there all or almost all the time.

Question (100 words): How can I check my breasts effectively for any changes?
Answer (Max 2000 words): There’s no special way to check your breasts. You can use the TLC method: TOUCH your breasts to feel for anything new or unusual, LOOK for visible changes, and CHECK any new or unusual changes with a GP.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data:
There’s no special way to check your breasts and you do not need any training. Everyone will have their own way of touching and looking for changes.
TOUCH your breasts
LOOK for changes
CHECK any new or unusual changes with a GP

Question (100 words): What areas should I check when examining my breasts?
Answer (Max 2000 words): When examining your breasts, check your whole breast area, including up to your collarbone (upper chest) and armpits for any changes.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Check your whole breast area, including up to your collarbone (upper chest) and armpits for changes.

Question (100 words): Are most breast changes a sign of cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Most breast changes, including lumps, are not cancer. However, it’s important to get any new or unusual changes checked by a healthcare professional to be sure.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Most breast changes, including lumps, are not cancer. But the sooner breast cancer is found, the more successful treatment is likely to be.

Question (100 words): How can I get support if I have questions or worries about my breasts?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can call Breast Cancer Now for free and confidential support if you have any questions or worries about your breasts or breast cancer. Their helpline number is 0808 800 6000.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have any questions or worries about your breasts or breast cancer, call us free and confidentially. 0808 800 6000

Question (100 words): What age group is most commonly affected by breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast cancer is most common in women over 50. However, it can also affect younger women, though it is less common.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast cancer is most common in women over 50. While uncommon, it can also affect younger women.

Question (100 words): Should I be concerned about changes that appear differently on various skin tones?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, some signs and symptoms of breast cancer may appear differently on various skin tones. It’s important to be aware of any new or unusual changes regardless of your skin tone and consult a healthcare professional if you notice anything concerning.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some of these signs and symptoms may appear differently on various skin tones.

Question (100 words): What does the TLC method stand for in breast self-examination?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The TLC method stands for TOUCH your breasts to feel for anything new or unusual, LOOK for visible changes, and CHECK any new or unusual changes with a GP.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data:
TOUCH your breasts
LOOK for changes
CHECK any new or unusual changes with a GP

Question (100 words): Is it normal for breast appearance to change throughout the menstrual cycle?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, it is normal for breast appearance and feel to change throughout the menstrual cycle due to hormonal fluctuations. However, any persistent or unusual changes should be checked by a healthcare professional.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Get used to checking regularly and be aware of anything that’s new or different for you.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I find a lump in my breast?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you find a lump in your breast, you should schedule an appointment with your GP to have it checked. Early detection and diagnosis are crucial for effective treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A lump or swelling in the breast, upper chest or armpit

Question (100 words): Can lifestyle changes help reduce the risk of breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): While lifestyle changes cannot guarantee the prevention of breast cancer, maintaining a healthy lifestyle with a balanced diet, regular exercise, and avoiding excessive alcohol can help reduce the risk.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Regularly checking your breasts is part of a healthy lifestyle approach to breast health.

Question (100 words): What are the first steps I should take if diagnosed with breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If diagnosed with breast cancer, the first steps include discussing treatment options with your healthcare team, which may include surgery, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, or hormone therapy, and seeking emotional support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Early detection is crucial for successful treatment.

Question (100 words): How can I ensure I’m checking my breasts correctly?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To ensure you’re checking your breasts correctly, use the TLC method: TOUCH your breasts to feel for lumps, LOOK for visible changes, and CHECK any new or unusual changes with a GP. Regular practice will help you become more familiar with your normal breast appearance and feel.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There’s no special way to check your breasts and you do not need any training. Everyone will have their own way of touching and looking for changes.

Question (100 words): What role does early detection play in breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Early detection of breast cancer significantly increases the chances of successful treatment. Regular self-examinations and prompt medical consultation for any unusual changes can lead to earlier diagnosis and more effective treatment options.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The sooner breast cancer is found, the more successful treatment is likely to be.

Question (100 words): Are there any specific signs I should watch for around the nipple?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, specific signs around the nipple to watch for include inversion of the nipple, rash or crusting around the nipple, and unusual discharge from the nipple. Any of these changes should be checked by a healthcare professional.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data:
A nipple change, for example it has become pulled in (inverted)
Rash or crusting around the nipple
Unusual liquid (discharge) from either nipple

Question (100 words): How can I maintain a healthy lifestyle to support my breast health?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To maintain a healthy lifestyle supporting breast health, focus on a balanced diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and whole grains, engage in regular physical activity, limit alcohol consumption, avoid smoking, and maintain a healthy weight. These practices can help reduce the risk of breast cancer.

Question (100 words): Why is early detection of breast cancer important?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Early detection of breast cancer is important because it increases the likelihood of successful treatment and better outcomes.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: But the sooner breast cancer is found, the more successful treatment is likely to be.

Question (100 words): What should I be aware of when checking my breasts?
Answer (Max 2000 words): When checking your breasts, be aware of any new or unusual changes, including lumps, skin changes, color changes, nipple changes, rashes, unusual discharge, and changes in size or shape.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Be aware of anything that’s new or different for you.

Question (100 words): What are the common symptoms of breast cancer I should look out for?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common symptoms of breast cancer include a lump or swelling in the breast, upper chest, or armpit; changes to the skin such as puckering or dimpling; a change in the nipple, such as inversion; rash or crusting around the nipple; changes in size or shape of the breast; unusual liquid discharge from the nipple; and a change in the color of the breast, which may look red or inflamed.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A lump or swelling in the breast, upper chest or armpitA change to the skin, such as puckering or dimplingA nipple change, for example it has become pulled in (inverted)Rash or crusting around the nippleChanges in size or shape of the breastUnusual liquid (discharge) from either nippleA change in the colour of the breast – the breast may look red or inflamed

Question (100 words): Is breast pain a sign of breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast pain on its own is usually not a sign of cancer. However, persistent pain in the breast or armpit that is present all or almost all the time should be checked by a healthcare professional.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: On its own pain in your breasts is not usually a sign of cancer. But look out for pain in your breast or armpit that’s there all or almost all the time.

Question (100 words): How should I check my breasts for any changes?
Answer (Max 2000 words): There’s no special way to check your breasts. Everyone will have their own way of touching and looking for changes. Get used to checking regularly and be aware of anything that’s new or different for you.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There’s no special way to check your breasts and you do not need any training. Everyone will have their own way of touching and looking for changes. Get used to checking regularly and be aware of anything that’s new or different for you.

Question (100 words): What areas should I include when checking my breasts?
Answer (Max 2000 words): When checking your breasts, include the whole breast area, including up to your collarbone (upper chest) and armpits.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Check your whole breast area, including up to your collarbone (upper chest) and armpits.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice any new or unusual changes in my breasts?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you notice any new or unusual changes in your breasts, you should check them with a GP. Most breast changes, including lumps, are not cancer, but early detection increases the likelihood of successful treatment.

Question (100 words): Why is early detection of breast cancer important?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Early detection of breast cancer is important because the sooner breast cancer is found, the more successful treatment is likely to be. Regular checks and prompt medical evaluation of any changes can significantly improve outcomes.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice persistent pain in my breast or armpit?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you notice persistent pain in your breast or armpit that is there all or almost all the time, you should get it checked by a GP. While pain alone is not usually a sign of cancer, persistent pain warrants medical evaluation.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: But look out for pain in your breast or armpit that’s there all or almost all the time.

Question (100 words): What are the common symptoms of breast cancer I should look out for?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common symptoms of breast cancer include a lump or swelling in the breast, upper chest, or armpit; changes to the skin such as puckering or dimpling; a change in the nipple, such as inversion; rash or crusting around the nipple; changes in the size or shape of the breast; unusual discharge from the nipple; and a change in the color of the breast, which may appear red or inflamed.

Question (100 words): What does it mean if my breast looks red or inflamed?

Question (100 words): What does a change in the skin of the breast look like?

Question (100 words): What should I do if I find a lump in my breast?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you find a lump in your breast, you should make an appointment to see a General Practitioner (GP) as soon as possible. While most lumps are not cancerous, it’s important to get them checked to rule out any serious conditions.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Get any new or unusual changes checked by a GP.

Question (100 words): Can changes in nipple appearance be a sign of breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, changes in nipple appearance, such as inversion or rash and crusting around the nipple, can be signs of breast cancer and should be evaluated by a healthcare professional.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A nipple change, for example it has become pulled in (inverted)Rash or crusting around the nipple

Question (100 words): What does unusual discharge from the nipple indicate?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Unusual discharge from the nipple can be a sign of breast cancer or other breast conditions and should be evaluated by a healthcare professional.

Question (100 words): Is redness or inflammation of the breast a symptom of breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, a change in the color of the breast, such as redness or inflammation, can be a symptom of breast cancer and should be checked by a healthcare professional.

Question (100 words): What are the three simple steps to check my breasts?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The three simple steps to check your breasts are: Touch your breasts to feel for anything new or unusual, Look for any changes in appearance, and Check any new or unusual changes with a GP.

Question (100 words): Why is early detection of breast cancer important?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Early detection of breast cancer is important because it increases the likelihood of successful treatment. The sooner breast cancer is found, the more effective the treatment options are likely to be.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Most breast changes, including lumps, are not cancer. But the sooner breast cancer is found, the more successful treatment is likely to be.

Question (100 words): What does it mean if my breast feels different from usual?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If your breast feels different from usual, it could be a sign of cancer. You should get any changes to the way your breasts feel or look checked by a GP.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A change to the way your breasts feel or look could be a sign of cancer. So get any new or unusual changes checked by a GP.

Question (100 words): How can I ensure I’m effectively checking my breasts for changes?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To ensure you’re effectively checking your breasts, get used to checking regularly, be aware of anything that’s new or different for you, and know your body better than anyone else. If in doubt, consult a healthcare professional.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Get used to checking regularly and be aware of anything that’s new or different for you. You know your body better than anyone

Question (100 words): What are the common symptoms of inflammatory breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The common symptoms of inflammatory breast cancer include redness, warmth, or swelling of the breast; skin changing color or looking bruised; ridges or thickening of the skin; skin looking dimpled or pitted like an orange (peau d’orange); an increase in breast size; persistent itching of the breast; an inverted nipple; swelling or lumps in the armpit or around the collarbone; and pain or tenderness in the breast. You may or may not have a lump.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Symptoms can include: Redness, warmth or swelling of the breast; The skin of the breast changing colour or looking bruised; Ridges or thickening of the skin; The skin looking dimpled or pitted like the skin of an orange (this is also known as peau d’orange); An increase in breast size; Persistent itching of the breast; An inverted (pulled-in) nipple; Swelling or lumps in the armpit or around the collarbone; Pain or tenderness in the breast.

Question (100 words): How is inflammatory breast cancer diagnosed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Inflammatory breast cancer is diagnosed through several tests including a mammogram (breast x-ray), ultrasound scan, breast MRI, and biopsy. If symptoms persist despite antibiotics, further tests like PET or CT scans and bone scans may be conducted to check for spread.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: At the breast clinic you may have several tests, including: Mammogram – a breast x-ray; Ultrasound scan – uses sound waves to produce an image; Breast MRI – uses magnetism and radio waves to produce a series of images of the inside of the breast; Biopsy – removal of breast tissue to be looked at under a microscope.

Question (100 words): What is the first treatment usually recommended for inflammatory breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Chemotherapy is usually the first treatment recommended for inflammatory breast cancer. It is given to reduce the size of the cancer and destroy any cancer cells that may have spread elsewhere in the body.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Chemotherapy is usually the first treatment recommended for inflammatory breast cancer, before any surgery. Because it’s the first treatment recommended, it’s called primary or neo-adjuvant chemotherapy.

Question (100 words): What type of surgery is commonly performed for inflammatory breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Most people with inflammatory breast cancer will have a mastectomy, which involves removing the whole breast, including the nipple area. Lymph nodes from under the arm are usually removed at the same time.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Usually, the whole breast is removed, including the nipple area (mastectomy). Your surgeon will normally remove the lymph nodes from under your arm (axilla) at the same time.

Question (100 words): What is radiotherapy and when is it used in treating inflammatory breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Radiotherapy uses high-energy x-rays to destroy cancer cells. It is often used after chemotherapy and surgery to treat inflammatory breast cancer, targeting the whole breast area and sometimes other regions like above the collarbone and under the arm.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Radiotherapy uses high energy x-rays to destroy cancer cells. It’s often used after chemotherapy and surgery to treat inflammatory breast cancer. You will usually have treatment to the whole breast area.

Question (100 words): What is targeted therapy and who might benefit from it?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Targeted therapy involves drugs that block the growth and spread of cancer by interfering with specific processes in cancer cells. People with HER2-positive breast cancer, which has high levels of the HER2 protein, may benefit from targeted therapies like trastuzumab and pertuzumab.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Targeted therapy is the name given to a group of drugs that block the growth and spread of cancer. They target and interfere with processes in the cells that help cancer grow. The most widely used targeted therapies are for HER2-positive breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What is hormone (endocrine) therapy and who needs it?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Hormone therapy is used for oestrogen receptor positive (ER-positive) breast cancers. It works by blocking the effect of oestrogen on breast cancer cells. If your cancer is ER-positive, your specialist will discuss which hormone therapy is most appropriate for you.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Hormone therapies block or stop the effect of oestrogen on breast cancer cells. You will only be prescribed hormone therapy if your breast cancer is ER-positive.

Question (100 words): What are bisphosphonates and why might they be prescribed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Bisphosphonates are drugs that can reduce the risk of breast cancer spreading in women who have been through menopause. They can also be used to treat osteoporosis or secondary breast cancer in the bone.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Bisphosphonates are a group of drugs that can reduce the risk of breast cancer spreading in women who have been through the menopause.

Question (100 words): What should I do if my symptoms do not improve with antibiotics?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If your symptoms do not improve with antibiotics, your GP will refer you to a breast clinic for further tests and evaluation.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you are prescribed antibiotics but your symptoms do not improve, your GP will refer you to a breast clinic.

Question (100 words): What kind of follow-up care can I expect after treatment for inflammatory breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After hospital-based treatment, you will continue to be monitored through follow-up appointments. The frequency of these appointments may decrease over time. Your treatment team will provide a contact for a breast care nurse for any questions or concerns between appointments.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: At the end of your hospital-based treatment, you will continue to be monitored. This is known as follow-up. Your treatment team will give you a name and contact number you can use if you have any questions or concerns between your appointments.

Question (100 words): Are there any clinical trials available for inflammatory breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, there are ongoing clinical trials aimed at improving treatment for inflammatory breast cancer. You can discuss participation in these trials with your treatment team.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Clinical trials are research studies that aim to improve treatment or care for patients. Studies into treatments for inflammatory breast cancer are ongoing.

Question (100 words): What emotional support is available for someone diagnosed with inflammatory breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Emotional support can be provided by breast care nurses, specialists, counsellors, or psychologists. You can also call the helpline on 0808 800 6000 for additional support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There are people who can support you, so don’t be afraid to ask for help if you need it. You can also call our helpline on 0808 800 6000 and talk through your diagnosis, treatment and how you are feeling with one of our team.

Question (100 words): Can inflammatory breast cancer be treated with surgery alone?
Answer (Max 2000 words): No, inflammatory breast cancer is usually treated with a combination of systemic treatments (like chemotherapy) and local treatments (like surgery and radiotherapy) due to its aggressive nature.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Treatment usually involves treating the whole body with drugs (systemic treatment) as well as the affected breast and the area around it (local treatment).

Question (100 words): What is the role of a breast care nurse in my treatment journey?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A breast care nurse provides support, answers your questions, and helps coordinate your care. They can also connect you with additional resources and emotional support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your treatment team will give you a name and contact number you can use if you have any questions or concerns between your appointments. This is usually for a breast care nurse.

Question (100 words): How soon after diagnosis is treatment for inflammatory breast cancer usually started?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Treatment for inflammatory breast cancer is usually started as soon as possible after diagnosis due to the fast-growing nature of the disease.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Because inflammatory breast cancer can develop quickly, treatment is usually started as soon as possible.

Question (100 words): What is the purpose of taking medical photographs of my breast during treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Medical photographs of your breast are taken to monitor how you respond to treatment and to document changes over time.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may also have medical photographs taken of your breast to see how you respond to treatment.

Question (100 words): Can pre-menopausal women with ER-positive breast cancer benefit from ovarian suppression?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, pre-menopausal women with ER-positive breast cancer may be offered ovarian suppression to stop the ovaries from making oestrogen, either permanently or temporarily.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Pre-menopausal women with ER-positive breast cancer may also be offered ovarian suppression. Ovarian suppression is the term used to describe treatments that stop the ovaries from making oestrogen, either permanently or temporarily.

Question (100 words): What lifestyle changes can help during and after treatment for inflammatory breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Adopting a healthy lifestyle, including a balanced diet, regular physical activity, and avoiding smoking, can help support your overall health during and after treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: N/A - Inferred from general advice on lifestyle and health.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience severe side effects from my treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience severe side effects from your treatment, contact your healthcare team immediately for advice and management.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: N/A - General advice on managing side effects.

Question (100 words): How can I get more information about inflammatory breast cancer and its treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can get more information by visiting breastcancernow.org, calling their helpline on 0808 800 6000, or discussing with your treatment team.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: For more information, see our booklets Treating primary breast cancer and Diagnosed with breast cancer: what now? Visit breastcancernow.org

Question (100 words): How should I record my pain levels and what details should I include?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You should rate your pain on a scale from 1 (no pain) to 10 (extreme pain). Note the location, type (aching, sharp, etc.), and whether it's constant or intermittent. Also, record how pain relief medications affect your pain and any side effects they cause. Additionally, note any activities that help or worsen the pain.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s useful to rate any pain you have on a scale from 1 (no pain) to 10 (extreme pain). Record where the pain is and what it feels like.

Question (100 words): What is the best way to track my fatigue levels?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Rate your fatigue from 1 (no fatigue) to 10 (extreme fatigue). Keep a record of when you experience treatment and how it affects your fatigue levels. This will help identify patterns and triggers.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Rate your fatigue level from 1 (no fatigue) to 10 (extreme fatigue – constantly tired, sleeping or resting most of the day).

Question (100 words): What other symptoms or side effects should I record besides pain and fatigue?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You should also record symptoms like breathlessness, nausea, diarrhea, constipation, poor appetite, weight changes, sleep problems, menopausal symptoms, sore mouth, taste changes, and numbness in hands and feet.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may also want to record any symptoms or side effects of your current or new treatment such as: •  Breathlessness • Nausea or vomiting • Diarrhoea or constipation • Poor appetite • Weight loss or gain • Problems sleeping • Menopausal symptoms such as hot flushes • Sore mouth and taste changes • Numbness in the hands and feet

Question (100 words): Can you explain the results of my blood tests?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your specialist can explain the results of your blood tests, including what the numbers mean and how they relate to your overall health and treatment plan.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Can you explain the blood test results to me? What do the results mean?

Question (100 words): What do the images on my scan show?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your specialist can show you the scan and explain what is visible, including the location and size of any tumors, and how they have changed over time.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Can you show me the scan and explain what’s on it?

Question (100 words): What is the goal of my current treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The aim of your treatment could be to shrink tumors, control symptoms, or prolong life. Your specialist can provide specific details based on your individual case.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: What is the aim of my treatment?

Question (100 words): What side effects might I experience with my new treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your specialist can inform you about potential side effects of your new treatment and provide strategies to manage them, including medications that can help.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: What sort of side effects will I get? What can I do to help manage these side effects? Will you give me something for these today?

Question (100 words): Are there other treatment options available for me?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, there may be other treatment options available. Your specialist can discuss alternative therapies, including clinical trials, that you might be eligible for.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: What other treatment options are available? Are there any clinical trials I can join?

Question (100 words): Who can I speak to for more information or support?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can speak to your nurse specialist, other healthcare professionals on your multidisciplinary team, or join support groups for additional information and emotional support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Who else can I speak to? Can I see a/my nurse specialist?

Question (100 words): How can I keep track of my hospital appointments and concerns?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Use the appointment record sheets in your organiser to keep a detailed log of your hospital appointments, including dates, emotional and physical wellbeing ratings, main concerns, new symptoms, questions, test results, and the plan for your treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Use the following pages to keep a record of your hospital appointments and anything you want to discuss.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience new symptoms?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Record any new symptoms in your organiser and report them to your doctor or specialist nurse as soon as possible for evaluation and management.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There’s also a section to help you identify any new symptoms to report to your doctor or specialist nurse.

Question (100 words): How can I get another copy of this organiser if I fill it up?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can order another copy of the organiser by visiting breastcancernow.org/personal-organiser.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you fill up the space in this organiser, you can order another copy at breastcancernow.org/personal-organiser

Question (100 words): What is the multidisciplinary team (MDT) and why is it important?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The multidisciplinary team (MDT) consists of healthcare professionals with different expertise who collaborate to provide comprehensive care. Recording their contact details ensures you can reach out for specific needs.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: People with breast cancer are cared for by a team of healthcare professionals, each with their own expertise. This is known as the multidisciplinary team (MDT).

Question (100 words): What kind of emotional concerns should I discuss with my treatment team?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Discuss emotional concerns such as sadness, anxiety, anger, hopelessness, and feelings about the future with your treatment team. They can provide support and resources to help manage these emotions.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Emotional concerns  ◻Sad or depressed  ◻Worry, fear and anxiety  ◻Managing worrying thoughts  ◻Anger, frustration or guilt  ◻Hopelessness  ◻Feeling different from other people  ◻Feelings about the future  ◻Explaining my feelings to others

Question (100 words): What physical concerns should I highlight during my appointments?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Highlight physical concerns such as uncontrolled symptoms, constipation, nausea, pain, fatigue, and menopausal symptoms. Your treatment team can offer solutions to better manage these issues.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Physical concerns  ◻Symptoms are not well controlled  ◻Constipation or diarrhoea  ◻Indigestion  ◻Nausea or vomiting  ◻Hair loss  ◻Mouth and dental problems  ◻Mobility  ◻Weight changes  ◻Appetite changes  ◻Taste changes  ◻Pain  ◻Fatigue  ◻Personal appearance and body image  ◻Menopausal symptoms  ◻Skin and nail problems  ◻Cough or breathlessness  ◻Concentration and memory  ◻Lymphoedema  ◻Other medical conditions

Question (100 words): What practical concerns should I address with my treatment team?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Address practical concerns such as caring responsibilities, household duties, housing, transport, and employment. Your treatment team can help you find resources and support to manage these areas.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Practical concerns  ◻My caring responsibilities  ◻Household duties  ◻Housing  ◻Transport and parking  ◻Travel to appointments ◻Bathing and dressing  ◻Changes to my independence  ◻Planning for my future  ◻Wigs  ◻Prostheses

Question (100 words): How can I get more information about my illness, treatment, or care?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Discuss your information preferences with your treatment team. They can provide details about your illness, treatment options, clinical trials, and other support services.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Information concerns  ◻Amount of information I prefer  ◻How I prefer to receive information (spoken or written)  ◻Information about my illness, treatment or care  ◻Accessing clinical trials  ◻Accessing other support

Question (100 words): What employment concerns should I discuss with my treatment team?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Discuss employment concerns such as continuing to work, support from employers, adjustments to your work environment, and the possibility of changing jobs. Your treatment team can offer advice and resources.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Employment concerns  ◻Continuing to work  ◻Support from employers  ◻Adjustments to work, workload or environment  ◻Needing to change jobs/finding new employment  ◻Stopping work

Question (100 words): What financial concerns should I address?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Address financial concerns such as benefits, pension, insurance, mortgage, rent, bills, and debt. Your treatment team can connect you with financial advisors and support services.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Financial concerns  ◻Benefits  ◻Pension  ◻Insurance or critical Illness cover  ◻Mortgage  ◻Rent  ◻Bills  ◻Debt  ◻Inheritance

Question (100 words): How can I ensure my cultural and language preferences are considered in my care?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Discuss your preferred language for information and any aids to communication with your treatment team. They can ensure your cultural background is considered in your care plan.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Language and cultural concerns  ◻Preferred language for written and spoken information  ◻Aids to communication  ◻How my cultural background affects my care

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience new or worsening symptoms?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience new or worsening symptoms that don't go away and don't have an obvious cause, you should inform your specialist nurse or doctor about them. It's important to report any symptoms that are new, persistent, or unexplained, as they may require further investigation.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have any new or worsening symptoms that don’t go away and don’t have an obvious cause, tell your specialist nurse or doctor about them.

Question (100 words): What are the common symptoms of secondary breast cancer in the bones?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common symptoms of secondary breast cancer in the bones include persistent pain in the bones (such as the back, hips, or ribs), symptoms of spinal cord compression (severe back pain, difficulty walking, numbness), and symptoms of hypercalcaemia (nausea, vomiting, fatigue, increased urination, confusion, and excessive thirst).
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Pain in your bones, for example in the back, hips or ribs, that doesn’t get better with pain relief and may be worse at night... Symptoms of hypercalcaemia such as nausea and vomiting, fatigue, passing large amounts of urine, confusion and being very thirsty

Question (100 words): What general symptoms should I be aware of with secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): General symptoms to be aware of with secondary breast cancer include feeling tired all the time, increased fatigue, and new symptoms that make you feel unwell or affect your daily life and quality of life.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: GENERAL SYMPTOMS • Feeling tired all the time • Increased fatigue • New symptoms making you feel unwell or that affect your daily/quality of life

Question (100 words): What are the symptoms of secondary breast cancer in the brain?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Symptoms of secondary breast cancer in the brain include headaches, dizziness, nausea or vomiting (especially in the morning), loss of balance, altered vision or speech, weakness or numbness, changes in mood or personality, and fits.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: BRAIN • Headaches • Dizziness • Nausea or vomiting, especially when waking up in the morning • Loss of balance • Altered vision or speech • Weakness or numbness • Changes in mood or personality • Fits

Question (100 words): How can secondary breast cancer affect the lymph nodes?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Secondary breast cancer can affect the lymph nodes by causing a lump or swelling under the arm, breastbone, or collarbone area, swelling in the arm or hand, pain, and a dry cough.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: LYMPH NODES • A lump or swelling under your arm, breastbone or collarbone area • Swelling in your arm or hand • Pain • Dry cough

Question (100 words): What symptoms might indicate secondary breast cancer in the liver?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Symptoms that might indicate secondary breast cancer in the liver include feeling sick all the time, discomfort or swelling under the ribs on the right side or across the upper abdomen, weight loss and loss of appetite, jaundice, and hiccups.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: LIVER • Feeling sick all the time • Discomfort or swelling under the ribs on the right side or across the upper abdomen • Weight loss and a loss of appetite • Jaundice • Hiccups

Question (100 words): What are the symptoms of secondary breast cancer in the lungs?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Symptoms of secondary breast cancer in the lungs include increased breathlessness (either when exerting yourself or at rest), a cough, and pain in the chest or back when breathing.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: LUNG • (Increased) feeling of breathlessness, either when exerting yourself or when resting • A cough • Pain in the chest or back when breathing

Question (100 words): What changes in the skin might indicate secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Changes in the skin that might indicate secondary breast cancer include lasting changes to the skin on the breast or chest wall (particularly around the scar or on the abdomen), changes in skin color or a rash, and painless nodules of different sizes.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: SKIN Lasting changes to the skin on the breast or chest wall, particularly around your scar, or on the abdomen (belly) including: • Change in the colour of the skin or a rash • Painless nodule(s) of different sizes

Question (100 words): Who wrote this booklet and who reviewed it?
Answer (Max 2000 words): This booklet was written by Breast Cancer Now’s clinical specialists and reviewed by healthcare professionals and people affected by breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Personal organiser was written by Breast Cancer Now’s clinical specialists, and reviewed by healthcare professionals and people affected by breast cancer.

Question (100 words): How can I get more copies of this booklet or provide feedback?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can order or download more copies of this booklet from breastcancernow.org/publications. To provide feedback, email health-info@breastcancernow.org.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can order or download more copies from breastcancernow.org/publications We welcome your feedback on this publication: health-info@breastcancernow.org

Question (100 words): What should I do if I need large print, Braille, or an audio CD version of this booklet?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you need a large print, Braille, or audio CD version of this booklet, email health-info@breastcancernow.org to request it.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: For a large print, Braille or audio CD version: Email health-info@breastcancernow.org

Question (100 words): What is the helpline number for Breast Cancer Now?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The helpline number for Breast Cancer Now is 0808 800 6000. You can call this number to discuss any concerns or get support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Call our Helpline on 0808 800 6000

Question (100 words): What should I report to my healthcare team regarding my symptoms?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You should report any symptoms to your healthcare team that are new, don’t go away, or don’t have an obvious cause. This may indicate a change in your cancer or other health issues that need attention.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Talk to your doctor or specialist nurse about ANY symptoms that: • Are new • Don’t go away • Don’t have an obvious cause

Question (100 words): What are the symptoms of spinal cord compression due to secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Symptoms of spinal cord compression include severe or unexplained back pain, difficulty walking, numbness, and loss of bladder or bowel control.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Symptoms of spinal cord compression such as severe or unexplained back pain, difficulty walking, numbness and loss of bladder or bowel control

Question (100 words): How can secondary breast cancer affect my mental health?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Secondary breast cancer can affect your mental health by causing increased fatigue, new symptoms that make you feel unwell, and changes in your daily life and quality of life. It’s important to seek support if you’re experiencing these effects.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: GENERAL SYMPTOMS • Feeling tired all the time • Increased fatigue • New symptoms making you feel unwell or that affect your daily/quality of life

Question (100 words): What should I do if I feel lonely or isolated due to my illness?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you feel lonely or isolated due to your illness, consider reaching out to friends, family, or support groups. You can also contact Breast Cancer Now’s helpline at 0808 800 6000 for additional support and resources.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: ◻Feeling lonely or isolated

Question (100 words): How can I talk to my children about my illness?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Talking to your children about your illness can be challenging. It’s important to be honest, age-appropriate, and provide reassurance. Consider seeking guidance from a healthcare professional or a support group for additional help.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: ◻Talking to my children about my illness

Question (100 words): What support is available for my family members?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Support for your family members can include counseling, support groups, and information resources. Breast Cancer Now offers various resources and can be contacted at 0808 800 6000 for more information.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: ◻Support for my family members

Question (100 words): How can I maintain my health and wellbeing during treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To maintain your health and wellbeing during treatment, focus on a balanced diet, regular exercise, managing alcohol and smoking, addressing sleeping problems, and paying attention to your mental health. Consider seeking professional advice for personalized recommendations.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: ◻Diet ◻Starting to exercise regularly ◻Returning to regular exercise ◻Alcohol ◻Smoking ◻Sleeping problems ◻Mental health

Question (100 words): What should I do if I have spiritual concerns related to my illness?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you have spiritual concerns related to your illness, consider accessing a religious or spiritual leader, discussing any changes to your faith or belief, and seeking support for any loss of meaning or purpose. Breast Cancer Now can provide additional resources and support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: ◻Access to religious/spiritual leader ◻Change to faith or belief ◻Loss of meaning/purpose

Question (100 words): What are the common signs of breast cancer I should look for?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common signs of breast cancer include a lump or swelling in the breast, upper chest, or armpit; changes to the skin such as puckering or dimpling; changes in the nipple, like inversion; rash or crusting around the nipple; changes in breast size or shape; unusual discharge from the nipple; and changes in breast color, such as redness or inflammation.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A lump or swelling in the breast, upper chest or armpitA change to the skin, such as puckering or dimplingA nipple change, for example it has become pulled in (inverted)Rash or crusting around the nippleChanges in size or shape of the breastUnusual liquid (discharge) from either nippleA change in the colour of the breast – the breast may look red or inflamed

Question (100 words): Is breast pain a sign of cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast pain alone is usually not a sign of cancer. However, persistent pain in the breast or armpit should be evaluated by a healthcare professional.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: On its own pain in your breasts is not usually a sign of cancer. But look out for pain in your breast or armpit that’s there all or almost all the time.

Question (100 words): How often should I check my breasts for changes?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You should get used to checking your breasts regularly and be aware of anything that’s new or different for you. There’s no specific frequency, but consistency is key.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Get used to checking regularly and be aware of anything that’s new or different for you.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice a new lump in my breast?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you notice a new lump or any unusual changes in your breast, you should make an appointment to have it checked by a GP as soon as possible.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Get any new or unusual changes checked by a GP.

Question (100 words): Are most breast changes due to cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Most breast changes, including lumps, are not due to cancer. However, it’s important to have any new or unusual changes checked by a healthcare professional to be sure.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Most breast changes, including lumps, are not cancer.

Question (100 words): Why is early detection of breast cancer important?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Early detection of breast cancer is crucial because the sooner it is found, the more successful the treatment is likely to be.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The sooner breast cancer is found, the more successful treatment is likely to be.

Question (100 words): Do I need special training to check my breasts?
Answer (Max 2000 words): No, you do not need any special training to check your breasts. Everyone will have their own way of touching and looking for changes.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There’s no special way to check your breasts and you do not need any training.

Question (100 words): What areas should I check when examining my breasts?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You should check your whole breast area, including up to your collarbone (upper chest) and armpits.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Check your whole breast area, including up to your collarbone (upper chest) and armpits.

Question (100 words): How can I get support if I have questions or worries about my breasts?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can call Breast Cancer Now for free and confidential support. They offer an interpreting service in over 240 languages.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have any questions or worries about your breasts or breast cancer, call us free and confidentially. We have access to an interpreting service in over 240 languages.

Question (100 words): What is the phone number for Breast Cancer Now support?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The phone number for Breast Cancer Now support is 0808 800 6000.

Question (100 words): Should I be concerned if I feel something new or unusual in my breast?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, you should be concerned and have any new or unusual changes in your breast checked by a GP.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Can you feel anything new or unusual? Look for changes. Does anything look different to you? Check any new or unusual changes with a GP.

Question (100 words): What does it mean if my nipple has become inverted?
Answer (Max 2000 words): An inverted nipple can be a sign of breast cancer and should be checked by a healthcare professional.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A nipple change, for example it has become pulled in (inverted)

Question (100 words): Is it normal for breasts to change in size or shape?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Changes in breast size or shape can be normal, but any new or unusual changes should be checked by a healthcare professional.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Changes in size or shape of the breast

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice unusual discharge from my nipple?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Unusual discharge from the nipple can be a sign of breast cancer and should be evaluated by a healthcare professional.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Unusual liquid (discharge) from either nipple

Question (100 words): Can inflammation or redness in the breast be a sign of cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, a change in the color of the breast, such as redness or inflammation, can be a sign of breast cancer and should be checked by a healthcare professional.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A change in the colour of the breast – the breast may look red or inflamed

Question (100 words): What is the best way to get to know how my breasts normally look and feel?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The best way is to regularly check your breasts and become familiar with any changes that are normal for you.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Getting to know how your breasts look and feel normally means you’ll be able to notice any unusual changes.

Question (100 words): Should I worry if I have a rash or crusting around my nipple?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, a rash or crusting around the nipple can be a sign of breast cancer and should be checked by a healthcare professional.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Rash or crusting around the nipple

Question (100 words): What are the red flags I should look for in my breasts?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Red flags include a lump or swelling, changes to the skin, nipple changes, rash or crusting around the nipple, changes in size or shape, unusual discharge, and changes in breast color.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A lump or swelling in the breast, upper chest or armpitA change to the skin, such as puckering or dimplingA nipple change, for example it has become pulled in (inverted)Rash or crusting around the nippleChanges in size or shape of the breastUnusual liquid (discharge) from either nippleA change in the colour of the breast – the breast may look red or inflamed

Question (100 words): How can I be confident in checking my breasts?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can be confident by regularly checking your breasts, becoming familiar with how they normally look and feel, and seeking professional advice for any new or unusual changes.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: We want everyone to have the confidence to check their breasts and report any new or unusual changes.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I find something unusual during my breast check?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you find something unusual during your breast check, you should make an appointment to have it evaluated by a healthcare professional as soon as possible.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Check anything that looks or feels different for you with a GP.

Question (100 words): What is zoledronic acid and why is it prescribed for breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Zoledronic acid is a drug given to reduce the risk of breast cancer coming back and spreading to the bones and other parts of the body. It belongs to a group of drugs called bisphosphonates, which slow down or prevent bone damage. It is prescribed for post-menopausal women who have had treatment for invasive breast cancer that has spread to the lymph nodes under the arm, or if other factors increase the risk of it returning.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Zoledronic acid is a drug given to reduce the risk of breast cancer coming back and spreading to the bones and other parts of the body... It is prescribed for women who have been through the menopause (post-menopausal women).

Question (100 words): How does zoledronic acid work in the body?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Zoledronic acid works by being absorbed in areas of the body where there is a lot of bone remodelling. This interferes with the remodelling process, which may reduce the risk of breast cancer spreading to the bones and elsewhere in the body.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Bisphosphonates like zoledronic acid work by being absorbed in areas of the body where there is a lot of bone remodelling. This interferes with the remodelling process so may reduce the risk of breast cancer spreading to the bones and elsewhere in the body.

Question (100 words): When should zoledronic acid treatment begin after surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Zoledronic acid is usually started within 3 months of final surgery. If you are having chemotherapy after surgery, you’ll usually start taking zoledronic acid within 2 months of completing chemotherapy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Zoledronic acid is usually started within 3 months of final surgery. If you are having chemotherapy after surgery, you’ll usually start taking zoledronic acid within 2 months of completing chemotherapy.

Question (100 words): How is zoledronic acid administered?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Zoledronic acid is given as a drip into a vein in your hand or arm (intravenously). The infusion is usually given in the chemotherapy department of your hospital and takes about 15 minutes.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Zoledronic acid is given as a drip into a vein in your hand or arm (intravenously). The infusion is usually given in the chemotherapy department of your hospital and takes about 15 minutes.

Question (100 words): What are the common side effects of zoledronic acid?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common side effects include flu-like symptoms such as joint and muscle pain, fatigue, shivering, and fever. Other common side effects are nausea, vomiting, headache, red or sore eyes, and anaemia.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Common side effects Flu-like symptoms Zoledronic acid can cause flu-like symptoms such as joint and muscle pain. Other flu-like effects include fatigue, shivering and fever. These can last for a few days.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience flu-like symptoms after zoledronic acid infusion?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience flu-like symptoms such as joint and muscle pain, fatigue, shivering, and fever after your infusion, your treatment team can advise you about taking mild pain relief to help.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your treatment team can advise you about taking mild pain relief to help.

Question (100 words): How can I manage nausea or vomiting caused by zoledronic acid?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience nausea or vomiting, your treatment team can prescribe anti-sickness drugs to relieve it.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your treatment team can prescribe you anti-sickness drugs to relieve it.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I get a headache after zoledronic acid infusion?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you get a headache after your infusion, let your treatment team know as they can advise you about taking mild pain relief.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Let your treatment team know if you get headaches as they can advise you about taking mild pain relief.

Question (100 words): What can be done if my eyes become sore or red after treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If your eyes become sore or red after treatment, your treatment team can prescribe eyedrops to relieve this.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your treatment team can prescribe eyedrops to relieve this.

Question (100 words): What are the less common side effects of zoledronic acid?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Less common side effects include diarrhoea, low calcium levels in the blood (hypocalcaemia), allergic reactions, osteonecrosis of the jaw (ONJ), fractures, and effects on the kidneys.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Less common side effects Diarrhoea This is usually mild. Your treatment team can prescribe anti-diarrhoea medication to help control this.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I have diarrhoea after zoledronic acid infusion?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you have diarrhoea, drink plenty of fluids to avoid getting dehydrated. Contact your treatment team if you have 4 or more episodes of diarrhoea within a 24-hour period.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Contact your treatment team if you have 4 or more episodes of diarrhoea within a 24-hour period. Drink plenty of fluids to avoid getting dehydrated.

Question (100 words): How is low calcium levels in the blood managed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Zoledronic acid can cause calcium levels in the blood to drop too low, known as hypocalcaemia. You’ll have regular blood tests to check your calcium levels. Early symptoms include tingling around the mouth and lips and in the hands and feet. Your treatment team may recommend calcium and vitamin D supplements.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your treatment team may recommend calcium and vitamin D supplements.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience an allergic reaction to zoledronic acid?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience breathlessness or develop an itchy rash, let your treatment team know straight away as it may indicate an allergic reaction.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Let your treatment team know straight away if you become breathless or start to develop an itchy rash.

Question (100 words): What is osteonecrosis of the jaw (ONJ) and how can it be prevented?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Osteonecrosis of the jaw (ONJ) is a rare but serious side effect where some of the jaw bone loses its blood supply and dies. To prevent it, see a dentist before starting treatment, maintain good dental hygiene, and avoid smoking. If you need dental work, ensure it is completely healed before starting zoledronic acid.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Osteonecrosis Zoledronic acid can cause some of the jaw bone to lose its blood supply and die. This is called osteonecrosis of the jaw (ONJ). It’s a rare but serious side effect of zoledronic acid.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience lasting pain in my thigh, hip, or groin?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience lasting pain in your thigh, hip, or groin, let your treatment team know as zoledronic acid can, in rare cases, cause the large bone in the upper leg (femur) to fracture.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have lasting pain in your thigh, hip or groin, let your treatment team know.

Question (100 words): How are the effects of zoledronic acid on the kidneys monitored?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Zoledronic acid can affect the way the kidneys work. You will have blood tests before you start treatment and throughout treatment to monitor this.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You will have blood tests before you start treatment and throughout treatment to monitor this.

Question (100 words): Can I continue zoledronic acid treatment if I need dental work?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you need dental work, it’s important to speak to your treatment team. Any dental problems with your teeth or gums must be completely healed before starting treatment. If you need a dental procedure, such as having a tooth removed, you’ll need to wait at least 4 weeks afterwards before starting or restarting zoledronic acid.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you need any dental work, it’s important to speak to your treatment team, as any dental problems with your teeth or gums must be completely healed before starting treatment.

Question (100 words): How often will I need zoledronic acid infusions?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You may be given an infusion of zoledronic acid every 6 months for 3 years or every 3 months for 2 years.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may be given an infusion of zoledronic acid every 6 months for 3 years or every 3 months for 2 years.

Question (100 words): What support is available if I have questions or concerns about zoledronic acid?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you'd like any further information on zoledronic acid or just want to talk things through, you can call the free helpline on 0808 800 6000. You can also find more support services online at breastcancernow.org/oursupport.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you'd like any further information on zoledronic acid or just want to talk things through, you can call our free helpline on 0808 800 6000.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I suspect I have osteonecrosis of the jaw (ONJ)?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you develop symptoms of ONJ such as lasting jaw pain, loose teeth, swelling, redness, or ulcers on the gums, let your treatment team and dentist know straight away.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Let your treatment team and dentist know straight away if you have any of these symptoms.

Question (100 words): Is it safe to continue my pregnancy if I have breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Most women continue their pregnancy while undergoing breast cancer treatment. There is no evidence that ending a pregnancy will improve outcomes. However, some women may choose to terminate the pregnancy, especially if chemotherapy is recommended in the first trimester.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Most women continue their pregnancy while having breast cancer treatment. There’s no evidence that ending a pregnancy (termination) will improve your outcome if you’re diagnosed with breast cancer during pregnancy.

Question (100 words): Who will be part of my treatment team during pregnancy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your treatment team will include a breast care nurse, breast surgeon, oncologist, obstetrician, and midwife, all experienced in caring for women with breast cancer during pregnancy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The teams looking after you will include a breast care nurse, breast surgeon, oncologist, obstetrician and midwife who have experience in caring for women with breast cancer during pregnancy.

Question (100 words): Can breast cancer during pregnancy affect my baby?
Answer (Max 2000 words): There is no evidence that having breast cancer during pregnancy affects your baby’s development. You cannot pass cancer cells to your baby, but your baby could inherit an altered gene if you have one.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There’s no evidence that having breast cancer during pregnancy affects your baby’s development in the womb. You cannot pass cancer cells on to your baby.

Question (100 words): Is breast cancer during pregnancy more aggressive?
Answer (Max 2000 words): There is no conclusive evidence that breast cancer during pregnancy is more aggressive. However, it can be more difficult to detect, leading to later-stage diagnoses.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There’s no conclusive evidence that breast cancer during pregnancy is more aggressive than breast cancer that happens at other times.

Question (100 words): What types of breast cancer surgery can I have during pregnancy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can have surgery safely during all trimesters. Options include mastectomy (removal of all breast tissue) and breast-conserving surgery (removal of the cancer with a margin of normal tissue). General anesthesia is considered safe, though there is a slight risk of miscarriage in early pregnancy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can have surgery safely during all trimesters of pregnancy. The 2 main types of breast surgery are: • Mastectomy – removal of all the breast tissue usually including the nipple area • Breast-conserving surgery – removal of the cancer with a margin (border) of normal breast tissue around it.

Question (100 words): Can I have breast reconstruction during pregnancy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Immediate breast reconstruction is not usually offered during pregnancy due to increased risks and longer surgery times. You can discuss delayed reconstruction with your treatment team after your baby is born.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast reconstruction at the same time as your mastectomy (immediate reconstruction) is not normally offered during pregnancy.

Question (100 words): What happens if cancer has spread to my lymph nodes?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If cancer has spread to your lymph nodes, your surgeon may recommend a lymph node clearance, where all lymph nodes under your arm are removed. A sentinel lymph node biopsy can be done using a radioisotope or magnetic tracer, which is safe during pregnancy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If tests before your operation show your lymph nodes contain cancer cells, your surgeon is likely to recommend a lymph node clearance.

Question (100 words): Can I have chemotherapy during pregnancy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Chemotherapy is not recommended during the first trimester due to risks to the baby. It is considered safe during the second and third trimesters, though babies may be born early and have a slightly lower birth weight.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Chemotherapy is not recommended during the first trimester as it may affect the development of an unborn baby or cause miscarriage. Chemotherapy is considered safe during the second and third trimesters.

Question (100 words): Is radiotherapy safe during pregnancy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Radiotherapy is not usually recommended at any stage of pregnancy due to the risk, even with a very low dose, to the baby.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Radiotherapy is not usually recommended at any stage of pregnancy, as even a very low dose may carry a risk to the baby.

Question (100 words): What tests and scans are safe during pregnancy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Ultrasound scans, mammograms with shielding, digital breast tomosynthesis, and MRI scans (without contrast dye) are considered safe during pregnancy. CT scans and bone scans are usually not recommended due to radiation risks.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You’ll usually be offered an ultrasound scan first, which uses sound waves to produce an image of the breast. This is completely safe and will not affect your baby in any way.

Question (100 words): Is it safe to have a biopsy during pregnancy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, core biopsies and fine needle aspirations are safe during pregnancy. There is a small risk of bruising or developing a milk fistula if breastfeeding.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A core biopsy uses a hollow needle to take a small sample of tissue from the breast and sometimes lymph nodes. This is done using a local anaesthetic. The sample is then sent to the laboratory where it is looked at under a microscope. This test is safe for you and your baby.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I need a bone scan while breastfeeding?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you need a bone scan while breastfeeding, you’ll usually be advised to discard your breast milk for a short time after the scan due to the radioactive material used.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you need a bone scan during breastfeeding, you’ll usually be given information recommending you discard the breast milk for a short time after the bone scan.

Question (100 words): Will I need to stop breastfeeding before treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You may be advised to stop breastfeeding before certain treatments. If your cancer only affects one breast, you may still be able to breastfeed from the unaffected breast.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you are advised to stop breastfeeding your treatment team or midwife will offer advice on how to do this.

Question (100 words): What side effects might I experience from chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common side effects of chemotherapy include nausea and vomiting. Anti-sickness and steroid treatments are considered safe for pregnant women to manage these side effects.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Side effects of chemotherapy include feeling sick (nausea) and being sick (vomiting). Anti-sickness and steroid treatments used to control and treat this are considered safe for pregnant women.

Question (100 words): Can I continue chemotherapy after giving birth?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, you can continue chemotherapy after giving birth, but you will not be able to breastfeed.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Chemotherapy can continue after your baby is born, but you will not be able to breastfeed.

Question (100 words): What additional scans might I need from 28 weeks of pregnancy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You may be offered growth scans from 28 weeks and an echocardiogram if you’ve had heart function problems during your breast cancer treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: In addition to the normal scans during pregnancy, you may be offered growth scans from 28 weeks.

Question (100 words): How will my baby’s growth and wellbeing be monitored during my treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your obstetric and midwife team will monitor the growth and wellbeing of your baby throughout your treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your obstetric and midwife team will monitor the growth and wellbeing of your baby.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I feel overwhelmed with the information about my treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): It can be helpful to bring someone with you to appointments who can listen and help you remember what was discussed. Your treatment team is there to support you and answer any questions you may have.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may feel overwhelmed with a lot of new information. It can be useful to take someone with you to appointments who can listen and help you remember what was said.

Question (100 words): What type of surgery is recommended during the first trimester of pregnancy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): During the first trimester, a mastectomy is more likely to be recommended because radiotherapy, which is usually needed after breast-conserving surgery, is not advised during pregnancy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: During the first trimester of pregnancy, you’re more likely to be offered a mastectomy.

Question (100 words): Can I have breast-conserving surgery during the second or third trimester?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, breast-conserving surgery may be an option during the second or third trimester, especially if chemotherapy is recommended and can be given after your baby is born.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re diagnosed in your second trimester and chemotherapy is recommended after surgery, breast-conserving surgery may be an option.

Question (100 words): Can I have radiotherapy during pregnancy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If your treatment team recommends radiotherapy during pregnancy, they will adapt it to protect the baby. For more information, refer to the Radiotherapy for primary breast cancer booklet.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If your treatment team would like you to have radiotherapy during pregnancy, they will discuss how your radiotherapy will be adapted to protect the baby.

Question (100 words): Can I take hormone therapy during pregnancy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Hormone therapies are not given during pregnancy as it’s not known whether they can harm a developing baby. If your breast cancer is ER-positive, you will begin hormone therapy after your baby is born.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Hormone therapies are not given during pregnancy as it’s not known whether they can harm a developing baby.

Question (100 words): Is targeted therapy safe during pregnancy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Targeted therapy is not usually given during pregnancy due to insufficient evidence on its effects on a developing baby. If suitable, you’ll start it after your baby is born.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Targeted therapy is not usually given during pregnancy. As these treatments are newer there’s less evidence on how they may affect a developing baby.

Question (100 words): Will I have a vaginal delivery if I have breast cancer during pregnancy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Most women diagnosed with breast cancer during pregnancy reach full term and have a vaginal delivery. However, this may depend on your individual circumstances and the advice of your obstetric and treatment teams.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Most women diagnosed with breast cancer during pregnancy reach the full term of their pregnancy and have a vaginal delivery.

Question (100 words): What happens if my baby needs to be born early?
