Answer (Max 2000 words): Paclitaxel is given intravenously, usually through a cannula in the hand or arm. It can also be administered via a Hickman line, PICC, or an implanted port.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Paclitaxel is given into a vein (intravenously)... You could also have paclitaxel through: A skin-tunnelled catheter (Hickman line), A peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC), An implanted port.

Question (100 words): What tests are done before starting paclitaxel treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Before starting paclitaxel, you will have blood tests, your height and weight measured, and tests to check your heart function, such as an ECG and echocardiogram.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You’ll have blood tests and your height and weight will be measured. You may also have tests to check your heart function, such as: An ECG (electrocardiogram), An echocardiogram (an ultrasound scan of the heart).

Question (100 words): How often and for how long will I receive paclitaxel treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): For primary breast cancer, paclitaxel is usually given every week or every 2 weeks for 9 to 12 weeks. The duration varies for locally advanced and secondary breast cancer based on individual circumstances.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: For primary breast cancer, you’ll usually have paclitaxel either every week or every 2 weeks for between 9 and 12 weeks.

Question (100 words): What are the common side effects of paclitaxel?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common side effects include effects on blood cells (increasing infection risk, anemia, bruising), hair loss, numbness and tingling in hands or feet, muscle and joint pain, nausea, skin reactions, sore mouth, and extreme tiredness.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Paclitaxel can temporarily affect the number of blood cells in the body... You may have pain, numbness or tingling in your hands and feet after you have your treatment.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience signs of infection during paclitaxel treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Contact your hospital immediately if you have a high or low temperature, suddenly feel unwell, or have symptoms of an infection such as a sore throat or cough.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You should contact your hospital immediately if you have any of the following: A high temperature (over 37.5°C) or low temperature (under 36°C), Symptoms of an infection, for example a sore throat, a cough.

Question (100 words): Will I lose my hair during paclitaxel treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, paclitaxel causes hair loss. Most people will lose all their hair, including eyebrows, eyelashes, and body hair. Hair loss usually begins about 2 weeks after the first treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Paclitaxel causes hair loss. Most people will lose all their hair, including eyebrows, eyelashes and body hair.

Question (100 words): What can I do to manage hair loss during paclitaxel treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can try scalp cooling to reduce hair loss. This involves wearing a cold cap before, during, and after treatment. Hair loss is usually temporary, and hair will begin to grow back after treatment ends.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can try scalp cooling to stop you losing some or all the hair on your head.

Question (100 words): What is peripheral neuropathy and how does it relate to paclitaxel?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Peripheral neuropathy is a side effect of paclitaxel that causes pain, numbness, or tingling in the hands and feet due to its effect on nerves. Symptoms can improve after treatment ends but may persist in some cases.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may have pain, numbness or tingling in your hands and feet after you have your treatment. This is due to the effect of paclitaxel on the nerves and is known as peripheral neuropathy.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience muscle or joint pain after paclitaxel treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Muscle or joint pain, known as taxane acute pain syndrome (TAPS), can occur after treatment. You may need pain relief or anti-inflammatory drugs like paracetamol or ibuprofen. Consult your treatment team for the correct dosage and duration.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your muscles or joints may ache or feel painful 2 or 3 days after you have your treatment. This usually wears off after a few days to a week but may last a bit longer.

Question (100 words): How is nausea and vomiting managed during paclitaxel treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You will be given anti-sickness medication before each cycle of chemotherapy and some to take home. If nausea and vomiting are severe, contact your treatment team or the 24-hour helpline.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You’ll be given anti-sickness medication, as tablets or into a vein, before each cycle of chemotherapy. You’ll also have some anti-sickness tablets to take home.

Question (100 words): What skin reactions can occur with paclitaxel and how are they treated?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You may develop a rash, skin color changes, or hand-foot syndrome. Your doctor may prescribe medication, gels, or creams to manage these symptoms.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may develop a rash anywhere on your body or your skin might change colour... Your treatment team may prescribe gels or creams to apply to the affected areas.

Question (100 words): How can I manage a sore mouth during paclitaxel treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Use a prescribed mouthwash to reduce soreness and prevent mouth ulcers. Use a small, soft toothbrush and see your dentist for a check-up before starting treatment. Avoid dental work during treatment if possible.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may be given mouthwash to reduce soreness and prevent mouth ulcers developing. It’s a good idea to use a small, soft toothbrush during this time.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience diarrhea or constipation during paclitaxel treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your chemotherapy team can prescribe medication to help control diarrhea or constipation. Contact your treatment team if you have diarrhea 4 or more times in 24 hours.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your chemotherapy team can prescribe medicine to help control it and can give you information about diet.

Question (100 words): What is cancer-related fatigue and how is it managed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Cancer-related fatigue is extreme tiredness that does not go away with rest or sleep. Inform your GP or treatment team, who can offer advice on managing your energy levels.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Cancer-related fatigue is extreme tiredness that does not go away with rest or sleep. It’s a very common side effect of breast cancer treatment.

Question (100 words): Can paclitaxel cause long-term side effects?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Some side effects like peripheral neuropathy may persist after treatment ends. Discuss any long-term concerns with your treatment team.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Symptoms may take longer to improve and, in some cases, may not go away completely.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I have an allergic reaction to paclitaxel?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Before each dose, you may be given steroids to reduce the chances of an allergic reaction. If you experience signs of an allergic reaction, contact your treatment team immediately.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Before each dose you may be given steroids to reduce the chances of an allergic reaction.

Question (100 words): How can I get emotional support during paclitaxel treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Seek emotional support from your treatment team, support groups, or counseling services. The helpline number 0808 800 6000 is available for additional support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Call our helpline on 0808 800 6000

Question (100 words): What should I do if I miss a paclitaxel treatment appointment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Contact your treatment team as soon as possible to reschedule your appointment and discuss any concerns or questions you may have.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You should be given a 24-hour contact number or told who to contact if you feel unwell at any time during your treatment.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience dizziness or lightheadedness during paclitaxel treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you feel dizzy or lightheaded during paclitaxel treatment, it may indicate low blood pressure. You should inform your treatment team immediately. They will monitor your blood pressure regularly and take necessary steps to manage it.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data:
Low blood pressure 
Your blood pressure will be checked regularly while you’re on paclitaxel. Let your treatment team know if you feel dizzy or lightheaded.

Question (100 words): How will paclitaxel affect my nails, and what should I do if I notice changes?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Paclitaxel may cause changes in your fingernails and toenails, such as color or texture changes, ridges, or increased brittleness. If you notice any signs of infection like redness, heat, swelling, or pain, report it to your treatment team immediately.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Paclitaxel may make your fingernails and toenails look different. Their colour or texture might change or ridges might form in the nails. They might also become more brittle and cracked. Occasionally the nail may lift off the nail bed and fall out, but they’ll grow back.

Question (100 words): What are the signs of an allergic reaction to paclitaxel, and what should I do if it happens?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Signs of an allergic reaction to paclitaxel include flushing, skin rash, itching, back pain, shortness of breath, faintness, fever, or chills. If you experience any of these symptoms, especially within the first few minutes of treatment, inform your treatment team immediately. They will stop the treatment and manage the reaction.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data:
Symptoms of an allergic reaction include: 
• Flushing 
• Skin rash 
• Itching 
• Back pain 
• Shortness of breath 
• Faintness 
• Fever or chills

Question (100 words): What are the symptoms of a blood clot, and what should I do if I suspect I have one?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Symptoms of a blood clot include pain, redness or discolouration of the skin, heat and swelling of the arm or leg, swelling, redness or tenderness where a central line is inserted, shortness of breath, pain or tightness in the chest, and an unexplained cough or coughing up blood. If you experience any of these symptoms, contact your treatment team or go to your local A&E department immediately.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data:
Blood clot symptoms 
Contact your treatment team or go to your local A&E department straight away if you have any of the following symptoms: 
• Pain, redness/discolouration of the skin, heat and swelling of the arm or leg 
• Swelling, redness or tenderness where a central line is inserted to give chemotherapy, for example in the arm, chest area or up into the neck 
• Shortness of breath 
• Pain or tightness in the chest 
• Unexplained cough or coughing up blood

Question (100 words): How might paclitaxel affect my fertility, and what should I discuss with my treatment team?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The effects of paclitaxel on fertility are not fully known and may depend on other chemotherapy drugs you are taking, your age, and your overall health. It’s important to discuss any fertility concerns with your treatment team before starting treatment. Some women may experience temporary or permanent amenorrhea (stoppage of periods) during chemotherapy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data:
Effects on fertility 
At the moment, we do not know whether paclitaxel affects fertility. The effects will depend on any other chemotherapy drugs you’re having at the same time, or have had in the past, and your age.

Question (100 words): Can I have sex during paclitaxel treatment, and what contraception should I use?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can still have sex during paclitaxel treatment. It’s advised to use barrier methods of contraception, such as condoms, during treatment and for 6 months after treatment. Men should also use contraception for 6 months after treatment ends. It’s important not to become pregnant while on treatment as paclitaxel can harm a developing baby.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data:
Sex, contraception and pregnancy 
You can still have sex during treatment. It’s thought chemotherapy drugs cannot pass into vaginal fluids or semen, but this cannot be completely ruled out. Most treatment teams will advise using barrier methods of contraception, such as condoms, during treatment and for 6 months after treatment.

Question (100 words): What should I know about alcohol consumption after paclitaxel treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Paclitaxel contains alcohol, so your blood alcohol level may be above the legal limit after treatment. You should not drive or operate machinery for a few hours after your treatment. If you’re addicted to alcohol or are worried about it, inform your treatment team before starting treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data:
Alcohol 
Paclitaxel contains alcohol, so after you have your treatment, your blood alcohol level may be above the legal limit. You should not drive or operate machinery for a few hours after your treatment.

Question (100 words): Can I get travel vaccinations while on paclitaxel treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You should not have live vaccines while on paclitaxel treatment as they could be harmful if your immune system is weakened. Live vaccines include mumps, measles, rubella, polio, BCG (tuberculosis), and yellow fever. It’s safe to have these vaccinations 6 months after your treatment finishes. Consult your GP or treatment team before having any vaccinations.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data:
Travel vaccinations 
If you’re planning a holiday or need to travel overseas, check with your treatment team first. You should not have any live vaccines while you’re having chemotherapy.

Question (100 words): When should I get a COVID-19 or flu vaccination if I’m on paclitaxel treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you’re on paclitaxel treatment, speak to your treatment team about the best time to get a COVID-19 vaccination. For the flu vaccine, which is not a live vaccine, talk to your chemotherapy team or breast care nurse about the best time to have your flu jab.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data:
COVID-19 vaccination 
If you’re having chemotherapy or targeted therapies, you’re advised to speak to your treatment team about the best time to have a COVID-19 vaccination. 
Flu vaccination 
Anyone at risk of a weakened immune system, and therefore more prone to infection, should have the flu vaccine. This includes people due to have, or already having, chemotherapy.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice pain, redness, or swelling at the injection site during paclitaxel treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience pain, redness, discolouration, or swelling where the cannula has been inserted or along the vein, inform your chemotherapy nurse immediately. If paclitaxel leaks out of the vein (extravasation), it can damage surrounding tissue, leading to tenderness, darkening, and hardening around the injection site.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data:
Reaction in the injection site 
You might get pain, redness, discolouration or swelling where the cannula (small plastic tube) has been inserted or anywhere along the vein.

Question (100 words): How will paclitaxel affect my liver, and what monitoring will be done?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Paclitaxel may temporarily affect how well your liver works. You will have regular blood tests to monitor your liver function throughout your treatment. Your liver function will usually return to normal when the treatment has stopped.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data:
Effects on the liver 
Paclitaxel may affect how well your liver works. This is temporary and your liver function will usually return to normal when the treatment has stopped.

Question (100 words): What are the rare side effects of paclitaxel on the heart, and how are they managed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Paclitaxel can cause changes in your heart rate, which will be carefully monitored during your treatment. These changes can usually be treated easily, and you will not have to stop your treatment. This is not the same as having an allergic reaction to paclitaxel.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data:
Rare side effects 
Changes in heart rate 
Paclitaxel can cause changes in your heart rate, so you will be carefully monitored for this during your treatment.

Question (100 words): What are the effects of paclitaxel on the lungs, and what should I do if I experience breathing problems?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Paclitaxel can cause scarring or inflammation of the lung tissue, known as interstitial lung disease (ILD) or pneumonitis. Contact your treatment team immediately if you have shortness of breath, a cough, chest tightness, or wheezing. You may need a chest x-ray or CT scan to check for ILD.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data:
Effects on the lungs 
Paclitaxel can cause scarring or inflammation of the lung tissue. You may hear this called interstitial lung disease (ILD) or pneumonitis. Contact your treatment team straight away if you have: 
• Shortness of breath 
• A cough, with or without a high temperature 
• Any new or worsening breathing problems, such as chest tightness or wheezing

Question (100 words): What should I do if I suspect I have interstitial lung disease (ILD) caused by paclitaxel?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you suspect you have ILD caused by paclitaxel, contact your treatment team immediately. You may need to stop treatment temporarily and have steroids to treat the inflammation. Early treatment can help prevent long-term damage to the lungs.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data:
Effects on the lungs 
If paclitaxel has caused inflammation to your lungs, you may need to stop treatment temporarily and have steroids to treat the inflammation. Early treatment of the inflammation can help to prevent long-term damage to the lungs.

Question (100 words): How will paclitaxel treatment affect my concentration and memory?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Treatment with paclitaxel can affect your ability to concentrate and make you more forgetful. This is sometimes referred to as “chemo brain” or “chemo fog,” but your treatment team may call it cognitive impairment. It usually improves over time after treatment has finished.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data:
Effects on your concentration 
Treatment can affect your ability to concentrate and make you more forgetful. This is sometimes referred to as “chemo brain” or “chemo fog”, but your treatment team may call it cognitive impairment. It usually improves over time after treatment has finished.

Question (100 words): What precautions should I take regarding live vaccines if I’m on paclitaxel treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You should not have live vaccines while on paclitaxel treatment as they could be harmful if your immune system is weakened. Live vaccines include mumps, measles, rubella, polio, BCG (tuberculosis), and yellow fever. It’s safe to have these vaccinations 6 months after your treatment finishes. Consult your GP or treatment team before having any vaccinations.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data:
Travel vaccinations 
If you’re planning a holiday or need to travel overseas, check with your treatment team first. You should not have any live vaccines while you’re having chemotherapy.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience tenderness, darkening, or hardening around the injection site after paclitaxel treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After a few weeks, you may notice tenderness, darkening, and hardening around where the cannula was inserted. This should fade in time. If you experience these symptoms, inform your treatment team.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: After a few weeks you may notice tenderness, darkening and hardening around where the cannula was inserted. This should fade in time.

Question (100 words): How will paclitaxel treatment affect my ability to drive or operate machinery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Paclitaxel contains alcohol, so your blood alcohol level may be above the legal limit after treatment. You should not drive or operate machinery for a few hours after your treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data:
Alcohol 
Paclitaxel contains alcohol, so after you have your treatment, your blood alcohol level may be above the legal limit. You should not drive or operate machinery for a few hours after your treatment.

Question (100 words): What should I discuss with my treatment team before starting paclitaxel treatment regarding fertility?
Answer (Max 2000 words): It’s important to discuss any fertility concerns with your treatment team before starting paclitaxel treatment. The effects on fertility are not fully known and may depend on other chemotherapy drugs you are taking, your age, and your overall health. Some women may experience temporary or permanent amenorrhea (stoppage of periods) during chemotherapy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data:
Effects on fertility 
At the moment, we do not know whether paclitaxel affects fertility. The effects will depend on any other chemotherapy drugs you’re having at the same time, or have had in the past, and your age.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience any new or worsening breathing problems during paclitaxel treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience any new or worsening breathing problems such as shortness of breath, a cough, chest tightness, or wheezing during paclitaxel treatment, contact your treatment team immediately. You may need a chest x-ray or CT scan to check for interstitial lung disease (ILD) or pneumonitis.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data:
Effects on the lungs 
Contact your treatment team straight away if you have: 
• Shortness of breath 
• A cough, with or without a high temperature 
• Any new or worsening breathing problems, such as chest tightness or wheezing

Question (100 words): What is docetaxel and how does it work?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Docetaxel is a chemotherapy drug that destroys cancer cells by affecting their ability to divide and grow. It is also known by brand names such as Taxotere. While it targets cancer cells, it can also affect other cells in the body, leading to side effects.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Docetaxel is a chemotherapy drug. Chemotherapy destroys cancer cells by affecting their ability to divide and grow.

Question (100 words): When is docetaxel given in breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Docetaxel is used to treat primary breast cancer, either before surgery to shrink the tumor or after surgery to reduce the risk of recurrence. It is also used for locally advanced or secondary breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Docetaxel is used to treat primary breast cancer (cancer that has not spread beyond the breast or the lymph nodes under the arm) together with other chemotherapy drugs.

Question (100 words): How is docetaxel administered?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Docetaxel is given intravenously, usually through a cannula in the hand or lower arm. It can also be administered through a skin-tunnelled catheter, a PICC line, or an implanted port.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Docetaxel is given into a vein (intravenously). This will usually be through a cannula, a small tube that’s inserted into a vein in the back of your hand or lower arm.

Question (100 words): How often will I receive docetaxel treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Docetaxel is typically given once every 3 weeks over about 1 hour. This period allows your body to recover between cycles.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Docetaxel is normally given once every 3 weeks, over about 1 hour. This is called a cycle.

Question (100 words): What tests are done before starting docetaxel treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Before starting docetaxel, you will have blood tests, measurements of your height and weight, and tests to check your heart function, such as an ECG or echocardiogram.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You’ll have blood tests and your height and weight will be measured. You may also have tests to check your heart function, such as: An ECG (electrocardiogram), a simple test that checks your heart rhythm An echocardiogram (an ultrasound scan of the heart)

Question (100 words): What are the common side effects of docetaxel?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common side effects include effects on blood cells (risk of infection, anaemia, bruising and bleeding), hair loss, numbness and tingling in hands or feet, painful muscles and joints, nausea and vomiting, fluid retention, skin reactions, nail reactions, sore mouth, taste changes, and extreme tiredness.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Like any treatment, docetaxel can cause side effects. Everyone reacts differently to drugs and some people have more side effects than others.

Question (100 words): Will I lose my hair with docetaxel treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, docetaxel causes hair loss. Most people will lose all their hair, including eyebrows, eyelashes, and body hair. Hair loss usually begins about 2 weeks after the first treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Docetaxel causes hair loss. Most people will lose all their hair, including eyebrows, eyelashes and body hair.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I suspect I have an infection during docetaxel treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Contact your hospital immediately if you have a high or low temperature, suddenly feel unwell, or have symptoms of an infection such as a sore throat, cough, or frequent urination.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You should contact your hospital immediately if you have any of the following: A high temperature (over 37.5°C) or low temperature (under 36°C), or whatever your treatment team has advised Suddenly feeling unwell, even with a normal temperature Symptoms of an infection, such as a sore throat, cough, needing to pass urine often or feeling cold or shivery

Question (100 words): Can I use scalp cooling to prevent hair loss with docetaxel?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, you can try scalp cooling to reduce hair loss. This involves wearing a cold cap before, during, and after your treatment to lower the temperature of your scalp and reduce blood flow to your hair follicles.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can try scalp cooling to stop you losing some or all the hair on your head. This involves wearing a cold cap before, during and for 1 to 2 hours after your treatment with the chemotherapy drugs.

Question (100 words): What is peripheral neuropathy and how does it relate to docetaxel?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Peripheral neuropathy is a side effect of docetaxel that causes pain, numbness, or tingling in the hands and feet due to its effect on the nerves. Symptoms can be mild to severe and may persist after treatment ends.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may have pain, numbness or tingling in your hands and feet after you have your treatment. This is due to the effect of docetaxel on the nerves and is known as peripheral neuropathy.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience nausea and vomiting during docetaxel treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You will be given anti-sickness medication before each cycle of chemotherapy. If nausea and vomiting are affecting you, inform your treatment team. Contact them if you have severe vomiting and cannot drink any fluids.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You’ll be given anti-sickness medication, as tablets or into a vein, before each cycle of chemotherapy. You’ll also have some anti-sickness tablets to take home.

Question (100 words): How can I manage fluid retention caused by docetaxel?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You may develop fluid retention, which can cause swollen ankles and legs. Steroid drugs given to prevent allergic reactions can also help reduce fluid buildup.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may develop a build-up of fluid in the body (oedema), which can take a few weeks to go away. This can appear as swollen ankles and legs and feeling short of breath. You’ll usually be given steroid drugs to prevent an allergic reaction to docetaxel.

Question (100 words): What skin reactions might I experience with docetaxel?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You may develop a rash, skin color changes, or hand-foot syndrome, which affects the palms of the hands and soles of the feet. Your treatment team may prescribe creams or gels to help manage these symptoms.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may develop a rash anywhere on your body or your skin might change colour. It could be red and itchy or you may feel flushed. Your treatment team might prescribe medicine to help.

Question (100 words): How should I care for my mouth during docetaxel treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Use a small, soft toothbrush and a prescribed mouthwash to reduce soreness and prevent mouth ulcers. See your dentist for a check-up before starting treatment and avoid dental work if possible.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may be given a mouthwash to reduce soreness and prevent mouth ulcers developing. It’s a good idea to use a small, soft toothbrush during this time. See your dentist for a check-up before chemotherapy begins.

Question (100 words): Will my taste change during docetaxel treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, your sense of taste may change, making some foods taste more salty, bitter, or metallic. This should return to normal once treatment has finished.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: While you’re having docetaxel, your sense of taste can change and some foods may taste different, for example more salty, bitter or metallic.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience extreme tiredness during docetaxel treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Inform your GP or treatment team if you think you have cancer-related fatigue. They can assess you and offer advice on how to manage your energy levels.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you think you have fatigue, tell your GP or treatment team. They can assess you and offer advice on how to manage your energy levels.

Question (100 words): How many cycles of docetaxel will I have for primary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): For primary breast cancer, you will usually have 3 to 6 treatment cycles of docetaxel.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: For primary breast cancer you’ll usually have 3 to 6 treatment cycles.

Question (100 words): Can docetaxel affect my nails?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, docetaxel may change the color, texture, or appearance of your fingernails and toenails. They might become more brittle, cracked, or develop ridges. Report any signs of infection to your treatment team.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Docetaxel may make your fingernails and toenails look different. Their colour or texture might change or ridges might form in the nails. They might also become more brittle and cracked.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I need dental work during docetaxel treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Speak to your treatment team about the best time to have dental work if it's necessary during your treatment. Avoid dental work if possible.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you need dental work during treatment, speak to your treatment team about the best time to have this.

Question (100 words): How can I manage diarrhoea or constipation caused by docetaxel?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your treatment team can prescribe medicine to help control diarrhoea or constipation and can give you information about diet. Contact your treatment team if you have diarrhoea 4 or more times in 24 hours.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your treatment team can prescribe medicine to help control it and can give you information about diet. Contact your treatment team if you have diarrhoea 4 or more times in 24 hours.

Question (100 words): How might docetaxel affect my concentration during treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Docetaxel can affect your ability to concentrate and make you more forgetful, a condition sometimes referred to as 'chemo brain' or 'chemo fog.' This cognitive impairment usually improves over time after treatment has finished.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Treatment can affect your ability to concentrate and make you more forgetful. This is sometimes referred to as “chemo brain” or “chemo fog” but your treatment team may call it cognitive impairment. It usually improves over time after treatment has finished.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience pain or a burning sensation around the cannula during docetaxel treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience pain, stinging, or a burning sensation around the cannula while docetaxel is being administered, inform your chemotherapy nurse immediately. This could indicate extravasation, where the drug leaks out of the vein, potentially damaging surrounding tissue.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Tell your chemotherapy nurse immediately if you have pain, stinging or a burning sensation around the cannula while the drug is being given.

Question (100 words): Can docetaxel cause changes in my heart rate or blood pressure?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, docetaxel can cause changes in your heart rate and affect your blood pressure. You will be carefully monitored for these changes during your treatment. Usually, they can be treated easily without stopping the treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Docetaxel can cause changes in your heart rate and affect your blood pressure, so you will be carefully monitored for this during your treatment.

Question (100 words): What are the symptoms of lung inflammation caused by docetaxel?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Docetaxel can cause lung inflammation, known as interstitial lung disease (ILD) or pneumonitis. Symptoms include shortness of breath, a cough (with or without a high temperature), chest tightness, and wheezing. If you experience these, contact your treatment team immediately.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Contact your treatment team straight away if you have: • Shortness of breath • A cough, with or without a high temperature • Any new or worsening breathing problems, such as chest tightness or wheezing

Question (100 words): How can I reduce the risk of an allergic reaction to docetaxel?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To reduce the risk of an allergic reaction, you will usually be given steroids as tablets for 3 days, starting the day before each cycle of chemotherapy. Take these as directed by your treatment team and do not stop taking them without consulting them first.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Before your treatment starts you will usually be given drugs called steroids to reduce the risk of an allergic reaction. You’ll usually have these as tablets for 3 days, starting the day before each cycle of chemotherapy.

Question (100 words): What are the symptoms of an allergic reaction to docetaxel?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Symptoms of an allergic reaction to docetaxel include flushing, skin rash, itching, back pain, shortness of breath, faintness, fever, or chills. If you experience a severe reaction, treatment will be stopped immediately, and you may not be given docetaxel again.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Symptoms of an allergic reaction include: • Flushing • Skin rash • Itching • Back pain • Shortness of breath • Faintness • Fever or chills

Question (100 words): What are the symptoms of a blood clot, and what should I do if I suspect one?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Symptoms of a blood clot include pain, redness/discoloration of the skin, heat and swelling of the arm or leg, swelling or tenderness where a central line is inserted, shortness of breath, pain or tightness in the chest, and an unexplained cough or coughing up blood. If you suspect a blood clot, contact your treatment team or go to your local A&E department immediately.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Contact your treatment team or go to your local A&E department straight away if you have any of the following symptoms: • Pain, redness/discolouration of the skin, heat and swelling of the arm or leg • Swelling, redness or tenderness where a central line is inserted to give chemotherapy, for example in the arm, chest area or up into the neck • Shortness of breath • Pain or tightness in the chest • Unexplained cough or coughing up blood

Question (100 words): Does docetaxel affect fertility, and what should I discuss with my treatment team?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The effects of docetaxel on fertility are not fully known and may depend on other chemotherapy drugs you are taking, your age, and past treatments. It’s important to discuss any fertility concerns with your treatment team before starting treatment. Some women may stop having periods during chemotherapy, which may be temporary.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: At the moment, we don’t know whether docetaxel affects fertility. The effects will depend on any other chemotherapy drugs you’re having at the same time, or have had in the past, and your age.

Question (100 words): Can I have sex during docetaxel treatment, and what contraception should I use?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can still have sex during treatment. Most treatment teams advise using barrier methods of contraception, such as condoms, during treatment with docetaxel and for 2 months after treatment. Men should use contraception for 4 months after treatment ends. It’s advised not to become pregnant while having treatment because docetaxel can harm a developing baby.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can still have sex during treatment. It’s thought chemotherapy drugs cannot pass into vaginal fluids or semen, but this cannot be completely ruled out. Most treatment teams will advise using barrier methods of contraception, such as condoms, during treatment with docetaxel and for 2 months after treatment.

Question (100 words): Why should I avoid driving or operating machinery after docetaxel treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Docetaxel contains alcohol, so after your treatment, your blood alcohol level may be above the legal limit. You shouldn’t drive or operate machinery for a few hours after your treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Docetaxel contains alcohol, so after you have your treatment, your blood alcohol level may be above the legal limit. You shouldn’t drive or operate machinery for a few hours after your treatment.

Question (100 words): Can I get travel vaccinations while on docetaxel treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You should not have live vaccines while you’re having chemotherapy. Live vaccines include mumps, measles, rubella, polio, BCG (tuberculosis), and yellow fever. It’s safe to have these vaccinations 6 months after your treatment finishes. Talk to your GP or treatment team before having any vaccinations.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You should not have any live vaccines while you’re having chemotherapy. Live vaccines include: • Mumps • Measles • Rubella (German measles) • Polio • BCG (tuberculosis) • Yellow fever

Question (100 words): When should I get the COVID-19 vaccination if I’m on docetaxel treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you’re having chemotherapy or targeted therapies, you’re advised to speak to your treatment team about the best time to have a COVID-19 vaccination.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re having chemotherapy or targeted therapies, you’re advised to speak to your treatment team about the best time to have a COVID-19 vaccination.

Question (100 words): Should I get the flu vaccine while on docetaxel treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, anyone at risk of a weakened immune system, including those having chemotherapy, should have the flu vaccine. The flu vaccine is not a live vaccine, so it does not contain any active viruses. Talk to your chemotherapy team or breast care nurse about the best time to have your flu jab.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The flu vaccine is not a live vaccine so does not contain any active viruses. Talk to your chemotherapy team or breast care nurse about the best time to have your flu jab.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice tenderness, darkening, and hardening around the cannula site after a few weeks?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After a few weeks, you may notice tenderness, darkening, and hardening around where the cannula was inserted. This is normal and should fade in time. If you have concerns, discuss them with your treatment team.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: After a few weeks you may notice tenderness, darkening and hardening around where the cannula was inserted. This should fade in time.

Question (100 words): How can I get more information and support during my docetaxel treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can find more information and support by calling the Breast Cancer Now helpline on 0808 800 6000 or visiting their website at breastcancernow.org. They offer free services, world-class research support, and change-making campaigns for those affected by breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can find out more about all our information and support services for people with breast cancer by calling our helpline on 0808 800 6000 or visiting our website breastcancernow.org

Question (100 words): What should I do if I suspect I have interstitial lung disease (ILD) while on docetaxel?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you suspect you have interstitial lung disease (ILD), contact your treatment team straight away. Symptoms include shortness of breath, a cough, chest tightness, and wheezing. You may need a chest x-ray or CT scan to check for ILD. If confirmed, you may need to stop treatment temporarily and have steroids to treat the inflammation.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Contact your treatment team straight away if you have: • Shortness of breath • A cough, with or without a high temperature • Any new or worsening breathing problems, such as chest tightness or wheezing

Question (100 words): Can docetaxel cause permanent lung damage?
Answer (Max 2000 words): In some cases, lung damage from interstitial lung disease (ILD) caused by docetaxel can be permanent and may worsen over time. Treatment for ILD can relieve symptoms, improve quality of life, and slow the progression of the disease.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: In some cases, lung damage from ILD can be permanent and may get worse over time. Treatment for ILD can relieve symptoms, improve quality of life and slow the progression of the disease.

Question (100 words): What precautions should someone in close contact with me take if they need a live vaccine?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If someone you have close contact with needs a live vaccine, speak to your treatment team or GP. They can advise what precautions you may need to take depending on the vaccination, as live vaccines could be harmful if you have a weakened immune system during chemotherapy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If anyone you have close contact with needs to have a live vaccine, speak to your treatment team or GP. They can advise what precautions you may need to take depending on the vaccination.

Question (100 words): How long should men use contraception after docetaxel treatment ends?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Men should continue to use contraception for 4 months after docetaxel treatment ends to ensure the drug is completely out of their system and to prevent any potential harm to a developing baby.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Men should also continue to use contraception for 4 months after treatment ends.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I’m addicted to alcohol or notice side effects from the alcohol in docetaxel?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you’re addicted to alcohol or notice any side effects from the alcohol in docetaxel, inform your treatment team before you start your treatment. They can provide support and guidance.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re addicted to alcohol, or are worried about it, tell your treatment team before you start your treatment. And let them know if you notice any side effects from the alcohol after your treatment.

Question (100 words): What are the common symptoms of secondary breast cancer in the liver?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common symptoms include pain in the abdomen or right shoulder, discomfort or pain in the right side under the ribs, nausea, loss of appetite and weight loss, hiccups, fluid build-up causing swelling (ascites), general unwell feeling, constant tiredness, itching, and jaundice (yellowing of the skin). These symptoms vary in severity depending on the extent of liver involvement.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Symptoms include: Pain in the tummy (abdomen) which may also be felt in the right shoulder, Discomfort or pain in the right side of the abdomen under the ribs, Feeling sick (nausea), Loss of appetite and weight loss, Hiccups, Build-up of fluid in the abdomen causing swelling (ascites), A general feeling of being unwell, Feeling constantly tired, Itching and yellowing of the skin (jaundice).

Question (100 words): How is secondary breast cancer in the liver diagnosed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Diagnosis involves a physical examination by a specialist, blood tests (liver function tests and tumour marker tests), imaging tests such as ultrasound, CT scan, PET-CT scan, and MRI scan, and possibly a liver biopsy to confirm the diagnosis.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may need one or more of the following tests for your doctor to confirm a diagnosis of secondary breast cancer in the liver and monitor it over time. Blood tests, Tumour marker tests, Ultrasound scan, CT (computerised tomography) scan, PET-CT (positron emission tomography-computerised tomography) scan, MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) scan, Liver biopsy.

Question (100 words): What treatments are available for secondary breast cancer in the liver?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Treatments may include hormone (endocrine) therapy, chemotherapy, targeted (biological) therapy, surgery, and local treatments like radiofrequency ablation, cryotherapy, or targeted radiotherapy. These treatments can be used alone or in combination.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your treatment may include: Hormone (endocrine) therapy, Chemotherapy, Targeted (biological) therapy, Surgery, Radiofrequency ablation, cryotherapy or targeted radiotherapy.

Question (100 words): Can surgery cure secondary breast cancer in the liver?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Surgery cannot cure secondary breast cancer in the liver, but it may be part of the treatment plan if the affected area is small, easily accessible, and there is no other secondary cancer elsewhere in the body. Liver transplants are usually not an option.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Although surgery will not cure secondary breast cancer in the liver, occasionally it may be part of a treatment plan. However, in most cases several areas of the liver are affected and surgery is not possible. Liver transplants are not usually an option for people who have secondary breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What is the role of hormone therapy in treating secondary breast cancer in the liver?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Hormone therapy is used to block or stop the effect of oestrogen on breast cancer cells, particularly for oestrogen receptor positive (ER+) breast cancers. Common hormone therapy drugs include aromatase inhibitors, fulvestrant, goserelin, leuprorelin, and tamoxifen.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Hormone therapies block or stop the effect of oestrogen on breast cancer cells. The most commonly used hormone therapy drugs are: Aromatase inhibitors (anastrozole, exemestane and letrozole), Fulvestrant (Faslodex), Goserelin (Zoladex), Leuprorelin (Prostap), Tamoxifen.

Question (100 words): What are targeted therapies for HER2 positive breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Targeted therapies for HER2 positive breast cancer include pertuzumab, trastuzumab, trastuzumab deruxtecan, trastuzumab emtansine, and tucatinib. These drugs target the HER2 protein that promotes cancer cell growth.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Targeted therapies for HER2 positive breast cancer include: Pertuzumab (Perjeta), Trastuzumab, Trastuzumab deruxtecan (Enhertu), Trastuzumab emtansine (Kadcyla), Tucatinib (Tukysa).

Question (100 words): What factors influence the choice of treatment for secondary breast cancer in the liver?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Treatment decisions are influenced by the extent of cancer within the liver, spread to other organs, symptoms, past treatments, cancer features, menopausal status, and general health. Your specialist will discuss these factors with you.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: When making decisions about how best to treat you, your treatment team will consider factors such as: How extensive the cancer is within the liver, Whether the cancer has spread to other organs, such as the bone or lungs, Any symptoms you have, What treatment you’ve had in the past, The features of the cancer, Whether you’ve been through the menopause, Your general health.

Question (100 words): What should I ask my treatment team about my treatment plan?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You should ask about your treatment options, the aim of your treatment, possible side effects and their management, additional treatment options, clinical trials, risks and benefits of each treatment, and who to report new symptoms to.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may want to ask your treatment team about: Your treatment options and why they’re recommending a particular drug or procedure, The aim of your treatment, The possible side effects and what you can do to help manage them, Whether there are any additional options for you, including new procedures or treatment at other centres, Any clinical trials you could take part in, The risks and benefits of each treatment, What to do if you get new symptoms and who to report them to.

Question (100 words): How does secondary breast cancer spread to the liver?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Secondary breast cancer spreads to the liver through the lymphatic system or the blood. The cancer cells from the breast travel to the liver and form new tumours.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast cancer cells can spread to the liver through the lymphatic system or the blood.

Question (100 words): What is the prognosis for secondary breast cancer in the liver?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The prognosis varies as each case is different. Treatment aims to control and slow down the spread of cancer, relieve symptoms, and improve quality of life. Life expectancy is difficult to predict.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: When breast cancer spreads to the liver, it can be treated but cannot be cured. Treatment aims to control and slow down the spread of the cancer, relieve symptoms and give you the best quality of life for as long as possible.

Question (100 words): What is the function of the liver and how is it affected by secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The liver produces bile, converts food into energy, stores glucose and vitamins, breaks down harmful substances, and produces proteins needed for blood clotting. Secondary breast cancer can impair these functions depending on the extent of liver involvement.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The liver produces bile which helps to digest food. Bile is stored in the gallbladder and released into the small bowel through the bile duct. The liver converts food into heat and energy, stores glucose and vitamins, and breaks down harmful substances such as alcohol and drugs. It also produces important proteins including those that are needed to help the blood to clot.

Question (100 words): What are the side effects of chemotherapy for secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common side effects of chemotherapy include nausea, vomiting, hair loss, fatigue, increased risk of infections, and changes in blood cell counts. Your treatment team will discuss these side effects and ways to manage them.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: For general information about chemotherapy, including side effects, see our Chemotherapy for breast cancer booklet, or read our information on individual chemotherapy drugs or combinations.

Question (100 words): Can secondary breast cancer in the liver be found without symptoms?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, secondary breast cancer in the liver can sometimes be found during a scan before it causes any symptoms, especially if breast cancer has recurred elsewhere and the treatment team wants to check for liver spread.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Sometimes secondary breast cancer in the liver may be found during a scan before it causes any symptoms. This might be the case if your breast cancer has come back elsewhere, and your treatment team wants to check whether it has spread to the liver.

Question (100 words): What is a liver biopsy and why is it done?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A liver biopsy involves removing a small piece of liver tissue under local anaesthetic to be examined under a microscope. It is done to confirm the diagnosis of secondary breast cancer in the liver and guide treatment decisions.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A biopsy involves removing a small piece of tissue from the liver, under local anaesthetic, to be examined under a microscope. An ultrasound is usually used as a guide.

Question (100 words): What is the role of imaging tests in diagnosing secondary breast cancer in the liver?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Imaging tests such as ultrasound, CT scan, PET-CT scan, and MRI scan are used to produce images of the liver to show any abnormalities, the number, size, and location of cancer areas, and the extent of liver involvement.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: An ultrasound scan uses high-frequency sound waves to produce an image of the liver to show any abnormalities. CT (computerised tomography) scan, PET-CT (positron emission tomography-computerised tomography) scan, MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) scan.

Question (100 words): What are the benefits of participating in clinical trials for secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Participating in clinical trials can provide access to new treatments that are not yet widely available, contribute to medical research, and help improve future treatment options for others with secondary breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may want to ask your treatment team about... Any clinical trials you could take part in.

Question (100 words): How can I manage fatigue caused by secondary breast cancer in the liver?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Managing fatigue involves pacing yourself, prioritizing activities, taking short rest breaks, staying hydrated, eating a balanced diet, and discussing any medications or treatments that may be contributing to fatigue with your healthcare team.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Symptoms include... Feeling constantly tired.

Question (100 words): What dietary changes can help manage symptoms of secondary breast cancer in the liver?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Eating a balanced diet rich in fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and lean proteins can help manage symptoms. Staying hydrated, eating small frequent meals, and avoiding alcohol and processed foods may also be beneficial.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: No direct excerpt, but general advice on diet can be inferred from managing symptoms and overall health.

Question (100 words): How can emotional support help me cope with secondary breast cancer in the liver?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Emotional support from family, friends, support groups, and professional counsellors can provide comfort, reduce feelings of isolation, and help you cope with the emotional challenges of living with secondary breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: No direct excerpt, but the importance of emotional support is implied throughout the document.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience new or worsening symptoms during treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You should report any new or worsening symptoms to your specialist or treatment team immediately. They can assess your condition, adjust your treatment plan if necessary, and provide additional support and care.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s important to report any new or persistent symptoms to your specialist.

Question (100 words): What are the treatment options for secondary breast cancer in the liver?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Treatment options include thermal ablation (using heat or freezing to destroy cancer cells), targeted radiotherapy (such as stereotactic radiotherapy or radiosurgery), and intrahepatic chemotherapy (delivering chemotherapy directly into the liver). These treatments aim to control the cancer and manage symptoms effectively.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Thermal ablation or cryoablation can be used alone or in combination with surgery. Targeted radiotherapy may be considered for some people with small secondary cancers in the liver. Intrahepatic chemotherapy and chemoembolisation involve giving chemotherapy directly into the liver.

Question (100 words): How is radiofrequency ablation (RFA) performed for liver tumors?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Radiofrequency ablation (RFA) involves inserting a needle into individual tumors in the liver and destroying them with heat. This is a specialist treatment and may not be widely available. Your treatment team can inform you if it is suitable for you.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Radiofrequency ablation (RFA) involves inserting a needle into individual tumours in the liver and destroying them with heat.

Question (100 words): What is stereotactic radiotherapy and how is it used?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Stereotactic radiotherapy is a very precise form of radiotherapy that allows high doses of radiation to be delivered with accuracy and minimal damage to surrounding tissue. It may be used to treat small secondary breast cancers in the liver.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Very precise radiotherapy (called stereotactic radiotherapy or radiosurgery) may be considered for some people with small secondary cancers in the liver.

Question (100 words): What is chemoembolisation and how does it work?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Chemoembolisation involves giving chemotherapy directly into the liver through a catheter into the main blood supply. The chemotherapy is delivered along with an oily liquid or foam that blocks the blood supply to the cancer, depriving it of oxygen and nutrients.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: In chemoembolisation, the chemotherapy is delivered along with an oily liquid or foam that blocks the blood supply to the cancer.

Question (100 words): How can I access treatments that are not routinely available on the NHS?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You may be able to access treatments through clinical trials or by seeking advice from organizations like Macmillan Cancer Support. Speak to your treatment team or call helplines for more information on available options.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some treatments for secondary breast cancer may not be routinely available on the NHS. You may still be able to access these treatments in other ways.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience pain due to secondary breast cancer in the liver?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Pain can be managed with various medications and should be regularly assessed by your healthcare team. Keeping a pain diary can help in managing and treating your pain effectively.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Most pain can be relieved or controlled. It’s very important your pain is assessed regularly by your nurse or doctor to make sure it stays under control.

Question (100 words): How can nausea and vomiting be managed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Nausea and vomiting can be controlled with anti-sickness drugs. Keeping a diary of what triggers these symptoms can help your treatment team find the best management strategy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Nausea and vomiting can almost always be controlled and treated with anti-sickness drugs.

Question (100 words): What can I do if I have a poor appetite and am losing weight?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you have a poor appetite and are losing weight, talk to your doctor or nurse about dietary supplements or consult a dietitian for specialist advice. Medication to increase your appetite may also be prescribed.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you still feel you’re not eating enough, or are losing weight, talk to your doctor or nurse about dietary supplements or ask to speak to a dietitian for specialist advice.

Question (100 words): What causes hiccups in people with secondary breast cancer in the liver?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Hiccups may be caused by the enlarged liver pressing on the diaphragm, causing it to spasm. Sitting upright and drinking small amounts frequently may help, and there are medicines available to relieve hiccups.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Hiccups may be a result of the enlarged liver pressing on the diaphragm and causing it to spasm.

Question (100 words): What is ascites and how is it treated?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Ascites is a large build-up of fluid in the abdomen. It can be treated with a procedure called paracentesis to drain the fluid, or with diuretics to slow down the build-up. In some cases, a permanent drain may be needed.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Ascites is a large build-up of fluid in the abdomen (tummy). A procedure called paracentesis may be used to drain the fluid to relieve symptoms.

Question (100 words): How can I manage cancer-related fatigue?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Cancer-related fatigue can be managed by addressing its causes, which may include stress, side effects of treatment, loss of appetite, medication, disturbed sleep, or cancer progression. Gentle exercise and good sleep hygiene can also help.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Fatigue may have a significant impact on your ability to cope with your cancer and its treatment.

Question (100 words): What are the symptoms of anaemia and how is it treated?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Symptoms of anaemia include feeling particularly tired, breathless, or dizzy. It can be diagnosed with a blood test and treated with tablets or a blood transfusion if necessary.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Having too few red blood cells is called anaemia. If you feel particularly tired, breathless or dizzy, let your treatment team know.

Question (100 words): What causes jaundice and how is it treated?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Jaundice occurs when the bile duct becomes blocked or the liver is seriously affected by cancer. It can be treated by inserting a stent to keep the bile duct open or with medication to relieve symptoms like itching.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Jaundice can occur when the bile duct becomes blocked or when the liver is seriously affected by the cancer.

Question (100 words): What are the symptoms of a blood clot and what should I do if I suspect one?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Symptoms of a blood clot include pain, redness, heat, and swelling in the arm or leg, shortness of breath, chest pain, and unexplained cough. If you experience these symptoms, contact your local A&E department, GP, or treatment team immediately.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you experience any of the following symptoms contact your local A&E department, GP or treatment team straight away.

Question (100 words): How can physical activity help me if I have secondary breast cancer in the liver?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Gentle, regular physical activity can help reduce symptoms like pain, nausea, and fatigue, and improve mood. Activities such as walking, swimming, and low-impact yoga are beneficial. It’s important to listen to your body and not overexert yourself.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: People who exercise, even gently, during and between treatments may tolerate treatments better and have less pain, sickness, problems sleeping and fatigue.

Question (100 words): What is palliative care and how can it help me?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Palliative care focuses on symptom control and support, improving quality of life for people with secondary breast cancer. It can be provided at any stage of the illness and helps manage symptoms like pain, fatigue, and emotional distress.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Palliative and supportive care focuses on symptom control and support.

Question (100 words): How can I find out about clinical trials for secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your specialist may discuss clinical trials with you, or you can inquire about eligible trials locally, regionally, or nationally. Information on current trials can be found on the Cancer Research UK and NIHR websites.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your specialist may talk with you about a clinical trial, or you can ask if there are any trials you’re eligible to join locally, regionally or nationally.

Question (100 words): What should I do if a recommended treatment is not available on the NHS?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If a treatment is not routinely available on the NHS, you can seek advice from Macmillan Cancer Support or speak to your treatment team for alternative options. Calling helplines can also provide additional support and information.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some treatments for secondary breast cancer may not be routinely available on the NHS. You may still be able to access these treatments in other ways.

Question (100 words): How can I manage itchy skin caused by jaundice?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To manage itchy skin caused by jaundice, keep your skin well moisturized with a non-perfumed skin cream. Avoid alcohol, spicy food, and heat, which can worsen itching. Medication may also be prescribed to relieve the itching.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Itchy skin Jaundice can cause itching, which may be worse at night or when you’re hot. It’s important to keep your skin well moisturised.

Question (100 words): What lifestyle changes can I make to cope better with secondary breast cancer in the liver?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Incorporating gentle physical activity, maintaining a balanced diet, staying hydrated, and seeking emotional support can help you cope better with secondary breast cancer in the liver. It’s important to listen to your body and make adjustments as needed.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Physical activity Although there has been little research into the benefits of exercise for people with secondary breast cancer, several studies have looked at its effectiveness for people with primary breast cancer.

Question (100 words): How can I find a GP exercise referral programme to help me increase my activity levels?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can find a GP exercise referral programme by contacting your GP or local health service. These programmes are designed to help you increase your activity levels and improve your health and wellbeing. Trained instructors will provide support and ensure the exercises are safe for your condition.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A GP exercise referral programme can help you increase your activity levels and improve health and wellbeing.

Question (100 words): What should I tell my exercise instructor about my health?
Answer (Max 2000 words): It’s important to inform your exercise instructor about any changes to your health, especially your secondary breast cancer diagnosis and any treatments you are undergoing. This will help them advise you on how to exercise safely and effectively.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s important the instructor knows about you and any changes to your health so they can advise you on how to exercise safely.

Question (100 words): What emotions might I experience after learning my cancer has spread to my liver?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You may experience a range of emotions such as isolation, fear, anxiety, sadness, uncertainty, depression, or anger. These are normal reactions to such news, and it’s important to acknowledge and address these feelings.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Knowing your cancer has spread to your liver can cause a range of emotions.

Question (100 words): Who can I talk to for professional emotional support?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can seek professional emotional support from your specialist nurse, palliative care nurse, hospice, or home care specialist nurse. They are trained to understand the specific needs of people with secondary cancers and can provide various forms of support, including arranging sessions with a counsellor or psychotherapist.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can talk to your specialist nurse, palliative care nurse, hospice or home care specialist nurse.

Question (100 words): How can I get referred to a palliative care nurse if I’m not in regular contact with one?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can ask your treatment team or GP to refer you to a palliative care nurse. Additionally, you can call the Breast Cancer Now helpline on 0808 800 6000 to discuss your concerns and find out what support may be available in your area.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re not in regular contact with a palliative care nurse, you can ask to be referred by your treatment team or GP.

Question (100 words): What support services does Breast Cancer Now offer for people with secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast Cancer Now offers various support services including face-to-face and online support, expert tips, peer-to-peer groups, and forums where you can share experiences and get advice. They also provide tailored information for younger women with secondary breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: We have different options, all facilitated by trained counsellors, to help you find the support you need.

Question (100 words): How can younger women with secondary breast cancer find support?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Younger women with secondary breast cancer can find support through Breast Cancer Now’s Younger Women with Secondaries Together programme. This connects them with other women under 45 with secondary breast cancer, providing a safe space to talk about their experiences and get tailored advice.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Younger Women with Secondaries Together connects you with other women under 45 with secondary breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What is the online Forum offered by Breast Cancer Now?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The online Forum offered by Breast Cancer Now is a space where thousands of people affected by breast cancer can listen, share, and support each other. It’s available day or night and provides a confidential space to talk about your experiences with people who understand.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Through our online Forum, we’re with you every day. For every experience. Every step of the way.

Question (100 words): How can I find local support for secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can find local support by contacting your local Cancer Information Centre. They may be able to provide additional resources and support groups in your area.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may be able to find other support in your area by contacting your local Cancer Information Centre.

Question (100 words): How can I support Breast Cancer Now’s work?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can support Breast Cancer Now’s vital care and research work by making a voluntary donation or including a gift in your will. Visit breastcancernow.org/give to find out more about how you can help.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast Cancer Now is a charity that relies on voluntary donations and gifts in wills.

Question (100 words): Who wrote the booklet on secondary breast cancer in the liver?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The booklet on secondary breast cancer in the liver was written by Breast Cancer Now’s clinical specialists and reviewed by healthcare professionals and people affected by breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Secondary breast cancer in the liver was written by Breast Cancer Now’s clinical specialists, and reviewed by healthcare professionals and people affected by breast cancer.

Question (100 words): How can I get more copies of the booklet or provide feedback?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can order or download more copies of the booklet from breastcancernow.org/publications. To provide feedback or request a large print, Braille, or audio CD version, email health-info@breastcancernow.org.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can order or download more copies from breastcancernow.org/publications We welcome your feedback on this publication: health-info@breastcancernow.org For a large print, Braille or audio CD version: Email health-info@breastcancernow.org

Question (100 words): What should I do if I need to talk through my concerns with a helpline nurse?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can call the Breast Cancer Now helpline on 0808 800 6000 to talk through your concerns with a helpline nurse. They are available to provide information and support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Call 0808 800 6000 to talk things through with our helpline nurses.

Question (100 words): Where can I find reliable breast cancer information online?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can find reliable breast cancer information by visiting breastcancernow.org. The website provides trusted information and support for those affected by breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Visit breastcancernow.org for reliable breast cancer information.

Question (100 words): What is the registration details of Breast Cancer Now?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast Cancer Now is a company limited by guarantee registered in England (9347608) and a charity registered in England and Wales (1160558), Scotland (SC045584), and Isle of Man (1200). Their registered office is at Fifth Floor, Ibex House, 42-47 Minories, London EC3N 1DY.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast Cancer Now is a company limited by guarantee registered in England (9347608) and a charity registered in England and Wales (1160558), Scotland (SC045584) and Isle of Man (1200). Registered Office: Fifth Floor, Ibex House, 42-47 Minories, London EC3N 1DY.

Question (100 words): What is the planned review date for the secondary breast cancer in the liver booklet?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The next planned review for the secondary breast cancer in the liver booklet is in March 2025.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: next planned review March 2025

Question (100 words): How can I access different formats of the booklet?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can access different formats of the booklet, such as large print, Braille, or audio CD, by emailing health-info@breastcancernow.org.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: For a large print, Braille or audio CD version: Email health-info@breastcancernow.org

Question (100 words): What disclaimer is provided regarding the health information in the booklet?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The disclaimer states that while every effort is made to ensure the health information is accurate and up to date, it doesn’t replace the information and support from professionals in your healthcare team. Breast Cancer Now doesn’t accept liability in relation to the use of any information contained in this publication.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: We make every effort to ensure that our health information is accurate and up to date, but it doesn’t replace the information and support from professionals in your healthcare team. So far as is permitted by law, Breast Cancer Now doesn’t accept liability in relation to the use of any information contained in this publication.

Question (100 words): How can I get more information about the sources used in the booklet?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can get more information about the sources used in the booklet by emailing health-info@breastcancernow.org.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: For a full list of the sources we used to research it: Email health-info@breastcancernow.org

Question (100 words): What should I do if I need immediate emotional support?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you need immediate emotional support, you can call the Breast Cancer Now helpline on 0808 800 6000. Helpline nurses are available to talk through your concerns and provide the support you need.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Call 0808 800 6000 to talk things through with our helpline nurses.

Question (100 words): What is DCIS and how does it differ from invasive breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): DCIS, or Ductal Carcinoma In Situ, is an early form of breast cancer where abnormal cells are found in the lining of a breast duct but have not spread outside the duct. Unlike invasive breast cancer, DCIS cells have not developed the ability to spread into surrounding breast tissue or other parts of the body.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: DCIS is an early form of breast cancer. Breast cancer starts when cells in the breast begin to divide and grow in an unusual and uncontrolled way. When cancer cells have developed in the ducts and stay in the ducts (in situ), it’s called DCIS.

Question (100 words): What are the common symptoms of DCIS?
Answer (Max 2000 words): DCIS usually does not present with symptoms. It is most commonly detected during routine breast screening or mammograms. In rare cases, symptoms may include a breast lump, nipple discharge, or a rash around the nipple known as Paget’s disease of the breast.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: DCIS usually has no symptoms. Most cases of DCIS are found during routine breast screening or if you have a mammogram (breast x-ray) for another reason.

Question (100 words): How is DCIS diagnosed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): DCIS is diagnosed through a series of tests including a mammogram, ultrasound scan, core biopsy, and sometimes a vacuum-assisted biopsy. These tests help determine the presence and grade of DCIS.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: DCIS is diagnosed using a range of tests. These may include: A mammogram (breast x-ray), An ultrasound scan (using sound waves to produce an image), A core biopsy of the breast and sometimes lymph nodes.

Question (100 words): What are calcifications and how are they related to DCIS?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Calcifications are tiny white dots seen on mammograms, which are spots of calcium salts. While they can be benign, they may also indicate DCIS. Further imaging and biopsies are conducted to determine if calcifications are cancerous.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: These white dots are spots of calcium salts called calcifications. Calcifications can sometimes be due to DCIS, but this is not always the case.

Question (100 words): What are the grades of DCIS and what do they indicate?
