Answer (Max 2000 words): DCIS is graded as low, intermediate, or high based on how different the cancer cells look from normal breast cells and their growth rate. Low-grade DCIS cells look most like normal cells and grow slowly, while high-grade cells look very different and may grow quickly.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: DCIS is graded as: Low grade – the cancer cells look most like normal breast cells and are slower growing, Intermediate grade – the cancer cells look less like normal breast cells and are growing faster than low grade, High grade – the cancer cells look different to normal breast cells and may be fast growing.

Question (100 words): Can DCIS develop into invasive breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If left untreated, DCIS may develop the ability to spread outside the ducts into surrounding breast tissue, becoming invasive breast cancer. However, there is no certain way to predict if this will happen.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If DCIS is not treated, the cancer cells may develop the ability to spread outside the ducts into the surrounding breast tissue. This is known as invasive breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What are the treatment options for DCIS?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Treatment for DCIS typically involves surgery, which may be breast-conserving surgery (lumpectomy) or a mastectomy. Additional treatments may include radiotherapy and hormone therapy, depending on the grade and characteristics of the DCIS.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Treatment is usually recommended if you have DCIS. This is because there’s no way of knowing if DCIS will become invasive.

Question (100 words): What is breast-conserving surgery for DCIS?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast-conserving surgery, also known as wide local excision or lumpectomy, involves removing the DCIS along with a margin of normal breast tissue around it. This procedure aims to preserve as much of the breast as possible.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast-conserving surgery is the removal of the DCIS with a margin of normal breast tissue around it. It’s also known as wide local excision or lumpectomy.

Question (100 words): What is a mastectomy and when is it recommended for DCIS?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A mastectomy is the removal of all breast tissue, usually including the nipple. It is recommended for DCIS when the affected area is large, involves multiple parts of the breast, or when clear margins cannot be achieved with a lumpectomy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A mastectomy is the removal of all the breast tissue, usually including the nipple area.

Question (100 words): How is the area of DCIS marked for surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The area of DCIS is typically marked using a fine wire (wire localisation), a small low-dose radioactive seed, or a radiation-free magnetic marker to guide the surgeon during the removal procedure.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The area may be marked by: A fine wire (called wire localisation), A small low-dose radioactive seed, A small radiation-free magnetic marker.

Question (100 words): Is lymph node removal necessary for DCIS?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Lymph node removal is generally not recommended for DCIS because the cancer cells have not spread outside the ducts. However, a sentinel lymph node biopsy may be considered in certain high-risk cases.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Lymph node (gland) removal is not usually recommended for people with DCIS.

Question (100 words): What is radiotherapy and when is it used after DCIS surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Radiotherapy uses high-energy x-rays to destroy cancer cells. It is usually offered after breast-conserving surgery to reduce the risk of DCIS recurrence or the development of invasive cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Radiotherapy uses high energy x-rays to destroy cancer cells. If you have breast-conserving surgery, you’ll usually be offered radiotherapy to the breast.

Question (100 words): What is hormone therapy and when is it used for DCIS?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Hormone therapy, or endocrine therapy, is used to block the effects of oestrogen on breast cancer cells. It is considered for ER-positive DCIS to reduce the risk of recurrence and the development of invasive cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Hormone therapies block or stop the effect of oestrogen on breast cancer cells. Different hormone therapy drugs do this in different ways.

Question (100 words): Are there any side effects of radiotherapy for DCIS?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common side effects of radiotherapy may include skin changes in the treated area, fatigue, and mild discomfort. These side effects are usually temporary and can be managed with appropriate care.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your treatment team will explain the benefits of radiotherapy for you and discuss any possible side effects.

Question (100 words): What should I expect during recovery after DCIS surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Recovery after DCIS surgery involves managing soreness and discomfort with pain relief, monitoring the surgical site for any signs of infection, and following your healthcare team’s instructions for wound care and activity levels.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: After your operation you may have some soreness and discomfort, but this can be managed with pain relief. There will be a scar, but this should fade in time.

Question (100 words): Can I have breast reconstruction after a mastectomy for DCIS?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, breast reconstruction is usually an option after a mastectomy for DCIS. It can be done immediately during the mastectomy or delayed until a later time. Some women may choose to use a breast prosthesis instead.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have a mastectomy, you’ll usually be able to have breast reconstruction.

Question (100 words): What follow-up care is needed after DCIS treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Follow-up care after DCIS treatment typically includes regular check-ups, mammograms, and possibly other imaging tests to monitor for any signs of recurrence or new breast changes.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: For more information, see our Breast reconstruction booklet.

Question (100 words): How can I manage emotional and psychological impacts after a DCIS diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Managing emotional and psychological impacts after a DCIS diagnosis can involve talking to a counselor, joining support groups, and maintaining a healthy lifestyle. It’s important to seek support from healthcare professionals and loved ones.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have any questions or concerns about your diagnosis and treatment, talk to your treatment team.

Question (100 words): What lifestyle changes can help after DCIS treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Adopting a healthy lifestyle, including a balanced diet, regular physical activity, and avoiding smoking, can help improve overall health and reduce the risk of recurrence after DCIS treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: For more information about this.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice new symptoms after DCIS treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you notice new symptoms such as a breast lump, changes in the breast, or unusual discharge, contact your healthcare team immediately for evaluation and further testing.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you're diagnosed with DCIS after noticing a breast change, it’s more likely you will also have an invasive breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What kind of follow-up will I have after my breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After your hospital-based treatments finish, you will continue to be monitored. This is known as follow-up. If you had breast-conserving surgery, follow-up will include regular mammograms to both breasts. If you had a mastectomy, you’ll have a mammogram on your other breast. The follow-up process will also depend on your age and the arrangements at the hospital where you’ve been treated.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: After treatment Follow-up You will continue to be monitored after your hospital-based treatments finish. This is known as follow-up.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice changes in my breast or scar area after surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): It’s important to be aware of any changes to the breast, chest, or surrounding area, whether you had breast-conserving surgery or a mastectomy. The area around the scar may feel lumpy, numb, or sensitive. You’ll need to get to know how it looks and feels so you know what’s normal for you. If you notice any changes, report them early to your GP or treatment team.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s important to be aware of any changes to the breast, chest or surrounding area, whether you had breast-conserving surgery or a mastectomy (with or without reconstruction).

Question (100 words): How can I get more information about what happens after my hospital-based treatments end?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can find more information about what happens after your hospital-based treatments end in our booklet titled 'After breast cancer treatment: what now?' This booklet provides detailed information on follow-up care and monitoring.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Our booklet After breast cancer treatment: what now? has more information about what happens after your hospital-based treatments end.

Question (100 words): What support is available if I feel anxious about my DCIS diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): It’s normal to feel anxious about a DCIS diagnosis. You can seek support from your treatment team, GP, or a counsellor or psychologist. Additionally, you can call the helpline on 0808 800 6000 or join the forum at forum.breastcancernow.org to speak to others going through a similar situation.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Being told you have DCIS can be a worrying time. Everyone reacts differently to their diagnosis and has their own way of coping.

Question (100 words): How can my family and friends support me during this time?
Answer (Max 2000 words): By letting your family and friends know how you feel, they can be more supportive. Sharing your feelings and concerns with them can help you cope better with your diagnosis and treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: By letting other people know how you feel, particularly your family and friends, they can be more supportive.

Question (100 words): What is the helpline number I can call for support?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can call our helpline on 0808 800 6000 for support and to talk through your concerns with trained helpline nurses.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can also call our helpline on 0808 800 6000.

Question (100 words): What is DCIS and who wrote this booklet about it?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is an early form of breast cancer. This booklet was written by Breast Cancer Now’s clinical specialists and reviewed by healthcare professionals and people affected by breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) was written by Breast Cancer Now’s clinical specialists, and reviewed by healthcare professionals and people affected by breast cancer.

Question (100 words): How can I order or download more copies of this booklet?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can order or download more copies of this booklet from breastcancernow.org/publications.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can order or download more copies from breastcancernow.org/publications

Question (100 words): What should I do if I have feedback on this publication?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can send your feedback on this publication to health-info@breastcancernow.org.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: We welcome your feedback on this publication: health-info@breastcancernow.org

Question (100 words): How can I get a large print, Braille, or audio CD version of this booklet?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can request a large print, Braille, or audio CD version of this booklet by emailing health-info@breastcancernow.org.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: For a large print, Braille or audio CD version: Email health-info@breastcancernow.org

Question (100 words): What is the medical disclaimer for this booklet?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The medical disclaimer states that while every effort is made to ensure the information is accurate and up to date, it doesn’t replace the information and support from professionals in your healthcare team. Breast Cancer Now doesn’t accept liability in relation to the use of any information contained in this publication.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: We make every effort to ensure that our health information is accurate and up to date, but it doesn’t replace the information and support from professionals in your healthcare team. So far as is permitted by law, Breast Cancer Now doesn’t accept liability in relation to the use of any information contained in this publication.

Question (100 words): What is the next planned review date for this booklet?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The next planned review date for this booklet is October 2027.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: BCC39 Edition 8, next planned review October 2027

Question (100 words): How can I contact Breast Cancer Now for more information or support?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can contact Breast Cancer Now by calling 0808 800 6000 to talk things through with helpline nurses or by visiting breastcancernow.org for reliable breast cancer information.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Call 0808 800 600 0 to talk things through with our helpline nurses. Visit breastcancernow.org for reliable breast cancer information.

Question (100 words): What is the registered office address of Breast Cancer Now?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The registered office of Breast Cancer Now is 6th Floor, The White Chapel Building, 10 Whitechapel High Street, London E1 8QS.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Registered Office: 6th Floor, The White Chapel Building, 10 Whitechapel High Street, London E1 8QS.

Question (100 words): How can I support Breast Cancer Now financially?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can support Breast Cancer Now by making donations or including gifts in wills. Visit breastcancernow.org/give to learn more about how you can help.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: We don’t get any government or NHS funding for our support services or health information. So, we rely on donations and gifts in wills to make our vital work happen. If you’d like to support us, go to breastcancernow.org/give

Question (100 words): What kind of research does Breast Cancer Now support?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast Cancer Now supports over 290 of the brightest minds in breast cancer research. They are discovering how to prevent breast cancer, live well with the disease, and save lives.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: We support over 290 of the brightest minds in breast cancer research. They’re discovering how to prevent breast cancer, live well with the disease, and save lives.

Question (100 words): What campaigns does Breast Cancer Now run?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast Cancer Now runs change-making campaigns to fight for the best possible treatment, services, and care for everyone affected by breast cancer, alongside thousands of dedicated campaigners.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: We fight for the best possible treatment, services and care for everyone affected by breast cancer, alongside thousands of dedicated campaigners.

Question (100 words): How can I get more information about the sources used in this booklet?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can get more information about the sources used to research this booklet by emailing health-info@breastcancernow.org.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: For a full list of the sources we used to research it: Email health-info@breastcancernow.org

Question (100 words): What should I do if I have concerns about my breast or scar area after surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you have any concerns about your breast or scar area after surgery, it’s important to speak with your GP or treatment team as soon as possible.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have any concerns, speak with your GP or treatment team.

Question (100 words): What is the importance of knowing how my breast or scar area should feel after surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Knowing how your breast or scar area should feel after surgery is important because the area around the scar may feel lumpy, numb, or sensitive. This familiarity will help you to feel more confident about noticing changes and reporting them early to your healthcare team.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You’ll need to get to know how it looks and feels so you know what’s normal for you. This will help you to feel more confident about noticing changes and reporting them early to your GP or treatment team.

Question (100 words): What is breast cancer and how does it start?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast cancer starts when cells in the breast begin to divide and grow in an unusual and uncontrolled way. It can be non-invasive (in situ) or invasive, with invasive breast cancer having the potential to spread to other parts of the body.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast cancer starts when cells in the breast begin to divide and grow in an unusual and uncontrolled way.

Question (100 words): What are the aims of treatment for breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The aims of treatment for breast cancer are to remove all the cancer in the breast and any affected lymph nodes (local control) and to destroy any cancer cells that may have spread through the bloodstream or lymphatic system (systemic treatment).
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Treatment for invasive breast cancer aims to remove all the cancer in the breast and any affected lymph nodes under the arm. This is called local control.

Question (100 words): What factors influence the treatment decisions for breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Treatment decisions are influenced by the specific features of the cancer, such as its size, location, type, and grade, as well as the patient's age and general health. Tests on breast tissue and the patient's body are also considered.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your treatment team will consider many different factors when deciding the best treatment for you.

Question (100 words): Who are the members of the multidisciplinary team (MDT) treating breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The multidisciplinary team includes a breast care nurse, chemotherapy nurse, clinical oncologist, medical oncologist, pathologist, radiologist, research nurse, surgeon, and therapeutic radiographer, among others.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: People with breast cancer are cared for by a team of healthcare professionals, each with their own expertise. This is known as the multidisciplinary team (MDT).

Question (100 words): What role does a breast care nurse play in my treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A breast care nurse provides information, support, and answers to any questions you may have throughout your treatment and recovery. They are often your main contact within the treatment team.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your nurse will try to answer any questions you have and will offer support during and after your hospital treatment.

Question (100 words): How involved can I be in making decisions about my treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can choose the level of involvement you want in treatment decisions. You can be fully involved, well informed but leave decisions to the team, or know as little as possible. You can change your mind at any stage.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can decide how much, or how little, involvement you want in decisions about your treatment.

Question (100 words): What are some questions I should ask my treatment team?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You might ask why a treatment is best for you, if there are other options, about clinical trials, when treatment will start, where it will be, how long it will take, possible side effects, impact on everyday life, fertility, and your prognosis.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Questions might include: Why is this the best treatment for me? Are there any other options? Are there any clinical trials I can take part in?

Question (100 words): What is the Nottingham Prognostic Index (NPI)?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The Nottingham Prognostic Index (NPI) is a scoring system that categorizes your prognosis as good, moderate, or poor based on the likely course and outcome of your disease.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The Nottingham Prognostic Index (NPI) is a scoring system that puts you into a prognosis category of good, moderate or poor.

Question (100 words): What are genomic assays and how are they used in treatment decisions?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Genomic assays are tests that look at groups of genes in breast cancer to help identify who is most likely to benefit from chemotherapy and the likelihood of cancer recurrence. Examples include EndoPredict, Oncotype DX, and Prosigna.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: These tests look at groups of genes found in the breast cancer. They help identify who is most likely to benefit from chemotherapy and how likely the cancer is to return (recurrence).

Question (100 words): Can I ask for a second opinion about my diagnosis and treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, you can ask for a second opinion through your treatment team. While it may not differ from your initial diagnosis and may slightly delay treatment, a short delay should not affect the outcome.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some people consider asking for a second opinion about their diagnosis and treatment. This can be done through your treatment team.

Question (100 words): What should I consider if I am thinking about declining treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If considering declining treatment, gather as much information as possible, think about the potential impact on your quality of life, and stay in touch with your treatment team for support. Discuss your decision with your GP.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Choosing not to have treatment is a very personal and sometimes difficult decision to make.

Question (100 words): What types of surgery are available for breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Surgery options for breast cancer include lumpectomy (removal of the tumor and some surrounding tissue) and mastectomy (removal of the entire breast). The choice depends on the size and location of the cancer, as well as patient preference.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Surgery and radiotherapy are treatments for local control.

Question (100 words): What is the role of radiotherapy in breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Radiotherapy uses high-energy rays to destroy cancer cells. It is often used after surgery to kill any remaining cancer cells in the breast or nearby lymph nodes, reducing the risk of cancer recurrence.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Radiotherapy is a doctor who specialises in the use of x-rays, ultrasound and scans to diagnose and treat disease.

Question (100 words): How does chemotherapy work in treating breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Chemotherapy uses drugs to destroy cancer cells throughout the body. It is often used after surgery to kill any cancer cells that may have spread and to reduce the risk of recurrence.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Chemotherapy, hormone therapy and targeted therapy are all types of systemic treatment.

Question (100 words): What is hormone therapy and when is it used?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Hormone therapy is used to treat breast cancers that are hormone receptor-positive. It works by blocking the effects of hormones that can stimulate cancer growth, such as oestrogen.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Hormone therapy is used to treat breast cancers that are hormone receptor-positive.

Question (100 words): What are the common side effects of breast cancer treatments?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common side effects of breast cancer treatments include fatigue, nausea, hair loss, changes in appetite, and emotional distress. The specific side effects depend on the type of treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: What are the possible side effects?

Question (100 words): How can I manage the emotional impact of a breast cancer diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Managing the emotional impact involves seeking support from healthcare professionals, such as your breast care nurse or a psychologist, joining support groups, and considering counseling or complementary therapies.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you keep feeling low or anxious, you can talk to your breast care nurse or GP who can help you with this.

Question (100 words): What lifestyle changes can help during and after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Lifestyle changes that can help include maintaining a healthy diet, engaging in regular physical activity, avoiding smoking and excessive alcohol, and managing stress through relaxation techniques or mindfulness.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may be interested in finding out more about: Counselling, Complementary therapies, Local support groups, Dietary information, Physical activity programmes

Question (100 words): What follow-up care is needed after finishing breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Follow-up care includes regular check-ups with your oncologist, mammograms, and blood tests to monitor for any signs of recurrence. It also involves managing any long-term side effects of treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Finishing treatment

Question (100 words): Where can I find more detailed information about breast cancer treatments?
Answer (Max 2000 words): More detailed information about breast cancer treatments can be found on the Breast Cancer Now website (breastcancernow.org) or by calling their Helpline on 0808 800 6000. Additional booklets and publications are also available.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can find more detailed information on each of the different treatment options, including side effects, in our other publications or on our website breastcancernow.org

Question (100 words): What are the different types of breast surgery available for breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): There are two main types of breast surgery: breast-conserving surgery (also known as wide local excision or lumpectomy) and mastectomy. Breast-conserving surgery removes the cancer with a border of normal breast tissue, while mastectomy removes all breast tissue, including the nipple area.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There are two main types of breast surgery: • Breast-conserving surgery, also known as wide local excision or lumpectomy, is the removal of the cancer with a border (margin) of normal breast tissue around it • Mastectomy is the removal of all the breast tissue including the nipple area

Question (100 words): What is the purpose of removing lymph nodes during breast cancer surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The purpose of removing lymph nodes is to check if any of them contain cancer cells. This helps the treatment team decide if additional treatment is needed. If cancer is found in the lymph nodes, further surgery, radiotherapy, or other treatments may be recommended.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have invasive breast cancer, your treatment team will want to check if any of the lymph nodes under the arm contain cancer cells. This helps them decide whether you will benefit from any additional treatment.

Question (100 words): What is a sentinel lymph node biopsy and when is it performed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A sentinel lymph node biopsy is a procedure to identify and remove the first lymph node(s) that cancer cells are most likely to spread to. It is performed if pre-surgery tests show no evidence of cancer in the lymph nodes. The biopsy helps determine if cancer has spread and guides further treatment decisions.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Sentinel lymph node biopsy is used if tests before surgery show no evidence of the lymph nodes containing cancer cells. It identifies whether the sentinel lymph node (the first lymph node or nodes that the cancer cells are most likely to spread to) is clear of cancer cells.

Question (100 words): What is breast reconstruction and when can it be done?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast reconstruction is a surgical procedure to create a new breast shape after breast cancer surgery. It can be done immediately during the same surgery or delayed months or years later. Reconstruction can use implants, tissue from another part of the body, or a combination of both.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast reconstruction is the creation of a new breast shape, or mound, using surgery. It may be done after a mastectomy or breast-conserving surgery. You can have reconstruction at the same time as breast cancer surgery (immediate reconstruction) or months or years later (delayed reconstruction).

Question (100 words): What are the potential side effects of chemotherapy for breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common side effects of chemotherapy include fatigue, nausea, hair loss, increased risk of infections, and changes in appetite. Some patients may also experience mouth sores, diarrhea, or constipation. These side effects vary depending on the specific drugs used and the individual's response to treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Chemotherapy destroys cancer cells using anti-cancer drugs. Chemotherapy is given to reduce the risk of breast cancer returning or spreading.

Question (100 words): How soon after diagnosis should breast cancer surgery be performed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): According to national guidance, breast cancer surgery should be performed within 31 days of you and your specialist agreeing to it. This timeline ensures timely treatment to reduce the risk of cancer progression.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If surgery will be your first treatment, national guidance states that you should have this within 31 days of you and your specialist agreeing to it.

Question (100 words): What is the role of hormone (endocrine) therapy in treating breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Hormone (endocrine) therapy is used to treat breast cancers that are hormone receptor-positive. It works by blocking the effects of hormones like estrogen that can stimulate cancer growth. This therapy can reduce the risk of cancer recurrence and is often used after surgery, chemotherapy, or radiotherapy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may have one or more of the following treatments, not necessarily in the order below: • Hormone (endocrine) therapy

Question (100 words): What is targeted (biological) therapy and when is it used in breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Targeted (biological) therapy uses drugs that specifically target certain proteins or other molecules involved in cancer growth. It is used for breast cancers that have specific characteristics, such as HER2-positive cancers. This therapy can be given before or after surgery and in combination with other treatments.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may have one or more of the following treatments, not necessarily in the order below: • Targeted (biological) therapy

Question (100 words): What should I do if I am asked to participate in a clinical trial for breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you are asked to participate in a clinical trial, you should take the time to fully understand the purpose of the trial, why you are considered suitable, and what it will mean for you. You will be given detailed written information and the opportunity to discuss your options with a research nurse and your treatment team. Your participation is voluntary, and declining to join a trial will not affect your standard treatment and care.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You will not be entered into a trial without your knowledge and without giving your informed consent.

Question (100 words): What is the difference between breast-conserving surgery and mastectomy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast-conserving surgery, also known as wide local excision or lumpectomy, removes the cancer with a border of normal breast tissue. Mastectomy removes all breast tissue, including the nipple area. The choice between these surgeries depends on the type and size of the cancer, its location in the breast, and the size of the breast.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast-conserving surgery, also known as wide local excision or lumpectomy, is the removal of the cancer with a border (margin) of normal breast tissue around it • Mastectomy is the removal of all the breast tissue including the nipple area

Question (100 words): What are the risks of developing lymphoedema after lymph node removal?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After lymph node removal, you may be at risk of developing lymphoedema, which is swelling of the arm, hand, or breast/chest area due to a build-up of lymph fluid. This condition can cause discomfort and requires careful management to reduce the risk of complications.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have lymph nodes removed you may be at risk of developing lymphoedema. Lymphoedema is swelling of the arm, hand or breast/chest area caused by a build-up of lymph fluid in the surface tissues of the body.

Question (100 words): What is the purpose of radiotherapy in breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Radiotherapy is used to destroy any remaining cancer cells after surgery. It helps reduce the risk of the cancer coming back in the breast or spreading to other parts of the body. Radiotherapy may also be used to treat the lymph nodes under the arm if cancer cells are found there.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Treatment for primary breast cancer aims to remove the cancer and reduce the risk of it coming back or spreading to other parts of the body.

Question (100 words): What factors determine whether chemotherapy is recommended for breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Chemotherapy is recommended based on several factors, including the size of the breast cancer, whether the lymph nodes are affected, the grade of the cancer, the oestrogen receptor (ER) and HER2 status, and the results of a genomic assay test if performed. Your treatment team will use these factors to decide if chemotherapy is suitable for you.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your treatment team will decide whether to recommend chemotherapy depending on: • The size of your breast cancer • Whether the lymph nodes are affected • The grade of your cancer • The oestrogen receptor (ER) and HER2 status • The result of a genomic assay test if this is done

Question (100 words): What is oncoplastic surgery and how does it benefit patients?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Oncoplastic surgery combines breast cancer surgery with plastic surgery techniques. It aims to remove the cancer while preserving as much of the breast as possible and achieving a good cosmetic result. This approach reduces the likelihood of noticeable differences between the breasts after surgery.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s more common for people to have oncoplastic surgery. This combines breast cancer surgery with plastic surgery techniques, and means it’s less likely you’ll notice a dent or a great difference between the breasts.

Question (100 words): What should I consider before deciding on breast reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Before deciding on breast reconstruction, consider the different options available, such as implants or tissue from another part of your body. Discuss the pros and cons with your breast surgeon and breast care nurse. Take your time to make a decision that feels right for you, and be aware that some medical conditions may affect your eligibility for reconstruction.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There are usually different options available for breast reconstruction and your breast surgeon and breast care nurse will explain which one is likely to suit you best. It’s helpful if you can take some time to consider these options without feeling under pressure to make a decision.

Question (100 words): What is the significance of the oestrogen receptor (ER) and HER2 status in breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The oestrogen receptor (ER) and HER2 status are important factors in determining the best treatment for breast cancer. ER-positive cancers may be treated with hormone therapy, while HER2-positive cancers may be treated with targeted therapies. These statuses help guide the choice of chemotherapy, hormone therapy, or targeted therapy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your treatment team will decide whether to recommend chemotherapy depending on: • The oestrogen receptor (ER) and HER2 status

Question (100 words): What is the role of bisphosphonates in breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Bisphosphonates are medications that help strengthen bones and reduce the risk of bone metastases in patients with breast cancer. They are often used in combination with other treatments to improve overall outcomes and reduce the risk of bone-related complications.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may have one or more of the following treatments, not necessarily in the order below: • Bisphosphonates

Question (100 words): How can I manage the emotional impact of a breast cancer diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Managing the emotional impact of a breast cancer diagnosis involves seeking support from friends, family, and support groups. Consider talking to a counselor or therapist who specializes in cancer care. Engaging in relaxation techniques, such as meditation or yoga, can also help. Remember, it's okay to feel a range of emotions, and seeking help is a sign of strength.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: N/A

Question (100 words): What lifestyle changes can help during and after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Adopting a healthy lifestyle can support your overall well-being during and after breast cancer treatment. This includes maintaining a balanced diet, engaging in regular physical activity, avoiding tobacco and limiting alcohol, managing stress, and getting adequate sleep. These changes can help improve your energy levels, reduce side effects, and enhance your quality of life.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: N/A

Question (100 words): What nutritional guidelines should I follow during breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): During breast cancer treatment, it's important to follow a balanced diet rich in fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and lean proteins. Stay hydrated and limit processed foods, sugars, and saturated fats. If you experience side effects like nausea or changes in taste, work with a dietitian to adjust your diet accordingly. Proper nutrition can help you maintain strength and support your body through treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: N/A

Question (100 words): What are the common symptoms of breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common symptoms of breast cancer include a lump or thickening in the breast or underarm, changes in breast size or shape, dimpling or redness of the skin, nipple changes or discharge, and pain in any area of the breast. It's important to note that some people with breast cancer may not experience any symptoms.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Common symptoms of breast cancer include a lump or thickening in the breast or underarm, changes in breast size or shape, dimpling or redness of the skin, nipple changes or discharge, and pain in any area of the breast.

Question (100 words): What types of surgery are used to treat breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The main types of surgery for breast cancer are lumpectomy (removal of the tumor and a small amount of surrounding tissue) and mastectomy (removal of the entire breast). Depending on the stage and type of cancer, a surgeon may also remove lymph nodes from under the arm.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The main types of surgery for breast cancer are lumpectomy and mastectomy. Depending on the stage and type of cancer, a surgeon may also remove lymph nodes from under the arm.

Question (100 words): How should I care for my surgical drains after breast cancer surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After surgery, you may have surgical drains to remove excess fluid. Ensure the drains are secured and empty them regularly as instructed by your healthcare team. Keep the area clean and dry, and watch for signs of infection such as redness, swelling, or unusual discharge.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Ensure the drains are secured and empty them regularly as instructed by your healthcare team. Keep the area clean and dry, and watch for signs of infection such as redness, swelling, or unusual discharge.

Question (100 words): What are the different types of cancer treatment available for breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast cancer treatments include surgery, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, hormone therapy, and targeted therapy. The choice of treatment depends on the type and stage of cancer, as well as individual patient factors.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast cancer treatments include surgery, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, hormone therapy, and targeted therapy.

Question (100 words): What medications might I need to take after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After breast cancer treatment, you may need to take medications such as hormone therapy (e.g., tamoxifen or aromatase inhibitors) to reduce the risk of cancer recurrence, or medications to manage side effects like nausea or pain.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may need to take medications such as hormone therapy to reduce the risk of cancer recurrence, or medications to manage side effects like nausea or pain.

Question (100 words): What are common side effects of chemotherapy for breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common side effects of chemotherapy include fatigue, nausea, hair loss, increased risk of infections, and changes in appetite. These side effects vary depending on the specific drugs used and individual patient responses.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Common side effects of chemotherapy include fatigue, nausea, hair loss, increased risk of infections, and changes in appetite.

Question (100 words): What should I do to prepare my body for breast cancer surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To prepare your body for breast cancer surgery, follow any pre-surgery instructions provided by your healthcare team, which may include dietary restrictions, stopping certain medications, and engaging in light physical activity to improve overall fitness.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Follow any pre-surgery instructions provided by your healthcare team, which may include dietary restrictions, stopping certain medications, and engaging in light physical activity to improve overall fitness.

Question (100 words): What can I expect during my recovery after breast cancer surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Recovery after breast cancer surgery varies but typically includes managing pain with prescribed medications, gradually increasing physical activity, attending follow-up appointments, and possibly participating in physical therapy to regain strength and mobility.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Recovery after breast cancer surgery includes managing pain with prescribed medications, gradually increasing physical activity, attending follow-up appointments, and possibly participating in physical therapy.

Question (100 words): What kind of follow-up care will I need after completing breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After completing breast cancer treatment, you will need regular follow-up care, which may include physical exams, imaging tests (like mammograms), and blood tests to monitor for any signs of recurrence or new issues.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You will need regular follow-up care, which may include physical exams, imaging tests, and blood tests to monitor for any signs of recurrence or new issues.

Question (100 words): How can I maintain a healthy lifestyle during and after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Maintaining a healthy lifestyle during and after breast cancer treatment involves eating a balanced diet, engaging in regular physical activity, avoiding tobacco and limiting alcohol, managing stress, and getting adequate rest.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Maintaining a healthy lifestyle involves eating a balanced diet, engaging in regular physical activity, avoiding tobacco and limiting alcohol, managing stress, and getting adequate rest.

Question (100 words): What dietary recommendations should I follow during breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): During breast cancer treatment, it is recommended to eat a balanced diet rich in fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and lean proteins. Staying hydrated and limiting processed foods and sugars can also be beneficial.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It is recommended to eat a balanced diet rich in fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and lean proteins. Staying hydrated and limiting processed foods and sugars can also be beneficial.

Question (100 words): Where can I find emotional support during my breast cancer journey?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Emotional support during your breast cancer journey can be found through support groups, counseling services, breast cancer organizations like Breast Cancer Now, and by talking to friends and family. It’s important to share your feelings and seek help when needed.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Emotional support can be found through support groups, counseling services, breast cancer organizations, and by talking to friends and family.

Question (100 words): What diagnostic tests are used to confirm breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Diagnostic tests used to confirm breast cancer include mammography, ultrasound, MRI, biopsy (removal of a small sample of tissue for examination), and possibly blood tests to check for tumor markers.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Diagnostic tests include mammography, ultrasound, MRI, biopsy, and possibly blood tests to check for tumor markers.

Question (100 words): What administrative steps should I take before my breast cancer surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Before your breast cancer surgery, ensure you have all necessary paperwork completed, understand your insurance coverage, arrange for transportation to and from the hospital, and discuss any concerns with your healthcare team.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Ensure you have all necessary paperwork completed, understand your insurance coverage, arrange for transportation, and discuss any concerns with your healthcare team.

Question (100 words): What are the red flags I should watch for after breast cancer surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After breast cancer surgery, watch for red flags such as signs of infection (redness, swelling, increased pain), unusual discharge from the surgical site, fever, or any sudden changes in your overall health. Contact your healthcare provider if you notice these symptoms.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Watch for signs of infection, unusual discharge, fever, or any sudden changes in your overall health. Contact your healthcare provider if you notice these symptoms.

Question (100 words): How often should I get a mammogram after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After breast cancer treatment, you will typically need to get regular mammograms. The frequency may vary, but it is often recommended to have a mammogram every year for the first few years post-treatment, and then as advised by your healthcare provider.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You will typically need to get regular mammograms, often recommended every year for the first few years post-treatment.

Question (100 words): Can I exercise during breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, exercising during breast cancer treatment can be beneficial. It’s important to start slowly and gradually increase the intensity. Consult with your healthcare team to develop a safe exercise plan tailored to your condition and treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Exercising during breast cancer treatment can be beneficial. Consult with your healthcare team to develop a safe exercise plan.

Question (100 words): What should I eat to support my body during chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): During chemotherapy, focus on eating small, frequent meals that are easy to digest. Include plenty of fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and lean proteins. Stay hydrated and avoid foods that may cause discomfort or nausea.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Focus on eating small, frequent meals that are easy to digest. Include plenty of fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and lean proteins.

Question (100 words): How can I manage stress and anxiety during breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Managing stress and anxiety during breast cancer treatment can be achieved through various methods such as mindfulness practices, talking to a therapist, joining support groups, engaging in hobbies, and maintaining a routine. It’s important to find what works best for you.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Managing stress and anxiety can be achieved through mindfulness practices, talking to a therapist, joining support groups, engaging in hobbies, and maintaining a routine.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I miss a dose of my breast cancer medication?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you miss a dose of your breast cancer medication, take it as soon as you remember, unless it’s almost time for your next dose. In that case, skip the missed dose and continue with your regular schedule. Do not double the dose to catch up. Always consult your healthcare provider for specific instructions.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Take it as soon as you remember, unless it’s almost time for your next dose. Do not double the dose to catch up. Always consult your healthcare provider for specific instructions.

Question (100 words): What is secondary breast cancer in the lung?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Secondary breast cancer in the lung occurs when cancer that started in the breast spreads to the lung. The cells that have spread to the lung are breast cancer cells. It’s not the same as having cancer that starts in the lung (lung cancer). Breast cancer cells can spread to the lung through the lymphatic system or the blood.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Secondary breast cancer in the lung occurs when cancer that started in the breast spreads to the lung.

Question (100 words): What are the symptoms of secondary breast cancer in the lung?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Symptoms can range from very mild to severe and may include breathlessness, wheezing, a persistent cough, coughing up blood, chest pain or tightness, loss of appetite and weight loss, and constant tiredness. Sometimes, the cancer can press on a nerve in the chest, causing a hoarse voice. A build-up of fluid between the lung and chest wall, known as a pleural effusion, can also cause breathlessness or a cough.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Symptoms include: • Breathlessness • Wheezing • A cough that does not go away • Coughing up blood • Pain or tightness in the chest that does not go away • Loss of appetite and weight loss • Feeling constantly tired

Question (100 words): What tests are used to diagnose secondary breast cancer in the lung?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Tests may include a chest x-ray, CT (computerised tomography) scan, PET-CT (positron emission tomography-computerised tomography) scan, lung biopsy, bronchoscopy, CT-guided lung biopsy, EBUS (endobronchial ultrasound), and blood tests. These tests help diagnose secondary breast cancer in the lung, confirm affected areas, and monitor the condition over time.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may need 1 or more of the following tests to help diagnose secondary breast cancer in the lung.

Question (100 words): How is secondary breast cancer in the lung treated?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Treatment aims to control and slow down the spread of the cancer, relieve symptoms, and improve quality of life. Treatment options may include hormone (endocrine) therapy, targeted therapy, chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and surgery. These treatments can be given alone or in combination.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your treatment may include: • Hormone (endocrine) therapy • Targeted therapy • Chemotherapy • Radiotherapy • Surgery

Question (100 words): What is hormone (endocrine) therapy for secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Hormone therapy blocks or stops the effect of oestrogen on breast cancer cells. It is used for oestrogen receptor positive (ER-positive) breast cancers. Common hormone therapy drugs include aromatase inhibitors, fulvestrant, goserelin, leuprorelin, and tamoxifen. It can take 2 to 3 months to see benefits.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Hormone therapies block or stop the effect of oestrogen on breast cancer cells.

Question (100 words): What is targeted therapy for secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Targeted therapy is a group of drugs that block the growth and spread of cancer by interfering with specific processes in cancer cells. For HER2-positive breast cancer, targeted therapies include pertuzumab, trastuzumab, trastuzumab deruxtecan, trastuzumab emtansine, and tucatinib.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Targeted therapy is the name given to a group of drugs that block the growth and spread of cancer.

Question (100 words): What should I ask my treatment team about my secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You may want to ask about whether your case has been discussed in an MDT meeting, the aim of your treatment, your treatment options, any additional options, clinical trials, the risks and benefits of each treatment, possible side effects, and referrals to specialists. It’s important to understand your treatment plan and who to contact if you experience new symptoms or side effects.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may want to ask your treatment team about: • Whether your case has been discussed in an MDT meeting • The aim of your treatment • Your treatment options and why they’re recommending a particular drug or procedure

Question (100 words): How is a lung biopsy performed for secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A lung biopsy is usually done while you're sedated. A small piece of tissue is removed from the lung under local anaesthetic. This can be done through a small cut in the skin or via a bronchoscope passed through the mouth and down into the lungs.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It involves removing a small piece of tissue from the lung under local anaesthetic, to be examined under a microscope.

Question (100 words): What is a pleural effusion and how is it treated?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A pleural effusion is a build-up of fluid between the lung and chest wall. It can cause breathlessness or a cough. Treatment may involve draining the fluid to relieve symptoms and improve breathing.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some people have a build-up of fluid between the lung and chest wall, known as a pleural effusion, which can cause breathlessness or a cough.

Question (100 words): What is the role of the multidisciplinary team (MDT) in treating secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The multidisciplinary team (MDT) consists of healthcare professionals with different expertise who meet regularly to discuss your care. They consider various factors such as the extent of cancer, symptoms, past treatments, and your general health to make treatment decisions.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You’ll be cared for by a team of healthcare professionals, each with their own expertise. This is known as the multidisciplinary team (MDT).

Question (100 words): Can secondary breast cancer in the lung be cured?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Secondary breast cancer in the lung can be treated but cannot be cured. Treatments aim to control and slow down the spread of the cancer, relieve symptoms, and improve quality of life.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: When breast cancer spreads to the lung, it can be treated but cannot be cured.

Question (100 words): How does secondary breast cancer affect the lungs?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Secondary breast cancer can affect the lungs by causing symptoms such as breathlessness, wheezing, persistent cough, and chest pain. It can also lead to complications like pleural effusion, where fluid builds up between the lung and chest wall.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Symptoms can range from very mild to severe, depending on whether 1 or 2 lungs are affected and where the cancer is in the lungs.

Question (100 words): What is the outlook for someone with secondary breast cancer in the lung?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The outlook for secondary breast cancer in the lung varies. As treatments have improved, more people are living longer after diagnosis. However, life expectancy is difficult to predict as each case is different. Factors such as the extent of cancer, affected areas, and cancer features influence prognosis.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: As treatments have improved, more and more people are living much longer after a diagnosis of secondary breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What is the function of the lungs and how are they structured?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The lungs take up most of the chest area, extending from the collarbone down to the abdomen. They are protected by the ribcage. The lungs inflate when we breathe in, facilitated by the diaphragm. Each lung is made up of sections called lobes, and air is carried to the lungs by the trachea, which divides into bronchi and then into smaller bronchioles, ending in alveoli where gas exchange occurs.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The lungs take up most of the chest area, extending from the collarbone down to the tummy (abdomen). They’re protected by the ribcage.

Question (100 words): What is the difference between secondary breast cancer in the lung and lung cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Secondary breast cancer in the lung occurs when cancer that started in the breast spreads to the lung. The cells that have spread to the lung are breast cancer cells. This is different from lung cancer, which starts in the lung. Secondary breast cancer may also be called metastatic breast cancer, advanced breast cancer, secondary tumours, or Stage 4 breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The cells that have spread to the lung are breast cancer cells. It’s not the same as having cancer that starts in the lung (lung cancer).

Question (100 words): What are the common procedures for taking a lung biopsy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common procedures for taking a lung biopsy include a bronchoscopy, where a tube called a bronchoscope is passed through the mouth and down into the lungs, and a CT-guided lung biopsy, where a biopsy is taken through the skin using a needle guided by a CT scan.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Another common procedure for taking a lung biopsy is a bronchoscopy. A tube called a bronchoscope is passed through the mouth and down into the lungs. A biopsy can then be done.

Question (100 words): What are tumour marker blood tests and how are they used in breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Tumour marker blood tests measure proteins in the blood that the body may produce in response to cancer. However, their reliability for breast cancer is unclear as they can also be raised for other reasons. If raised at diagnosis, some treatment teams may continue to check them regularly, but they are not used alone to make treatment decisions.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some people have a blood test for tumour markers. These are proteins found in the blood that the body may produce in response to cancer.

Question (100 words): What factors influence the treatment decisions for secondary breast cancer in the lung?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Treatment decisions are influenced by factors such as the extent of cancer within the lung, whether the cancer has spread to other organs, any symptoms you have, past treatments, the features of the cancer, menopausal status, and your general health. Your treatment team will discuss these factors with you.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: When making decisions about how best to treat you, your treatment team will consider: • How much cancer is within the lung • Whether the cancer has spread to other organs • Any symptoms you have • What treatment you’ve had in the past • The features of the cancer • Whether you’ve been through the menopause • Your general health

Question (100 words): What is the role of the respiratory team in treating secondary breast cancer in the lung?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The respiratory team specialises in treating people with breathing difficulties. They can help plan your treatment or manage your symptoms. Your care will continue under your usual breast treatment team, but with involvement or advice from the respiratory team.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may also be referred to the respiratory team, which specialises in treating people with breathing difficulties. They can help plan your treatment or manage your symptoms.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience new symptoms or side effects during treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience new symptoms or side effects during treatment, it’s important to report them to your GP, breast care nurse, or treatment team. They can provide guidance on what to do and may adjust your treatment plan accordingly.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: What to do if you get new symptoms or treatment side effects, and who to report them to

Question (100 words): What are the targeted therapies used for HER2-negative, ER-positive breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Targeted therapies for HER2-negative, ER-positive breast cancer include Abemaciclib (Verzenios), Alpelisib (Piqray), Everolimus (Afinitor), Palbociclib (Ibrance), and Ribociclib (Kisqali). These are usually taken alongside hormone therapy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some targeted therapies are used to treat HER2-negative, oestrogen receptor positive (ER-positive) breast cancer. These are usually taken alongside hormone therapy.

Question (100 words): What targeted therapies are used for triple negative breast cancers?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Targeted therapies for triple negative breast cancers include Atezolizumab (Tecentriq), Pembrolizumab (Keytruda), and Sacituzumab govitecan (Trodelvy).
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Targeted therapies used to treat some triple negative breast cancers – cancers that are oestrogen receptor negative, progesterone receptor negative and HER2-negative – that have spread include: Atezolizumab (Tecentriq), Pembrolizumab (Keytruda), Sacituzumab govitecan (Trodelvy)

Question (100 words): How does chemotherapy work in treating secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Chemotherapy destroys cancer cells by affecting their ability to divide and grow. Various chemotherapy drugs may be used alone or in combination with targeted therapies.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Chemotherapy destroys cancer cells by affecting their ability to divide and grow.

Question (100 words): What are the main treatments for secondary breast cancer in the lung?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The main treatments for secondary breast cancer in the lung are drugs, and sometimes surgery or radiotherapy. These treatments can relieve symptoms but won’t treat cancer in other areas of the body.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Drugs are the main treatment for secondary breast cancer in the lung.

Question (100 words): What is stereotactic radiotherapy and when is it used?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Stereotactic radiotherapy, also known as radiosurgery, uses high-energy x-rays to destroy cancer cells with precision. It is used for a limited number of small secondary cancers in the lungs when the patient has good general health and fitness.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Radiotherapy uses high-energy x-rays to destroy cancer cells. You may be offered very precise radiotherapy if you have a limited number of small secondary cancers in the lungs and have a good level of general health and fitness.

Question (100 words): When might surgery be considered for secondary breast cancer in the lung?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Surgery may be considered if the area of secondary breast cancer in the lung is very small, easily accessible, and there is no other secondary breast cancer elsewhere in the body.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Although surgery will not cure secondary breast cancer in the lung, occasionally it may be part of a treatment plan.

Question (100 words): What is Video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS)?
Answer (Max 2000 words): VATS is a type of operation that allows doctors to see inside the chest and lungs using a thin tube with a built-in camera (thoracoscope) placed through a small cut in the side of the chest.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) is a type of operation that allows doctors to see inside the chest and lungs.

Question (100 words): What are clinical trials and how can they help in treating secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Clinical trials are research studies that look at new treatments or different ways of giving existing treatments. They can offer new options for treatment and are commonly part of the treatment plan for secondary breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Clinical trials and research studies are commonly offered as part of treatment for secondary breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What is palliative and supportive care and why is it important?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Palliative and supportive care focuses on symptom control and support, significantly improving the quality of life for people with secondary breast cancer and their families. It can be beneficial at any stage of the illness.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Palliative and supportive care focuses on symptom control and support. It’s an extremely important part of the care and treatment for many people with secondary breast cancer and can significantly improve quality of life for them and their families.

Question (100 words): What should I do if a treatment for secondary breast cancer is not routinely available on the NHS?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If a treatment is not routinely available on the NHS, you may still access it through clinical trials, early or compassionate access schemes, or privately. Speak to your treatment team or call Macmillan Cancer Support for more information.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some treatments for secondary breast cancer may not be routinely available on the NHS. You may still be able to access these treatments in other ways, such as a clinical trial, early or compassionate access schemes, or privately.

Question (100 words): What are the common symptoms of secondary breast cancer in the lung?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common symptoms include breathlessness (dyspnoea), cough, and pain. These symptoms can vary in intensity and may require different management strategies.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breathlessness is 1 of the more common symptoms of secondary breast cancer in the lung. The medical term for this is dyspnoea.

Question (100 words): How can I manage breathlessness caused by secondary breast cancer in the lung?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can manage breathlessness through practical measures like using a fan, cooling your face with cold water, sitting forward with arms and elbows on a raised surface, and learning relaxation and breathing techniques. Medication may also be prescribed.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There are several practical things you can do to help ease your breathlessness.

Question (100 words): What is lymphangitis and how is it treated?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Lymphangitis is the inflammation and scarring of lymph channels in the lung caused by breast cancer cells. It is treated with chemotherapy and sometimes steroid drugs like dexamethasone or prednisolone.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Sometimes breast cancer cells can block the lymph channels in the lung, causing inflammation and scarring. This is called lymphangitis.

Question (100 words): How can physiotherapy help with breathlessness?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Physiotherapy can help by teaching relaxation and breathing techniques, such as controlled breathing using lower chest muscles and diaphragm, to help you breathe more slowly and effectively.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Physiotherapy can be helpful in treating breathlessness.

Question (100 words): What medications can help ease breathlessness?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Medications that can help ease breathlessness include Lorazepam (a benzodiazepine), Ventolin (which relaxes the airways), and low doses of codeine or morphine.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If necessary, your treatment team or GP can give you medicines to help ease breathlessness.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I have an ongoing cough due to secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Cough medicines, mucolytic medicines to loosen phlegm, and a nebuliser may be recommended. If the cough is severe, codeine-based drugs, low-dose morphine, or steroids may be prescribed.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: An ongoing cough is a common symptom that can be distressing and tiring.

Question (100 words): How is pain managed in secondary breast cancer in the lung?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Pain is managed through regular assessments by your specialist nurse, treatment team, or GP. Pain relief medications, anti-inflammatory drugs, steroids, and other drugs may be used. A pain diary can help track and manage pain.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Pain relief is a very important part of the care of many people with secondary breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What is a pleural effusion and how is it treated?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A pleural effusion is a build-up of fluid between the pleural layers, often confirmed by a chest x-ray. It is treated by removing the fluid with a needle and syringe or a drainage tube, and sometimes a pleurodesis procedure is performed to seal the pleural layers together.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A pleural effusion is a build-up of extra fluid between the pleural layers.

Question (100 words): Why might I experience poor appetite and weight loss with secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Poor appetite and weight loss can be due to the effects of the cancer, treatment, or anxiety. Eating little and often instead of having set meals might help.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You might find you can’t eat as much as usual. This might make it harder to maintain your weight and get enough energy.

Question (100 words): What is pleurodesis and when is it performed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Pleurodesis is a procedure where a drug or powder is injected into the drain to seal the two layers of the pleura together, preventing fluid build-up. It is performed after draining a pleural effusion.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: This involves injecting a drug or powder into the drain, then leaving the drain clamped for about 1 hour before removing it. This aims to seal the 2 layers of the pleura together to prevent the fluid building up again.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I'm experiencing extreme tiredness?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you're experiencing extreme tiredness, known as cancer-related fatigue, it's important to discuss this with your specialist nurse, treatment team, or GP. They can provide guidance on managing fatigue and may suggest dietary supplements or medication to help increase your appetite. For more detailed information, refer to the Secondary breast cancer information pack.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Extreme tiredness (cancer-related fatigue) Cancer-related fatigue is 1 of the most common symptoms in people with secondary breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What are the symptoms of a blood clot I should watch for?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Symptoms of a blood clot include pain, redness or discolouration of the skin, heat and swelling of the arm or leg, swelling, redness or tenderness where a central line is inserted, shortness of breath or a sudden increase in breathlessness, pain or tightness in the chest, and an unexplained cough or coughing up blood. If you experience any of these symptoms, contact your treatment team or go to your local A&E department immediately.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Contact your treatment team or go to your local A&E department straight away if you have any of the following symptoms: • Pain, redness/discolouration of the skin, heat and swelling of the arm or leg

Question (100 words): Can exercise help with secondary breast cancer in the lung?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, exercise can help. Although research specifically on secondary breast cancer is limited, studies on primary breast cancer show that gentle exercise during and between treatments can improve tolerance to treatments, reduce pain and sickness, improve sleep, and lessen fatigue. It’s important to choose activities you enjoy and can safely perform, such as walking, swimming, or cycling.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Research has shown that people who exercise, even gently, during and between breast cancer treatments may tolerate them better.

Question (100 words): How can I manage breathlessness while exercising?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To manage breathlessness while exercising, avoid exercising in very cold or dry conditions, start with a gentle warm-up, and consider activities that involve relaxation, such as yoga. Walking with rest stops can also be helpful. Additionally, pursed lip breathing can reduce air pressure and make it easier for your lungs to expand and contract.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There are a number of things you can do to avoid or reduce breathlessness while exercising.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I feel isolated or depressed after my diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you feel isolated, scared, anxious, angry, or depressed after your diagnosis, seek support from your specialist nurse, palliative care nurse, or a counsellor. They can provide emotional support, help with pain and symptom control, and offer different coping strategies. You can also call the Breast Cancer Now helpline on 0808 800 6000 for additional support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may be able to cope with these feelings on your own or with the support of the people closest to you.

Question (100 words): Are there any support groups for younger women with secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, Breast Cancer Now offers a support group called Younger Women with Secondaries Together, which provides a safe space for women under 45 with secondary breast cancer to talk about their experiences and receive tailored information on treatment and living with the disease.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Younger Women with Secondaries Together gives you the chance to meet other women under 45 with secondary breast cancer.

Question (100 words): How can I find local support for breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can find local support by contacting your local Cancer Information Centre. Speak to your specialist nurse or treatment team to learn about the specific support available in your area.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may be able to find other support in your area by contacting your local Cancer Information Centre.

Question (100 words): What are the symptoms of secondary breast cancer in the lung?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Symptoms of secondary breast cancer in the lung can include breathlessness, pain, loss of appetite, tiredness, and fatigue. Some people may have no symptoms at all.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some people with secondary breast cancer in the lung have no symptoms while others have breathlessness, pain, loss of appetite, tiredness and fatigue.

Question (100 words): Can dietary supplements help if I'm not eating enough?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, if you're not eating enough, are losing weight, or have no interest in food, talk to your specialist nurse, treatment team, or GP about dietary supplements. You can also consult a dietitian for specialist advice.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you still feel you’re not eating enough, are losing weight or have no interest in food, talk to your specialist nurse, treatment team or GP about dietary supplements.

Question (100 words): What kind of medication might I be prescribed to help with appetite?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You may be prescribed medication to help increase your appetite if you're experiencing a lack of interest in food or significant weight loss. Discuss this with your healthcare team for personalized recommendations.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: In some cases, you may be prescribed medication to help increase your appetite.

Question (100 words): How can I get more information about managing fatigue?
Answer (Max 2000 words): For more information on managing fatigue, you can refer to the Secondary breast cancer information pack provided by Breast Cancer Now.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: For more information on managing fatigue, see our Secondary breast cancer information pack.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I suspect I have a pulmonary embolism?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you suspect you have a pulmonary embolism, contact your treatment team or go to your local A&E department immediately. Symptoms include shortness of breath, sudden increase in breathlessness, pain or tightness in the chest, and unexplained cough or coughing up blood.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have a DVT, there’s a risk part of the blood clot could break away and travel to the lung. This is known as a pulmonary embolism (PE).

Question (100 words): What types of exercise are recommended for people with secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Recommended exercises include aerobic activities such as walking, swimming, or cycling, as well as activities like dancing and gardening. Light toning or conditioning exercises such as stretching or low-impact yoga can also be beneficial.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: When choosing your exercise, try to focus on aerobic-type activities such as walking, swimming or cycling.

Question (100 words): How can a GP exercise referral programme help me?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A GP exercise referral programme can help you increase your activity levels and improve your health and wellbeing. Trained instructors can provide support and ensure you exercise safely, taking into account any changes to your health.
