Answer (Max 2000 words): The exact effect and safety of taking herbal products or supplements after a diagnosis of breast cancer is not fully understood. Ask your treatment team or pharmacist before taking any herbal medicines or supplements.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Many people consider taking herbal products or supplements while having treatment for breast cancer.

Question (100 words): Can I get pregnant while taking exemestane?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Taking exemestane while pregnant may be harmful to a developing baby. It’s possible to become pregnant even if your periods have stopped with ovarian suppression. Use a non-hormonal method of contraception like condoms, Femidoms, or a diaphragm.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Taking exemestane while pregnant may be harmful to a developing baby.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I think I am pregnant while taking exemestane?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you think you may be pregnant, stop taking exemestane and inform your specialist as soon as possible.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you think you may be pregnant, stop exemestane and tell your specialist as soon as possible.

Question (100 words): Is breastfeeding safe while taking exemestane?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breastfeeding is not recommended while taking exemestane because there’s a risk the drugs could be passed on through breast milk.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breastfeeding is not recommended while having exemestane.

Question (100 words): How can I find emotional support during my treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can find emotional support through Breast Cancer Now’s Someone Like Me service. Call 0114 263 6490 to connect with someone who understands what you’re going through.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Find somebody who understands what you’re going through with Someone Like Me.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I have questions or concerns about exemestane?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you have any worries or questions about taking or stopping exemestane, you can call Breast Cancer Now’s helpline free on 0808 800 6000 or email nurse@breastcancernow.org.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have any worries or questions about taking or stopping exemestane, you can call us free on 0808 800 6000.

Question (100 words): How long should I take exemestane?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your treatment team will tell you when to stop taking exemestane. There’s evidence that exemestane continues to reduce the risk of breast cancer coming back for many years after you stop taking it.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your treatment team will tell you when to stop taking exemestane.

Question (100 words): What are the common side effects of exemestane?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common side effects of exemestane include hair loss or thinning, skin rash or itching, liver function changes, swelling of hands and feet, and vaginal bleeding. Side effects vary from person to person.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Side effects caused by exemestane will be different for each person.

Question (100 words): Can exemestane interact with other hormone therapies?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Do not take other drugs containing oestrogen, such as hormone replacement therapy (HRT), while you’re taking exemestane as this may interfere with its effectiveness.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Do not take other drugs containing oestrogen, such as hormone replacement therapy (HRT), while you’re taking exemestane.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience symptoms of a blood clot?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience symptoms such as pain, redness/discolouration, heat and swelling of the arm or leg, shortness of breath, pain or tightness in the chest, or an unexplained cough, contact your local A&E department, GP, or treatment team straight away.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you experience any of the following symptoms contact your local A&E department, GP or treatment team straight away.

Question (100 words): Can I switch to another hormone drug if exemestane stops working?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If exemestane stops working, your specialist may prescribe another hormone drug. Hormone therapy is a common treatment for secondary breast cancer and many people take it for a long time.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If exemestane stops working, your specialist may prescribe another hormone drug.

Question (100 words): What should I discuss with my treatment team before starting exemestane?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Discuss any fertility concerns, the use of non-hormonal contraception if you’re sexually active, and the impact of exemestane on breastfeeding. Also, inform them about any other medications you are taking.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Discuss any fertility concerns with your treatment team before you begin your treatment.

Question (100 words): What treatments for breast cancer can cause hair loss?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Chemotherapy, targeted (biological) therapies, immunotherapy, radiotherapy, and hormone (endocrine) therapy can cause hair loss. The extent of hair loss varies depending on the specific treatment and dosage.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Chemotherapy destroys cancer cells by interfering with their ability to divide and grow. It can affect healthy cells throughout the body such as the cells in hair follicles, which is why chemotherapy can make your hair fall out.

Question (100 words): How does chemotherapy cause hair loss?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Chemotherapy causes hair loss by interfering with the ability of cells to divide and grow, which affects not only cancer cells but also healthy cells in hair follicles.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Chemotherapy destroys cancer cells by interfering with their ability to divide and grow. It can affect healthy cells throughout the body such as the cells in hair follicles, which is why chemotherapy can make your hair fall out.

Question (100 words): Does radiotherapy cause hair loss?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, radiotherapy can cause hair loss, but only in the specific area being treated. For example, if you’re having radiotherapy to the lymph nodes in your armpit, you’ll lose underarm hair in that area.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Radiotherapy uses high-energy x-rays to destroy cancer cells. Like chemotherapy, it affects healthy cells as well as cancer cells so can cause hair loss, but only in the specific area being treated.

Question (100 words): Can hormone therapy cause hair loss?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, hormone (endocrine) therapy can cause hair thinning. This is usually mild and might only occur for a short time, but in some cases, it can continue until treatment ends.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Taking hormone therapy such as tamoxifen, anastrozole (Arimidex), exemestane (Aromasin) or letrozole (Femara) can cause hair thinning. This is usually mild and might only occur for a short time.

Question (100 words): Is hair loss from breast cancer treatment permanent?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Hair loss from breast cancer treatment is almost always temporary, but in some cases, it can be long-lasting or permanent, especially with certain targeted therapies or prolonged treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Hair loss from breast cancer treatment is almost always temporary, but in some cases it can be long lasting or permanent.

Question (100 words): How can I prepare for hair loss before treatment starts?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can prepare for hair loss by cutting your hair short or shaving it off before treatment starts. This can help you feel more in control. You can also choose a wig beforehand if you plan to wear one.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some people find that being prepared beforehand means it’s easier to come to terms with losing their hair.

Question (100 words): What is scalp cooling and how does it help with hair loss?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Scalp cooling is a technique used during chemotherapy to reduce hair loss. It involves wearing a cooling cap that lowers the temperature of the scalp, which may reduce the amount of chemotherapy that reaches the hair follicles.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you are going to use scalp cooling (see page 16) the timing of any hair loss may be different.

Question (100 words): How soon after chemotherapy will I start losing my hair?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Hair loss usually starts two to three weeks after your first chemotherapy treatment. The timing can vary depending on the type of drugs used, the dose, and how often you have chemotherapy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have chemotherapy every two to three weeks, hair loss will usually start two to three weeks after your first treatment.

Question (100 words): When will my hair start to grow back after chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your hair will usually start to grow back around three to six months after your chemotherapy has finished. Some people find that it starts to grow back before they have completed all their chemotherapy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your hair will usually start to grow back around three to six months after your chemotherapy has finished.

Question (100 words): How can I care for my scalp during and after treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can care for your scalp by using mild, fragrance-free shampoos and avoiding harsh chemicals. Keep your scalp moisturized and protect it from the sun with a scarf or hat.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: This can also affect your body hair including eyebrows, eyelashes, nasal and pubic hair, and chest hair for men.

Question (100 words): What should I tell my children about my hair loss?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Prepare your children by explaining that hair loss is a side effect of treatment and is usually not permanent. Let them know what you plan to wear on your head, such as a wig or headscarf.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your children may find it upsetting to see you without any hair and it might help if you prepare them for the fact that this may happen.

Question (100 words): How can I cope with the emotional impact of hair loss?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Talk to your treatment team about your feelings, seek support from friends and family, and consider joining a support group. It can also help to talk to others who have experienced hair loss.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There’s no right or wrong way to feel and, whether you lose some or all of your hair, the experience can be very distressing.

Question (100 words): What types of headwear can I use if I lose my hair?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can use wigs, scarves, hats, or fringe hairpieces. Some hospitals and local organizations offer services to help you choose and try on different types of headwear.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you think you’ll want to wear a wig, it can be useful to choose it before you lose your hair.

Question (100 words): Can I donate my hair if I choose to cut it short before treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, you can donate your hair to organizations that make wigs for people with hair loss. Check the ‘Useful organisations’ section on page 55 for more information.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some people donate their hair if they have it cut off. There are organisations that you can donate your hair to for them to make into wigs for anyone with hair loss.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience hair thinning from hormone therapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Talk to your treatment team or GP about your hair thinning. They can provide advice and support. Hair thinning is usually mild and may only occur for a short time.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Taking hormone therapy such as tamoxifen, anastrozole (Arimidex), exemestane (Aromasin) or letrozole (Femara) can cause hair thinning. This is usually mild and might only occur for a short time.

Question (100 words): How can I prevent infection if I shave my head before treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Avoid using a razor or clippers without a guard to reduce the risk of scratching or cutting the skin, which could lead to infection. Use hair clippers with a guard for safety.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you shave your hair off, avoid using a razor or clippers without a guard to reduce the risk of scratching or cutting the skin, which could lead to infection.

Question (100 words): What support is available for people experiencing hair loss from breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Support is available from your treatment team, support groups, and organizations like Breast Cancer Now. You can call their free Helpline on 0808 800 6000 for more information.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you are finding these feelings overwhelming you may wish to speak to your treatment team or find further counselling and support.

Question (100 words): How can I recreate my eyebrows and eyelashes if I lose them?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can use makeup to recreate the illusion of eyebrows and eyelashes. Some hospitals and local organizations offer tips and guidance on this.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Practical tips on using makeup to give the illusion of eyelashes and eyebrows

Question (100 words): Will my hair grow back the same as before after treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your hair may grow back with a different texture or color. It’s common for hair to be softer or curlier than before. The color may also be different.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: When your hair grows back it may have a different texture or colour to how it was before. It may be softer, curlier or straighter than before. The colour may also be different.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I’m experiencing overwhelming feelings about hair loss?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Speak to your treatment team, seek counseling, or contact support organizations like Breast Cancer Now. They can provide emotional support and guidance.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you are finding these feelings overwhelming you may wish to speak to your treatment team or find further counselling and support.

Question (100 words): Can scalp cooling prevent hair loss during chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Scalp cooling may help prevent some or all hair loss during chemotherapy by reducing blood flow to the hair follicles, thus limiting the amount of chemotherapy drugs that reach them. However, its effectiveness varies depending on the chemotherapy drugs and doses used, and it may not work for everyone. If hair is preserved, it might be patchy or thinner. Scalp cooling is suitable for all hair types but may be less effective on Afro hair.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Scalp cooling may stop you losing some, or all, of the hair on your head during chemotherapy.

Question (100 words): What are the two methods of scalp cooling available?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The two widely available methods of scalp cooling are using a cold cap, which is a gel-filled hat that is chilled and replaced at regular intervals, and a refrigerated cooling machine that continuously pumps a liquid coolant through a single cap. Both methods require wearing a cold cap before, during, and for one to two hours after chemotherapy treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: One method uses a cold cap, which is a gel filled hat that is chilled and replaced at regular intervals during your chemotherapy treatment to keep the scalp cool. The other system uses a refrigerated cooling machine to continuously pump a liquid coolant through a single cap.

Question (100 words): Does scalp cooling increase the risk of secondary cancers in the scalp?
Answer (Max 2000 words): No, studies have found that scalp cooling does not increase the risk of developing secondary breast cancer in the scalp. Some doctors were initially concerned that constricted blood vessels might limit the amount of chemotherapy reaching the area, but research has not supported this concern.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Studies looking at people who had scalp cooling during their chemotherapy treatment have found that scalp cooling does not increase the risk of developing secondary breast cancer in the scalp.

Question (100 words): Is scalp cooling suitable for everyone receiving chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Scalp cooling is not suitable for everyone. It is not recommended for patients receiving radiotherapy to treat breast cancer that has spread to the brain, as hair loss cannot be prevented in this case. Additionally, the effectiveness may vary based on the type and dose of chemotherapy drugs used.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Scalp cooling is not suitable if you’re having radiotherapy to treat breast cancer that has spread to the brain, as hair loss can’t be prevented.

Question (100 words): What tips can help make scalp cooling more comfortable?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To make scalp cooling more comfortable, you can remove hair extensions, weaves, or braids before cooling; gently comb your hair back to make the front hairline visible; lightly dampen your hair with lukewarm water; apply a small amount of conditioner to help remove the cap; and ensure the cold cap covers the whole scalp and fits snugly. Wearing warm layers, sipping hot drinks, and using blankets can also help if you feel cold.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The following tips may help: • Removing hair extensions, weaves or braids before scalp cooling • Gently combing back your hair with a wide tooth comb or your fingers so the front hairline is visible • Lightly dampening your hair underneath the cap with lukewarm water • Applying a small amount of conditioner to the hair to help remove the cap • The cold cap should cover the whole scalp and fit snugly

Question (100 words): Do I need to cut my hair short before using a cold cap?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You do not need to cut your hair short before using a cold cap. However, if your hair is very long or thick, cutting it may help reduce weight and make it more manageable.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You don’t need to cut your hair short before you start using a cold cap. However, if your hair is very long or thick it may be helpful to cut it to reduce some weight and make it more manageable.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience discomfort with the cold cap?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience discomfort, aching, or nausea with the cold cap, these side effects are usually mild and should go away as you get used to the cold. Wearing warm layers, sipping hot drinks, and covering yourself with blankets can help. If the discomfort persists, speak to your chemotherapy nurse or treatment team, who may recommend mild pain relief such as paracetamol.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re struggling with the side effects of the cold cap speak to your chemotherapy nurse or treatment team. They may recommend taking mild pain relief, such as paracetamol, before wearing the cold cap.

Question (100 words): How should I care for my hair during chemotherapy if I don’t lose it?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If chemotherapy doesn’t cause hair loss, it may still make your hair brittle, dry, or straw-like. To care for your hair, use a mild, unperfumed shampoo and conditioner, wash your hair no more than twice a week, use warm rather than hot water, pat your hair dry rather than rubbing it, and brush or comb your hair gently with a soft hairbrush or wide-tooth plastic comb. Avoid tight hairstyles, strong chemicals, and excessive heat.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If chemotherapy doesn’t cause hair loss, it may make it brittle, dry or straw-like, so it’s a good idea to treat your hair as gently as possible.

Question (100 words): When will I start losing my hair after beginning chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Hair loss usually begins gradually within two to three weeks of starting chemotherapy. For some people, it may be sooner and more sudden. The first signs may be finding hair on your pillow in the morning or extra hair in your hairbrush.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Hair loss will usually begin gradually within two or three weeks of starting chemotherapy.

Question (100 words): How should I care for my scalp if I experience hair loss?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience hair loss, care for your scalp by using a small amount of unperfumed moisturiser or natural oils like coconut or almond if it’s dry, flaky, or itchy. Protect your scalp from the sun by covering your head or using a high protection factor sun cream. Continue to wash your scalp regularly, and if you wear a wig, headscarf, or hat, wash these regularly to keep them clean and avoid irritation.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Looking after your scalp if you experience hair loss is important as this area may feel tender and the skin may be sensitive.

Question (100 words): What are my options for headwear if I lose my hair?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You have several options for headwear if you lose your hair, including wigs, headscarves, hats, or other headwear. Choose what makes you feel comfortable, whether it’s a wig for special occasions, a hat or headscarf for everyday wear, or going without any head covering.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Many people wear wigs, headscarves, hats or other headwear until their hair grows back.

Question (100 words): Are wigs available on the NHS, and how can I get one?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Synthetic wigs are available on the NHS and are free in Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland. In England, you may need to pay a charge unless you qualify for a free wig based on certain criteria such as low income or specific benefits. Some hospitals may provide a free synthetic wig even if you are not eligible for help with the cost. Speak to your treatment team to find out if you’re entitled to a free wig.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Synthetic wigs are available on the NHS. They are free in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. In England, you’ll usually have to pay a charge for an NHS wig.

Question (100 words): Can I get financial help towards the cost of a wig if I’m not eligible for a free one?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you’re not eligible for a free wig, you may still get one through the NHS at a subsidised rate if you have a low income. You’ll need to apply using an HC1 form, which you can get from your hospital or nhsbsa.nhs.uk/nhs-low-income-scheme. You may also be able to get financial help from Macmillan Cancer Support, but your treatment team, GP, or social worker will need to apply for you.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you aren’t entitled to a free wig you can still get one through the NHS at a subsidised rate if you have a low income.

Question (100 words): What should I expect during a wig fitting appointment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): During a wig fitting appointment, an appliance officer or specialist wig fitter will advise you and fit you with a suitable wig. Many hospitals have a limited range, but if you can’t find a suitable wig, your treatment team may recommend another local supplier. Wig fitters usually have a private room for fittings, and you may find it helpful to bring a relative or friend for support. Some fitters offer telephone or video appointments.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Many hospitals have an appliance officer or specialist wig fitter who can give you advice and fit you with a suitable wig.

Question (100 words): How often can I get a new wig on the NHS?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You may be entitled to a new wig on the NHS every six months if necessary. Your chemotherapy or breast care nurse should advise you on how to get your replacement wig.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may be entitled to a new wig on the NHS every six months if necessary.

Question (100 words): Can I claim back VAT on a wig purchased from a shop?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, people whose hair loss is caused by cancer treatment do not have to pay VAT on wigs bought from a shop or other supplier. To claim back the VAT, you’ll need to complete and post a VAT form, which most stores will provide at the time of purchase. The tax can’t be claimed back at a later date.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: People whose hair loss is caused by cancer treatment do not have to pay VAT on wigs bought from a shop or other supplier.

Question (100 words): What should I avoid doing to protect my hair during treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To protect your hair during treatment, avoid overly tight plaits or braids, elastic bands, hair colours and dyes, perms, relaxers, products containing alcohol, excessive heat from hair straighteners, hairdryers, hot brushes, and heated rollers, and hair extensions, weaves, and braids.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Things to avoid: • Overly tight plaits or braids as they may cause tension and this may damage your hair • Using elastic bands to tie back hair • Hair colours and dyes, perms, relaxers and other products containing strong chemicals • Products containing alcohol, such as hairspray, which can irritate the scalp • Excessive heat from hair straighteners, hairdryers, hot brushes and heated rollers • Hair extensions, weaves and braids as these can weaken the hair

Question (100 words): How can changes in diet and lifestyle improve the condition of my hair?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Hair thinning, poor condition, or a dry and itchy scalp can be related to poor diet, stress, and excessive alcohol consumption. Making changes to your diet and lifestyle, such as eating a balanced diet and reducing stress, may help improve the condition of your hair.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Hair thinning, poor condition or a dry and itchy scalp can also be related to poor diet, stress and drinking too much alcohol. Changes to your diet and lifestyle may help improve the condition of your hair.

Question (100 words): Where can I find more information about scalp cooling and caring for my hair type?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can find more information about scalp cooling and caring for your specific hair type at coldcap.com and cancerhaircare.co.uk. These resources provide detailed guides and videos to help you prepare for and manage hair loss during treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can find more information about scalp cooling and caring for your hair type at coldcap.com

Question (100 words): What support is available for emotional and practical help with hair loss?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The charity Cancer Hair Care offers further information and support to help people prepare for and manage hair loss. You can visit their website at cancerhaircare.co.uk for more resources and videos on scalp cooling and hair care. Additionally, speaking to your treatment team or local cancer information centre can provide more information about services available in your area.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The charity Cancer Hair Care has further information to help people prepare for hair loss (cancerhaircare.co.uk).

Question (100 words): What should I do if my hospital wig fitting service can't match my hair type?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If your hospital wig fitting service or local wig supplier is unable to offer you a wig that matches your hair type and texture, you may need to find a specialist wig fitter. Your breast care nurse or treatment team may be able to offer information on what is available in your area. For further support and advice, you can contact Cancer Hair Care or Cancer Black Care.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If your hospital wig fitting service or local wig supplier is unable to offer you a wig that matches your hair type and texture, you may need to find a specialist wig fitter.

Question (100 words): What are the differences between synthetic and real hair wigs?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Synthetic wigs are light, easy to care for, often pre-styled, and can be washed and left to drip dry. They are also cheaper, costing between £50 and £200. Wigs made from real hair can last longer but need more careful handling, professional cleaning, and restyling, and cost between £200 and £2,000.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Synthetic wigs are light and easy to care for. They’re often pre-styled and can be washed and left to drip dry. They’re also cheaper than real hair wigs.

Question (100 words): Can wigs be professionally styled to look more natural?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, wigs can be cut and styled by trained hair professionals to look more natural and feel more personal. It’s important to check that your hairdresser or wig specialist has experience in cutting wigs.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Wigs can be cut and styled to make them look more natural and feel more personal.

Question (100 words): How should I wear my wig to ensure it fits snugly?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your wig should fit snugly and shouldn’t move around your head. If you’re worried about it falling off, secure it with hypoallergenic double-sided tape. If it feels hot and itchy, you can wear a thin cotton lining or skullcap under your wig.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your wig should fit snugly and shouldn’t move around your head.

Question (100 words): What should I avoid doing with a synthetic wig?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Avoid excessive heat or steam if you have a synthetic wig as it can damage the wig. Don’t get too close to flames as this can melt synthetic hair or damage real hair.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Avoid excessive heat or steam if you have a synthetic wig as it can damage the wig.

Question (100 words): How long will an 'off-the-shelf' wig last if worn every day?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you have an 'off-the-shelf' wig and wear it every day, it will last about three to four months. After that, the elastic gets looser and this affects the fit, although it may be possible to replace the elastic.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have an ‘off-the-shelf’ wig and wear it every day it will last about three to four months.

Question (100 words): What are some alternatives to wearing a wig?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Some people choose not to wear a wig. Hats, headscarves, and turbans can be found in a wide variety of styles and colours and can help you feel more confident about the way you look. They can also keep you warm in winter and protect your head from the sun in summer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some people choose not to wear a wig. Whether or not you wear a wig, there may be times when you want to cover your head.

Question (100 words): What type of fabric is best for headscarves?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The most comfortable headscarves are made from a natural fabric that is gentle on the scalp and allows it to breathe. Soft cotton is probably best, as satin and silk materials can slide off the head more easily.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The most comfortable headscarves are made from a natural fabric that are gentle on the scalp and allow it to breathe.

Question (100 words): How do I tie a basic headscarf?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To tie a basic headscarf, lay a square headscarf flat with the underside facing up. Fold the headscarf diagonally into a triangle. Place the headscarf on your head with the folded edge about 2.5cm below your natural hairline and the points at the back. Tie the outer points into a double knot behind your head over the middle triangle point.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: 1. Lay a square headscarf flat with the underside facing up. Fold the headscarf diagonally into a triangle.2. Place the headscarf on your head with the folded edge about 2.5cm below your natural hairline and the points at the back.3. Tie the outer points into a double knot behind your head over the middle triangle point.

Question (100 words): What can I do to give more height and a better head shape with a headscarf?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To give more height and a better head shape with a headscarf, you can scrunch or pleat the long edge of the headscarf, roll the edge of the headscarf around a 25cm long foam tube before putting it on your head, or place a foam shoulder pad on the crown of your head under the headscarf and attach it with double-sided tape.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: To give more height and a better head shape you can: • Scrunch or pleat the long edge of the headscarf • Roll the edge of the headscarf around a 25cm long foam tube (such as a finger bandage) before putting it on your head • Place a foam shoulder pad on the crown of your head under the headscarf.

Question (100 words): What are some tips for creating a twisted headband?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To create a twisted headband, twist the long ends separately, bring them forward and tie them at the front of your head, continue twisting and tucking the ends in around your head, and at the back, twist the short end and tuck it in. You may find it helps to twist one end at a time and secure it with a hairgrip, paperclip, or elastic band while you twist the other one.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: 1. Twist the long ends seperately.2. Bring them forward and tie them at the front of your head.3. Continue twisting and tucking the ends in around your head.4. At the back, twist the short end and tuck it in.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I lose my eyelashes due to chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you lose your eyelashes, your eyes may get sore easily. If your eyes become irritated, ask your treatment team for some eye drops to help reduce the soreness. You can use eyeliner to draw along the top of your eyelid to give the illusion of lashes. If your eyes aren’t feeling sore or sensitive, you may want to try false eyelashes.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you lose your eyelashes, your eyes may get sore easily. If your eyes become irritated ask your treatment team for some eye drops to help reduce the soreness.

Question (100 words): How can I recreate the appearance of my eyebrows if I lose them?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you lose your eyebrows or they are thinner, you can recreate a natural appearance by using eyebrow makeup in a shade that matches your original hair colour. You can also use stick-on eyebrows or have your eyebrow shape recreated with semi-permanent makeup techniques like micropigmentation or microblading.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you lose your eyebrows or they are thinner, you may be very conscious of how this changes the way you look. You can recreate a natural appearance by using eyebrow makeup in a shade that matches your original hair colour.

Question (100 words): What should I avoid if I’ve lost hair under my arms?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Avoid highly perfumed deodorants if you’ve lost hair under your arms, as they can irritate the skin.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Avoid highly perfumed deodorants if you’ve lost hair under your arms, as they can irritate the skin.

Question (100 words): Where can I find quick and simple makeup video tutorials for people dealing with hair loss?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can find quick and simple makeup video tutorials for people dealing with hair loss and skin changes after breast cancer treatment on the Breast Cancer Now website at breastcancernow.org/makeup-tutorials.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can find quick and simple makeup video tutorials for people dealing with hair loss and skin changes after breast cancer treatment on our website breastcancernow.org/makeup-tutorials

Question (100 words): What is semi-permanent makeup and how long does it last?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Semi-permanent makeup, such as micropigmentation or microblading, involves a tattooing technique where colour (pigment) is implanted into the skin. It can last between two and three years, depending on your skin type.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Both micropigmentation and microblading are types of semi-permanent makeup. Both use a tattooing technique where colour (pigment) is implanted into the skin.

Question (100 words): What are some ways to change the emphasis away from hair loss?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Some people feel more confident if attention is directed away from their hair and their head. This can be achieved with jewellery, makeup, or clothing.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some people feel more confident if attention is directed away from their hair and their head. There are a number of ways of doing this, such as with jewellery, makeup or clothing.

Question (100 words): What resources are available for advice on wearing headwear?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The organisation HeadWrappers offers advice, online support, video tutorials, and practical tips on wearing headwear. You can find more details at headwrappers.org.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The organisation HeadWrappers offers advice, online support, video tutorials and practical tips on wearing headwear.

Question (100 words): Where can I find suppliers of hats, turbans, and fringes?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can find a list of suppliers of hats, turbans, and fringes on the Breast Cancer Now website at breastcancernow.org/headwearsuppliers.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can find a list of suppliers of hats, turbans and fringes on our website at breastcancernow.org/headwearsuppliers

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience skin changes and sensitivity due to chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Boots, in partnership with Macmillan, offer trained beauty advisors who can give skincare and beauty advice for people having treatment for cancer. Visit boots.com/macmillan/feelmorelikeyou for more details.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Boots, in partnership with Macmillan, offer trained beauty advisors who can give skincare and beauty advice for people having treatment for cancer.

Question (100 words): What is microblading and how long does it last?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Microblading is a semi-permanent makeup technique done by hand to recreate the look of natural eyebrows. It usually lasts between one year and 18 months, depending on your skin type.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Microblading is done by hand and involves drawing precise hair strokes that recreate the look of natural eyebrows. The colour is not implanted as deep into the skin as micropigmentation, which means it doesn’t last as long. How long it lasts depends on your skin type but usually it will last between one year and 18 months.

Question (100 words): Are there any risks associated with getting semi-permanent makeup while on chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, there may be a risk of infection if you get semi-permanent makeup while undergoing chemotherapy. It is advisable to check with your treatment team before proceeding with such procedures.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you are currently having chemotherapy, there may be a risk of infection from having these procedures done.

Question (100 words): What is Look Good Feel Better and how can it help me?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Look Good Feel Better is an organization offering free workshops on hair care, skincare, and makeup to help manage the visible side effects of cancer treatment. They provide tips on redefining the eye area for those who have lost their eyebrows and eyelashes.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Look Good Feel Better is an organisation offering free hair care, skincare and makeup workshops to help women and men with the visible side effects of cancer treatment. This includes redefining the eye area for people who have lost their eyebrows and eyelashes.

Question (100 words): Will my hair grow back after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): For most people, hair usually starts to grow back once treatment is finished. It may initially be weak and fragile but will become stronger over time.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: For most people hair usually starts to grow back once their treatment is finished, and sometimes it may start to grow back before it’s finished. It may be weak and fragile or softer to begin with but over time the condition and texture of hair becomes stronger.

Question (100 words): Can hair grow back differently after treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, hair can sometimes grow back with a different color, texture, curliness, or straightness. This change may be temporary or permanent.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Hair can sometimes grow back differently to what it was like before treatment. For example: • The colour may change • The texture may be different • It may be curlier • It may be straighter This change may only be temporary but occasionally it will be permanent.

Question (100 words): How quickly does hair typically grow back after treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Hair regrowth varies from person to person, but most people will have a full covering of hair three to six months after treatment finishes. For some, it may be patchy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: How quickly hair regrows will vary from person to person but most people will have a full covering of hair three to six months after treatment finishes. For some people this may be patchy.

Question (100 words): Is there anything I can do to speed up hair regrowth?
Answer (Max 2000 words): There is limited evidence that a drug called minoxidil may help when applied to the scalp. You should consult your GP, a dermatologist, or a trichologist about this option.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There is limited evidence that a drug called minoxidil may help when applied to the scalp. Minoxidil can also be found in some hair loss treatments. You can talk to your GP, a dermatologist (doctor who specialises in skin problems) or a trichologist (person who specialises in hair loss problems but is not medically trained) about the possibility of using minoxidil.

Question (100 words): Can diet affect hair regrowth?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, a healthy, balanced diet provides all the nutrients needed for healthy hair. However, there is limited evidence supporting the use of supplements for hair growth.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The condition of our hair is strongly linked to lifestyle factors including diet. A healthy diet that is balanced and varied provides all the nutrients needed for healthy hair.

Question (100 words): Should I color my hair immediately after it grows back?
Answer (Max 2000 words): It’s best to wait until your hair is longer and in good condition before applying permanent hair color. Cancer Hair Care recommends waiting until at least an inch (2.5cm) of hair has grown.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s best to wait until your hair is longer and your hair and scalp are in good condition before applying permanent hair colour. Although there is limited research in this area Cancer Hair Care recommends you allow at least an inch (2.5cm) of hair to grow before colouring it, so you can be sure the hair is of a good quality.

Question (100 words): Can I use temporary or semi-permanent dyes to test hair color?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, temporary or semi-permanent dyes are a good way to find out if a hair color suits you before trying a permanent color.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Temporary or semi-permanent dyes are a good way to find out if a hair colour suits you before you try a permanent colour.

Question (100 words): Is hair loss from chemotherapy always temporary?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Hair loss from chemotherapy is almost always temporary, but some drugs like taxanes may cause long-lasting or permanent hair loss.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Hair loss caused by chemotherapy is almost always temporary. However, there is evidence that some chemotherapy drugs may result in long lasting or permanent hair loss.

Question (100 words): What happens to hair after radiotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After radiotherapy, hair in the treated area may grow back thinner, patchy, or may not grow back at all, depending on the dose and number of treatments.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: After radiotherapy, any hair that you have lost from the treated area will usually grow back (see page 45). However, the hair may grow back thinner, patchy or may not grow back at all. This will depend on the dose of radiotherapy and the number of treatments you’ve had.

Question (100 words): Can hormone therapy cause hair loss?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, hormone therapy may cause some hair loss and thinning. Hair should return to its previous state after treatment ends, though this may take time.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some people continue taking hormone therapy for up to ten years, which may cause some hair loss and hair thinning. Once you finish this treatment your hair should return to how it was before treatment (see page 45). However, this may take time and for some people hair may not fully return to the same thickness.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience long-term hair loss after treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You may wish to consult a specialist such as a dermatologist or trichologist for advice. Organizations like Alopecia UK can also provide support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If hair loss after treatment persists, you may wish to ask for advice from a specialist. Your treatment team or GP may be able to refer you to a dermatologist (doctor who specialises in skin problems) who has a specialist interest in managing hair loss.

Question (100 words): What are some options for camouflaging long-lasting hair loss?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Options include semi-permanent makeup like micropigmentation, hair concealers, and hair replacement systems.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Camouflaging long lasting hair loss or thinning Semi-permanent makeup Micropigmentation can be used on the scalp, eyes and eyebrows to recreate the illusion of hair. Microblading is another technique that can be used to create the illusion of eyebrows.

Question (100 words): Where can I find support for dealing with hair loss?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast Cancer Now offers various support services including a Helpline, Someone Like Me service, online community forums, and local courses or support groups.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast Cancer Now has a number of services to help support you: • Speak to our nurses or trained experts by calling our Helpline on 0808 800 6000 (Monday to Friday 9am–4pm and Saturday 9am–1pm) • When you’re facing breast cancer treatment and hair loss, it can help to talk it through with someone who’s been there too. Call our Someone Like Me service on 0114 263 6490 • You can also chat to other people who understand what you’re going through in our friendly community for support day and night.

Question (100 words): How can I find my local cancer information center?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can find your local cancer information center through the NHS website at nhs.uk/service-search.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can find your local cancer information centre through the NHS website at nhs.uk/service-search

Question (100 words): What should I consider before getting semi-permanent makeup?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Ensure you choose a reliable provider with good recommendations, especially one that specializes in hair loss. A skin-sensitivity test (patch test) should be done at least 24 hours before the procedure.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: As the results are semi-permanent, make sure you choose a reliable provider that has good recommendations. You may want to look for a provider that specialises in hair loss. The provider should do a skin-sensitivity test (patch test), usually a minimum of 24 hours before having any semi-permanent makeup.

Question (100 words): Can applying bimatoprost help with eyelash regrowth?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, studies have shown that applying bimatoprost to the eyelids may improve the regrowth of eyelashes. Consult your GP, a trichologist, or a dermatologist about this option.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Studies have also shown that applying the drug bimatoprost to the eyelids may improve the regrowth of eyelashes. You can talk to your GP, a trichologist or a dermatologist about whether this is an option for you.

Question (100 words): What are the common side effects of hair regrowth after treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common side effects include hair that may initially be weak, fragile, or have a different texture, color, or pattern. These changes may be temporary or permanent.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: For most people hair usually starts to grow back once their treatment is finished, and sometimes it may start to grow back before it’s finished. It may be weak and fragile or softer to begin with but over time the condition and texture of hair becomes stronger.

Question (100 words): What organizations can I contact for support with hair loss due to breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can contact several organizations for support with hair loss due to breast cancer treatment. These include Alopecia UK, British Hair and Nail Society, Cancer Black Care, Cancer Hair Care, Fruitfly Collective, Institute of Trichologists, Look Good Feel Better, and HeadWrappers. Each organization offers different types of support, from information and advice to practical resources and emotional support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Useful organisations Hair loss support Alopecia UK – alopecia.org.uk British Hair and Nail Society – bhns.org.uk Cancer Black Care – cancerblackcare.org.uk Cancer Hair Care – cancerhaircare.co.uk Fruitfly Collective – parents.fruitflycollective.com Institute of Trichologists – trichologists.org.uk Look Good Feel Better – lookgoodfeelbetter.co.uk

Question (100 words): Where can I find headwear designed for people experiencing hair loss?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can find headwear designed for people experiencing hair loss on the Breast Cancer Now website. They list organizations that supply headwear tailored to meet the needs of individuals with hair loss. Additionally, suppliers like Chemo Hair Loss Coach, Lucinda Ellery, My New Hair, and HeadWrappers offer specialized headwear and practical tips.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The Breast Cancer Now website lists organisations who supply headwear designed to meet the needs of people experiencing hair loss.

Question (100 words): Are there any online resources for children to understand hair loss due to cancer?
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Fruitfly Collective – a website to support parents who have cancer. They have resources and special kits to help with difficult conversations and to help children understand what cancer is.

Question (100 words): Can I get financial support for the cost of a wig?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, Macmillan Cancer Support provides specialist information and financial support to people with cancer, including one-off grants that can be used towards the cost of a wig.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Macmillan Cancer Support – macmillan.org.uk  0808 808 0000 Provides specialist information and financial support to people with cancer, including one-off grants that can be used towards the cost of a wig.

Question (100 words): Where can I find real hair wigs for children who have lost their hair due to cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The Little Princess Trust provides real hair wigs to boys and girls across the UK and Ireland who have lost their hair through cancer treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Little Princess Trust – littleprincesses.org.uk Provides real hair wigs to boys and girls across the UK and Ireland that have lost their own hair through cancer treatment.

Question (100 words): What is Wig Bank and how can it help me?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Wig Bank is a charity that collects wigs people no longer need, cleans them, and sells them at a discounted rate. There are Wig Bank services available in different parts of the UK, making wigs more accessible and affordable for those in need.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Wig Bank – wigbank.com Wig bank is a charity that collects wigs people no longer need, cleans them and sells them at a discounted rate.

Question (100 words): How can I recycle my wig or headscarf to help others?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Twice as nice, run by Cancer Hair Care, recycles wigs and headscarves that are no longer needed. They clean them and give them to others when needed, ensuring that resources are reused effectively.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Twice as nice – cancerhaircare.co.uk Twice as nice, run by Cancer Hair Care, recycles wigs and headscarves that are no longer needed.

Question (100 words): What support does Black Women Rising offer for Black people affected by breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Black Women Rising provides support for Black people affected by breast cancer, from awareness to diagnosis, treatment, and life after treatment. They offer a platform to showcase stories and provide vital support throughout the cancer journey.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Black Women Rising – blackwomenrisinguk.org A platform to showcase the stories and provide vital support for Black people affected by breast cancer.

Question (100 words): How can I access professionally run skincare and makeup workshops for women with cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Look Good Feel Better offers professionally run skincare and makeup workshops in hospitals and cancer support centers around the country for women living with cancer. Their website and workshops include practical tips for women who have lost their eyelashes and eyebrows.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Look Good Feel Better – lookgoodfeelbetter.co.uk Offers professionally run skincare and makeup workshops in hospitals and cancer support centres around the country for women living with cancer.

Question (100 words): Where can I find a directory of qualified trichologists?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The Institute of Trichologists includes a directory of qualified trichologists. This resource can help you find a professional who specializes in hair and scalp conditions.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Institute of Trichologists – trichologists.org.uk A professional association of trichologists. Includes a directory of qualified trichologists.

Question (100 words): What is the Confidence Kit from Look Good Feel Better?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The Confidence Kit from Look Good Feel Better includes a DVD and booklet full of tips for women living with cancer. It can be ordered from their online shop and provides practical advice and support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can also order a ‘Confidence Kit’ from their online shop, which includes a DVD and booklet full of tips.

Question (100 words): How can I order free resources like hair loss dollies for children?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can order free resources such as hair loss dollies for children from Chemo Hair Loss Coach. These resources are designed to help children understand and cope with hair loss due to cancer treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Chemo Hair Loss Coach – chemohairlosscoach.com An online supplier of hair loss products such as headwear and fringes specifically for people with cancer-related hair loss and new growth. You can also order free resources such as hair loss dollies for children.

Question (100 words): What solutions does Lucinda Ellery offer for managing hair loss?

Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Lucinda Ellery – lucindaellery-hairloss.co.uk A company offering solutions for managing hair loss and thinning. They specialise in permanent hair loss solutions and hair loss caused by cancer treatment.

Question (100 words): Where can I find a wig styling service for people with cancer-related hair loss?
Answer (Max 2000 words): My New Hair lists a national network of independent salons and professionals who offer a wig styling service for people suffering from cancer and medical hair loss.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: My New Hair – mynewhair.org Lists a national network of independent salons and professionals who offer a wig styling service for people suffering from cancer and medical hair loss.

Question (100 words): How can I support Breast Cancer Now’s work?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can support Breast Cancer Now’s vital care and research work by visiting breastcancernow.org/give to make a voluntary donation or include a gift in your will.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast Cancer Now is a charity that relies on voluntary donations and gifts in wills.

Question (100 words): What is the purpose of the Living with Secondary Breast Cancer online course?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The Living with Secondary Breast Cancer online course contains videos and support for secondary breast cancer and hair loss, providing valuable resources and community support for those affected.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: For people with secondary breast cancer, you can register for our Living with Secondary Breast Cancer online course. This course contains videos and support for secondary breast cancer and hair loss.

Question (100 words): How can I contact Breast Cancer Now for more information or support?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can contact Breast Cancer Now by calling their Helpline on 0808 800 6000 or visiting their website at breastcancernow.org for more information and support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Call our Helpline on 0808 800 6000 For breast cancer care, support and information, call us free on  0808 800 6000  or visit  breastcancernow.org

Question (100 words): Where can I find more copies of this booklet or other publications from Breast Cancer Now?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can order or download more copies of this booklet and other publications from Breast Cancer Now by visiting breastcancernow.org/publications.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can order or download more copies from breastcancernow.org/publications

Question (100 words): How can I provide feedback on this publication?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can provide feedback on this publication by emailing health-info@breastcancernow.org. Your feedback helps improve the quality and relevance of their resources.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: We welcome your feedback on this publication:  health-info@breastcancernow.org

Question (100 words): What is secondary breast cancer in the brain?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Secondary breast cancer in the brain occurs when breast cancer cells spread to the brain. It is also known as metastatic breast cancer, advanced breast cancer, secondary tumors, or stage 4 breast cancer. This condition is different from primary brain cancer, as the cancer originates in the breast and spreads to the brain through the lymphatic system or blood.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Secondary breast cancer in the brain happens when cancer that started in the breast has spread to the brain. The cells that have spread to the brain are breast cancer cells. It’s not the same as having cancer that starts in the brain.

Question (100 words): What are the common symptoms of secondary breast cancer in the brain?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common symptoms include headaches, nausea and vomiting, weakness or numbness down one side of the body, unsteadiness or loss of balance, seizures, difficulty with speech, vision problems, changes in behavior or mood, confusion, and memory problems. These symptoms vary depending on the affected area of the brain.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Symptoms will depend on which area of the brain is affected. This is because different parts of the brain are responsible for different functions in the body.

Question (100 words): What tests are used to diagnose secondary breast cancer in the brain?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Tests may include a neurological examination, CT (computerized tomography) scan, MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) scan, brain biopsy, and blood tests. These tests help determine the presence, location, and extent of the cancer in the brain.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your treatment team will examine you and discuss any symptoms you have. You may need 1 or more of the following tests to help diagnose secondary breast cancer in the brain.

Question (100 words): How is secondary breast cancer in the brain treated?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Treatment options include steroids to reduce swelling, radiotherapy to destroy cancer cells, surgery to remove tumors, hormone (endocrine) therapy, targeted therapy, and chemotherapy. The choice of treatment depends on various factors such as the number and location of tumors, symptoms, past treatments, and overall health.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Treatment for secondary breast cancer in the brain aims to relieve symptoms, slow down the growth of the cancer, and give you the best quality of life for as long as possible.

Question (100 words): What is the role of steroids in treating secondary breast cancer in the brain?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Steroids, such as dexamethasone, are used to reduce swelling and pressure caused by the growth of secondary breast cancer in the brain. They can also relieve symptoms like headaches and nausea. Steroids are usually taken as tablets and the dose is gradually reduced once symptoms are controlled.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Steroid drugs, such as dexamethasone, can reduce swelling and pressure caused by the growth of secondary breast cancer in the brain or its treatment (such as radiotherapy). They can also relieve symptoms such as headaches and nausea.

Question (100 words): What are the side effects of steroids used in treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common side effects of steroids include sleeplessness, indigestion, infections like thrush, increased appetite, mood swings, weight gain, muscle weakness, restlessness, skin changes, diabetes, blood clots, and a swollen or puffy face. Taking steroids with food and earlier in the day can help mitigate some side effects.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some of the more common side effects of steroids in high doses are: Sleeplessness, when taken later in the day; Indigestion, when taken on an empty stomach; Infections including thrush (candidiasis) in the mouth; Increased appetite; Mood swings; Weight gain; Muscle weakness; Feeling restless or agitated; Skin changes; Diabetes; Blood clots; Swollen or puffy face.

Question (100 words): What is stereotactic radiosurgery or radiotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Stereotactic radiosurgery or radiotherapy is a precise radiation treatment that delivers high doses of radiation to targeted areas of the brain with extreme accuracy, avoiding healthy brain tissue. It is often used for single or small areas of secondary cancer in the brain and can be given as a single treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Stereotactic radiosurgery or radiotherapy is a very precise radiation treatment. It may be considered if you have a single area of secondary cancer or a few small areas of secondary cancer in the brain.

Question (100 words): What is whole brain radiotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Whole brain radiotherapy uses high-energy x-rays to treat the entire brain. It is commonly used to treat multiple areas of secondary breast cancer in the brain. It may cause more side effects compared to stereotactic radiosurgery due to its broader impact on brain tissue.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Radiotherapy is the most common treatment for secondary breast cancer in the brain. It uses high energy x-rays to destroy cancer cells. You may have it as Stereotactic radiosurgery or radiotherapy or Whole brain radiotherapy.

Question (100 words): How does secondary breast cancer spread to the brain?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Secondary breast cancer spreads to the brain through the lymphatic system or the blood. Cancer cells from the breast travel to the brain, where they form new tumors. This process can occur months or years after the primary breast cancer diagnosis.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast cancer cells can spread to the brain through the lymphatic system or the blood.

Question (100 words): What is the prognosis for secondary breast cancer in the brain?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The prognosis for secondary breast cancer in the brain varies and depends on factors such as the extent of cancer in the body, the areas affected, and the features of the breast cancer. While it cannot be cured, improved treatments mean many people are living longer after diagnosis.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: When breast cancer spreads to the brain, it can be treated but cannot be cured. As treatments have improved, more and more people are living longer after their diagnosis, including lots of people with a diagnosis of secondary breast cancer in the brain.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience new symptoms?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Report any new or ongoing symptoms to your GP, breast care nurse, or treatment team. Symptoms to watch for include headaches, nausea, weakness, unsteadiness, seizures, speech difficulties, vision problems, behavioral changes, confusion, and memory issues.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Report any new or ongoing symptoms to your GP, breast care nurse or treatment team, including: Headache; Feeling sick (nausea) and being sick (vomiting); Weakness or feeling numb down 1 side of the body; Unsteadiness or loss of balance and coordination; Fits (seizures); Difficulty with speech; Problems with vision; Changes in behaviour, mood or personality; Confusion; Memory problems.

Question (100 words): Can secondary breast cancer in the brain be cured?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Secondary breast cancer in the brain cannot be cured, but it can be treated to relieve symptoms, slow down the growth of the cancer, and improve quality of life. Treatment aims to manage the condition effectively.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: When breast cancer spreads to the brain, it can be treated but cannot be cured.

Question (100 words): What is a brain biopsy and when is it needed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A brain biopsy involves removing a small piece of tissue from the brain under general anesthesia to confirm the diagnosis of secondary breast cancer. It is rarely needed as symptoms and scans usually provide enough information for diagnosis.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: In most cases, your treatment team will be able to tell if you have secondary breast cancer in the brain from your symptoms and scans. Very occasionally you may need a biopsy to confirm the diagnosis.

Question (100 words): What is leptomeningeal metastases and how is it treated?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Leptomeningeal metastases occur when breast cancer spreads to the tissues and fluid surrounding the brain and spinal cord. Treatment may include steroids, radiotherapy, and chemotherapy, sometimes administered directly into the fluid surrounding the brain and spinal cord.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Sometimes breast cancer spreads to tissues and fluid that surround the brain and spinal cord. This is known as leptomeningeal metastases. Treatment can include steroids, radiotherapy and chemotherapy.

Question (100 words): Who will be part of my treatment team for secondary breast cancer in the brain?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your treatment team will include your usual breast treatment team and the neuro-oncology multidisciplinary team (MDT), which specializes in treating brain tumors. This team includes neurosurgeons, neuro-oncologists, clinical nurse specialists, and radiographers.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your care will continue under your usual breast treatment team. They will often ask the advice of the neuro-oncology multidisciplinary team (MDT). This team specialises in treating tumours in the brain and includes neurosurgeons, neuro-oncologists, clinical nurse specialists and radiographers.

Question (100 words): What questions should I ask my treatment team about my care?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You may want to ask about the aim of treatment, your treatment options, risks and benefits, possible side effects, referrals to specialists, what to do if you get new symptoms, and whether your case has been discussed in an MDT meeting. You can also ask for a specialist nurse to explain your plan.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may want to ask your treatment team about: The aim of treatment; Your treatment options and why they’re recommending a particular drug or procedure; Whether there are any additional options for you, including new procedures or treatment at other hospitals or cancer centres; Whether there are any clinical trials you could take part in; The risks and benefits of each treatment; The possible side effects of your treatment and what you can do to help manage them; Whether a referral to a speciali

Question (100 words): Why is it important not to stop taking steroids suddenly?
Answer (Max 2000 words): It is important not to stop taking steroids suddenly because your body will have adjusted to the medication and produces less of its natural steroids. Stopping suddenly can cause your body to go into shock. The dose must be gradually reduced.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s very important not to stop taking steroids suddenly. If you take steroids for more than a few days, your body will start to produce less of the natural steroids that it needs to function. When you stop taking steroid medication, your body has to readjust. The dose must be gradually reduced, rather than stopping them suddenly.

Question (100 words): What is the purpose of a blue steroid card?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The blue steroid card is given to patients who take steroids for more than three weeks. It serves as a reminder to healthcare providers about the patient's steroid use, especially in emergency situations or when seeking dental care.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: In the UK, if you take steroids for more than 3 weeks you will be given a blue steroid card. Always keep hold of the card and show it to any doctor or nurse treating you. You should also tell your dentist that you are taking steroids if you need to have any dental work done.

Question (100 words): How can I manage the side effects of steroids?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To manage side effects, take steroids earlier in the day to avoid sleeplessness, and with food to prevent indigestion. Your treatment team can provide additional support, such as referring you to a dietitian if you’re concerned about weight gain.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Taking steroids earlier in the day can help prevent sleeplessness at night. Taking them with food at breakfast and lunchtime will help avoid side effects like indigestion. You will usually be given another tablet to protect your stomach lining.

Question (100 words): What is the difference between stereotactic radiosurgery and whole brain radiotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Stereotactic radiosurgery is a precise radiation treatment that targets specific areas of the brain with high doses of radiation, causing fewer side effects. Whole brain radiotherapy treats the entire brain and may cause more side effects due to its broader impact on brain tissue.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Stereotactic radiosurgery or radiotherapy is a very precise radiation treatment. It may be considered if you have a single area of secondary cancer or a few small areas of secondary cancer in the brain. High doses of radiation are delivered with extreme accuracy to targeted areas, avoiding healthy brain tissue. Because of this, stereotactic radiosurgery causes fewer side effects than whole brain radiotherapy.

Question (100 words): What are the common side effects of radiotherapy for secondary breast cancer in the brain?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common side effects of radiotherapy include fatigue, which is extreme tiredness that doesn’t go away with sleep, and hair loss. Hair usually starts to grow back 2 to 3 months after treatment has finished, although it may not grow back completely or evenly. Radiotherapy can also cause changes to the brain tissue, leading to problems thinking clearly, difficulty managing tasks, and poor memory or confusion. These symptoms will settle over time for many people, and an occupational therapist can help manage everyday tasks.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Fatigue is a common side effect of radiotherapy, especially after radiotherapy to the brain. Hair loss is another common side effect. Hair usually starts to grow back 2 to 3 months after treatment has finished, although it may not grow back completely or evenly. Whole brain radiotherapy can cause changes to the brain tissue. You may have problems thinking clearly, difficulty managing tasks you previously found easy, and poor memory or confusion.

Question (100 words): When might surgery be recommended for secondary breast cancer in the brain?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Surgery might be recommended if there is a single or very few areas of cancer in the brain that the surgeon can safely operate on. It may also be considered if the cancer is causing pressure on the brain. Surgery is more likely if it will improve your quality of life, considering your general health and fitness, and whether secondary breast cancer is affecting other areas of your body.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Although it will not cure secondary breast cancer in the brain, your treatment team might recommend surgery to remove the area or areas of cancer. Surgery is more likely if there is a single or very few areas of cancer in the brain that the surgeon can safely operate on. It may also be considered if the cancer is causing pressure on the brain.

Question (100 words): What is stereotactic radiotherapy and where can it be performed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Stereotactic radiotherapy is a specialist treatment that delivers high doses of radiation to a small, precise area. It’s not available in all hospitals, so you may need to travel to a different cancer center to have it.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Stereotactic radiotherapy is a specialist treatment that’s not available in all hospitals, so you may need to travel to a different cancer centre to have it.

Question (100 words): What is whole brain radiotherapy and when is it used?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Whole brain radiotherapy is given to the entire brain and is used if there are several areas of secondary breast cancer in different parts of the brain, or if you have leptomeningeal metastases. It may also be given after surgery or stereotactic radiosurgery. It’s usually administered in daily doses over 1 to 10 days, though this can vary.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Whole brain radiotherapy may be given to the whole brain if there are several areas of secondary breast cancer in different parts of the brain, or if you have leptomeningeal metastases (see page 10). Whole brain radiotherapy may also be given after surgery or stereotactic radiosurgery.

Question (100 words): How can fatigue from radiotherapy be managed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Fatigue from radiotherapy can be managed by ensuring adequate rest, pacing activities, and seeking support from healthcare professionals. An occupational therapist can also help manage everyday tasks. For more detailed information, refer to the Secondary breast cancer information pack.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Fatigue is a common side effect of radiotherapy, especially after radiotherapy to the brain. Fatigue is extreme tiredness that doesn’t go away with sleep.

Question (100 words): What are the side effects of hormone (endocrine) therapy for breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The side effects of hormone therapy can vary depending on the specific drug used. Common side effects may include hot flashes, joint pain, mood changes, and vaginal dryness. It’s important to discuss any side effects with your treatment team, as they can offer strategies to manage them.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Hormone therapies block or stop the effect of oestrogen on breast cancer cells. Different hormone therapy drugs do this in different ways.

Question (100 words): What are the commonly used hormone therapy drugs for breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Commonly used hormone therapy drugs include Aromatase inhibitors (anastrozole, exemestane, and letrozole), Fulvestrant (Faslodex), Goserelin (Zoladex), Leuprorelin (Prostap), and Tamoxifen. Your treatment team may prescribe the same drug again or change it to a different one based on your specific situation.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The most commonly used hormone therapy drugs are: • Aromatase inhibitors (anastrozole, exemestane and letrozole) • Fulvestrant (Faslodex) • Goserelin (Zoladex) • Leuprorelin (Prostap) • Tamoxifen

Question (100 words): What is HER2-positive breast cancer and how is it treated?
Answer (Max 2000 words): HER2-positive breast cancer has a higher-than-normal level of a protein called HER2 on the cancer cell surface, which makes the cancer grow more quickly. Treatment includes targeted therapies such as Pertuzumab (Perjeta), Trastuzumab, Pertuzumab and trastuzumab combined (Phesgo), Trastuzumab deruxtecan (Enhertu), Trastuzumab emtansine (Kadcyla), and Tucatinib (Tukysa). These may be given together with other treatments.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some breast cancer cells have a higher-than-normal level of a protein called HER2 on their surface, which makes them grow more quickly. This is known as HER2-positive breast cancer. Targeted therapies for HER2-positive breast cancer include: • Pertuzumab (Perjeta) • Trastuzumab • Pertuzamab and trastuzumab combined (Phesgo) • Trastuzumab deruxtecan (Enhertu) • Trastuzumab emtansine (Kadcyla) • Tucatinib (Tukysa)

Question (100 words): What are the targeted therapies used for HER2-negative, ER-positive breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Targeted therapies for HER2-negative, ER-positive breast cancer include Abemaciclib (Verzenios), Alpelisib (Piqray), Everolimus (Afinitor), Palbociclib (Ibrance), and Ribociclib (Kisqali). These are usually taken alongside hormone therapy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some targeted therapies are used to treat HER2-negative, ER-positive breast cancer. These are usually taken alongside hormone therapy. These include: •  Abemaciclib (Verzenios) • Alpelisib (Piqray) •  Everolimus (Afinitor) •  Palbociclib (Ibrance) •  Ribociclib (Kisqali)

Question (100 words): What chemotherapy drugs are used to treat secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Several chemotherapy drugs are used to treat secondary breast cancer, including those given alone or in combination with other treatments such as targeted therapies. The specific drugs offered will depend on various factors, including any previous chemotherapy and how long ago it was administered.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Several chemotherapy drugs are used to treat secondary breast cancer. These drugs may be given alone or in combination with other treatments, such as targeted therapies.

Question (100 words): How can I find clinical trials for secondary breast cancer?
