Answer (Max 2000 words): You can find listings of current trials on the Cancer Research UK website (cancerresearch.org.uk) and on the National Institute for Health Research (NIHR) website (bepartofresearch.nihr.ac.uk). Additionally, Make 2nds Count, a charity that supports research into secondary breast cancer, also has a list of trials on its website make2ndscount.co.uk.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can also find listings of current trials on the Cancer Research UK website (cancerresearch.org.uk) and on the National Institute for Health Research (NIHR) website (bepartofresearch.nihr.ac.uk). Make 2nds Count, a charity that supports research into secondary breast cancer, also has a list of trials on its website make2ndscount.co.uk

Question (100 words): What is palliative and supportive care, and who can benefit from it?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Palliative and supportive care focuses on symptom control and support, aiming to improve the quality of life for people with secondary breast cancer and their families. It can be beneficial at any stage of the illness, alongside medical treatment, helping to prevent and relieve symptoms like pain or fatigue, and addressing emotional, social, and spiritual effects.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Palliative and supportive care are extremely important for many people with secondary breast cancer and can significantly improve quality of life for them and their families. This type of care focuses on symptom control and support.

Question (100 words): How are fits (seizures) managed in secondary breast cancer patients?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Seizures may be managed with epilepsy drugs prescribed by your doctor, usually taken as tablets. It’s important to inform your GP or treatment team if you start having seizures, as they can have different causes.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have seizures, your doctor may prescribe epilepsy drugs to keep them under control. You usually take them as tablets.

Question (100 words): What can be done to manage nausea and vomiting in secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Nausea and vomiting can be managed with anti-sickness drugs, steroids, or benzodiazepines. Keeping a record of what makes it worse or when it happens can help your treatment team decide the best treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: In most cases, nausea and vomiting can be controlled and treated with anti-sickness drugs, steroids or benzodiazepines.

Question (100 words): How is pain managed in secondary breast cancer patients?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Pain is managed with steroids and pain relief medications. It’s important to have your pain assessed regularly by your specialist nurse, treatment team, or GP to ensure it stays under control. Recording your pain in a pain diary can help your doctor decide how to control it.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Steroids and pain relief can control most pain. But it’s very important your pain is assessed regularly by your specialist nurse, treatment team or GP to make sure it stays under control.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I suspect I have a blood clot?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you suspect you have a blood clot, contact your treatment team or go to your local A&E department immediately. Symptoms include pain, redness or discolouration of the skin, heat or swelling of the arm or leg, swelling, redness or tenderness where a central line is inserted, shortness of breath or a sudden increase in breathlessness, pain or tightness in the chest, unexplained cough or coughing up blood.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Contact your treatment team or go to your local A&E department straight away if you have any of the following symptoms: • Pain, redness or discolouration of the skin, heat or swelling of the arm or leg • Swelling, redness or tenderness where a central line is inserted to give chemotherapy, for example in the arm, chest area or up into the neck • Shortness of breath or a sudden increase in breathlessness • Pain or tightness in the chest • Unexplained cough or coughing up blood

Question (100 words): What is the blood-brain barrier and how does it affect treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The blood-brain barrier is a natural filter that protects the brain from harmful chemicals, allowing only certain substances to pass from the blood to the brain tissues. Because of this barrier, some drugs may not be as effective in treating secondary breast cancer in the brain as they are in other parts of the body. Your treatment team can discuss this with you.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The blood–brain barrier is a natural filter that protects the brain from harmful chemicals. It only allows certain substances to pass from the blood to the brain tissues. Because of the blood–brain barrier some drugs may not be as effective in treating secondary breast cancer in the brain as they are in other parts of the body.

Question (100 words): What options are available if a treatment for secondary breast cancer is not routinely available on the NHS?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If a treatment is not routinely available on the NHS, you may still be able to access it through compassionate or early access schemes. You can ask your treatment team if any of these may be helpful to you and how you might access them. Macmillan Cancer Support also provides further information on this.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some treatments for secondary breast cancer may not be routinely available on the NHS. You may still be able to access these treatments in other ways, for example compassionate or early access schemes.

Question (100 words): How can complementary therapies help in managing symptoms of secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): When used alongside conventional drug treatment, some complementary therapies have been shown to be helpful in reducing symptoms such as stress and anxiety, which may make pain worse in people with cancer. Information about complementary therapies, relaxation, and wellbeing can be found on the Breast Cancer Now website.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: When used alongside conventional drug treatment, some complementary therapies have been shown to be helpful in reducing symptoms such as stress and anxiety, which may make pain worse in people with cancer.

Question (100 words): What is the role of an occupational therapist in managing secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): An occupational therapist can help you manage everyday tasks if you experience problems thinking clearly, difficulty managing tasks, and poor memory or confusion due to whole brain radiotherapy. Ask your treatment team or GP if you’d like to be referred.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: An occupational therapist can help you to manage everyday tasks. Ask your treatment team or GP if you’d like to be referred.

Question (100 words): Can I continue exercising if I have secondary breast cancer in the brain?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, you can continue exercising, even gently, during and between treatments. Studies show that physical activity can help you tolerate treatments better, reduce pain and sickness, improve sleep, and decrease fatigue. However, it's important to avoid activities that could put you at risk of injury, especially if you have symptoms like balance problems or seizures. Your treatment team can provide guidance on safe exercise options.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: People who exercise, even gently, during and between breast cancer treatments may tolerate them better. Other benefits include less pain, less sickness, improved sleep and less fatigue.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience symptoms like blurred vision or seizures?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience symptoms such as blurred vision, seizures, weakness, dizziness, or balance problems, it’s important to avoid activities that could put you at risk of injury. For example, if you have balance problems, using an exercise bike may be safer than cycling outdoors. If you have seizures, try to avoid exercising alone. Always consult your treatment team for personalized advice.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: While symptoms such as blurred vision, seizures, weakness, dizziness or balance problems may not stop you exercising, it’s important you do not put yourself at unnecessary risk of injury.

Question (100 words): How can a GP exercise referral programme help me?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A GP exercise referral programme can help you increase your activity levels and improve your health and wellbeing. Trained instructors can provide support and ensure that you exercise safely, especially if you have changes in your health due to secondary breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A GP exercise referral programme can help you increase your activity levels and improve health and wellbeing.

Question (100 words): Do I need to inform the DVLA about my secondary breast cancer in the brain?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, by law, you are required to inform the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) or the Driver and Vehicle Agency (DVA) in Northern Ireland if you have secondary cancer in the brain. This is because it could affect your ability to drive safely. You may need to give up your licence temporarily or permanently.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you drive, you are required by law to tell the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA, or DVA in Northern Ireland) that you have secondary cancer in the brain.

Question (100 words): What are the emotional impacts of having secondary breast cancer in the brain?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Knowing that your cancer has spread to your brain can cause a range of emotions, including isolation, fear, anxiety, anger, and depression. Giving up your driving licence can also impact your lifestyle and independence. It’s important to seek support from loved ones, professional support services, or Breast Cancer Now’s helpline for emotional support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Knowing your cancer has spread to your brain can cause all kinds of emotions. There may be times when you feel isolated, scared, anxious, angry or depressed.

Question (100 words): What support services are available for me if I have secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): There are various support services available, including professional support from specialist nurses, palliative care nurses, and counsellors. You can also join support groups, forums, and local cancer information centres. Breast Cancer Now offers a helpline, online resources, and face-to-face or online support groups.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can talk to your specialist nurse, palliative care nurse, hospice or home care specialist nurse. They will understand the specific needs of people with secondary cancer and will be able to help support you.

Question (100 words): Can I reapply for my driving licence after treatment for secondary breast cancer in the brain?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You may be able to reapply for your driving licence after a period of time if the areas of secondary cancer in the brain are under control. Check with the DVLA or DVA, and consult your treatment team or GP for advice on when you might be eligible to reapply.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may be able to reapply for your licence after a period of time if the areas of secondary cancer in the brain are under control.

Question (100 words): What practical help is available to me if I can no longer drive?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you can no longer drive, you may be able to access practical help such as transport services or financial support to help you get to hospital appointments. Ask your specialist nurse or local cancer information centre about available services.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can ask your specialist nurse or local cancer information centre about services or practical help that may be available, like transport or financial support to help you get to hospital appointments.

Question (100 words): How can professional support help me cope with secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Professional support from specialist nurses, palliative care nurses, counsellors, or psychotherapists can help you cope with the emotional and physical challenges of secondary breast cancer. They can provide pain and symptom control, emotional support, and arrange for you to talk to a mental health professional.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some people find professional support helpful. You can talk to your specialist nurse, palliative care nurse, hospice or home care specialist nurse.

Question (100 words): What resources does Breast Cancer Now offer for people with secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast Cancer Now offers a range of resources including a helpline, online information packs, support groups, forums, and local cancer information centres. These resources provide information, emotional support, and practical help for people living with secondary breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: For more information on exercise and general health and wellbeing, see our Secondary breast cancer information pack.

Question (100 words): How can I find local support for secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can find local support by contacting your local cancer information centre through your hospital. Speak to your specialist nurse or treatment team to learn about available local support services.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may be able to find other support in your area by contacting your local cancer information centre through your hospital.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I feel isolated or depressed due to my diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you feel isolated or depressed, seek support from your treatment team, specialist nurses, or mental health professionals. You can also join support groups, forums, or contact Breast Cancer Now’s helpline for emotional support and resources.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There may be times when you feel isolated, scared, anxious, angry or depressed.

Question (100 words): Is there a specific support group for younger women with secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, Breast Cancer Now offers a support group called Younger Women with Secondaries Together, which provides a safe space for women under 45 with secondary breast cancer to talk about their experiences and receive tailored information and support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Younger Women with Secondaries Together gives you the chance to meet other women under 45 with secondary breast cancer.

Question (100 words): How can I access Breast Cancer Now’s forum for support?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can access Breast Cancer Now’s forum by signing up at forum.breastcancernow.org. The forum allows you to talk about your experiences in a safe, confidential space with people who understand what you’re going through.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Thousands of people affected by breast cancer use our forum, and they’re always ready to listen, share and support each other.

Question (100 words): What are the benefits of physical activity for people with secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Physical activity can help people with secondary breast cancer tolerate treatments better, reduce pain and sickness, improve sleep, decrease fatigue, and improve mood. Even gentle exercise can provide these benefits.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Studies have shown it has benefits for people with primary breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What should I avoid if I have balance problems or seizures?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you have balance problems, avoid activities that require balance, such as outdoor cycling. If you have seizures, avoid exercising alone to ensure safety. Consult your treatment team for personalized advice.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have balance problems, an exercise bike may be better than cycling outdoors. If you have seizures, try to avoid exercising alone.

Question (100 words): How can I get guidance on safe exercise during treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your treatment team can provide guidance on how much exercise you can do depending on your situation and any symptoms you may have. They can help you find safe and appropriate exercise options.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your treatment team can give you guidance on how much exercise you can do depending on your situation.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I continue to drive despite having secondary breast cancer in the brain?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Continuing to drive despite having secondary breast cancer in the brain can result in fines or prosecution if you are involved in an accident. It’s important to inform the DVLA or DVA and follow their guidance to ensure your safety and compliance with the law.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may be fined if you continue to drive or face prosecution if you are involved in an accident.

Question (100 words): How can I cope with the emotional impact of giving up my driving licence?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Giving up your driving licence can feel like a loss of independence. Seek support from loved ones, professional support services, or Breast Cancer Now’s helpline to help you cope with these emotions and find practical solutions.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Giving up your driving licence can also have a huge impact on your lifestyle and independence.

Question (100 words): What is the role of Breast Cancer Now in supporting people with secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast Cancer Now provides life-changing support, world-class research, and change-making campaigns to help people affected by breast cancer. They offer free services, support groups, forums, and resources to help you navigate your diagnosis, treatment, and life beyond breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Life-changing support Whoever you are, and whatever your experience of breast cancer, our free services are here.

Question (100 words): Why do I need to do exercises after my breast surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): These exercises help you regain arm and shoulder movement after surgery and radiotherapy for breast cancer. They can improve symptoms caused by tight scars and cording, prevent long-term problems with arm and shoulder movement, posture, and stiffness, and reduce the risk of lymphoedema.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: These exercises can help you regain arm and shoulder movement after surgery and radiotherapy for breast cancer.

Question (100 words): Who are the exercises suitable for?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The exercises are suitable for people who have had breast surgery, lymph node removal, and radiotherapy. If you’ve recently had a breast reconstruction, consult your surgeon, breast care nurse, or physiotherapist before starting any exercises.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The exercises are suitable for people who have had: • Breast surgery • Lymph node removal • Radiotherapy

Question (100 words): When should I start the exercises?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Ideally, start the exercises before your surgery to build up flexibility and movement. Aim to begin again the day after your surgery. If you can’t start within a couple of days, speak to your breast care nurse or physiotherapist.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Ideally, you should start these exercises before your surgery. You should then aim to begin the exercises again the day after your surgery.

Question (100 words): How should the exercises feel?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You should not feel pain when doing the exercises. A stretching or pulling sensation is normal. Always do the warm-up at the start and the cool-down at the end of each session to help avoid injury and prevent stiffness.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You should not feel pain when doing the exercises. However, a stretching or pulling sensation is normal.

Question (100 words): When should I stop the exercises?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Stop doing the exercises and speak to your surgeon, physiotherapist, or breast care nurse if you have a seroma, a wound infection, or if the pain worsens during or after the exercises.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Stop doing the exercises and speak to your surgeon, physiotherapist or breast care nurse as soon as possible if you have: • A seroma • A wound infection or problems with your wound healing • Pain that gets worse during these exercises or continues once you’ve finished them

Question (100 words): How long should I continue doing the exercises?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you’ve had surgery, continue the exercises until you’ve regained the range of movement you had before your operation. If you’ve had radiotherapy, continue doing the exercises as long as you’re still feeling tightness and stiffness.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’ve had surgery, keep doing the exercises until you’ve got back the range of movement you had before your operation. If you’ve had radiotherapy, it’s a good idea to do the exercises for as long as you’re still feeling tightness and stiffness.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I have difficulty getting my range of movement back?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Talk to your breast care nurse or physiotherapist if you’re having difficulty getting your range of movement back, are unsure how long to continue the exercises, or have concerns about your recovery after surgery.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Talk to your breast care nurse or physiotherapist if: • You’re having difficulty getting your range of movement back • You’re not sure how long to continue the exercises • You have concerns about your recovery after surgery

Question (100 words): How often should I do the exercises?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Try to do the exercises 3 times a day (morning, around midday, and evening) for the first 3 months. After 3 months, continue exercises 1, 3, and 6 once a day to help reduce discomfort and stiffness.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Try to do the exercises 3 times a day (morning, around midday and evening) for the first 3 months.

Question (100 words): What are the basic exercises I can do after surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Basic exercises include shoulder shrugs, shoulder circling, bent arm forwards, bent arm sideways, back scratching, and winging it. During the first week, do not raise your arms above shoulder level.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Basic exercises You can do these exercises sitting down or standing up. During the first week after surgery, do not raise your arms above shoulder level (90 degrees) when doing these exercises.

Question (100 words): What are the advanced exercises I can do after surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Advanced exercises include wall climbing and arm lifts. These exercises help improve shoulder flexibility and range of motion.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Advanced exercises Wall climbing Step 1 With your feet apart, stand close to and facing a wall. Put both hands on the wall at shoulder level.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I have removable stitches or a drain?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you have removable stitches or a drain, wait until these have been removed before starting the exercises.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: *If you have removable stitches or a drain, wait until these have been removed

Question (100 words): What is the importance of warm-up and cool-down in these exercises?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The warm-up at the start and the cool-down at the end of each session help avoid injury and prevent stiffness.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Always do the warm-up at the start and the cool-down at the end of each session to help avoid injury and prevent stiffness.

Question (100 words): Can I do the exercises if I have difficulty lying down?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, you can do the exercises in a sitting position if you have difficulty lying down, such as due to breathlessness.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Alternative If you have difficulty lying down – for example because of breathlessness – you can do this exercise in a sitting position, leaning back in your chair.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I develop symptoms of cording after surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you develop symptoms of cording after surgery, contact your breast care nurse or physiotherapist as soon as possible.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You should also contact your breast care nurse or physiotherapist as soon as possible if you: • Develop symptoms of cording after surgery

Question (100 words): What is lymphoedema and how can exercises help reduce its risk?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Lymphoedema is the swelling of the arm, hand, breast, or chest area caused by a build-up of lymph fluid. Exercises can help reduce the risk by improving arm and shoulder movement and preventing stiffness.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Reduce the risk of lymphoedema (swelling of the arm, hand, breast or chest area caused by a build-up of lymph fluid)

Question (100 words): What should I do if I had shoulder problems before my surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you had shoulder problems before your surgery, speak to your breast care nurse or physiotherapist as soon as possible.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You should also contact your breast care nurse or physiotherapist as soon as possible if you: • Had shoulder problems before your surgery

Question (100 words): What is a seroma and what should I do if I develop one?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A seroma is a collection of fluid that forms under a wound after an operation. If you develop a seroma, stop the exercises and speak to your surgeon, physiotherapist, or breast care nurse.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: • Develop a seroma (a collection of fluid that forms under a wound after an operation) after surgery

Question (100 words): How can I get more information or support regarding these exercises?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can get more information or support by contacting Breast Cancer Now’s helpline nurses at 0808 800 6000 or visiting breastcancernow.org for reliable breast cancer information.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Call 0808 800 6000 to talk things through with our helpline nurses. Visit breastcancernow.org for reliable breast cancer information.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I feel pain during the exercises?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you feel pain during the exercises, stop and speak to your breast care nurse or physiotherapist. You may be advised to take some pain relief before doing the exercises.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If at any time you become concerned about your range of movement or level of discomfort, speak to your breast care nurse or physiotherapist.

Question (100 words): How can I order or download more copies of this booklet?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can order or download more copies of this booklet from breastcancernow.org/publications or by emailing health-info@breastcancernow.org.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can order or download more copies from breastcancernow.org/publications

Question (100 words): What is letrozole and what is it used for?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Letrozole is a hormone therapy drug used to treat breast cancer in women who have gone through menopause. It is also used in premenopausal women with ovarian suppression. It works by reducing the amount of oestrogen in the body, which helps to slow or stop the growth of oestrogen receptor positive (ER+) breast cancers.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Letrozole is a hormone therapy drug used to treat breast cancer in women who have gone through a natural menopause (when periods stop). It can also be used in premenopausal women having ovarian suppression (treatment to stop the ovaries working).

Question (100 words): How does letrozole work in the body?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Letrozole works by inhibiting the aromatase enzyme, which is responsible for producing oestrogen in body fat after menopause. By reducing oestrogen levels, letrozole helps to prevent the growth of oestrogen receptor positive breast cancer cells.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Letrozole belongs to a group of drugs called aromatase inhibitors. Aromatase inhibitors stop the aromatase enzyme from working. This means there’s less oestrogen in the body to help breast cancer cells to grow.

Question (100 words): When is letrozole prescribed for breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Letrozole is prescribed for women who have gone through menopause and have oestrogen receptor positive breast cancer. It can also be given to premenopausal women alongside ovarian suppression treatments. It is used as adjuvant therapy after surgery to reduce the risk of cancer recurrence.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Letrozole is suitable for women who have been through the menopause and whose breast cancer is oestrogen receptor positive.

Question (100 words): How is letrozole taken?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Letrozole is taken as a tablet once a day, with or without food. It is best to take it at the same time every day to maintain consistent levels in the body.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Letrozole is taken as a tablet once a day, with or without food. It’s best to take it at the same time every day.

Question (100 words): How long will I need to take letrozole?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The duration of letrozole treatment varies. For primary breast cancer, it is usually taken for five to ten years. For metastatic breast cancer, it is taken as long as it remains effective and side effects are manageable.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: People being treated for primary breast cancer will usually take letrozole for five to ten years.

Question (100 words): What are the common side effects of letrozole?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common side effects of letrozole include joint and muscle pain, hot flushes, night sweats, increased sweating, low mood, extreme tiredness, difficulty sleeping, and osteoporosis. These side effects vary in severity and duration among individuals.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Common side effects Aching or pain in the joints and muscles, Menopausal symptoms Hot flushes, night sweats and increased sweating, Low mood and depression, Extreme tiredness

Question (100 words): How can I manage joint and muscle pain caused by letrozole?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Joint and muscle pain can often be managed with mild pain relief like paracetamol or anti-inflammatory drugs such as ibuprofen. Gentle exercises like yoga, pilates, or brisk walking may also help. In some cases, switching to a different hormone therapy may be considered.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Aching or pain in the joints and muscles is often mild and temporary, although for some people it’s more severe and longer lasting. It can usually be relieved with mild pain relief like paracetamol or an anti-inflammatory drug such as ibuprofen.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience hot flushes and night sweats from letrozole?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Hot flushes and night sweats are common side effects. To manage them, you can try wearing lightweight clothing, using fans, and avoiding triggers like spicy foods and alcohol. If they significantly affect your quality of life, discuss with your healthcare provider for additional strategies.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Hot flushes, night sweats and increased sweating are common side effects of letrozole.

Question (100 words): Can letrozole cause mood changes or depression?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, letrozole can cause low mood and depression. It is important to talk to your GP or treatment team if you experience these symptoms. They may suggest counselling, mindfulness, exercise, or antidepressant medication to help manage your mood.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Low mood and depression Many people feel low or depressed.

Question (100 words): What can I do to manage extreme tiredness from letrozole?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Extreme tiredness, or cancer-related fatigue, can be managed by pacing yourself, taking short naps, and ensuring you get enough rest. It is also important to rule out other causes like anaemia. Discuss with your healthcare provider for personalized advice.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Extreme tiredness Cancer-related fatigue is extreme tiredness and exhaustion that doesn’t go away with rest or sleep.

Question (100 words): Does letrozole affect bone health?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, letrozole can lead to osteoporosis due to reduced oestrogen levels. To maintain bone health, increase your intake of calcium and vitamin D, stop smoking, and engage in regular weight-bearing exercises. Your specialist may also prescribe bisphosphonates if needed.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Osteoporosis (thinning of the bone) Letrozole reduces the amount of oestrogen in the body. A lack of oestrogen over time can cause osteoporosis.

Question (100 words): Can letrozole cause high blood pressure or high cholesterol?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Letrozole may cause high blood pressure (hypertension) and can raise cholesterol levels. Your GP will monitor these levels and provide treatment if necessary. If you have a history of high cholesterol, discuss this with your specialist or GP.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: High blood pressure (hypertension) and high cholesterol Letrozole can cause high blood pressure (hypertension) in some people.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I miss a dose of letrozole?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you miss a dose of letrozole, do not take an extra dose the next day. The level of drug in your body will remain high enough from the previous day. Simply take your next scheduled dose at the usual time.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you miss a dose, you don’t need to take an extra dose the next day. The level of drug in your body will remain high enough from the day before.

Question (100 words): Are there any dietary considerations while taking letrozole?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To support bone health, increase your intake of calcium and vitamin D through supplements or foods like milk, cheese, yoghurt, oily fish, mushrooms, and eggs. Maintain a balanced diet and stay hydrated.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: To help keep your bones healthy you can increase your intake of calcium and vitamin D.

Question (100 words): Can letrozole affect my hair or skin?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Letrozole may cause hair loss or thinning, and some women may notice an increase in downy facial hair. You may also experience skin changes like rashes or dry skin. These usually resolve after treatment ends.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Changes to hair or facial hair You may have some hair loss or thinning while taking letrozole. A small number of women notice an increase in downy facial hair. Skin changes You may develop a skin rash or dry skin while taking letrozole.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience severe side effects from letrozole?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience severe side effects, contact your healthcare provider immediately. They may adjust your dosage, switch you to a different medication, or provide additional treatments to manage your symptoms.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re worried about any side effects, regardless of whether they are listed here, talk to your GP or treatment team.

Question (100 words): Can letrozole be taken with other medications?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Letrozole can generally be taken with other medications, but it is important to inform your healthcare provider about all the medications you are taking to avoid potential interactions. They will advise you on the best course of action.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: This booklet does not list all the possible side effects. If you’re worried about any side effects, regardless of whether they are listed here, talk to your GP or treatment team.

Question (100 words): Is letrozole suitable for men with breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The use of letrozole in men with breast cancer has not been studied. Another drug called tamoxifen is more commonly used for men with breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The use of letrozole in men with breast cancer has not been studied and another drug called tamoxifen is more commonly used.

Question (100 words): How often should I have my bone density checked while on letrozole?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your bone density may be checked every two to three years while you’re taking letrozole, depending on the results from the initial scan or if your specialist has any concerns about your bone health.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your bone density may be checked every two to three years while you’re taking letrozole, depending on the results from the initial scan or whether your specialist has any concerns.

Question (100 words): What support is available if I feel emotionally affected by taking letrozole?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you feel emotionally affected by taking letrozole, talk to your GP or treatment team. They can refer you for counselling, suggest mindfulness practices, or recommend exercise to improve your mood. Your breast care nurse may also provide support or information about local services.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Talk to your GP or treatment team about how to manage a change in mood. Some people find counselling or mindfulness helpful. Others find exercise improves their mood.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience vaginal bleeding after starting letrozole?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience vaginal bleeding after starting letrozole, it is important to inform your specialist. This bleeding can occur when changing from one hormone therapy to another and may also be due to vaginal dryness. If the bleeding continues for more than a few days, seek medical advice.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Vaginal bleeding can happen in the first few weeks after starting letrozole. It most commonly occurs when changing from one hormone therapy to another. This may also be due to vaginal dryness (see page 13). If the bleeding continues for more than a few days, tell your specialist.

Question (100 words): Can letrozole cause a fast heart rate or chest pain?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, letrozole can cause a fast heart rate (palpitations) and chest pain, particularly in older individuals. If you experience these symptoms, it is important to speak to your GP or treatment team for further evaluation and management.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may feel like your heart is racing (heart palpitations) when taking letrozole, which is more common in older people. Some people also experience chest pain. Speak to your GP or treatment team if you have any of these symptoms.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice swelling in my arms, hands, feet, or ankles while taking letrozole?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you notice swelling in your arms, hands, feet, or ankles while taking letrozole, it is important to inform your GP. This swelling, known as oedema, should be evaluated to determine the cause and appropriate management.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can get swollen arms, hands, feet and ankles. If you notice this or any other swelling, let your GP know.

Question (100 words): How can I manage vaginal dryness caused by letrozole?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Vaginal dryness caused by letrozole can be managed with vaginal moisturisers and lubricants. These can be obtained on prescription from your GP or purchased from a chemist or online. It is also beneficial to discuss this with your healthcare provider for personalized recommendations.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Vaginal dryness is often caused by reduced levels of oestrogen or blocking its action can cause vaginal changes, such as dryness or irritation. There are a number of treatments that can help with vaginal dryness, including vaginal moisturisers and lubricants.

Question (100 words): Is it normal to have a low sex drive while taking letrozole?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, it is common for women to experience a decrease in sex drive (libido) while taking letrozole. This can continue for many months but may improve over time. It is important to communicate with your partner and explore new ways of sharing intimacy and pleasure.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Many women find their desire for sexual contact decreases. Loss of desire can continue for many months but as time moves on this may start to improve.

Question (100 words): What is carpal tunnel syndrome and how can it be managed while taking letrozole?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Carpal tunnel syndrome is a condition caused by pressure on a nerve in your wrist, leading to pain, tingling, and numbness in your arm, hand, or fingers. Using a wrist splint can help manage symptoms. It is important to speak to your GP or specialist if you experience these symptoms.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) is pressure on a nerve in your wrist. This causes pain, tingling and numbness in your arm, hand or fingers. Using a wrist splint can help.

Question (100 words): What are the symptoms of blood clots and what should I do if I experience them?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Symptoms of blood clots include pain, redness/discolouration, heat, and swelling of the arm or leg, swelling, redness, or tenderness where a central line is inserted, shortness of breath, pain or tightness in the chest, and unexplained cough or coughing up blood. If you experience any of these symptoms, contact your local A&E department, GP, or treatment team immediately.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you experience any of the following symptoms contact your local A&E department, GP or treatment team straight away: Pain, redness/discolouration, heat and swelling of the arm or leg; Swelling, redness or tenderness where a central line is inserted to give chemotherapy, for example in the arm, chest area or up into the neck; Shortness of breath; Pain or tightness in the chest; Unexplained cough or coughing up blood.

Question (100 words): Do I need to stop letrozole gradually?
Answer (Max 2000 words): No, you do not need to stop letrozole gradually. Your treatment team will inform you when to stop taking it. However, it is important to discuss any concerns about stopping letrozole with your specialist, as not taking the drug for the recommended time may increase the risk of your breast cancer coming back.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your treatment team will tell you when to stop taking letrozole. You won’t need to stop taking it gradually.

Question (100 words): Can I take other medications while on letrozole?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you are taking other prescribed or over-the-counter medicines, it is important to check with your treatment team or pharmacist if they can be taken with letrozole. Do not take other drugs containing oestrogen, such as hormone replacement therapy (HRT), while you’re taking letrozole as this may interfere with its effectiveness.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re taking any other prescribed or over-the-counter medicines, check with your treatment team or pharmacist if you can take these with letrozole. Do not take other drugs containing oestrogen, such as hormone replacement therapy (HRT), while you’re taking letrozole as this may interfere with its effectiveness.

Question (100 words): Is it safe to take herbal medicines or supplements while on letrozole?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The exact effect and safety of taking herbal products or supplements after a diagnosis of breast cancer is not fully understood. It is important to ask your treatment team or pharmacist before taking any herbal medicines or supplements while on letrozole.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Many people consider taking herbal products or supplements while having treatment for breast cancer. However, the exact effect and safety of taking these after a diagnosis of breast cancer is not fully understood. Ask your treatment team or pharmacist before taking herbal products or supplements.

Question (100 words): Can I become pregnant while taking letrozole?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Taking letrozole while pregnant may be harmful to a developing baby. It is possible to become pregnant while taking letrozole even if your periods have stopped with ovarian suppression. If you are sexually active with a chance of becoming pregnant, your specialist is likely to advise you to use a non-hormonal method of contraception while taking letrozole.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Taking letrozole while pregnant may be harmful to a developing baby. It’s possible to become pregnant while taking letrozole even if your periods have stopped with ovarian suppression. If you’re sexually active with a chance of becoming pregnant, your specialist is likely to advise you to use a non-hormonal method of contraception while taking letrozole.

Question (100 words): Is breastfeeding recommended while taking letrozole?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breastfeeding is not recommended while taking letrozole, or within a week of the last dose. This is because there is a risk that the drugs could be passed on through breast milk.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breastfeeding is not recommended while having letrozole, or within a week of the last dose. This is because there’s a risk the drugs could be passed on through breast milk.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I think I may be pregnant while taking letrozole?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you think you may be pregnant while taking letrozole, it is important to stop the medication and inform your specialist as soon as possible.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you think you may be pregnant, stop letrozole and tell your specialist as soon as possible.

Question (100 words): How can I find emotional support during my breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Finding emotional support is crucial during breast cancer treatment. You can find somebody who understands what you’re going through with Someone Like Me by calling 0114 263 6490. Additionally, you can call the Breast Cancer Now Helpline on 0808 800 6000 to talk through your concerns or visit breastcancernow.org/oursupport for more information.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Being diagnosed with breast cancer can make you feel lonely and isolated. Find somebody who understands what you’re going through with Someone Like Me. Call our Someone Like Me service on 0114 263 6490.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I have worries or questions about taking or stopping letrozole?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you have any worries or questions about taking or stopping letrozole, you can call the Breast Cancer Now Helpline free on 0808 800 6000 to talk through your concerns. You can also email nurse@breastcancernow.org for further assistance.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have any worries or questions about taking or stopping letrozole, you can call us free on 0808 800 6000 to talk through your concerns.

Question (100 words): How can I support Breast Cancer Now’s work?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast Cancer Now relies on voluntary donations and gifts in wills to support its vital care and research work. If you have found this information helpful, please visit breastcancernow.org/give to make a donation.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast Cancer Now is a charity that relies on voluntary donations and gifts in wills. If you have found this information helpful, please visit breastcancernow.org/give to support our vital care and research work.

Question (100 words): What information sources were used to create this booklet?
Answer (Max 2000 words): This booklet was written by Breast Cancer Now’s clinical specialists and reviewed by healthcare professionals and people affected by breast cancer. For a full list of sources, email health-info@breastcancernow.org.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Letrozole was written by Breast Cancer Now’s clinical specialists, and reviewed by healthcare professionals and people affected by breast cancer. For a full list of the sources we used to research it: Email health-info@breastcancernow.org

Question (100 words): How can I order or download more copies of this booklet?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can order or download more copies of this booklet from breastcancernow.org/publications.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can order or download more copies from breastcancernow.org/publications

Question (100 words): What should I do if I have feedback on this publication?
Answer (Max 2000 words): We welcome your feedback on this publication. You can send your feedback to health-info@breastcancernow.org.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: We welcome your feedback on this publication: health-info@breastcancernow.org

Question (100 words): Can I get this booklet in large print, Braille, or audio CD format?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, you can request this booklet in large print, Braille, or audio CD format by emailing health-info@breastcancernow.org.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: For a large print, Braille or audio CD version: Email health-info@breastcancernow.org

Question (100 words): What should I do when I receive a breast cancer diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): When you receive a breast cancer diagnosis, it's important to take notes, record your appointments (with permission), and consider bringing a family member or friend for support. It's normal to feel a range of emotions, and talking about your feelings with a trusted person or healthcare professional can be beneficial. You can also call the helpline for additional support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Being diagnosed with breast cancer can be overwhelming and you may struggle to take in what you’re being told. At your hospital appointments, it may be helpful to: • Take a family member or friend • Take notes on what’s said • Record your appointment on your mobile phone (remember to ask permission first)

Question (100 words): How should I tell my family and friends about my diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can tell your family and friends about your diagnosis in a way that feels comfortable for you. Choose a time and place where you feel at ease, share the basic facts, and let the conversation progress naturally. You can provide them with information booklets or direct them to helpful websites. If needed, ask a trusted person to help you convey the information.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You might be worried about telling people about your breast cancer diagnosis and how they may react. Who you tell and how you tell them is up to you and there’s no right or wrong way.

Question (100 words): What is the best way to talk to my children about my breast cancer diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): It's important to talk to your children about your breast cancer diagnosis as soon as possible. Be honest and age-appropriate in your explanations. Children often sense when something is wrong, and knowing the truth can help reduce their anxiety. You can seek support from your breast care nurse, school or nursery, and organizations like Fruitfly Collective for additional resources.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Evidence suggests that children are less frightened if they know what’s happening, even if they do not fully understand.

Question (100 words): What treatments are typically offered for breast cancer in younger women?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Younger women with breast cancer may be offered a combination of treatments including surgery, chemotherapy, radiotherapy, hormone therapy, ovarian suppression, targeted therapy, and bisphosphonates. The specific treatments depend on the type and features of your cancer, and your treatment plan will be tailored to your individual situation.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may be offered a combination of treatments including: • Surgery • Chemotherapy • Radiotherapy • Hormone (endocrine) therapy • Ovarian suppression (stopping the ovaries from working either temporarily or permanently) • Targeted therapy • Bisphosphonates

Question (100 words): How can breast cancer treatments affect my fertility?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Some breast cancer treatments, particularly chemotherapy, can affect your fertility by reducing the number and quality of your eggs. This can lead to temporary or permanent changes in your menstrual cycles and early menopause. Hormone therapy may also cause your periods to stop temporarily. It's important to discuss fertility concerns with your treatment team before starting treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some breast cancer treatments, such as chemotherapy, can affect your ability to become pregnant (your fertility). It’s important to discuss any fertility concerns with your treatment team before you begin your treatment.

Question (100 words): What are my options for fertility preservation before starting breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Before starting breast cancer treatment, you may consider fertility preservation options such as egg or embryo freezing. Your treatment team should refer you to a fertility specialist to discuss these options as soon as possible after diagnosis. The Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority (HFEA) provides more information on fertility preservation.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your treatment team should offer you a referral to a fertility specialist to discuss the option of preserving your fertility. This should be as soon as possible after diagnosis to prevent any delays in your treatment.

Question (100 words): What type of contraception should I use during breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): During breast cancer treatment, it's important to avoid pregnancy. You should use a reliable barrier method of contraception, such as condoms. In some cases, an intrauterine device (IUD) may be suitable, but you should consult your treatment team. The contraceptive pill is not advised after a breast cancer diagnosis.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s important to avoid getting pregnant while having breast cancer treatment, as treatment can harm a developing baby. You’ll usually be advised to use a barrier method of contraception, such as condoms.

Question (100 words): Can I continue my pregnancy if I am diagnosed with breast cancer during pregnancy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, most women can continue their pregnancy while receiving breast cancer treatment without affecting their baby’s development. Your treatment team and obstetrician will provide information and support to ensure both your health and your baby’s safety.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re diagnosed with breast cancer during pregnancy, you can usually have effective treatment for your breast cancer without it affecting your baby’s development. Most women continue their pregnancy while having breast cancer treatment.

Question (100 words): What should I know about my prognosis after a breast cancer diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After a breast cancer diagnosis, you may have questions about your prognosis. Some people seek detailed information, while others prefer not to think about it. You can discuss your prognosis with your treatment team or call the helpline for support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: After a diagnosis of breast cancer many people will naturally start to think about what their outlook (prognosis) might be. Some people might want as much information as possible about their prognosis, while others might not want to think about it.

Question (100 words): Are there any clinical trials available for breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, you may be eligible to participate in a clinical trial. If you're interested, discuss this option with your treatment team. You can find more information about available trials on the Be Part of Research or Cancer Research UK websites.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may be able to take part in a clinical trial if you’re eligible. If this is something you’re interested in, talk to your treatment team and they can advise you.

Question (100 words): What support is available for younger women diagnosed with breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): There are several support resources available for younger women diagnosed with breast cancer, including helplines, information booklets, and organizations like Breast Cancer Now. These resources can provide emotional support, practical advice, and information about treatment and fertility.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’ve been diagnosed with breast cancer as a younger woman, you’ll probably have lots of questions and be feeling all sorts of emotions. Your care and support needs as a younger woman are often different to those of older women diagnosed with breast cancer.

Question (100 words): How can I manage the emotional impact of a breast cancer diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Managing the emotional impact of a breast cancer diagnosis involves allowing yourself to feel your emotions, seeking support from friends, family, or healthcare professionals, and utilizing resources like helplines and support groups. Talking about your feelings and concerns can help you cope better.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You might feel shocked, scared, angry and upset. All these feelings are normal. It might help to talk them through with a friend, relative or your breast care nurse.

Question (100 words): What should I consider regarding work and finances after a breast cancer diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After a breast cancer diagnosis, consider discussing your situation with your employer to explore options like flexible working hours or temporary leave. You may also need to look into financial support options, such as benefits or grants, to help manage any financial strain.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: This booklet covers topics younger women have told us are important to them, including: • Work and finances

Question (100 words): How can I involve my family in my breast cancer treatment journey?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Involve your family by keeping them informed about your diagnosis and treatment plan. Ask them for specific support, such as accompanying you to appointments or helping with household tasks. Open communication can help them understand how to best support you.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Friends and family will probably want to help but they might not know how. It can help to give them specific tasks, like coming to appointments with you or looking after younger children.

Question (100 words): What are the common side effects of chemotherapy for breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common side effects of chemotherapy for breast cancer include nausea, fatigue, hair loss, and increased risk of infections. These side effects vary depending on the specific drugs used and individual patient factors. Your healthcare team will provide guidance on managing these side effects.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Chemotherapy causes changes in your ovaries, reducing the number and quality of your eggs which can affect your ability to become pregnant.

Question (100 words): How can I maintain a healthy lifestyle during breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Maintaining a healthy lifestyle during breast cancer treatment involves eating a balanced diet, staying physically active as much as possible, getting enough rest, and avoiding tobacco and excessive alcohol. Consult your healthcare team for personalized advice.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: N/A

Question (100 words): What nutritional advice should I follow during breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): During breast cancer treatment, focus on a diet rich in fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and lean proteins. Stay hydrated and limit processed foods and sugars. Your healthcare team may recommend specific dietary changes based on your treatment and overall health.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: N/A

Question (100 words): What follow-up care is needed after completing breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After completing breast cancer treatment, regular follow-up care is essential. This includes periodic check-ups, imaging tests, and blood work to monitor for any signs of recurrence. Your healthcare team will provide a personalized follow-up plan.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: N/A

Question (100 words): How can I access additional information and support for breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can access additional information and support for breast cancer through organizations like Breast Cancer Now, by calling their helpline, visiting their website, or ordering their publications. These resources offer detailed information and emotional support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can order or download any of the Breast Cancer Now publications mentioned in this booklet at breastcancernow.org/publications

Question (100 words): What are the red flags I should watch for during breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): During breast cancer treatment, watch for red flags such as severe pain, signs of infection (fever, chills), unusual bleeding or discharge, and significant changes in your overall health. Report any concerning symptoms to your healthcare team immediately.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: N/A

Question (100 words): Can I get pregnant after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Generally, you should assume you could still get pregnant unless you're 40 or over and have not had a period for at least a year after finishing your treatment, or you're under 40 and have not had a period for at least 2 years after finishing your treatment. However, this varies for each person. You may be able to have tests around 3 to 6 months after you’ve finished treatment to check your fertility.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Generally, you should assume you could still get pregnant unless: • You’re 40 or over and have not had a period for at least a year after finishing your treatment • You’re under 40 and have not had a period for at least 2 years after finishing your treatment

Question (100 words): Is there a risk of breast cancer returning if I get pregnant after treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): There’s no evidence that you’re at increased risk of the cancer returning if you get pregnant and have a baby after your breast cancer treatment. There’s also no evidence that there are any health risks for children born after breast cancer treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re able to get pregnant and have a baby after your breast cancer treatment, there’s no evidence that you’re at increased risk of the cancer returning.

Question (100 words): How long should I wait before getting pregnant after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Many treatment teams advise waiting for 2 years after treatment has finished before becoming pregnant. This is because the possibility of the cancer coming back can reduce over time, and you may be at greatest risk in the first 2 years after diagnosis. However, if you would prefer not to wait for 2 years, speak to your treatment team for personalized advice.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Many treatment teams advise waiting for 2 years after treatment has finished before becoming pregnant.

Question (100 words): Can I take a break from hormone therapy to try to get pregnant?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Some women choose to take a break from hormone therapy if they want to try to get pregnant. They can then restart treatment after the birth of their baby if they’re able to get pregnant. An ongoing study suggests a temporary break from taking hormone treatment to have a baby is safe for some women. If this is something you’d like to consider, speak to your treatment team.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some women choose to take a break from hormone therapy if they want to try to get pregnant.

Question (100 words): How long should I wait after finishing hormone therapy before trying to get pregnant?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you’re planning to get pregnant after you’ve finished taking hormone therapy, it’s best to wait at least 3 months to allow time for the drug to leave the body completely.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re planning to get pregnant after you’ve finished taking hormone therapy, it’s best to wait at least 3 months to allow time for the drug to leave the body completely.

Question (100 words): Can targeted therapy drugs affect my fertility?
Answer (Max 2000 words): It’s not fully understood whether targeted therapy drugs affect fertility. You should avoid getting pregnant while taking targeted therapy drugs as they may cause harm to a developing baby. If you’re considering trying to become pregnant when you’ve finished any of these treatments, discuss this with your treatment team.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s not fully understood whether targeted therapy drugs affect fertility.

Question (100 words): What are the options if I cannot conceive naturally after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you cannot conceive naturally because your breast cancer treatment has damaged your ovaries, you may be able to become pregnant using donated eggs. The eggs are fertilised with sperm from your partner or a donor and the embryo is transferred to your womb. Some women choose other ways to grow their family, such as adoption, fostering or surrogacy, and others choose not to become parents.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you cannot conceive naturally because your breast cancer treatment has damaged your ovaries, you may be able to become pregnant using donated eggs.

Question (100 words): How does a family history of breast cancer affect my risk?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Sometimes, someone’s family history suggests they and other family members could be at increased risk of developing breast cancer. This is known as having a significant family history. A significant family history may mean there’s a chance that there’s an altered gene in that family that increases the risk of breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Sometimes, someone’s family history suggests they and other family members could be at increased risk of developing breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What are the common inherited genes associated with breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The most common inherited altered genes associated with breast cancer are BRCA1 and BRCA2. Other altered genes, including TP53, ATM, CHEK2 and PALB2, can increase your risk of breast cancer if you inherit them, although they’re much rarer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The most common inherited altered genes associated with breast cancer are BRCA1 and BRCA2.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I’m worried about my family history of breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you’re worried about your family history or your risk of having an altered gene, talk to your treatment team. If you have a significant family history of breast or ovarian cancer, your treatment team may refer you to a family history or genetics clinic for further assessment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re worried about your family history or your risk of having an altered gene, talk to your treatment team.

Question (100 words): How can genetic testing help in my breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Finding out whether you have an altered gene can help your treatment team in planning your treatment and follow-up. If you’re found to have an altered gene, you’ll be given information on the options available to you, including risk-reducing surgery and follow-up screening.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Finding out whether you have an altered gene can help your treatment team in planning your treatment and follow-up.

Question (100 words): How might a breast cancer diagnosis affect my relationship with my partner?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A breast cancer diagnosis can affect relationships in different ways. You may find that an existing relationship changes after you’ve been diagnosed with breast cancer. Some couples become closer and their relationship gets stronger. But a relationship can also become strained. It might help to talk openly about your feelings and what impact the cancer and treatment has on both of you.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A breast cancer diagnosis can affect relationships in different ways.

Question (100 words): What support is available for single women diagnosed with breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Being diagnosed with breast cancer if you’re single can bring its own challenges, particularly if you live alone and are used to being independent. Speak to your treatment team if you need more support, either emotionally or with your day-to-day tasks.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Being diagnosed with breast cancer if you’re single can bring its own challenges, particularly if you live alone and are used to being independent.

Question (100 words): How can I talk about my breast cancer with a new partner?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Deciding when and how to talk about your breast cancer with a new partner can be difficult. But as you get to know someone and feel more comfortable with them, you may find it easier to talk about all aspects of your life, including your breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Deciding when and how to talk about this can be difficult.

Question (100 words): How can I manage changes to my body after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast cancer and its treatments can cause changes to your body and the way you look. You may have scars after surgery, lose your hair if you had chemotherapy, or experience changes in weight. Support is available through organizations like Flat Friends, Keeping Abreast, and Look Good Feel Better to help you deal with these changes.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast cancer and its treatments can cause changes to your body and the way you look.

Question (100 words): What are common menopausal symptoms after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Treatments such as chemotherapy and hormone therapy can cause menopausal symptoms like hot flushes, night sweats, vaginal dryness, joint pain, poor concentration and mood changes. Talk with your treatment team if you have menopausal symptoms. They may be able to help you manage them or refer you to a specialist menopause clinic for further advice and support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Treatments such as chemotherapy and hormone therapy can cause menopausal symptoms like hot flushes, night sweats, vaginal dryness, joint pain, poor concentration and mood changes.

Question (100 words): How can breast cancer treatments affect my bone health?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Some treatments for breast cancer can affect your bone health, which can increase your risk of developing osteoporosis. An early menopause, before the age of 45, means you’ll have lower levels of the hormone oestrogen in your body. This can increase the risk of osteoporosis. Some hormone therapy drugs can also lower the amount of oestrogen in the body and increase the risk of osteoporosis.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some treatments for breast cancer can affect your bone health, which can increase your risk of developing osteoporosis.

Question (100 words): What financial support is available for breast cancer patients?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A breast cancer diagnosis and treatment can put a strain on you financially. For example, it may affect your ability to work or mean you have extra costs like childcare. Speak to your treatment team or GP for advice on benefits and financial support available to you.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A breast cancer diagnosis and treatment can put a strain on you financially.

Question (100 words): How can I get emotional support during my breast cancer journey?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Counselling can be very helpful, and discussing your feelings with someone impartial can help you both to see things more clearly. Organisations like Relate offer relationship counselling. Many hospitals also have counselling services, some specialising in cancer, and there may be services in your local community too.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Counselling can be very helpful, and discussing your feelings with someone impartial can help you both to see things more clearly.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I suspect a recurrence of breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you notice any unusual symptoms or changes in your body that concern you, it’s important to contact your healthcare provider immediately. Early detection and treatment of a recurrence can significantly improve outcomes. Common signs to watch for include new lumps, changes in the breast or nipple, and unexplained pain or swelling.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you notice any unusual symptoms or changes in your body that concern you, it’s important to contact your healthcare provider immediately.

Question (100 words): Can I claim benefits if I have breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, you may be able to claim benefits if you have breast cancer. Several factors will be taken into account, such as your age, income, savings, and how much National Insurance you’ve paid. Organisations like Maggie’s, Macmillan Cancer Support, Citizens Advice, and Turn2us can help you understand what financial support you may be entitled to.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may be able to claim benefits if you have breast cancer. Organisations that can help you understand what financial support you may be entitled to include: • Maggie’s • Macmillan Cancer Support • Citizens Advice • Turn2us, a charity that helps people access welfare, grants and support services

Question (100 words): Do I have to tell my employer about my breast cancer diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): No, you do not have to tell your employer that you have cancer, but it could help them to be more supportive and flexible. You have the right for any information you do provide about your breast cancer to be kept private and only discussed with other colleagues with your permission.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You do not have to tell your employer that you have cancer, but it could help them to be more supportive and flexible. You have the right for any information you do provide about your breast cancer to be kept private and only discussed with other colleagues with your permission.

Question (100 words): What are my rights at work if I have breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your rights as an employee are protected by the Equality Act 2010. Under the Equality Act, anyone who has or has had cancer is classed as disabled. This protects people with breast cancer from any discrimination at work, including the recruitment process. Your employer has to make reasonable adjustments to help you continue to work or return to work.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your rights as an employee are protected by the Equality Act 2010. Under the Equality Act, anyone who has or has had cancer is classed as disabled. This protects people with breast cancer from any discrimination at work, including the recruitment process.

Question (100 words): What reasonable adjustments can my employer make for me?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Reasonable adjustments might include a phased return to work, temporary changes to your work hours, time off for medical appointments, and adjustments to your role, such as reducing your workload.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Reasonable adjustments might include: • A phased return to work • Temporary changes to your work hours • Time off for medical appointments • Adjustments to your role, such as reducing your workload

Question (100 words): How can I ease back into work after treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You could talk to your employer about creating a return to work plan to ease yourself back into your working environment. You might also consider a phased return to work, where you slowly build up to your working hours. This can help if you’re still experiencing the side effects of treatment, such as fatigue and having trouble concentrating.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’ve had time off while having treatment, you could talk to your employer about creating a return to work plan to ease yourself back into your working environment. You might also consider a phased return to work, where you slowly build up to your working hours.

Question (100 words): What should I do if my current job doesn’t suit me anymore after treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You might feel that your current job doesn’t suit you anymore and decide to look for a new one. The organisation Working With Cancer offers coaching sessions and career advice to people who’ve had a cancer diagnosis to help them with their return to work or in changing careers.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You might also feel that your current job doesn’t suit you anymore and decide to look for a new one. The organisation Working With Cancer offers coaching sessions and career advice to people who’ve had a cancer diagnosis to help them with their return to work or in changing careers.

Question (100 words): How will I be followed up after my breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You’ll continue to be monitored after your hospital treatment has finished. This is known as follow-up. How you’re followed up after treatment will depend on how likely you are to have side effects from treatment, the risk of your cancer coming back, and arrangements at the hospital where you’ve been treated. You’ll usually be offered regular mammograms, depending on the type of surgery you’ve had.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You’ll continue to be monitored after your hospital treatment has finished. This is known as follow-up. You’ll usually be offered regular mammograms, depending on the type of surgery you’ve had.

Question (100 words): What are the signs and symptoms of breast cancer recurrence I should look out for?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Be aware of any changes to your breast or chest area including swelling on your chest, in your armpit or around your collarbone, a change in shape or size, a change in skin texture, such as puckering or dimpling, the nipple has become pulled in (inverted) or looks different, liquid (discharge) that comes from the nipple without squeezing it, swelling in the arm or hand, redness or a rash on the skin, in or around the nipple or in the area of the scar line of your treated breast, a lump or thickening that feels different.
