Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Be aware of any changes to your breast or chest area including: • Swelling on your chest, in your armpit or around your collarbone • A change in shape or size • A change in skin texture, such as puckering or dimpling • The nipple has become pulled in (inverted) or looks different, for example changed position or shape • Liquid (discharge) that comes from the nipple without squeezing it • Swelling in the arm or hand • Redness or a rash on the skin, in or around the nipple or in the area of the sc

Question (100 words): How can I manage my worries about breast cancer recurrence?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you’re finding it difficult to cope, you can talk to other women on the Breast Cancer Now online forum, find more tips on managing anxiety on their website, or call their helpline to talk through your concerns with one of their nurses.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re finding it difficult to cope, you can talk to other women on our online forum at breastcancernow.org/forum You can find more tips on managing anxiety on our website too, or call our helpline to talk through your concerns with one of our nurses.

Question (100 words): What support is available for younger women with breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Younger Women Together gives tailored support and the chance to meet people who understand what you’re going through, in a space that’s just for women aged 18–45. During in-person events or online courses, you’ll be able to share your experiences with other younger women with breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Younger Women Together gives tailored support and the chance to meet people who understand what you’re going through, in a space that’s just for women aged 18–45.

Question (100 words): Where can I find peer support after my breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Someone Like Me services match people with a primary breast cancer diagnosis to a trained volunteer who’s had a similar experience. They'll be a phone call or email away to answer your questions, offer support or simply listen.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Our Someone Like Me services match people with a primary breast cancer diagnosis to a trained volunteer who’s had a similar experience. They'll be a phone call or email away to answer your questions, offer support or simply listen.

Question (100 words): How can I get professional emotional support?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You might want to talk to someone who is specially trained in providing emotional support. This could be a counsellor linked to your GP practice or hospital, or a psychiatrist or clinical psychologist at your hospital who works with cancer patients. Your treatment team or breast care nurse can advise you on how to get more help.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You might want to talk to someone who is specially trained in providing emotional support. This could be a counsellor linked to your GP practice or hospital, or a psychiatrist or clinical psychologist at your hospital who works with cancer patients.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice something unusual after my treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Talk to your GP or breast care nurse about any symptoms that are new or unusual for you, don’t have an obvious cause, or don’t go away. Get to know how your breast or scar area should feel so you know what’s normal for you.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Talk to your GP or breast care nurse about any symptoms that: • Are new or unusual for you • Don’t have an obvious cause • Don’t go away

Question (100 words): What is the Moving Forward course and how can it help me?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The Moving Forward course allows you to connect with people who understand through supportive, open conversations in a safe, confidential space. You’ll find the tools you need to feel more empowered, confident and in control, so you can move forward with your life. The course takes place over 2 half days on consecutive weeks, either in person or online.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Moving Forward allows you to connect with people who understand through supportive, open conversations in a safe, confidential space. And you’ll find the tools you need to feel more empowered, confident and in control, so you can move forward with your life.

Question (100 words): What resources are available to help parents and carers talk to children about cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The Fruitfly Collective provides resources, kits, and ideas to help parents and carers talk to children and young people about cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Fruitfly Collective • fruitflycollective.com • Resources, kits and ideas to help parents and carers talk to children and young people about cancer

Question (100 words): Where can I find support if I was diagnosed with cancer during pregnancy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Mummy’s Star offers support for women diagnosed with cancer during pregnancy and in the first 12 months after birth, and their families, through advice, advocacy, and emotional and financial support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Mummy’s Star • mummysstar.org • Support for women diagnosed with cancer during pregnancy and in the first 12 months after birth, and their families, through advice, advocacy, and emotional and financial support

Question (100 words): Are there support groups for young adults with cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Shine Cancer Support provides support and events for young adults in their 20s, 30s, and 40s living with any type of cancer diagnosis.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Shine Cancer Support • shinecancersupport.org • Support and events for young adults in their 20s, 30s and 40s living with any type of cancer diagnosis

Question (100 words): How can I find and participate in clinical trials for breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Be Part of Research and Cancer Research UK provide databases to help patients find out about and sign up for health and social care research studies and clinical trials that are taking place in the UK.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Be Part of Research • bepartofresearch.nihr.ac.uk • A database to help patients find out about and sign up for health and social care research studies that are taking place in the UK Cancer Research UK • cancerresearchuk.org/about-cancer/find-a-clinical-trial • Search for and sign up to clinical trials

Question (100 words): What information and support is available for adoption and fostering?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Adoption UK and CoramBAAF provide information about adoption and support for adoptive families, as well as information on adoption and fostering.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Adoption UK • adoptionuk.org • Information about adoption and support for adoptive families CoramBAAF • corambaaf.org.uk • Information on adoption and fostering and works with everyone involved with adoption and fostering across the UK

Question (100 words): Where can I find advice about fertility treatments?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority (HFEA) provides impartial and accurate advice about IVF, clinics, and other fertility treatments.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority • hfea.gov.uk • The UK’s fertility regulator, providing impartial and accurate advice about IVF, clinics and other fertility treatments

Question (100 words): What support is available for women who choose not to have reconstruction after a mastectomy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Flat Friends provides information and support for women who do not have reconstruction after a mastectomy. Their website is flatfriends.org.uk.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Flat Friends • flatfriends.org.uk • Information and support for women who do not have reconstruction after a mastectomy

Question (100 words): Where can I find information and support if I am considering breast reconstruction after a mastectomy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Keeping Abreast offers information and support for women who’ve had or are thinking about having reconstruction after a mastectomy. Visit keepingabreast.org.uk for more details.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Keeping Abreast • keepingabreast.org.uk • Information and support for women who’ve had or are thinking about having reconstruction after a mastectomy

Question (100 words): Are there workshops or tutorials to help me deal with the physical effects of cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Look Good Feel Better provides workshops and online tutorials with advice and support to help people deal with the physical effects of cancer. Visit lookgoodfeelbetter.co.uk for more information.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Look Good Feel Better • lookgoodfeelbetter.co.uk • Workshops and online tutorials with advice and support to help people deal with the physical affects of cancer

Question (100 words): What resources are available for women experiencing menopausal symptoms after cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Menopause and Cancer offers support and resources for women going through menopause after cancer treatment. Visit menopauseandcancer.org for assistance.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Menopausal symptoms Menopause and Cancer • menopauseandcancer.org • Support and resources for women going through menopause after cancer treatment

Question (100 words): Where can I get help with legal, financial, and other practical issues after a cancer diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Citizens Advice provides help for legal, financial, and other practical issues through free, independent, and confidential advice. Visit citizensadvice.org.uk for support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Financial and practical support Citizens Advice • citizensadvice.org.uk • Help for legal, financial and other practical issues through free, independent and confidential advice

Question (100 words): What kind of support does Macmillan Cancer Support offer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Macmillan Cancer Support offers a wide range of support including information, support centers, and online communities. You can contact them via their helpline at 0808 808 0000 or visit macmillan.org.uk.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Macmillan Cancer Support • macmillan.org.uk • Helpline: 0808 808 0000 • A wide range of support including information, support centres and online communities

Question (100 words): Where can I find individual confidential advice and support groups for people affected by cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Maggie’s offers individual confidential advice through nurses and advisors based at local Maggie’s centers, as well as information and support groups for people affected by cancer and their families. Visit maggies.org for more information.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Maggie’s • maggies.org • Individual confidential advice through nurses and advisors based at local Maggie’s centres, as well as information and support groups for people affected by cancer and their families

Question (100 words): What resources are available for people facing financial insecurity due to cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Turn2Us provides information and practical help for people facing financial insecurity. Visit turn2us.org.uk for assistance.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Turn2Us • turn2us.org.uk • Information and practical help for people facing financial insecurity

Question (100 words): How can I get help with returning to work or finding employment after a cancer diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Working With Cancer offers one-to-one coaching to help people with cancer return to work, stay in work, and look for work. They also provide advice to employers. Visit workingwithcancer.co.uk for more information.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Working With Cancer • workingwithcancer.co.uk • One-to-one coaching to help people with cancer return to work, stay in work and look for work. Also offers advice to employers to help employees navigate cancer in the workplace

Question (100 words): What services does Breast Cancer Now offer for people affected by breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast Cancer Now offers life-changing support, world-class research, and change-making campaigns to help people affected by breast cancer. They provide free services, support over 290 researchers, and fight for the best possible treatment and care.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Life-changing support Whoever you are, and whatever your experience of breast cancer, our free services are here. World-class research We support over 290 of the brightest minds in breast cancer research. Change-making campaigns We fight for the best possible treatment, services and care for everyone affected by breast cancer

Question (100 words): How can I contact Breast Cancer Now for support or information?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can contact Breast Cancer Now by calling their helpline on 0808 800 6000 or visiting their website at breastcancernow.org for reliable breast cancer information.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Call 0808 800 6000 to talk things through with our helpline nurses. Visit breastcancernow.org for reliable breast cancer information.

Question (100 words): What is the charitable status and registration details of Breast Cancer Now?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast Cancer Now is a company limited by guarantee registered in England (9347608) and a charity registered in England and Wales (1160558), Scotland (SC045584), and Isle of Man (1200).

Question (100 words): How can I support Breast Cancer Now's vital work?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can support Breast Cancer Now's vital work by making donations or gifts in wills. Visit breastcancernow.org/give to learn more about how you can help.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’d like to support us, go to breastcancernow.org/give

Question (100 words): What is breast reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast reconstruction is surgery to create a new breast shape after surgery to remove your whole breast (mastectomy) or part of the breast (breast-conserving surgery). The aim is to create a breast shape that looks as natural as possible and matches the breast on the other side in size, shape, and position.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast reconstruction is surgery to create a new breast shape. It may be done after surgery to remove your whole breast (mastectomy) or part of the breast (breast-conserving surgery).

Question (100 words): When can breast reconstruction be done?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast reconstruction can be done at the same time as a mastectomy or breast-conserving surgery (immediate reconstruction) or months or years later (delayed reconstruction). Some people may be offered reconstruction as a 2-stage operation known as a delayed-immediate reconstruction.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may have reconstruction: • At the same time as a mastectomy or breast-conserving surgery (immediate reconstruction) • Months or years later (delayed reconstruction)

Question (100 words): What are the types of breast reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A new breast shape can be created using a breast implant, your own tissue from another part of the body, or a combination of an implant and your own tissue. Your treatment team will explain the benefits and limitations of the options suitable for you.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A new breast shape can be created using: • A breast implant • Your own tissue from another part of the body • A combination of an implant and your own tissue

Question (100 words): Who is part of the treatment team for breast reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your treatment team usually includes a breast surgeon (sometimes called an oncoplastic surgeon), a plastic surgeon, and a breast care nurse or breast reconstruction nurse.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your treatment team will usually include a: • Breast surgeon, sometimes called an oncoplastic surgeon • Plastic surgeon • Breast care nurse or breast reconstruction nurse

Question (100 words): How does radiotherapy affect breast reconstruction options?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Radiotherapy can increase the risk of scar tissue forming around an implant and can affect a reconstruction that uses your own tissue, making the breast feel firmer, reducing its size, and possibly altering its shape. Your treatment team will discuss suitable options for your individual case.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Radiotherapy can increase the risk of scar tissue forming around an implant. It can also affect a reconstruction that uses your own tissue, making the breast feel firmer, reducing its size and possibly altering its shape.

Question (100 words): Can men have breast reconstruction after a mastectomy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Reconstruction is not commonly offered to men who have a mastectomy for breast cancer, but you can talk to your treatment team to find out what options are suitable to improve the appearance and evenness of the chest after surgery.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Reconstruction is not commonly offered to men who have a mastectomy for breast cancer. But you can talk to your treatment team to find out what options are suitable to improve the appearance and evenness of the chest after surgery.

Question (100 words): What if I am advised not to have breast reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Some people are advised not to have breast reconstruction due to the type or stage of their breast cancer, or because they have other medical conditions that increase the risk of complications after surgery. Your surgeon should explain the reasons why, and you can ask for a second opinion if needed.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some people are advised not to have breast reconstruction. This may be because of the type or stage of their breast cancer, or because they have other medical conditions that increase the risk of complications after surgery.

Question (100 words): How does smoking affect breast reconstruction options?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Smoking significantly increases the risk of developing complications from surgery and may affect your options for reconstruction. Your breast care nurse or surgeon is likely to advise you to stop smoking before and after your operation to reduce this risk.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Smoking significantly increases the risk of developing complications from surgery and may affect your options for reconstruction.

Question (100 words): Why do women choose to have breast reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Women choose to have breast reconstruction for different reasons, such as restoring their natural appearance, improving confidence, or helping them feel more confident in intimate or sexual relationships. It's important to make a decision based on what's right for you.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Women choose to have breast reconstruction for different reasons. You may want to restore your natural appearance after breast cancer surgery.

Question (100 words): What are the limitations of breast reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): While most women are satisfied with the result, not everyone’s experience is positive. A reconstructed breast will not feel, look, or move exactly the same as a natural breast. There will be loss of sensation and potential need for more surgery to improve symmetry.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A reconstructed breast will not feel, look or move exactly the same as your natural breast. It will often be a slightly different size and shape.

Question (100 words): Will a reconstructed breast have a nipple?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Reconstructed breasts may or may not have a nipple. Some women may have their nipple removed as part of the operation, while others may have the option of a nipple-sparing mastectomy or nipple grafting.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Reconstructed breasts may or may not have a nipple. Women who have a mastectomy may have their nipple removed as part of the operation.

Question (100 words): What are the benefits of immediate reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The benefits of immediate reconstruction include having a breast shape straight away, potentially better cosmetic results if the skin and nipple are preserved, and possibly less scarring compared to delayed reconstruction.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Benefits of immediate reconstruction • You’ll have a breast shape straight away, which may help you feel more confident with your appearance after surgery

Question (100 words): What are the benefits of delayed reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The benefits of delayed reconstruction include having completed most or all breast cancer treatment before reconstruction, more time to consider options, and potentially better management of pre-existing medical conditions.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Benefits of delayed reconstruction • You will have completed most or all your breast cancer treatment before you have reconstruction

Question (100 words): What are the limitations of immediate reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The limitations of immediate reconstruction include a longer operation and recovery time, potential delays in additional treatments if complications arise, and possible effects of radiotherapy on the reconstruction’s appearance.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Limitations of immediate reconstruction • Your operation and recovery will be longer than having a mastectomy without reconstruction

Question (100 words): What are the limitations of delayed reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The limitations of delayed reconstruction include being flat after mastectomy until reconstruction, potentially less good cosmetic appearance compared to immediate reconstruction, more scarring, inability to keep the nipple, and potential effects of previous radiotherapy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Limitations of delayed reconstruction • You’ll be flat after your mastectomy and may want to wear a breast prosthesis for symmetry until you have your reconstruction

Question (100 words): How can I help decide whether to have breast reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): It can be helpful to talk to other women who have had breast reconstruction or chosen not to have it. Support services like Someone Like Me, Keeping Abreast, and Flat Friends can provide information and support to help you make your decision.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It can be helpful to talk to other women who have had breast reconstruction before making your decision.

Question (100 words): What should I expect during and after breast reconstruction surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): During and after surgery, you should expect to have a new breast shape created, potential differences in sensation, and a recovery period that may involve additional hospital appointments and operations to achieve the desired cosmetic result.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: During and after surgery: what to expect

Question (100 words): Where can I find support for breast reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can find support through organizations like Breast Cancer Now, Keeping Abreast, and Flat Friends. These organizations offer information, support, and the opportunity to connect with others who have undergone similar experiences.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Finding support

Question (100 words): What is the role of a breast care nurse in breast reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A breast care nurse provides support, information, and guidance throughout the breast reconstruction process. They can help you understand your options, prepare for surgery, and manage your recovery.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your treatment team will usually include a: • Breast care nurse or breast reconstruction nurse

Question (100 words): What factors should I consider when deciding on the timing of breast reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): When deciding on the timing of breast reconstruction, consider whether you want a breast shape immediately after surgery (immediate reconstruction) or prefer to have it later (delayed reconstruction). Think about the benefits and limitations of each option, your overall treatment plan, and your personal preferences.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Choosing whether to have breast reconstruction or when to have it is a complex and personal decision.

Question (100 words): What are the benefits of immediate breast reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The benefits of immediate breast reconstruction include having a breast shape straight away, which may help you feel more confident with your appearance after surgery. If the skin of the breast and the nipple are preserved, the cosmetic results can be better than with a delayed reconstruction. There may also be less scarring than with a delayed reconstruction.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Benefits of immediate reconstruction • You’ll have a breast shape straight away, which may help you feel more confident with your appearance after surgery • If the skin of the breast and the nipple are preserved, the cosmetic results can be better than with a delayed reconstruction• There may be less scarring than with a delayed reconstruction

Question (100 words): What are the limitations of immediate breast reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The limitations of immediate breast reconstruction include a longer operation and recovery time compared to having a mastectomy without reconstruction. If complications such as infection occur, this may delay additional treatments like chemotherapy or radiotherapy. Radiotherapy after surgery can sometimes affect the appearance of the reconstruction, potentially requiring more surgery in the future.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Limitations of immediate reconstruction• Your operation and recovery will be longer than having a mastectomy without reconstruction• If you develop complications after surgery that slow down wound healing, such as an infection, this may occasionally delay any additional treatments such as chemotherapy or radiotherapy• If you’re having radiotherapy after surgery, it can sometimes affect the appearance of immediate reconstruction, which may mean you need more surgery in the future

Question (100 words): What are the benefits of delayed breast reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The benefits of delayed breast reconstruction include having completed most or all of your breast cancer treatment before reconstruction. You’ll have more time to consider your options and make a decision about the type of reconstruction you would like. If you have pre-existing medical conditions, having a delayed reconstruction may allow these to be managed so the operation can be done safely.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Benefits of delayed reconstruction • You will have completed most or all your breast cancer treatment before you have reconstruction• You’ll have more time to consider your options and make a decision about the type of reconstruction you would like• If you have pre-existing medical conditions, having a delayed reconstruction may allow these to be managed so the operation can be done safely

Question (100 words): What are the limitations of delayed breast reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The limitations of delayed breast reconstruction include being flat after your mastectomy and potentially needing to wear a breast prosthesis for symmetry until reconstruction. The cosmetic appearance may not be as good as immediate reconstruction, and there may be more scarring. You will not be able to keep your nipple. Previous radiotherapy may limit your options, and there may be a long wait in some areas.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Limitations of delayed reconstruction • You’ll be flat after your mastectomy and may want to wear a breast prothesis for symmetry until you have your reconstruction. This could be many months or years• The cosmetic appearance of delayed reconstruction may not be as good as having an immediate reconstruction• There may be more scarring with delayed reconstruction• You will not be able to keep your nipple • If you have had previous radiotherapy, this may limit your options for delayed reconstructi

Question (100 words): How can I prepare for breast reconstruction surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To prepare for breast reconstruction surgery, discuss the procedure thoroughly with your surgeon to ensure you understand the process and have realistic expectations. Ask about the scars, whether you can keep your nipple, and view photographs of previous reconstructions. You may also request to speak with someone who has had the same type of reconstruction.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Preparing for reconstruction Can you show me where the scars would be on my body and what they would look like? Can I keep my nipple? If not, what are my options to recreate a nipple in the future? Can you show me any photographs or images of your previous breast reconstructions? Can I see the type of implant I might have? Can I speak to someone who has had the same type of reconstruction?

Question (100 words): What is the recovery time for breast reconstruction surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The recovery time for breast reconstruction surgery varies depending on the type of procedure. For implant reconstruction, the recovery time is usually shorter than for reconstruction using your own tissue. Your surgeon will provide specific details about your expected recovery time.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Recovery How long would I have to stay in hospital? What drains or dressing may I have? What is the recovery time for this operation? How much pain is there likely to be? When would I be able to move about, exercise and drive? Would I need to wear a support bra or support underwear after the operation?

Question (100 words): Will I need additional surgery after breast reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You may need additional surgery after breast reconstruction to achieve a better match between the reconstructed breast and your natural breast. This could be due to changes in weight, the need to replace a damaged implant, or to address issues like hardening around the implant.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: After reconstruction What will my breast look and feel like after surgery? Will I need any additional surgery or procedures after my reconstruction? Can I see pictures of breast reconstructions?

Question (100 words): What are the different types of breast implants used in reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): There are two types of breast implants used in reconstruction: fixed-volume implants, which are usually filled with silicone, and tissue expander implants, which are gradually filled with saline over time to stretch the skin. The choice depends on your specific situation and the recommendations of your surgeon.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Types of breast implant There are 2 types of breast implant. Fixed-volume implant A fixed-volume implant has a silicone outer shell and is usually filled with silicone. Tissue expander implant An expander implant is an empty implant or one that’s partly filled with silicone, which has a silicone outer lining. After surgery, the implant is gradually filled or “inflated” over time using salt water (saline).

Question (100 words): How is immediate reconstruction using an implant performed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Immediate reconstruction using an implant can be done as a single procedure where a fixed-volume silicone implant is inserted at the same time as your mastectomy, or as a 2-stage procedure where a temporary tissue expander implant is used and later replaced with a fixed-volume silicone implant.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: How implant reconstruction is done Immediate reconstruction Immediate reconstruction using an implant can be done as a single or 2-stage procedure. Single procedure A fixed-volume silicone implant is inserted in front of or under the chest muscle at the same time as your mastectomy. 2-stage procedure Some women have a temporary tissue expander implant which is expanded over time and later replaced with a fixed-volume silicone implant.

Question (100 words): How long do breast implants typically last?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Most breast implants are expected to last between 10 and 20 years. However, you do not need to have your implant replaced unless you are having problems with it.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: How long implants last Most breast implants are expected to last between 10 and 20 years and will probably need replacing at some point. However, you do not need to have your implant replaced unless you are having problems with it.

Question (100 words): What is a tissue expander implant and how is it used?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A tissue expander implant is an empty or partly filled implant that is gradually inflated with saline over time to stretch the skin. It is often used when there is not enough skin left on the chest to comfortably cover and support an implant, especially in delayed reconstruction. It may not be suitable if you have had radiotherapy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Tissue expander implant An expander implant is an empty implant or one that’s partly filled with silicone, which has a silicone outer lining. After surgery, the implant is gradually filled or “inflated” over time using salt water (saline). This type of reconstruction is often considered if you do not have enough skin left on your chest to comfortably cover and support an implant, especially if you’re having delayed reconstruction. It may not be suitable if you have had radiotherapy.

Question (100 words): Can I see examples of breast reconstructions before my surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, it can be helpful to see photographs or images of different types of reconstruction. While looking at images online or in booklets can be useful, asking to see photographs from your own surgeon can provide a more personalized view and help you prepare for the procedure.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Can I see pictures of breast reconstructions? People often want to see photographs or pictures of different types of reconstruction. While it may be helpful to look at images online or in booklets, asking to see photographs from your own surgeon can be a good way to help you prepare.

Question (100 words): What are the benefits of having reconstruction using an implant?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The benefits of having reconstruction using an implant include a quicker operation, shorter recovery time, less scarring, and usually a good cosmetic result. There are typically no additional scars elsewhere on your body.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Benefits of having reconstruction using an implant • The operation is usually quicker than breast reconstruction using your own tissue• Recovery time is usually shorter than breast reconstruction using your own tissue • There’s usually less scarring and no additional scars elsewhere on your body• Reconstruction using an implant can give a good cosmetic result

Question (100 words): What are the limitations of having reconstruction using an implant?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The limitations of having reconstruction using an implant include the implant feeling firmer and colder, moving less naturally than reconstruction using your own tissue, and potential differences in shape when not wearing a bra. There may be visible scars, less sensation in the reconstructed breast, and the need for future surgeries to replace or adjust the implant.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Limitations of having reconstruction using an implant • Implants can feel firmer and colder and move less naturally than reconstruction using your own tissue • When you’re not wearing a bra, there may be a more obvious difference in shape with the natural breast, as the reconstructed breast is less likely to droop• You’ll have scars on or around the reconstructed breast • As with all types of reconstruction, the reconstructed breast will have less or no sensation compared to the natural breast •

Question (100 words): What is a fixed-volume implant and how is it used in reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A fixed-volume implant has a silicone outer shell and is usually filled with silicone. It is the simplest type of reconstruction operation and typically has a quicker recovery time compared to other types of reconstruction.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Fixed-volume implant A fixed-volume implant has a silicone outer shell and is usually filled with silicone. Using a fixed-volume implant alone is the simplest type of reconstruction operation. The recovery time is usually quicker than for other types of reconstruction.

Question (100 words): What is the role of a surgical mesh in breast reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A surgical mesh, such as ADM (acellular dermal matrix) made from animal tissue or synthetic alternatives, is used during breast reconstruction to support the breast implant. It is attached to the chest muscle to create a pocket that holds the implant in place, helping to create a natural droop, shape, and contour.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Supporting the breast implant A surgical mesh can be used during breast reconstruction to support the breast implant. It’s attached to the chest muscle to create a pocket that holds the implant in place. This helps create a natural droop, shape and contour.

Question (100 words): What is a dermal sling and when might it be used?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A dermal sling is a procedure where your own tissue from the lower half of the breast is used to support the implant. This type of surgery is likely to reduce your breast size and may require further surgery to the other breast to achieve a better match.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have larger, more droopy breasts, your surgeon may consider using your own tissue from the lower half of the breast to support the implant. This procedure is known as a dermal sling. Having this type of surgery is likely to reduce your breast size. You may need further surgery to the other breast, either at the same time or in the future, to get a better match.

Question (100 words): Can reconstruction delay my other cancer treatments like chemotherapy and radiotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Reconstruction can potentially delay other cancer treatments. If complications such as infection occur after surgery, this may slow down wound healing and delay additional treatments like chemotherapy or radiotherapy. It’s important to discuss this with your surgeon.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Reconstruction and your other treatment Can reconstruction delay my other cancer treatments, like chemotherapy and radiotherapy? If I need radiotherapy will this affect my options for reconstruction?

Question (100 words): What should I ask my surgeon before deciding on breast reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Before deciding on breast reconstruction, you should ask your surgeon about the best type of reconstruction for you, the benefits and limitations of the procedure, whether you are suitable for immediate reconstruction, how reconstruction might affect your other cancer treatments, and what the recovery process will involve.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Questions to ask your surgeon Discussing your operation with your breast or plastic surgeon before deciding is important. They’ll want to make sure you fully understand the process and, if you’re having reconstruction, have realistic expectations of how your reconstructed breast will look and feel.

Question (100 words): What is oncoplastic surgery and how is it used in breast-conserving surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Oncoplastic surgery is a technique used in breast-conserving surgery to maintain the shape and symmetry of the breast when cancer is removed. This involves repositioning the remaining breast tissue to fill the area where the cancer was removed, known as therapeutic mammoplasty.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Reconstruction with breast-conserving surgery Combining surgery to remove the cancer with techniques to improve the look of the breast is called oncoplastic surgery. Repositioning the remaining breast tissue During the same operation to remove the cancer, the remaining breast tissue can be repositioned to shape the breast and fill the area where the cancer was removed. This type of surgery is known as therapeutic mammoplasty.

Question (100 words): What are the two main ways to place breast implants during reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The two main ways to place breast implants are under the chest muscle and in front of the chest muscle. Placing the implant under the chest muscle helps to keep it in place and hide its outline, often using a surgical mesh for support. Placing the implant in front of the chest muscle is a newer technique, also using a surgical mesh for support and a more natural appearance.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Inserting the implant under the chest muscle helps to keep the implant in the right place and hide its outline.... Placing the implant in front of the chest muscle is a newer technique and may not be suitable for everyone.

Question (100 words): What is breast animation deformity?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast animation deformity occurs when the chest wall muscle contracts after surgery, causing the breast implant and overlying skin to move. This can sometimes be visible within the cleavage area of the breast and may cause discomfort.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Sometimes after surgery the chest wall muscle can contract, causing the breast implant and overlying skin to move. This is known as breast animation deformity.

Question (100 words): Are breast implants safe?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Implants used in the UK meet specific safety standards, and surgeons continue to recommend them for women considering breast reconstruction. However, there are very rare types of cancer associated with breast implants, known as BIA-ALCL and BIA-SCC.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Implants used in the UK meet specific safety standards and surgeons continue to recommend them to women considering breast reconstruction.... Two very rare types of cancer have been found in a very small number of women with breast implants.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice a lump or swelling around my breast implant?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you develop a lump or swelling around your implant, regardless of how many years later, contact your GP or treatment team immediately so your symptoms can be checked out. In most cases, BIA-ALCL and BIA-SCC can be treated successfully by removing the implant.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The most common symptom for BIA-ALCL and BIA-SCC is a swelling around the implant and breast. If you develop a lump or a swelling around your implant, regardless of how many years later, contact your GP or treatment team so you can get your symptoms checked out.

Question (100 words): What is flap or autologous reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Flap or autologous reconstruction uses your own tissue, including skin, fat, and sometimes muscle, to create a new breast shape. The tissue used is called a flap and is most commonly taken from the tummy (lower abdomen), but can also be taken from the buttock, inner thigh, or back.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: This type of breast reconstruction uses your own tissue, including the skin, fat and sometimes a muscle, to create a new breast shape. The tissue used to create the breast shape is called a flap.

Question (100 words): Who might be offered reconstruction using their own tissue?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Women with larger breasts that have a natural droop may be more suited to flap reconstruction. It is also commonly used in delayed reconstruction, particularly if you have had radiotherapy. Women who do not want to have an implant may also prefer this option.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Women with larger breasts that have a natural droop may be more suited to this technique. Flap reconstruction is commonly used in delayed reconstruction, particularly if you have had radiotherapy.

Question (100 words): When might flap reconstruction not be suitable?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Flap reconstruction may not be suitable if you have pre-existing health conditions such as diabetes, if you smoke, if you are very overweight (have a high BMI), or if you are very slim and may not have enough tissue to use.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Flap reconstruction may not be suitable if: • You have pre-existing health conditions, such as diabetes • You smoke, as smoking significantly increases your risk of complications • You’re very overweight (have a high BMI), as your risk of complications is much higher • You’re very slim, as you may not have enough tissue to use

Question (100 words): How will the reconstructed breast look and feel using my own tissue?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Using your own tissue means the reconstructed breast will look and feel more similar to your natural breast compared to using an implant. It may provide a better match with your other breast in the long term, though it will usually have less or no sensation.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Using your own tissue means the reconstructed breast will look and feel more similar to your natural breast, compared to using an implant.... However, a reconstructed breast will usually have less or no sensation compared to your natural breast.

Question (100 words): What are the benefits of having reconstruction using my own tissue?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The benefits include a closer appearance and feel to your natural breast, changes in the reconstructed breast similar to your other breast if you gain or lose weight, a natural droop as you age, and less likelihood of needing further surgery in the future compared to implant reconstruction.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Benefits of having reconstruction using your own tissue... The appearance and feel can be much closer to your natural breast compared to implant reconstruction... The reconstructed breast will develop a natural droop as you age... Although you may have a longer operation or more operations initially, you’re less likely to need further surgery in the future compared to implant reconstruction

Question (100 words): What are the limitations of having reconstruction using my own tissue?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The limitations include scars on your body where the tissue flap was taken from, a longer operation, hospital stay, and recovery time than implant reconstruction, less or no sensation in the reconstructed breast, and possible differences in color, texture, or hair on the transferred skin.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Limitations of having reconstruction using your own tissue... You’ll have scars on your body where the tissue flap was taken from, as well as scars on or around the reconstructed breast... It usually involves a longer operation, hospital stay and recovery time than implant reconstruction... As will all types of reconstruction, the reconstructed breast will have less or no sensation compared to the natural breast... The area of skin that is transferred from a different part of your body may be a

Question (100 words): How is reconstruction using my own tissue done?
Answer (Max 2000 words): During surgery, skin, fat, and sometimes muscle are taken from another part of the body (donor site) and used to create the reconstructed breast. The donor site needs a good blood supply for the reconstruction to be successful. There are two ways your surgeon can achieve this: free flap reconstruction and pedicled flap reconstruction.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: During surgery, skin, fat and sometimes muscle are taken from another part of the body (donor site) and used to create the reconstructed breast.... There are 2 ways your surgeon can achieve this. Free flap reconstruction... Pedicled flap reconstruction

Question (100 words): Why is a good blood supply important for flap reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A good blood supply is crucial, especially for free flap reconstruction, to ensure the tissue remains healthy. If the flap does not have a good blood supply, the tissue may die. You may have specialized scans before your operation to check the blood supply, and the reconstructed breast will be closely monitored post-surgery.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Having a good blood supply is very important, particularly if you’re having a free flap reconstruction. If the flap does not have a good blood supply the tissue may die.... In the first few days after your reconstruction, the reconstructed breast will be closely monitored to check the blood supply is good and the tissue remains healthy.

Question (100 words): What is a DIEP flap reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A DIEP flap reconstruction uses a free flap of skin and fat, but little or no muscle, to form the new breast shape. The flap is taken from the lower abdomen and includes the skin and fat between the belly button and the groin, along with the blood vessels.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A DIEP reconstruction uses a free flap of skin and fat, but little or no muscle, to form the new breast shape. The flap is taken from the lower abdomen. It includes the skin and fat between the belly button and the groin, along with the blood vessels.

Question (100 words): What kind of scarring can I expect after DIEP reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): There will be scarring on the breast and on the abdomen – usually below the bikini line stretching from hip to hip. The belly button is repositioned during this type of surgery, leaving a circular scar around it. If you have a skin-sparing mastectomy without keeping the nipple, there may also be a circular scar around where your nipple was.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There’ll be scarring on the breast and on the abdomen – usually below the bikini line stretching from hip to hip. The belly button is repositioned during this type of surgery, leaving a circular scar around it. If you have a skin-sparing mastectomy without keeping the nipple, there may also be a circular scar around where your nipple was.

Question (100 words): What is an LD flap reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): An LD flap reconstruction uses a large muscle in the back just below the shoulder blade, known as the latissimus dorsi muscle. The skin, fat, muscle, and blood vessels are moved from the back but remain attached to the body at the end nearest the armpit. The flap is then tunneled under the skin below the armpit and brought round to the front of the body to lie on the chest wall and form the new breast.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: This procedure uses a large muscle in the back just below the shoulder blade, known as the latissimus dorsi muscle. The skin, fat, muscle and blood vessels are moved from the back but remain attached to the body at the end nearest the armpit. The flap is then turned and carefully tunnelled under the skin below the armpit. It is brought round to the front of the body to lie on the chest wall and form the new breast.

Question (100 words): What are the possible side effects after LD flap reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After recovering from an LD flap reconstruction, some women may notice weakness or stiffness in the shoulder during everyday activities. This is an important consideration if you’re very active, such as if you regularly swim, climb, row, play tennis, or golf.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: After recovering from an LD flap reconstruction, some women may notice weakness or stiffness in the shoulder during everyday activities. Possible weakness will be an important consideration if you’re very active, for example if you regularly swim, climb, row, play tennis or golf.

Question (100 words): What kind of scarring can I expect after LD reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The scar on the back is usually horizontal and hidden along the bra line, or it can be diagonal. The scar on the breast will vary depending on your shape, the size of your breast, and whether you have the reconstruction done at the same time as your mastectomy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The scar on the back is usually horizontal and hidden along the bra line, or it can be diagonal. The scar on the breast will vary depending on your shape, the size of your breast and whether you have the reconstruction done at the same time as your mastectomy.

Question (100 words): What are SGAP and IGAP flap reconstructions?
Answer (Max 2000 words): SGAP and IGAP flap reconstructions use fat and skin taken from the buttock to create a new breast shape. SGAP uses tissue from the upper buttock, while IGAP uses tissue from the lower buttock. Tissue taken from the buttock area can feel firmer than your natural breast tissue.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Two procedures use fat and skin taken from the buttock to create a new breast shape: • SGAP (superior gluteal artery perforator) flap – tissue from the upper buttock • IGAP (inferior gluteal artery perforator) flap – tissue from the lower buttock Tissue taken from the buttock area can feel firmer than your natural breast tissue.

Question (100 words): What kind of scarring can I expect after SGAP/IGAP reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): There will be a scar and an indentation in the top of the buttock area (SGAP) or lower buttock crease (IGAP). One buttock may be smaller than the other one, which may be noticeable when wearing tighter fitting clothing.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There will be a scar and an indentation in the top of the buttock area (SGAP) or lower buttock crease (IGAP). One buttock may be smaller than the other one, which may be noticeable when wearing tighter fitting clothing.

Question (100 words): What are the free flap procedures that involve taking tissue from the thigh?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Several free flap procedures involve taking tissue from the upper, inner thigh. These include TUG/TMG (transverse upper/myocutaneus gracilis) flap, DUG (diagonal upper gracilis) flap, PAP (profunda artery perforator) flap, and LTP (lateral thigh perforator) flap. These procedures may be suitable for women with small or medium-sized breasts.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A number of free flap procedures involve taking tissue from the upper, inner thigh. These include: • TUG/TMG (transverse upper/myocutaneus gracilis) flap • DUG (diagonal upper gracilis) flap • PAP (profunda artery perforator) flap • LTP (lateral thigh perforator) flap These procedures may be suitable for women with small or medium-sized breasts.

Question (100 words): What type of underwear should I wear after breast reconstruction surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You may need to wear supportive underwear, such as a support bra, for several weeks after surgery to reduce swelling, bruising, and fluid collection. It's advisable to have at least two support bras for alternating use. If tissue was taken from your tummy, buttock, or inner thigh, you may also need support pants or shorts.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may have to wear supportive underwear for some weeks after surgery to reduce the risk of swelling, bruising and fluid collection.

Question (100 words): Where will my scars be located after inner thigh flap reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After inner thigh flap reconstruction, you will have a scar in the fold of the groin extending to the fold of the buttock area. Additionally, there will be a scar on the breast where the flap is placed.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The scar is placed in the fold of the groin and runs to the fold of the buttock area. You will also have a scar on the breast where the flap is placed.

Question (100 words): What is lipomodelling and when is it used?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Lipomodelling, or fat transfer, involves taking fat from one part of the body and injecting it into the breast. It can be used after breast-conserving surgery to improve appearance, after breast reconstruction to adjust size or shape, or before delayed breast reconstruction to improve skin after a mastectomy and radiotherapy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: This technique involves taking fat from 1 part of the body, such as the tummy, thigh or lower back, and injecting it into the breast.

Question (100 words): How long do I need to stay in the hospital after breast reconstruction surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The hospital stay varies depending on the type of reconstruction. For implant reconstruction, you may stay 1–3 days. For other types like DIEP/SIEA, LD, SGAP/IGAP, and TUG/TMG/PAP/DUG/LTP, the stay is usually 3–5 days.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Hospital stay 1–3 days 3–5 days 3–5 days 3–5 days 3–5 days

Question (100 words): Will I lose sensation in my breast after reconstruction surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, loss of sensation in the breast is common after most types of breast reconstruction surgery, regardless of the method used.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Sensation in breast after surgery? Loss of sensation Loss of sensation Loss of sensation Loss of sensation Loss of sensation

Question (100 words): What are the common side effects after lipomodelling?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common side effects after lipomodelling include small scars where fat was removed, bruising, swelling, and pain in the area where the fat was taken. Sometimes, a lump known as fat necrosis can form in the injection area.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You’ll usually have some small scars where fat has been removed. Bruising, swelling and pain in the area where the fat is taken is common and will usually settle over time. Sometimes a lump, known as fat necrosis, can form in the area where fat was injected

Question (100 words): How long is the recovery time after breast reconstruction surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Recovery time varies by the type of reconstruction. For implant reconstruction, recovery is 4–6 weeks. For other types like DIEP/SIEA, LD, SGAP/IGAP, and TUG/TMG/PAP/DUG/LTP, recovery is 6–12 weeks.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Recovery time 4–6 weeks 6–12 weeks 6–12 weeks 6–12 weeks 6–12 weeks

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience ongoing pain after breast reconstruction surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience ongoing pain that does not improve after breast reconstruction surgery, you should inform your treatment team so they can assess you and provide appropriate pain management.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have ongoing pain that does not improve, let your treatment team know so they can assess you.

Question (100 words): What exercises should I do after breast reconstruction surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A physiotherapist or your breast care nurse or surgeon may give you specific exercises to do after your surgery. These exercises may be tailored to the type of breast reconstruction you had. If lymph nodes under your arm were operated on, you may also receive exercises to help regain arm and shoulder movement.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A physiotherapist or your breast care nurse or surgeon may give you some exercises to do after your surgery. These exercises may be specific to the type of breast reconstruction you have had.

Question (100 words): What is nipple reconstruction and when is it done?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Nipple reconstruction is a procedure to create a nipple if it cannot be preserved during a mastectomy. It is usually done several months after breast reconstruction surgery to allow the breast to heal and settle into the correct position.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Nipple reconstruction is usually done several months after your breast reconstruction surgery.

Question (100 words): What are the options for creating a nipple after breast reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Options for creating a nipple after breast reconstruction include surgical nipple reconstruction, nipple and areola tattooing, or using prosthetic nipples. The choice depends on personal preference and the advice of your treatment team.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: This can be done using surgery or a nipple tattoo, or a combination of both.

Question (100 words): What is involved in nipple and areola tattooing?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Nipple and areola tattooing involves using tattooing techniques to create the appearance of a nipple and areola. It can be done to enhance the appearance of a surgically reconstructed nipple or to create the appearance without surgical reconstruction. The procedure may be done over several outpatient appointments.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Nipple and areola tattooing is an option if you have had a nipple reconstruction. It can give a more natural appearance and match with the opposite breast.

Question (100 words): What are prosthetic nipples and how are they used?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Prosthetic nipples are artificial nipples made of soft silicone that can be worn on a reconstructed breast. They are either self-sticking or come with special skin glue to hold them in place. They are available in different sizes and skin colors, and some hospitals offer custom-made options to match the other breast.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Prosthetic nipples are artificial nipples made of soft silicone that can be worn on a reconstructed breast.

Question (100 words): What type of pain relief will I receive after breast reconstruction surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After breast reconstruction surgery, you will receive pain relief, commonly through a device called a PCA (patient-controlled analgesia), which delivers pain relief directly into your vein. After a day or two, you will usually continue with pain relief tablets, which you may also take home.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You’ll be given pain relief after your operation. It’s common after breast reconstruction to have pain relief through a device called a PCA (patient-controlled analgesia).

Question (100 words): How is the blood supply to the reconstructed breast monitored after surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you have reconstruction using your own tissue, your reconstructed breast will be closely monitored to ensure it has a good blood supply and there is no swelling. You may be given padding or a special blanket to keep the area warm in the first 24 to 48 hours to improve blood flow.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have reconstruction using your own tissue, your reconstructed breast will be monitored closely. This is to make sure the area has a good blood supply and there’s no swelling.

Question (100 words): When can I return to normal activities after breast reconstruction surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The time to return to normal activities depends on the type of reconstruction and your general health. Gradually reintroducing activities is usually the best approach. You can find more detailed information in the booklet 'Your operation and recovery'.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: How long it takes to get back to your normal daily activities will depend on what type of reconstruction you have had. Gradually reintroducing activities slowly is generally the best way.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I'm unhappy with the size or shape of my reconstructed breast?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you are unhappy with the size or shape of your reconstructed breast or your other breast, you should inform your breast care nurse or surgeon. They can discuss possible options with you, which may include further surgery to achieve better symmetry.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re unhappy with the size or shape of the reconstructed breast or your other breast, let your breast care nurse or surgeon know. They can talk to you about possible options.

Question (100 words): How long does it take for the reconstructed breast to heal and settle?
Answer (Max 2000 words): It can take several months for your reconstructed breast to fully heal and settle, and for your scars to fade. Patience is important during this period.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It can take several months for your reconstructed breast to heal and settle and for your scars to fade.

Question (100 words): What are the considerations for different types of breast reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Considerations vary by the type of reconstruction. For example, implant reconstruction may not be suitable if you smoke or have pre-existing health conditions. Flap reconstructions may affect your ability to do certain sports and are not suitable for those with a high BMI or who smoke.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: May not be suitable if you smoke May not be suitable if you: • Have pre-existing health conditions • Have scars on your abdomen from previous surgery • Smoke • Have a high BMI • Are very slim

Question (100 words): What is the typical surgery time for different types of breast reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The surgery time varies by the type of reconstruction. Implant reconstruction typically takes 1.5–3 hours, while other types like DIEP/SIEA, LD, SGAP/IGAP, and TUG/TMG/PAP/DUG/LTP usually take 4–6 hours.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Surgery time 1.5–3 hours 4–6 hours 4–6 hours 4–6 hours 4–6 hours

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice bleeding and bruising after reconstruction surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you notice bleeding and bruising after reconstruction surgery, it's important to monitor the area for swelling, discomfort, and hardness. If a large haematoma develops, you may need an operation to stop the bleeding. Bruising is common and usually resolves within a few weeks.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Sometimes blood collects in the reconstructed breast, causing swelling, discomfort and hardness. This is called a haematoma. If a very large haematoma develops in the first few days after surgery, you may need an operation to stop the bleeding. Bruising to the reconstructed breast, and any area where tissue was taken, is common. It usually goes away after a few weeks.

Question (100 words): How will I know if I have a wound infection after reconstruction surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Signs of a wound infection include the wound feeling tender, swollen, or warm to touch, redness in the area, fluid (discharge) from the wound, and feeling generally unwell with a raised temperature. Contact your breast care nurse, surgeon, or GP immediately if you experience these symptoms.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Contact your breast care nurse, surgeon or GP straight away if you have any signs of a wound infection, such as: The wound feeling tender, swollen or warm to touch, Redness in the area, Fluid (discharge) from the wound, Feeling generally unwell with a raised temperature.

Question (100 words): What are the reasons for delayed wound healing after reconstruction surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Delayed wound healing can be caused by infection, pre-existing health conditions such as diabetes, being overweight, and smoking. Most wounds heal within 6 weeks, but some may take longer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Reasons for delayed wound healing include: Infection, Pre-existing health conditions such as diabetes, Being overweight, Smoking.

Question (100 words): What is a seroma and how is it treated?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A seroma is a collection of fluid that can develop in the reconstructed breast or any area tissue was taken from. The fluid is normally reabsorbed naturally over time. If a seroma causes discomfort, is large, or does not reduce in size, your surgeon may draw off the fluid with a needle and syringe.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A collection of fluid can develop in the reconstructed breast or any area tissue was taken from. This is called a seroma. The fluid is normally reabsorbed naturally over time. If a seroma causes discomfort, is large or does not reduce in size, your surgeon may draw off the fluid with a needle and syringe.

Question (100 words): What happens if the tissue flap fails after reconstruction surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If the tissue flap does not have a good enough blood supply, part or all of the flap may fail. Your treatment team will monitor the reconstruction closely. If the blood supply is insufficient, the surgeon will need to remove the affected tissue. Your surgeon will discuss possible options for further reconstruction.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: With all flap reconstructions, there’s a small risk the flap does not have a good enough blood supply. This can cause part or all of the flap to fail. Your treatment team will monitor the reconstruction closely in the days straight after your operation. If they’re concerned, you may need another operation to try to assess the blood supply. If the blood supply is not good enough, the surgeon will need to remove the affected tissue.

Question (100 words): What is capsular contracture and how is it treated?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Capsular contracture is a condition where the scar tissue capsule around an implant toughens and tightens, making the breast feel hard and possibly distorting its shape. It may cause pain. Treatment may involve removing the implant and capsule, possibly replacing it with another implant or discussing other reconstruction options.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: After implant reconstruction, a thin layer of scar tissue builds up around the implant to form a capsule. This is part of the healing process. In most cases this capsule stays soft, but sometimes it can toughen and tighten around the implant. This can make the breast feel hard and may distort the shape of the breast. Some people also have pain. When this happens, it’s called capsular contracture.

Question (100 words): Can implants be damaged during physical activities?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Implants are designed to be durable and are not easily damaged during physical activities. Modern implant linings are strong, and the silicone gel is firm, making the risk of leaks and tears small. However, if you notice any change in the shape of your reconstructed breast, or if it becomes misshapen, uncomfortable, or swollen, inform your GP, surgeon, or breast care nurse.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some people worry about damaging their implant if they’re doing activities such as sports. Implants do not get damaged easily. Modern implant linings are strong, and the silicone gel is firm, which makes the risk of leaks and tears small.

Question (100 words): What causes rippling after implant reconstruction and how is it treated?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Rippling, or wrinkling, can occur after implant reconstruction, especially in slim individuals or those with implants placed in front of the chest muscle. Your surgeon may suggest injecting fat from another part of your body into the affected area to improve the appearance.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Implants can sometimes crease. This can cause wrinkling or rippling which you may notice in any part of the breast. This is often more common in people who are slim or who have had their implant placed in front of the chest muscle.

Question (100 words): What are the risks of bulges or hernias after flap reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After some tissue flap reconstructions, there’s a small risk of a bulge or hernia in the area the tissue was taken from. A hernia occurs when part of an internal organ, often a small piece of the intestine, bulges through a weak area in a muscle. You’ll usually need an operation to repair a hernia. The risk is lower if the tissue flap does not include a muscle.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: After some tissue flap reconstructions, there’s a small risk of a bulge or hernia in the area the tissue was taken from. A hernia happens when part of an internal organ, often a small piece of the intestine, bulges through a weak area in a muscle.

Question (100 words): Will I lose sensation in the reconstructed breast?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Loss of sensitivity in the reconstructed breast can be difficult to come to terms with. You may also experience loss of sensation in the area where a tissue flap was taken. Nerve pain and altered sensation may improve over time, but for some people, the sensation will not return.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Loss of sensitivity in the reconstructed breast can be difficult to come to terms with. You may also have loss of sensation in the area where a tissue flap was taken. You may have nerve pain and altered sensation while your reconstruction is healing. This may improve over time, but for some people the sensation will not return.

Question (100 words): What is fat necrosis and how is it treated?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Fat necrosis is a condition where a lump forms if an area of fatty tissue in the reconstructed breast is damaged or if the blood supply is poor. The lump usually softens over time, and the body will break it down. If symptoms persist, your surgeon will discuss possible treatment options.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A lump can form if an area of fatty tissue in the reconstructed breast is damaged or if the blood supply is poor. It can also happen in the area where a tissue flap was taken. The medical name for this is fat necrosis.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice a new lump in my reconstructed breast?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you notice a new lump or any changes in your reconstructed breast, inform your treatment team immediately so they can check it out. This is important for early detection and management of any potential issues.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you notice a new lump or any changes in your reconstructed breast, let your treatment team know so they can check it out.

Question (100 words): Will I need mammograms after breast reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You will not have mammograms on the reconstructed breast after a mastectomy, as there is no breast tissue to be scanned. However, you’ll be offered regular mammograms on your remaining breast and any remaining breast tissue if you had breast-conserving surgery.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You will not have mammograms on the reconstructed breast after a mastectomy. This is because there is no breast tissue to be scanned. You’ll be offered regular mammograms on your remaining breast.

Question (100 words): What should I look out for after breast reconstruction surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After breast reconstruction surgery, be aware of any changes to the breast, chest, or surrounding area. Look out for changes in appearance or shape, lumps or lumpy areas, changes in skin texture or swelling in the upper arm, and redness or a rash on the skin or scar line of your reconstructed breast.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Whatever type of surgery you have, be aware of any changes to the breast, chest or surrounding area afterwards. This is important even if you’re having follow-up appointments or regular mammograms.

Question (100 words): How should I care for my scars after reconstruction surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your treatment team will advise you on when you can start moisturising and massaging your scars to help them heal. It’s important to use high factor suncream on your scars after surgery. Initially, scars will feel uneven and may feel tight and tender. They are often red to begin with but fade and become less obvious over time.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your treatment team can tell you when you can start moisturising and massaging your scars to help them heal. It’s important to use high factor suncream on your scars after your surgery. At first your scars will feel uneven and may feel tight and tender. Scars are often red to begin with but fade and become less obvious over time.

Question (100 words): What are hypertrophic and keloid scars, and how are they treated?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Hypertrophic scars are raised scars that can take several years to settle. Keloid scars are similar but continue to grow and can cover normal tissue even after healing. They can be painful, tender, and itchy. If concerned about your scars, inform your breast care nurse, surgeon, or GP for assessment and possible treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Sometimes the body can produce too much collagen, causing scars that are more raised than usual. These are called hypertrophic scars and can take several years to settle. Some people develop keloid scarring. This is similar to a hypertrophic scar but continues to grow and can cover normal tissue even after it has healed. Keloid scars can be painful, tender and itchy.

Question (100 words): What support organizations are available for breast cancer patients considering reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Several organizations offer support and information for breast cancer patients considering reconstruction, including the Association of Breast Surgery (ABS), British Association of Plastic, Reconstructive and Aesthetic Surgeons (BAPRAS), Flat Friends, Keeping Abreast, and Macmillan Cancer Support. These organizations provide practical, emotional, and financial support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Association of Breast Surgery (ABS) has an information section about breast surgery and reconstruction on its website. British Association of Plastic, Reconstructive and Aesthetic Surgeons (BAPRAS) The website has information on breast reconstruction and gives access to a list of plastic surgery units. Flat Friends For women who have had a mastectomy without breast reconstruction. Offers support and information through their website and a closed Facebook group. Keeping Abreast Information and su

Question (100 words): What should I record in my notes after breast reconstruction surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): In your notes, record questions to ask your surgeon, your reconstruction options, names and contact details of your treatment team, dates of referrals, hospital appointments or surgery, and details of any local support services.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may want to use this space to record information such as: Questions to ask your surgeon, Your reconstruction options, Names and contact details of your treatment team, Dates of referrals, hospital appointments or surgery, Details of any local support services

Question (100 words): How can I get more information about breast reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can get more information about breast reconstruction by visiting the websites of organizations such as Breast Cancer Now, Association of Breast Surgery (ABS), British Association of Plastic, Reconstructive and Aesthetic Surgeons (BAPRAS), and Macmillan Cancer Support. These websites offer detailed information and support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Useful organisations: Association of Breast Surgery (ABS), British Association of Plastic, Reconstructive and Aesthetic Surgeons (BAPRAS), Macmillan Cancer Support

Question (100 words): What is the role of Breast Cancer Now in supporting breast cancer patients?
