Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast Cancer Now provides life-changing support, world-class research, and change-making campaigns for breast cancer patients. They offer free services, support over 290 researchers, and fight for the best possible treatment and care for everyone affected by breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: We’re Breast Cancer Now, the research and support charity. However you’re experiencing breast cancer, we’re here. Life-changing support, World-class research, Change-making campaigns

Question (100 words): Why was I referred to the breast clinic?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You were referred to the breast clinic by your GP because you have a symptom or breast change that needs investigating. A referral does not mean you have cancer; it could be normal breast changes or a benign condition.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your GP may refer you to a breast clinic if you have a symptom or breast change that needs investigating. A referral to a breast clinic does not mean you have cancer.

Question (100 words): It's normal to feel worried. You can manage anxiety by keeping busy, talking to family and friends, or contacting specialist nurses through the helpline 0808 800 6000.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Having investigations for a breast problem can be a worrying and stressful time. You can also speak to our specialist nurses through our free helpline 0808 800 6000.

Question (100 words): What happens during a breast examination at the clinic?
Answer (Max 2000 words): During a breast examination, a doctor or nurse will physically check your breasts while you are sitting and lying down. They will also examine the lymph nodes under your arm and around your neck.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The doctor or nurse may want to check both your breasts when you are sitting, and again when you are lying down. They’ll also examine the lymph nodes (glands) under your arm and around your neck.

Question (100 words): What is a mammogram and how is it done?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A mammogram is a breast x-ray. You will remove your clothing from the waist up, and your breasts will be placed one at a time on the x-ray machine. Your breast will be pressed down firmly, and at least two pictures of each breast will be taken.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A mammogram is a breast x-ray. You’ll be asked to remove your clothing from the waist up and stand in front of the mammography machine.

Question (100 words): What is a 3D mammogram and how does it differ from a regular mammogram?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A 3D mammogram, or digital breast tomosynthesis (DBT), uses lower dose x-rays to make 3D images. The breast is positioned similarly to a regular mammogram, but the x-ray arm rotates around the breast, taking multiple pictures at different angles.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: 3D mammograms (tomosynthesis) Digital breast tomosynthesis (DBT) is a more detailed type of mammogram used in some hospitals. DBT makes 3D images using lower dose x-rays.

Question (100 words): What is an ultrasound scan and how is it performed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): An ultrasound scan uses sound waves to produce an image of the breast tissue. You will undress from the waist up, lie on a couch with your arm above your head, and a handheld scanning probe will be moved over your breast.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: An ultrasound scan uses sound waves to produce an image of the breast tissue. You’ll be asked to undress from the waist up and lie on a couch with your arm above your head.

Question (100 words): What does it mean if my imaging results are described as M1 or U1?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If your imaging results are described as M1 (mammogram) or U1 (ultrasound), it means that the breast tissue appears normal.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: M1 Normal breast tissue U1 Normal breast tissue

Question (100 words): What is a core biopsy and how is it done?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A core biopsy uses a hollow needle to take samples of breast tissue. You will have a local anaesthetic, a small cut is made in the skin, and samples of tissue are taken with the biopsy needle.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Core biopsy A core biopsy (also called a core needle biopsy) uses a hollow needle to take samples of breast tissue.

Question (100 words): What should I expect after having a core biopsy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After a core biopsy, a small dressing or plaster is usually applied. You may experience some aching and bruising for a few days or weeks. Pain relief can be taken if needed.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: After your core biopsy A small dressing or plaster is usually applied. You’ll be asked to keep this on for a day or so afterwards.

Question (100 words): What is a fine needle aspiration (FNA) and how is it performed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Fine needle aspiration (FNA) uses a fine needle and syringe to take a sample of cells. You may have a local anaesthetic first to numb the area.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Fine needle aspiration (FNA) FNA uses a fine needle and syringe to take a sample of cells. You may have a local anaesthetic first to numb the area.

Question (100 words): What is a vacuum assisted biopsy and when is it used?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A vacuum assisted biopsy is used if a previous biopsy did not give a definite result or if the area of concern is difficult to target. It involves using a special needle connected to a vacuum device to collect several samples of breast tissue.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Vacuum assisted biopsy You may be offered a vacuum assisted biopsy if: • A biopsy has not given a definite result and more breast tissue is needed to make a diagnosis

Question (100 words): Why might a metal marker be inserted during a biopsy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A metal marker may be inserted during a biopsy to help locate the area of concern for future procedures. It is usually made of titanium and can be left in place.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Inserting a metal marker Sometimes if the area of concern is small or difficult to see on a mammogram or ultrasound, a small metal marker (or clip) is placed in the breast where the biopsy was taken.

Question (100 words): What does it mean if my biopsy results are described as B2 or C2?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If your biopsy results are described as B2 (core biopsy) or C2 (FNA), it means that the tissue or cells appear benign (not cancerous).
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: B2 Benign (not cancer) C2 Benign (not cancer)

Question (100 words): How long will I be at the breast clinic for my tests?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You may be at the breast clinic for several hours to complete all necessary tests. Your assessment may be done in a one-stop clinic, or you may need to make another appointment to finish your tests.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: How long will it take? You may be at the breast clinic for several hours so you can have all the necessary tests.

Question (100 words): Can I bring someone with me to my breast clinic appointment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, you can usually bring a partner, close friend, or relative for company or support. Some people prefer to go on their own.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can usually take a partner, close friend or relative with you for company or support. Some people prefer to go on their own.

Question (100 words): What should I wear to my breast clinic appointment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You may want to wear a top that’s easy to remove, as you may need to undress from the waist up for certain tests like mammograms and ultrasounds.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may want to wear a top that’s easy to remove.

Question (100 words): What if I need further tests after my initial breast clinic visit?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If further tests are needed, you may be asked to make another appointment to complete them. Your specialist team will guide you through the next steps.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: In some cases, you may be asked to make another appointment to finish your tests.

Question (100 words): How are the results of my breast imaging and biopsy described?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The results of your breast imaging and biopsy are described using letters and numbers. For example, M1 or U1 means normal breast tissue, while M5 or U5 indicates cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: How imaging results are described You may hear your results described as a letter and a number.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience side effects after a biopsy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience side effects like pain, bruising, or tenderness after a biopsy, you can take pain relief as advised. Contact your healthcare provider if symptoms persist or worsen.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: After your core biopsy Once the local anaesthetic wears off, your breast may ache. It may be bruised for the next few days or weeks. You can take pain relief if the area is tender or painful.

Question (100 words): How can I find more information and support during this process?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can find more information and support by visiting breastcancernow.org or calling the helpline on 0808 800 6000. Specialist nurses are available to answer your questions and provide emotional support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can also speak to our specialist nurses through our free helpline 0808 800 6000 and our website breastcancernow.org

Question (100 words): How will I receive my breast clinic results?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You will be informed by the breast clinic on how and when you will receive your results. This could be through a follow-up appointment, over the phone, or by letter. It's advisable to have a support person with you when receiving results and to take notes.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The breast clinic will let you know how and when you’ll get your results. They may ask you to come back for your results, or they may give them to you over the phone or by letter.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I'm anxious about my breast clinic results?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you're feeling anxious about your results, you can contact the free helpline on 0808 800 6000 for support or visit the website breastcancernow.org to discuss your concerns.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re anxious about your results or would like to talk through any concerns, you can call our free helpline on 0808 800 600 0 or visit our website breastcancernow.org

Question (100 words): What does it mean if my breast assessment shows normal changes or a benign condition?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A breast assessment showing normal changes or a benign condition means that no cancerous cells were found. The specialist will explain the condition and whether any treatment or follow-up is needed. It's still important to continue being breast aware and report any changes to your GP.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: For most people, a breast assessment will show normal breast changes or a benign (not cancer) breast condition. In this case, the specialist will explain what it is and whether you need any treatment or follow-up.

Question (100 words): What happens if my results show I have breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If your results indicate breast cancer, a specialist will discuss your diagnosis with you and introduce you to a breast care nurse who can provide support and information. You will receive written information and have a point of contact for further assistance.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If your results show you have breast cancer, a specialist will discuss your diagnosis with you and introduce you to a breast care nurse. They can provide support and written information.

Question (100 words): How can I be breast aware?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Being breast aware involves knowing how your breasts normally look and feel. If you notice any unusual changes, you should see your GP promptly. Regular self-checks and attending mammograms if eligible are also important.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast awareness means getting to know how your breasts look and feel so you know what’s normal for you. If you notice any changes that are unusual for you, see your GP as soon as you can.

Question (100 words): What is the national breast screening programme in the UK?
Answer (Max 2000 words): In the UK, women aged 50 up to their 71st birthday are invited for mammograms every three years as part of the national breast screening programme. This helps detect cancer early, even before symptoms appear.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: In the UK, women aged 50 up to their 71st birthday are invited for mammograms every 3 years as part of a national breast screening programme. Breast screening can detect cancer before you have any symptoms.

Question (100 words): Where can I find more information about benign breast conditions?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can find more information about benign breast conditions on the Breast Cancer Now website at breastcancernow.org or by requesting leaflets at the clinic.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may be given our leaflets about individual benign breast conditions at the clinic. You can also find information about these conditions on our website breastcancernow.org

Question (100 words): What support services are available for breast cancer patients?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast Cancer Now offers a range of free support services including helplines, online resources, and printed materials. You can access these services by calling 0808 800 6000 or visiting breastcancernow.org.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can also find a range of free support services on our website at breastcancernow.org/support-for-you

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice changes in my breasts after getting my results?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you notice any changes in your breasts after receiving your results, it's important to see your GP as soon as possible, regardless of how soon after you got your results.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Even if your results show you have normal breast changes or a benign breast condition, it’s still important to be breast aware (see page 13). Go back to your GP if you notice any changes in your breasts, no matter how soon after you get your results.

Question (100 words): How can I get more information about breast cancer diagnosis and treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can read Breast Cancer Now’s booklets such as 'Diagnosed with breast cancer: what now?' and 'Treating primary breast cancer' for more detailed information. These can be found on their website at breastcancernow.org.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may also want to read our booklets Diagnosed with breast cancer: what now? and Treating primary breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What national guidelines are available for suspected breast cancer referrals?
Answer (Max 2000 words): National guidelines for suspected breast cancer referrals can be found on the websites of NICE for England and Wales, Northern Ireland Guidance for Suspected Cancer for Northern Ireland, and Scottish Referral Guidelines for Suspected Cancer for Scotland.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: National referral guidelines for suspected breast cancer England and Wales National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) nice.org.uk/guidance/ng12 Northern Ireland Northern Ireland Guidance for Suspected Cancer – Red Flag Criteria nican.hscni.net (search for “red flag criteria”) Scotland Scottish Referral Guidelines for Suspected Cancer cancerreferral.scot.nhs.uk

Question (100 words): What is the role of a breast care nurse?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A breast care nurse provides support, written information, and acts as a point of contact for patients diagnosed with breast cancer. They are there to help guide you through your diagnosis and treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If your results show you have breast cancer, a specialist will discuss your diagnosis with you and introduce you to a breast care nurse. They can provide support and written information. They will also be a point of contact for you.

Question (100 words): How can I support Breast Cancer Now’s work?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can support Breast Cancer Now’s work by making a donation or leaving a gift in your will. This helps fund their support services, health information, and research efforts.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: We don’t get any government or NHS funding for our support services or health information. So, we rely on donations and gifts in wills to make our vital work happen. If you’d like to support us, go to breastcancernow.org/give

Question (100 words): What should I do if I need more information about my breast clinic appointment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): For more detailed information about your breast clinic appointment, you can email health-info@breastcancernow.org or visit breastcancernow.org/publications to order or download more copies of the leaflet.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: For a full list of the sources we used to research it: Email health-info@breastcancernow.org You can order or download more copies from breastcancernow.org/publications

Question (100 words): How can I provide feedback on the breast clinic appointment leaflet?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can provide feedback on the breast clinic appointment leaflet by emailing health-info@breastcancernow.org. Your input helps improve the information provided.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: We welcome your feedback on this publication: health-info@breastcancernow.org

Question (100 words): What formats are available for the breast clinic appointment leaflet?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The breast clinic appointment leaflet is available in large print, Braille, and audio CD formats. You can request these by emailing health-info@breastcancernow.org.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: For a large print, Braille or audio CD version: Email health-info@breastcancernow.org

Question (100 words): What is the medical disclaimer for the breast clinic appointment leaflet?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The medical disclaimer states that while Breast Cancer Now makes every effort to ensure the information is accurate, it does not replace professional healthcare advice. Breast Cancer Now does not accept liability for the use of the information contained in the publication.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: We make every effort to ensure that our health information is accurate and up to date, but it doesn’t replace the information and support from professionals in your healthcare team. So far as is permitted by law, Breast Cancer Now doesn’t accept liability in relation to the use of any information contained in this publication, or third-party information included or referred to in it.

Question (100 words): How often is the breast clinic appointment leaflet reviewed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The breast clinic appointment leaflet is reviewed every two years. The next planned review is scheduled for September 2027.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: BCC70 Edition 8, next planned review September 2027

Question (100 words): What is the registered office of Breast Cancer Now?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The registered office of Breast Cancer Now is located at 6th Floor, The White Chapel Building, 10 Whitechapel High Street, London E1 8QS.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Registered Office: 6th Floor, The White Chapel Building, 10 Whitechapel High Street, London E1 8QS.

Question (100 words): How can I contact Breast Cancer Now for help and support?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can contact Breast Cancer Now for help and support by calling their free helpline on 0808 800 6000 or visiting their website at breastcancernow.org.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Call 0808 800 6000 to talk things through with our helpline nurses. Visit breastcancernow.org for reliable breast cancer information.

Question (100 words): What are the different types of breast pain?
Answer (Max 2000 words): There are three types of breast pain: cyclical breast pain, which is related to a woman’s menstrual cycle; non-cyclical breast pain, which is not related to periods and can have various causes; and chest wall pain, which feels like it’s in the breast but originates elsewhere, such as from a pulled muscle or inflammation around the ribs.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There are 3 types of breast pain: • Cyclical breast pain – pain related to a woman’s periods (menstrual cycle) • Non-cyclical breast pain – lasting pain in the breast that’s not related to periods • Chest wall pain – pain that feels as though it’s in the breast but is coming from somewhere else

Question (100 words): What causes cyclical breast pain?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Cyclical breast pain is caused by changing hormone levels during the menstrual cycle. Hormonal changes make the breast tissue more sensitive, leading to pain. It often occurs a week or so before a period and can affect both breasts.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Cyclical breast pain is linked to changing hormone levels during the menstrual cycle. Hormonal changes make the breast tissue more sensitive, which can cause pain.

Question (100 words): How can I manage cyclical breast pain?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Management of cyclical breast pain may include reassurance from your GP that it’s a normal part of your menstrual cycle, dietary changes such as a low-fat diet and reduced caffeine and alcohol, wearing a supportive bra, relaxation therapies, and possibly changing your contraception if it started with the use of hormonal methods.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your GP may suggest changes to your diet that might help to reduce pain, but there’s limited evidence to show these work. These include eating a low-fat diet and increasing the amount of fibre you eat. Your GP may also recommend reducing caffeine and alcohol.

Question (100 words): What are the common causes of non-cyclical breast pain?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Non-cyclical breast pain can be caused by a benign breast condition, previous breast surgery, injury to the breast, having larger breasts, side effects from certain drugs or herbal remedies, and stress or anxiety.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s often unclear what causes non-cyclical breast pain, but it can be related to: • A benign (not cancer) breast condition • Previous surgery to the breast • Injury to the breast • Having larger breasts • A side effect from a drug treatment, such as certain antidepressants, and some herbal remedies such as ginseng • Stress and anxiety

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience new or different breast pain?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience new or different breast pain, or if you have other symptoms like a lump, swelling, or changes to the nipple, you should make an appointment with your GP. They will examine your breasts and may refer you to a breast clinic for further assessment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Make an appointment with your GP if you’re concerned about breast pain that’s new or different for you, or you’ve also got other symptoms in your breast, like a lump, swelling, changes to the nipple or a change in colour.

Question (100 words): How is chest wall pain different from breast pain?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Chest wall pain feels like it’s coming from the breast but actually originates from elsewhere, such as a pulled muscle in the chest or inflammation around the ribs (costochondritis or Tietze syndrome). It can be sharp, spread down the arm, and worsen with movement.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Chest wall pain may feel as though it’s coming from the breast, but really it comes from somewhere else. It’s also known as extra-mammary pain, meaning it’s outside the breast.

Question (100 words): Can changing my diet help with breast pain?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your GP may suggest dietary changes such as a low-fat diet, increased fiber intake, and reduced caffeine and alcohol to help manage breast pain, although the evidence for their effectiveness is limited.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your GP may suggest changes to your diet that might help to reduce pain, but there’s limited evidence to show these work. These include eating a low-fat diet and increasing the amount of fibre you eat. Your GP may also recommend reducing caffeine and alcohol.

Question (100 words): Is wearing a supportive bra helpful for breast pain?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, wearing a supportive and well-fitting bra during the day, during physical activity, and at night can be helpful in managing breast pain.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Wearing a supportive and well-fitting bra during the day, during any physical activity and at night can be helpful.

Question (100 words): Can relaxation therapies help with cyclical breast pain?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Some women have found relaxation therapies, such as relaxation CDs or apps, acupuncture, and aromatherapy, useful in reducing the symptoms of cyclical breast pain.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some women have found relaxation therapy useful in reducing their symptoms of cyclical breast pain, such as relaxation CDs or apps, or other complementary therapies such as acupuncture and aromatherapy.

Question (100 words): What should I do if my breast pain started after beginning hormone replacement therapy (HRT)?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If your breast pain started or increased while taking HRT and does not settle after a short time, inform your GP. HRT can sometimes cause benign changes in the breast that may need to be evaluated by your GP or a specialist.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If your pain started or increased while taking HRT and does not settle after a short time, tell your GP. HRT can sometimes cause benign (not cancer) changes in the breast, which may need to be seen by your GP or specialist.

Question (100 words): Can evening primrose oil help with breast pain?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Some women find that evening primrose or starflower oil, which contain an essential fatty acid called GLA, help with breast pain. However, research has shown that taking additional GLA does not always help the pain. It’s best to consult your GP before use, especially if you have a history of breast cancer or epilepsy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your GP may suggest you try evening primrose or starflower oil (which contain GLA), as some women have found it helps them to feel better generally.

Question (100 words): What over-the-counter pain relief can I use for breast pain?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory pain relief, such as ibuprofen, can help with breast pain, particularly non-cyclical pain. You can apply it directly to the affected area as a gel or take it as a tablet. Paracetamol can also be used. Always consult your doctor or pharmacist before use, especially if you have asthma, stomach ulcers, or kidney problems.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Research has shown that non-steroidal anti-inflammatory pain relief, such as ibuprofen, can help breast pain, particularly non-cyclical pain.

Question (100 words): When might a doctor prescribe tamoxifen for breast pain?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A doctor may consider prescribing tamoxifen for severe, long-lasting breast pain that has not responded to other treatments. Tamoxifen works by blocking the hormone oestrogen and has side effects such as hot flushes, night sweats, and mood changes.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If your pain is severe, goes on for a long time or you’ve tried the things listed above and they have not helped, your doctor may consider giving you a hormone-suppressing drug, such as tamoxifen.

Question (100 words): How is chest wall pain treated?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Treatment for chest wall pain depends on its cause. For a pulled muscle, rest and pain relief such as paracetamol or ibuprofen may help. For inflammation around the ribs (costochondritis or Tietze syndrome), rest, pain relief, and possibly injections of local anaesthetic and steroid may be recommended. Smoking can worsen inflammation, so quitting may help.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Treatment for chest wall pain will depend on what’s causing it. Pulled muscle: If your chest wall pain is caused by a pulled muscle in your chest, this is likely to improve over time and can be treated with pain relief.

Question (100 words): Is breast pain usually a sign of breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast pain on its own is rarely a sign of breast cancer. However, it’s important to see your GP if the pain increases or changes, or if you notice any other changes in your breasts.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Having breast pain on its own is rarely a sign of breast cancer. But it’s still important to go back to your GP if the pain increases or changes, you notice any other changes in your breasts, or you need support.

Question (100 words): How can I keep track of my breast pain?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can use a pain chart to record the amount of breast pain you experience each day. This helps you and your GP or nurse understand when your pain occurs. For premenopausal women, note the day your period starts each month with the letter P.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: This chart is to help you and your GP or nurse to see when your breast pain occurs. Record the amount of breast pain you experience each day by shading in each circle as shown.

Question (100 words): What should I do if breast pain is affecting my daily activities?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If breast pain is affecting your daily activities and making you feel anxious or low in mood, seek support. You can call the free helpline on 0808 800 6000 to speak to a specialist nurse for more information and support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If breast pain is affecting your daily activities, it may make you feel anxious or low in mood. If you’d like more information or support, you can call our free helpline on 0808 800 6000 to speak to one of our specialist nurses.

Question (100 words): Can stress and anxiety cause breast pain?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, stress and anxiety can be related to non-cyclical breast pain. Managing stress through relaxation techniques and seeking support can help alleviate symptoms.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s often unclear what causes non-cyclical breast pain, but it can be related to: • Stress and anxiety

Question (100 words): What are the side effects of tamoxifen?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The side effects of tamoxifen can include hot flushes, night sweats, and mood changes. It’s important to discuss the benefits and possible risks with your doctor before starting this treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Side effects of tamoxifen can include: • Hot flushes • Night sweats • Mood changes

Question (100 words): How can I get more information or support about breast pain?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can get more information or support about breast pain by calling the free helpline on 0808 800 6000 to speak to a specialist nurse. You can also visit breastcancernow.org for reliable information about breast conditions and breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’d like more information or support, you can call our free helpline on 0808 800 6000 to speak to one of our specialist nurses.

Question (100 words): What is a fibroadenoma?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A fibroadenoma is a common benign breast condition that usually feels like a smooth lump in the breast. It is not cancerous and often moves easily under the skin. Fibroadenomas can occur at any age but are more common in younger women.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A fibroadenoma is a very common benign (not cancer) breast condition. It usually feels like a smooth lump in the breast.

Question (100 words): What are the symptoms of a fibroadenoma?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The main symptom of a fibroadenoma is a smooth, easily movable lump in the breast. It is usually painless but can sometimes feel tender or painful, especially just before a period.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A fibroadenoma usually feels like a smooth lump in the breast that moves easily under the skin. Fibroadenomas are usually painless.

Question (100 words): Who is most commonly affected by fibroadenomas?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Fibroadenomas are most commonly found in younger women, particularly those in their 20s and 30s. However, they can occur at any age, including in women who have been through menopause and, very rarely, in men.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Fibroadenomas often start to develop during puberty. They are commonly found in women in their 20s and 30s.

Question (100 words): What are the different types of fibroadenomas?
Answer (Max 2000 words): There are several types of fibroadenomas, including simple fibroadenomas, complex fibroadenomas, giant fibroadenomas, juvenile fibroadenomas, and multiple fibroadenomas. Each type has distinct characteristics and potential implications.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Most fibroadenomas are about 1 to 3cm in size and are called simple fibroadenomas. Some fibroadenomas are called complex fibroadenomas.

Question (100 words): What causes fibroadenomas?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The exact cause of fibroadenomas is unknown, but it is thought that they may develop due to the effects of the hormone oestrogen. They form from a lobule in the breast.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s not known what causes fibroadenomas, but it’s thought they may occur because of the effects of the hormone oestrogen.

Question (100 words): How is a fibroadenoma diagnosed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Diagnosis of a fibroadenoma typically involves a visit to a breast clinic where tests such as an ultrasound scan, a mammogram, and possibly a biopsy may be performed to confirm the diagnosis.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: At the breast clinic you’ll have a range of tests which may include: An ultrasound scan (using sound waves to produce an image), A mammogram (breast x-ray), A biopsy (using a needle to take a small sample of tissue to be looked at under a microscope).

Question (100 words): Do fibroadenomas require treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Most fibroadenomas do not require treatment. However, if a fibroadenoma is large, complex, or causing discomfort, surgery may be recommended to remove it.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Most fibroadenomas do not need treatment. In most cases you will not need any treatment or follow-up if you have a fibroadenoma.

Question (100 words): What is the procedure for removing a fibroadenoma?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The procedure for removing a fibroadenoma is called an excision biopsy, which is usually performed under general anaesthetic. Another option is a vacuum-assisted excision biopsy, which uses a special needle and vacuum device to remove the fibroadenoma.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The operation is called an excision biopsy and is usually done under general anaesthetic. You may be offered a vacuum assisted excision biopsy to remove a small fibroadenoma.

Question (100 words): Can fibroadenomas change in size?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Most fibroadenomas stay the same size, but some may get smaller or even disappear over time. A small number may get bigger, especially during pregnancy, breastfeeding, or while taking hormone replacement therapy (HRT).
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Most fibroadenomas stay the same size. Some get smaller and some eventually disappear over time.

Question (100 words): Does having a fibroadenoma increase the risk of breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): For most people, having a fibroadenoma does not increase the risk of breast cancer. However, a complex fibroadenoma may very slightly increase the risk.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: For most people, having a fibroadenoma does not increase the risk of developing breast cancer. If you were diagnosed with a complex fibroadenoma, your risk is very slightly increased.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice a lump in my breast?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you notice a lump in your breast, you should see your GP. They may refer you to a breast clinic for further evaluation and testing.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: See your GP if you notice a lump in your breast.

Question (100 words): What happens during a breast clinic appointment for a fibroadenoma?
Answer (Max 2000 words): During a breast clinic appointment, you may undergo tests such as an ultrasound scan, a mammogram, and possibly a biopsy to confirm the diagnosis of a fibroadenoma.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: At the breast clinic you’ll have a range of tests which may include: An ultrasound scan (using sound waves to produce an image), A mammogram (breast x-ray), A biopsy (using a needle to take a small sample of tissue to be looked at under a microscope).

Question (100 words): Is a biopsy always needed to diagnose a fibroadenoma?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A biopsy is not always needed to diagnose a fibroadenoma, especially in younger women. However, it may be required if there is any doubt about the diagnosis.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re under 25, you’re less likely to need a biopsy to confirm whether you have a fibroadenoma. However, you may have a biopsy if there’s any doubt about the diagnosis.

Question (100 words): What are the potential side effects of removing a fibroadenoma?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Potential side effects of removing a fibroadenoma include bruising, pain for a few days, and a slight dent in the breast where the fibroadenoma was removed. The procedure usually does not affect the shape of the breast.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: This procedure can cause some bruising and pain for a few days afterwards. Removing a fibroadenoma does not usually affect the shape of the breast, but there may be a slight dent in the breast where it has been removed.

Question (100 words): Can men get fibroadenomas?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Although very rare, men can get fibroadenomas. The diagnosis and treatment are the same as for women.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Although very rare, men can get fibroadenomas. Fibroadenomas in men are diagnosed and treated in the same way as in women.

Question (100 words): What is a complex fibroadenoma?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A complex fibroadenoma is a type of fibroadenoma where some of the cells have different features when looked at under a microscope. Having a complex fibroadenoma can very slightly increase the risk of developing breast cancer in the future.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some fibroadenomas are called complex fibroadenomas. When these are looked at under a microscope, some of the cells have different features.

Question (100 words): What is a giant fibroadenoma?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A giant fibroadenoma is a fibroadenoma that grows to more than 5cm. These most commonly develop during pregnancy or breastfeeding.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Occasionally, a fibroadenoma can grow to more than 5cm. This may be called a giant fibroadenoma.

Question (100 words): What is a juvenile fibroadenoma?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A juvenile fibroadenoma is a fibroadenoma found in teenage girls.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A fibroadenoma found in teenage girls may be called a juvenile fibroadenoma.

Question (100 words): Can I have more than one fibroadenoma?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, it is possible to have more than one fibroadenoma. While most people have a single fibroadenoma, multiple fibroadenomas can occur.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: While most people have a single fibroadenoma, it’s possible to have more than 1.

Question (100 words): What should I do for follow-up care after a fibroadenoma diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): For most fibroadenomas, no follow-up care is needed. However, you should go back to your GP or the breast clinic if the fibroadenoma gets bigger or if you notice any other changes.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: In most cases you will not need any treatment or follow-up if you have a fibroadenoma. Usually you’ll only be asked to go back to your GP or the breast clinic if a fibroadenoma gets bigger or you notice any other changes.

Question (100 words): What are breast cysts?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast cysts are benign, fluid-filled sacs that develop in the breast tissue. They are a common cause of breast lumps and can occur in one or both breasts. They form when milk-producing glands fill with fluid.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast cysts are a benign (not cancer) condition. They’re 1 of the most common causes of a breast lump, and can develop in either 1 or both breasts.

Question (100 words): Who is most likely to develop breast cysts?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast cysts are most common in women aged between 35 and 50, especially those who are premenopausal or postmenopausal and taking hormone replacement therapy (HRT). They are less common after menopause unless HRT is used.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You’re more likely to get breast cysts if you are: • Between 35 and 50 years old • Premenopausal (still have periods) • Postmenopausal (no longer have periods) but taking HRT

Question (100 words): What do breast cysts feel like?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast cysts can feel like soft or hard lumps and vary in size from a few millimeters to several centimeters. They may feel uncomfortable or painful, particularly before a period due to hormone changes.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast cysts can feel like a soft or hard lump depending on the amount of fluid in them. They can be any size, ranging from a few millimetres to several centimetres.

Question (100 words): How are breast cysts diagnosed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast cysts are diagnosed through a combination of a physical examination, mammogram, and ultrasound scan. If a lump is felt, a fine needle may be used to draw off fluid to confirm it’s a cyst.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: At the breast clinic you’ll have a breast examination. You may also have a mammogram or an ultrasound scan (using sound waves to produce an image of the breast), or both.

Question (100 words): Do I need treatment for a breast cyst?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Most breast cysts do not require treatment as they often go away on their own. If a cyst is large or causes discomfort, the fluid may be drawn off using a fine needle.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have a breast cyst, you will not usually need any treatment or follow-up. Most cysts go away by themselves and are nothing to worry about.

Question (100 words): Can breast cysts be prevented?
Answer (Max 2000 words): There is no known way to prevent breast cysts as they occur naturally in response to hormone changes. Using HRT may increase the risk of developing cysts.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Cysts happen in response to normal hormone changes and there’s no known way to prevent them. If you take HRT, this can increase your risk of developing new cysts.

Question (100 words): Do breast cysts increase the risk of breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Having breast cysts does not increase the risk of developing breast cancer. However, it’s important to continue monitoring your breasts and report any changes to your GP.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Having a breast cyst does not increase your risk of developing breast cancer in the future.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I find a lump in my breast?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you find a lump in your breast, it’s important to see your GP. They may refer you to a breast clinic for further examination and tests to determine the nature of the lump.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you see your GP because you have found a breast lump, they may be able to say whether it feels like a cyst. However, they’re still likely to refer you to a breast clinic where you’ll be seen by specialist doctors or nurses and have further tests.

Question (100 words): What happens during an ultrasound for breast cysts?
Answer (Max 2000 words): During an ultrasound for breast cysts, sound waves are used to create an image of the breast. This helps determine if a lump is solid or fluid-filled. It is a painless procedure.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: An ultrasound scan (using sound waves to produce an image of the breast) can help show if a lump is solid or fluid-filled.

Question (100 words): Why might a mammogram be less effective in younger women?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Younger women often have denser breast tissue, which can make mammogram images less clear. This density can mask normal changes or benign conditions like cysts.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Younger women’s breast tissue can be dense, which can make the x-ray image less clear.

Question (100 words): What is the procedure for aspirating fluid from a breast cyst?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To aspirate fluid from a breast cyst, a fine needle is inserted into the cyst, and the fluid is drawn off using a syringe. This procedure is usually guided by ultrasound.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If the lump can be easily felt, your specialist may put a fine needle into it and draw off the fluid to confirm that it’s a fluid-filled cyst.

Question (100 words): What should I expect after having fluid aspirated from a breast cyst?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After fluid is aspirated from a breast cyst, you may feel some discomfort and the area might be bruised and tender for a few days. Pain relief like paracetamol can help.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You might feel some discomfort as the fluid is being drawn off, and the area may feel bruised and tender for a few days afterwards. Taking pain relief like paracetamol can help.

Question (100 words): Can breast cysts come back after treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, breast cysts can come back or new ones can develop. If this happens, the treatment is usually the same as before.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast cysts can come back or you may develop new cysts. The treatment for cysts is usually the same each time.

Question (100 words): What color can the fluid from a breast cyst be?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The fluid drawn from a breast cyst can vary in color, ranging from clear to very dark. If it is blood-stained, it may be sent to a laboratory for further testing.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The fluid drawn off from the cyst can vary in colour and range from clear to very dark.

Question (100 words): How often should I check my breasts for changes?
Answer (Max 2000 words): It’s important to regularly check your breasts for any new or unusual changes. If you notice anything different, it’s advisable to consult your GP.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Get into the habit of regularly checking your breasts.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice changes in my breasts after a cyst was found?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you notice any changes in your breasts after a cyst was found, it’s important to go back to your GP for further evaluation, regardless of how soon after the cyst was discovered.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s still important to go back to your GP if you notice any changes in your breasts, no matter how soon after your cyst was found.

Question (100 words): Is it normal to feel anxious about having a breast cyst?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, it is normal to feel anxious about having a breast cyst. Even though cysts are benign, it’s common to worry about breast cancer. Seeking support and information can help alleviate anxiety.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s normal to feel anxious about having a breast cyst.

Question (100 words): Where can I get more information about breast cysts and breast health?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can get more information about breast cysts and breast health by calling Breast Cancer Now’s free helpline on 0808 800 6000 or visiting their website at breastcancernow.org.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re worried about breast cancer or have questions about breast health, you can call our free helpline on 0808 800 6000 or talk to us online at breastcancernow.org

Question (100 words): What is the importance of being breast aware?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Being breast aware means regularly checking your breasts for any changes and knowing what is normal for you. This helps in early detection of any abnormalities and ensures timely medical consultation.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can find out more about being breast aware in our booklet Know your breasts: a guide to breast awareness and screening.

Question (100 words): How can I get a large print, Braille, or audio CD version of this leaflet?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can request a large print, Braille, or audio CD version of this leaflet by emailing health-info@breastcancernow.org.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: For a large print, Braille or audio CD version: Email health-info@breastcancernow.org

Question (100 words): What is fat necrosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Fat necrosis is a benign (non-cancerous) condition where damaged fatty tissue forms a lump in the breast. It often occurs after an injury or surgery.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Fat necrosis is a benign (not cancer) breast condition. It usually feels like a firm, round lump in the breast.

Question (100 words): What are the common symptoms of fat necrosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common symptoms include a firm, round lump in the breast, which is usually painless, and thickened, red, or bruised skin around the lump.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Common symptoms of fat necrosis can include: • A firm, round lump or lumps in the breast, which are usually painless • Thickened, red or bruised skin around the lump

Question (100 words): Can fat necrosis cause pain?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Less commonly, fat necrosis can cause tenderness or pain, dimpled skin, or an inverted nipple.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Less common symptoms include: • Tenderness or pain • Dimpled skin or indentation around the lump • The nipple being pulled in (inverted)

Question (100 words): Who is most likely to get fat necrosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Fat necrosis is more common in women around the age of 50, though it can affect women of any age and, rarely, men.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Fat necrosis can affect women of any age, but it’s more common in women around the age of 50. Men can also get fat necrosis, but this is rare.

Question (100 words): What causes fat necrosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Fat necrosis can be caused by trauma or injury to the breast, including accidents, surgery, biopsies, radiotherapy, or fat transfer procedures.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It can be caused by any type of trauma or injury to the breast. This can include: • Damage or injury caused by an accident such as a seatbelt injury or fall • Breast surgery including lumpectomy, breast reduction, breast reconstruction or enlargement • Breast biopsy • Radiotherapy to the breast • Fat transfer (lipomodelling) – when fat taken from one part of the body is injected into the breast

Question (100 words): How is fat necrosis diagnosed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Diagnosis involves a breast examination, mammogram, ultrasound scan, and possibly a biopsy to confirm the condition.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: At the breast clinic, you may have: • A breast examination • Mammogram (breast x-ray) • Ultrasound scan – using high-frequency sound waves to produce an image • Core biopsy – using a hollow needle to take a small sample of tissue to be looked at under a microscope, several tissue samples may be taken at the same time • Fine needle aspiration (FNA) – using a fine needle and syringe to take a sample of cells to be looked at under a microscope

Question (100 words): Does fat necrosis require treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Fat necrosis usually does not require treatment as it is harmless and the body often breaks it down naturally over time.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Fat necrosis does not usually need treatment Fat necrosis is harmless so you will not usually need any treatment or follow-up.

Question (100 words): When might surgery be needed for fat necrosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Surgery may be recommended if the biopsy is inconclusive, the area is uncomfortable, or the lump does not go away or gets bigger.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: However, an operation to remove your fat necrosis may be recommended if: • The biopsy has not given enough information to confirm a diagnosis of fat necrosis • The area of fat necrosis is uncomfortable or tender • The lump or lumpy area does not go away by itself or gets bigger

Question (100 words): What type of surgery is used to remove fat necrosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): An excision biopsy, which can be done under local or general anaesthetic, is typically used to remove the affected tissue.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you need surgery, you’ll usually have an excision biopsy. This is an operation to remove the dead or damaged tissue. This can be done using either a local anaesthetic (where the area is numbed) or general anaesthetic (medication to make you sleep).

Question (100 words): What are the options for pain relief for fat necrosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If fat necrosis causes discomfort, pain relief options include paracetamol or anti-inflammatory drugs like ibuprofen.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If your fat necrosis causes discomfort but you’re not having an operation to remove it, your doctor may suggest treating it with pain relief such as paracetamol or an anti-inflammatory drug like ibuprofen.

Question (100 words): Can fat necrosis form cysts?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, fat necrosis can sometimes form cysts filled with oily fluid, known as oil cysts, which usually do not require treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Sometimes, within an area of fat necrosis, the damaged tissue breaks down to an oily fluid that can form as a cyst (oil cyst).

Question (100 words): Does having fat necrosis increase my risk of breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): No, having fat necrosis does not increase your risk of developing breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Having fat necrosis does not increase your risk of developing breast cancer in the future.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice changes in the area of fat necrosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): It’s important to go back to your GP if you notice any changes to the area of fat necrosis or anywhere else in your breasts.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s important to go back to your GP if you notice any changes to the area of fat necrosis or anywhere else in your breasts.

Question (100 words): How long does it take for fat necrosis to go away?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The body usually breaks down fat necrosis naturally over time, which can take several months to years depending on the size of the lump.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: In most cases the body will break down the fat necrosis naturally over time. Depending on the size of the lump, this can take several months and sometimes years.

Question (100 words): Can fat necrosis look like breast cancer on scans?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, fat necrosis can sometimes look like breast cancer on mammograms and scans, which is why a biopsy may be needed for confirmation.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Fat necrosis can sometimes look like breast cancer on mammograms and scans.

Question (100 words): Why might a biopsy be needed for fat necrosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A biopsy may be needed if there is any doubt about the diagnosis from mammograms or ultrasound scans to confirm that it is fat necrosis.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If there’s any doubt about what the mammogram or ultrasound scan shows, you’ll have a biopsy.

Question (100 words): What is a vacuum-assisted excision biopsy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A vacuum-assisted excision biopsy involves making a small cut in the skin under local anaesthetic and using a special device to suck out the fat necrosis.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may be offered a vacuum assisted excision biopsy to remove your fat necrosis. This involves making a small cut in the skin under local anaesthetic. Breast tissue is then sucked out using a special device until the fat necrosis is removed.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I’m worried about breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you’re worried about breast cancer or have questions about breast health, you can call the free helpline on 0808 800 6000 or visit breastcancernow.org for more information.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re worried about breast cancer or have questions about breast health, you can call our free helpline on 0808 800 6000 or talk to us online at breastcancernow.org

Question (100 words): Is fat necrosis more common in younger or older women?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Fat necrosis is more common in women around the age of 50, though it can affect women of any age.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Fat necrosis can affect women of any age, but it’s more common in women around the age of 50.

Question (100 words): What tests might I have if I’m under 40 and have symptoms of fat necrosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you’re under 40, you’re more likely to have an ultrasound than a mammogram due to denser breast tissue, though a mammogram may still be needed.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re under 40, you’re more likely to have an ultrasound than a mammogram. Younger women’s breast tissue can be denser which can make the x-ray image less clear. However, you may still need a mammogram to complete your assessment.

Question (100 words): What are breast calcifications?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast calcifications are small calcium salts that can occur anywhere in the breast. They are very common in women but can also be found in men. These calcifications do not cause any symptoms and are usually not felt. They are typically caused by benign changes in the breast.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast calcifications are small calcium salts that can occur anywhere in the breast. They’re very common in women but can be found in men. Breast calcifications do not cause any symptoms and you will not be able to feel them. They’re usually caused by benign (not cancer) changes in the breast.

Question (100 words): Do breast calcifications cause any symptoms?
Answer (Max 2000 words): No, breast calcifications do not cause any symptoms. You will not be able to feel them. They are usually discovered incidentally during a mammogram or other breast imaging tests.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast calcifications do not cause any symptoms and you will not be able to feel them.

Question (100 words): What causes breast calcifications?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast calcifications are usually due to benign changes in the breast that happen as you get older. They can also form because of other benign conditions, such as a fibroadenoma or breast cyst, or due to infections, injuries, or previous breast surgeries.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast calcifications are usually due to benign changes in the breast that happen as you get older.

Question (100 words): How are breast calcifications diagnosed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast calcifications are usually found by chance on a routine screening mammogram or during an investigation at a breast clinic for another breast problem. They appear as bright white dots or specks on a mammogram.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast calcifications are usually found by chance on a routine screening mammogram or an investigation at a breast clinic for another breast problem.

Question (100 words): What are the types of breast calcifications?
Answer (Max 2000 words): There are two main types of breast calcifications: microcalcifications, which are very small and can sometimes be an early sign of cancer, and macrocalcifications, which are larger and usually benign.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Microcalcifications are very small. They often occur because of benign changes, but occasionally microcalcifications can be an early sign of cancer. Macrocalcifications are larger. They usually occur because of benign changes and do not need to be investigated.

Question (100 words): What further tests are done if calcifications are found?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If calcifications look indeterminate or suspicious, further tests such as a tomosynthesis mammogram, ultrasound scan, core biopsy, or vacuum-assisted biopsy may be conducted to make an accurate diagnosis.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If the calcifications look indeterminate (uncertain) or suspicious, you’ll need more tests to help make an accurate diagnosis.

Question (100 words): Do breast calcifications need to be treated?
Answer (Max 2000 words): In most cases, breast calcifications do not need to be treated. If they are benign, they do not need to be removed and will not cause any harm. Treatment is only considered if there is a suspicion of cancer or an unusual change.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: In most cases you will not need any treatment for breast calcifications. If the calcifications look benign, they do not need to be removed and will not cause you any harm.

Question (100 words): When is surgery needed for breast calcifications?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Surgery may be needed to remove the area of calcification if it’s not possible to get a biopsy, if a biopsy does not confirm a diagnosis, if biopsy results show an unusual change (atypia), or if there is a sign of early cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may need an operation to remove the area of calcification if: • It’s not possible to get a biopsy of the area • A biopsy does not confirm a diagnosis • Biopsy results show an unusual change (called atypia) • Biopsy results show a sign of an early cancer

Question (100 words): How is the area for surgery located?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The exact position of the calcification is located using a process called localisation. This involves inserting a small magnetic or radioactive seed into the breast, which is then used to guide the surgeon during the operation.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: As calcifications cannot be felt, before the operation the exact position has to be ‘located’ so the surgeon can remove the right area. This is called localisation.

Question (100 words): What happens after surgery for breast calcifications?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After surgery, you may experience soreness and discomfort, which can be managed with pain relief. There will be a scar, but it should fade over time. Follow-up will depend on the results of the surgery and any further tests needed.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: After your operation, you may feel soreness and discomfort, which you can manage with pain relief. There will be a scar, but this should fade in time.

Question (100 words): Do breast calcifications increase the risk of breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Most breast calcifications do not increase the risk of breast cancer. However, if the calcifications are due to an unusual change, this may slightly increase the risk. It’s important to continue being breast aware and report any changes to your GP.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Most breast calcifications do not increase your risk of breast cancer. If the breast calcifications are due to an unusual change, this may slightly increase your risk of breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice changes in my breasts after being told I have calcifications?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you notice any changes in your breasts, no matter how soon after being told you have calcifications, it’s important to go back to your GP. Being breast aware and reporting any changes is crucial for early detection.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s important to continue to be breast aware and go back to your GP if you notice any changes in your breasts, no matter how soon after you were told you have calcifications.

Question (100 words): What is a core biopsy and how is it done?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A core biopsy uses a hollow needle to take a small sample of breast tissue. It is done using a mammogram or ultrasound for guidance and is performed under local anaesthetic, where the area is numbed. Several tissue samples may be taken at the same time.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A core biopsy uses a hollow needle to take a small sample of breast tissue. It’s done using a mammogram or ultrasound for guidance. Several tissue samples may be taken at the same time. This procedure will be done using a local anaesthetic, where the area is numbed.

Question (100 words): What is a vacuum-assisted biopsy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A vacuum-assisted biopsy is a procedure that takes a little longer than a core biopsy. After an injection of local anaesthetic, a small cut is made in the skin, and a special needle connected to a vacuum device is placed through this. Breast tissue is then sucked through the needle into a collecting chamber.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: This procedure takes a little longer than a core biopsy. After an injection of local anaesthetic, a small cut is made in the skin. A special needle connected to a vacuum device is placed through this. Using a mammogram or ultrasound as a guide, breast tissue is then sucked through the needle by the vacuum into a collecting chamber.

Question (100 words): What is a vacuum-assisted excision biopsy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A vacuum-assisted excision biopsy is a procedure similar to a vacuum-assisted biopsy but may remove more tissue. This can sometimes avoid the need for an operation under general anaesthetic.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Occasionally, you may have a vacuum assisted excision biopsy to remove an area of calcification. This is a similar procedure to a vacuum assisted biopsy, but more tissue may be removed.

Question (100 words): Why might a metal marker be inserted during a biopsy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A small metal clip or marker may be placed in the breast where the biopsy has been taken. This is done so the area can easily be found again if you need another biopsy or surgery. The clip is usually made of titanium and can be safely left in the breast.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Sometimes a small metal clip (or marker) may be placed in the breast where the biopsy has been taken. This is so the area can easily be found again if you need another biopsy or surgery.

Question (100 words): What is localisation in the context of breast surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Localisation is the process of identifying the exact position of the calcification in the breast before surgery. This is done using a small magnetic or radioactive seed inserted into the breast, which helps the surgeon locate the area to be removed.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: As calcifications cannot be felt, before the operation the exact position has to be ‘located’ so the surgeon can remove the right area. This is called localisation.

Question (100 words): What type of anaesthetic is used during surgery for breast calcifications?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The surgery for breast calcifications is done under general anaesthetic, where you are given medication to make you sleep. This allows the procedure to be performed without you feeling any pain.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The operation is done under general anaesthetic, where you’re given medication to make you sleep.

Question (100 words): What follow-up is needed after the removal of breast calcifications?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If tests show the calcifications are due to benign changes, no further treatment or follow-up is needed. If the calcifications are part of another benign condition or an unusual change, you will be informed if follow-up is necessary. If calcifications are an early sign of breast cancer, your treatment team will discuss next steps.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If tests show the calcifications are due to benign changes, you will not need any more treatment or follow-up. If the calcifications are part of another benign breast condition or an unusual change (atypia), you’ll be told if you need any follow-up.

Question (100 words): How can I be breast aware after being diagnosed with calcifications?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To be breast aware, regularly check your breasts for any changes, such as lumps, thickening, or changes in the skin. Report any new or unusual changes to your GP promptly. You can find more information in the booklet 'Know your breasts: a guide to breast awareness and screening.'
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can find out more about being breast aware in our booklet Know your breasts: a guide to breast awareness and screening.

Question (100 words): What is hyperplasia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Hyperplasia is a benign breast condition where there's an increase in the number of cells lining the ducts or lobules of the breast. It does not usually cause any symptoms.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Hyperplasia is a benign (not cancer) breast condition. It does not usually cause any symptoms in the breast.

Question (100 words): What is atypical hyperplasia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Atypical hyperplasia is a benign condition where cells lining the ducts or lobules increase in number and develop an unusual pattern or shape. It increases the risk of breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Atypical hyperplasia (also called epithelial hyperplasia) happens when cells lining the ducts or lobules increase in number and develop an unusual pattern or shape.

Question (100 words): How is hyperplasia diagnosed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Hyperplasia and atypical hyperplasia are usually diagnosed by chance when breast tissue removed during a biopsy or surgery is examined under a microscope.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: DiagnosisHyperplasia and atypical hyperplasia do not usually cause any symptoms. Because of this, they’re usually found by chance when breast tissue that has been removed during a biopsy or breast surgery is examined under a microscope in the laboratory.

Question (100 words): Do I need treatment for usual ductal hyperplasia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): No, usual ductal hyperplasia does not require any treatment or follow-up.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Usual ductal hyperplasia does not need any treatment or follow-up.

Question (100 words): What treatment is available for atypical hyperplasia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): For atypical hyperplasia, more tissue may be removed via a vacuum-assisted excision biopsy or a surgical excision biopsy to examine the area more thoroughly.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have atypical hyperplasia, your doctor may want you to have more tissue removed to examine the area more thoroughly.

Question (100 words): What is a vacuum-assisted excision biopsy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A vacuum-assisted excision biopsy involves numbing the area with local anaesthetic, making a small cut in the skin, and using a special needle connected to a vacuum device to remove breast tissue.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Vacuum assisted excision biopsyAfter an injection of local anaesthetic (where the area is numbed), a small cut is made in the skin. A special needle connected to a vacuum device is placed through this cut.

Question (100 words): What happens during a surgical excision biopsy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): During a surgical excision biopsy, tissue is removed under local or general anaesthetic. Your surgeon may use dissolvable or non-dissolvable stitches, which may need to be removed a few days after surgery.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Surgical excision biopsySometimes a vacuum assisted excision biopsy is not possible. If this is the case, you will have a surgical excision biopsy, under local or general anaesthetic.

Question (100 words): Will I have a scar after a surgical excision biopsy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, the operation will leave a scar, but it will fade over time.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The operation will leave a scar, but this will fade over time.

Question (100 words): Do I need follow-up if I have atypical hyperplasia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, if you have atypical hyperplasia, you may need follow-up such as yearly mammograms, though this depends on your individual circumstances and hospital arrangements.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Follow-upIf you have atypical hyperplasia, you may need follow-up such as yearly mammograms.

Question (100 words): How often should I check my breasts if I have hyperplasia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): It’s important to regularly check your breasts and report any new or unusual changes to your GP, regardless of your hyperplasia diagnosis.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s still important to go back to your GP if you notice any changes in your breasts, no matter how soon after your diagnosis of hyperplasia.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice changes in my breasts?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you notice any changes in your breasts, no matter how soon they appear after your diagnosis, you should go back to your GP for an evaluation.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Go back to your GP if you notice any changes, no matter how soon they appear after your diagnosis of atypical hyperplasia.

Question (100 words): Is hyperplasia common in women under 35?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Hyperplasia is more common in women over 35, but it can affect women of any age.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Hyperplasia usually develops naturally as the breast changes with age. It’s more common in women over 35 but can affect women of any age.

Question (100 words): Can men get hyperplasia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, hyperplasia can affect men, although it is very rare.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Hyperplasia and atypical hyperplasia can also affect men, but this is very rare.

Question (100 words): What is the difference between usual and atypical ductal hyperplasia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Usual ductal hyperplasia does not require treatment, whereas atypical ductal hyperplasia may require further tissue removal for examination due to its increased risk of breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: When hyperplasia occurs in the ducts it’s called ductal hyperplasia. Ductal hyperplasia can be either “usual” or “atypical”. Atypical means “not typical”.

Question (100 words): How can I learn more about being breast aware?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can learn more about being breast aware by reading the booklet 'Know your breasts: a guide to breast awareness and screening' available from Breast Cancer Now.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can find out more about being breast aware in our booklet Know your breasts: a guide to breast awareness and screening.

Question (100 words): Where can I get further information or support?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can get further information or support by calling Breast Cancer Now’s free helpline on 0808 800 6000.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’d like further information or support, call our free helpline on 0808 800 6000.

Question (100 words): What is the risk of breast cancer with usual ductal hyperplasia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Having usual ductal hyperplasia can slightly increase your risk of developing breast cancer in the future, but the risk is very small and does not require treatment or follow-up.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Having usual ductal hyperplasia can slightly increase your risk of developing breast cancer in the future. However, this risk is so small that you will not need treatment or follow-up.

Question (100 words): What is the risk of breast cancer with atypical hyperplasia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Having atypical hyperplasia increases your risk of breast cancer. Your treatment team will explain if and how you will be followed up.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have atypical hyperplasia, your risk of breast cancer is increased. Your treatment team will explain if and how you will be followed up.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I’m worried about my risk of breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you’re worried about your risk of breast cancer, you can speak to your GP or treatment team for more information and support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re worried about your risk of breast cancer, you can speak to your GP or treatment team.

Question (100 words): How can I order or download more copies of this leaflet?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can order or download more copies of this leaflet from breastcancernow.org/publications.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can order or download more copies from breastcancernow.org/publications

Question (100 words): What is an intraductal papilloma?
Answer (Max 2000 words): An intraductal papilloma is a benign, wart-like lump that develops in one or more of the milk ducts in the breast. It is usually found close to the nipple but can be anywhere in the breast. It is most common in women over 40.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Intraductal papilloma is a benign (not cancer) breast condition where a wart-like lump develops in 1 or more of the milk ducts in the breast.

Question (100 words): What are the symptoms of an intraductal papilloma?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Symptoms of an intraductal papilloma may include a lump in the breast and discharge of clear or blood-stained fluid from the nipple. It is usually not painful but may cause some discomfort or pain around the area.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may notice: • A lump in the breast • Discharge of clear or blood-stained fluid from the nipple

Question (100 words): Does having an intraductal papilloma increase breast cancer risk?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A single intraductal papilloma generally does not increase the risk of developing breast cancer. However, having multiple intraductal papillomas or atypical cells within the papilloma may slightly increase the risk.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A single intraductal papilloma generally does not increase the risk of developing breast cancer. If you have multiple intraductal papillomas, you may have a slightly higher risk of developing breast cancer.

Question (100 words): How are intraductal papillomas diagnosed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Intraductal papillomas can be diagnosed during routine breast screening using a mammogram, after breast surgery for nipple discharge, or if you visit your GP with symptoms. You will be referred to a breast clinic for further evaluation by specialist doctors or nurses.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Intraductal papillomas can be found: • During routine breast screening using a mammogram (breast x-ray) • After breast surgery, for example to treat nipple discharge • If you go to your GP with symptoms

Question (100 words): What is an excision biopsy?
