Answer (Max 2000 words): An excision biopsy is a surgical procedure to remove the intraductal papilloma. It can be done under local or general anesthesia. The removed tissue is examined under a microscope to confirm the diagnosis.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may be offered an operation called an excision biopsy to remove the intraductal papilloma. This can be done under a local or general anaesthetic.

Question (100 words): What is a vacuum assisted excision biopsy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A vacuum assisted excision biopsy involves using a special needle connected to a vacuum device to remove breast tissue through a small cut in the skin. This procedure is guided by a mammogram or ultrasound and can often be done without general anesthesia.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may be offered a vacuum assisted excision biopsy to remove the intraductal papilloma. After an injection of local anaesthetic, a small cut is made in the skin. A special needle connected to a vacuum device is placed through this cut.

Question (100 words): What happens if I continue to have nipple discharge after surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If nipple discharge persists after initial surgery, you may need further surgery to remove the affected duct or ducts (microdochectomy) or all the major ducts (total duct excision). This is usually done under general anesthesia.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’ve had surgery and continue to have discharge from your nipple, you may need to have another operation to remove: • The affected duct or ducts (microdochectomy) • All the major ducts (total duct excision, also known as Hadfield’s procedure)

Question (100 words): Will I have a scar after surgery for an intraductal papilloma?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, surgery for an intraductal papilloma will leave a scar. However, this scar will fade over time. Your treatment team will provide information on how to care for the wound.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The operation will leave a scar, but this will fade over time.

Question (100 words): What kind of pain can I expect after surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After surgery, you may experience some bruising and pain for a few days. You may also notice changes in sensation in the breast or nipple area, including sharp, stabbing, or shooting pains. This is normal and should improve over time.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may notice some changes in sensation in the breast or nipple area in the weeks after the operation. This can include sharp, stabbing or shooting pains. This is normal.

Question (100 words): Can I breastfeed after having surgery for an intraductal papilloma?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you have had a total duct excision, you will not be able to breastfeed from that breast. However, you may still be able to breastfeed from the breast if you have had a microdochectomy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’ve had a total duct excision, you will not be able to breastfeed from that breast. However, you may be able to breastfeed from the breast if you have had a microdochectomy.

Question (100 words): How soon can I return to work after surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Most people can return to work after a couple of days following surgery for an intraductal papilloma. Your treatment team will provide specific advice based on your recovery.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Most people can return to work after a couple of days. Your treatment team will let you know if there is anything else to consider while you recover.

Question (100 words): Do I need follow-up appointments after having an intraductal papilloma removed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you had a single intraductal papilloma removed, you will not usually need follow-up appointments. However, if you had multiple papillomas or papillomas with atypical cells, you may need follow-up appointments to monitor your condition.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you had a single intraductal papilloma removed, you will not usually need to go back to the breast clinic for any follow-up appointments. You’re more likely to have follow-up appointments if you had multiple intraductal papillomas or intraductal papillomas that contained atypical cells.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice new changes in my breasts after treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Even after treatment for an intraductal papilloma, it’s important to be breast aware and report any new or unusual changes in your breasts to your GP. Regular breast self-examinations are recommended.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Even though your intraductal papilloma has been removed, it’s still important to be breast aware and go back to your GP if you notice any other changes in your breasts.

Question (100 words): Where can I get more information or support?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can get more information and support by calling Breast Cancer Now’s free helpline on 0808 800 6000. They provide comprehensive resources and support for those affected by breast conditions.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’d like any further information or support, call our free helpline on 0808 800 6000.

Question (100 words): What is the difference between intraductal papilloma and papillary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Intraductal papilloma is a benign breast condition, meaning it is not cancerous. Papillary breast cancer, on the other hand, is a type of breast cancer. Although the names are similar, they are different conditions with different treatments and prognoses.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Although the names are similar, intraductal papilloma is not the same as papillary breast cancer.

Question (100 words): Can men get intraductal papillomas?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, men can get intraductal papillomas, although it is very rare. The condition is more commonly found in women, particularly those over 40.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Men can also get intraductal papillomas, but this is very rare.

Question (100 words): What is juvenile papillomatosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Juvenile papillomatosis is a rarer condition that affects teenage girls and younger women. It involves the development of multiple intraductal papillomas.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A rarer condition called juvenile papillomatosis affects teenage girls and younger women.

Question (100 words): What type of anesthesia is used for excision biopsy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): An excision biopsy for an intraductal papilloma can be performed under either local or general anesthesia, depending on the specific circumstances and patient preference.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: An excision biopsy to remove the intraductal papilloma can be done under a local or general anaesthetic.

Question (100 words): What should I expect during a breast clinic appointment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): During a breast clinic appointment, you will see specialist doctors or nurses who will evaluate your condition. You can find more detailed information about what to expect in Breast Cancer Now’s booklet 'Your breast clinic appointment.'
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You will be referred to a breast clinic where you’ll see specialist doctors or nurses. You can find out more information about what to expect at the breast clinic in our booklet Your breast clinic appointment.

Question (100 words): What are dissolvable stitches and how are they used in surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Dissolvable stitches are used in surgery to close wounds. They dissolve on their own over time and do not need to be removed. Your surgeon may use them during an excision biopsy for an intraductal papilloma.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your surgeon may use dissolvable stitches placed under the skin. These will not need to be removed.

Question (100 words): What is a sclerosing lesion of the breast?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A sclerosing lesion of the breast is a benign (not cancerous) area of hardened breast tissue. It is also known as sclerosis of the breast. The most common types are sclerosing adenosis, radial scars, and complex sclerosing lesions.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A sclerosing lesion of the breast is a benign (not cancer) area of hardened breast tissue. Sometimes it’s also called sclerosis of the breast.

Question (100 words): Who is most commonly affected by sclerosing lesions of the breast?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Sclerosing lesions of the breast are more common in women in their 40s, but they can occur at any age. Men can also get them, though it is very rare.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: They are more common in women in their 40s but can occur at any age. Men can also get sclerosing lesions of the breast, but this is very rare.

Question (100 words): What are the symptoms of sclerosing adenosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Most women with sclerosing adenosis will not notice any symptoms. Occasionally, some may notice a small lump, and very rarely, some may experience pain in one specific area of the breast, which may worsen before a period.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Most women will not notice any symptoms. Occasionally some people may notice a small lump. Others may have pain in their breast, but this is very rare.

Question (100 words): How is sclerosing adenosis diagnosed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Sclerosing adenosis is often diagnosed after a routine mammogram (breast x-ray) or following tests for a different breast problem. If it looks like breast cancer on a mammogram, a biopsy may be needed to confirm the diagnosis.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Sclerosing adenosis is often diagnosed after a routine mammogram (breast x-ray) or following tests for a different breast problem.

Question (100 words): What types of biopsies are used to diagnose sclerosing lesions?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The types of biopsies used include core biopsy, stereotactic core biopsy, vacuum-assisted biopsy, and occasionally excision biopsy. These procedures involve taking samples of breast tissue to examine under a microscope.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Core biopsy, Stereotactic core biopsy, Vacuum assisted biopsy, Excision biopsy

Question (100 words): Is treatment usually needed for sclerosing adenosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You will not usually need any treatment or follow-up for sclerosing adenosis. However, it’s important to continue being breast aware and report any new or unusual changes to your GP.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You will not usually need any treatment or follow-up for sclerosing adenosis.

Question (100 words): Does sclerosing adenosis increase the risk of breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Sclerosing adenosis does not increase the risk of breast cancer. However, it’s still important to be breast aware and know the signs and symptoms to look out for.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Sclerosing adenosis does not give you a higher risk of breast cancer but it’s still important to be breast aware.

Question (100 words): What are radial scars and complex sclerosing lesions?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Radial scars and complex sclerosing lesions are benign areas of hardened breast tissue. They are similar to sclerosing adenosis but are usually larger and may look similar to breast cancer on a mammogram.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Radial scars and complex sclerosing lesions are also benign areas of hardened breast tissue.

Question (100 words): What are the symptoms of radial scars and complex sclerosing lesions?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Most people will not notice any symptoms of radial scars and complex sclerosing lesions.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Most people will not notice any symptoms.

Question (100 words): How are radial scars and complex sclerosing lesions diagnosed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Radial scars and complex sclerosing lesions are often found after a routine mammogram or following tests for a different breast problem. A core biopsy is usually suggested to confirm the diagnosis.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Radial scars and complex sclerosing lesions are often found after a routine mammogram or following tests for a different breast problem.

Question (100 words): How are radial scars and complex sclerosing lesions treated?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After a core biopsy, a vacuum-assisted excision may be performed to ensure the affected area is completely removed. The tissue is then sent to a laboratory to confirm it’s not cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: After your core biopsy results are back, your doctor may suggest doing a vacuum assisted excision to make sure the affected area is completely removed.

Question (100 words): Do radial scars or complex sclerosing lesions increase the risk of breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Experts disagree, but most doctors think the risk is only increased if something else, like atypical hyperplasia, is found in the tissue. More research is needed to understand the link.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Experts disagree about whether having a radial scar or complex sclerosing lesion might slightly increase your risk of breast cancer in the future.

Question (100 words): Why is it important to be breast aware after a diagnosis of a sclerosing lesion?
Answer (Max 2000 words): It’s important to continue being breast aware and report any new or unusual changes to your GP, no matter how soon after your diagnosis.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s important to continue to be breast aware and go back to your GP if you notice any changes in your breasts, no matter how soon after your diagnosis of a sclerosing lesion.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice a new or unusual change in my breast?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You should check your breasts by touching them for anything new or unusual, looking for changes, and checking any new or unusual changes with your GP.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Touch your breasts. Can you feel anything new or unusual? Look for changes. Does anything look different to you? Check any new or unusual changes with your GP.

Question (100 words): Where can I find more information about being breast aware?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can find more information about being breast aware in Breast Cancer Now’s booklet 'Know your breasts: a guide to breast awareness and screening.'
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can find out more about being breast aware in our booklet Know your breasts: a guide to breast awareness and screening.

Question (100 words): Who can I contact if I have questions or worries about my breasts or breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can call Breast Cancer Now’s helpline free and confidentially on 0808 800 6000 if you have any questions or worries about your breasts or breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have any questions or worries about your breasts or breast cancer, call us free and confidentially on 0808 800 6000

Question (100 words): How can I order or download more copies of this leaflet?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can order or download more copies of this leaflet from breastcancernow.org/publications.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can order or download more copies from breastcancernow.org/publications

Question (100 words): What should I do if I need a large print, Braille, or audio CD version of this leaflet?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can email health-info@breastcancernow.org to request a large print, Braille, or audio CD version of this leaflet.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: For a large print, Braille or audio CD version: Email health-info@breastcancernow.org

Question (100 words): Who wrote and reviewed this leaflet?
Answer (Max 2000 words): This leaflet was written by Breast Cancer Now’s clinical specialists and reviewed by healthcare professionals and people affected by breast conditions.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Sclerosing lesions of the breast was written by Breast Cancer Now’s clinical specialists, and reviewed by healthcare professionals and people affected by breast conditions.

Question (100 words): What is the medical disclaimer for this leaflet?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The medical disclaimer states that while every effort is made to ensure the information is accurate and up to date, it doesn’t replace the information and support from professionals in your healthcare team. Breast Cancer Now doesn’t accept liability in relation to the use of any information contained in this publication.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: We make every effort to ensure that our health information is accurate and up to date, but it doesn’t replace the information and support from professionals in your healthcare team. So far as is permitted by law, Breast Cancer Now doesn’t accept liability in relation to the use of any information contained in this publication.

Question (100 words): What is duct ectasia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Duct ectasia is a benign breast condition caused by normal breast changes that happen with age. It affects the breast ducts, the tubes that carry milk to the nipple, causing them to shorten and widen.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Duct ectasia is a benign (not cancer) breast condition. It’s caused by normal breast changes that happen with age.

Question (100 words): Who can get duct ectasia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Duct ectasia is more common in women approaching menopause (from 35 years onwards) but can affect women of any age. Men can also get it, though it is very rare.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Although it’s more common in women approaching the menopause, duct ectasia can affect women of any age. Men can also get duct ectasia, but this is very rare.

Question (100 words): What are the symptoms of duct ectasia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Symptoms may include discharge from the nipple (thick, watery, brown, green, or bloodstained), breast pain, a lump behind the nipple, red or tender nipple, or an inverted nipple.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Symptoms of duct ectasia: Discharge from the nipple, Breast pain, A lump felt behind the nipple, The nipple can be red or tender, The nipple is pulled inwards (inverted).

Question (100 words): How is duct ectasia diagnosed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Diagnosis involves a breast examination by a GP, followed by referral to a breast clinic for tests such as a mammogram, ultrasound scan, core biopsy, or fine needle aspiration.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Diagnosing duct ectasia: After examining your breasts, your GP is likely to refer you to a breast clinic, where you’ll be seen by specialist doctors or nurses.

Question (100 words): Do I need treatment for duct ectasia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Most cases do not require treatment. Symptoms usually clear up by themselves. Pain can be managed with paracetamol. Infections may require antibiotics. Surgery is considered if symptoms persist.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Most cases of duct ectasia do not need any treatment or follow-up. Duct ectasia is a normal part of ageing, and any symptoms will usually clear up by themselves.

Question (100 words): What kind of surgery is done for duct ectasia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Surgery may involve removing the affected duct or ducts (microdochectomy) or all major ducts (total duct excision). The procedure is usually done under general anesthesia.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Surgery: If you continue to have discharge from the nipple without squeezing, you may be offered an operation to remove the affected duct or ducts.

Question (100 words): How long do I stay in the hospital after duct ectasia surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Most people are in the hospital for the day, but some may need to stay overnight. You’ll have a small wound near the areola with stitches, covered by a dry dressing.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The operation is usually done under a general anaesthetic. Most people are in hospital for the day, but you might have to stay overnight.

Question (100 words): Will I have a scar after duct ectasia surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, the operation will leave a small scar near the areola, but it will fade over time.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The operation will leave a small scar, but this will fade in time.

Question (100 words): Can duct ectasia affect my nipple sensitivity?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, after surgery, your nipple may be less sensitive than before. For some people, it may become inverted.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: After the operation your nipple may be less sensitive than before. For a few people it may become inverted.

Question (100 words): Does duct ectasia increase my risk of breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): No, having duct ectasia does not increase your risk of developing breast cancer in the future.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Having duct ectasia does not increase your risk of developing breast cancer in the future.

Question (100 words): What should I do if my symptoms return after surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If your symptoms return, you may need further surgery to remove more ducts. It’s important to go back to your GP if you have any new symptoms.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If this happens you may need further surgery to remove more ducts. It’s important to go back to your GP if you have any new symptoms.

Question (100 words): How can I manage pain from duct ectasia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can manage pain with over-the-counter pain relief such as paracetamol. Avoid squeezing the nipple to prevent further discharge.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have any pain you may want to take pain relief such as paracetamol.

Question (100 words): What tests are done if I have bloodstained nipple discharge?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you have bloodstained nipple discharge, it may be tested in addition to other diagnostic tests like a mammogram or ultrasound.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have nipple discharge that’s bloodstained, this may also be tested.

Question (100 words): What is a core biopsy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A core biopsy involves using a hollow needle to take a small sample of breast tissue to be examined under a microscope.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A core biopsy of the breast (using a hollow needle to take a small sample of breast tissue to be looked at under a microscope – several tissue samples may be taken at the same time)

Question (100 words): What is a fine needle aspiration (FNA)?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A fine needle aspiration involves using a fine needle and syringe to take a sample of cells from the breast to be examined under a microscope.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A fine needle aspiration (FNA) of the breast (using a fine needle and syringe to take a sample of cells to be looked at under a microscope)

Question (100 words): How can I be breast aware after being diagnosed with duct ectasia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Regularly check your breasts for any new or unusual changes and report them to your GP. You can find more information in the booklet 'Know your breasts: a guide to breast awareness and screening' or call the helpline on 0808 800 6000.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s important to go back to your GP if you notice any changes in your breasts, no matter how soon after your diagnosis of duct ectasia.

Question (100 words): What should I avoid doing if I have duct ectasia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Avoid squeezing the nipple as this may cause further discharge. If you have pain, use pain relief like paracetamol.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Try not to squeeze the nipple as this may cause further discharge.

Question (100 words): What kind of follow-up care is needed after duct ectasia diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Regular follow-up with your GP is important. Monitor your breasts for any new or unusual changes and report them promptly.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s important to go back to your GP if you have any new symptoms.

Question (100 words): Where can I get more information about duct ectasia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can get more information by reading Breast Cancer Now’s booklets, visiting their website, or calling their free helpline on 0808 800 6000.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can find out more about being breast aware in our booklet Know your breasts: a guide to breast awareness and screening. You can also call our free helpline on 0808 800 6000 and talk to one of our nurses.

Question (100 words): What are the red flags I should look out for with duct ectasia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Red flags include persistent or worsening symptoms, new lumps or changes in the breast, and bloodstained nipple discharge. These should be reported to your GP immediately.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have any new symptoms, it’s important to go back to your GP.

Question (100 words): What should I eat to maintain a healthy diet during breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To maintain a healthy diet, aim to eat a variety of foods from the four main food groups: fruits and vegetables, starchy foods, dairy or dairy alternatives, and proteins. Follow the Eatwell Guide for balanced proportions. Choose unsaturated oils, limit high-fat, high-salt, and high-sugar foods, and stay hydrated with 6 to 8 glasses of water daily. You can still enjoy less healthy foods occasionally.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: To eat healthily, try to eat a variety of foods from each of the 4 main food groups every day. The Eatwell Guide shows the different types of foods you should eat and in what proportions.

Question (100 words): How can I manage my diet if I have a reduced appetite during treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If your appetite is reduced, try eating smaller, more frequent meals or snacks instead of large meals. Consider drinking nutrient-rich liquids like milkshakes, smoothies, or soups. Light physical activity, such as a short walk, may also help increase your appetite.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If your appetite is small, or taste changes are affecting your diet, eating little and often can be better than having large meals.

Question (100 words): What should I do if chemotherapy makes me feel sick or causes vomiting?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you feel sick or vomit during chemotherapy, drink plenty of fluids like water or herbal teas. Eating small, frequent meals and choosing cold foods may help. Anti-sickness drugs prescribed by your chemotherapy team can also be effective.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Drink plenty of fluids, such as water or herbal teas. Taking frequent sips is better than trying to drink large amounts in one go. Herbal teas such as mint or ginger can help if you’re feeling sick.

Question (100 words): How can I manage a sore mouth caused by chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To manage a sore mouth, clean your teeth or dentures gently, use an alcohol-free mouthwash, and choose soft or liquid foods. Avoid crunchy, salty, spicy, acidic, or hot foods and citrus drinks. Regular cleaning of dentures and avoiding smoking and alcohol can also help.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Chemotherapy can make your mouth sore or dry, making it uncomfortable to eat. You might find it helpful to: Clean your teeth or dentures with a soft brush after eating and floss gently.

Question (100 words): What dietary changes can help with constipation during treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To alleviate constipation, increase your intake of high-fiber foods such as bran flakes, beans, lentils, vegetables, fruit, brown rice, wholemeal bread, and wholewheat pasta. Drink plenty of fluids and engage in regular physical activity like walking.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Eating high-fibre foods can help. These include: High-fibre breakfast cereals, such as bran flakes or shredded wheat, Beans and lentils, Vegetables (fresh or frozen), Fruit (fresh, frozen, canned and dried), Brown rice, Wholemeal bread, Wholewheat pasta

Question (100 words): Can short-term fasting around chemotherapy help reduce side effects?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Some studies suggest that short-term fasting around the time of chemotherapy may help reduce side effects, but more research is needed. Always consult your treatment team or GP before considering fasting.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some studies suggest short-term fasting around the time of chemotherapy may help reduce side effects. However, more research is needed before any recommendations can be made.

Question (100 words): What should I eat if I have radiotherapy around my collarbone or breastbone?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you have radiotherapy around your collarbone or breastbone, you may experience a sore throat, dry mouth, difficulty swallowing, or indigestion. Eating a balanced diet and staying hydrated is important. Liquid pain relief before eating may help.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re having radiotherapy around your collarbone or breastbone, you may have a sore throat, dry mouth, difficulty swallowing or indigestion. If this happens, speak to your treatment team.

Question (100 words): How can I manage weight gain during hormone therapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Weight gain during hormone therapy can be managed by following the Eatwell Guide, reducing portion sizes, avoiding unhealthy snacks, and increasing physical activity. Consult your GP or breast care nurse for personalized advice.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re having hormone therapy, you might find your weight increases. This may be because you’re less active due to fatigue or joint pain, or because of appetite changes.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I have high cholesterol while on hormone therapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you have high cholesterol while on hormone therapy, follow a healthy diet, maintain a healthy weight, and consult your GP for further dietary changes or medication. Regular monitoring of cholesterol levels is important.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Hormone therapy drugs such as anastrozole and letrozole can increase the level of bad cholesterol (LDL) in your blood.

Question (100 words): How can I manage shopping and cooking during treatment if I feel fatigued?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you feel fatigued, accept offers of help, use online shopping services, or ask local shops for telephone ordering and delivery. Frozen and tinned fruits and vegetables are nutritious alternatives if you can't shop regularly.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Try to accept any offers of help, even if you’re used to coping on your own. You can also take advantage of online shopping or ask local shops if they have a telephone ordering and delivery service.

Question (100 words): Do I need to change my diet if I already have a medical condition like diabetes?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you have a pre-existing medical condition like diabetes, you don’t need to change your diet due to breast cancer treatment. Consult your breast care nurse or treatment team to ensure your condition remains under control during treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re already following a specific diet because you have a medical condition – such as diabetes, Crohn’s disease or irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) – having breast cancer doesn’t mean your diet has to change.

Question (100 words): How can I lose weight safely after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To lose weight safely after treatment, aim for a gradual weight loss of about 0.5 to 1kg per week. Follow the Eatwell Guide, avoid unhealthy snacks, reduce portion sizes, and increase physical activity. Consult your GP or breast care nurse for personalized advice.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you want to lose weight after treatment, aim for a realistic weight loss of about 0.5 to1kg (1 to 2 pounds) a week. You can do this by making small changes to your usual eating and exercise habits.

Question (100 words): What role does diet play in recovery and future health after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Diet plays a crucial role in recovery and future health after breast cancer treatment. Consult your breast care nurse, GP, or practice nurse to assess your current weight and diet. They can help you create a plan for any necessary changes.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: After treatment for breast cancer, you may have gained or lost weight, or you may want to know if diet can play a role in your recovery and future health.

Question (100 words): Why might I gain weight during and after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Weight gain during and after treatment can be due to side effects of drugs, fluid retention, reduced physical activity, increased eating due to anxiety, and menopausal symptoms resulting from treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may put on weight during and after treatment due to: The side effects of some drugs, which can increase appetite, The body retaining fluid, Being less active than usual, Eating more than usual when you’re anxious or because your usual routine has changed, The menopause (as a result of your treatment)

Question (100 words): What should I avoid if I have a sore mouth during treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you have a sore mouth, avoid crunchy, salty, very spicy, acidic, or hot foods. Also, avoid citrus drinks like lemon, lime, orange, and grapefruit juice. Smoking and drinking alcohol can worsen a sore mouth.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Avoid crunchy, salty, very spicy, acidic or hot foods, Avoid citrus drinks like lemon, lime, orange and grapefruit juice

Question (100 words): How can I manage taste changes during chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To manage taste changes, try a variety of foods to find what you like best. You may prefer strongly flavored foods or use herbs and spices. Using reusable plastic or wooden cutlery and glass pots and pans can help reduce a metallic taste.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your taste may change during chemotherapy, making foods taste bland or different. You may prefer to eat strongly flavoured foods or use herbs and spices when cooking.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience diarrhea during chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience diarrhea during chemotherapy, drink plenty of fluids to avoid dehydration. Contact your chemotherapy team if you have four or more episodes of diarrhea in 24 hours. They can prescribe medication if necessary.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Occasionally, some chemotherapy drugs can cause diarrhoea. Your GP or treatment team can prescribe medication for diarrhoea if necessary. Drink plenty of fluids to avoid dehydration.

Question (100 words): How can I stay hydrated during breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To stay hydrated, aim to drink 6 to 8 glasses of water a day. Carrying a water bottle with you can help. Herbal teas like mint or ginger can also be beneficial if you feel sick.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Drink plenty of fluids – aim for 6 to 8 glasses a day. Carrying a water bottle with you during the day can help you stay hydrated

Question (100 words): What should I know about hidden sugars in my diet?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Be aware that some seemingly healthy foods may contain a lot of sugar, such as dried fruit, alcoholic drinks, and some diet foods. Always check labels to monitor your sugar intake.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some foods that seem healthy may contain a lot of sugar. For example, dried fruit contains much more sugar than fresh fruit. Alcoholic drinks and some diet foods may also have a high amount of sugar.

Question (100 words): How can I find more information about specific diets like vegetarian, vegan, or South Asian diets?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Alternative versions of the Eatwell Guide are available online for people following vegetarian, vegan, African and Caribbean, and South Asian diets. More information can be found on page 23 of the booklet.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There are alternative versions of the Eatwell Guide available online for people following vegetarian, vegan, African and Caribbean, and South Asian diets. Find more information on page 23.

Question (100 words): How much physical activity should I aim for each week?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You should aim for at least 150 minutes of physical activity each week. This can be broken down into shorter sessions, such as 25-minute sessions.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Be active for 150 minutes a week – you can break this up, for example into 25-minute sessions

Question (100 words): What should I do to maintain a healthy weight during treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To maintain a healthy weight, limit alcohol, swap sugary drinks for water, choose healthier options when eating out, avoid skipping meals, and seek support from friends, family, or local weight management services.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data:
Limit the amount of alcohol you drink 
• Swap sugary drinks for water – you could add some sugar-free squash for extra flavour 
• Choose healthier options when eating out and remember that takeaways can be high in fat and calories 
• Avoid skipping meals or extreme dieting 
• Ask a friend or family member to help support and motivate you – they could join you for healthy meals or workouts

Question (100 words): What can I do if I’ve lost weight during my treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you’ve lost weight, aim to eat more calories and protein. Add an extra 300 to 500 calories a day, eat three meals and some snacks, include protein-rich foods, healthy fats, and high-calorie drinks. Your GP can prescribe high-protein or high-energy drinks if needed.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: To put on weight in a healthy way, you need to eat more calories and more protein. Adding an extra 300 to 500 calories a day is a good aim.

Question (100 words): How can I improve my bone health during treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To improve bone health, ensure you get enough calcium and vitamin D. Good sources of calcium include dairy products, fortified cereals, dried fruit, fish with edible bones, green leafy vegetables, pulses, and nuts. Vitamin D can be obtained from sunlight, margarine, egg yolks, oily fish, and fortified cereals. Your GP may recommend supplements if needed.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s important to get enough calcium from your diet as calcium is vital for healthy bones.

Question (100 words): Should I take dietary supplements during or after treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Unless you’re having problems recovering from treatment, you do not need to take supplements. Talk to your breast care nurse, treatment team, or GP before taking any supplements, as they may affect how certain cancer treatments work.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Talk to your breast care nurse, treatment team or GP before taking any supplements or other treatments bought over the counter or online.

Question (100 words): Can diet affect the risk of breast cancer coming back?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, diet can affect the risk of breast cancer recurrence. The World Cancer Research Fund recommends eating a healthy diet high in fiber and low in saturated fats, being physically active, maintaining a healthy weight, and limiting alcohol.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The World Cancer Research Fund (WCRF) recommends that people who have had breast cancer follow advice to reduce their risk of cancer coming back.

Question (100 words): What are high-fiber foods and why are they important?
Answer (Max 2000 words): High-fiber foods include wholegrains, pulses, starchy foods with skins on, vegetables, and fruits. They are important because they may reduce the risk of breast cancer recurrence, improve digestive health, and help prevent heart disease and some cancers.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: High-fibre foods tend to be lower in calories and can help you feel full for longer. Experts think fibre has many health benefits including improving digestive health and helping prevent heart disease and some cancers.

Question (100 words): What foods should I limit to reduce the risk of breast cancer recurrence?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You should limit foods high in saturated fat, such as butter, fatty cuts of meat, processed meats, full-fat dairy products, chocolate, biscuits, and cakes. Replace these with healthier fats like olive oil, oily fish, avocado, nuts, and seeds.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There is some evidence that saturated fat may increase the risk of recurrence, but again further research is needed to find out more.

Question (100 words): Are soya products safe to eat if I’ve had breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Current evidence suggests that a diet containing naturally occurring phytoestrogens, like those found in soya, is safe if you’ve had breast cancer and may be beneficial. However, soya supplements are not recommended due to limited research on their safety.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Current evidence suggests a diet containing naturally occurring phytoestrogens is safe if you’ve had breast cancer and may be beneficial.

Question (100 words): Do dairy products increase the risk of breast cancer coming back?
Answer (Max 2000 words): No, there is no evidence that dairy products increase the risk of breast cancer recurrence. They can be part of a healthy diet but try to opt for lower-fat options to maintain a healthy weight.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There is no evidence that dairy products increase the risk of breast cancer coming back.

Question (100 words): Should I follow a sugar-free diet to reduce the risk of breast cancer recurrence?
Answer (Max 2000 words): No, there’s no evidence that a sugar-free diet will reduce your risk of breast cancer recurrence. You can still eat sugar but in moderation to avoid weight gain.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There’s no evidence that following a sugar-free diet will reduce your risk of breast cancer recurrence.

Question (100 words): Are organic foods better for reducing the risk of breast cancer recurrence?
Answer (Max 2000 words): No, no association has been found between eating an organic diet and the risk of breast cancer recurrence.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: No association has been found between eating an organic diet (before or after diagnosis) and the risk of breast cancer recurrence.

Question (100 words): What is the recommended alcohol intake for someone who’s had breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): NICE recommends limiting alcohol intake to below 5 units a week for someone who’s had breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: NICE (National Institute for Health and Care Excellence) recommends that people who’ve had breast cancer limit their alcohol intake to below 5 units a week.

Question (100 words): Are special cancer diets effective in reducing the risk of breast cancer recurrence?
Answer (Max 2000 words): No, there’s no conclusive evidence that special cancer diets reduce the risk of breast cancer recurrence. These diets can be restrictive, expensive, and may lead to nutrient deficiencies.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There’s no conclusive evidence that special cancer diets like these reduce the risk of breast cancer recurrence.

Question (100 words): Is there a special diet recommended for people with secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): No, there’s no scientific evidence that people with secondary breast cancer should follow a special diet. A healthy, balanced diet can help give you energy and improve your mood.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There’s no scientific evidence that people with secondary breast cancer should follow a special diet, or that a particular diet can make a difference to your outlook (prognosis).

Question (100 words): Where can I find more information about diet and breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can find more information on the Breast Cancer Now website, NHS website, and by contacting organizations like the British Dietetic Association, British Nutrition Foundation, and World Cancer Research Fund.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can find more information about physical activity and breast cancer on our website.

Question (100 words): Can I get support for weight management from my GP?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, your GP can recommend and refer you to local support services for weight management, including dietitians and free NHS weight loss plans.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your GP can also recommend and refer you to local support services.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I’m experiencing appetite and taste changes during treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you’re experiencing appetite and taste changes, talk to your treatment team or ask to speak to a dietitian for specialist advice on managing these symptoms.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you need help, you can talk to your treatment team, or ask to speak to a dietitian for specialist advice.

Question (100 words): Are there any cookbooks recommended for people with a cancer diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, The Royal Marsden Cancer Cookbook and The Life Kitchen cookbook are recommended for people with a cancer diagnosis. They offer healthy and tasty recipes for during and after treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The Royal Marsden Cancer Cookbook contains over 150 healthy and tasty recipes for people with a cancer diagnosis.

Question (100 words): What is the role of diet in breast cancer prevention?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Diet plays a significant role in breast cancer prevention. Consuming a balanced diet rich in fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and lean proteins can help reduce the risk of breast cancer. Limiting the intake of processed foods, red meats, and alcohol is also recommended. A healthy diet can contribute to maintaining a healthy weight, which is a crucial factor in reducing breast cancer risk.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Diet and breast cancer was written by Breast Cancer Now’s clinical specialists, and reviewed by healthcare professionals and people affected by breast cancer.

Question (100 words): Can specific foods help reduce the risk of breast cancer recurrence?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Certain foods may help reduce the risk of breast cancer recurrence. Foods rich in antioxidants, such as berries, nuts, and green leafy vegetables, can be beneficial. Omega-3 fatty acids found in fish like salmon and flaxseeds may also have protective effects. It is important to maintain a varied and balanced diet to support overall health and potentially reduce recurrence risk.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Diet and breast cancer was written by Breast Cancer Now’s clinical specialists, and reviewed by healthcare professionals and people affected by breast cancer.

Question (100 words): Is it safe to consume soy products if I have breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, it is generally safe to consume soy products if you have breast cancer. Soy contains isoflavones, which have both estrogen-like and anti-estrogenic effects. Moderate consumption of soy has not been shown to increase the risk of breast cancer recurrence. However, it is advisable to discuss soy intake with your healthcare provider to ensure it aligns with your specific treatment plan.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Diet and breast cancer was written by Breast Cancer Now’s clinical specialists, and reviewed by healthcare professionals and people affected by breast cancer.

Question (100 words): How can I manage weight gain during breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Managing weight gain during breast cancer treatment involves a combination of a balanced diet and regular physical activity. Focus on eating nutrient-dense foods and avoid excessive calorie intake. Engage in moderate exercise, such as walking or yoga, as tolerated. Consulting a dietitian can provide personalized advice to help manage weight effectively during treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Diet and breast cancer was written by Breast Cancer Now’s clinical specialists, and reviewed by healthcare professionals and people affected by breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What should I eat to boost my energy during breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To boost energy during breast cancer treatment, focus on eating a variety of nutrient-rich foods. Include complex carbohydrates like whole grains, proteins from lean meats, beans, and legumes, and healthy fats from sources like avocados and nuts. Staying hydrated and eating small, frequent meals can also help maintain energy levels.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Diet and breast cancer was written by Breast Cancer Now’s clinical specialists, and reviewed by healthcare professionals and people affected by breast cancer.

Question (100 words): Are there any dietary restrictions I should follow after breast cancer surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After breast cancer surgery, there are generally no strict dietary restrictions. However, it is important to eat a balanced diet to support healing and recovery. Focus on consuming plenty of fruits, vegetables, lean proteins, and whole grains. Stay hydrated and avoid excessive alcohol and processed foods. Always follow any specific dietary advice provided by your healthcare team.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Diet and breast cancer was written by Breast Cancer Now’s clinical specialists, and reviewed by healthcare professionals and people affected by breast cancer.

Question (100 words): Can a plant-based diet help in breast cancer recovery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A plant-based diet can be beneficial for breast cancer recovery. It emphasizes fruits, vegetables, whole grains, legumes, nuts, and seeds, which are rich in vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants. These nutrients can support the immune system and overall health. However, ensure the diet is balanced and provides all necessary nutrients, possibly with the guidance of a dietitian.

Question (100 words): What role does hydration play in breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Hydration plays a crucial role in breast cancer treatment. Adequate fluid intake helps maintain bodily functions, aids in the metabolism of medications, and supports overall health. It is especially important during treatment to prevent dehydration, which can exacerbate side effects like fatigue and constipation. Aim to drink plenty of water throughout the day.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Diet and breast cancer was written by Breast Cancer Now’s clinical specialists, and reviewed by healthcare professionals and people affected by breast cancer.

Question (100 words): How can I deal with taste changes during breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Taste changes during breast cancer treatment can be managed by experimenting with different flavors and textures. Use herbs and spices to enhance the taste of foods. Cold foods may taste better than hot ones. Staying hydrated and maintaining good oral hygiene can also help. If taste changes persist, consult your healthcare provider for further advice.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Diet and breast cancer was written by Breast Cancer Now’s clinical specialists, and reviewed by healthcare professionals and people affected by breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience nausea during breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience nausea during breast cancer treatment, try eating small, frequent meals rather than large ones. Ginger, either as a tea or in small amounts in food, can help alleviate nausea. Avoid strong smells and opt for bland, easy-to-digest foods. If nausea persists, speak to your healthcare provider about anti-nausea medications.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Diet and breast cancer was written by Breast Cancer Now’s clinical specialists, and reviewed by healthcare professionals and people affected by breast cancer.

Question (100 words): Is it important to take supplements during breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): While a balanced diet should provide most of the necessary nutrients, some people may benefit from supplements during breast cancer treatment. However, it is crucial to consult with your healthcare provider before starting any supplements, as some can interact with treatments or have adverse effects. Your provider can recommend appropriate supplements if needed.

Question (100 words): How can I support my immune system through diet during breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Supporting your immune system through diet during breast cancer treatment involves eating a variety of nutrient-rich foods. Include plenty of fruits and vegetables for vitamins and antioxidants, lean proteins for immune function, and whole grains for fiber. Probiotic-rich foods like yogurt can also support gut health, which is linked to immune function.

Question (100 words): What should I know about alcohol consumption during breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): It is generally recommended to limit or avoid alcohol during breast cancer treatment. Alcohol can interfere with the effectiveness of certain treatments and may increase the risk of side effects. Additionally, alcohol consumption has been linked to a higher risk of breast cancer recurrence. Always discuss alcohol intake with your healthcare provider.

Question (100 words): Can diet affect the side effects of breast cancer medications?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, diet can affect the side effects of breast cancer medications. For example, a high-fiber diet can help mitigate constipation caused by certain medications. Staying hydrated can reduce the risk of kidney-related side effects. It is important to maintain a balanced diet and discuss any concerns about medication side effects with your healthcare provider.

Choose nutrient-dense foods that are easy to eat, such as smoothies, soups, and soft foods. Staying hydrated is also important. If needed, consult a dietitian for personalized advice and meal plans that suit your appetite and dietary needs.

Question (100 words): What are the benefits of a Mediterranean diet for breast cancer patients?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The Mediterranean diet, rich in fruits, vegetables, whole grains, lean proteins, and healthy fats like olive oil, has been associated with numerous health benefits for breast cancer patients. It can help reduce inflammation, support heart health, and may lower the risk of breast cancer recurrence. This diet emphasizes a balanced and varied intake of nutrients.

Question (100 words): How can I get support for dietary changes during breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can get support for dietary changes during breast cancer treatment by consulting a registered dietitian who specializes in oncology nutrition. They can provide personalized advice and meal plans. Additionally, support groups and resources from organizations like Breast Cancer Now can offer guidance and community support.

Question (100 words): What should I eat to help with chemotherapy-induced mouth sores?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To help with chemotherapy-induced mouth sores, choose soft, bland foods that are easy to eat and gentle on the mouth. Examples include yogurt, mashed potatoes, scrambled eggs, and smoothies. Avoid spicy, acidic, and crunchy foods that can irritate the sores. Staying hydrated is also important.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Diet and breast cancer was written by Breast Cancer Now’s clinical specialists, and reviewed by healthcare professionals and people affected by breast cancer.

Question (100 words): How can I manage diarrhea caused by breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To manage diarrhea caused by breast cancer treatment, focus on a diet that includes easily digestible foods like bananas, rice, applesauce, and toast (BRAT diet). Avoid dairy, fatty foods, and caffeine, which can worsen diarrhea. Stay hydrated with clear fluids and consult your healthcare provider for medications if needed.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Diet and breast cancer was written by Breast Cancer Now’s clinical specialists, and reviewed by healthcare professionals and people affected by breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What are the common symptoms of breast cancer I should look out for?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common symptoms of breast cancer include a lump or swelling in the breast, upper chest, or armpit; changes to the skin such as puckering or dimpling; changes in the color of the breast, which may look darker, red, or inflamed; nipple changes like inversion; rash or crusting around the nipple; unusual discharge from the nipple; and changes in the size or shape of the breast. Persistent pain in the breast or armpit may also be a symptom.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A lump or swelling in the breast, upper chest or armpit... Changes in size or shape of the breast... On its own pain in your breasts is not usually a sign of cancer. But look out for pain in your breast or armpit that’s there all or almost all the time.

Question (100 words): How often should I check my breasts for changes?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You should check your breasts regularly, ideally once a month. This helps you become familiar with the normal look and feel of your breasts, making it easier to notice any changes that may occur.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: No matter what size or shape your breasts are, check them regularly.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice a change in my breast?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you notice any changes in your breast, such as a lump, skin changes, nipple inversion, or unusual discharge, you should check these changes with your GP as soon as possible. Early detection is crucial for effective treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Check anything that looks or feels different for you with a GP.

Question (100 words): Can breast cancer symptoms appear differently on various skin tones?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, breast cancer symptoms can appear differently on various skin tones. It's important to be aware of this and look for any changes that are unusual for you, regardless of your skin tone.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Signs and symptoms may appear differently on various skin tones.

Question (100 words): Is breast pain alone a sign of breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): On its own, breast pain is usually not a sign of cancer. However, you should be cautious of persistent pain in your breast or armpit that is present all or almost all the time, as this could be a symptom.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: On its own pain in your breasts is not usually a sign of cancer. But look out for pain in your breast or armpit that’s there all or almost all the time.

Question (100 words): What is the importance of checking my armpits and upper chest for changes?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Checking your armpits and upper chest for changes is important because breast tissue extends into these areas, and symptoms of breast cancer can appear here. Regular checks help ensure that any changes are detected early.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Check all parts of your breasts, your armpits and up to your collarbone (upper chest) for changes.

Question (100 words): What are the first steps I should take if I find a lump in my breast?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you find a lump in your breast, the first step is to make an appointment with your GP. They will evaluate the lump and may recommend further tests, such as a mammogram or biopsy, to determine if it is cancerous.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Check anything that looks or feels different for you with a GP.

Question (100 words): How can I perform a breast self-examination effectively?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To perform a breast self-examination effectively, use the Touch Look Check method: Touch your breasts to feel for any lumps or changes, Look for visible changes such as dimpling or redness, and Check any changes with your GP. Regular self-examinations help you become familiar with your breasts and notice any abnormalities early.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: TOUCH YOUR BREASTS LOOK FOR CHANGES CHECK ANY CHANGES WITH YOUR GP

Question (100 words): What are the potential side effects of breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The potential side effects of breast cancer treatment can vary depending on the type of treatment. Common side effects include fatigue, nausea, hair loss, changes in appetite, and emotional distress. Some treatments may also cause long-term effects such as lymphedema or heart problems.

Question (100 words): How can I manage the emotional impact of a breast cancer diagnosis?

Question (100 words): What types of surgery are commonly used to treat breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common surgical procedures for breast cancer include lumpectomy (removal of the tumor and a small margin of surrounding tissue), mastectomy (removal of the entire breast), and lymph node dissection (removal of lymph nodes in the armpit). The type of surgery depends on the stage and location of the cancer.

Question (100 words): What is the role of medication in breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Medication plays a crucial role in breast cancer treatment. It can be used to shrink tumors before surgery (neoadjuvant therapy), kill cancer cells after surgery (adjuvant therapy), or manage symptoms and side effects. Common medications include chemotherapy, hormone therapy, and targeted therapy.

It's also important to discuss any concerns or questions with your surgeon.

Lifestyle changes, such as a healthy diet and regular exercise, are also important.

Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: To find out more about secondary breast cancer, visit breastcancernow.org/sbcsymptoms

Question (100 words): What are the possible signs of secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Possible signs of secondary breast cancer include severe or ongoing headaches, a dry cough, feeling out of breath, constipation, persistent nausea, discomfort or swelling under the ribs, loss of balance or limb weakness, feeling full quickly, lumps or swellings under the arm, unexpected weight loss, bloating, altered vision or speech, extreme fatigue, and persistent bone pain.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: POSSIBLE SIGNS OF SECONDARY (METASTATIC) BREAST CANCER

Question (100 words): Who should I contact if I suspect secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you suspect secondary breast cancer based on new, persistent symptoms, you should contact your breast care nurse or GP for an evaluation.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Tell your breast care nurse or GP if you have symptoms that are new, don’t have an obvious cause and don’t go away.

Question (100 words): What organization provides support and information about secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast Cancer Now provides support and information about secondary breast cancer. You can visit their website at breastcancernow.org/sbcsymptoms for more details.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast Cancer Now is a company limited by guarantee registered in England (9347608) and a charity registered in England and Wales (1160558), Scotland (SC045584) and Isle of Man (1200).

Question (100 words): What are the common symptoms of breast cancer recurrence?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common symptoms of breast cancer recurrence include feeling sick, severe or ongoing headaches, feeling much more tired than usual, constipation, feeling full quickly when eating, discomfort or swelling under the ribs or across the upper abdomen, any lumps or swellings under the arm, breastbone, or collarbone, loss of balance or weakness/numbness of the limbs, a dry cough or feeling out of breath, altered vision or speech, unexpected weight loss and loss of appetite, and persistent bone pain in areas like the back, hips, or ribs.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Feeling sick, severe or ongoing headaches, feeling much more tired than usual, constipation, feeling full quickly when eating, discomfort or swelling under the ribs or across the upper abdomen, any lumps or swellings under the arm, breastbone, or collarbone, loss of balance or weakness/numbness of the limbs, a dry cough or feeling out of breath, altered vision or speech, unexpected weight loss and loss of appetite, and persistent bone pain in areas like the back, hips, or ribs.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice new or unusual symptoms after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you notice new or unusual symptoms after breast cancer treatment, it is important to talk to your GP or breast care nurse. Pay attention to symptoms that don’t have an obvious cause or don’t go away, as these could be signs of recurrence.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Talk to your GP or breast care nurse about any symptoms that are: • New or unusual for you • Don’t have an obvious cause • Don’t go away

Question (100 words): What changes in the breast or chest area should I be aware of after treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After breast cancer treatment, be aware of any changes in the breast or chest area such as swelling on your chest, in your armpit or around your collarbone, a change in shape or size, a change in skin texture like puckering or dimpling, an inverted or differently looking nipple, liquid discharge from the nipple without squeezing it, swelling in the arm or hand, redness or a rash on the skin, and any lumps or thickening that feels different.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Look for changes to the other breast too. • Swelling on your chest, in your armpit or around your collarbone • A change in shape or size • A change in skin texture, such as puckering or dimpling • The nipple has become inverted (pulled in) or looks different, for example changed position or shape • Liquid (discharge) that comes from the nipple without squeezing it • Swelling in the arm or hand • Redness or a rash on the skin, in or around the nipple or in the area of the scar line of your treate

Question (100 words): Can breast cancer recur in the remaining breast tissue after a lumpectomy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, breast cancer can recur in the remaining breast tissue after a lumpectomy. It’s important to be vigilant about any changes in the breast or chest area and report them to your healthcare provider.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’ve had a lumpectomy or breast-conserving surgery, the cancer could come back in the remaining breast tissue.

Question (100 words): What are the signs that breast cancer may have spread to other parts of the body?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Signs that breast cancer may have spread to other parts of the body include severe or ongoing headaches, loss of balance or weakness/numbness of the limbs, a dry cough or feeling out of breath, altered vision or speech, and persistent bone pain in areas like the back, hips, or ribs.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Sometimes breast cancer cells can spread from the breast to other parts of the body. This is known as secondary (metastatic) breast cancer. Possible signs of secondary breast cancer include: AFTER BREAST CANCER TREATMENT

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience persistent bone pain after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience persistent bone pain, especially in areas like the back, hips, or ribs, that doesn’t improve with pain relief and may be worse at night, you should consult your healthcare provider as it could be a sign of breast cancer recurrence.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Pain in your bones, for example in the back, hips or ribs, that doesn’t get better with pain relief and may be worse at night

Question (100 words): How can I differentiate between normal post-surgery changes and signs of breast cancer recurrence?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Differentiating between normal post-surgery changes and signs of breast cancer recurrence can be challenging. Any new or unusual symptoms, especially those that don’t have an obvious cause or don’t go away, should be discussed with your healthcare provider to rule out recurrence.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Talk to your GP or breast care nurse about any symptoms that are: • New or unusual for you • Don’t have an obvious cause • Don’t go away

Question (100 words): What are the symptoms of secondary (metastatic) breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Symptoms of secondary (metastatic) breast cancer can include severe or ongoing headaches, loss of balance or weakness/numbness of the limbs, a dry cough or feeling out of breath, altered vision or speech, and persistent bone pain in areas like the back, hips, or ribs.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Sometimes breast cancer cells can spread from the breast to other parts of the body. This is known as secondary (metastatic) breast cancer. Possible signs of secondary breast cancer include: AFTER BREAST CANCER TREATMENT

Question (100 words): What should I look for in the other breast after having breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After having breast cancer treatment, you should look for any changes in the other breast, such as swelling, changes in shape or size, changes in skin texture, nipple inversion or changes, unexpected nipple discharge, swelling in the arm or hand, and redness or rash on the skin.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Look for changes to the other breast too. • Swelling on your chest, in your armpit or around your collarbone • A change in shape or size • A change in skin texture, such as puckering or dimpling • The nipple has become inverted (pulled in) or looks different, for example changed position or shape • Liquid (discharge) that comes from the nipple without squeezing it • Swelling in the arm or hand • Redness or a rash on the skin, in or around the nipple or in the area of the scar line of your treate

Question (100 words): What are the signs of breast cancer recurrence in the chest wall or skin after a mastectomy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Signs of breast cancer recurrence in the chest wall or skin after a mastectomy include swelling on the chest, changes in shape or size, changes in skin texture like puckering or dimpling, nipple inversion or changes, unexpected nipple discharge, swelling in the arm or hand, and redness or rash on the skin.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’ve had a mastectomy, the cancer could come back in the chest wall or in the skin.
