Question (100 words): How can Breast Cancer Now support someone worried about breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast Cancer Now offers life-changing support for anyone worried about breast cancer, dealing with a diagnosis, or living with or beyond treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Whoever you are, and whatever your experience of breast cancer, our free services are here.

Question (100 words): What kind of research does Breast Cancer Now support?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast Cancer Now supports over 290 of the brightest minds in breast cancer research, focusing on prevention, living well with the disease, and saving lives.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: We support over 290 of the brightest minds in breast cancer research.

Question (100 words): How can I contact Breast Cancer Now for more information or support?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can contact Breast Cancer Now by calling their helpline on 0808 800 6000 or visiting their website at breastcancernow.org for reliable breast cancer information.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Call 0808 800 6000 to talk things through with our helpline nurses. Visit breastcancernow.org for reliable breast cancer information.

Question (100 words): What are the common signs of breast cancer I should look for?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common signs of breast cancer include a lump or swelling in the breast, upper chest, or armpit; changes to the skin such as puckering or dimpling; changes to the nipple, like inversion; rash or crusting around the nipple; changes in size or shape of the breast; unusual discharge from the nipple; and a change in the color of the breast, which may appear red or inflamed.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A lump or swelling in the breast, upper chest or armpitA change to the skin, such as puckering or dimplingA nipple change, for example it has become pulled in (inverted)Rash or crusting around the nipple Changes in size or shape of the breastUnusual liquid (discharge) from either nippleA change in the colour of the breast – the breast may look red or inflamed

Question (100 words): Is breast pain a sign of cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast pain on its own is usually not a sign of cancer. However, persistent pain in the breast or armpit that is present all or almost all the time should be checked by a healthcare professional.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: On its own, pain in your breasts is not usually a sign of cancer. But look out for pain in your breast or armpit that’s there all or almost all the time.

Question (100 words): How should I check my breasts for any changes?
Answer (Max 2000 words): There’s no special way to check your breasts. You can touch and look for any new or unusual changes. Get used to checking regularly and be aware of anything that’s new or different for you. Check your whole breast area, including up to your collarbone and armpits.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There’s no special way to check your breasts and you do not need any training. Everyone will have their own way of touching and looking for changes. Get used to checking regularly and be aware of anything that’s new or different for you. Check your whole breast area, including up to your collarbone (upper chest) and armpits.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice a new or unusual change in my breasts?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you notice any new or unusual changes in your breasts, it’s important to get them checked by a GP. Most breast changes, including lumps, are not cancer, but early detection increases the likelihood of successful treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A change to the way your breasts feel or look could be a sign of cancer. So get any new or unusual changes checked by a GP. Most breast changes, including lumps, are not cancer. But the sooner breast cancer is found, the more successful treatment is likely to be.

Question (100 words): How can I get support if I have questions or worries about my breasts?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can call Breast Cancer Now for free and confidential support. They offer an interpreting service in over 240 languages. Their contact number is 0808 800 6000.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have any questions or worries about your breasts or breast cancer, call us free and confidentially. We have access to an interpreting service in over 240 languages. 0808 800 6000

Question (100 words): Why is it important to know how my breasts normally look and feel?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Knowing how your breasts normally look and feel helps you to notice any unusual changes. This awareness can lead to early detection of potential issues, including breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Getting to know how your breasts look and feel normally means you’ll be able to notice any unusual changes. Você Conhece o seu Corpo Melhor do Que Ninguém

Question (100 words): What are the common changes to look for in the skin of the breast?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common changes to look for in the skin of the breast include puckering, dimpling, rash, or crusting around the nipple. These can be signs of underlying issues that need to be checked by a healthcare professional.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A change to the skin, such as puckering or dimplingRash or crusting around the nipple

Question (100 words): Can changes in the size or shape of the breast be a sign of cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, changes in the size or shape of the breast can be a sign of cancer and should be evaluated by a healthcare professional.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Changes in size or shape of the breast

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice an unusual discharge from my nipple?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you notice an unusual discharge from your nipple, it’s important to have it checked by a healthcare professional, as it could be a sign of an underlying issue.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Unusual liquid (discharge) from either nipple

Question (100 words): Is redness or inflammation of the breast a sign of cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Redness or inflammation of the breast can be a sign of cancer and should be evaluated by a healthcare professional.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A change in the colour of the breast – the breast may look red or inflamed

Question (100 words): How often should I check my breasts for changes?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You should check your breasts regularly. There’s no specific frequency, but making it a habit will help you notice any new or unusual changes more easily.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Get used to checking regularly and be aware of anything that’s new or different for you.

Question (100 words): What areas should I include when checking my breasts?
Answer (Max 2000 words): When checking your breasts, include the entire breast area, up to your collarbone (upper chest), and your armpits.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Check your whole breast area, including up to your collarbone (upper chest) and armpits.

Question (100 words): Should I be concerned about breast pain if it comes and goes?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast pain that comes and goes is usually not a cause for concern. However, persistent pain should be evaluated by a healthcare professional.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: On its own, pain in your breasts is not usually a sign of cancer. But look out for pain in your breast or armpit that’s there all or almost all the time.

Question (100 words): What does it mean if my nipple has become inverted?
Answer (Max 2000 words): An inverted nipple can be a sign of an underlying issue, including breast cancer, and should be checked by a healthcare professional.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A nipple change, for example it has become pulled in (inverted)

Question (100 words): Are most breast lumps cancerous?
Answer (Max 2000 words): No, most breast lumps are not cancerous. However, any new or unusual lump should be evaluated by a healthcare professional to rule out cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Most breast changes, including lumps, are not cancer.

Question (100 words): Why is early detection of breast cancer important?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Early detection of breast cancer is important because it increases the likelihood of successful treatment and better outcomes.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: But the sooner breast cancer is found, the more successful treatment is likely to be.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I find a lump in my breast?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you find a lump in your breast, you should schedule an appointment with your healthcare provider to have it evaluated. Most lumps are benign, but it’s important to get a professional assessment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Get any new or unusual changes checked by a GP.

Question (100 words): Can changes in breast color indicate cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, changes in breast color, such as redness or inflammation, can indicate cancer and should be evaluated by a healthcare professional.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A change in the colour of the breast – the breast may look red or inflamed

Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Get used to checking regularly and be aware of anything that’s new or different for you.

Question (100 words): What areas should I include when checking my breasts?
Answer (Max 2000 words): When checking your breasts, include the entire breast area, up to your collarbone (upper chest), and your armpits.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Check your whole breast area, including up to your collarbone (upper chest) and armpits.

Question (100 words): Can I use any special tools or training to check my breasts?
Answer (Max 2000 words): No special tools or training are needed to check your breasts. Everyone has their own way of examining their breasts, and it’s important to be familiar with what is normal for you.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There’s no special way to check your breasts and you do not need any training. Everyone will have their own way of touching and looking for changes.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice persistent pain in my breast or armpit?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience persistent pain in your breast or armpit, it’s important to have it evaluated by a healthcare professional, even though pain alone is usually not a sign of breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: On its own, pain in your breasts is not usually a sign of cancer. But look out for pain in your breast or armpit that’s there all or almost all the time.

Question (100 words): How can I get help in a language other than English if I have concerns about breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast Cancer Now offers a free, confidential helpline with access to an interpreting service in over 240 languages. You can call them at 0808 800 6000 for support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have any questions or worries about your breasts or breast cancer, call us free and confidentially. We have access to an interpreting service in over 240 languages. 0808 800 6000

Question (100 words): What are the benefits of early detection of breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Early detection of breast cancer increases the likelihood of successful treatment and better outcomes. Regular self-examinations and prompt medical evaluation of any changes can lead to earlier diagnosis.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Most breast changes, including lumps, are not cancer. But the sooner breast cancer is found, the more successful treatment is likely to be.

Question (100 words): Why is it important to be aware of how my breasts normally look and feel?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Being aware of how your breasts normally look and feel helps you to recognize any unusual changes more easily. This awareness is crucial for early detection of potential issues, including breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Getting to know how your breasts look and feel normally means you’ll be able to notice any unusual changes.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice skin changes like puckering or dimpling on my breast?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you notice skin changes such as puckering or dimpling on your breast, it’s important to have these changes evaluated by a healthcare professional, as they can be signs of breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A change to the skin, such as puckering or dimpling

Question (100 words): What are the common symptoms of breast cancer I should look out for?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common symptoms of breast cancer include a lump or swelling in the breast tissue, upper chest (including the collarbone) or armpit, changes to the skin such as puckering or dimpling, a change in the color of the breast/chest (darker, red, or inflamed), a nipple change (e.g., inversion), rash or crusting around the nipple, unusual liquid (discharge) from either nipple, and changes in size or shape of the breast/chest. Persistent pain in the breast/chest or armpit is also a concern.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: These include: A lump or swelling in the breast tissue, upper chest (including the collar bone) or armpit, A change to the skin, such as puckering or dimpling, A change in the colour of the breast/chest – this may look darker, red or inflamed, A nipple change, for example it has become pulled in (inverted), Rash or crusting around the nipple, Unusual liquid (discharge) from either nipple, Changes in size or shape of the breast/chest.

Question (100 words): Is pain in the breast tissue always a sign of breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Pain in the breast tissue alone is not usually a sign of breast cancer. However, persistent pain in the breast/chest or armpit that is present all or almost all the time should be evaluated by a healthcare professional.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: On its own, pain in breast tissue is not usually a sign of breast cancer. But look out for pain in your breast/chest or armpit that’s there all or almost all the time.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice something unusual in my chest area?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you notice anything that feels new or unusual in your chest area, even if you feel well, it is important to make an appointment with your GP for an evaluation.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you notice anything that feels new or unusual, even if you feel well, make an appointment with your GP.

Question (100 words): How can I check my chest for changes at home?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can check your chest for changes at home by touching your chest to feel for any lumps or swelling, looking for changes in the skin such as puckering or dimpling, noting any changes in color, checking for nipple changes, and observing for any unusual discharge or persistent pain.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: TOUCH YOUR CHEST LOOK FOR CHANGES CHECK WITH A GP

Question (100 words): Can men get breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, men can get breast cancer. Breast cancer can affect anyone because everyone has breast tissue.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast cancer can affect anyone We all have breast tissue, so it’s important for everyone to know the signs and symptoms of breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What are the first steps I should take if I suspect breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you suspect breast cancer, the first step is to make an appointment with your GP. They will evaluate your symptoms and may recommend further tests such as a mammogram, ultrasound, or biopsy to confirm the diagnosis.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you notice anything that feels new or unusual, even if you feel well, make an appointment with your GP.

Question (100 words): What types of tests are used to diagnose breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Tests used to diagnose breast cancer may include a clinical breast exam, mammogram, ultrasound, MRI, and biopsy. These tests help determine the presence and extent of breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you notice anything that feels new or unusual, even if you feel well, make an appointment with your GP.

Question (100 words): What should I expect during a breast cancer biopsy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): During a breast cancer biopsy, a small sample of breast tissue is removed and examined under a microscope to check for cancer cells. The procedure is usually done under local anesthesia, and you may experience some discomfort or bruising afterward.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: N/A - Not explicitly mentioned in the document, but implied by the recommendation to see a GP for evaluation.

Question (100 words): How is breast cancer treated?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast cancer treatment may include surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, hormone therapy, or targeted therapy. The specific treatment plan depends on the type and stage of breast cancer, as well as individual patient factors.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: N/A - Treatment options are not detailed in the document, but general categories of treatment are mentioned.

Question (100 words): What is the role of surgery in breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Surgery is a common treatment for breast cancer and may involve removing the tumor (lumpectomy) or the entire breast (mastectomy). Surgery aims to remove cancerous tissue and reduce the risk of the cancer spreading.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: N/A - Surgery is mentioned as a common treatment, but specific procedures are not detailed in the document.

Question (100 words): What are the common side effects of breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common side effects of breast cancer treatment may include fatigue, nausea, hair loss, changes in appetite, and emotional distress. These side effects vary depending on the type of treatment received.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: N/A - Side effects are not detailed in the document, but general categories of treatment are mentioned.

Question (100 words): How can I manage the emotional impact of a breast cancer diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Managing the emotional impact of a breast cancer diagnosis can involve seeking support from friends and family, joining a support group, speaking with a counselor or therapist, and practicing self-care activities such as meditation or exercise.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: N/A - Emotional support strategies are not detailed in the document, but the importance of support is implied.

Question (100 words): What lifestyle changes can help during breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Lifestyle changes that can help during breast cancer treatment include maintaining a healthy diet, staying physically active, avoiding tobacco and excessive alcohol, and managing stress through relaxation techniques.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: N/A - Lifestyle changes are not detailed in the document, but general health practices are implied.

Question (100 words): What nutritional advice is recommended for breast cancer patients?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Nutritional advice for breast cancer patients often includes eating a balanced diet rich in fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and lean proteins, staying hydrated, and limiting processed foods and sugars. It’s also important to consult with a dietitian for personalized advice.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: N/A - Nutritional advice is not detailed in the document, but general health practices are implied.

Question (100 words): What follow-up care is needed after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Follow-up care after breast cancer treatment typically includes regular check-ups with your oncologist, imaging tests such as mammograms, and monitoring for any signs of recurrence. It’s important to attend all scheduled appointments and report any new symptoms to your healthcare provider.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: N/A - Follow-up care is not detailed in the document, but the importance of regular check-ups is implied.

Question (100 words): Are there any red flags I should watch for after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Red flags to watch for after breast cancer treatment include new lumps or changes in the breast, persistent pain, unexplained weight loss, and any new or worsening symptoms. If you experience any of these, contact your healthcare provider immediately.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: N/A - Red flags are not detailed in the document, but the importance of monitoring for new symptoms is implied.

Question (100 words): How can I prepare for breast cancer surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Preparing for breast cancer surgery may involve following pre-surgery instructions from your surgeon, arranging for transportation and support after the procedure, and discussing any concerns or questions with your healthcare team.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: N/A - Pre-surgery preparation is not detailed in the document, but general advice on consulting healthcare providers is given.

Question (100 words): What is the recovery process like after breast cancer surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Recovery after breast cancer surgery varies depending on the type of surgery performed. It may involve managing pain, caring for surgical wounds, gradually resuming normal activities, and attending follow-up appointments with your surgeon.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: N/A - Recovery process is not detailed in the document, but general advice on consulting healthcare providers is given.

Question (100 words): What resources are available for breast cancer patients and their families?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Resources available for breast cancer patients and their families include support groups, counseling services, educational materials, and charities such as Breast Cancer Now, which provide information, advocacy, and financial assistance.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: breastcancernow.org Breast Cancer Now is a charity registered in England and Wales (1160558), Scotland (SC045584) and the Isle of Man (1200). BCN247

Question (100 words): How can I find a support group for breast cancer patients?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can find a support group for breast cancer patients by contacting local hospitals, cancer centers, or organizations like Breast Cancer Now. They often provide listings of support groups and can help you connect with others who are going through similar experiences.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: breastcancernow.org Breast Cancer Now is a charity registered in England and Wales (1160558), Scotland (SC045584) and the Isle of Man (1200). BCN247

Question (100 words): What is triple negative breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Triple negative breast cancer is a type of breast cancer that tests negative for oestrogen receptors, progesterone receptors, and HER2 protein. This means it does not respond to hormone therapies or HER2-targeted treatments.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Triple negative breast cancer is the name given to breast cancer that is: Oestrogen receptor negative (ER-negative), Progesterone receptor negative (PR-negative), HER2-negative.

Question (100 words): How common is triple negative breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Around 15% of all breast cancers are triple negative. It is more common in women with an altered BRCA gene, particularly BRCA1, Black women, premenopausal women, and women under 40.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Around 15% of all breast cancers are triple negative. Triple negative breast cancer is more common in: Women with an altered BRCA gene, particularly BRCA1, Black women, Women who have not yet reached the menopause, Women under 40.

Question (100 words): Should I consider genetic testing if I have triple negative breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, if you have triple negative breast cancer, especially if diagnosed under 60, you should be offered genetic testing to check for altered BRCA genes, as this significantly increases breast cancer risk.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have triple negative breast cancer, you’re more likely to have an altered BRCA1 gene than someone whose breast cancer is hormone receptor positive.

Question (100 words): What treatments are available for triple negative breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Treatments include chemotherapy, surgery, radiotherapy, bisphosphonates, targeted therapies like PARP inhibitors, and immunotherapies. Hormone and HER2-targeted therapies are not effective.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Chemotherapy, surgery, radiotherapy, bisphosphonates, targeted therapies such as PARP inhibitors, and immunotherapies are used. Hormone and HER2-targeted therapies are not effective.

Question (100 words): Can chemotherapy be used before surgery for triple negative breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, chemotherapy can be used before surgery to slow the growth of a rapidly growing breast cancer, shrink a larger cancer, or destroy any cancer cells that may have spread.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Chemotherapy may be used before surgery to slow the growth of a rapidly growing breast cancer. Or it might be given to shrink a larger breast cancer before surgery.

Question (100 words): What are the main types of breast surgery for triple negative breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The main types of breast surgery are breast-conserving surgery (lumpectomy) and mastectomy. Most women who have a mastectomy will have the option for breast reconstruction.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The two main types of breast surgery are: Breast-conserving surgery, also known as wide local excision or lumpectomy, Mastectomy – removal of all the breast tissue, including the nipple area.

Question (100 words): Is radiotherapy necessary after breast surgery for triple negative breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, radiotherapy is usually recommended after breast-conserving surgery to the remaining breast tissue and may be recommended after a mastectomy to the chest wall and nearby lymph nodes.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you had breast-conserving surgery (a wide local excision or lumpectomy) you will usually have radiotherapy to the remaining breast tissue on that side. After a mastectomy, your treatment team may recommend you have radiotherapy to the chest wall.

Question (100 words): What are bisphosphonates and when are they used in triple negative breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Bisphosphonates are drugs that reduce the risk of breast cancer spreading in post-menopausal women and can strengthen bone in secondary breast cancer in the bone. They can be given as a tablet or intravenously.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Bisphosphonates are a group of drugs that can reduce the risk of breast cancer spreading in post-menopausal women. They can also be given for secondary breast cancer in the bone.

Question (100 words): What are PARP inhibitors and who might benefit from them?
Answer (Max 2000 words): PARP inhibitors are targeted therapies that work in cancer cells with a change in the BRCA gene. Olaparib is a PARP inhibitor that may be offered to those with triple negative breast cancer and an altered BRCA gene.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: PARP inhibitors are a type of targeted therapy that work in cancer cells that have a change in the BRCA gene. If you have triple negative breast cancer with an altered BRCA gene, your treatment team may talk to you about a drug called olaparib.

Question (100 words): Are there any immunotherapies available for triple negative breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, immunotherapies like sacituzumab govitecan, atezolizumab, and pembrolizumab are available for certain triple negative breast cancers, depending on the stage and features of the cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Immunotherapies you may be offered include: Sacituzumab govitecan (Trodelvy), Atezolizumab (Tecentriq), Pembrolizumab (Keytruda).

Question (100 words): Is triple negative breast cancer more likely to come back after treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Research shows that the risk of triple negative breast cancer coming back or spreading is higher in the first few years but becomes similar to other types of breast cancer after around 5 years.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Research has shown that the risk of triple negative breast cancer coming back or spreading is higher in the first few years than for some other types of breast cancer. However, after around 5 years the risks are similar to, and may be lower than, other types of breast cancer.

Question (100 words): How can I find out about clinical trials for triple negative breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can find information about clinical trials for triple negative breast cancer on the Cancer Research UK website and the Make 2nds Count website. Your treatment team can also provide information about suitable trials.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Cancer Research UK (cancerresearch.org.uk) has a list of current trials for triple negative breast cancer. You can find out more about clinical trials for secondary breast cancer on the Make 2nds Count website at make2ndscount.co.uk.

Question (100 words): What support services are available for triple negative breast cancer patients?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast Cancer Now offers a free Helpline, email support, and various other support services. You can call 0808 800 6000 or email nurse@breastcancernow.org for assistance.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Our specialist team are ready to listen on our free Helpline. Call 0808 800 6000 (Monday to Friday 9am–4pm and Saturday 9am–1pm). You can also email nurse@breastcancernow.org.

Question (100 words): What types of breast cancer are more likely to be triple negative?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Medullary and metaplastic breast cancers are more likely to be triple negative. However, most triple negative breast cancers are invasive breast cancer (no special type).
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some types of primary breast cancer are more likely to be triple negative than others. These include medullary and metaplastic breast cancer.

Question (100 words): Can triple negative breast cancer spread to other parts of the body?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, triple negative breast cancer can spread to other parts of the body, such as the bones, lungs, liver, or brain, making it secondary breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Triple negative breast cancer can be: Secondary breast cancer – has spread to another part of the body, such as the bones, lungs, liver or brain.

Question (100 words): What is the role of lymph node surgery in triple negative breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Lymph node surgery is performed to check if cancer cells have spread to the lymph nodes under the arm. This helps determine if additional treatment is needed after surgery.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your treatment team will want to check if any of the lymph nodes (glands) under the arm contain cancer cells. This, along with other information about your breast cancer, helps them decide whether you will benefit from any additional treatment after surgery.

Question (100 words): Are there any lifestyle changes recommended during triple negative breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Maintaining a healthy lifestyle, including a balanced diet, regular physical activity, and avoiding smoking and excessive alcohol, is recommended to support overall health during treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Although specific lifestyle changes are not detailed in the document, maintaining a healthy lifestyle is generally recommended to support overall health during cancer treatment.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience severe side effects from my treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience severe side effects from your treatment, contact your healthcare team immediately. They can provide guidance on managing side effects and may adjust your treatment plan if necessary.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Although specific instructions are not provided in the document, it is crucial to contact your healthcare team if you experience severe side effects from your treatment.

Question (100 words): How often should I have follow-up appointments after triple negative breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Follow-up appointments are typically scheduled regularly after treatment to monitor your health and check for any signs of cancer recurrence. The frequency of these appointments may vary based on your individual treatment plan.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Although specific follow-up schedules are not detailed in the document, regular follow-up appointments are essential to monitor your health and check for any signs of cancer recurrence.

Question (100 words): What should I know about participating in clinical trials for triple negative breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Clinical trials for triple negative breast cancer aim to find new and effective treatments. Before participating, discuss the potential benefits and risks with your healthcare team and ensure you understand the trial's purpose and procedures.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Clinical trials are trying to find out if different treatments will be helpful in treating triple negative breast cancer. You can find out more about clinical trials for secondary breast cancer on the Make 2nds Count website at make2ndscount.co.uk.

Question (100 words): What is EC-T chemotherapy and how does it work?
Answer (Max 2000 words): EC-T is a combination of three chemotherapy drugs: epirubicin, cyclophosphamide, and docetaxel or paclitaxel. It works by destroying cancer cells by affecting their ability to divide and grow. However, it can also affect other cells in the body, leading to side effects.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: EC-T is a combination of 3 chemotherapy drugs. It takes its name from the initials of the 3 drugs: E – epirubicin, C – cyclophosphamide, T – docetaxel (Taxotere) or paclitaxel (Taxol), which belong to a group of drugs called taxanes. Chemotherapy destroys cancer cells by affecting their ability to divide and grow.

Question (100 words): Who might be offered EC-T chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): EC-T chemotherapy is typically offered to patients with primary breast cancer that hasn't spread beyond the breast or lymph nodes. It may be given before surgery to shrink the tumor or after surgery to reduce the risk of recurrence.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may be offered EC-T chemotherapy if you have primary breast cancer. This is breast cancer that has not spread beyond the breast or lymph nodes (glands) under the arm.

Question (100 words): How is EC-T chemotherapy administered?
Answer (Max 2000 words): EC-T chemotherapy is given intravenously, usually through a cannula in the hand or arm. It can also be administered through a Hickman line, PICC line, or an implanted port.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: EC-T is given into a vein (intravenously). This will usually be through a cannula, a small tube that’s inserted into a vein in the back of your hand or lower arm.

Question (100 words): What tests are done before starting EC-T chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Before starting EC-T chemotherapy, you will have blood tests, measurements of your height and weight, and tests to check your heart function, such as an ECG, echocardiogram, or MUGA scan.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You’ll have blood tests and your height and weight will be measured. You may also have tests to check your heart function, such as: An ECG (electrocardiogram) – a simple test that checks your heart rhythm, An echocardiogram (echo) – an ultrasound scan of the heart, A MUGA (multiple-gated acquisition) scan – an injection and heart scan.

Question (100 words): What is the schedule for EC-T chemotherapy treatments?
Answer (Max 2000 words): EC-T chemotherapy is given in two parts: EC (epirubicin and cyclophosphamide) is usually given once every 2 or 3 weeks, and T (docetaxel or paclitaxel) is given after completing EC sessions, usually once every 3 weeks.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: EC is usually given once every 2 or 3 weeks, over about 1 hour. Docetaxel is usually given once every 3 weeks, over about 1 hour.

Question (100 words): Why is there a gap between each EC-T chemotherapy cycle?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The gap between each cycle allows your body to recover. Chemotherapy can reduce the number of blood cells, and the gap ensures your blood cell counts return to normal before the next cycle.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The gap between each cycle of treatment gives your body time to recover. Chemotherapy can reduce the amount of blood cells in your body.

Question (100 words): How is the risk of an allergic reaction managed during EC-T chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Before each treatment, you will usually be given steroids to reduce the risk of an allergic reaction. You will be closely monitored during treatment for any signs of a reaction.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Before each treatment of EC-T, you will usually be given drugs called steroids to reduce the risk of an allergic reaction. You’ll be monitored closely during your treatment so that any reaction can be dealt with immediately.

Question (100 words): What are the common side effects of EC-T chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common side effects include effects on blood cells (risk of infection, anaemia, bruising and bleeding), nausea and vomiting, diarrhoea or constipation, hair loss, extreme tiredness, numbness and tingling in hands and feet, reaction at the injection site, bladder irritation, and sore mouth.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Like any treatment, EC-T can cause side effects. Everyone reacts differently to drugs and some people will have more side effects than others.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience severe side effects during EC-T chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience severe side effects, contact your treatment team or the 24-hour helpline number immediately. They can provide guidance and necessary interventions.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re worried about any side effects, regardless of whether they’re listed here, talk to your chemotherapy nurse or treatment team.

Question (100 words): Will I lose my hair during EC-T chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, EC-T chemotherapy usually causes hair loss, including hair on your head, eyebrows, eyelashes, and body hair. Hair loss typically begins about 2 weeks after the first treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: EC-T causes hair loss. Most people will lose all their hair, including hair on their head, eyebrows, eyelashes and body hair.

Question (100 words): Can I do anything to prevent hair loss during EC-T chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can try scalp cooling to reduce hair loss. This involves wearing a cold cap before, during, and after your treatment. However, it may not work for everyone.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can try scalp cooling to stop you losing some or all of the hair on your head. This involves wearing a cold cap before, during and for 1 to 2 hours after your treatment with chemotherapy drugs.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice blood in my urine during EC-T chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you notice blood in your urine, contact your treatment team immediately. Chemotherapy drugs, particularly cyclophosphamide, can irritate the bladder lining.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Tell your treatment team if you notice: Blood in your urine, Irritation, burning or stinging when you pee.

Question (100 words): How can I manage nausea and vomiting during EC-T chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You will be given anti-sickness medication before each cycle of chemotherapy and some to take home. If nausea and vomiting are affecting you, inform your treatment team.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You’ll be given anti-sickness medication, as tablets or into a vein, before each cycle of chemotherapy. You’ll also have some anti-sickness drugs to take home.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I feel extremely tired during EC-T chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Extreme tiredness, or fatigue, is a common side effect. Inform your GP or treatment team, who can offer advice on managing your energy levels.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you think you have fatigue, tell your GP or treatment team. They can assess you and offer advice on how to manage your energy levels.

Question (100 words): What is peripheral neuropathy and how can it be managed during EC-T chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Peripheral neuropathy is pain, numbness, or tingling in your hands and feet caused by docetaxel and paclitaxel affecting the nerves. Inform your treatment team if you experience these symptoms so they can monitor them.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may have pain, numbness or tingling in your hands and feet while having EC-T. This is called peripheral neuropathy and happens if docetaxel and paclitaxel affect the nerves.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I have a high temperature during EC-T chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A high temperature (over 37.5°C) or low temperature (under 36°C) can indicate an infection. Contact your hospital immediately if you experience this.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: But generally you should contact your hospital immediately if you have any of the following: A high temperature (over 37.5°C) or low temperature (under 36°C)

Question (100 words): How can I manage diarrhoea or constipation during EC-T chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your chemotherapy team can provide medicine to help control diarrhoea or constipation. Drinking plenty of fluids can also be helpful. Contact your chemotherapy team if you have diarrhoea 3 or more times in 24 hours.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your chemotherapy team can give you medicine to help control it and can give you information about diet. Drinking plenty of fluids can also be helpful.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience numbness and tingling in my hands and feet during EC-T chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Inform your treatment team if you experience numbness and tingling in your hands and feet. They can monitor your symptoms and provide appropriate care.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have symptoms of peripheral neuropathy, tell your treatment team so they can monitor them.

Question (100 words): What is the purpose of having EC-T chemotherapy before surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): EC-T chemotherapy before surgery, known as neo-adjuvant chemotherapy, is used to shrink a larger breast cancer, making breast-conserving surgery an option, or to slow down the growth of a fast-growing cancer and reduce the risk of spread.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may have EC-T chemotherapy before surgery to shrink a larger breast cancer. This may mean breast-conserving surgery (a lumpectomy or wide local excision) is an option, rather than a mastectomy.

Question (100 words): What types of breast cancer are more likely to receive EC-T chemotherapy before surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Patients with certain types of breast cancer, such as inflammatory breast cancer, HER2-positive breast cancer, or triple-negative breast cancer, are more likely to receive EC-T chemotherapy before surgery.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may be more likely to have chemotherapy before surgery if you have a certain type of breast cancer, such as inflammatory breast cancer, HER2-positive breast cancer or triple negative breast cancer.

Question (100 words): Why might my taste change during EC-T chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your taste may change while you’re having EC-T. Some food may taste different, for example more salty, bitter or metallic. You may no longer enjoy some foods you used to like. This is a common side effect and should return to normal once your treatment has finished. Speak to your treatment team for ways to manage this.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your taste may change while you’re having EC-T. Some food may taste different, for example more salty, bitter or metallic. You may no longer enjoy some foods you used to like.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I lose my appetite during EC-T chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You may lose your appetite while having EC-T. Talk to your treatment team or breast care nurse about this. They can give you advice and information to help deal with loss of appetite and may refer you to a dietitian if needed. See our booklet Diet and breast cancer for more information.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may lose your appetite while having EC-T. Talk to your treatment team or breast care nurse about this.

Question (100 words): Why do I feel more forgetful and have trouble concentrating during treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Treatment can affect your ability to concentrate and make you more forgetful. This is sometimes called “chemo brain” or “chemo fog”, but your treatment team may call it cognitive impairment. It usually improves over time after treatment has finished. You can read more information about this on our website breastcancernow.org.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Treatment can affect your ability to concentrate and make you more forgetful.

Question (100 words): Will EC-T chemotherapy cause menopausal symptoms?
Answer (Max 2000 words): EC-T may cause menopausal symptoms if you haven’t already been through the menopause. This is because it affects the ovaries, which produce the hormone oestrogen. Your periods may stop or become irregular during chemotherapy. Other common menopausal symptoms can include hot flushes, night sweats, mood changes, joint aches and pains, vaginal dryness, and changes to your sex drive. Talk to your breast care nurse or treatment team about ways of coping with any of these symptoms.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: EC-T may cause menopausal symptoms if you haven’t already been through the menopause.

Question (100 words): Why do my muscles and joints ache after EC-T chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your muscles or joints may ache or become painful 2 to 3 days after you have treatment, particularly docetaxel or paclitaxel. This usually improves after a few days. However, it can be very painful and you may need to take mild pain relief such as paracetamol or anti-inflammatory drugs such as ibuprofen.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your muscles or joints may ache or become painful 2 to 3 days after you have treatment, particularly docetaxel or paclitaxel.

Question (100 words): What causes fluid retention during EC-T chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You may develop a build-up of fluid in the body (oedema), particularly when having docetaxel or paclitaxel. It may cause swollen ankles and legs and shortness of breath. This can take a few weeks to get better. You’ll usually be given steroid drugs to prevent an allergic reaction, which will also help reduce the chance of fluid building up.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may develop a build-up of fluid in the body (oedema), particularly when having docetaxel or paclitaxel.

Question (100 words): Will I gain weight during EC-T chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You may put on weight, but you’ll usually lose it again once treatment finishes. This can vary from person to person and may take up to several months. Physical activity and eating a healthy diet may help with this. For more information on healthy eating, see our booklet Diet and breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may put on weight, but you’ll usually lose it again once treatment finishes.

Question (100 words): What are the less common side effects of EC-T chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Less common side effects include heart changes, sore eyes and runny nose, headaches, skin changes, sore hands and feet, and nail changes. If you experience any of these, inform your treatment team immediately.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Less common side effects include heart changes, sore eyes and runny nose, headaches, skin changes, sore hands and feet, and nail changes.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience heart changes during EC-T chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Epirubicin can affect your heart and blood pressure. This is usually temporary but for a small number of people it may be permanent. Before you start chemotherapy, your treatment team may arrange a heart (cardiac) function test. You will also be carefully monitored during your treatment. If you have pain or tightness in your chest, feel breathless or notice changes to your heartbeat at any time during or after treatment, tell your treatment team straight away.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Epirubicin can affect your heart and blood pressure.

Question (100 words): Can EC-T chemotherapy cause changes to my skin?
Answer (Max 2000 words): EC-T can make your skin dry, more sensitive or prone to reactions. If you develop a rash tell your treatment team as soon as possible. Your skin may be more sensitive to the sun, so use a high factor (SPF) sun cream.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: EC-T can make your skin dry, more sensitive or prone to reactions.

Question (100 words): What is hand-foot syndrome and how is it treated?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You may develop soreness or redness on the palms of your hands and soles of your feet. This is called palmar-plantar or hand-foot syndrome. Your treatment team or GP can prescribe creams or medication to treat hand-foot syndrome.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You may develop soreness or redness on the palms of your hands and soles of your feet. This is called palmar-plantar or hand-foot syndrome.

Question (100 words): Can EC-T chemotherapy affect my nails?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Chemotherapy may cause changes to the appearance of your nails. This can be a change in the nail colour or texture, such as ridges forming. Nails can also become more brittle and cracked. Occasionally the nail may lift off the nail bed and fall out, but it will grow back.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Chemotherapy may cause changes to the appearance of your nails.

Question (100 words): What are the rare side effects of EC-T chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Rare side effects include damage to the lungs, liver or kidney changes, and a small risk of developing a rare type of blood cancer in the future. You’ll have regular blood tests to monitor your liver and kidneys throughout your chemotherapy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Rare side effects include damage to the lungs, liver or kidney changes, and a small risk of developing a rare type of blood cancer in the future.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I suspect a blood clot during EC-T chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Blood clots can be life-threatening and should be treated quickly. Contact your treatment team or go to your local A&E department straight away if you have any of the following symptoms: pain in your arm or leg, redness/discolouration of the skin of the arm or leg, heat and swelling of the arm or leg, swelling, redness or tenderness where a central line is inserted, shortness of breath that comes on suddenly, pain or tightness in the chest, unexplained cough or coughing up blood.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Blood clots can be life-threatening and should be treated quickly.

Question (100 words): Can I have sex during EC-T chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can still have sex during treatment. It’s thought chemotherapy drugs cannot pass into vaginal fluids or semen, but this cannot be completely ruled out. Most treatment teams will advise using barrier methods of contraception, such as condoms or female condoms, during treatment and for a few days after chemotherapy is given.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can still have sex during treatment.

Question (100 words): How does EC-T chemotherapy affect fertility?
Answer (Max 2000 words): EC-T chemotherapy causes changes in the ovaries, which can affect your ability to become pregnant (fertility). How likely you are to lose this ability (become infertile) also depends on things like whether you have had chemotherapy in the past, other health conditions and your age. Many women stop having periods during chemotherapy, but this may be temporary. If you’re aged around 40 and over, your periods are less likely to return after you’ve finished chemotherapy than if you’re under 40. In men, EC-T chemotherapy can affect sperm production which can lead to temporary or permanent infertility.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: EC-T chemotherapy causes changes in the ovaries, which can affect your ability to become pregnant (fertility).

Question (100 words): What vaccinations should I avoid during EC-T chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You should not have any live vaccines while you’re having chemotherapy. Live vaccines include mumps, measles, rubella (German measles), polio, BCG (tuberculosis), and yellow fever. It’s safe to have these vaccinations 6 months after your treatment finishes. Talk to your GP or treatment team before having any vaccinations.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You should not have any live vaccines while you’re having chemotherapy.

Question (100 words): When should I get the flu vaccine during EC-T chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Anyone at risk of a weakened immune system, and therefore more prone to infection, should have the flu vaccine. This includes people due to have, or already having, chemotherapy. The flu vaccine is not a live vaccine so does not contain any active viruses. Talk to your chemotherapy team or breast care nurse about the best time to have your flu jab.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The flu vaccine is not a live vaccine so does not contain any active viruses.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I need to travel overseas during EC-T chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you’re planning a holiday or need to travel overseas, check with your treatment team first. You should not have any live vaccines while you’re having chemotherapy. If anyone you have close contact with needs to have a live vaccine, speak to your treatment team or GP. They can advise what precautions you may need to take depending on the vaccination.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re planning a holiday or need to travel overseas, check with your treatment team first.

Question (100 words): Where can I find further support during EC-T chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your treatment team and breast care nurse can help with any questions you have. You can also speak to our specialist nurses by calling our free helpline 0808 800 6000 or visiting our website breastcancernow.org. You can find people going through treatment at the same time as you on the monthly chemotherapy threads on our online forum forum.breastcancernow.org. You can also speak to someone else who has had chemotherapy for primary breast cancer through our Someone Like Me service.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your treatment team and breast care nurse can help with any questions you have.

Question (100 words): What is breast cancer and how does it start?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast cancer begins when breast cells start dividing and growing in an abnormal and uncontrolled manner. Primary breast cancer is cancer that has not spread beyond the breast or the axillary lymph nodes.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Rak piersi zaczyna się, kiedy komórki piersi rozpoczynają podziały i rozrost w odbiegający od normy i niekontrolowany sposób. Pierwotny rak piersi to rak, który nie rozprzestrzenił się poza pierś albo pachowe węzły chłonne.

Question (100 words): What are the goals of treating invasive breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The goals of treating invasive breast cancer are to remove all the cancer present in the breast and any affected lymph nodes under the arm (local control) and to destroy any cancer cells that may have spread to other parts of the body (systemic treatment).
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Leczenie inwazyjnego raka piersi ma na celu usunięcie całego nowotworu obecnego w piersi oraz wszelkich objętych chorobą węzłów chłonnych pod pachą. Inne metody leczenia mają na celu zniszczenie wszelkich komórek nowotworowych, które mogły się rozprzestrzenić z piersi do innych obszarów ciała przez krwiobieg lub układ limfatyczny.

Question (100 words): What factors influence the choice of breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The choice of breast cancer treatment is influenced by several factors including the size and location of the cancer, whether it has spread to the lymph nodes, the type and grade of the cancer, and the presence of certain receptors on the cancer cells.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Na to, które metody leczenia są zalecane, mają wpływ następujące czynniki: Rozmiar raka piersi, Lokalizacja raka w obrębie piersi, Rodzaj raka piersi, Stopień złośliwości raka piersi, Czy rak rozprzestrzenił się do pachowych węzłów chłonnych.

Question (100 words): Who is part of the multidisciplinary team (MDT) treating breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The multidisciplinary team (MDT) treating breast cancer includes a breast care nurse, a chemotherapy nurse, a clinical oncologist, a medical oncologist, a pathologist, a radiologist, a research nurse, a surgeon, and a radiography therapist, among others.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Do zespołu należą: Pielęgniarka zajmująca się chorymi na raka piersi, Pielęgniarka specjalizująca się w chemioterapii, Onkolog kliniczny, Onkolog medyczny, Patolog, Radiolog, Pielęgniarka specjalizująca się w badaniach klinicznych, Chirurg, Technik radiologii.

Question (100 words): What is the role of a breast care nurse in my treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A breast care nurse provides information, answers your questions, and offers support throughout your hospital treatment and beyond. They are often referred to as your 'key worker'.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Twoja pielęgniarka spróbuje odpowiedzieć na wszelkie Twoje pytania, a także zapewni Ci wsparcie podczas leczenia szpitalnego i po nim. Stanowisko to czasem określa się jako „kluczowy pracownik”.

Question (100 words): Can I take my time to decide on my treatment plan?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, you do not have to start treatment in a hurry. You can take a few days to think about your treatment options without it affecting the outcome of your treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Nie musisz rozpoczynać leczenia w pośpiechu. Zanim zdecydujesz, co zrobić, możesz poświęcić kilka dni na przemyślenie zaproponowanych opcji leczenia.

Question (100 words): What are some questions I should ask about my treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You should ask why a particular treatment is best for you, if there are other options, if there are clinical trials you can join, when treatment will start, where you will receive treatment, how long it will last, possible side effects, how it will affect your daily life, your fertility, and your prognosis.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Przykładowe pytania: Dlaczego ta metoda leczenia jest dla mnie najlepsza? Czy są inne opcje? Czy istnieją badania kliniczne, w których mogę wziąć udział? Kiedy rozpocznie się leczenie? Gdzie mam się zgłosić na leczenie? Jak długo potrwa moje leczenie? Jakie są możliwe skutki uboczne? Jak leczenie wpłynie na moje codzienne życie? Jak leczenie wpłynie na moją płodność? Jakie są rokowania (prognozy)?

Question (100 words): What is the Nottingham Prognostic Index (NPI)?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The Nottingham Prognostic Index (NPI) is a scoring system that helps determine the prognostic category of your breast cancer as good, moderate, or poor. It helps predict the likely course and outcome of the disease.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Wskaźnik prognostyczny Nottingham Prognostic Index (NPI) to system punktacji, który pozwala określić kategorię prognostyczną jako dobrą, umiarkowaną lub złą.

Question (100 words): What is PREDICT and how is it used in treatment decisions?
Answer (Max 2000 words): PREDICT is an online decision-making tool that estimates the benefits of chemotherapy, hormonal therapy, and targeted therapy after surgery, based on information about you and your breast cancer. It is not suitable for everyone, but your doctor or breast care nurse will inform you if it is useful in your case.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: PREDICT to narzędzie online służące do podejmowania decyzji. Pozwala ono oszacować korzyści z chemioterapii, terapii hormonalnej i terapii celowanej po operacji, na podstawie informacji dotyczących Ciebie i Twojego raka piersi.

Question (100 words): What are genomic tests and how do they help in treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Genomic tests, also known as gene expression profiling or genetic tests, look at groups of genes found in breast cancer. They help determine who may benefit most from chemotherapy and the likelihood of the cancer coming back (recurrence).
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Te badania zajmują się grupami genów stwierdzanymi przy raku piersi. Pomagają one ustalić, kto może najbardziej skorzystać z chemioterapii oraz jakie jest prawdopodobieństwo ponownego pojawienia się raka (wznowy).

Question (100 words): What should I do if I'm feeling emotionally overwhelmed by my diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you're feeling persistently low or anxious, talk to your breast care nurse or GP for support. Our brochure 'Diagnosis of breast cancer: what next?' can also help you navigate your emotions and treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Jeżeli stale masz obniżony nastrój i czujesz niepokój, możesz porozmawiać ze swoją pielęgniarką zajmującą się chorymi na raka piersi lub lekarzem rodzinnym, aby uzyskać pomoc w tym zakresie.

Question (100 words): Where can I find more detailed information about my treatment options and side effects?
Answer (Max 2000 words): More detailed information about treatment options and side effects can be found in other publications or on the website breastcancernow.org. You can also call the helpline at 0808 800 6000 for additional support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Bardziej szczegółowe informacje dotyczące poszczególnych opcji leczenia, w tym skutków ubocznych, znajdują się w innych naszych publikacjach lub na stronie internetowej breastcancernow.org Ponadto istnieje możliwość zatelefonowania na infolinię pod numerem 0808 800 6000.

Question (100 words): What types of support services are available to me during and after treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Support services may include advice and help, complementary therapies, local support groups, dietary information, physical activity programs, and more. Your breast care nurse can inform you about the options available to you.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Mogą być również dostępne różne usługi wspierające. Różnią się one w zależności od obszaru dotkniętego nowotworem. Możesz potrzebować dalszych informacji na następujące tematy: Porady i pomoc, Terapie wspomagające, Lokalne grupy wsparcia, Informacje dietetyczne, Programy aktywności fizycznej.

Question (100 words): How involved do I need to be in making decisions about my treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can decide how much or how little you want to be involved in decisions about your treatment. Some people want to know everything and be fully involved, while others prefer to be well-informed but leave decisions to the treatment team. You can change your mind at any stage.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Możesz zdecydować, w jak dużym lub w jak małym stopniu chcesz się angażować w decyzje dotyczące Twojego leczenia.

Question (100 words): What happens if my treatment plan needs to be changed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your treatment plan may change as more information about your cancer becomes available, such as results from tests on breast tissue removed during surgery.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Plan leczenia może ulegać zmianom, w miarę jak pojawią się dalsze informacje na temat nowotworu (na przykład wyniki badań wykonywanych na tkankach piersi usuniętych podczas operacji).

Question (100 words): What is local control in breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Local control in breast cancer treatment refers to the removal of all cancer present in the breast and any affected lymph nodes under the arm, typically achieved through surgery or radiotherapy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Leczenie inwazyjnego raka piersi ma na celu usunięcie całego nowotworu obecnego w piersi oraz wszelkich objętych chorobą węzłów chłonnych pod pachą. Określa się to nazwą miejscowa kontrola lub kontrola lokoregionalna.

Question (100 words): What is systemic treatment in breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Systemic treatment in breast cancer aims to destroy any cancer cells that may have spread from the breast to other parts of the body through the bloodstream or lymphatic system, and to reduce the risk of future cancer occurrence in other areas. Methods include chemotherapy, hormonal therapy, and targeted therapy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Inne metody leczenia mają na celu zniszczenie wszelkich komórek nowotworowych, które mogły się rozprzestrzenić z piersi do innych obszarów ciała przez krwiobieg lub układ limfatyczny, i zmniejszenie ryzyka, że rak w przyszłości wystąpi w innych obszarach ciała. Do metod leczenia systemowego należą: chemioterapia, terapia hormonalna i terapia celowana.

Question (100 words): How is the prognosis of breast cancer determined?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The prognosis of breast cancer is determined by factors such as the size and location of the cancer, whether it has spread to the lymph nodes, the type and grade of the cancer, and the presence of certain receptors on the cancer cells. Tools like the Nottingham Prognostic Index (NPI) and PREDICT can also help estimate prognosis.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Na to, które metody leczenia są zalecane, mają wpływ następujące czynniki: Rozmiar raka piersi, Lokalizacja raka w obrębie piersi, Rodzaj raka piersi, Stopień złośliwości raka piersi, Czy rak rozprzestrzenił się do pachowych węzłów chłonnych. PREDICT to narzędzie online służące do podejmowania decyzji. Pozwala ono oszacować korzyści z chemioterapii, terapii hormonalnej i terapii celowanej po operacji.

Question (100 words): What is the role of genomic tests in breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Genomic tests analyze groups of genes found in breast cancer to help determine who may benefit most from chemotherapy and the likelihood of the cancer coming back (recurrence).
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Te badania zajmują się grupami genów stwierdzanymi przy raku piersi. Pomagają one ustalić, kto może najbardziej skorzystać z chemioterapii oraz jakie jest prawdopodobieństwo ponownego pojawienia się raka (wznowy).

Question (100 words): What should I do if I need emotional support during my treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you need emotional support, talk to your breast care nurse or GP. Additionally, our brochure 'Diagnosis of breast cancer: what next?' provides information on emotional aspects and support available to you.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Jeżeli stale masz obniżony nastrój i czujesz niepokój, możesz porozmawiać ze swoją pielęgniarką zajmującą się chorymi na raka piersi lub lekarzem rodzinnym, aby uzyskać pomoc w tym zakresie. Nasza broszura Diagnoza raka piersi: co dalej? przeznaczona jest dla wszystkich, którzy próbują sobie poradzić z diagnozą raka piersi i leczeniem.

Question (100 words): What are the common genetic tests used in breast cancer diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common genetic tests used in breast cancer diagnosis include EndoPredict, Oncotype DX, and Prosigna. These tests help determine the best treatment options based on the genetic profile of the tumor.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Przykłady testów wykorzystywanych w badaniach genetycznych to: • EndoPredict • Oncotype DX • Prosigna

Question (100 words): What should younger women consider when deciding on breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Younger women should consider the impact of treatment on fertility, new relationships, and family life. It's important to gather information and discuss options with healthcare providers.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Kobiety, które w momencie rozpoznania raka piersi nie przeszły jeszcze menopauzy, często mierzą się z dodatkowymi problemami.

Question (100 words): Is it common for patients to seek a second opinion about their diagnosis and treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, seeking a second opinion is a common practice. It can provide additional reassurance and may slightly delay treatment, but it generally does not affect the outcome.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Niektóre osoby biorą pod uwagę zasięgnięcie innej opinii w kwestii rozpoznania i leczenia.

Question (100 words): What are the reasons some patients might refuse recommended treatments for breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Patients may refuse treatment due to personal, religious, or cultural beliefs, experiences of family or friends, fear of treatment, or concerns about quality of life and family impact.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Może to mieć różne przyczyny. Niektóre osoby mają bardzo mocne przekonania osobiste, religijne lub kulturowe wiodące do odmowy leczenia.

Question (100 words): What are clinical trials and why might I be invited to participate in one?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Clinical trials are research studies aimed at improving treatment and patient care. You might be invited to participate to test new drugs, surgical methods, radiation doses, or treatment combinations.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Badania kliniczne to badania naukowe mające na celu ulepszenie leczenia i opieki nad pacjentami.

Question (100 words): What are the primary treatment methods for primary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The primary treatment methods for primary breast cancer include surgery, chemotherapy, radiotherapy, hormonal therapy, targeted therapy, and bisphosphonates.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Leczenie pierwotnego raka piersi ma na celu usunięcie nowotworu oraz zmniejszenie ryzyka jego nawrotu lub rozprzestrzeniania się do innych części ciała.

Question (100 words): What is the goal of surgical treatment for breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The goal of surgical treatment is to remove the tumor along with a margin of healthy breast tissue to reduce the risk of local recurrence and prevent the spread of cancer to other parts of the body.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Jej celem jest usunięcie nowotworu wraz z częścią (marginesem) otaczającej go zdrowej tkanki piersi.

Question (100 words): What are the two main types of breast surgery for cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The two main types of breast surgery are breast-conserving surgery (lumpectomy) and mastectomy. The type recommended depends on the tumor's type, size, location, and whether it affects multiple areas of the breast.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Istnieją dwa podstawowe rodzaje operacji piersi: • Operacja oszczędzająca, znana również pod nazwą wycięcia guzka lub lumpektomii • Mastektomia (amputacja piersi)

Question (100 words): What is a breast-conserving surgery and what is its purpose?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast-conserving surgery, or lumpectomy, involves removing the tumor with a margin of healthy breast tissue. Its purpose is to preserve as much of the breast as possible while ensuring complete removal of the tumor.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Operacja oszczędzająca pierś jest to zabieg, przy którym nowotwór jest usuwany z częścią (marginesem) zdrowej tkanki piersi.

Question (100 words): When is a mastectomy recommended and what does it involve?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A mastectomy is recommended for large tumors, multiple tumor areas, or inflammatory breast cancer. It involves removing all breast tissue, including the nipple area.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Przykłady sytuacji, w których może być zalecana mastektomia, to między innymi: • Nowotwór, który zajął duży obszar piersi • Więcej niż jeden obszar piersi jest objęty nowotworem • Rozpoznano zapalnego raka piersi

Question (100 words): What is the difference between a simple mastectomy and other types of mastectomies?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A simple mastectomy involves removing all breast tissue, skin, and the nipple area. Other types include skin-sparing mastectomy and nipple-sparing mastectomy, which preserve more of the breast's skin and nipple.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Prosta mastektomia to usunięcie całej tkanki piersi, wraz ze skórą i obszarem brodawki sutkowej.

Question (100 words): Is it necessary to remove the healthy breast if I have breast cancer in one breast?
Answer (Max 2000 words): It is usually not necessary or recommended to remove the healthy breast unless there is a high risk of developing primary breast cancer on the other side, such as due to a genetic mutation or strong family history.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Badania wykazują, że zazwyczaj nie jest to konieczne ani zalecane, z wyjątkiem sytuacji, kiedy istnieje podwyższone ryzyko wystąpienia pierwotnego raka piersi po drugiej stronie.

Question (100 words): What is the role of lymph nodes in breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Lymph nodes are checked to see if cancer cells have spread. If cancer is found in the lymph nodes, they may be removed during breast surgery.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: W przypadku inwazyjnego raka piersi opiekujący się Tobą zespół będzie chciał sprawdzić, czy którykolwiek z pachowych węzłów chłonnych zawiera komórki nowotworowe.

Question (100 words): What is a sentinel lymph node biopsy and why is it performed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A sentinel lymph node biopsy is performed to check if the first lymph node to which cancer is likely to spread contains cancer cells. It helps determine if further lymph nodes need to be removed.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Biopsja wartowniczego węzła chłonnego pozwala ona sprawdzić, czy wartowniczy węzeł chłonny (pierwszy węzeł chłonny, do którego z największym prawdopodobieństwem może rozprzestrzenić się rak) nie zawiera komórek nowotworowych.

Question (100 words): What are the potential side effects of a sentinel lymph node biopsy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Potential side effects include blue-green discoloration of urine and body fluids due to the dye used, and temporary skin discoloration around the biopsy site. Rare allergic reactions to the dye can occur but are easily treatable.

Question (100 words): What happens if cancer cells are found in the sentinel lymph node?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If cancer cells are found in the sentinel lymph node, it may be necessary to remove additional lymph nodes to ensure all cancerous cells are eliminated.

Question (100 words): Can chemotherapy be used before surgery to reduce the number of lymph nodes to be removed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, in some hospitals, chemotherapy may be offered before surgery to reduce the number of lymph nodes that need to be removed, especially if up to three lymph nodes are affected.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I decide not to undergo one or more recommended treatments?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you decide not to undergo recommended treatments, gather as much information as possible, consider discussing your decision with your healthcare team, and stay in contact with them for support. You may also want to discuss your decision with your family doctor.

Question (100 words): How long should I wait for surgery after it has been agreed upon with my specialist?
Answer (Max 2000 words): According to national guidelines, surgery should be performed within 31 days of agreeing to it with your specialist.

Question (100 words): What factors determine the type of breast surgery I will undergo?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The type of breast surgery recommended depends on the tumor's type, size, location, whether it affects multiple areas of the breast, and the size of your breasts. Your healthcare team will explain why a particular surgery is best for you.

Question (100 words): What are the treatment options if cancer cells are found in the sentinel lymph node?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If cancer cells are found in the sentinel lymph node, depending on the number of cells, the following options may be recommended: undergoing another surgery to remove some or all remaining lymph nodes, radiotherapy of the armpit area, or no further treatment of the armpit area if breast radiotherapy and chemotherapy or hormonal therapy are used.

Question (100 words): When is a sentinel lymph node biopsy recommended before chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A sentinel lymph node biopsy may be recommended before starting chemotherapy to help plan further treatment of the armpit area after chemotherapy.

Question (100 words): Is a sentinel lymph node biopsy necessary for DCIS?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A sentinel lymph node biopsy is necessary for DCIS only if a mastectomy is performed or if there is a high likelihood of also having invasive breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What is the purpose of evaluating the sentinel lymph node during breast surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The purpose of evaluating the sentinel lymph node during breast surgery is to determine if cancer cells are present. If they are, the surgeon may remove more lymph nodes, potentially avoiding a second surgery.

Question (100 words): What is lymphedema and what causes it?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Lymphedema is swelling in the arm, hand, or chest/breast area caused by the accumulation of lymph fluid in the tissues on the surface of the body. It can occur after the removal of lymph nodes.

Question (100 words): What is breast reconstruction and when can it be performed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast reconstruction is a surgical procedure to create a new breast shape. It can be performed after a mastectomy or breast-conserving surgery, either immediately or several months/years later.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Rekonstrukcja piersi to chirurgiczne wytworzenie nowego kształtu piersi. Może ona zostać wykonana po mastektomii lub po operacji oszczędzającej pierś. Rekonstrukcja może być wykonywana w tym samym czasie co operacja raka piersi (rekonstrukcja jednoczesna, natychmiastowa) lub kilka miesięcy lub lat później (rekonstrukcja opóźniona).

Question (100 words): What are the methods used for breast reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast reconstruction can be achieved using an implant, tissue from another area of the body, or a combination of both. If the nipple is not preserved, a new nipple can be created using surgical methods or tattooing.
