Question (100 words): How does chemotherapy work in treating breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Chemotherapy destroys cancer cells using anti-cancer drugs. It is used to reduce the risk of cancer recurrence or spread.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Chemioterapia niszczy komórki nowotworowe z użyciem leków przeciwnowotworowych. Chemioterapię stosuje się w celu zmniejszenia ryzyka nawrotu lub rozprzestrzenienia się raka.

Question (100 words): When is chemotherapy typically given after surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Chemotherapy is usually given a few weeks after surgery to allow your body time to recover. It is known as adjuvant chemotherapy and aims to reduce the risk of cancer recurrence by destroying any cancer cells that may have spread from the breast to other parts of the body.

Question (100 words): How is chemotherapy administered?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Most chemotherapy drugs used for primary breast cancer are given intravenously. However, some can also be taken orally in the form of tablets or capsules.

Question (100 words): What areas are treated with radiotherapy after breast-conserving surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After breast-conserving surgery, radiotherapy may be applied to the remaining breast tissue on that side (whole breast irradiation) or to the area where the breast cancer was located (partial breast irradiation). An additional dose may be recommended if invasive cancer was removed.

Question (100 words): When is radiotherapy typically given after surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Radiotherapy is usually given after surgery. If you are receiving chemotherapy after surgery, radiotherapy typically follows the completion of chemotherapy. It is usually administered daily for one to three weeks on an outpatient basis.

Zazwyczaj radioterapia jest stosowana codziennie, przez okres od jednego do trzech tygodni, w warunkach ambulatoryjnych.

Question (100 words): What is hormonal therapy and when is it used?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Hormonal therapy blocks or stops the effect of estrogen on breast cancer cells. It is used for breast cancers that are estrogen receptor-positive (ER+). It is usually started after surgery (and after chemotherapy if used) to reduce the risk of cancer recurrence or spread.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Terapia hormonalna blokują lub powstrzymują wpływ estrogenu na komórki raka piersi. Terapia hormonalna zostanie przepisana tylko w przypadku raka piersi ER+. Terapia hormonalna zwykle zaczyna się po operacji (i po chemioterapii, jeśli jest stosowana), w celu zmniejszenia ryzyka nawrotu raka lub rozprzestrzenienia się go na inne obszary ciała.

Question (100 words): What are the common types of hormonal therapy for breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common types of hormonal therapy for breast cancer include Tamoxifen, Anastrozole, Letrozole, Exemestane, and Goserelin. The type of hormonal therapy depends on various factors, such as whether a woman has gone through menopause.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Przykłady terapii hormonalnej raka piersi to: Tamoksyfen, Anastrozol, Letrozol, Eksemestan, Goserelina.

Question (100 words): What is targeted therapy and when is it used?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Targeted therapy is a group of drugs that block cancer growth and spread by interfering with cellular processes. It is used for breast cancers that are HER2-positive. Examples include trastuzumab, pertuzumab, and neratinib. It is usually given after surgery (and after chemotherapy if used) to reduce the risk of cancer recurrence or spread.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Terapie celowane to grupa leków, które blokują rozrost raka i jego rozprzestrzenianie. Terapię celowana zwykle podaje się po operacji (i po chemioterapii, jeśli jest stosowana), w celu zmniejszenia ryzyka nawrotu raka lub rozprzestrzenienia się go na inne obszary ciała.

Question (100 words): What are bisphosphonates and when are they used?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Bisphosphonates are a group of drugs that can reduce the risk of breast cancer spread in postmenopausal women. They can also slow down or prevent bone damage. They are often given to people with osteoporosis or those at risk of osteoporosis. They are usually given after treatment for invasive breast cancer that has spread to the axillary lymph nodes.

Question (100 words): How can lymphedema be managed after lymph node removal?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Lymphedema can be managed through a combination of specialized massage, compression garments, and skin care. It's important to seek guidance from a lymphedema specialist to develop a personalized management plan.

Question (100 words): What factors determine the type of hormonal therapy prescribed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The type of hormonal therapy prescribed depends on several factors, including whether a woman has gone through menopause and her risk of osteoporosis. Your healthcare team will consider these factors to determine the most appropriate therapy.

Question (100 words): Can hormonal therapy be given before surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, hormonal therapy can be given before surgery, known as neoadjuvant hormonal therapy. It may be used to reduce the size of the cancer before surgery.

Question (100 words): What should I discuss with my healthcare team before starting chemotherapy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Before starting chemotherapy, discuss any concerns about fertility with your healthcare team. Chemotherapy can affect fertility, so it's important to address this issue beforehand.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I feel overwhelmed after being diagnosed with breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): It's common to feel stressed and anxious after a breast cancer diagnosis. Question (100 words): How can I maintain a healthy diet during breast cancer treatment?

Question (100 words): Is it important to stay physically active during breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, staying physically active can help reduce some side effects of treatment and lower the risk of breast cancer recurrence. For exercises specific to post-surgery recovery, refer to the 'Ćwiczenia po operacji raka piersi' brochure.

Question (100 words): What complementary therapies are available for breast cancer patients?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Complementary therapies, such as herbal remedies and vitamin supplements, can be used alongside conventional treatment. However, it's important to inform your breast cancer nurse or doctor about any complementary therapies you are considering to ensure they do not interfere with your treatment.

Question (100 words): How will breast cancer affect my work and finances?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast cancer can impact your work and financial situation. You are entitled to certain protections and benefits, such as disability certification, which can provide workplace protections and additional support. Some hospitals also offer benefits advice services.

Question (100 words): What happens after I finish my breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After finishing your treatment, you will continue to be monitored through follow-up appointments to check your recovery. Question (100 words): Are there any courses or programs to help me adjust after treatment?

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience side effects from my treatment?

Question (100 words): How can I find reliable information about my breast cancer diagnosis?

Question (100 words): What is the role of a breast cancer nurse?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A breast cancer nurse provides specialized care and support to patients diagnosed with breast cancer. They offer information, emotional support, and help navigate the healthcare system and treatment options.

Question (100 words): How can I contribute to breast cancer research and support?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can support breast cancer research and patient care by making a donation to Breast Cancer Now. Your contributions help fund vital research and provide essential support services to those affected by breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What are the common symptoms of breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common symptoms of breast cancer include a lump or thickening in the breast or armpit, changes in breast size or shape, dimpling of the skin, nipple changes, or unusual discharge. If you notice any of these symptoms, consult your healthcare provider for further evaluation.

Question (100 words): What types of surgery are used to treat breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The types of surgery used to treat breast cancer include lumpectomy (removal of the tumor and a small margin of surrounding tissue), mastectomy (removal of the entire breast), and reconstructive surgery (to rebuild the breast after mastectomy). The choice of surgery depends on the stage and type of cancer.

Question (100 words): How should I care for my surgical drains and wounds after breast cancer surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Proper care of surgical drains and wounds is crucial for healing and preventing infection. Follow your healthcare provider’s instructions on how to clean and dress the wound, monitor for signs of infection, and manage the drains. Detailed guidance can be found in post-surgery care brochures.

Question (100 words): What medications are commonly used in breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common medications used in breast cancer treatment include chemotherapy drugs, hormone therapy drugs (such as tamoxifen), and targeted therapy drugs (such as Herceptin). These medications aim to kill cancer cells, block hormone receptors, or target specific proteins on cancer cells.

Question (100 words): What are the common side effects of breast cancer treatments?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common side effects of breast cancer treatments include fatigue, nausea, hair loss, changes in appetite, and emotional distress. These side effects vary depending on the type of treatment. It’s important to discuss potential side effects with your healthcare team.

Question (100 words): How can I prepare physically and emotionally before breast cancer surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Preparing for breast cancer surgery involves both physical and emotional prehabilitation. This may include gentle exercises to improve strength and flexibility, maintaining a healthy diet, and seeking emotional support to manage anxiety and stress. Consult your healthcare team for personalized advice.

Question (100 words): What is the main goal of a clinical trial for breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The main goal of a clinical trial is to improve the understanding and treatment of breast cancer. This can involve testing new drugs or other treatments to determine their safety and effectiveness.

Question (100 words): What are the common symptoms of breast cancer I should look out for?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common symptoms of breast cancer include a new lump or swelling in the breast, upper chest, or armpit; changes to the skin such as puckering or dimpling; a change in the nipple, like inversion; rash or crusting around the nipple; changes in the size or shape of the breast; unusual discharge from the nipple; and a change in the color of the breast, such as redness or inflammation.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A change to the way your breasts feel or look could be a sign of cancer. So get any new or unusual changes checked by a GP.

Question (100 words): How often should I check my breasts for any changes?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You should get used to checking your breasts regularly. There is no specific frequency, but being consistent and aware of any new or different changes is important.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Get used to checking regularly and be aware of anything that’s new or different for you.

Question (100 words): Is breast pain a sign of breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast pain alone is usually not a sign of cancer. However, persistent or almost constant pain in the breast or armpit should be checked by a GP.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: On its own pain in your breasts is not usually a sign of cancer. But look out for pain in your breast or armpit that’s there all or almost all the time.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice a new lump in my breast?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you notice a new lump in your breast, you should make an appointment to see your GP. Most breast changes, including lumps, are not cancer, but it's important to get any new or unusual changes checked.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A change to the way your breasts feel or look could be a sign of cancer. So get any new or unusual changes checked by a GP.

Question (100 words): Do I need any special training to check my breasts?
Answer (Max 2000 words): No, you do not need any special training to check your breasts. Everyone will have their own way of touching and looking for changes. The important thing is to get used to checking regularly and be aware of anything that’s new or different for you.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There’s no special way to check your breasts and you do not need any training.

Question (100 words): What areas should I check when examining my breasts?
Answer (Max 2000 words): When examining your breasts, you should check the whole breast area, including up to your collarbone (upper chest) and armpits.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Check your whole breast area, including up to your collarbone (upper chest) and armpits.

Question (100 words): Can changes in the nipple be a sign of breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, changes in the nipple, such as inversion, rash, or crusting around the nipple, can be a sign of breast cancer and should be checked by a GP.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A change to the nipple, for example it has become pulled in (inverted) or rash or crusting around the nipple.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I find something unusual in my breast?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you find something unusual in your breast, such as a lump, skin changes, or nipple changes, you should make an appointment to see your GP to get it checked.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Get any new or unusual changes checked by a GP.

Question (100 words): Is it normal for breasts to change in size or shape?
Answer (Max 2000 words): While some changes in breast size or shape can be normal, any new or unusual changes should be checked by a GP to rule out breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Changes in size or shape of the breast.

Question (100 words): What does unusual discharge from the nipple indicate?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Unusual discharge from the nipple can be a sign of breast cancer and should be checked by a GP.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Unusual liquid (discharge) from either nipple.

Question (100 words): Can inflammation or redness in the breast be a sign of cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, a change in the color of the breast, such as redness or inflammation, can be a sign of breast cancer and should be checked by a GP.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A change in the colour of the breast – the breast may look red or inflamed.

Question (100 words): How can I get support if I have questions or worries about my breasts?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can call Breast Cancer Now for free and confidential support. They have access to an interpreting service in over 240 languages.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have any questions or worries about your breasts or breast cancer, call us free and confidentially. We have access to an interpreting service in over 240 languages.

Question (100 words): What is the importance of knowing how my breasts normally look and feel?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Knowing how your breasts normally look and feel means you’ll be able to notice any unusual changes more easily. This can help in the early detection of breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Getting to know how your breasts look and feel normally means you’ll be able to notice any unusual changes.

Question (100 words): Should I be concerned about temporary breast pain?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Temporary breast pain is usually not a cause for concern. However, if the pain is persistent or almost constant, it should be checked by a GP.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: On its own pain in your breasts is not usually a sign of cancer. But look out for pain in your breast or armpit that’s there all or almost all the time.

Question (100 words): What are the first steps I should take if I notice a change in my breast?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The first step is to make an appointment with your GP to get any new or unusual changes checked. Early detection is key to successful treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Get any new or unusual changes checked by a GP. Most breast changes, including lumps, are not cancer. But the sooner breast cancer is found, the more successful treatment is likely to be.

Question (100 words): Can I use illustrations as a guide for checking my breasts?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, illustrations can be a helpful guide. However, it's important to check anything that looks or feels different for you with a GP.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: These illustrations are meant as a guide. Check anything that looks or feels different for you with a GP.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I feel a lump in my armpit?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you feel a lump in your armpit, you should make an appointment to see your GP. Lumps in the armpit can sometimes be a sign of breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A new lump or swelling in the breast, upper chest or armpit.

Question (100 words): Is it normal for breast skin to have dimples or puckering?
Answer (Max 2000 words): While some dimpling or puckering can be normal, any new or unusual changes in the breast skin should be checked by a GP.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Changes to the skin, such as puckering or dimpling.

Question (100 words): How can I ensure I’m checking my breasts effectively?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To check your breasts effectively, get used to checking regularly and be aware of anything that’s new or different for you. There is no specific way to check, but being consistent is key.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Get used to checking regularly and be aware of anything that’s new or different for you.

Question (100 words): What resources are available for me if I need to talk to someone about my breast concerns?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast Cancer Now offers free and confidential support. They provide access to an interpreting service in over 240 languages if you need to talk to someone about your breast concerns.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have any questions or worries about your breasts or breast cancer, call us free and confidentially. We have access to an interpreting service in over 240 languages.

Question (100 words): What is primary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Primary breast cancer is breast cancer that has not spread beyond the breast or under the arm. It starts when cells in the breast begin to grow abnormally.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Primary breast cancer is breast cancer that has not spread beyond the breast or under the arm.

Question (100 words): What are the different types of breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast cancer can be invasive or non-invasive (in situ). Invasive breast cancer can spread to other parts of the body, while non-invasive cannot.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast cancer can be invasive or non-invasive. Non-invasive can also be called in situ. Invasive breast cancer can spread to other parts of the body.

Question (100 words): What are the common feelings after being diagnosed with breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common feelings include fear, shock, anger, guilt, and sadness. There’s no right or wrong way to feel, and it’s important to talk to your treatment team or breast care nurse if you’re feeling low or worried.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Being told you have breast cancer can make you feel lots of different emotions. These could be fear, shock, anger, guilt, sadness.

Question (100 words): What treatments are available for invasive breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Treatments include surgery, radiotherapy, chemotherapy, targeted therapy, and hormone therapy. The goal is to remove all the cancer in the breast and under the arm.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Treatment for invasive breast cancer tries to remove all the cancer in the breast and any under the arm. Treatment could include: Surgery, Radiotherapy, Other treatments that try to destroy any cancer cells that may have already spread from the breast into the body.

Question (100 words): Who is part of my treatment team?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your treatment team can include a breast care nurse, chemotherapy nurse, clinical oncologist, medical oncologist, pathologist, surgeon, radiologist, and therapeutic radiographer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your treatment team can include: Breast care nurse, Chemotherapy nurse, Clinical oncologist, Medical oncologist, Pathologist, Surgeon, Radiologist, Therapeutic radiographer.

Question (100 words): What factors influence the choice of my breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Factors include your age, overall health, the presence of cancer in more than one part of the breast, whether the cancer has spread under the arm, and the size of the cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your treatment team will think about many different things when deciding the best treatment for you. Some of these are: Your age, Your health, If there is cancer in more than one part of the breast, If the cancer has spread under the arm, The size of the cancer.

Question (100 words): What tests will I need before starting treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Tests may include taking cells from the breast for analysis, x-rays, scans, and blood tests. These help determine the best treatment for you.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Tests will be done on cells taken from the breast. These tests are important because they help decide what sort of treatment will work best for you.

Question (100 words): Can I get a second opinion on my diagnosis and treatment plan?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, you can ask your treatment team for a different doctor to review your diagnosis and treatment plan. This is called a second opinion.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can ask your treatment team for a different doctor to look at your diagnosis and treatment if you want to. This is called a second opinion.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I decide not to have treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): It’s important to get all the information you can and think about your decision carefully. Stay in touch with your treatment team for support and discuss your decision with your doctor.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Choosing not to have treatment is very personal and can be a hard decision to make. Before you say no to treatment it is important to get all the information you can and think about your decision carefully.

Question (100 words): What are clinical trials and can I participate?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Clinical trials are research studies to improve treatment and care for patients. You can participate if you give informed consent, which means fully understanding the trial and its implications before agreeing to take part.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Clinical trials do research to improve the treatment and care for patients. You will only take part in a clinical trial if you give your informed consent.

Question (100 words): How can I manage my emotional wellbeing during treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Support services like counselling are available. Staying active and eating healthily can also help lower some side effects of treatment and improve your overall wellbeing.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There are support services available to help you, like counselling. But being active can help to lower some side effects of treatment and may lower the chance of breast cancer coming back.

Question (100 words): What should I know about diet during treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Eating healthily can make you feel better and give you more energy. Some treatments can affect how you eat and drink, so it’s important to maintain a healthy diet.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: But eating healthily can make you feel a bit better and give you more energy.

Question (100 words): How will breast cancer affect my work and finances?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You may be able to get benefits and extra support. Anyone who has or has had breast cancer is classed as disabled, which means you are protected against being treated badly at work because of your cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Many people worry about how breast cancer will affect their work and money. Anyone who has or has had breast cancer is classed as disabled.

Question (100 words): What happens after I finish my treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You will need follow-up appointments to monitor your recovery. Initially, these may be frequent, but they will become less frequent over time. Your breast care nurse will be your main contact for any questions or worries.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: After your treatment ends, you may still need to go to hospital to see how you are getting better. This is known as follow up.

Question (100 words): How can I get more support and information?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can call the Breast Cancer Now helpline on 0808 800 6000, use their text relay service, email nurse@breastcancernow.org, or visit their online forum at breastcancernow.org/forum.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Worried about breast cancer, or have a question about breast health? Our team are ready to listen on our free helpline. Call 0808 800 6000 Monday to Friday 9am–4pm and Saturday 9am–1pm.

Question (100 words): What is the role of a breast care nurse?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A breast care nurse provides information and support to anyone diagnosed with breast cancer. They are also called a key worker and can help you access other support services.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The breast care nurse is trained to give information and support to anyone diagnosed with breast cancer. They can also be called a key worker.

Question (100 words): How much should I be involved in decisions about my treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can decide how much you want to be involved in decisions about your treatment. You can change your mind at any time during your treatment.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You can decide how much you want to be involved in decisions about your treatment. You can change your mind about how much you want to be involved at any time in your treatment.

Question (100 words): What questions should I ask my treatment team?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You might want to ask why a treatment is best for you, if there are other treatments available, when treatment will start, where it will take place, how long it will last, what side effects to expect, how it will affect your daily life, if it will impact your ability to have children, and how successful the treatment is likely to be.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Questions you might want to ask: Why is this the best treatment for me? Are there any other treatments I could have? When will treatment start? Where will I need to go for treatment? How long will my treatment take? What are side effects I could get? How will the treatment affect my everyday life? Will the treatment make it harder for me to have children? How successful do you think treatment will be?

Question (100 words): What is the importance of taking time to think about my treatment options?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Taking a few days to think about your treatment options is very unlikely to make a difference to your treatment and may help you feel more in control of what is happening.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: You should be able take a few days to think about your treatment options before you decide what you want to do. Taking a little time to think about your treatment is very unlikely to make a difference to your treatment.

Question (100 words): What support is available after finishing treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Support and information needs may continue after finishing treatment. Follow-up appointments will monitor your recovery, and your breast care nurse will be available for any questions or concerns.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: For many people the need for support and information does not end when treatment finishes. After your treatment ends, you may still need to go to hospital to see how you are getting better.

Question (100 words): What is the first treatment for primary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Surgery is usually the first treatment for primary breast cancer. It aims to remove the cancer and some of the healthy cells around it to reduce the likelihood of the cancer coming back or spreading to other parts of the body.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Surgery is usually the first treatment for people with primary breast cancer. It tries to remove the cancer and some of the healthy cells around it.

Question (100 words): How soon after agreeing to surgery should it be performed?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If surgery is your first treatment, you should have it within 31 days of you and your treatment team agreeing to it.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If surgery is your first treatment, you should have this within 31 days of you and your treatment team agreeing to it.

Question (100 words): What is the goal of the surgeon during breast cancer surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The surgeon will try to remove the cancer without changing how you look too much.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The surgeon will try to remove the cancer without changing how you look too much.

Question (100 words): What are the two main types of breast surgery for cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The two main types of breast surgery are breast conserving surgery, which removes the cancer and some healthy cells around it, and mastectomy, which removes all of the breast and nipple.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There are two main types of breast surgery: Breast conserving surgery removes the cancer and some of the healthy cells around it. Mastectomy removes all of the breast and nipple.

Question (100 words): What factors determine the type of surgery I will have?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The type of surgery you will have is determined by the type of breast cancer, the size of the cancer, its location in the breast, and whether there is cancer in more than one part of the breast.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The type of surgery you will be asked to have will be decided by: The type of breast cancer, The size of the breast cancer, Where the cancer is in the breast, If there is cancer in more than one part of the breast.

Question (100 words): What is breast conserving surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast conserving surgery is where the cancer is removed along with some of the healthy cells around it. This surgery aims to keep as much of your breast as possible while ensuring the cancer has been completely removed.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast conserving surgery is where the cancer is removed and some of the healthy cells around it. This surgery tries to keep as much of your breast as possible while making sure the cancer has been completely removed.

Question (100 words): Why is it important to remove healthy cells around the cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): It is important to remove healthy cells around the cancer to lower the chance of any cancer cells being left behind. The cells will then be tested to check if there is any cancer in the healthy cells.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It is important that the cancer is removed with some of the healthy cells around it to lower the chance of any cancer cells being left behind.

Question (100 words): What is a mastectomy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A mastectomy is a surgery that removes all of the breast and nipple. You might have a mastectomy if the cancer takes up a large part of the breast or if there is cancer in more than one part of the breast.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A mastectomy removes all of the breast and nipple. You might have a mastectomy if: The cancer takes up a large part of the breast, There is cancer in more than one part of the breast.

Question (100 words): What is breast reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast reconstruction is a type of plastic surgery that makes a new breast or remakes the shape of your breast. You can have this at the same time as breast cancer surgery or months or years later.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast reconstruction is a type of plastic surgery that makes a new breast or remakes the shape of your breast. You can have this at the same time as breast cancer surgery or months or years later.

Question (100 words): What are the options for breast reconstruction?
Answer (Max 2000 words): There are normally different options for breast reconstruction. Your surgeon and breast care nurse will talk to you about which one is best for you. You should take your time to think about your options before deciding.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There are normally different options for breast reconstruction. Your surgeon and breast care nurse will talk to you about which one is best for you.

Question (100 words): Do I need to have the other breast removed if I have a mastectomy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Research shows that it is not normally needed to remove the other breast unless you have a higher chance of getting primary breast cancer in the other breast. It is important to talk about your cancer with your surgeon.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some people who are having a mastectomy think about if they should have the breast that does not have cancer removed as well. Research shows this is not normally needed.

Question (100 words): Why do doctors check the lymph nodes under the arm?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Doctors check the lymph nodes under the arm to see if any of them have cancer cells. This helps them decide if more treatment will help you.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have invasive breast cancer, your treatment team will want to check if any of the lymph nodes under the arm have cancer cells.

Question (100 words): What happens if cancer cells are found in the lymph nodes?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If cancer cells are found in the lymph nodes, the surgeon may remove more lymph nodes. This can help avoid the need for a second surgery. There is a chance you could get swelling of the arm, hand, breast, or chest if lymph nodes are removed.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If they find cancer cells, the surgeon may then remove more lymph nodes, so you will not have to have a second surgery.

Question (100 words): What is the role of the treatment team in deciding my surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Your treatment team, which includes doctors and healthcare professionals with different skills and knowledge, will explain why they think the surgery is best for you based on various factors like the type and size of the cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your treatment team will explain why they think the surgery is best for you.

Question (100 words): Can I get support if I am worried about breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, you can get support by calling the free helpline on 0808 800 6000, Monday to Friday 9am–4pm and Saturday 9am–1pm. You can also use the text relay service by calling 18001 0808 800 6000 or email nurse@breastcancernow.org.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Worried about breast cancer, or have a question about breast health? Our team are ready to listen on our free helpline. Call 0808 800 6000 Monday to Friday 9am–4pm and Saturday 9am–1pm.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience side effects from the dye used in tests?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience side effects like feeling sick or getting a rash from the dye, these are rare and can be easily treated. Inform your healthcare team immediately.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some people may feel sick or get a rash because of the dye but this is rare and can be easily treated.

Question (100 words): What is the purpose of an ultrasound scan before surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): An ultrasound scan uses sound waves to take pictures of the inside of the body. It helps doctors check if there are any abnormal cells under your arm that need further testing for cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: An ultrasound scan uses sound waves to take pictures of the inside of the body. If your scan does not look normal, you will have some cells taken from under your arm to check for cancer.

Question (100 words): What is chemotherapy and when might it be suggested before surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses special drugs to kill the cancer. Your treatment team might suggest chemotherapy before surgery to shrink the cancer, making it easier to remove.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses special drugs to kill the cancer. Your treatment team might want to do another test on a special lymph node to make sure there really is no cancer in your lymph nodes.

Question (100 words): What are the chances of recovery with breast conserving surgery versus mastectomy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The chances of getting better and of the cancer not coming back are the same for breast conserving surgery with radiotherapy as for mastectomy.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The chances of you getting better and of the cancer not coming back are the same for breast conserving surgery with radiotherapy as for mastectomy.

Question (100 words): How can I find more trusted information and support for breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can find more trusted information and support for breast cancer by visiting breastcancernow.org, calling their helpline on 0808 800 6000, or joining their online forum to talk with others who have experience with breast cancer.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Find information you can trust to help to understand breast cancer and order booklets at breastcancernow.org/publications. We have an online forum where you can talk about your experience of breast cancer with us and with lots of other people with experience of breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I feel sick all the time?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience persistent nausea or a feeling of sickness, it could be a symptom of secondary breast cancer spreading to the liver. It's important to report this symptom to your specialist nurse or doctor for further evaluation.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Feeling sick all the time

Question (100 words): Why do I have discomfort or swelling under my ribs?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Discomfort or swelling under the ribs on the right side or across the upper abdomen may indicate that secondary breast cancer has spread to the liver. You should inform your healthcare provider about this symptom.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Discomfort or swelling under the ribs on the right side or across the upper abdomen

Question (100 words): What could cause unexplained weight loss and loss of appetite?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Unexplained weight loss and a loss of appetite can be symptoms of secondary breast cancer progression, particularly if it has spread to the liver. It’s crucial to discuss these symptoms with your doctor.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Weight loss and a loss of appetite

Question (100 words): Why am I experiencing jaundice?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Jaundice, a yellowing of the skin and eyes, can be a sign that secondary breast cancer has spread to the liver. This symptom should be reported to your healthcare team immediately.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Jaundice

Question (100 words): What does persistent hiccups indicate?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Persistent hiccups can be a symptom of secondary breast cancer affecting the liver. If you experience this, it’s important to contact your healthcare provider.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Hiccups

Question (100 words): Why do I feel breathless even when resting?
Answer (Max 2000 words): An increased feeling of breathlessness, whether during exertion or rest, may indicate that secondary breast cancer has spread to the lungs. Report this symptom to your doctor.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Increased feeling of breathlessness, either when exerting yourself or when resting

Question (100 words): What could a persistent cough mean?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A persistent cough can be a symptom of secondary breast cancer spreading to the lungs. It’s important to inform your healthcare provider about this symptom.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A cough

Question (100 words): Why do I have chest or back pain when breathing?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Pain in the chest or back when breathing may indicate that secondary breast cancer has spread to the lungs. You should discuss this symptom with your doctor.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Pain in the chest or back when breathing

Question (100 words): What should I do if I have bone pain that doesn’t improve with pain relief?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Bone pain, especially in the back, hips, or ribs that doesn’t improve with pain relief and may worsen at night, could indicate that secondary breast cancer has spread to the bones. Report this to your healthcare provider.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Pain in your bones, for example in the back, hips or ribs, that doesn’t get better with pain relief and may be worse at night

Question (100 words): What are the symptoms of spinal cord compression?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Symptoms of spinal cord compression include severe or unexplained back pain, difficulty walking, numbness, and loss of bladder or bowel control. These symptoms require immediate medical attention.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Symptoms of spinal cord compression such as severe or unexplained back pain, difficulty walking, numbness and loss of bladder or bowel control

Question (100 words): What are the symptoms of hypercalcaemia?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Symptoms of hypercalcaemia include nausea and vomiting, fatigue, passing large amounts of urine, confusion, and excessive thirst. These symptoms should be reported to your doctor.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Symptoms of hypercalcaemia such as nausea and vomiting, fatigue, passing large amounts of urine, confusion and being very thirsty

Question (100 words): What does a lump or swelling under my arm mean?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A lump or swelling under your arm, breastbone, or collarbone area may indicate that secondary breast cancer has spread to the lymph nodes. It’s important to inform your healthcare provider about this symptom.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: A lump or swelling under your arm, breastbone or collarbone area

Question (100 words): Why is my arm or hand swelling?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Swelling in your arm or hand can be a symptom of secondary breast cancer affecting the lymph nodes. You should report this symptom to your doctor.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Swelling in your arm or hand

Question (100 words): What could persistent fatigue mean?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Feeling tired all the time or increased fatigue can be a general symptom of secondary breast cancer progression. It’s important to discuss this with your healthcare provider.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Feeling tired all the time

Question (100 words): What should I do if I have new, persistent symptoms?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you have new symptoms that don’t go away and don’t have an obvious cause, it’s important to tell your specialist nurse or doctor about them, as they may indicate secondary breast cancer progression.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have new or worsening symptoms that don’t go away and don’t have an obvious cause, tell your specialist nurse or doctor about them.

Question (100 words): What are the symptoms of secondary breast cancer in the brain?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Symptoms of secondary breast cancer in the brain include headaches, dizziness, nausea or vomiting (especially in the morning), loss of balance, altered vision or speech, weakness or numbness, changes in mood or personality, and fits. These symptoms require immediate medical attention.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Headaches, Dizziness, Nausea or vomiting, especially when waking up in the morning, Loss of balance, Altered vision or speech, Weakness or numbness, Changes in mood or personality, Fits

Question (100 words): What changes in the skin should I report?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Lasting changes to the skin on the breast or chest wall, particularly around your scar, or on the abdomen, including changes in color, a rash, or painless nodules of different sizes, should be reported to your healthcare provider.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Lasting changes to the skin on the breast or chest wall, particularly around your scar, or on the abdomen (belly) including: Change in the colour of the skin or a rash, Painless nodule(s) of different sizes

Question (100 words): How can I contact my healthcare team for concerns?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can contact your healthcare team via telephone or email. Make sure to reach out if you have any concerns or new symptoms.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Contact Telephone Email

Question (100 words): What general symptoms should I be aware of?
Answer (Max 2000 words): General symptoms to be aware of include feeling tired all the time, increased fatigue, and new symptoms that make you feel unwell or affect your daily life. Report these to your healthcare provider.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: GENERAL SYMPTOMS •Feeling tired all the time •Increased fatigue •New symptoms making you feel unwell or that affect

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice any new symptoms?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you notice any new symptoms that are persistent, don’t have an obvious cause, or don’t go away, it’s important to talk to your doctor or specialist nurse about them. Early reporting can help in managing the condition effectively.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: It’s not possible to list all the symptoms of progression. Talk to your doctor or specialist nurse about ANY symptoms that are: •new •don’t go away •don’t have an obvious cause

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice a lump in my breast?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you notice a lump in your breast, it's important to contact your healthcare provider immediately for an evaluation. Early detection is crucial for effective treatment. Your provider may recommend a series of tests, including a mammogram, ultrasound, or biopsy, to determine the nature of the lump.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast Cancer Now provides detailed guides on breast awareness and screening to help you understand what to look for and when to seek medical advice.

Question (100 words): What types of surgery are available for breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The types of surgery for breast cancer include lumpectomy (removal of the tumor and a small margin of surrounding tissue), mastectomy (removal of the entire breast), and reconstructive surgery (to rebuild the breast after removal). The choice of surgery depends on the stage of cancer, tumor size, and personal preferences.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast Cancer Now offers comprehensive information on various surgical options and what to expect during and after the procedure.

Question (100 words): How should I care for my surgical drains after breast cancer surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After breast cancer surgery, you may have surgical drains to remove excess fluid. Care for them by keeping the area clean, emptying the drains regularly as instructed, and watching for signs of infection such as redness or unusual discharge. Follow your healthcare provider’s specific instructions for drain care.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast Cancer Now provides detailed guides on post-surgery care, including how to manage surgical drains and wounds to promote healing and prevent complications.

Question (100 words): What are the common treatments for breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common treatments for breast cancer include surgery, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, hormone therapy, and targeted therapy. The choice of treatment depends on the type and stage of cancer, as well as individual health factors. A combination of these treatments may be used for the best outcome.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast Cancer Now offers extensive resources on various treatment options and their potential side effects to help you make informed decisions.

Question (100 words): What medications might I need to take after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After breast cancer treatment, you may need to take medications such as hormone therapy (e.g., tamoxifen, anastrozole) to reduce the risk of cancer recurrence, or medications to manage side effects like nausea or pain. Always follow your healthcare provider’s prescriptions and attend regular check-ups.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast Cancer Now provides detailed leaflets on specific medications used in breast cancer treatment, including their benefits and potential side effects.

Question (100 words): What are the common side effects of chemotherapy for breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common side effects of chemotherapy for breast cancer include fatigue, nausea, hair loss, and increased risk of infections. These side effects vary depending on the specific drugs used and individual reactions. Your healthcare team will provide strategies to manage these symptoms.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast Cancer Now offers resources on managing the side effects of chemotherapy to help you cope during treatment.

Question (100 words): What pre-surgery preparations should I consider for breast cancer surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Pre-surgery preparations for breast cancer surgery may include physical prehabilitation exercises to improve strength and endurance, discussing any medications you’re taking with your healthcare provider, and arranging for post-surgery support at home. It’s also important to have a clear understanding of the surgical procedure and recovery process.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast Cancer Now provides guides on exercises and other preparations to help you get ready for surgery and enhance your recovery.

Question (100 words): What can I expect during my recovery after breast cancer surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Recovery after breast cancer surgery varies but typically includes managing pain, caring for surgical wounds, gradually resuming normal activities, and attending follow-up appointments. It’s important to follow your healthcare provider’s advice on physical activity, diet, and any prescribed medications.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast Cancer Now offers comprehensive information on what to expect during recovery and how to manage any challenges that arise.

Question (100 words): What follow-up care is needed after completing breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Follow-up care after completing breast cancer treatment includes regular check-ups with your healthcare provider, monitoring for any signs of recurrence, managing long-term side effects, and maintaining a healthy lifestyle. This may involve periodic imaging tests and blood work.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast Cancer Now provides detailed guides on the importance of follow-up care and what it entails to ensure long-term health and well-being.

Question (100 words): How can I maintain a healthy lifestyle after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Maintaining a healthy lifestyle after breast cancer treatment involves eating a balanced diet, engaging in regular physical activity, avoiding tobacco and limiting alcohol, and managing stress. It’s also important to attend all follow-up appointments and screenings as recommended by your healthcare provider.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast Cancer Now offers resources on lifestyle changes and healthy habits to support your well-being after treatment.

Question (100 words): What dietary recommendations are there for breast cancer survivors?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Dietary recommendations for breast cancer survivors include eating a variety of fruits and vegetables, whole grains, lean proteins, and healthy fats. It’s advisable to limit processed foods, red meats, and sugary drinks. Consulting a dietitian can provide personalized advice based on your specific needs and health status.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast Cancer Now provides detailed dietary guidelines and resources to help you make informed choices about your nutrition post-treatment.

Question (100 words): Where can I find emotional support during my breast cancer journey?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Emotional support during your breast cancer journey can be found through support groups, counseling services, and helplines offered by organizations like Breast Cancer Now. Connecting with others who understand your experience can provide comfort and practical advice.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast Cancer Now offers various support services, including helplines and support groups, to help you navigate the emotional challenges of breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What diagnostic tests are used to confirm breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Diagnostic tests used to confirm breast cancer include mammography, ultrasound, MRI, and biopsy. These tests help determine the presence, size, and type of breast cancer, guiding the treatment plan. Your healthcare provider will recommend the appropriate tests based on your symptoms and medical history.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast Cancer Now provides detailed information on the various diagnostic tests used to confirm breast cancer and what each test involves.

Question (100 words): How can I order Breast Cancer Now publications?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can order Breast Cancer Now publications by visiting their website at breastcancernow.org/publications, scanning the provided QR code, or calling their order line at 0345 092 0814. Most titles are also available in large print, Braille, and audio CD format upon request.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast Cancer Now offers a straightforward ordering process for their publications, ensuring you have access to the information you need.

Question (100 words): What are the red flags I should watch for after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Red flags to watch for after breast cancer treatment include new or worsening symptoms such as unexplained pain, swelling, skin changes, or unusual discharge. These could indicate a recurrence or other complications. It’s important to report any concerning symptoms to your healthcare provider promptly.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast Cancer Now provides information on signs to watch for post-treatment to ensure early detection of any issues.

Question (100 words): What is the role of hormone therapy in breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Hormone therapy plays a crucial role in treating hormone receptor-positive breast cancer by blocking the effects of estrogen or reducing estrogen levels in the body. This helps prevent cancer cells from growing. Common hormone therapies include tamoxifen and aromatase inhibitors like anastrozole.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast Cancer Now offers detailed leaflets on hormone therapy, explaining how it works and its importance in certain types of breast cancer treatment.

Question (100 words): How can I manage lymphedema after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Managing lymphedema after breast cancer treatment involves a combination of strategies including compression garments, specialized exercises, skin care, and possibly manual lymphatic drainage. It’s important to work with a healthcare provider experienced in lymphedema management to develop a personalized plan.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast Cancer Now provides comprehensive guides on managing lymphedema, including exercises and care tips to help reduce symptoms and improve quality of life.

Question (100 words): What exercises are recommended after breast cancer surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Recommended exercises after breast cancer surgery include gentle stretching, range-of-motion exercises, and gradually increasing physical activity as advised by your healthcare provider. These exercises help improve flexibility, strength, and overall well-being. It’s important to start slowly and avoid overexertion.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast Cancer Now offers detailed exercise guides tailored for post-surgery recovery to help you regain strength and mobility safely.

Question (100 words): How can I reduce my risk of developing breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Reducing your risk of developing breast cancer involves maintaining a healthy weight, engaging in regular physical activity, limiting alcohol consumption, avoiding tobacco, and being aware of your family history. Regular breast screenings and discussions with your healthcare provider about risk-reducing strategies are also important.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast Cancer Now provides resources on lifestyle changes and risk-reducing strategies to help lower your chances of developing breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What should I know about breast reconstruction after mastectomy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast reconstruction after mastectomy is a surgical procedure to rebuild the breast mound. It can be done immediately after mastectomy or delayed. Options include implant-based reconstruction and autologous reconstruction using your own tissue. Discuss the pros and cons with your healthcare provider to make an informed decision.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast Cancer Now offers detailed information on breast reconstruction options, helping you understand the process and what to expect.

Question (100 words): What are the common symptoms of breast cancer in men?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common symptoms of breast cancer in men include a lump or swelling in the breast, changes to the skin of the breast such as dimpling or redness, and discharge from the nipple. If you notice any of these symptoms, it's important to see a doctor for further evaluation.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast cancer starts when cells in the breast tissue begin to divide and grow in an unusual and uncontrolled way.

Question (100 words): What types of surgery are available for men with breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The two main types of surgery for men with breast cancer are mastectomy, which involves removing all breast tissue, and breast-conserving surgery (lumpectomy), which involves removing the cancer with a margin of normal tissue. Most men undergo a mastectomy due to the limited amount of breast tissue.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There are 2 main types of surgery: Mastectomy – removal of all the breast tissue including the nipple and areola, and Breast-conserving surgery (also known as wide local excision or lumpectomy) – removal of the cancer with a margin (border) of normal breast tissue around it.

Question (100 words): What is a sentinel lymph node biopsy and why is it done?
Answer (Max 2000 words): A sentinel lymph node biopsy is a procedure to check if cancer cells have spread to the first lymph node(s) that drain lymph from the breast. It helps determine if further lymph node surgery or radiotherapy is needed. This is often done if pre-surgery tests show no evidence of lymph node involvement.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The sentinel lymph node is the first lymph node cancer cells are likely to spread to. The procedure is usually done at the same time as your cancer surgery but may be done before.

Question (100 words): Is breast reconstruction commonly offered to men after surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast reconstruction is not usually offered to men, but options to improve the appearance and evenness of the chest, such as surgery for symmetry or nipple reconstruction, may be discussed with your treatment team based on your individual situation.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Breast reconstruction is not usually offered to men but this may depend on your individual situation.

Question (100 words): What is the role of chemotherapy in treating breast cancer in men?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Chemotherapy is used to destroy cancer cells and can be given before or after surgery. It aims to reduce the risk of cancer recurrence or to control and slow the growth of cancer in cases of secondary breast cancer. Different chemotherapy drugs and combinations may be used.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Chemotherapy destroys cancer cells by affecting their ability to divide and grow.

Question (100 words): How does radiotherapy help in the treatment of breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Radiotherapy uses high-energy x-rays to destroy cancer cells. It is often given after breast-conserving surgery to reduce the risk of cancer recurrence in the remaining breast tissue. It may also be given to the chest wall after a mastectomy if cancer has spread to the lymph nodes.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Radiotherapy uses high-energy x-rays to destroy cancer cells.

Question (100 words): What is hormone (endocrine) therapy and who might need it?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Hormone therapy is used to block the effects of oestrogen on breast cancer cells. It is prescribed for men with oestrogen receptor-positive (ER-positive) breast cancer. The most common drug used is tamoxifen, taken daily for at least 5 years.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Hormone therapies block or stop the effect of oestrogen on breast cancer cells.

Question (100 words): What are the common side effects of tamoxifen?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common side effects of tamoxifen include hot flushes and loss of sex drive (libido). If you experience these side effects, speak to your breast care nurse, treatment team, or GP for support and possible management options.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Tamoxifen can cause side effects, which may include hot flushes and loss of sex drive (libido).

Question (100 words): How can men manage changes to their body after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Changes to the body, such as alterations in chest shape or hair loss, can be challenging. Initially, you may feel unhappy or shocked, but these intense feelings usually lessen over time. If you continue to feel uncomfortable, speak to your breast care nurse, treatment team, or GP for further support or counseling.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: The first few times you look at your body after the operation may be difficult and you may feel unhappy or shocked. However, the initial intense feelings you may have should lessen over time as you get more used to how you look.

Question (100 words): How might breast cancer treatment affect sex and intimacy?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Breast cancer treatments can have physical and emotional effects that impact sex and intimacy. Hormone therapy, like tamoxifen, may cause loss of sex drive or difficulty with erections. Open communication with your partner, trying different forms of intimacy, and seeking professional support can help manage these changes.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Treatments for breast cancer can also have physical and emotional effects that can affect sex and sex drive.

Question (100 words): Can chemotherapy affect fertility in men?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Yes, chemotherapy can affect sperm production, leading to temporary or permanent infertility. If fertility is a concern, discuss this with your treatment team before starting treatment. Sperm banking may be an option to preserve fertility.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Chemotherapy can affect sperm production, which can lead to temporary or permanent infertility in men.

Question (100 words): What is the significance of genetic testing for men with breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Genetic testing is important for men with breast cancer because they have a higher risk of having an inherited altered gene compared to women. Identifying an altered gene can inform treatment decisions and allow family members to assess and manage their own risk.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Men with breast cancer are at a higher risk of having an altered gene than women with breast cancer. Because of this, you should be offered genetic testing to find out if you have an inherited altered gene.

Question (100 words): What is the aim of treatment for primary breast cancer in men?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The aim of treatment for primary breast cancer, which has not spread beyond the breast tissue or lymph nodes, is to remove the cancer and reduce the risk of it coming back or spreading to other parts of the body.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If the cancer has not spread beyond the breast tissue or the lymph nodes under the arm (primary breast cancer), treatment aims to remove the cancer and reduce the risk of it coming back or spreading to other parts of the body.

Question (100 words): What is the difference between primary and secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Primary breast cancer is confined to the breast or lymph nodes under the arm, while secondary or metastatic breast cancer is when cancer cells have spread to other parts of the body. Secondary breast cancer can be treated but cannot be cured.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Primary breast cancer is breast cancer that has not spread beyond the breast or lymph nodes under the arm... Secondary or metastatic breast cancer is when breast cancer cells spread from the breast to other parts of the body.

Question (100 words): What support is available for men diagnosed with breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Support is available through helplines, such as the one provided by Breast Cancer Now (0808 800 6000), where you can speak to nurses. Additionally, there are booklets and online resources to help you understand your diagnosis, treatment options, and managing side effects.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Being a man diagnosed with breast cancer can make you feel isolated, but support is available and we’re here to help.

Question (100 words): What is the role of targeted therapy in treating breast cancer in men?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Targeted therapy involves using drugs that block the growth and spread of cancer by interfering with specific processes in cancer cells. While breast cancer in men is less likely to be HER2-positive, if it is, drugs like trastuzumab and pertuzumab may be offered.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Targeted therapy is the name given to a group of drugs that block the growth and spread of cancer.

Question (100 words): How is the treatment for breast cancer in men tailored?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Treatment for breast cancer in men is tailored based on the individual's specific situation, including the type and stage of cancer, genetic factors, and overall health. Your treatment team will explain the reasons for your particular treatment plan.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Your treatment will be tailored to your individual situation.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience side effects from breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience side effects from breast cancer treatment, speak to your breast care nurse, treatment team, or GP. They can provide advice on managing side effects and may refer you for further support or counseling if needed.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have any questions about side effects, you can also talk to your breast care nurse or treatment team.

Question (100 words): What is the importance of follow-up care after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Follow-up care is crucial to monitor your recovery, manage any long-term side effects, and detect any signs of cancer recurrence early. Regular appointments with your healthcare team will help ensure ongoing support and care.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Information on follow-up care is not explicitly provided in the excerpt, but it is a standard practice in cancer care to monitor patients post-treatment.

Question (100 words): How can I maintain a healthy lifestyle during and after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Maintaining a healthy lifestyle during and after breast cancer treatment involves eating a balanced diet, staying physically active, managing stress, and avoiding tobacco and excessive alcohol. These practices can help improve your overall well-being and recovery.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Information on maintaining a healthy lifestyle is not explicitly provided in the excerpt, but general advice on lifestyle during and after cancer treatment is commonly recommended.

Question (100 words): What is lymphoedema and what causes it?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Lymphoedema is swelling of the arm, hand, or chest area caused by a build-up of fluid in the surface tissues of the body. It can be caused by damage to the lymphatic system, such as from surgery or radiotherapy to the lymph nodes under the arm and surrounding area.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Lymphoedema is swelling of the arm, hand or chest area caused by a build-up of fluid in the surface tissues of the body. This can be caused by damage to the lymphatic system, for example because of surgery or radiotherapy to the lymph nodes under the arm and surrounding area.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I experience symptoms of a blood clot?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you experience symptoms such as pain, redness, or swelling of the arm or leg, shortness of breath, or chest pain, contact your treatment team or go to your local A&E department immediately, as blood clots can be life-threatening.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Blood clots can be life-threatening and they should be treated quickly. Contact your treatment team or go to your local A&E department straight away if you have any of the following symptoms: Pain, redness/discolouration of the skin, heat and swelling of the arm or leg.

Question (100 words): How can I manage fatigue during and after treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Fatigue can be managed by discussing it with your treatment team, who may offer strategies or refer you to resources such as Macmillan Cancer Support’s booklet 'Coping with fatigue'. Rest, gentle exercise, and a balanced diet can also help.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Fatigue is extreme tiredness and exhaustion that does not go away with rest or sleep. It can affect you physically and emotionally. It’s a common side effect of breast cancer treatment and may last for weeks or months after your treatment has finished.

Question (100 words): How can I talk to my children about my breast cancer diagnosis?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Be open and honest with your children about your diagnosis. Resources from organizations like The Fruitfly Collective, Macmillan Cancer Support, and Maggie’s can provide guidance. Your breast care nurse or treatment team can also offer support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Deciding when and what to tell your children can be difficult. You know your children better than anyone else. Although you might want to protect them from knowing about your diagnosis, being open and honest with them can make them feel less frightened, even if they do not fully understand.

Question (100 words): What diet should I follow during and after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Maintain a balanced diet rich in fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and lean proteins. Avoid processed foods and excessive sugar. Consult resources like Breast Cancer Now’s 'Diet and breast cancer' booklet for more detailed guidance.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Knowing what to eat during and after treatment for breast cancer can be difficult. You may have a loss or increase of appetite, you may put on or lose weight, and food and drink might taste different to usual.

Question (100 words): How can physical activity help me during and after treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Regular exercise can help maintain or improve your physical and mental health, reduce side effects like fatigue and lymphoedema, and may even lower the risk of cancer recurrence. Consult the 'Exercises after breast cancer surgery' leaflet for specific exercises.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Regular exercise and physical activity can help maintain or improve your physical and mental health during and after treatment for breast cancer.

Question (100 words): What financial support is available for me if I’m affected by breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You may be entitled to certain benefits or financial help. Contact Macmillan Cancer Support for advice on finances, welfare rights, and energy bills. Some hospitals also have welfare and benefits advisors.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Anyone who has or has had breast cancer is classed as disabled. This means you are protected against discrimination at work and during the recruitment process. You might be entitled to certain benefits or other financial help.

Question (100 words): What should I do if I notice signs of breast cancer recurrence?
Answer (Max 2000 words): If you notice any changes such as swelling, changes in breast tissue or scar, skin texture changes, or unusual discharge, contact your treatment team or GP immediately.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If breast cancer does come back, it’s called recurrence. It’s important to know what signs and symptoms to look out for.

Question (100 words): How can I get emotional support during my breast cancer journey?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Speak to your breast care nurse or treatment team for referrals to counselling or talking therapies. Join support groups like The Men’s Virtual Meet Up or use Breast Cancer Now’s Someone Like Me service for peer support.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you’re struggling emotionally, speak to your breast care nurse or treatment team. They can refer you for counselling or talking therapies, or let you know about local support groups.

Question (100 words): What is follow-up care after breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Follow-up care involves continued monitoring after hospital-based treatment ends. This may include regular mammograms and appointments with your breast care nurse. You should be given a contact number for any questions or concerns.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: At the end of your hospital-based treatment, you will continue to be monitored. This is called follow-up.

Question (100 words): How can I reduce the risk of lymphoedema after treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): To reduce the risk of lymphoedema, avoid tight clothing, maintain a healthy weight, practice good skin care, and engage in gentle exercises. Consult the 'Reducing your risk of lymphoedema' booklet for more tips.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Our Reducing your risk of lymphoedema booklet has more information and tips to help.

Question (100 words): What are the common symptoms of secondary breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Common symptoms of secondary breast cancer include unexpected weight loss, severe headaches, a dry cough, feeling breathless, extreme fatigue, and bone pain that doesn’t improve with pain relief.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Some symptoms to be aware of include: Unexpected weight loss and a loss of appetite, Severe or ongoing headaches, A dry cough or feeling of breathlessness, Feeling much more tired than usual, Pain in your bones, for example in the back, hips or ribs, that does not get better with pain relief and may be worse at night.

Question (100 words): How can I access further support and information about breast cancer?
Answer (Max 2000 words): You can access further support by calling Breast Cancer Now’s helpline on 0808 800 6000, visiting their online forum, or using their Someone Like Me service to connect with a trained volunteer who has had a similar experience.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Further support There are lots of different ways to get the support you need. Helpline If you want more information or just want to talk things through, our nurses are ready to listen on our free helpline.

Question (100 words): What should I know about sperm banking before treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Sperm banking is an option to preserve fertility before treatment. You can find more information on the Cancer Research UK and Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority websites.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: There’s more information about sperm banking on the Cancer Research UK (cancerresearchuk.org) and Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority (hfea.gov.uk) websites.

Question (100 words): How can I manage work and finances during my breast cancer treatment?
Answer (Max 2000 words): Discuss your situation with your treatment team. You may continue working with reduced hours or take a break. You are protected against discrimination at work and may be entitled to benefits. Contact Macmillan Cancer Support for financial advice.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: People often worry about the impact their breast cancer diagnosis may have on their work and financial situation. Speak to your treatment team about how your diagnosis and treatment may affect your daily life.

Question (100 words): What exercises can help me after breast cancer surgery?
Answer (Max 2000 words): After surgery, engage in shoulder and arm exercises to regain movement and function. Consult the 'Exercises after breast cancer surgery' leaflet for specific exercises.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: If you have surgery as part of your treatment, our Exercises after breast cancer surgery leaflet has information on shoulder and arm exercises that can help you regain the movement and function you had before your operation.

Question (100 words): What is the Moving Forward course and how can it help me?
Answer (Max 2000 words): The Moving Forward course offers supportive conversations in a safe space to help you feel empowered and confident after treatment. You can attend it face-to-face or online.
Actual Excerpt from the Source Data: Our Moving Forward course can help. Through supportive, open conversations in a safe, confidential space, you’ll connect with people who understand. And you’ll find the tools you need to feel more empowered, confident and in control.

Question (100 words): How can I get trusted information about breast cancer?
